DOLLAR SKIDS TO RECORD LOW
The dollar plunged to record lows against the German mark, dragging down the American bond and stock markets and stirring fear of further damage to the U.S. economy. 1
 
SNAGS IN AIRLIFT TO SOMALIA
The plan for a U.S. military airlift to famine-stricken Somalia has run into problems. Relief officials assert that the U.S. put the plan into effect hastily without adequate preparations to guard the food from looters or rival fighters. 1
 
IRAQ INVITES U.N. TO VISIT SHIITES
Baghdad offered to let members of the United Nations Security Council inspect the southern marshes inhabited by thousands of Iraqi Shiite Muslims who are said to be under armed attack by the Iraqi Army and Air Force. 4
 
NO THREAT TO ME, YELTSIN SAYS

British newspapers published more photographs that showed the Duchess of York entwined with a Texas businessman at a pool in France. The pictures stirred criticism of the former Sarah Ferguson and of the British royalty as an institution. 3

THE CHANGING FACE OF BOSTON
It is a city in the throes of rapid ethnic change. According to the 1990 census, nearly 4 of every 10 residents of Boston are members of minority groups, not including the Hispanic population, which is also increasing. The numbers have been changing so rapidly that many Bostonians believe that whites will be a minority before the decade is out. 5

LEAD WORRIES IN BROOKLYN
A painting crew sandblasting the Williamsburg Bridge repeatedly rained lead-paint chips into Brooklyn earlier this summer before city officials suspended the project under pressure from the state. In the community beneath the bridge, residents are anxious about findings of "elevated" and potentially dangerous levels of lead under and around the bridge. 1

HEADLINE: DOLLAR, IN PLUNGE, HITS ALL-TIME LOW AGAINST THE MARK

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar, plagued by a weak economy and more attractive interest rates abroad, plunged to all-time lows against the German mark yesterday. The decline dragged down the American bond and stock markets and raised fears of economic disruptions both in the United States and Europe.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.5 percent, or 50.79 points, to close at 3,254.10, while the bond market gave up gains it made in the last two weeks. The sharp fall in the markets is an unwelcome development for the President, who in his acceptance speech on Thursday night asked voters to trust him as the better steward of the nation's economy. 
 Initially, traders appeared to be granting the President his wish, as stocks and bonds rose, but those rallies were turned into routs.
 
Currency Traders Lead
 "The whole downdraft in stocks and bonds is off the dollar," said Joseph Liro, a financial economist at S. G. Warburg & Company in New York. "The central banks came in, rattled their swords, and they scared nobody."
If the dollar's slide cannot be contained, confidence in the American economy could be damaged. The cost of imports could rise, increasing inflation. And investors could push up long-term interest rates, threatening an already fragile recovery. The dollar's fall, analysts said, could also intensify the tensions within the European Community, where the mark is the dominant currency, forcing even higher interest rates there and threatening the chances for a smooth transition to a unified Europe by the end of the century.
 
Repeated Efforts Fail
 The Federal Reserve, 14 European central banks and the Bank of Canada bought dollars repeatedly in the foreign exchange market yesterday in an unsuccessful effort to support the sinking currency. By the end of the day, the dollar had fallen more than 1 percent against the mark.
Analysts are anxious about the outlook both here and in Europe because there is no simple way to halt a further decline in the dollar. Higher interest rates would support the dollar by attracting more foreign investment, but the Federal Reserve cannot raise short-term interest rates without strangling an economic recovery that is already nearly lifeless. Still, the mere possibility of higher rates upset the stock and bond markets.
Conversely, a cut in European rates would narrow the differential of more than six percentage points that now favors the mark and other European currencies over the dollar. But such rate cuts are unlikely because the Germans, who set the European economic tone, have insisted on higher rates to fight inflation after the unification of the two Germanys.
This leaves international economic cooperation, which is supposed to ease the transition through difficult economic times, in gridlock. Intervention in the foreign exchange markets by central banks is the only tool left to support the dollar. But it may not be effective alone, if traders are betting that the United States and its economic allies will not take more powerful economic steps to support the foundering currency.
"You are raising all kinds of concerns," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation in New York.
In late trading in New York, the dollar was at 1.4295 against the mark, 1 percent below the previous record closing low in New York of 1.4470, which it reached Thursday. The dollar also easily pierced the 1.4430 level, the lowest level reached in intraday trading since the mark was created in 1948. The dollar also fell sharply against the pound, the Swiss franc and the French franc. It fell less sharply against the yen because Japan's economy is in crisis and interest rates in Japan are not very high.
 
Intervention Called Mild
 John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said one reason the intervention was not very effective was that the amount of dollar buying was not large, although there were as many as five rounds of intervention, and 16 central banks involved. And, he added, the mildness of the intervention effort might signal that the United States and its allies did not care if the dollar declined further, as long as the fall is slow and orderly.
In the bond market, the failure of the intervention wiped out a rally that came in part on relief that Mr. Bush emphasized the need to reduce Federal spending and the budget deficits. It had pushed up the price on the Treasury's 30-year bond and reduced yields to levels not seen since the summer of 1986. But in late trading the price of the 30-year bond was down almost half a point, or $4 for a $1,000 face value, and the yield had jumped to 7.35 percent, from 7.26 percent earlier in the day.
The dollar has been falling since the spring for two main reasons: the lack of a strong economic recovery here and the wide difference in interest rates available to investors here and in Europe. A strong economic recovery in the United States would have attracted foreign investment and, therefore, dollar buying.
In addition, interest rates in Europe are three times higher than in America. This makes it very costly to hold dollars instead of marks or other European currencies.
 
Regulating the Rate of Decline
 Analysts said the dollar-intervention effort had two purposes. One goal was to keep the dollar's decline, which has been persistent but slow recently, from shifting into high gear. Such a fall could panic investors by shaking confidence in the outlook for the United States economy. The Federal Reserve might be prevented from lowering interest rates further to help the recovery because that could weaken the dollar more.
The second goal is to weaken the German mark and reduce the tension that is threatening harmony within the European Monetary System. The French are to vote in September on the Maastricht Treaty, which outlines the road to a political and economic union in Europe by 1999. A fall in the dollar could force a realignment of the exchange rates within the system or an increase in interest rates. Either move could play into the hands of the opponents of a unified Europe and lead to a French vote against the Maastricht Treaty. That would definitely set back the drive to unity.
 
Good and Bad Effects
 Beyond the impact of a sudden or uncontrolled fall, the dollar decline has good and bad effects. It is costly for Americans traveling abroad: trips to Europe now can cost 13 percent more than four months ago. The fall can also increase inflation by making imports more expensive, but that is less of a threat with the American economy growing so slowly.
On the other hand, a weak dollar can make American products more competitive abroad. Mr. Bush highlighted exports in his acceptance speech, because if more foreigners buy American goods, more Americans will be employed producing them.

HEADLINE: $113 Million Is Estimated As a Surplus

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Connecticut will close the books on its first fiscal year with a state income tax with a surplus of almost $113 million in its $8 billion budget, according to an estimate from the Legislature's budget office.
The projection was released late Thursday, only two days before the one-year anniversary of the income tax law on Saturday, and it prompted angry denunciations all over again by tax opponents who said it only proved their assertion that the state was worsening the recession by taking too much money out of residents' wallets. Last month, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. predicted a surplus of only $30 million; four months ago, the surplus was expected to come in at $100,000. 
 "This just shows that taxpayers were overtaxed," said the House minority leader, Representative Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol.
Most of the surplus, however, did not arise from collecting too much in income taxes. The director of the General Assembly's Office of Fiscal Analysis, Ralph J. Caruso, said that income tax collections had actually come in $57 million less than predicted for the year that ended June 30. Sales tax collections were also down, coming in $31.5 million less than predicted, Mr. Caruso said.
He said the surplus was mainly due to a windfall of more than $100 million in Federal grant money that was applied for during the fiscal year, but not planned on when the budget bill was signed a year ago.
Under state law, the surplus must be used to make an accelerated payment on the $966 million in loans taken out by the state government last year to pay for two years of accumulated deficits.
The State Comptroller, William E. Curry Jr., whose office will issue its final report next week closing the books on year one of the income tax, said his numbers generally agreed with the Legislature's.
Shortly after Mr. Weicker announced last month that Connecticut would show its first surplus in five years, Mr. Curry said he was investigating whether the Department of Revenue Services -- the administration's tax arm -- had deliberately held back some tax refund checks until after the start of the fiscal year to "pad" the surplus.
Mr. Curry said in an interview today that his office would release its final report on that issue next week, along with a final word on the total value of the checks held over.
Preliminary reports said that perhaps $10 million to $12 million in refunds had been held up, and Mr. Curry said the total had in fact been "over that," though he declined to provide specifics. Officials at the tax department have said that larger refunds are routinely held to recheck the math, and such in-house audits accounted for the fiscal-year deadline slipping past.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
CLINTON SAYS BUSH IS UNTRUSTWORTHY ON JOBS AND TAXES

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton accused President Bush today of using lies and distortions to sidestep responsibility for the nation's economic woes and to paint the Democratic opposition as unworthy of public trust.
Mr. Clinton, who saw his once-commanding lead in public opinion surveys shrink as the Republican convention took center stage this week, used today's speech and remarks afterward to direct his sharpest criticism yet at Mr. Bush and to try to recapture the public's attention from the Republicans. 
 "Last night we heard a desperate candidate for President promise another short-term capital-gains tax cut for the rich, the fool's gold of an across-the-board tax cut in the face of a $400 billion deficit, and a balanced-budget amendment with no serious proposal to balance the budget," he said. "These promises are false, and they too will betray us, if we follow them."
 
Bush Called 'Untrustworthy'
 Mr. Clinton's assessment grew even more harsh when he responded to reporters' questions immediately after the speech to the Detroit Economic Club. He said that voters should consider the President "personally untrustworthy" because he broke his promise not to raise taxes and did not create the 15 million new jobs he promised in his 1988 Republican campaign.
"It was appalling to me that a man that has the Presidency of the United States is so desperate to hold onto his job that he would say something that absolutely flew in the face of the plain truth," he said of the President's as sessment of Mr. Clinton's own record.
"He didn't tell the truth last night about my tax record or his," Mr. Clinton said. "He didn't tell the truth last night about my tax proposals."
The Democratic nominee used the speech, which had been billed as a major address on the economy, to mount a new phase of his campaign. Now that the Republican convention has concluded, Mr. Clinton plans to hurry to remind voters of the problems he will hold the President responsible for during the final months of the campaign.
 
Comparing Records
 By turning around Mr. Bush's discussion of trustworthiness and returning the debate to the troubled economy, the Democrats also hope to undermine Republican efforts to raise character questions about Mr. Clinton.
"We've heard it all before," the Arkansas Governor said. "We've seen it all before. We've tried it all before. It's read-my-lips all over again, except this time we can read the record."
The President's speech, he said, relied on twisting the facts about Mr. Clinton's record in Arkansas and personal background to turn the political debate into an ill-defined discussion of family values instead of one about the state of the economy.
"He is a great fearmonger," Mr. Clinton said of the President. "That's what they're good at. That's what they know to do. 'If you're not with us, you're not American' -- all that kind of stuff. That's what they're good at. I tell you this. The American people are not going to let this country continue to go in the wrong direction. They cannot believe that he is totally free of responsibility."
Mr. Clinton said his economic plan was more far-reaching than anything Mr. Bush had proposed. He said he would cut the deficit in half within four years, create tax credits to help the development of new technologies and to aid the working poor, and create a new college scholarship and apprenticeship programs.
"I do believe people should take responsibility for their actions," said Mr. Clinton, who has often said his economic plan would create more opportunity but require greater individual responsibility in return. "And that includes the President of the United States."
Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore, and their wives will leave Ohio this weekend for a three-state bus tour, on which they are expected to use their most effective strategy to try to regain some of the popularity they enjoyed before the Republicans' convention.
 
Attacks Both Ways
 Each side used the phrase "smoke screen" to assail the other's strategy today. Torie Clarke, the press secretary for the Bush-Quayle campaign, said that Mr. Clinton "has got the political conscience of a weather vane."
The Republicans have said that Mr. Clinton has offered conflicting versions of his stand on abortion and his record of military service.
But Mr. Clinton said Mr. Bush's conflicts are more fundamental and affect the lives of all Americans.
"The test of Presidential character is whether we use the power of this office to help the American people realize their potential," he said. "The test of family values is not whether Al Gore and I love our wives and children as much as George Bush and Dan Quayle do, but whether we get up every day worrying about your children and your future."
Mr. Clinton dismissed Mr. Bush's plan for an across-the-board tax cut that would be offset by spending cuts and another proposal to reduce the deficit by allowing taxpayers to make voluntary contributions as "campaign fantasies."
"Three years and seven months into his Presidency, George Bush still has no agenda, no strategy, no vision -- nothing to say about creating jobs in America," Mr. Clinton said.
 
Address to Black Journalists
 At an earlier address today to the annual convention of the National Association of Black Journalists, Mr. Clinton faulted Mr. Bush for blaming Congress for his Administration's failures. The nation, he said, had become "decidedly more unequal" and had been hobbled by flawed economic theories promoted by Republican leaders.
"The thing that's holding us back today is the blinders that are on so many people who have had their heads filled up so long with all this supply-side, trickle-down rhetoric," he said.
Mr. Clinton also took specific aim at elements of the President's acceptance speech. He disputed Mr. Bush's assertion that he had raised taxes 128 times in Arkansas during his 11 years in office. By the yardstick the Republicans used to reach that total -- including routine increases in fees and surcharges, in addition to tax increases -- Mr. Bush had raised Federal taxes 78 times in three years, Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Clinton also said that Mr. Bush's efforts to blame Congress for budgets that increased the deficit was off the mark because, according to the Congressional Budget Office, the budgets Mr. Bush sent to Congress would have increased the deficit by $1 billion.
"This is something I want to read in every article about this from now on," Mr. Clinton told the journalists.
Mr. Clinton also defended his record on welfare restructuring and improving graduation rates in his home state.
Mr. Bush, he said, wanted to take "credit for every victory around the world" but take no responsibility for the problems created by a flagging economy.
"Of all the whoppers George Bush tried to get away with in his speech last night, the biggest one wasn't even about me," Mr. Clinton said. "It came at the end, when this President compared himself to Harry Truman. Harry Truman had a sign on his desk in the Oval Office that said, 'The buck stops here.' If George Bush had a sign on his desk, it would say, 'Don't blame me. I'm just the President."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Wives Are Defended
 CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (Special to The New York Times) -- In Cleveland, speaking to 5,000 people who had gathered in the heart of the business district for a late afternoon rally, Mr. Clinton fairly shouted out a defense of his wife, Hillary, and his running mate's wife, Tipper.
"Did you believe it?" he asked the cheering, partisan crowd, referring to repeated references Thursday night by Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle to traditional American values and to scornful Republican references to Mrs. Clinton and Mrs. Gore throughout the Houston convention.
"They said that the election was about family values," he continued. "When Tipper Gore was leading a national effort to get the record companies of this country to voluntarily label their music, they thought she was great. She didn't become the enemy of family values until she wanted to kick them out of the White House.
"When my wife was helping cut the infant mortality rate in our state and in our region by half, sticking up for the kids of this country, Mrs. Bush wrote a book and bragged about Hillary. She didn't become an enemy of the family until she wanted to kick George Bush out of the White House for sticking it to the American family.
"Family values? Give me a break!"
Then Mr. Clinton accused Mr. Bush of bending the truth of campaign rhetoric more than any other President in the past half century or so.
"Last night, for the first time in my lifetime," he said, "a President of the United States stood before the American people and said things about his opponent that he knew were downright false, that he had been called on repeatedly. But he said them anyway."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview;
Bush Pulls Close in Poll, but Not With Women

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The Republican National Convention propelled President Bush into a competitive position with Gov. Bill Clinton today, but the newly renominated Mr. Bush also confronted the sudden re-emergence of a split between men and women in support of his ticket, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
The poll, taken overnight among 500 registered voters, seemed to put the Presidential race in a virtual dead heat, although the results were considered somewhat less reliable than most polls that question more people and last several days. 
 As the race ended the nominating phase and moved into a head-to-head contest that will include as many as three Presidential debates, Mr. Bush left Houston today for a three-day Southern campaign swing sounding combative.
"They say Clinton has a good reaction squad," he shouted at a final rally here before heading off to Mississippi to resume his attack on Mr. Clinton and the Democrats in Congress. "We're going to give them plenty to react to, every single minute."[Page 8.]
Mr. Bush clearly got some of what he had wanted from his convention. The new poll showed Mr. Clinton ahead of Mr. Bush by 45 percent to 42 percent, compared with his lead of 52 percent to 35 percent before the convention. The margin of sampling error in the nationwide telephone poll last night was plus or minus five percentage points.
At 14 points, Mr. Bush's post-convention surge, significantly smaller than Mr. Clinton's own 24-point boost after his convention, was about average for a Presidential candidate, according to a historical analysis provided by the Gallup Organization.
 
Gender Gap Growing
 Both sides said that the results of polls like this one, conducted immediately after a dramatic event, can be fleeting. And there were several warning signs for the President's re-election team that tempered the results. One that suddenly re-emerged after disappearing following the Democratic convention in July was the gap between men and women voters: women favored Mr. Clinton over Mr. Bush by a significant margin, while men were shifting to Mr. Bush by a smaller margin.
Although Mr. Bush's all-but-inevitable post-convention bounce was somewhat larger than had been expected, his low job-performance ratings remained virtually unchanged. His overall image was somewhat improved, but on balance, voters still said they had an unfavorable opinion of him.
 
No Impact on Congress
 After four days in which the Republicans suggested that working mothers made the wrong choice, demanded a ban on abortion and launched a strong personal attack on Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, the number of Americans who said Mr. Bush was mostly on the attack and not explaining his positions increased.
And despite the heavy focus on attacking Congress at the Republican convention, voters did not indicate any change in whom they planned to vote for, with the Democrats slightly favored. When asked whom they would vote for in their House district, without reference to names on any ballot, 43 percent said they would vote for the Democratic candidate; 37 percent said they would vote for the Republican.
But the poll also showed that voters' views of Mr. Clinton had shifted from positive to slightly negative. After four days of Mr. Clinton's punching back at Mr. Bush from outside the convention, the number who thought Mr. Clinton was doing more attacking than talking about his own positions had risen slightly, although most still said he was primarily promoting his own ideas.
Mr. Bush made clear in a farewell talk to party leaders here today that he did not intend to slow his assault on Mr. Clinton.
In an unusually blunt preview of his fall campaign strategy, Mr. Bush announced that he also planned to step up his assault on Congress by traveling to Congressional districts and attacking individual lawmakers. That strategy, used by Harry S. Truman in 1948 and by Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1940, carries the risk of making Mr. Bush appear even more negative in his campaigning.
Campaign strategists said that Mr. Bush's targets would include Democratic leaders and the 12 Democrats who had co-sponsored a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget, which Mr. Bush supports, and then voted against the measure on the House floor this summer.
 
Guilt by Association
 Mr. Bush said his goal would be to link Mr. Clinton with Congress in voters' minds and to tar the Democrat with the scandals and mismanagement on Capitol Hill. "Let them try to sever that umbilical cord," Mr. Bush said, chopping at the air with his hands.
The President's campaign strategists were heartened by the polls and by his decision to include economic proposals, however vague, in his acceptance speech after months of indecision and inaction at the White House.
"That gives us something to run on the rest of the way that provides the most dramatic contrast with Clinton," Charles Black, a senior campaign strategist, said as the Bush team headed back to Washington to prepare for Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to take over the White House staff and the campaign operation on Monday.
"It's clear we seized momentum at this convention and that we've made this a competitive race," Mr. Black said.
But he tried to temper his enthusiasm, given the expectation in the Bush and Clinton camps that Mr. Bush may slip back in the polls a bit, perhaps as early as this weekend, as the glow of the convention fades.
In 1980, when President Jimmy Carter's handling of the economy had the same low approval among voters as Mr. Bush's performance, the race between Mr. Carter and Ronald Reagan also was in a dead heat after the incumbent Democrat's convention.
"The convention reminds people of the differences between Republicans and Democrats, and what they like about having Republicans in the White House, and what makes them hesitant about having Democrats in the White House," Mr. Black said. "But the personal numbers are something entirely different."
The Clinton campaign's internal polling also reflected Mr. Bush's surge from the convention, Clinton aides said. But the Democrats took heart from other findings that suggested, as the New York Times/CBS News poll did, that voters still give Mr. Bush's performance poor reviews.
Only 40 percent of those surveyed said they approved of the way Mr. Bush had handled his job, essentially unchanged from 38 percent who held that opinion in a poll taken before the convention.
"Bush may have helped himself in the short run, but he's left himself with a lot of long-term vulnerabilities," said George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director. "His job-performance rating is still low."
In the last three Presidential elections, the Republican candidate has won despite having considerably less support among women than among men. But this is the year of family values, and Republican and Democratic strategists alike suggested that Mr. Bush was feeling the effects of the convention's offensive on that front. At times, that offensive turned into a biting assault on the lives led by Mr. Clinton and his wife, who did not give up her legal career when she had a child.
Throughout the campaign, there has been no consistent difference in support for Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton among men and women. After the Democratic convention in July, public opinion polls showed no split between the sexes.
But the new poll showed that men now say they favor Mr. Bush over Mr. Clinton by 47 percent to 40 percent, while women favor Mr. Clinton by 49 percent to 37 percent.
The re-emergence of a gap between men and women was due almost entirely to a shift by men toward Mr. Bush. Before the Republican convention, men gave Mr. Clinton a 19-point margin of support, while women similarly gave him a 15-point margin. But in Thursday's polling men had shifted to give Mr. Bush a 7-point margin, while women had remained with Mr. Clinton by a 12-point margin.
Although attacks on homosexuals emerged as a central part of the family-values theme at the convention, the poll results suggest that the Republicans may have a hard time using that in the campaign. While 50 percent of adults said homosexuality should not be considered an acceptable way of life, 79 percent said in a separate question that homosexuals should have equal rights in terms of job opportunities.
 
On to the Debates
 Two other national polls that included interviewing on Thursday also showed a tightening contest, although to a lesser degree. An ABC News poll of 469 likely voters surveyed on Thursday showed a 9-point Clinton lead. A Gallup Poll for CNN and USA Today taken Wednesday and Thursday, based on 801 registered voters, showed a 12-point Clinton advantage. Each result was narrower than the respective polling organization's pre-convention sounding.
With the conventions behind them, the next major milestone the candidates are facing is the debates. Mr. Bush has accepted Mr. Clinton's challenge for the traditional debates, but he has not formally agreed to dates or conditions for the encounters.
The Commission on Presidential Debates, an unofficial bipartisan group that sponsored the 1988 campaign debates, has proposed three 90-minute, nationally televised Presidential debates and one Vice-Presidential debate this year. The group wants to replace the familiar panel of journalists with one moderator to encourage give-and-take between the candidates.
How the Poll Was Conducted
 
 
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Thursday evening with 656 adults around the United States, exclud ing Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 500 said they were registered voters.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its popu lation. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers werethen screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
 The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relat ing to region, race, sex, age and educa tion.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than five percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all regis tered voters in the country.
The potential sampling error for small er subgroups is larger. For example, for results based on men it is plus or minus seven percentage points, while for wom en it is six percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the prac tical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. And polls conducted in just one night can be subject to further error because of the limited time available to call back respondents who are difficult to reach.

HEADLINE: Cairns Journal;
Hoping Tourists Will Say Sayonara

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRNS, Australia

 BODY:
Capt. James Cook discovered the endless beaches and dense rain forests here along the Great Barrier Reef in 1770. The Japanese rediscovered them sometime in the late 1980's, and that, the locals say, is when everything began to change.
On the main street of this once isolated town, advertisements are in both English and Japanese. With Japan's offices emptying for August, the glass-bottomed tour boats bobbing up and down over the reef are filled with what the Australians call "YOL's," the "young office ladies" who fly in from Tokyo to ooh and ahhh at the tropical fish below. 
 And as recession has gripped most of Australia, the region of Queensland that stretches from the glitzy hotels of the Gold Coast to the blue-green waters of the reef has become a comparatively prosperous object of envy.
 
A Whiff of Extortion
 Nonetheless, Lionel Van Dorssen and his fellow retailers in Cairns say they are not happy. Just behind the waves of tourists, they contend, came a wave of Japanese businesses that bought up a startling number of the best hotels and golf courses and staffed many of them with Japanese.
Then Japanese tour operators visited the stores and demanded big commissions -- 20 or 30 percent of the sales they generate -- for bring busloads of tourists to the front door.
"What's getting up the noses of everyone in town," said Mr. Van Dorssen, a former member of the town council, "is that Japanese tourists are here for three or four days, and unless you've been willing to pay the price, you never see them."
What triggered all this, of course, was something the residents of the reef could not have anticipated: For many Japanese, Hawaii has become a bit passe. Young Japanese in Tokyo complain that the beaches of Honolulu, the No. 1 destination for Japanese tourists, are now far too crowded with their compatriots.
 
Some Unhappy Memories
 The barrier reef is an alluring alternative, only six and a half hours from Tokyo, plenty of sand and golf courses, a carefully nurtured frontier image and -- best of all for weary office workers on a six-day holiday -- no jet lag.
Last year more than a half million Japanese visited Australia, including nearly a quarter of all of Japan's honeymooners. That is twice the number of Americans.
But if the arrival of jumbo jets full of infinitely polite tourists eager to spend heavily once seemed like an easier form of gold prospecting, it has turned out to be considerably more complicated. Throughout Australia, particularly in a conservative corner like this where some people are eager to remind visitors of the Japanese bombing of Darwin a half-century ago, Japan periodically crops up as a political football.
 
Investment Withers
 Two years ago a plan to build a major new high-tech city outside of Adelaide became an emotional issue in the federal elections. Critics said the plan, developed by Japan's Ministry for International Trade and Industry, was the first step in a Japanese takeover of Australia.
(Now the complaint is the opposite. Hit by a recession back home, the biggest worry is that the Japanese will abandon the project.)
With elections approaching, the current question is how to deal with giant tour buses like the one that pulled up the other day in front of Bentines. The neon-lit store is staffed almost entirely by Japanese who push Australian opals, Crocodile Dundee-style hats and toy koalas.
"Be very careful in this town," a young Japanese tour guide told her wards as they disembarked, to glares from some nearby storekeepers. The stores she was leading them to, she said, all had offices in Tokyo to deal with any returned goods, and they knew how demanding Japanese customers can be. "Other stores may not be as reliable," she said. "You should be very, very careful."
 
Who Guides the Guides?
 With emotions already high, another Japanese tour company wandered into trouble a few weeks ago when it asked permission to bring in 2,000 Japanese tour guides over the next three years. So many Japanese tourists are pouring into the country, they said, particularly older people with little or no English, that the meager language skills of the local tourist industry were being overwhelmed.
Queenslanders saw it differently. If Japanese tourists wanted to pet fuzzy hopping animals or dive the reef, they said with typical national directness, they should do it with Australian guides, drawn from the 30 percent of young people who the Government says are unemployed.
But even with 90,000 Australian students now learning Japanese, the Government has little sympathy for the complaints of the Queenslanders. "They are biting the hand that feeds them," said Richard Woolcott, one of the country's top diplomats.
Perhaps surprisingly, the Australians get a more sympathetic hearing at the Japanese Embassy. Fearful that the bus tours give Japan a bad image, Japan's Foreign Ministry has been encouraging more young people to travel independently, out of the reach of the Tokyo tour operators.
"Their No. 1 complaint," said Yasukuni Enoki, the embassy's senior political officer, "is that when they go out on the streets of Sydney or walk along the beach, they see too many Japanese."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
The dollar plunged to record lows against the German mark. The decline dragged down the American bond and stock markets and raised fears of economic disruptions both in the United States and Europe. The slide, attributed to the weak economy and more attractive interest rates abroad, is an unwelcome development for President Bush, who has asked voters to trust him as the better steward of the nation's economy. [Page 1.]
Stock prices plunged as a falling dollar and worries that an economic recovery would be stifled by higher interest rates set off a wave of computer-driven sell programs. The Dow fell 50.79, or 1.5 percent, to 3,254.10, its lowest close in four months. [36.] 
 Treasury bond prices sank as the dollar's fall ended a rally the bond market had been staging in response to President Bush's acceptance speech Thursday night. [36.]
The dollar's plunge came despite the intervention of 16 central banks to support it. [42.]
Grain and soybean futures settled higher in quiet trading. [42.]
 
 International
Japan's stock market staged a spectacular rally this week, following heavy Government intervention to stabilize the nation's faltering financial system. Still, many analysts doubted the rally would be sustained or that the economy was really regaining its footing. They attributed the market's gains to what is known as short-covering, quick purchases to replace borrowed stock, rather than to a long-term surge in demand. [34.]
 
The Economy
Customs duties on imports from China of up to 100 percent on $3.9 billion worth of goods were threatened by the Bush Administration unless China opened its markets to American goods. [33.]
The President's idea to force the Government to spend less by allowing the public to earmark tax payments for debt reduction implies spending cuts far more severe than are politically feasible, various budget analysts said. [33.]
 
Companies
An advertising agency can be culpable for false claims, a Federal judge ruled. She decided that Friedman Benjamin Inc., which wrote razor blade ads for Wilkinson Sword, was just as liable as the blade maker and should share responsibility for $953,000 in damages that she ordered paid to Gillette. [33.]
Efforts to reorganize T.W.A. so it can emerge from bankruptcy were said to be progressing. Carl C. Icahn, the airline's chairman, and its creditors have made major concessions to make the carrier's pension fund viable and to guarantee jobs for its pilots, people involved in the talks said. [33.]
Honeywell settled patent infringement cases with seven camera makers that it had accused of using its patented technology for autofocus lenses. It will be paid more than $124 million. The agreements were negotiated separately with Canon Inc., the Eastman Kodak Company, Konica, the Kyocera Corporation, Matsushita, Nikon and Premier. [35.]
Travelers plans loss insurance for theft of telephone services, which occurs when criminals tap into certain corporate telephone systems and steal long-distance calls. Most industry consultants agree that annual costs from all types of telephone fraud might exceed $2.2 billion. [35.]
 
Today's Columns
An Administration effort to simplify depositing payroll withholding taxes for small business has come under an unforeseen barrage of criticism from small-business advocates in industry, in Congress and within the Administration itself. Everyone agrees the notoriously complex regulations need changing, however. John H. Cushman Jr.: Your Taxes. [34.]
A microwave camera was patented to allow pilots to peer through fog and see the runway. It was invented at the Thermotrex Corporation, a military electronics company based in San Diego. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 NEW YORK CITY
 
 WILLIAMSBURG DUSTED
WITH LEAD PAINT
A painting crew sandblasting the Williamsburg Bridge repeatedly rained sand, dust and lead-paint chips into Brooklyn earlier this summer before city officials suspended the project under pressure from the state. The maintenance of the aging bridge has been halted for more than a month, and in the community beneath it, residents are anxious about findings of "elevated"' and potentially dangerous levels of lead in dust around the bridge. Page 1.
 
 A REPRIEVE FOR COUNCIL PRESIDENT
Mayor Dinkins and the City Council agree that the office of City Council President should be abolished. They just can't agree how to do it. An effort to put a referendum on the November ballot that would abolish the office failed because Council leaders and the administration could not agree on the details. Page 25.
 
 POLICE SHOOTING CALLED JUSTIFIED
A police detective who fatally shot a robbery suspect in May, sparking angry demonstrations in Brooklyn, will not be prosecuted. District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said, "There is no evidence that the police conduct in this incident was anything but justified." A spokesman for Mr. Hynes said the office had been unable to find anyone who disputed the police account and that the shooting was so clearly justified that the case was not presented to a grand jury. Page 25.
 
 REGION
 
 A SURPLUS
IN HARTFORD
Connecticut will close the books on its first fiscal year with a state income tax with a surplus of almost $113 million, according to an estimate from the legislature's budget office. The projection was released only two days before the one-year anniversary of the income-tax law, prompting angry denunciations all over again by tax opponents who said it only proved that the state was worsening the recession by taking too much money from residents. Page 26.
 
 CUOMO RESPONDS TO BUSH CRITICISM
Lest anyone misinterpret President Bush's convention-speech swipe at Mario M. Cuomo as a throwaway line, the New York Governor charged today that the Republicans were using him and his state to reinforce the country's ethnic and racial prejudices. Page 26.
 
 A DAY OF PROTEST IN TRENTON
Protesting the biggest layoff of state workers in New Jersey history, hundreds of union members rallied outside the State House in a one-day strike against the Department of Human Services. Page 26.
 
 A GUILTY PLEA IN ALBANY COUNTY
Albany County's former executive, James Coyne, pleaded guilty to three felony counts of making false statements on bank loan applications. In exchange, the Government agreed to drop the other charges in a 21-count indictment. Mr. Coyne could receive up to six years in prison and a maximum fine of $750,000. Page 26.
 
 FOR SALE: ONE BRIDGE, ALMOST NEW
It seemed like a bargain at the time: a six-ton steel bridge, almost new, on sale for only $91,700. Now, it's a white elephant that officials of Greenburgh, N.Y., are desperate to get rid of. Page 26.
 
 Two New Jersey beaches stay closed. Page 26.
 
 About New York by Douglas Martin 25

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: With the Convention Over, Americans Pause to Talk Politics;
In a Reagan Democrat Area, Signs of Unease Over Bush

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDEN GROVE, Calif., Aug. 21

 BODY:
If President Bush is to be re-elected he must retain the Reagan Democrats who deserted their party in the 1980's. And here, deep in the heart of Reagan Democrat country, in northern Orange County suburbs hit hard by the recession, it is anything but certain that he can do so.
"He's out of touch," said Pat Kinda, a housewife preparing dinner on Thursday evening as the President prepared to accept the Republican nomination in Houston. She said she had eagerly voted for Ronald Reagan, and less eagerly for George Bush four years ago. 
 "He's a nice guy, but he and Barbara were raised rich," she said, explaining why she, long a registered Democrat, would not vote Republican this year. "They have no idea how people live. We feel helpless."
On Election Day, Mrs. Kinda said, she and her husband, Joe, who runs a silk-screen business, will vote neither for Mr. Bush nor his Democratic rival, Bill Clinton ("He'd give the store away"), but for Ross Perot, writing in his name if necessary.
 
Unease and Unhappiness
 Mrs. Kinda's voice reflected the political unease and unhappiness flowing through blue-collar Democratic precincts in northern Orange County cities that voted heavily for Mr. Reagan in the booming 1980's, but now, with this corner of Reagan Country particularly hard hit by the troubled economy, the Republican message on abortion and "family values" falls flat.
"These are working-class people and they are the first to get laid off," said George T. Urch, chief of staff to Tom Umberg, the State Assemblyman who represents Garden Grove in Sacramento. "During the last recession we were insulated. But this time we have not been insulated at all."
Mr. Umberg's constituents are mostly people who migrated to California from the Midwest, seeking a better life and finding it in lush Orange County. But now they see it all threatened by a slumping economy, by factory layoffs and, increasingly, by foreign immigration.
Out of disgust for what they saw as the liberal drift of the Democratic Party, they have voted overwhelmingly Republican in the last three Presidential elections.
Even Mr. Umberg's wife, Robin, who described herself as a conservative on military and economic issues, voted for Mr. Reagan in 1980 and 1984, and stuck with Mr. Bush four years ago.
But not this year. "Friends of my children are having terrible hardships," she said. "I am really worried what is happening to families and homes. The cold war is over. Now we need to look at domestic issues. Bush has had his chance."
If the Republicans had hoped that their stand against abortion and the "family values" issue would help keep Reagan Democrats, there was little sign of that in door-to-door interviews with registered Demorats in two precincts here in the hours before Mr. Bush's speech on Thursday.
The President still has some friends in Leonard and Kathleen Kackley, who live in the Fairlane mobile home park and drifted away from their Democratic roots to vote for Mr. Reagan.
Mr. Kackley, a 73-year-old retired school custodian, said he would vote for Mr. Bush again ("I don't think Clinton's got the experience"), but was not impressed with the President's stand on abortion. "I think a woman should have a right to choose," he said.
The family values theme had at least some resonance with Mrs. Kackley, who complained about excessive sexuality in the media, including images of scantily clad women. Asked if he shared such concerns, her husband said, "No, I don't object -- at my age I've got a right to look."
After the President's speech Mrs. Kackley said she generally liked the message. On the economy and Mr. Bush's efforts to end the recession, she said: "I feel like he knows what's going on and would pull us out of it. But you hear people saying, 'You know how Republicans are.' So, I don't know."
Not far away, Robert and Anita Milhollin were holding a garage sale. Mr. Milhollin is a registered Republican, but he talked like a Reagan Democrat. A contractor, he said he had not worked for nine months and is beginning to have trouble making ends meet.
He said he is now ready to go Democratic. "I know quite a few people who've been in their homes for 10 or 15 years who are out of work and are losing their homes," he said.
Then he erupted with a complaint that is common among longtime residents who resent the influx of Vietnamese and Korean immigrants.
"Reagan let in a lot of boat people and gave them carte blanche to buy property up," he said, voice rising. "Now we have Little Saigon here. If you're going to live here, then get away from this Little Saigon, speak English. We're all Americans. We don't have a Dutchtown for me."
Family values? "Bunch of bull-harkey."
Abortion? "I have no right to tell people what to do."

HEADLINE: Black Journalists Tell of Facing New Job Pressures

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Reporters and editors who gathered here for a convention of the National Association of Black Journalists said the Los Angeles riots highlighted both the growing opportunities for blacks in the field and the problem of balancing questions of profession and race.
Indeed, many black reporters, editors and producers say they face mounting job pressures and complexities that they never anticipated, stemming from their emergence into newsrooms, radio stations and television stations that are still dominated largely by whites who have little familiarity with issues that concern blacks. 
 About 1,300 journalists, a number that is down from previous years partly because many black journalists were covering the Republican convention in Houston, attended the association's 17th annual convention, which began Wednesday and ends Sunday.
A report by the organization on news coverage of the Los Angeles riots concluded that "many black reporters believe they were assigned to the story primarily because they are black." The report cited complaints from many that they were not allowed to write important news articles.
 
Flattering Coverage Expected
 Black reporters often say they want to use their jobs to redress negative stereotypes or to focus attention on problems that they believe have been covered by the press inadequately.
However, they say, white supervisors may oppose or fail to understand their ideas. At the same time, black groups or individuals may expect flattering coverage from the reporter, based on common heritage.
"I was constantly harassed by a black mayor who perceived that me and my staff were too harsh," said Vernon Smith, now an assistant managing editor of The Dallas Morning News. "There is an unwritten rule that black journalists are supposed to look after their own."
Another type of pressure from black politicians was typified by remarks by Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan. Addressing a seminar on Wednesday, Mr. Conyers exhorted the journalists, many of whom have had to struggle to get their jobs, "not to fear endangering your careers or getting yourselves fired."
Amplifying his remarks later, Mr. Conyers, who is black, said, "We need activists in journalism" who will "challenge managerial practices."
 
Fairness and Balance
 More often, however, looking after one's own involves addressing issues of fairness and balance.
Michael Ottey, a reporter with The Asbury Park Press in New Jersey, told editors he was offended by a spate of photographs in the newspaper showing black male suspects being led away in handcuffs. "Somehow, whenever a white person was arrested they seemed to dig up his graduation picture for the newspaper," he said.
After a survey of their coverage the editors concluded that Mr. Ottey's objection was valid, said Fred Kerr, the paper's managing editor for news, and wrote a memorandum "to treat these subjects with consistent neutrality with regard to anything that perpetuates racial stereotypes."
In covering the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Jeff Rivers, an associate editor of The Hartford Courant, said, "There were expectations that they could confide in me."
A journalist "must not cross over the line" between objectivity and participation, he said. "Some black organizations have an idea that you will look out for them, so your stories result in disappointment."
Garry Pierre-Pierre, a Haitian-American reporter for The Fort Lauderdale (Fla.) Sun Sentinel, said he believed his choice of story subjects by itself constituted activism. "If I don't do them, who will?" he asked.
But a black reporter who favors stories that deal with issues of economic or social justice may "get pigeon-holed," said Jason Johnson, a reporter with The Dallas Morning News. "It's the price you pay, but otherwise they won't get done very well."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Watch;
View From the Booth: A Faulty Bush Speech

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
It was George Bush's moment to speak directly to the American people.
With the cameras focused mercilessly close in, he looked confident and determined. He spoke forcefully. And he had a bad word to say for just about everyone: Congressional leaders, Bill Clinton, Mario Cuomo, yes, even the King. 
 "I guess you'd say his plan is really 'Elvis economics,' " the President said, referring to Governor Clinton's proposals. "America will be checking into the 'Heartbreak Hotel.' "
Accusing one's opponents of "voodoo economics" is one thing; slighting Elvis is another. But this year, it seems, nothing is off limits, not even cultural icons. And if there was one clear message that viewers took away from the final night of the Republican convention it was that this campaign is likely to set records for nastiness.
"Elvis, of course, is Bill Clinton's patron saint," Andrea Mitchell said Friday morning on the NBC News program "Today." "That was really a low blow."
 
'Laundry List'
 All week long, newscasters, television commentators and even Republican officials had been billing the President's acceptance speech as his last, best hope to explain why he shouldn't lose his job. Mr. Bush's task, they said, was to lay out a compelling vision for the future and clear plan for tackling the nation's domestic problems.
As it turned out, though, this was not the most propitious buildup for a speech that seemed to have contempt for the President's opponents as its only unifying theme.
On Friday morning news programs, the President's supporters tried to put a new spin on the speech, saying its real aim had been to draw the distinctions between the candidates. But most television commentators were less forgiving.
The President's speech, they said, was a disappointment. Several called it a "laundry list" of proposals left over from the President's State of the Union address.
"There was a shortage of new initiatives," said Charles Kuralt of CBS. "I wonder if the President helped himself enough."
"I'd give it a gentleman's 'C,' as they say at Yale," said Tim Russert of NBC. "It was a real missed opportunity."
 
Borrowed Jokes
 The sense that the Bush administration was short on new ideas was evident not just from its proposals, but also from its jokes. If some of the President and Vice President's one-liners seemed familiar to convention viewers, it was because they were. Some, in fact, had been borrowed from the Democrats.
In his acceptance speech, Vice President Dan Quayle twice repeated the refrain "It's time for them to go," a line lifted directly from Senator Al Gore, his Democratic opponent. Mr. Quayle used the line to refer to Democrats in Congress; Mr. Gore had used it to refer to you-know-who.
Mr. Quayle also offered his version of the "you're no Jack Kennedy" line that Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the Democratic candidate for Vice President in 1988, had used so effectively against him, and that former President Ronald Reagan had already recycled on Monday night. Mr. Quayle attacked Mr. Clinton for comparing himself to another Presidential candidate with a background only in state government by saying, "Bill Clinton, you're no Ronald Reagan."
As Tom Brokaw of NBC observed after Mr. Quayle tried the Bentsen line yet again: "They've probably worn that one out."
The Republicans, who had some trouble this year putting on the kind of grand spectacle for which they are famous, did manage to pull off one television coup Thursday night -- the largest balloon drop in convention history. But even here there were bumpy moments.
After the President's speech, tens of thousands balloons, some the size of medicine balls, rained down from the rafters of the Astrodome. Seen in a wide shot, the balloons formed vast, cascading ribbons of red, white and blue. But when the cameras focused in on Mr. and Mrs. Bush, viewers saw they were not just waving from the stage but struggling to fend off some of the enormous balloons that were bouncing off their heads.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: With the Convention Over, Americans Pause to Talk Politics;
If These Are Typical Voters, The President Is in Trouble

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIVER ROUGE, Mich., Aug. 21

 BODY:
Forget the polls and columnists and odds makers. If there are such things as typical voters, a Mr. and Mrs. Taxpayer with the pulse of the electorate for all its rage and ambivalence, they are James and Bonnie Szalkie.
They are Midwestern Rust Belt, blue-collar Bush Democrats, ripe for Republican talk about family values and a strong America but on edge about the economy and an Administration they feel has lost touch with the Kmart crowd. 
 They are the kind of voters who can decide elections. For as long as they have been eligible to go to the polls, they have voted for the winner of each Presidential campaign: Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon, Nixon, Carter, Reagan, Reagan, Bush.
 
Shaking Their Heads
 Thursday night the Szalkies -- he is 50 years old, she is 49 -- sat in front of their television console, an auto worker and a homemaker in matching brown velour easy chairs, watching the man they last voted into the White House accept the Republican nomination for President and appeal once again for their vote.
As the grainy picture of George Bush pounding on the lectern flickered across the set, they yawned during the part about the end of the cold war, winced at the barbs at Bill Clinton and Mario M. Cuomo, and shook their heads when President Bush said the world economy was in transition, when they see recession.
"He still doesn't see how bad off this country is," Mr. Szalkie said. "I can't believe he's that blind."
Mrs. Szalkie looked into the distant face of a patrician President talking about things that mattered little to her and neared a boil. "He makes we want to reach out across the screen and grab him by the throat and say, 'Wake up, George,' " she said, lighting another cigarette. "I want him to talk about issues, not about other politicians. Forget Cuomo and all the rest."
The Szalkies live in a modest brick house on a narrow street lined with older Fords and pickup trucks in a factory town past its prime. They have watched steel mills and machine shops shut down around them in the last decade, the unemployment rate here hangs at 12 percent and their grown children struggle for jobs earning not much more than minimum wage.
As the economy has worsened, fluctuated and stalled, they have cut back on vacations and dinners out and the once-requisite new car every couple of years. Like many other voters, they have not lost a paycheck during the recent recession, but nonetheless they feel a vague sense of doom and vulnerability.
It is a discontent that goes deeper than the latest consumer index figures. It has to do with the feeling of disconnection from the party that they say seduced them in the 1980's and betrayed them in the 1990's.
Like an inamorata dumped by a suitor, Mrs. Szalkie says she can see through the Republicans and the promises of trickle-down prosperity. She says she has learned her lesson. "I don't care what the Republicans say," she said. "They're for the rich. I guess I'll never be rich, so to hell with them."
She has returned to her Democratic roots with gusto, sporting Clinton bumper stickers in front and back of the car. "Clinton would have to say he's a secret member of the Ku Klux Klan for me not to stick with him now," she said.
Mr. Szalkie has not made up his mind yet, finding the confetti and rhetoric of both parties' conventions more dizzying than enlightening. Like the American electorate, he is a bundle of contradictions. He loves the talk about family values -- although he is not quite certain what the term means -- but believes that women should have the right to an abortion. ("There's no way a man can decide abortion," he said. "They're men. They can't get pregnant.") He was angry that President Bush went back on his promise of no new taxes, but says he is certain that taxes must be raised to pare down the Federal budget deficit.
He turned off the television set on Thursday night disappointed.
"He let me down," Mr. Szalkie said. "He didn't commit himself to nothing. Not one thing did he commit himself to."
Mr. Szalkie did not like the finger-pointing at Congress and the name-calling aimed at the Democrats. "Slashing and slamming the Democrats, that's all he has going for him," Mr. Szalkie said. "It's sleazy. He should be above that."
This is not to say that Mr. Szalkie is sold on Governor Clinton, though. He worries that the Democratic nominee does not have enough foreign policy experience. But as impressed as the Szalkies are with President Bush's stature on the world stage, the President's lingering on the topic only reminded the Szalkies of the other thing that disappointed them about President Bush, the resolution of the Persian Gulf war.
"He was knocking on Saddam Hussein's front door," Mr. Szalkie said. "He should have taken him out when he had the chance."
Mrs. Szalkie chimed in, "That was his biggest mistake."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "He still doesn't see how bad off this country is," said James Szalkie, an auto worker in River Rouge, Mich., as he and his wife, Bonnie, sat in front of their television and watched President Bush speak at the convention. Both voted for Mr. Bush in 1988. "I can't believe he's that blind," Mr. Szalkie said. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot;
No New Plans? Read My Book, Perot Says

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

 BODY:
Like a nearly forgotten boomerang traveling a long, looping arc, Ross Perot, the Dallas billionaire, is trying to return to the Presidential race, if not as as candidate, then at least as an influence.
Since July 16 when he abruptly pulled out of the Presidential race, Mr. Perot has been financing a grass-roots organization called United We Stand, America that has continued to collect signatures on nominating petitions so that the Texas computer services magnate would qualify for the ballot in all 50 states. 
 Recently Mr. Perot gave a series of interviews with network news shows in which he continued to leave the door open -- a door that was never fully closed -- for his re-entry into the Presidential sweepstakes.
His new book, "United We Stand," went on sale yesterday. The book describes itself as a "plan for the 21st century" and provides specific recommendations to solve many of this country's most nettlesome economic and social problems. Aides to Mr. Perot say he hopes his volunteer network and his presence on the ballot will force President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton to address the issues and concerns laid out in his book.
 
'A Powerful Force'
 "He feels that he can effectively influence the debate," said Sharon Holman, Mr. Perot's press secretary. "He wants to influence the debate. The United We Stand volunteers can be a powerful force to do that. By staying together, and by his staying on the ballot, there is a great deal of leverage to do it."
The latest effort by Mr. Perot to inject himself into the Presidential campagn is a much more modest affair, compared with his last attempt. The Dallas headquarters from which the campaign is being directed occupies just a few rooms in the North Dallas office building that, in his previous attempt, had been just about taken over by Mr. Perot's campaign structure.
Aside from a few accountants and other experts needed to comply with reporting requirements for the Federal Elections Commission, Mr. Perot employs a skeleton staff. Longtime aides like Thomas W. Luce 3d and Morton Meyerson are not involved in Mr. Perot's latest effort. The telephone bank, which is staffed by a group of volunteers, has been reduced to 12 lines to handle incoming calls. At its height in Mr. Perot's abortive campaign, the telephone bank had 100 lines.
 
Offices in Every State
 Mr. Perot is also financing 64 offices in all 50 states to co-ordinate efforts to get him on the ballot and to support his nationwide volunteer force. Ms. Holman declined to say how much Mr. Perot is contributing to the effort.
Mr. Holman said that Mr. Perot is on the ballot in 36 states, and volunteers have turned in petitions in an additional 6 states and the District of Columbia that are awaiting certification. In another 8 states -- New York, Wisconsin, New Mexico, Arizona, Hawaii, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Vermont -- Mr. Perot's volunteers have not yet gathered enough signatures to place his name on the ballot.
In one state, New York, Mr. Perot has difficulty finding enough volunteers to get the job done, and is paying individuals $10 an hour to work in the petition drive. Ms. Holman said New York is the only state where people are being paid to help collect signatures.
While Mr. Perot is listed as the author of the 117-page book, it is actually the product of the research staff headed by John P. White, which developed positions for Mr. Perot in his campaign. Many of these positions have been reported before and some, like the line-item veto, have already been embraced by both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton. Proceeds from the sale of the book will go to the United We Stand, America organization, Ms. Holman said.
 
Bold Departures Outlined
 Some of the recommendations represent a bold departure from the platform of both the Democratic and Republican parties. For example, Mr. Perot suggests cutting Federal discretionary spending by 15 per cent, eliminating such programs as the space station. He advocates the elimination of all farm subsidies for large agricultural corporations, cutting the tax deduction for business entertainment to 50 percent of its cost from the current 80 percent and scrapping some weapons systems like the B-2 bomber, and the Seawolf submarine.
Mr. Perot also proposes getting rid of the tax deduction for the amount of a home mortgage of more than $250,000 and raising the income tax rate for high income families and individuals to 33 per cent from the present 31 percent. He also advocates a 10-cents-a-gallon tax on gasoline in each of the next five years and raising taxes on Social Security receipts for individuals who earn more than $25,000 and families earning more than $32,000.
Since income for retirees generally comes from investments like stocks and bonds, and it would take a rather large investment to earn such amounts, Mr. Perot estimates that his proposal would only affect about 18 percent of all retirees.
Mr. Perot's book, published by Hyperion Press, also contains a number of his folksy recommendations, particularly those concerning what he views as the imperiousness of Federal officials, that he made in his campaign speeches and interviews. For example, he suggests that top government officials be banned from using government airplanes. By making Federal officials fly on commercial airlines, Mr. Perot said, they would stay in touch with the average citizen.
"They should go out to the airport, get in line, lose their baggage, eat a bad meal, and stay in touch with how normal people live," he writes.
As he traveled about the country promoting his candidacy, Mr. Perot always flew in his private jet.

HEADLINE: Uncertainty in Connecticut G.O.P. Stronghold

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 21

 BODY:
This is the kind of town that looms large in the Republican vision of America. It has shady streets lined with white clapboard houses, a picturesque town green, and a fondness for self-history that reaches back to pilgrim days.
But the order of Milford masks the dramatic changes of the last few years. More women are working outside the home than ever before; many people have lost the jobs they had at local factories that once seemed so secure, and managing the requirements of a municipality -- from traffic to sewage -- has grown more difficult as revenues have fallen. 
 There seems to be an uncertainty here, about the future and about who would best lead the nation toward it, and this week's speeches and campaign promises from President Bush seem to have done little to dispel that, even in a town that has voted Republican in the last three Presidential elections.
 
Looking Elsewhere
 "It is all very superficial, the things that they're saying," said Marti Reed, a registered Republican who owns a gift shop on Broad Street here and who has been following the convention in the newspaper. "The issues are the economy and world peace. I really think that they've got to have some problem-solving." She described President Bush as "a very nice man" but added that she wasn't sure he was "powerful enough."
On Monday the President is scheduled to speak in Ansonia, a depressed manufacturing city just north of here. "I don't think he's going to be met with a lot of happy faces," Ms. Reed said.
Thursday night, as Mr. Bush delivered his hourlong acceptance speech, he failed to impress David Dyer, a lifelong Republican who lives in a beachfront community here and who had marched into City Hall earlier in the day to switch his party affiliation, a decision prompted, he said, by Patrick J. Buchanan's address on Monday.
"The Republicans are in denial," Mr. Dyer, a 41-year-old data-processing specialist, said as the President promised to preserve family values, cut taxes and oppose abortion. "It's like a family in denial. They refuse to see reality or deal in reality."
"The diehard Republicans are going to go crazy over anything he says," Mr. Dyer added, as placards fluttered on the television screen and the cameras showed delegates wearing elephant tattoos on their cheeks, sunglasses proclaiming "Bush-Quayle," and hats topped with cutouts of the President's grinning face. "But those that are standing on the fence, they want to hear some admission of wrongdoing and what he's going to be doing differently."
 
Worry in Community
 Milford's voters are a mixed lot. There are 8,298 registered Democrats, and 7,159 Republicans. Then there are 12,608 more voters who are unaffiliated, as well as 8 people who joined A Connecticut Party, the party established by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. when he campaigned as an independent two years ago. There are white-collar as well as blue-collar workers, some of whom commute to New York City every morning and others who drive to their jobs, some of them assembling ball-point pens, shavers and other products.
"Connecticut is still hurting very badly," said Kathy Lutz, the Democratic Town Chairman for Milford. "You listen to talk about things are better, but you just can't sell that story around here. Our real estate values are very, very depressed. Lower interest rates have made little or no difference. And people are worried about losing jobs or having their hours cut back.
 At Harrison's Hardware, a Milford institution for 85 years, the hard-pressed economy is seldom far from the minds of shoppers.
The President mentioned hardware stores specifically in his address, saying that if the Democrats recaptured the White House, such stores would display signs advising "Closed for despair." How did that impress workers in Harrison's?
"A place like this is probably a piece of Americana," said David Ryan, a salesman who described himself as a diehard Democrat. "The whole speech sounded like they were in the corner and they better watch out or they'll be ousted."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Opens Fall Campaign, Attacking

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRANSON, Mo., Aug. 21

 BODY:
Offering himself as the 1992 version of Harry S. Truman, President Bush today opened his general election drive in the former President's home state with a torrent of fighting words at Gov. Bill Clinton, Congress and the press.
At spirited rallies before flag-waving partisans at the water's edge in Gulfport, Miss., and then at a country-and-western theme park here in the Ozarks, Mr. Bush pronounced the Republican National Convention a success and said the race was already tightening. 
 But he devoted most of his oratory not to touting his own accomplishments or goals but to bitterly attacking the Governor of the state just south of here as espousing ideas that are "clear, present and dangerous." He also accused Mr. Clinton of "wishy-washy indecision" on the Persian Gulf war.
Except for the Presidential seal on the lecterns, Mr. Bush, his collar open, his sleeves rolled up, looked and sounded more like a challenger than a man who has occupied the White House for nearly four years. He spent more time ridiculing Mr. Clinton's economic policies than seeking support for the across-the-board tax cut that he proposed Thursday night but mentioned only in passing today.
 
Going to the People
 "Two weeks ago they were totally writing off the Bush-Quayle ticket, all those smart talking heads on television," Mr. Bush said as Vice President Quayle stood by his side in Gulfport, both sweating through their dress shirts in the stifling humidity. "But we are going to take it to the American people. We're going to the people with our message.
"For nine months," he continued as the crowd roared, "the Governor of Arkansas has been distorting my record. And I don't care what the polls say, I'm going to take this case to the American people like Truman did -- go against the Congress, go against the opponent, say what I'm for."
Arriving at another rally at the Silver Dollar City park in Branson, the Republican President again sought to shroud himself in the image of the Democratic son of Missouri who took on Congress in the 1948 campaign. "He was a big underdog and he fought back," Mr. Bush said. "And he wrapped another Governor challenging him right around the do-nothing Congress. I'm going to do the same thing with the Governor of Arkansas."
 
Gloom and Doom
 If Mr. Bush's vitriol today is any indication, voters are in store for a political season that will make the Truman race seem tame. Calling his stop in Gulfport "the first step into the future," Mr. Bush sought to build on the political lift from the Republican convention and, indeed, many of his passages today rang familiar to anyone who heard his speech Thursday night.
If anything, Mr. Bush's oratory today was even more pointed. After barely a night's sleep after the convention's closing gavel fell, Mr. Bush wasted no time in mocking those who predict he will not win re-election.
"We came down here to Houston with more dire predictions, more gloom-and-doom negativism than I've ever seen in my long, long time in the political arena or, indeed, the private arena," Mr. Bush said at a brief appearance with Mr. Quayle before the Republican National Committee as he was leaving Houston. "A lot of that is turning around," he said.
The day lacked the spontaneity of the the Clinton-Gore bus caravan after the Democratic National Convention; there were many empty seats at the party's send-off in Houston, and though the two rallies drew thousands of enthusiastic supporters, some campaign officials had predicted larger crowds.
There was no doubt, though, that the reception today -- where supporters repeatedly broke into chants of "four more years, four more years" -- was a welcome improvement over the first post-convention outing of Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle four years ago. It was then, at a stop at Mr. Quayle's hometown of Huntington, Ind., that thousands of supporters greeted the freshly-minted ticket, but caused a ruckus by turning on the press for a stream of reports questioning the Vice President's military record and, more broadly, his preparedness for the office. Mr. Quayle tried, rather unsuccessfully, to defend himself to reporters.
Today the campaign played it safe; there were no news conferences, and Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle parted ways in Mississippi. The crowds were almost all white, and in friendly Southern territory where campaign officials hope to shore up their political base before moving on to more contentious battleground states.
The coming days should bring continued brisk campaigning before receptive audiences. From here, Mr. Bush has scheduled stops in Georgia, Alabama and Texas on Saturday and Illinois on Sunday before returning to Washington. He leaves again on Monday for New Jersey and Connecticut.
Mr. Quayle is also expected to keep up a heavy pace on the road, and today he praised the President's acceptance speech and vowed to press on, speaking everywhere about family values.
"I'm going to say it again and again and again," the Vice President said this morning in Houston. "We will not back down from talking about traditional values."
 
The President's Crusade
 But it was Mr. Bush who dominated the day as he hammered away with sound bites he is sure to repeat over and over in what he calls his "crusade" in next 74 days:
The "gridlocked" Congress: "Throw them out with their PAC's, their privileges and their perks."
Bill Clinton: "Follow that old Elvis Presley song, Return to Sender."
Change: "This election isn't simply about change. It's about who do you trust to make the change work for you."
By the day's end, one thing was clear: this would-be Harry Truman has only begun to bash.
