HEADLINE: Doubts Voiced on Bush Plan For Taxpayer to Cut Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The President's idea to force the Government to spend less by allowing the public to earmark tax payments for debt reduction implies spending cuts far more severe than are politically feasible, various budget analysts said today.
The proposal was thus seen as highly unlikely to get the necessary approval of Congress, particularly as currently dominated by Bush adversaries, these skeptics said. 
 "Politically, it represents a huge barrier for Democrats, certainly, and probably a good number of Republicans, to climb over," said Norman Ture, a Reagan Administration Treasury official who now heads the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation.
While some commentators dismissed the checkoff as a gimmick, there was little doubt that the plan, assuming enactment, would be an immensely powerful weapon against the growth of Government spending. Yet even maximum participation by the public would only restrain the growth of the national debt, not pare it back.
Under the plan, taxpayers would be able to specify that up to 10 percent of their tax payments be placed in a special trust fund. A similar checkoff already in effect allows designation of $1 to finance Presidential campaigns. With that checkoff, as with the one proposed, the amount of tax owed is not affected.
What carries the plan's potential beyond a meaningless bookkeeping entry is the companion requirement. "We need to make sure that Congress doesn't just turn around and borrow more money to spend more money," the President said in his speech. "So I will require that for every tax dollar set aside to cut the debt, the ceilings on spending will be cut by an equal amount."
In effect, each earmarked dollar would produce an across-the-board spending cut, an outcome that would indeed serve an Administration goal of empowering taxpayers.
These cuts of as much as $50 billion a year -- the Treasury collects about $500 billion from the individual income tax -- would be in addition to $293 billion in cuts over five years that the Administration proposes to achieve by capping entitlement programs.
To get even half the savings from entitlements, said Carol Cox Wait, president of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, "you'll still be testing the outer limits of people's tolerance for expenditure restraint." So, in her view, there would be little room for the additional cuts forced by the earmarking mechanism. Such cuts would be spread equally across four areas -- military, domestic, international and certain entitlements.
The Bush plan has its origins in Congress, where a similar proposal was put forward this summer by Representative Robert Walker of Pennsylvania and Senator Robert Smith of New Hampshire, both Republicans. Another one, pressed by Representative Charles E. Bennett, a Florida Democrat, would require taxpayers to supply extra money if they wanted to contribute to a deficit-reduction fund.
 
Raising Money
 The Treasury already has a program under which taxpayers can send extra money for debt reduction when filing their tax return, but this money -- $114,794 last year -- goes directly into general revenues.
Leon E. Panetta, a California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, said today that the earmarking proposal would create a budget "nightmare," citing among other things "uncertainty" about what would be required.
"Rather than rolling the dice with the budget, the President should take the lead and work with the Congress to set new spending targets and deficit reduction goals, just as was done in 1990," Mr. Panetta said. "Deficit reduction is certainly necessary, but it should be accomplished in an orderly way that allows for advance planning and careful spending decisions."
 
Previous Opposition
 Representative Bennett today was circulating copies of testimony given in May by the Treasury's tax legislative counsel who said the department has "consistently opposed voluntary checkoffs to the tax return, regardless of how meritorious" the purpose, including Federal debt reduction.
"These types of well-intended and seemingly innocent proposals create complexity, confusion and administrative burdens," said Terrill A. Hyde, the Treasury lawyer.
A spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service said today that he foresaw little administrative difficulty, suggesting that the checkoff -- though not necessarily its instructions -- would add only one or two lines to the tax forms.

HEADLINE: Aid for the Rich, Not the Economy

 BODY:
George Bush's acceptance speech echoed the same theme as virtually every other Republican leader at the Houston convention: The problem with the economy is not President Bush's program but an obstinate Congress that refuses to go along. According to this argument, the difference between economic stagnation and growth is a matter of tax cuts proposed by Mr. Bush and rejected by Congressional Democrats.
The theme may make for effective sound bites. But it is nonetheless absurd. The tax cuts proposed by Mr. Bush have more to do with rewarding wealthy friends than jump-starting the economy. Had Congress granted his every wish, including the vague ones he announced in Houston, the overall economy would barely have noticed. 
 Take Mr. Bush's obsessive call for a cut in the tax on capital gains, the profit from selling stocks, bonds and other investments. The evidence is overwhelming that such a cut would have a trivial impact on economic growth. Indeed, based on estimates by the President's own chief economic adviser, Michael Boskin, the cut would boost the economy by -- at most -- a measly 0.2 percent. Yet, disgracefully, it remains the centerpiece of the Mr. Bush's domestic agenda.
The thread that runs through the President's tax cuts is reward for the wealthy. How else can he explain his plan to cut the capital gains tax on past investments? That would produce windfall profits for asset holders, but do nothing to spur investment. Similar proposals to bail out real estate investors would do nothing to redirect investment toward new plant and equipment, the engine of growth.
Even where Mr. Bush was on to something potentially useful -- for example, lowering taxes on retirement accounts to spur saving -- he backed gimmicks that would needlessly line the pockets of high-income families and send the Federal deficit rocketing upward. On net, this tax cut would hurt the economy.
Some supply-side zealots believe tax cuts make an economic program. But the U.S. tried such nostrums in the 1980's, only to find they led to a consumption binge and billowing deficits.
Tax changes can be effective, but in ways Mr. Bush has never dared to propose. What about scrapping the personal and corporate income tax codes, which often discourage savings and investment, in favor of a consumption tax that would encourage them? Such a tax should be structured to protect low-income families.
That would be worth fighting for: pro-growth and fair. Another way to attack economic malaise is to borrow planks from Bill Clinton's platform. The key to growth is putting skilled workers together with state-of-the-art equipment. That would require targeted tax incentives. But it would also require expensive public investments in schools and infrastructure paid for by broad-based taxes.
Judging from this week's convention oratory, Republicans wouldn't go near such a sensible program because to them all taxes seem evil no matter what their purpose.
Mr. Clinton makes impossible claims for his economic program and ducks its costs. But his proposals at least add up to a program. The President's do not, and that's not Congress's fault.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Bush's Big Bash

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Woody Allen and Fergie, the Duchess of York, were lucky. The stories of their messy family lives reached Houston too late for God's angry Republicans who had loosed their terrible swift swords upon foes of Bushness and Quaylitude.
Has there ever been such a joyful public bashing of the irrelevant by adults presumed capable of running a large, heavily armed institution? The bashers will doubtless reply, "Where were you when the Democrat Party was dishing it out in New York?" 
 To which I can only point out that biology is kind. As it prepares the aged to accept death, so it enables us all to forget with life-restoring swiftness life's most blatant idiocies, our own as well as politicians'. Within a week or two all memory of Houston's squalid summonses to fear and hate will vanish too from memory.
Meantime, however, let us recall those, not so lucky as Woody and Fergie, whom this Convention so loved to hate. They included Hillary Clinton, Bart Simpson, Murphy Brown, homosexuals and liberals en masse, the entire Congress, nonJudeo-Christians and the media, but especially the media elite.
Buses also had a bad week. Buses had made the mistake of serving as vehicles of transport for agents of the Democrat Party. One wanted to sympathize with buses. After all, they are poor people's last hope for getting out of town without committing car theft. Yet they had let themselves be used by the Democrat Party.
The buses were dupes of Democrat-ism, just as clearly as addlepated, pinko, ultra-left-liberal fellow travelers in the old days had been dupes of Communism. Victory in the war against Clintonhood and Goredom will not be won by softness on dupes.
At the Convention's end we had been offered so much to fear and hate that buses seemed the easy place to start the job. People of squeamish personality find it easier to kick a bus in its tires than to put the boot into Mrs. Clinton.
And what was a man to do about the terrible Democrat-Congress situation that had caused all the unemployment, bankruptcies, poverty, savings and loan rip-offs and homelessness, not to mention leaving 35 million people without health insurance plus creating unwed mothers and too much sex in movies and television, despite the heroic ingenuity with which Mr. Bush had fought these catastrophes?
I can tell you what one red-blooded American lad wanted to do: He wanted to go right to Washington and mug a Congressman. He might have done so too, but he realized it was not what a true Judeo-Christian would do. So he said, "All right, I'll do the civilized thing and vote against Congressman Frank Wolf."
"But the Convention doesn't want you to do that," I cautioned. "The Convention is down on Democrat Congressmen, and Wolf is not a Democrat Congressman. He is a Republic Congressman."
It was that kind of week. All that hate building up inside a viewer, and no way to let it out. The Convention seemed to be suffering the same difficulty on its side of the TV tube. You could sense its pain in the occasional dig at Mario Cuomo.
For years the Republics had been preparing to run against Cuomo, had drawn up all those plans, gathered all that data, were just rearing for a crack at Mario. And he had spoiled it all, undone all that preparation, had deprived them of the opportunity to point with horror at squalid Times Square, had Cuomo, the rat!
Things and people that escaped Houston unbashed provide brooding material for heavy thinkers. Most notable of course was Communism. Now flourishing in China with Mr. Bush's indulgent acquiescence, Communism became a non-ism. Chelsea Clinton, daughter of Hillary, escaped unbashed, as did Willie Horton, rap music and bloody violence in TV and movies.
Why Republicans recoil from sex-as-entertainment but are unruffled by entertainment bloodshed is not logically explicable. Mr. Bush, of course, is pals not only with the gun lobby but also with Arnold Schwarzenegger, whose mass cop-killings as "The Terminator" made him a star, but the sense that shows about violence are manly while shows dealing with sex are dirty is anchored deep in the national psyche.
The Woody and Fergie stories are sex stories, but pure soap-opera stuff. It would have been interesting to hear Dan Quayle bash the soaps. Too bad the news arrived too late.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Honeywell Patent Suit Is Settled

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Honeywell Inc. announced yesterday that it had settled with seven camera makers it had accused of infringing its patented technology for autofocus lenses, and would be paid more than $124 million.
 The agreements were negotiated separately with Canon Inc., the Eastman Kodak Company, Konica, the Kyocera Corporation, Matsushita, Nikon and Premier, Honeywell said. 
Investors reacted positively to the news. On a day when broad market averages tumbled, Honeywell's stock price rose by $1.375, to $64.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Doing the Accounting
 Christopher J. Steffen, an executive vice president and chief financial officer at the Minneapolis-based company, said Honeywell reported $13.9 million in gross proceeds from the settlement in the second quarter. The remainder will be reported in the current quarter, he said.
 Royalties for camera sales by these companies will continue through March 28, 1995, Honeywell said, when its applicable autofocus patents expire.
 The settlements yesterday follow a $127.5 million payment made in March by the Minolta Camera Company.
 
Verdict in New Jersey
 Minolta made the payment after a Federal jury in New Jersey found in February that Minolta had willfully infringed two patents for the autofocus technology, and awarded Honeywell $96.35 million.
 The money awarded by the trial jury applied only to damages until the trial. It did not reflect compensation for sales outside the United States, interest or other matters that were included in the final settlement.
 Following the Minolta award, Honeywell filed suits to force the largely Japanese camera industry to pay royalties for the autofocus technology, now an integral part of the modern camera.
 Last spring, Honeywell said it would seek patent-infringement settlements from as many as 15 companies.
 
Where Will They Spend It?
 Analysts said Honeywell might use the proceeds from the settlements to continue a five-year, $600 million stock repurchase program announced late last year, or to make an acquisition in one of the company's three key businesses: space and aviation, industrial controls, and home and building controls.
 But the awards do little to alter the company's longer-term prospects, the analysts said.
 "After they have gotten all the cash from these suits, the issue going forward is what does their book of business look like," said Elliott Rogers, a vice president at Cowan & Company in New York.
 "I think Honeywell's growth will be restrained by a slowdown in the aerospace business, which had been one of their key driving forces, as well as sluggish economic growth worldwide, which is dampening demand for their products."

HEADLINE: Drop in Dollar Chokes Off Rally in Bonds

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices sank yesterday as the dollar fell to a record low against the German mark.
 The dollar's decline quashed a rally the bond market had been staging in response to President Bush's speech to the Republican convention on Thursday. 
In the speech, Mr. Bush pledged tax cuts but also said they would be linked to restrained Government spending. The market had been fearful that Mr. Bush would make proposals that would have the effect of increasing the Federal budget deficit. Higher deficits force the Government to issue more debt securities, depressing the prices of existing bonds.
 But yesterday's early rally faltered as bond traders focused on the action in the currency markets, where the dollar's decline defied efforts by central banks to push it higher.
 
Keeping the Dollar Down
 The dollar has fallen recently largely over concern about the direction of the American economy and the higher interest rates available on investments in other countries. Higher rates abroad draw money away from investments denominated in dollars, including Treasury bonds.
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond fell 13/32 , or $4.06 for $1,000 in face amount, tumbling from gains of more than $5 in morning trading. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, ended at 7.35 percent, up from 7.32 percent late Thursday.
 In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities had gains of as much as 3/8 point, intermediate maturities gained up to 17/32 and long-term issues rose 7/16 , the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
 The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
 The Lehman Brothers Treasury bond index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 2.99, to 1,271.90.
 Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 3.13 percent as the discount rate fell a basis point, to 3.07 percent. Yields on six-month bills held at 3.26 percent as their discount stayed at 3.17 percent. Yields on the one-year bills sold at auction Thursday rose to 3.44 percent as the discount gained 4 basis points, to 3.32 percent.
 A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity.
 The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, fell to 3 1/8 percent, from 3 1/4 percent late Thursday.
 The Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was unavailable.

HEADLINE: Fed Division On Rate Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Most Federal Reserve System leaders favored cutting interest rates when they met June 30 and July 1 if new signs of economic weakness appeared, minutes of the session released today show.
 The minutes showed that the panel was divided on the interest rate cut, which occurred July 2. The cut occurred after the Labor Department reported that the civilian unemployment rate bounded to 7.8 percent in June from 7.5 percent in May as the number of nonfarm jobs fell by 63,000. 
The Fed pushed the discount rate to 3 percent from 3 1/2 percent on loans that it makes to banks, and pressured the Federal funds rate on loans between banks to a target of 3 1/4 percent from 3 3/4 on July 2.
 The Federal Open Market Committee, which heavily influences the Federal funds rate, was split on whether interest rates should be cut in a 10-to-2 vote during the June 30-July 1 meeting.
 Voting against a rate cut were John P. LaWare, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, and Thomas Melzer, president of the St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank.

HEADLINE: Economic Fears Cut 50.79 From Dow

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
Stock prices plunged yesterday as a falling dollar and worries that an economic recovery would be stifled by higher interest rates set off a wave of computer-driven sell programs.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 50.79 points, or 1.5 percent, to 3,254.10, its lowest close in four months. 
Today was a simple case of the dollar killing the bond market, and the stock market following," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer at John Hancock Mutual Funds in Boston. "I think it's a temporary downturn, but there was no stopping it."
 The Dow jumped sharply in the opening minutes of trading, fed by a positive response to President Bush's promise to cut both taxes and spending if he is re-elected in November. But prices were drifting downward just before noon, when traders noticed that efforts by the Federal Reserve and other central banks to prop up the dollar had failed.
 As the dollar sank to its lowest level ever against the German mark, bond traders saw hopes for lower interest rates extinguished, and once they began to sell, stocks began a nose dive of their own.
 
Intervention Failed
 "When news came along that central bank intervention was less than successful," said Philip H. Smyth of Birinyi Associates, "the selling began."
 The largest of seven computerized sell programs tracked yesterday by Mr. Smyth began at 11:45 and lasted about 25 minutes, forcing the Dow down 30 points. It involved about 400 of the 500 stocks in the Standard & Poor's index, he said, as well as 100 smaller stocks in the Nasdaq composite index.
 For the day, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 3.41, to 414.85, while the Nasdaq composite index lost 4.16, to 563.70. Gaining stocks, at 667, were smothered by 1,040 losing ones.
 Trading was active, with 204.8 million shares changing hands, up from the 183.4 million on Thursday.
 Other analysts said the selling was compounded by the expiration of stock and index options, which usually encourage program trading in one direction or the other, making the market more vulnerable to wild price swings.
 "Expirations accounted for some of the action," said Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research at Gruntal & Company. "There's been a lot of bearishness. At this point, the market is very close to becoming oversold."
 
Bounce Expected Next Week
 Mr. Seagle said he expected a bounce in the market next week, especially ifpolls over the weekend indicated a surge of support for President Bush following the Republican convention.
 "There's been a lot of uncertainty about the election, and a lot of worry about Bush," Mr. Seagle said. "I think we're starting to see a turn in that."
 He also noted that the Dow had come close to 3,250, seen by technical analysts as an important support level. If selling continues, he warned, the Dow could fall much further.
 Mr. Freedman expressed optimism that the market would rebound soon, particularly if the economy continued to move toward recovery.
 "The market is still jittery about the dollar," he said. "But the alternatives to stocks and bonds still aren't there. Maybe the summer rally is over, but there is room to move upward."
 Yesterday's most active stock was USX Marathon, which fell 1/8, to 18 5/8, over concern that the company's board would soon cut its dividend.
 B. F. Goodrich fell 3 1/8, to 40 1/2, after analysts sharply cut their earnings estimates for the chemical concern for two years. Reynolds Metals dropped 3 3/8, to 50, and Alcoa fell 3 1/8, to 64 3/4.
 Among smaller stocks, the Russell index of 2,000 stocks dropped 0.94 point, to 190.01, and the American Stock Exchange index fell 1.56, to 384.31
 Biogen Inc. fell 2 1/8, to 25 3/8, while Gensia Pharmaceuticals fell 2 3/8, to 36 3/8.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
YOUNG MEN & FIRE, by Norman Maclean. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) This courageous, many-layered posthumous work by the author of "A River Runs Through It" offers to wrest truths of artistry, of mortality and of tragic form from the story of 13 men killed in a Montana forest fire in 1949.
UP IN THE OLD HOTEL: And Other Stories, by Joseph Mitchell. (Pantheon, $27.50.) Stories, profiles and articles written for The New Yorker between 1938 and 1965 by a reporter of genius.
ANCESTRAL VOICES, by Etienne van Heerden. (Viking, $21.) First published in Afrikaans in 1986, this dark, portentous novel broods on a nation's history through the generations of the Moolman family, a bigoted, jealous, strange, spectacular lot.
VIRGIN TIME, by Patricia Hampl. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A literary account, by the author of "A Romantic Education," of a personal journey, through pilgrimage and conventual life, into a Roman Catholic heritage she had thought to be dead.
THE VOLCANO LOVER: A Romance, by Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) One of our paramount critics extends her neck without damage in this grand, vigorous, witty and moral historical novel about Lord Nelson, his lover Emma Hamilton, her husband and Neapolitan society in the 18th century.
THE GREAT DEEP: The Sea and Its Thresholds, by James Hamilton-Paterson. (Random House, $23.) An intricate, scholarly, painful survey of the oceans and their imperilment by humanity.
THE LINCOLN COUNTY WAR: A Documentary History, by Frederick Nolan. (University of Oklahoma, $49.95.) Mr. Nolan's primary research and thoughtful treatment capture the spirit of a justly infamous episode of rotten behavior in the West.

PUB-DATE: August 23, 1992

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 900 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER

 BODY:
THE CHANGING ATMOSPHERE: A Global Challenge, by John Firor. (Yale University, $8.) This book on the environment is strong medicine -- "about as agreeable as a dose of ipecac," our reviewer, Malcolm W. Browne, said in 1990. The author points out that we must be ready either to change our habits or invent substitutes for all that is being destroyed. "Mr. Firor's book is persuasive because it is based more on evenhanded analysis than on advocacy," Mr. Browne noted.
THE ADAPTABLE MAN, by Janet Frame. (Braziller, $9.95.) In this novel, first published 27 years ago, the New Zealand author Janet Frame explores the ways human beings have tried to adapt to the 20th century. One of her characters, Alwyn Maude, has committed an act that seems horrifyingly but quintessentially modern: a senseless murder. In 1965 our reviewer, Wilfrid Sheed, called the book "an original novel, comic, intense, stylish, from one of the most interesting writers around." Braziller is also reissuing DAUGHTER BUFFALO ($8.95), the author's only novel set in New York City and one whose characters, not coincidentally, are all in love with death. "She makes morbidity a spectacle, a brilliant, mutilating feast," Josephine Hendin said here in 1972. 
 WHY GORBACHEV HAPPENED, by Robert G. Kaiser. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.) The author, who has updated his book with a new introduction, shows how Mikhail Gorbachev succeeded in freeing his country from its Stalinist legacy but was unable to remain its leader. Mr. Gorbachev's political policies ironically strengthened his enemies, while his economic reforms failed to push far enough. Last year our reviewer, Marshall I. Goldman, described this book as an "excellent chronicle. . . . It is hard to find a contemporary drama that is more absorbing." For the former Soviet leader's own perspective, there is THE AUGUST COUP: The Truth and the Lessons (Harper Perennial, $10). Although our reviewer, Philip Taubman, found this memoir a bit wooden and self-serving, "it is hard to begrudge Mr. Gorbachev the chance to see himself as he once was," he said last year. Raisa Gorbachev gets her say in I HOPE, reminiscences and reflections translated by David Floyd (Harper Perennial, $10). Here the former Soviet First Lady proves herself "a woman of considerable intelligence," Jane Taubman said in The Book Review in 1991. "She was more than a bit player in bringing about the reforms that forever changed the course of Russian history."
TRAFFIC AND LAUGHTER, by Ted Mooney. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.) In this surreal novel, which begins in a slightly skewed contemporary Los Angeles, a female disk jockey and a South African actress become pawns -- along with the atomic bomb -- in an eccentric extortion plot to procure world peace. "This is new-wave literary joke making at its best -- and its most serious," our reviewer, Douglas Glover, said in 1990.
WOODY ALLEN: A Biography, by Eric Lax. (Vintage, $13.) Mr. Lax had full access -- or as full as anyone gets -- to Woody Allen, a film maker whose success with women appears oddly parallel to Cyrano de Bergerac's and who can make New York seem like a place worth escaping to instead of from. "What [Mr. Lax] gives us is Woody Allen as a personality whom we both like and dislike," Molly Haskell said here last year. "The moody maestro wouldn't want it any other way."
AFTER SHOCKS/NEAR ESCAPES, by Stephen Dobyns. (Penguin, $10.) Lucy Recabarren has seen her world literally come apart. A survivor of the enormous earthquake that rocked Chile in 1960, she looks back on its physical losses and emotional repercussions. Last year our reviewer, Ron Loewinsohn, found this novel "intelligently conceived and competently executed."
SIGNS OF THE TIMES: Deconstruction and the Fall of Paul de Man, by David Lehman. (Poseidon, $13.) Deconstruction, the literary theory that held that all meaning in language is essentially relative, shifting and undefinable, was ultimately undermined by the discovery of some very clear meanings in the writings of one of its proponents. In 1987, Paul de Man, a native of Belgium, a Yale professor and a leading deconstructionist who had died four years before, was exposed as the author of a large number of pro-Nazi articles in his youth. This book is a "valuably detailed if sometimes highly polemical account of the ensuing crisis," Malcolm Bradbury said in The Book Review last year.
BEYOND DESERVING, by Sandra Scofield. (Plume, $10.) Winner of an American Book Award, this novel is populated by characters who might have come out of a self-help book like "Smart Women, Foolish Choices." But the women of the Fisher clan, a southern Oregon family, actually prefer their men a little rough around the edges. " 'Beyond Deserving' pleasingly satirizes aspects of our therapeutic society," our reviewer, Rand Richards Cooper, said last year, calling this an "intelligent and observant novel."
THE LAST DETECTIVE, by Peter Lovesey. (Bantam, $4.99.) Mr. Lovesey, who traditionally mines the past for his mysteries, has made this one strictly contemporary, except, perhaps, for the rather Luddite inclinations of his English hero, Detective Superintendent Peter Diamond, who competes against modern forensic technology to find the murderer of a former soap-opera star. Last year our reviewer, Josh Rubins, admired this "bravura performance from a veteran showman."

GEOGRAPHIC: UNITED STATES (79%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (54%); NEW YORK, USA (79%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (79%);

SECTION: Section 7; Page 5; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Present at the Re-Creation

BYLINE: By Bernard Gwertzman; Bernard Gwertzman is the foreign editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:

RUSSIA TRANSFORMED: BREAKTHROUGH TO HOPE
Moscow, August 1991.
By James H. Billington.
202 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $19.95. 
 JAMES H. BILLINGTON, the Librarian of Congress, has spent his life studying, writing and teaching Russian history. In August 1991 he found himself in Moscow on routine library business. He had no way of knowing, of course, that midway through his two-week trip he would become a witness to a major turning point in Russian history -- the ineffectual effort by Communist Party, military and K.G.B. hard-liners to reverse the unmistakable trend toward the breakup of the Soviet Union and the dissolution of the Communist Party. The failed coup only accelerated those tendencies.
It was a remarkable time indeed for those in Moscow for the few days in August. Every writer dreams of what it would be like to be present at such a moment. This is particularly true of historians, whose professional careers are spent vicariously reading about the exploits of others. And Mr. Billington is very sympathetic when he says, "It was exhilarating for me, as a historian who had studied Russia for nearly half a century, to be present for events that I knew from the beginning would be historic." He notes that another American, the journalist and political activist John Reed, happened to be in Petrograd when the Bolsheviks carried out their successful takeover in 1917. But Mr. Billington acknowledges that unlike Reed, he did not get very close to any of the major players and took no photos and only a few notes. "Russia Transformed: Breakthrough to Hope," then, is not really a chronicle of the coup, although in its brevity it provides a useful review of the high points. Instead, Mr. Billington's book adds something of a different dimension to supplement the journalistic accounts on this anniversary.
The putsch, as Russians call it, was over quickly. It was announced with forboding on Moscow television in the early hours before people went to work on Monday, Aug. 19, and within 72 hours a shaky Mikhail S. Gorbachev was free from Crimean house arrest and back in Moscow. Unlike the Bolsheviks in 1917, who had no qualms about seizing power brutally, chasing Aleksandr Kerensky into exile and murdering the Czar and his family, the coup leaders had no stomach for violence. As a result, they allowed Boris N. Yeltsin, then the most popular politician in Moscow, to stand them down at his "White House," the headquarters of the Russian Government, which became the rallying point for democrats and all others who wanted to see an end to the old system.
For those who came together around Mr. Yeltsin, the triumph was unexpected, and therefore all the more spectacular. They, and most of Moscow, had assumed on Aug. 19 that the combined powers of the party, the army and the K.G.B. would insure a successful coup and an end to Mr. Gorbachev's experiments in political freedom and economic change, which were generally popular even if Mr. Gorbachev was not. Thus the victory over the coup was regarded by most Russians as a chudo, or miracle, and it took on almost a spiritual dimension, which Mr. Billington, an expert on Russian cultural history, documents very perceptively.
"When free television returned after 48 hours of junta control, the resistance was instantly mythologized in a series of beautiful documentaries that portrayed the struggle in the manner of the ancient chronicles -- the original, Christian literature of Russia -- as a pure struggle between good and evil, light and darkness," he writes. "Moscow was again belokamenny, the 'white-stoned' city of legend."
The trouble was, of course, that Mr. Gorbachev was no Ivan the Terrible or Peter the Great, at a time when the country was desperate for leadership. Mr. Gorbachev's popularity was low before the coup because of the perception that he was a bit of a windbag, with lots of talk and little action. Just as the leaders of the putsch were indecisive, Mr. Gorbachev in victory was equally Hamletlike. He first tried to preserve the Communist Party but then presided over its dissolution.
And after trying to keep the union together with halfhearted diplomatic efforts, he finally resigned as president on Dec. 25, 1991, acknowledging that the Soviet Union had collapsed, with each of the 15 former component republics claiming its own independence and national sovereignty. In turn, Mr. Yeltsin, who in August had been Mr. Gorbachev's savior, now rose to power as the head of the largest state. But from the heights of popularity, Mr. Yeltsin found himself within a year also being mocked for his failure to bring about a dramatic improvement in the Russian people's way of life.
Mr. Billington remains guardedly optimistic. He notes at the end that a year after the coup, in the summer of 1992, "cynicism was great, corruption was increasing, political conflict was in the open; and there was some nostalgia for the relative order and predictability of the Communist era. The near-term prognosis seemed ominous." Yet, he concludes, the Russians had survived their first winter without either internal social upheaval or outright conflict: "Russia's horizons seemed somehow to be widening even as its borders contracted. Russians had been released in August from the fear of power to discover the power of hope."

PUB-DATE: August 23, 1992

SECTION: Section 6; Page 23; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5167 words

HEADLINE: Tender Trap

BYLINE: By Bill Carter; Bill Carter covers television for The Times.

 BODY:
IN THE COLONNADE outside the Oval Office, Barbara Walters tests the white wrought-iron bench where she will sit to question the President of the United States.
The bench is not the most comfortable place to sit. But the Rose Garden is bathed in sunshine this summer morning, and Dorrance Smith, the assistant to the President for media affairs, thinks the interview will look sensational against that backdrop. 
 Walters sits with a stack of index cards in her lap, each card containing a question she intends to ask. She has already done the research -- most of it herself -- prepared the questions, supervised the publicity and approved the wardrobe, makeup and hair.
Softly la-ti-dah-ing an unidentifiable tune, Walters looks at herself on camera, analyzing the angles, the lighting and the sounds the rustling wind makes in her microphone. As always, she sits camera right, exposing her left side. ("After all this time," she says, "I know that's my better side.")
It is a Monday morning, five days from the broadcast of her ABC news-magazine program, "20/20." The breezy colonnade is the site of the latest episode in the remarkably enduring television institution known as the Barbara Walters Interview.
If anything, the institution has only grown in importance in recent years, fed by ever intensifying competition from other network news magazines and syndicated talk shows. The range of what people are willing to say on television has changed. Walters, who has always sought to establish a personal intimacy with her interview subjects, has unquestionably been the chief agent of the change that has brought to prominence other probers of the personal, from Phil Donahue to Oprah Winfrey.
Though some critics continue to find her unforgivably irritating, and have never stopped complaining that her questions are too soft, her approach too chummy, the 60-year-old Walters has survived an unmatched run of 30 years as the most recognizable woman in network news. Despite the competition and the critics, she remains the interviewer of record for American television.
In the past year, Walters has had one of her strongest runs of big interviews. She has landed exclusive sessions with the former hostage Terry Waite; with the tennis star Arthur Ashe immediately after his revelation that he has AIDS; with the so-called suicide doctor Jack Kevorkian. At a time when politics has become primary programming on television, she has talked with Boris Yeltsin, and with Ross Perot twice -- as he was dipping a toe in and then withdrawing abruptly from the Presidential race.
The White House, extremely careful about its media opportunities, chose Walters as the vehicle for the President's first prime-time interview during the campaign. Smith, who knows television -- and Walters -- well from his days at ABC News, where he was executive producer of "Nightline," says: "We picked Barbara because she's a fair interview. She knows what a prime-time interview is." As Smith hovers, Walters discreetly turns over her stack of index cards -- just in case he might try to take a peek.
The interview with the President and Mrs. Bush is cordial, but not overly chummy. Walters presses the President on his record, and the dissatisfaction of the voters. When she mentions the stories of Perot's "investigating" Bush's sons, the President bristles visibly and answers angrily. His reaction will receive national coverage. That will help spark intensified verbal attacks from both campaigns that wind up diminishing Perot's standing in the opinion polls -- and, apparently, his stomach for major-league politics.
Afterwards, Walters declares herself pleased with the interview. To mark the occasion, the ABC crew assembles to pose with the Bushes for a photograph on the Rose Garden steps. Before leaving, Walters asks the President to autograph one of her index cards.
IN EVERY INTERVIEW, Barbara Walters sits forward in her chair, holding a stack of index cards in her lap, glancing at them quickly, unobtrusively. The rest of the time she leans toward her subject, her eyes boring in, almost squinting with intensity. But her facial expression is benign, her body language unthreatening. The unspoken message behind her gaze is: "I understand; I care; I'm here for you."
Even when her questions seem bland or unchallenging -- her critics would call them cloying -- the people she interviews often feel as though she hasgot way below skin level. Anthony Hopkins, who appeared on her pre-Oscar celebrity interview special in March, found the effect unnerving at first. "The interview was terribly intimate," he said.
Intimacy is expressly what Walters is going for. She gets to people on camera with that look and some deceptively simple questions. "What was the best time for you? The worst time?"
Walters's questions make some people cringe. Part of this has to do with who she is: the journalist as celebrity; the interviewer who rode a speedboat with Don Johnson, who mamboed with Patrick Swayze, the woman who urged Jimmy Carter to "be good to us" and to "be wise with us."
Still, even her most adamant critics would find it hard to dispute her success. Inside an ABC news division top-heavy with stars -- Peter Jennings, Ted Koppel, Diane Sawyer -- Walters is the highest-paid, making an estimated $3 million to $4 million a year in salary. In truth, she is doing even better than that, after recently selling off to ABC the rights to her library of celebrity specials.
ABC is not complaining about a dime. With both "20/20" and the celebrity specials significant moneymakers for the network, Walters probably generates more profits than any other broadcast journalist. And yet, rather stunningly, ABC News almost let its chief rainmaker slip out the door last year. Walters was seriously wooed by CBS. The deal, as Walters describes it, involved "much more money," her own prime-time magazine program, the best producers and correspondents CBS had and a guaranteed time slot: 10 P.M. Monday, after CBS's powerhouse comedies. (The time period was given to "Northern Exposure," which this year became the biggest dramatic hit on television.)
Unaccountably, ABC had simply allowed its exclusive renegotiation period with Walters to lapse.
For Walters, always intensely conscious of her professional standing, an indication that she may not have been an urgent priority for her bosses is not easily shrugged off. "My problems weren't money but sometimes feeling less than part of the team," she says. "I felt I was being neglected in news. I was bringing in all this money, and I was sort of taken for granted."
The CBS deal would have had a downside, however. It would have meant jumping networks for the second time in her career, something that would have guaranteed the kind of relentless scrutiny that accompanied her move to ABC from NBC in 1976. Then, her precedent-setting, $1-million-a-year salary -- to be both anchor of ABC's evening news and do her own specials -- left her open to a fusillade of slams as the symbol of television news selling out to entertainment values.
At the outset, the move to ABC turned into the biggest fiasco of Walters's career. Her teaming with the incumbent anchor, Harry Reasoner, descended quickly into overt hostility. Eventually, the new ABC News president, Roone Arledge, installed a new anchor threesome, reassigning Walters to do special interviews. That project wound up producing Walters's own version of shuttle diplomacy in the late 1970's with her interviews of Menachem Begin and Anwar Sadat. Despite those successes, Walters says, "I'm still kind of shell-shocked from 15 years ago."
Late last year, she finally signed on for five more years at ABC, partly out of loyalty to Arledge, mostly because she decided the CBS offer, great as it was, wasn't worth the changes it would mean in her life. "If I had been thinking only of money," Walters says, "I would do a syndicated talk show, because I'm one of the few who could cross over into that. And then I would make $75 million a year. I would make Oprah money."
ON ANOTHER MONDAY MORNING this year, Barbara Walters is getting set up for Desiree Washington, the young woman whom the heavyweight boxer Mike Tyson had been convicted of raping. Representative of the latest source of ratings-generating interviews -- the unexpected headline-maker -- Washington has chosen Walters and "20/20" as the one forum in which to tell her side of the story.
In the days since hearing she had landed Washington for this exclusive interview, Walters worried that the young woman might get cold feet -- or else, and worse, might agree to do an interview with another prominent television questioner first.
"For all I know," Walters fretted the night before the interview, "she could be sitting down with Ed Bradley right now." Bradley, the "60 Minutes" correspondent, had scored one of the bigger coups in the can-you-top-this sweepstakes among the network news-magazine programs: he had landed the first television interview with Anita Hill.
That had been preceded by another interview Walters had missed, with Patricia Bowman, the woman who accused William Kennedy Smith of rape. Diane Sawyer, of the other ABC news magazine, "Prime Time Live," got that one.
"I had gone after Anita Hill and so had Diane and everybody else," Walters says. "I didn't eat my heart out. I knew that Ed Bradley could offer things I could not offer. And Diane had also been turned down."
It would be difficult, of course, to find an interview scorecard that compares with that of Barbara Walters. The list of one-on-one interviews she has conducted reads like the index of a late 20th-century history book: Eisenhower, Nixon, Johnson, Begin, Sadat, Carter, Castro, the Shah, Reagan, Qaddafi, Arafat, Thatcher, Bush, Yeltsin. It would be far easier to list the important world leaders of the past 30 years whom Walters hasn't talked to: among them Gorbachev, Mandela, Ho Chi Minh, Mao.
But as news programs have spread all over network television, the chase for the big interview has clearly become frenzied -- even for the leader of the pack. "One of the things now in television that makes it not as much fun is the enormous competition," Walters says, "and the attitude out there that if you don't get it, somehow you've failed. And the biggest competition that we have is from 'Prime Time,' which is almost the identical program to ours. Diane is my colleague and we like each other very much. But we are probably more competitive than anybody. Diane and I have a kind of feeling that if we don't get the interview, we want the other one to get it, rather than '60 Minutes.' But having said that, I mean, when Diane got the interview with Patricia Bowman, it was as if I'd failed."
So the Desiree Washington interview, though newsworthy on its own, is also clearly a counterpunch. As Walters candidly admits, "I do feel a little grateful she's doing the interview with me."
Going into the interview, Walters expects to feel empathy for Washington, but says that has nothing to do with gratitude. It is simply what almost always happens when she immerses herself through her research in all the intimate details of a person's life. "You really feel you know the person," Walters says of the process.
In Washington's case, Walters says she expects to feel even more. "This girl is barely 18," Walters says, "and I do feel maternal toward her. I can think of my own daughter, who could easily be in this position." Walters's daughter, Jacqueline, now 24, is a frequent reference point in her mother's conversation.
More than anything else, what distinguishes a Barbara Walters interview, whether from her traditional genres -- leaders of the world stage and the Hollywood screen -- or the new category of news makers with a story to tell, is that effort to get at the essence of who a person is, more than simply what he or she may think or have to say.
As one of her regular "20/ 20" producers, Ene Riisna, puts it, "She makes an interview like a play; she always goes for the emotional revelation."
When Washington arrives at the Pierre Hotel suite ABC has set up for the interview, it is instantly obvious that she is even more skittish than Walters anticipated. She has come alone; no lawyers, no parents. As she sits for a microphone test, surrounded by technicians and production assistants, the slightly built, softly pretty young woman looks like a fawn in the middle of a crowded interstate.
Walters immediately senses the danger. She compliments Washington on her clothes, tells her how glamorous she's going to look on camera. But Washington is agitated, and continually pages through a notebook where she has written down what she wants to say.
Nothing could be worse, as far as Walters is concerned. A nervous interview that sounds rehearsed is a disaster. She tells Washington to put away the notes. "Don't worry," Walters says, "I'll help you."
Still, as the crew is set to begin, Washington looks one breath from panic. "Can we practice first?" she asks Walters. It is a suggestion Walters resists, because preinterviewing leads to stilted answers. Walters continues to stroke and soothe Washington verbally, saying, "You've already gone through the most important test of your life, so what does this matter?"
A few seconds later, the cameras roll and the formal interview begins, almost without Desiree Washington realizing it. And it flows; it has the rhythms Walters seeks. As the interview ends, Washington and Walters stand to remove their microphones. Washington looks totally drained. Walters, as if in slow motion, reaches out her arms, puts them around the young woman's shoulders and gives her a hug.
BARBARA WALTERS'S apartment occupies a full floor on Fifth Avenue overlooking the park. It is densely decorated with art and furniture. "I moved here when I got married," Walters says, referring to her third marriage, to the television executive Merv Adelson, whom she is divorcing. "My husband wanted a larger apartment. So he's gone, but the apartment stayed."
Much of the crew who worked on the Desiree Washington interview that morning has assembled in the main working room of the apartment, the library. The entire room is blood-red: walls, bookshelves, floor-to-ceiling cabinet doors. In the middle of the room are two enormous exercise machines, a Stair Master and a treadmill. A giant stuffed tiger sits across the bars of the treadmill, looking like a permanent occupant.
Walters, in slacks and a comfortable-looking purple sweater, is conducting the "paper edit" on the transcript of the Washington interview, the first step before the actual video is edited. (Typically, an hourlong interview will end up as about 22 minutes on the air.) Martin Clancy, the producer, sits next to Walters on a couch. Spread around on the floor are the assistant producers and researchers. The room is a din of conflicting voices. Walters's elderly poodle enters periodically and yaps. The two live-in employees who have been with her for years wander through, bringing cookies and tea, answering phones.
As she works, Walters watches the big-screen television across the room, waiting for a "20/20" promo. "In the past couple of years, the promos have all gone to 'Prime Time,' " Walters says matter-of-factly. "The feeling was they were in chaos."
For the Washington interview, however, Walters wants a big promotional push. At the commercial break, she turns up the sound to hear the promo. Everybody in the room hates it. The consensus is that the promo fails to communicate the obvious strengths of the interview.
Walters picks up the phone and calls the executive producer of "20/20," Victor Neufeld. " 'Prime Time' 's promo tonight was wonderful," she says. "No one is going to watch us."
She then volunteers to work on a new promo in the morning. Watching her in action, Clancy shakes his head and laughs. "The energy level is simply amazing," he says.
After the editing session ends, Walters conducts a brief tour of some of her favorite mementos -- two hallway walls covered with drawings and photographs.
"This is my radical wall," she says proudly, pointing to rows of photos of Castro, Sadat, Begin, Qaddafi, Arafat. She points to the inscription from Arafat, "Revolution until victory," and Castro: "As a remembrance of the most difficult interview that I have had in all the days of my life."
In another section, she points to a group shot. "This is the first group that went to China with Nixon." Walters scans the notable faces in the crowd. "There's Nixon. There's Ron Ziegler. Here I am, pushy cookie." She is up close to Nixon in the middle. "And way over here," she says, tracing her finger to the opposite side of the crowd shot, "that's Diane. She was an assistant press secretary. There were only two women on the trip who were reporters, Helen Thomas and me."
THE SUNSHINE IS garishly bright outside a secluded bungalow deep within the verdant grounds of the Beverly Hills Hotel. Inside, Barbara Walters sits thumbing through her index cards, getting ready for Tom Cruise. "I've restructured the Scientology questions," she says.
Walters has been debating about how much to make of Cruise's membership in the much-debunked Church of Scientology. "I know I've got to ask him about it. But I also know this show will be on Academy Award night and that the audience will find Scientology rather boring."
For Walters this is not going to be a tough call, though she realizes it opens her to more criticism about preferring soft personal information to harder news. Walters's top priority is what prime-time television viewers -- not other news reporters -- want to hear. "A long time ago I decided I couldn't do interviews to please the editors of The New York Times," she says.
In place of debating the merits of Scientology, Walters will emphasize Cruise's childhood. "I have a lot about his father abandoning the family." She pauses and says, sotto voce, "I like difficult childhoods."
All around her there is activity again among the troupe that constitutes the specials unit: Bill Geddie, the executive producer; his production team; Walters's friend Sally Safir, who doubles as fashion consultant; Walters's personal assistants, Monica Caulfield and Moira McCann. Walters's hair stylist, Bryant Renfroe, is spraying and arranging her bangs; her makeup artist, Sajata, who goes by one name only, is dabbing her gently.
After what Geddie calls a long pursuit, Tom Cruise has consented to sit for the interview many Hollywood stars now consider a defining moment in their careers. "It is definitely the American interview you do when you have made it in the movies," Anthony Hopkins says.
Pat Kingsley, Cruise's powerhouse publicity woman, who has delivered about a dozen stars to Walters's side, says: "It's Barbara Walters. This is a woman who has interviewed heads of state, presidents and kings. She's the only one who does that. It's major league."
Beyond that, Walters has maintained good relations with the Hollywood crowd by having a reputation for never giving stars a hard time. "I don't want to hurt them and they know that," Walters says. She makes a definite distinction between how she conducts a celebrity interview and how she conducts a news interview. She won't do a movie star on "20/20."
Still, as Kingsley puts it: "It's not a hard-hitting interview. That would be too risky for the stars. But they are not totally softball questions either. She somehow makes people feel comfortable in a rather awkward situation."
For Cruise, Walters stays mostly with the personal side: his childhood, his failed marriage to the actress Mimi Rogers, his current marriage to the actress Nicole Kidman. She does not press him hard about Scientology. She asks him about it. He answers. She moves on.
Cruise relaxes in the interview, even laughs a lot. In the limousine after the interview, Walters is up, thrilled with how the day has gone. "I liked him enormously," she says. "And he was happy. I like that. I don't want them to go away discouraged."
ONE WEEK WHEN Walters was working on both "Nightline" and "20/20," she said, "I have to laugh because I wonder what all the people who hate me are going to watch this week."
Some people truly detest Barbara Walters. They ridicule the distinctions she makes between celebrities and news figures, saying all her interviews are equally gushy. They point to her own rich and famous life style, her association with powerful friends, and contend such access to power can only compromise a journalist.
Critics cite what they view as an unfailing tendency to fawn on those in power, especially those who may have been targets of a hostile press, as she herself has been. A centerpiece of her interview with Vice President Dan Quayle, for example, was a number of questions about how tough the media and the late-night comedians had been on him and the impact of all the pillorying on his family.
One producer who has worked with her frequently says, "She has a lot of people who are afraid of her." This producer claims Walters is a master at manipulating people. "She's a chameleon," the producer says, adding that she isn't as successful in interviews as her supporters believe her to be. "She's good at getting the interview coup. She always goes for the gotcha question, the one that reveals the person. She doesn't follow up."
Even as far back as her days on the "Today" show, according to another producer, Walters was susceptible to the allure of power. "Barbara has a very strong respect for power and position," the producer Stuart Schulberg was quoted as saying in a 1974 Newsweek profile. "She will not ask the ultimate jugular question."
Walters has heard every sort of criticism for years, of course, but she has not changed her style much in response to it. In the first of her Ross Perot interviews this year, Walters risked the wrath of the hard-news crowd by spending half her time with Margot Perot. But Mrs. Perot had never been interviewed on television, and Walters believed that the similarities and differences among the three wives of the potential candidates was a matter of real viewer interest.
CBS president Howard Stringer, who tried to hire her away last year, says it's pointless to compare Walters with someone with a more bellicose style, like Mike Wallace of "60 Minutes." "Barbara is an idiosyncratic interviewer," Stringer says. "That's part of what makes her effective." The chief idiosyncrasy: Walters questions people but doesn't challenge them. She will probe, she will press; she will not prosecute.
Walters herself emphatically repudiates charges that she's too soft, maintaining, "I don't do silly, giddy interviews." She thinks it simply makes sense for her to spend more time finding out whether Mrs. Perot advises her husband and less time pressing Perot on his plan to cut the deficit. "You have to know when the audience's eyes are going to glaze over," she says.
As for the other consistent criticism of her, her willingness to interview a celebrity one day and a head of state the next, she argues that journalists all over television do both sorts of stories. "I did it all the time on the 'Today' show, when you had the news maker at 7:30 and the celebrity at 8:30 and nobody said a thing."
Walters ruefully remembers her first days at ABC, when she was excoriated by some of her television news colleagues for her exhortation to the Carters to be good and wise. "I do think the statute of limitations should have run out on that one by now," Walters says. "If I had it to do over, I probably wouldn't have said it."
Then there was the infamous Katharine Hepburn tree question. The truth about that one, Walters says, is that Hepburn instigated it by describing herself as an old tree. Walters insists she never said, "If you could be any kind of tree, what kind would you be?" With a real edge in her voice, she dismisses the tree episode as apocryphal. "It's Baba Wawa stuff," Walters says, referring to the apparently still-painful memory of the "Saturday Night Live" parody of her performed by Gilda Radner. "Back then everybody was gunning for me.
"They criticized me for everything at the beginning," Walters recalls. "My salary, the way I pronounce my R's. Who is this terrible person on with this serious newsman, Harry Reasoner? I felt very wounded. I had a mother, a father, a retarded sister and a daughter I was supporting. And my career was finished. I was drowning. I was not only drowning, I was reading every day about people who were happy to put my head under the water. I remember thinking, I should really go to a psychiatrist to work this out. And then I thought: What is there to work out? I'm failing. I made a mistake. What's he going to say to me?"
Walters acknowledges that she still feels the sting of negative comments. After the Perot interview, she was "tremendously offended" when a reporter in this newspaper identified her as "celebrity questioner Barbara Walters." But overall, she says, the critics in the news media are kinder now. "They say, 'Gee, you know, she works hard. It's O.K.' "
Walters attributes her lingering sense of insecurity to growing up with the unpredictability of her father's career as a nightclub owner. That had brought her at an early age into the world of show business and introduced her to a lavish life style. ("I joke and say there isn't a penthouse in New York I haven't lived in.") But after her father, overextended, lost his nightclubs, she was forced into a position of having to support her family. That early push to make it on her own has clearly fueled the unstinting, full-speed-ahead drive that has kept her where she is for so long.
Current producers and co-workers have virtually nothing negative to say about her. Many assert that working with Walters was the best professional experience of their careers. Even the producer who came to dislike her intensely, who charges that "the only thing she values is the image of herself on television," admits: "She is not a prima donna. She is the hardest working woman I have ever known. That's how she's gotten where she's gotten."
As for being too cozy with the elite people she interviews, Walters contends that social connections never interfere with her work. When she talks about how she sets up an interview, the story often includes a detail like: "I ran into Martina in Aspen on New Year's Eve." But that meeting resulted in a news-making interview with the tennis star Martina Navratilova that made "20/ 20" the highest-rated program in television that week.
Walters's friends include Beverly Sills, the agent Mort Janklow and the financier Felix Rohatyn. She dates prominent, powerful men. In recent months she has been seeing a lot of Senator John Warner of Virginia, the former husband of Elizabeth Taylor. (Walters had interviewed the Senator and the actress together in 1977 and, in this instance anyway, appears to have violated her own policy of never dating men she has interviewed.)
For all of Walters's financial success, she knows that as long as she remains at a network, she will never make the kind of money available to stars like Oprah Winfrey and Phil Donahue in syndication. Yet she refuses to look down her nose at her daytime counterparts. From Walters's point of view, what Oprah and Phil do is not all that different from what she does, even if they occasionally have to concoct a program out of thin women who love fat men and mothers who date their daughters' boyfriends.
"I could do that stuff," Walters says. "We in news are so pure. But the audience doesn't care. They think what Oprah does is news. The audience can't tell the difference."
WHEN Barbara Walters has trouble getting someone to discuss a sensitive subject, she often resorts to a question like: "What is the greatest misconception about you?"
And yet, when asked that question herself, she hesitates. First, she says, she's really very funny in person. Finally, she concludes: "I'm really rather shy."
At times her answers are a bit studied, but often they reveal a surprising vulnerability. That comes through most of all when she's talking about her daughter, Jacqueline. Walters doesn't get to see her often. The adopted daughter of Walters and her second husband, the late theatrical producer Lee Guber, Jacqueline now lives in the Pacific Northwest.
When Walters talks of the price she has paid to be where she is, she invariably invokes Jacqueline. In private moments and even in public speeches, she often tells the same story about the time the young Jacqueline said, "Mummy doesn't drive; Mummy doesn't play games; Mummy burns the meat loaf; all Mummy can do is television."
One longtime associate confirms the clear implication of Walters's quote, that it has been very hard at times for Jacqueline to be Barbara Walters's daughter. If Barbara Walters interviewed herself, she would no doubt focus heavily on the price she has paid in her personal life for her success.
Still, she is unabashedly proud at having done so much in television. "There are not too many people who've been working at this as long as I have and at the level I have -- and are still going," she says in a very soft voice.
Colleagues like Victor Neufeld and Ene Riisna frequently use the word "unrelenting" about her. When Walters says, as she often does these days, "I tell myself that I'm at the point in my life and my career where I have to relax a little," it gets a laugh of disbelief from producer Martin Clancy. One former producer says, "Barbara will die with the red light on."
And yet, Walters maintains, she has changed. She points to the interview with Raisa Gorbachev this spring, which had been promised to her, but which went, through some Russian misunderstanding of American television deadlines, to Maria Shriver on NBC. "Five years ago, I would have said, But, my God, she promised me. I'd get on a plane to Moscow and it would have been on the air that night. But now I'm not going to get on a plane to Moscow." Indeed, she says, the real reason she didn't go to CBS was, "I don't want to climb any more mountains."
But what if there were somebody really interesting at the top? What if she could land, say, Saddam Hussein? "I'd go anywhere for Saddam Hussien," she says immediately. Or Castro, again? "I would leave tomorrow to do Fidel Castro." Or, on the day after the Los Angeles riots last spring, Rodney King? "I'd go today."
"I don't want to tell you that if there was a hot news interview, I wouldn't go in a second," Walters explains. "The difference is if I don't get it, I don't sit up at night.
Walters used to say that she had stopped auditioning. But she really hasn't, she admits. "When I'm on 'Nightline,' I'm probably auditioning for ABC News, saying: 'See, I can do this kind of thing too. Just don't think because I do Anthony Hopkins that I can't do the unemployed. Take me seriously.' If I'm auditioning for anything, it's for them to take me seriously."
