PUB-DATE: August 23, 1992

SECTION: Section 6; Page 41; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4091 words

HEADLINE: House Revolutionary

BYLINE: By Adam Clymer; Adam Clymer is the chief Congressional correspondent of The New York Times.

 BODY:
A ROOM FULL OF THREE DOZEN CLEAN-CUT COLLEGE Juniors who are spending their summer as volunteers at the Republican National Committee might seem like an unlikely place to recruit revolutionaries. Not to Newt Gingrich.
The House Republican whip rushed over to the Capitol Hill Club, a Republican watering hole, one afternoon last month between critical meetings on enterprise zone bills and speeches assailing Democrats. In a 20-minute break from his war on Congress, he told them the welfare state was strangling their dreams. "We will not make it through your lifetime without radical change," he said. "You're either going to force the changes, or your generation is going to suffer a long, steady decline in the quality of life. 
 "I am essentially a revolutionary," he told them. And like any good revolutionary, he identified enemies: bureaucrats who run city governments for their own comfort and not the public's; senior faculty members out of touch with reality, and, above all, the Democrats. Occasionally, he said, virtuous Democrats do come to Congress, but they are quickly told by their leaders: "If you ever want to get on a decent committee, you better learn to sell out." To whom? To the Democrats' basic elements, "a coalition of big-city machines, trial lawyers, union leaders, left-wing activists and political incumbents."
Although Gingrich tends to say so many words so fast that his high voice gets chirpy, like a tape recorder on fast-forward, the volunteers were captivated. They smiled, asked a few respectful questions and applauded as he exhorted them: "Real revolutions are made by the young. They are made by the energetic. They are made by the risk-takers." Then he dashed back to vote against a Democratic bid to kill Vice President Dan Quayle's White House Council on Competitiveness.
Newton Leroy Gingrich, at age 49, is no longer young, but he is an energetic risk-taker. He leads one of the least-noticed but potentially most far-reaching campaigns of this bizarre political year. Gingrich is trying to use voters' anger at government to end 38 years of Democratic control of the House. Outright Republican control would require winning 52 more seats, an awesome electoral swing, but picking up an attainable 30 or so would enable Republicans to dominate the House in alliance with conservative Democrats. The Republicans now hold 166 seats out of 435. Gingrich says the odds are "better than even that we will be above 200 for the first time since 1956. The odds are very, very good."
Gingrich pursues that goal of Republican control in the well of the House, taunting Democrats as corrupt and despotic. He works at it in Capitol back rooms, hammering out policy statements so that Republicans can argue they stand for change. He nourishes it in the office of his political action committee, Gopac, with telephone hookups that enable dozens of Republican challengers around the country to tie their strategies to his. And he travels the country raising money for Republicans by preaching a gospel of lower taxes as the route to economic growth and more prisons and longer sentences as the path to domestic order.
Largely because of his efforts, the Republican campaign for House seats is more organized than it has been in years, unlike the uncertain Bush campaign. For months, Gingrich has argued openly that the President needed to do more to define his campaign goals, to call for radical change, to sound more like, well, like Gingrich. Relations with the White House have been bumpy as a result.
Yet for all the interest Gingrich claims to have in public policy issues like medical care or better schools, in his 14 years in the House he has spent most of his energy going after one colleague after another on ethical grounds. He says his motives were not partisan, but all but one of his targets have been Democrats. His biggest scalp was Jim Wright's; he brought down the Speaker of the House in 1989, accusing him of circumventing the rules by accepting payoffs and selling a pseudo-book.
He portrays himself as forced by knowledge of evil he has acquired to pursue such charges or become an accomplice. "I don't think I'm a Savanarola," the Baptist lawmaker said in an interview in May in his PAC office. "I don't think I have any great interest in running around and finding sin." But he plays very rough. He insists that one of his own aides who worked against Wright was falsely accused of spreading the rumor in 1989 that incoming Speaker Thomas S. Foley was a homosexual. The reporter who accused her, Lars-Erik Nelson of The Daily News, insists that his article was accurate and says Gingrich sent a letter to his editor, on Congressional stationery, demanding he be fired. Nor does he confine his attacks to colleagues who can fight back. He outraged Foley and many Republicans with a charge they thought far-fetched by saying a Foley aide might have participated in a coverup of corruption in the House post office.
His most strenuous campaign has been on the House bank, coaching and encouraging a group of seven Republican freshmen who made a national scandal out of a peculiar, terribly run, financial institution in which some members' deposits covered their colleagues' sometimes spectacular overdrafts. No taxpayers' money was involved, though Gingrich said the practices reflected "systemic, institutional corruption." But the growing scandal became political dynamite through a combination of Republican attacks, the inability of Speaker Foley to sense political danger and insistent newspaper and radio talk-show arguments that the dubious checks symbolized how remote Congress was from real life. That argument, however distant from the hard work, education and honesty that actually characterizes Congress today, took hold in an environment in which nothing is getting done about health care or schools or crime.
Gingrich argues that Foley's inability to recognize a "tidal wave" of public opinion caused the damage. But a tidal wave is a natural phenomenon; this was more like a forest fire, and Gingrich was there when it started, with gasoline.
His hairsbreadth victory in a July 22 Georgia Republican primary is both the best evidence of his claim to be a revolutionary, ready to take great risks, and of the potency of the enmity he has unleashed. His own 22 overdrafts, including a $9,463 check to the Internal Revenue Service, were the heaviest weapons against him in an anti-incumbent campaign waged by an underfinanced former state senator. After lavishing $1.1 million on the race, Gingrich survived, by 980 votes, and the district is so Republican that he seems a shoo-in in November. If anti-incumbency campaigns like the one waged against him defeat enough Democrats, he may someday achieve his ambition of becoming Speaker of the House. It is a goal he has nourished since his teens, when his stepfather, a combat infantryman, was transferred from Germany to Fort Benning and a bookish Newt entered politics by running a successful high-school student council campaign.
But as his own close call demonstrated, incumbent Republicans are at risk, too. The man he calls "my closest friend in the House," Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, announced plans to retire after disclosures of 125 overdrafts. Gingrich sounds pained about Weber's decision, though Weber says Gingrich has never told him of his sorrow. "He has no desire to do me any political harm," Weber observes, and adds, "Newt's sense of the cause that he's pursuing outweighs all other causes in his mind."
REPUBLICANS OFTEN follow Gingrich out of frustration with Democratic rule. As Representative Henry J. Hyde, an Illinois Republican and hardly one of Gingrich's leading supporters, argues, House Republicans find themselves in a "legislative ghetto" where they are barely tolerated. "That can be infuriating," he says. "Even a bunny rabbit, when cornered, will fight back."
Gingrich has prodded his traditionally more accommodating boss, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the minority leader, to complain about such indignities as the fact that Democrats hog the committee staff jobs, with an average of 5.3 staffers compared with 2.6 for each Republican, and regularly write floor procedures to keep the Republicans from even offering amendments.
The fractious Democrats need those advantages, because their rank and file appears to want an organizational free lunch, complaining of weak leadership but unable to follow with any discipline. Thus, the Democrats are often barely able to find a consensus in their own party, and they don't dare risk letting a skillfully drawn amendment shatter it. Representative Frank D. Riggs of California, one of Gingrich's noisy freshmen, says he came to Congress to deal with housing and education and got into reform issues only after finding that "the legislative process is effectively closed to constructive minority input."
In all this, the House is quite different from the Senate. There, nothing gets done without bipartisan cooperation, whether it is by Robert J. Dole breaking a logjam on unemployment compensation or John C. Danforth working with Edward M. Kennedy and overcoming the Bush Administration's opposition to a civil rights bill. The Senate's rules and, even more, its traditions dictate respect for the minority. The best lawmakers there, like Kennedy and Dole and Lloyd Bentsen, know how to find allies across party lines.
But in the House, the Democrats seem oblivious to G.O.P. unhappiness. It is Gingrich who makes that cauldron of irritability boil over. As Norman Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute says, "Newt and a handful of allies can take a polarized situation and make it 10 times worse."
AS BEFITS A Revolutionary, Gingrich cuts a rumpled figure as he races to keep appointments and catch planes. He dresses like the assistant professor he once was, carrying more books and papers than conveniently fit under his arm. His distinctive helmet of gray hair provides a low-maintenance signature; it's cut these days at Great Clips of Marietta, Ga., and dries naturally after his morning shower. His airplane reading tends to be heavy stuff: "Lincoln and the Radicals" by T. Harry Williams, "The Conservative Party From Peel to Churchill" by Robert Blake.
On the road, he stops to call his wife, Marianne, several times a day. If he finds the time, he visits local zoos. (He used speaking fees that exceeded what House rules allowed him to help the Atlanta zoo buy two baby rhinoceroses, Bo and Rosie, who have delighted his nieces, Susan and Emmy.)
He has two married daughters from his first marriage, to his high-school math teacher whom he followed after graduation to Emory University and wed. They were divorced soon after he got to Congress, with her campaign help. He married Marianne, an urban planner whom he met on a political trip to Ohio, in 1981. They live quietly in a town house in Marietta; they have a one-bedroom apartment on Capitol Hill.
The family has been little in the public eye, but last month one of the daughters, Kathy Gingrich Lubbers, made news with an abortion-rights appeal. Gingrich firmly opposes abortion and does not quarrel with his party's staunch stand against it, but Lubbers came to Washington from her home in Greensboro, N.C., where she is opening a coffee-bean roasting company, to tell a news conference sponsored by the National Republican Coalition for Choice: "If the Republican Party is to appeal to young people in general and specifically to women, we must throw off the stranglehold that the anti-choice movement has on the apparatus of the party."
She said that her father had never tried to silence her and that "our family is big enough to encompass both sides of this issue." For his part, Gingrich said, "Both my family and my party are strong enough to have healthy, spirited debates."
Gingrich came to the House from the campus of West Georgia College, where he taught history, environmental studies and a course on the future. He won his first election in 1978, on his third try, at age 35. In his speeches, he praises the college for a program it started to encourage third-graders to read by paying them $2 for every book they read and explained to an adult. He says the program shows children that reading is profitable and that adults care about it, lessons he says billions in Federal aid have never taught. He does not say that he financed the program for its first few years, from excess speaking fees.
BUT THE Gingrich revolution is not about endowing zoos, or even reading programs. This is how he defined it in a speech he gave in the House on Jan. 3; the chamber was all but empty, but he was facing the C-Span camera and its dedicated following of a couple of hundred thousand Congress addicts, an audience he has played to with after-session speeches since he arrived:
"Taking the streets back from violent crime and drugs, so local TV news is no longer a death watch, would be a revolution in every major American city. Replacing welfare with workfare and ending a process by which teen-age mothers have children outside marriage with ignorant, irresponsible male children who have sex but are not fathers would be a revolution. Having schools that are disciplined, require homework and beat the Japanese in math and science would be a revolution. Replacing the most expensive, red tape-ridden litigious health-care system in the world with a revitalized, health-oriented private system we can afford, and that would be available to everyone, would be a revolution. Having government bureaucracies that are lean, efficient, courteous and customer-service oriented would be a revolution. Having a tax code that favored work, savings and investment, that helped create more and better jobs, greater productivity and higher take-home pay to make us the fastest growing industrial economy in the world would be a revolution."
Everything on that list, except probably teen-age pregnancy, is something the Federal Government might be able to do something about. Ideas of this sort were Gingrich's passion in his first few years in Congress. With Vin Weber, he founded the Conservative Opportunity Society, and he performed for the C-Span audience, even if he didn't know anyone out there who was watching except some junior Reagan White House staffers.
That sort of follow-through and hard work have not been much in evidence lately. An 11-month effort to write a health-care bill that emphasizes private insurance and individual efforts to cut costs is about the only recent effort in the domain of ideas that he has been a part of. He has taken no action at all on the one concrete promise in his Jan. 3 speech, a commitment to find money and land for prisons so that violent offenders can be kept locked up and not turned loose because of overcrowding. Gingrich asserts he would rather work on ideas and win elections on them. But, he said in an interview in his Gopac office -- in a bland office building near the Capitol where aides prepared for that night's hookup with challengers -- building a consensus on ideas "is a backbreaking, slow, difficult process."
Nor does he think an all-out effort to spell out revolutionary ideas would help Republicans right away with the public. Such efforts, he says, would not get press attention. "It is much easier to communicate, in the current generation of news media, about scandal than about substance," he says. Moreover, conservative ideas have not been much use to House Republicans lately. After winning 192 seats with Ronald Reagan in 1980, a dozen years of supporting two of the most conservative Administrations in history have not led to further gains. Indeed, the Republicans have never won more than 182 seats since. Today's 166 leave them 52 short of a majority, only 7 ahead of where they were the morning of Reagan's election.
No one on Capitol Hill doubts that November's elections will produce more House Republicans. Reapportionment following the census has shifted seats to Republican parts of the country. The subsequent process of drawing the new district maps has helped the G.O.P., too, as Republican appointments to the Federal courts produced rulings at least neutral and sometimes friendly to Republicans when legislatures and governors could not agree.
But there is more to this year's G.O.P. hopes for the House. Active recruiting by the National Republican Congressional Committee and by Gingrich's Gopac has produced 941 Republican hopefuls, half again as many as sought nominations two years ago. Gopac's most important effort now is to find them money, not by giving it to them directly but by finding donors. In direct gifts, it can lawfully give only $10,000 to each candidate. But there is no limit to how much it can steer their way. Its goal is finding 100 donors, or people promising to raise $1,000, for each of 170 nonincumbent Republicans.
That goal will not be reached. Political money is short this year. But because of Gopac, quite a few Republican challengers will get more money than they otherwise would have. Indeed, a Federal Election Commission report this month showed that 208 Republican hopefuls had raised $50,000 by June 30, up from 114 two years ago. One who wasn't there yet, Steve Stockman, went to a lunch atop a Houston bank building where Gingrich was drumming up backing from businessmen and developers. After the pasta salad and speeches, Stockman approached one guest, former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally, and told him he was running against Jack Brooks, the formidable Galveston lawmaker who is finishing his 20th term in the House and heads the Judiciary Committee. Connally gripped his hand and said, "Give me your card and I'll send you $1,000." That night in Irvine, Calif., Gingrich's gospel of Gopac and "revolution" enlisted 35 volunteers to raise or give $1,000 from a crowd of about 400 Republicans.
Money isn't all Gingrich offers. Each Thursday night, he gets on a telephone hookup with 60 to 90 Republican challengers, offering them commentary on recent events and advice about how to campaign. Just after the Los Angeles riots, he warned them to be sure to denounce "racism, police brutality and violence," and not to forget any of the three. Then, once a month, Gingrich stages a press conference in Washington with telephone hookups to their campaign headquarters, so challengers can identify themselves with, or even claim credit for, legislative proposals like the Republican health-care plan or a bill to limit the number of years someone can receive Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
Campaigning on scandal alone may not be enough for Republican challengers if they ignore national problems, Gingrich believes. Or, as he put it in a brief appearance at a candidates' training session just before the April lunch in Houston: "Don't focus in only on scandal on the Hill. They're interesting. They're great soap opera. They're important. But they have to be attached to people's lives." To do this, he said, challengers should list the problems the Democratic Congress is not solving, like health care or jobs, and then say: "And by the way, the guys who are failing you on every front can't manage the Capitol. So they have managed to both screw up the Capitol and screw up your lives and it's their fault."
GINGRICH IS offering advice to others he hasn't followed himself, for his House career has been continually confrontational. And he has brought the House minority leader, Michel, along -- to a degree. They still offer something of a good cop, bad cop routine, with Michel as the genial veteran who can sit down and talk with Foley and Gingrich as the tough guy who boasts that polls now show only a fifth of the public approves of how Congress is doing its job. "We've accommodated pretty well to each other's different traits," Michel says. He adds that when Gingrich won his position as whip by two votes over a Michel ally in 1989, he had feared constant friction between them. He also worried that Gingrich would not attend to the basic duty of "whipping" Republicans into agreement on how to vote. "Some of the earlier concerns I had have dissipated," Michel says. "Quite frankly, we complement one another." He says he hopes that in 1993 he will be Speaker, "being credible and being respected and having a fair and even hand," while Gingrich could be the Republican majority leader "who gives the opposition fits."
That might be a relief for the next Bush Administration, if there is one, for in between his fights with Democrats, Gingrich has tangled with the President and his aides. In 1990, he took on President Bush and the rest of the Republican leadership in both houses over that year's budget agreement, which violated G.O.P. orthodoxy and Bush's own campaign promises by imposing tax increases to accompany spending cuts. In 1991 he harassed the President into asking Congress to pass capital-gains tax cuts instead of adjourning, which made Bush look silly.
But most of the time, he has assaulted Democrats, and on issues of character, not policy. In 1984, he was speaking to an empty House and a C-Span camera, attacking one Democrat after another for supposedly unpatriotic sympathies for the Sandinistas. Speaker Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr. was enraged when he heard about it, and ordered the cameras to pan to show the empty chamber. Then, O'Neill took the House floor to denounce Gingrich, saying: "My personal opinion is that you deliberately stood in the well before an empty House and you challenged their patriotism, and it is the lowest thing that I have ever seen in my 32 years in the House." Gingrich won that round, when the Speaker suffered the remarkable rebuke of being ruled out of order for using unparliamentary language.
He went on to other battles, pushing the Ethics Committee or the whole House into stiffer sanctions against various Democrats and one Republican, Representative Dan Crane of Illinois, who was censured for having sex with a House page. He put less formal pressure on two other backbench Republicans to resign.
Gingrich's two-year confrontation with Wright over the propriety of the Speaker's money-making schemes had the air of a vendetta. Gingrich was outraged at Wright's personal effort to negotiate a political settlement in Nicaragua. Wright resigned after the Ethics Committee decided there were dozens of charges against him worth pursuing. Soon after, the committee rejected a counterattack from Wright's backers. They had charged that businessmen concealed campaign contributions to Gingrich with $5,000 investments in a book he wrote in 1984. They lost their money when the book did not sell.
His support among Republicans in the House is solid, stronger than when he squeaked through to the whip's job in 1989. A Connecticut moderate like Nancy Johnson sings his praises, recalling how he helped her devise parliamentary tactics to push abortion rights even though he disagreed with her aim. Scott Klug of Wisconsin, one of his freshman followers, found him encouraging on the House bank issue when many senior members were not. Gingrich told them: "If you guys think this is right, go for it." He worries some Republicans, like his friend Weber, who is troubled by the emphasis on personal attacks even as he hails Gingrich as a rare Representative who thinks about politics on a grand scale, beyond the next election or the next amendment.
Some Republicans who will not talk for attribution see him as a destructive force. They agree with Representative David R. Obey, a senior Wisconsin Democrat whom Gingrich says he respects for his diligence and trustworthiness. Obey says he sometimes sees "the ghost of Joe McCarthy" in Gingrich. "Newt enjoys smearing people's character," he says. "He contributes to the destruction of the body politic."
For years, Democrats have said his tactics amount to a desire to burn the House down, in the expectation that since it has a Democratic majority, more Democrats than Republicans will suffer and new Republicans will take their places.
That view of him is now spreading on both sides of the House. One lawmaker after another agrees with the notion that Gingrich is the political equivalent of the Air Force major in a famous interview amid the rubble of Ben Tre in South Vietnam. It was just after the Tet offensive in 1968, and the major explained, "It became necessary to destroy the town in order to save it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Never far from a phone, left, or a cadre of strategists, right, Gingrich presses his attack. Here, he does it from the Republican whip's office. (Photographs by Robert McNeeley for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: August 23, 1992

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1835 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Once and Future Audubon

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
The critic Reyner Banham once wrote that "architecture is that which changes land use," and in built-up cities like New York such changes can be traumatic. Taj Mahal, anyone? Not in my backyard. Even when a good building replaces an eyesore, the disruption can be painful, for it robs us of memories and violates our sense of control. For cities to work as social organisms, people need to feel a proprietary interest in their surroundings. Yet almost every ground-breaking shatters that benign illusion of ownership.
This fall, the jackhammers will start pounding on a piece of property in upper Manhattan that has aroused more than the usual amount of emotional upheaval. The Audubon Research Building, whose design has just been completed, has been a focus of controversy for a decade. The issues it has raised range from the civil rights of minorities to the possible hazards of conducting biological research in populous urban settings. These issues largely lie beyond the scope of architecture. They would remain unresolved no matter how well or badly the Audubon were designed, or even if nothing were built here. But this project is one in which architectural and social values are not easily separated. Indeed, the strength of the building's design, by Davis, Brody & Associates, is in the sensitivity with which it brings these values into coherent relationship. 
 Architecture is not the only thing that changes land use. On Feb. 21, 1965, a hail of bullets struck Malcolm X as he began to lecture from the stage of the Audubon Ballroom. With his assassination, this community meeting and recreation hall at 165th Street and Broadway was transformed into an unofficial landmark in the struggle for civil rights. That is why, when Columbia University announced plans in 1982 to demolish the ballroom and an adjacent theater to build a $22 million commercial science laboratory near Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, many viewed the proposal as an act of violence.
In a city struggling to come to grips with the causes of racial tension, the proposal to tear down the Audubon looked like one more cause. Though the building was decrepit and largely abandoned, it nonetheless overflowed with meaning, and so, alas, did Columbia's proposal. It dripped with disregard for history and for the university's responsibility to help a city heal.
Protests over the proposal forced Columbia back to the drawing boards several times, most recently in 1990, thanks to the persistence of Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger, whose approval was required for public financing. Her determination to improve the plan risked killing it altogether, but it also created an opportunity to review competing visions of a contested urban space.
To the university, the land (leased from the city) represented the potential for profit from renting space to research labs. Columbia-Presbyterian considered the facility essential to attracting research scientists to its staff. The city's Economic Development Corporation and the state's Urban Development Corporation viewed the project as a chance to increase New York's share of the booming biotechnology industry. The focus of the New York Landmarks Conservancy was the building itself, a 1913 classic of decorative art by Thomas Lamb, a leading designer of theaters in the movie palace era. For the Malcolm X Coalition to Save the Audubon Ballroom, the building was valuable because of an event that took place within it.
The Audubon controversy did not come out of nowhere. It arose from a history of tensions between Columbia University and its neighbors. As a building associated with a legendary figure of the 1960's, the Audubon inevitably evoked memories of the campus riots that erupted in 1968 in the wake of Columbia's plan to build a gymnasium in Morningside Park, a public space. And no 60's flashbacks are needed to instill distrust of Columbia-Presbyterian's expansionist ambitions. With its stark walls rising like fortress bulwarks from the streets of Washington Heights, the hospital complex is a case study in architectural alienation.
Yet possibly no one could detest the hospital's buildings more than the people who have to work inside them. And you don't have to be black to be stirred by the life of Malcolm X, rich to have a stake in economic opportunity, or a preservationist to fear change. To live in New York is to embrace contradictions, and even in the contentious atmosphere surrounding the Audubon, common interests transcended factional differences.
Ms. Messinger's mission was to map out that common ground -- and she did it successfully, as it turned out. Under the terms of a plan approved by the city Board of Estimate, Columbia agreed to retain and restore the Audubon's Broadway facade, along with its lobby and about half of the ballroom, including the stage where the assassination took place. The theater structure will be demolished. The ballroom's restored interiors will house a community health clinic as well as a memorial to Malcolm X, for which a design competition will be organized by the city's Department of Cultural Affairs. As part of the package, Columbia will also offer neighborhood job training and medical school scholarships.
Now it has fallen to Max Bond, Lewis Davis and their associates at Davis, Brody to cast this agreement in stone -- and in metal, glass and terra-cotta tile. The firm's design for the Audubon Research Building gives new meaning to the term civil engineering: it seeks to balance by formal means the competing stakes in the land the building will occupy. That balance is achieved most conspicuously in the marriage between the Audubon's restored facade and the lab tower that will rise behind it. The two halves of that marriage, though both the work of Davis, Brody, have been approached almost like separate projects. That makes sense: research in this building will proceed in two directions. The memorial will unearth the past, while, upstairs, lab workers will explore the future.
It would be tragic if the restoration work, supervised by the architect John Torborg, were not made the subject of a show. Heinrich Schliemann didn't lavish nearly so much care on his beloved Troy. Combining archival research, structural analysis and the resuscitation of nearly extinct techniques of applied decoration, this has indeed been a painstaking work of urban archeology. But the Audubon's exterior is more than a historical artifact. It also endows the project with the ready-made elements of superb urban design. The vertical rhythm supplied by Lamb's two-story window bays will make the new building (to be finished in 1994) uncommonly street-friendly. The facade's gleaming white surfaces, set off with green and yellow polychromy, banded by a cornice of gray zinc, will make it a pleasure to walk by.
Inevitably, something will be lost with this pristine re-creation of a 1913 design. It cannot match the emotional intensity of a hastily painted graffito proclaiming that "Malcolm X Lives." Though there are tentative plans to build a memorial park on a wedge-shaped plot across the street, the exterior form of the Audubon will convey no overt sign of his memory. The link between the facade and Malcolm X is that of analogy. Malcolm X's speeches called for grass-roots movements to resist the status quo. Historical preservation is such a movement; its spread to communities like Harlem and Washington Heights is also a legacy of the 1960's.
The six-story research lab, rising from behind the Audubon's facade, is a frankly Modern structure. The lab harmonizes with Lamb's architecture but makes no attempt to emulate its ornate style. Its window mullions echo Lamb's but are set on a different grid. Cast stone panels of buff, green and gray take Lamb's palette to a deeper shade, a backdrop for his polychromy.
The lab tower actually combines two blocks of labs beneath one roof. Set parallel to Broadway and St. Nicholas Avenue, the six-story lab units nearly touch at the angle where St. Nicholas meets 165th Street. They are hinged together at the angle by a curved bay that contains the building's entrance.
The exterior massing, or modeling, of these elements is the key to the design's strength. What could have turned out a modern box with a period facade tacked on is instead a visually complex assemblage that changes with the vantage point: a building as multifaceted as the community it will serve. The composition is further enriched by a screen that projects the windows forward. The Audubon's front becomes, in effect, a facade joined to a facade.
Massing -- more accurately, the reduction of mass -- is also the key to the master plan for the Audubon Biomedical Science and Technology Center, a complex that will eventually add several more research buildings to the blocks just north of the ballroom. The plan, also designed by Davis, Brody, seeks to alleviate the impact of Columbia-Presbyterian's fortress wall. Unlike the hospital complex, the research park will be aerated by streets passing through it. With their low roof lines and ground-floor shops, the buildings won't be blockbusters. Instead, they'll filter out into the neighborhood like ambassadors of architectural good will.
It will be a challenge for the architects to devise forms for these buildings as visually rich and urbanistically sound as those Lamb left behind. And Lamb's architecture confers another quality that defies duplication: a sense of time, and time's disruptions, a vision of architecture as a slow, patient art that is subject to change and mutation as it takes shape in the public eye. The evocation of that quality is the opportunity offered by many additions to older buildings, a type of architecture that is bound to dominate the cityscape as time goes by.
The growth of a building can be tortuous, and there's no reason why its form should not reflect that. If there are common goals that transcend competing differences, there is also an ideal of difference that can transcend common ground: diversity of opinion, of taste, of priorities that change with time. Architects should not hesitate to embody this ideal. Since the Audubon project was first proposed, it has served to bring conflicts to light, and this process will not end when the building is completed. While the master plan's additional buildings do not jeopardize historic sites, they will no doubt provide grounds for angry outbursts for years to come.
Calling forth such disagreements may in fact be as valid a function of architecture as trying to resolve them through design. The Research Building would not have attained its present design had its opponents remained silent, and if the memorial is to be more than a mute pile of cleaned-up terra cotta, we would do well to keep their contribution in mind. In that way, the building will not only memorialize a historical figure. It will also honor his exercise of a principle in which all have a stake: free speech.

HEADLINE: Law for Disabled

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your "New Federal Law For the Disabled Slow to Take Hold" on July 12 does a lot to underscore the problem of accessibility for individuals with disabilities. The accessibility standard referred to in the article is the Americans With Disabilities Act Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG). There are over 44 million Americans with disabilities covered by the act. 
 The greatest impact in terms of achieving accessibility lies in new construction. It is in this area that the law is very clear concerning what has to be done: all new construction must comply with the standard. In addition, current estimates are that compliance will only add 1 or 2 percent to the cost of new construction. The retrofitting of facilities to comply with the standard is very often extremely expensive and on occasion may not be even feasible. But the law views "readily achievable" as an ongoing process and what is not readily achievable today may be so tomorrow, either through technological advances or increased economic resources of the entities covered by the act.
 
RONALD P. KOZBERG
Mountainside, N.J.
 
The writer is president of Expert Strategies, a consultant on the disabled.

HEADLINE: Resolving Property 'Takings'

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
TWO HUNDRED AND ONE years have passed since the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution guaranteed that private property would not be "taken for public use, without just compensation." Judges, landlords and government officials are still trying to figure out exactly what that means.
Several critical cases -- involving a historic Art Deco movie theater in Philadelphia's Center City, oceanfront lots on the Isle of Palms in South Carolina and wetland acreage on Long Beach Island in Ocean County, N.J. -- suggest to some that the ill-defined line between a constitutional land-use regulation and an unconstitutional "taking" may be shifting in owners' favor. 
 "I think the courts have come to place a great value on property rights under the Constitution," said Norman Marcus, former general counsel of the New York City Planning Department and a partner at Bachner, Tally, Polevoy & Misher.
"The 50's, 60's and 70's saw greater value placed on other rights in the Bill of Rights," he said. "The 80's and 90's are seeing property rights coming to the fore."
In 1989, the New York State Court of Appeals struck down as a "taking" a New York City law that banned the conversion, alteration or demolition of single-room-occupancy hotels and required owners to restore and lease units at controlled rents. A year later, in United States Claims Court, the Loveladies Harbor development concern of Long Beach, N.J., which had been barred by the Corps of Engineers from building houses on wetland acreage, won a $2.68 million award, plus interest, on the ground that its property had been taken. The case is on appeal.
BUT there have also been decisions that support regulators. Less than a month ago, for instance, the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court upheld the landmark status of the interior of the Four Seasons restaurant in the Seagram Building. It said that a "taking" claim by the owner was without merit, since the landlord was "not substantially deprived of the economic benefit of this space."
Preservationists nationwide are awaiting, with some trepidation, a new decision from the Pennsylvania Supreme Court in the case of the former Boyd Theater in Philadelphia, now known as the Sam Eric. It was officially designated as historic in April 1987, subjecting it to municipal oversight akin to that given New York City landmarks.
In July 1991, the court ruled 4 to 3 that by designating the theater over the owner's objections, the Philadelphia Historical Commission had "taken" the property for public use without just compensation, violating a clause in the state constitution that is patterned on the Fifth Amendment.
A month later, the court accepted the case for reargument on the "taking" issue.
Meanwhile, designation efforts in Pennsylvania have been caught in "suspended animation," said Brent D. Glass, the state's historic preservation officer.
"If, indeed, a mere designation is a taking, you don't have to be a nuclear scientist to figure out the potential liability," said Richard Tyler, Philadelphia's historic preservation officer and executive director of the Philadelphia Historical Commission.
"Given the potential liability for a city that is not exactly awash in money," he said, "we've stopped the designation of privately-owned property, unless the owner has expressly asked that it be done."
The proposed Rittenhouse-Fitler Historic District, in and around Rittenhouse Square, with some 2,500 properties, is now on hold, as are districts planned for Society Hill, Girard Estate, Spruce Hill and Penn-Knox, which have about 5,400 properties among them.
At the heart of the controversy is a 65-year-old theater at Chestnut and 19th Streets. It appears outside to be a somewhat elegant, if faded, neighborhood cinema. Inside, it reveals itself as an ornate, cavernous, exuberant movie palace. A 1986 assessment by the commission cited "its spectacular Art Deco design, which remains almost completely intact both on the interior and exterior."
The owner at the time of designation, the Sameric Corporation, objected forcefully and sued the city. Its challenge was continued by United Artists' Theater Circuit, which now owns the building.
In rearguing its case, the City of Philadelphia cited the 1978 decision by the United States Supreme Court that upheld the landmark status of Grand Central Terminal. "Local historic preservation laws, such as Philadelphia's, do not effect a taking under the Fifth Amendment," the city said.
But United Artists' Theater Circuit said that Pennsylvania courts "have applied a stricter standard to 'taking' than the Federal courts" and that "private property occupies a more hallowed ground in our Constitution than it does under the Federal Constitution."
To the extent that the Boyd Theater case rests on the Pennsylvania constitution, it would be more difficult to appeal in Federal courts and, perhaps, more insulated from legal battles in other states.
Laurie Beckelman, the chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, said she was not worried about any effects locally. "I feel very confident, in looking at case law in New York, that we're in very good shape," she said.
BUT Jerold S. Kayden, a lawyer and senior fellow at the Lincoln Institute of Land Policy in Cambridge, Mass., noted that if the Pennsylvania Supreme Court held to its finding of a taking, "private-property advocates can act like constitutional Johnny Appleseeds, attempting to sow the Pennsylvania message in state after state."
A "taking" is apparent enough when the state condemns property under its power of eminent domain, compensates the owners, empties the land of occupants and uses the property for a new high school, a highway right-of-way or an urban renewal project.
Far less clear is the extent to which a regulation amounts to a "taking," when an owner still possesses property but is greatly restricted in using it.
Two months ago, the United States Supreme Court ruled in the case of David H. Lucas, a developer. He bought two lots on the Isle of Palms in 1986 for $975,000, with the view of building single-family houses on them. But the state's Beachfront Management Act, enacted in 1988, prohibited the construction of permanent habitable structures on the property.
In a 6-to-3 opinion, written by Justice Antonin Scalia, the Supreme Court said that "when the owner of real property has been called upon to sacrifice all economically beneficial uses in the name of the common good, that is, to leave his property economically idle, he has suffered a taking."
The justices decided the case under the factual assumption, accepted by the South Carolina courts but disputed by Justice Harry A. Blackmun and others, that Mr. Lucas's lots had been "rendered valueless" under the coastal-zone construction ban.
Justice Scalia and his colleagues in the majority -- Sandra Day O'Connor, William H. Rehnquist, Clarence Thomas and Byron R. White, with Anthony M. Kennedy concurring -- stopped short of declaring that Mr. Lucas had actually suffered a taking, however.
Rather, they returned the case to the South Carolina courts, saying that in order to win its case, the state would have to demonstrate that, even before the 1988 ban, there were existing "background principles of nuisance and property law that prohibit the uses he now intends in the circumstances in which the property is presently found."
Dissenting from the opinion, Justice Blackmun called it "a missile to kill a mouse," and said, "My fear is that the court's new policies will spread beyond the narrow confines of the present case." Justice John Paul Stevens also dissented and Justice David H. Souter filed a separate statement.
Interpretations vary as to the significance of Lucas v. South Carolina Coastal Council. A forum, "After Lucas," moderated by Mr. Marcus, is scheduled Sept. 17, at 6 P.M., in the New York County Lawyers Association building, 14 Vesey Street, near Broadway.
Mr. Lucas's lawyer, A. Camden Lewis, of Lewis, Babcock & Hawkins in Columbia, S.C., said the court's instruction to focus on "background principles" -- that is, what owners could have expected to do with property at the time of purchase -- "will really help landowners in the long run."
HE also said the opinion "set up a guideline that hadn't heretofore been established," which he defined as follows: "A regulation will always be a taking if it takes away all valuable economic use."
Justices Blackmun and Stevens view this development warily. The rule may "greatly hamper the efforts of local officials and planners who must deal with increasingly complex problems in land-use and environmental regulation," Justice Stevens said.
"The threshold inquiry for imposition of the court's new rule, 'deprivation of all economically valuable use,' itself cannot be determined objectively," Justice Blackmun wrote. "As the court admits, whether the owner has been deprived of all economic value of his property will depend on how 'property' is defined."
"The issue of what is the property interest at stake is going to be a whole new battleground," Mr. Kayden said. "Defining what the property is determines whether the owner wins or loses."
For example, if the developer of a 100-acre rural tract were required to leave 90 percent of it in a natural state, how would the court define the affected property? Would it be the 90 acres that the government had frozen, or the parcel as a whole, within which 10 acres provide an economic return?
This question has particular relevance to the Loveladies Harbor case, in which the developer was barred from building on a 12.5-acre portion of a 250-acre parcel, most of which had already been developed.
IT also is key to the case of Grand Central Terminal, whose landmark status was upheld by the New York Court of Appeals in 1977 and the United States Supreme Court in 1978, against a "taking" claim by the owner, the Penn Central Transportation Company.
In that case, the courts considered the parcel as a whole, saying that even if the terminal could not operate at a reasonable profit, some income from Penn Central's real estate holdings in the area "must realistically be imputed to the terminal."
In Footnote 7 of the Lucas opinion, the justices described this as "an extreme -- and, we think, unsupportable -- view."
"That suggests that Penn Central is in doubt," said Richard A. Samp, chief counsel of the Washington Legal Foundation. About Loveladies Harbor, he said, "The fact that development proceeded in separate tracts and the specific decision by the Corps applied only to this one discrete parcel suggests that, under Footnote 7, the developer will win."
Other than the issue of property definition, however, Mr. Kayden said the Lucas case was "old wine in old bottles."
"The legal reasoning follows pretty squarely on existing Supreme Court jurisprudence," he said. "Further, it's a very narrow decision because it applies only in the case of a 100-percent wipeout. And that situation occurs quite rarely."
"Nothing in the Lucas decision affects routine forms of land-use regulation," said Stephen Neal Dennis, executive director of the National Center for Preservation Law.
For the New York City Planning Department, the message from the Lucas case was that "we need to be very careful as to how we regulate," the counsel, William Valletta, said. But he added, "I don't think it ultimately is going to change the outcomes."
Because the High Court reached no definitive decision, the South Carolina Coastal Council is conducting "business as usual" in regulating beaches, wetlands and coastal waterways, said a spokeswoman, Donna Gress. She noted that under a 1990 revision to the beachfront act, Mr. Lucas would be entitled to apply for a construction permit, although there is no guarantee he would get one.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Tara on Campus;
Westchester Irish Center

 BODY:
A vision of Tara, the ancient seat of Irish kings, is obviously on the minds of a group of Irish investors who have signed a $14 million contract to purchase the 57-acre main campus of King's College in the Westchester village of Briarcliff Manor.
Their plan is to transform the campus into a site for Gaelic football and hurling games, as well as art and drama programs and a genealogy center. 
 "This was a unique opportunity to group a wide selection of Irish cultural activities in one location," said Edward Sheeran, chairman of Tara Circle, the investors' group. Mr. Sheeran is also president of Rockfield Corporation, a golf resort development company.
Several months ago, Tara Circle started looking for a site for Irish sporting events, which used to be played at the now-shuttered Gaelic Park in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
When they found the Briarcliff Manor site, with three athletic fields, a library, gym, banquet halls and a music building, they expanded their plan to suit the accommodations.
The group paid $150,000 last month toward a required $700,000 down payment. The remainer is due in two installments. The balance of the purchase price is expected to be financed by bonds issued through Westchester County's Industrial Development Agency.
According to Mr. Sheeran, the group has already raised $1 million from Irish groups for the project.
The campus was for sale because Kings College is moving to Warwick in Orange County.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Wall Street Leasing;
Cooling a Securities Firm's Wanderlust

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
"IF the economics are comparable, then we get to the convenience issue," said William J. Ahearn, first vice president of Prudential Securities. The economics were made comparable, in the end, with those in Jersey City by tax relief granted by New York City, so downtown Manhattan was free to prove itself on the convenience issue. No trouble there.
Mr. Ahearn was elaborating on the decision-making process that led the nation's third largest securities firm to make a major commitment to the Wall Street area, announced by Mayor David N. Dinkins on Aug. 5. The company is taking a million square feet of space in Chase Manhattan Bank's 2.1-million-square-foot tower at One Water Street, known as One New York Plaza, at the Battery. And it is renewing its lease on 500,000 square feet in Jack Resnick & Sons' One Seaport Plaza, or 199 Water Street, near South Street Seaport. 
 It amounts to a downtown consolidation more than a great expansion. The company is currently in 11 locations with 1.4 million square feet. It is keeping only its Seaport Plaza presence, and giving up locations that include 100 Gold Street, where it has 500,000 square feet, and 127 John Street, with 160,000 square feet.
Still, the decision by Prudential Securities to keep its operations in Manhattan is an important plus for the downtown market, where the latest figures from brokerage houses show that about 20 percent of the space is available. One New York Plaza had one of the largest single blocks of readily available space.
The decision demonstrates that in the current market lower Manhattan can offer costs that are competitive with New Jersey's. That requires cooperation by government, since it is in the area of taxes and energy costs specifically that New York City has been uncompetitive. Tenants still will pay more in New York City to outfit the space they lease, since labor costs are about 20 percent higher than New Jersey's, said Rodger G. Parker, senior vice president for real estate of Prudential Securities.
Mr. Parker was also the senior real estate official at Paine Webber in 1985, when it was deciding where to consolidate its 10 New York City operations. Paine Webber ultimately kept its headquarters and other front-office functions in Manhattan and moved back-office operations to Hartz Mountain's Lincoln Harbor development in Weehawken, N.J.
"Economics drove that deal, too," said Mr. Parker. Three thousand jobs were lost in New York City.
Abatements alone do not make buildings competitive, of course. Chase Manhattan Bank is spending about $50 million on improvements to the lobby, elevator cabs and plaza at One New York Plaza, and an additional $50 million on asbestos removal.
Asbestos-removal costs were a key factor in an assessment reduction won by Chase in a court suit. They vary widely depending on specific conditions in a building, and were a notably high $25 a square foot at One New York Plaza, said Joel R. Marcus, of the Manhattan firm of Pottish & Freyberg, who represented Chase in the suit.
The court cut the assessment to $85 million from $170 million for the contested period, lowering property taxes to about $3.50 a square foot from almost double that amount, Mr. Marcus said. Refund money will help pay for asbestos removal costs, he said.
Beyond that, the city and the Power Authority of the State of New York put together an abatement package worth at least $106 million over 20 years, leading to an average rent of about $28.50 a square foot per year for Prudential Securities. The figure represents base rent plus annual taxes and the tenant's share of operating costs.
In addition, Prudential Securities itself is investing $147 million to prepare its new One New York Plaza space -- almost $150 a square foot. Most of the money is for a data center, trading floor and special generators to assure uninterrupted power. Company headquarters will stay at One Seaport Plaza.
TWO major attractions for Prudential Securities were the building's large floors -- the company is taking the 16 floors in the base of the building, with 62,000 square feet on each floor -- and the availability of the space by 1994, when existing leases expire and the move-in gets under way. The firm's consultants were Joseph Hilton & Associates and LaSalle Partners, both of Manhattan.
"Today downtown needs government stimulus -- a cost structure that makes it competitive," said Martin Turchin of Edward S. Gordon, representing Chase. Instead of the $10 to $14 a square foot per year normally spent on taxes and electricity on a big lease for a heavily computerized brokerage operation, these costs to the tenant must be held to $7 or $8 a square foot, Mr. Turchin said.
This makes it possible more or less to match the fixed taxes over 15 years offered in Jersey City enterprise zones, he said. But the competition is not from the New York region alone. Prudential Securities considered moving back-office operations to Los Angeles, San Francisco, Houston and West Virginia before narrowing the field to Colgate-Palmolive's 42-acre Jersey City development and lower Manhattan, Mr. Parker said.
The vacancy rate downtown closely reflects the employment situation in the financial services industry and activities related to it. One baromter of this is the employment level in the securities industry and the commodities business in the city, which is tracked by the Federal States Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Employment stands at about 125,000, the bureau says, and it has stabilized this year after a decline since 1987. But it has stabilized at about 125,000 jobs, down 23 percent from the peak of 163,000 in 1987. Most are in the financial district.
"Employment is about where it was in 1985," said said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner. "It hasn't erased the gains of the 70's or before."
Vacancy figures reflect the post-recession business bankruptcies and consolidations that set off the employment drop. Edward S. Gordon, the brokerage firm, counts the inventory below Canal Street as 91 million square feet of rentable space. It says 20.3 million of it is available. In the financial district proper (excluding the City Hall area and the World Trade Center) 15 million square feet of a total of 55 million square feet is available, the firm says. Much of the space is concentrated in a handful of buildings, some with problems that prevent current marketing.
Cushman & Wakefield, another brokerage, finds a downtown vacancy rate of 18 percent in primary buildings and 22 percent in secondary buildings.
A new 12-year tax exemption on renovation work in commercial buildings south of 96th Street should help many buildings. The law allows a 100 percent abatement on taxes attributable to the post-improvement assessment increase for eight years, phasing out to zero abatement over the next four years. North of 23d Street the incentive expires in July 1994. To the south it is good until 1999.
Jon Lukomnik, assistant commissioner of finance, said that the cost of asbestos removal would be calculated as an expense item that lowers a building's net income -- the basis of assessment calculations. In this way a portion of the cost will recovered by the building over 10 years.
One New York Plaza is not the only building facing big costs, including asbestos removal, to remain competitive.
Olympia & York Properties, with well-publicized problems internationally, has told investors who hold notes secured by 55 Water Street, a 53-story development with 3.2 million square feet of space, that 1.5 million square feet of leases are coming due in mid-1993. And 650,000 square feet more will be available by the end of 1997.
The cost of preparing this space for tenants could total $100 million to $200 million or more over five years, the bondholders were told.
And at 55 Broad Street, the Rudin Organization has spent heavily for an asbestos clean-up and other work in a building that was emptied in the aftermath of a move-out by Drexel Burnham & Company. About 387,000 square feet is now on the market.
"We're negotiating with four tenants," said Lewis Rudin. "Hopefully we will make one or two deals. If we don't, we'll keep plugging."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: East Harlem Block;
30 More Affordables

 BODY:
One of the oldest community development corporations in New York City, Hope Community Inc., has opened a 30-unit affordable housing complex called Hope Place at 415 East 115th Street in East Harlem.
The development is an important phase in a community-planned strategy to revitalize 115th Street between First and Pleasant Avenues. Thus far, three buildings with 62 units have been completed by the 24-year-old organization, each with the help of more than $500,000 in low-interest loans and grants from the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, as well as $1.1 million in equity from the New York Equity Fund.
"This is one more thing on a whole block that is turning around," said Joan Lebow, a spokesperson for the Local Initiatives entity. 
 Hope Place opened last month and now is totally occupied. It has studios and one-, two- and three-bedroom apartments, with 30 percent of the apartments set aside for the homeless. Rents range from $328 to $489 a month. The architect is Herbert L. Mandel of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Auto Insurance: Another View

 BODY:
In his letter to the New Jersey editor on July 19, responding to the article "No-Frills Insurance Proposed for Cars," attorney Paul Hofmann criticized the recent proposals to reduce the minimum liability requirements for New Jersey drivers, contending that innocent victims could suffer "severe financial hardships." 
 What he failed to consider was that many drivers today simply cannot afford the state's current high minimum coverage requirements. As a result, an estimated half-million New Jersey motorists are driving around without any auto insurance. It is these drivers who pose the greatest threat to bankrupting the so-called innocent victims -- not to mention themselves -- should they become involved in accidents.
By lowering the minimum liability requirements, the state can make insurance more affordable and thus encourage more drivers to purchase at least basic policies. Anyone worried about being hit by a driver without substantial liability coverage or a driver with no insurance can purchase additional personal injury protection coverage.
The mini-policies currently being debated are designed to provide drivers with greater options and to help insure that those with limited resources are not priced out of the auto insurance market. By various means, these policies would also help control lawsuits for non-economic loss, a leading generator of high costs that all insured drivers must share.
The American Insurance Association, whose companies write about one-third of New Jersey's total property-casualty insurance premium volume, urges the administration and the Legislature to take a closer look at these mini-policies and support the insurance industry's effort to develop a system that will help make insurance more affordable.
 
PAUL C. BLUME
Counsel for New Jersey
American Insurance Association
Washington

HEADLINE: Doubts Plague Mortgage Plan For Firefighters and the Police

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
WHEN the Residential Mortgage Investment Program was signed into law by Gov. Jim Florio in January, it was hailed by all concerned. It permitted police officers and firefighters to tap into their pension system for mortgages carrying very low interest rates.
But since then, the program has created confusion and dissension in the ranks of the state's 35,000 uniformed employees. 
 The program allows a police officer or a firefighter to borrow up to $175,000 from the $5.7 billion pension fund for financing a first-time home purchase or for refinancing an existing mortgage on a home. The employee would pay an interest rate of 5.57 percent, while current rates are about 8 percent.
"Some people look at this like it's the greatest thing since Scotch and water," said William Flynn, president of the Firemen's Mutual Benevolent Association, a Rahway-based union with 5,000 members statewide. "But we're telling members to be very cautious because there are just too many unanswered questions."
One of those unanswered questions, Mr. Flynn said, is whether the Internal Revenue Service will treat the mortgage as a taxable distribution of retirement funds. That uncertainty might be expected to discourage some who would apply for the loans, but they are also aware that the money available is limited to 10 percent of the pension fund -- so if they hesitate too long, they may miss out.
Some union leaders are concerned that the program will upset the stability of the pension fund itself. As a result, the program has created something of a generational split, with older employees who are closer to drawing their pensions opposing it, and younger employees favoring it.
The law, which was sponsored by State Senator John A. Lynch, Democrat of New Brunswick, allows state pension officials to set aside 10 percent of the Police and Firemen's Retirement System for the mortgages. The retirement fund, which was recently valued at $5.7 billion, has about 35,000 active members.
Police union officials say the pension mortgage program was developed not only to provide low-interest mortgages to members, but also to help stimulate the state's real-estate and construction industries.
"It will put people to work, it's a good move for the economy and it certainly benefits police and firemen," said Frank Casey, consulting coordinator for the state Policemen's Benevolent Association.
 
Low Interest Rate
 The program is being administered by the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, an autonomous state agency that administers other low-interest mortgage programs for residential real estate.
Jerry Keelen, assistant director of single-family programs for the agency, said the interest rate for mortgages granted under the program was based on the average yield of United States Treasury bills plus two percentage points. Currently, Mr. Keelen said, the interest rate for a pension mortgage stands at 5.57 percent.
Mr. Keelen said that 25 percent of the funds earmarked for the program was intended for first-time home buyers, with the rest available for refinancing existing mortgages. A first-time home buyer is defined as someone who has not owned a home within the last three years.
About 20 mortgage companies doing business in the state are now taking applications for the mortgages. The companies are allowed to charge only an application fee, which averages about $300, and a flat charge of $1,500 instead of the "points" that are typically charged for mortgages. Each point is 1 percent of the mortgage amount, and lenders usually charge borrowers several points to process a mortgage.
 
Flood of Applications
 In addition, Mr. Keelen said, there is a $325 one-time charge that must be paid by borrowers to his agency to cover the costs of administering the program, and there is also a $30 monthly fee to cover the costs of processing loan payments and to maintain tax, insurance and foreclosure escrows.
Though no mortgages have yet been issued under the program, Mr. Keelen said, "there are literally millions of dollars' worth of applications at the banks."
Most of those, he said, are for refinancing of existing mortgages. "Our projection is that the average loan will be $125,000 and that we'll probably have a maximum of about 4,000 loans," he said, referring to both refinancings and new home purchases.
As an example of the potential savings the new program could provide, a $125,000 30-year loan at an interest rate of 10 percent, not uncommon for an existing mortgage, would cost $1,097 a month. A new 8 percent loan, which is the current conventional mortgage rate, would cost $917 a month. On the other hand, a 5.57 percent loan, the current rate for the pension mortgage program, would cost $715.
 
Substantial Savings
 The difference between a $125,000 30-year loan taken out today at 8 percent and the same loan taken out at 5.57 percent, when paid over the full 30 years, amounts to $72,720.
But some state and union officials are concerned that the Internal Revenue Service might interpret the use of pension funds for private mortgages as a distribution that is subject to income taxes and penalties. Such an interpretation, if upheld by the courts, could cost borrowers many thousands of dollars in taxes and penalties.
Anticipating that problem, the state treasurer's office hired a Washington law firm that specializes in taxes, Arnold & Porter, to determine whether the borrowed money would be taxable. The firm issued an opinion stating that it believed that the mortgages should not be treated as taxable distributions, but then added an ominous caveat.
"You must be aware that the Internal Revenue Service likely would not agree with our opinion, and that, upon audit, the conclusions reached may be challenged," the opinion stated.
 
Concerns Over Tax Status
 Edward J. McBride Jr., an assistant counsel to Governor Florio, said the opinion "speaks for itself" about the possibility that borrowers could be taxed at some point in the future.
"The question that no one can give an answer to at all is whether the I.R.S. will ever say anything about it," Mr. McBride said. "That's not even a legal call."
To alert prospective borrowers to the potential problem, Mr. McBride said, every application package contains a form warning of possible taxes and penalties and advising the applicant to consult with his or her own tax adviser.
But those who want to participate in the program feel a certain sense of urgency despite the unresolved tax question.
Vincent Frammigen, president of the Fraternal Order of Police, a 12,000-member organization of police and corrections officers, said that because of the limited amount of money available, fewer than 15 percent of the pension fund's members would be able to take advantage of the program.
 
Dangers of Real Estate
 Another concern voiced by union officials is that the program will undermine the stability of the pension fund.
"This is no time to be investing in mortgages," Mr. Flynn of the Firemen's Mutual Benevolent Association said. "The economy is just not right. You can go down any street in any town and see houses that are boarded up because of foreclosures."
The last thing the pension fund needs, Mr. Flynn said, is to end up owning houses that it had to take back because borrowers defaulted on their loans. And that, he said, is a distinct possibility, given the potential for layoffs of police officers and firefighters in municipalities strapped for cash.
Peter Smith, president of the 5,500-member New Jersey chapter of the International Association of Fire Fighters, said the younger members were in favor of the program while the more senior members were opposed to it because of concern about the future stability of the pension fund.
"At first blush, we thought this would be a great idea," Mr. Smith said. "But the more we looked into it, the less attractive it became."
 
Support From Police Union
 Some police union officials, on the other hand, staunchly support the program.
"I see no real drawbacks to this," Mr. Casey of the Policemen's Benevolent Association said. "I don't see anything wrong with a policeman getting a mortgage if the money's available and then paying it back like he would to a normal bank."
Mr. Casey added that officials of the Policemen's Benevolent Association, after conferring with tax experts, were confident that the income tax issue would not be a problem. "As far as we know," he said, "our president is telling the membership that the problem is corrected."
The president of the association, Frank Ginesi, did not return several telephone calls seeking his comment.
In the view of Mr. Frammigen, president of the Fraternal Order of Police, the tax issue is still very much alive. He cited the state's requirement that applicants sign documents indicating their awareness of potential tax liability.
"That's getting everybody off the hook except the person who's applying for the mortgage," Mr. Frammigen said.
One potential applicant who has not yet filed is Michael T. Cranwell, a Union City fire captain who wants to refinance his existing mortgage. "I'm on hold until I find out definitely what's going on," he said. "I just knew this sounded too good to be true."
