HEADLINE: As Global Talks Stall, Regional Trade Pacts Multiply

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Colombian roses will be more available in Venezuela, Israeli shoes will be more common in Central Europe and Mexican watermelons will be cheaper in the United States. The reason: a striking proliferation of regional free-trade deals.
Countries around the world have signed and ratified more such agreements in the last five years than in the preceding decade. And an even larger batch of regional deals, including the North American Free Trade Agreement that was formally announced by the United States, Mexico and Canada 11 days ago, have been recently struck by negotiators and are at various stages of approval. 
 With the end of the cold war and the stagnation of negotiations aimed at simultaneously lowering trade barriers globally, these regional pacts are emerging as the trade side of what has been widely called the New World Order. The success or failure of these arrangements will help determine economic growth and consumer prices around the world, affecting people in ways from the jobs they hold to the price of vegetables at the local supermarket.
Whether the regional trade agreements are a good thing is a matter of some debate. Many economists worry that they may lead to an undermining of global free-trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 103-nation pact that has set the world's free-trade rules since 1947. They also fear a rise in protectionism as countries use regional agreements to steer business toward their allies, instead of buying goods from whatever country produces them most cheaply.
"My judgment is that the revival of regionalism is unfortunate," wrote Jagdish Bhagwati, an economics professor at Columbia University and special adviser to the GATT, in a paper presented at a recent World Bank conference. "But, given its political appeal and its likely spread, I believe that it is important to contain and shape it" through GATT rules barring protectionist clauses in the agreements.
But the Bush Administration and some academic economists say that the agreements are not a problem, at least in principle, and a book by an M.I.T. scholar, published last week, suggests that regional free-trade deals are better than no free trade at all, and that they help countries force other countries to open their markets.
"I've never heard anyone in the Administration suggesting that regional agreements are a substitute for multilateral agreements -- they can and should be complementary," said Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
The strongest views in favor of regional free-trade pacts come from business groups that see them as a way for the United States to demand deep concessions from its trading partners, while threatening loss of access to the American market if these demands are not met. American officials have been reluctant to pursue this strategy in the GATT, where the American market counts for less.
"Everybody gets caught up with principles instead of threatening retaliation; with some of these countries in the GATT, you can't deal with them civilly," said Harvey E. Bale Jr., the pharmaceutical industry's chief lobbyist on trade issues and a former Reagan Administration trade negotiator.
Whatever the consequences, the rapid spread of free-trade pacts is remarkable. During the past year in the Western hemisphere, five Andean nations have agreed to form a free-trade area, Chile has struck deals with Argentina and Mexico and is negotiating with Venezuela and Costa Rica, and Canada and the United States have agreed to add Mexico to their free-trade area.
Nor is the trend limited to the Americas. The countries of Southeast Asia set up a free-trade area last January, while 11 countries around the Black Sea are moving in that direction. Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland have announced plans to negotiate a free-trade area. The seven-nation European Free Trade Association, or E.F.T.A., has inked separate deals with Israel, Turkey, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary.
Even the granddaddy of all free-trade areas, the European Community, is joining the tide. It struck a deal last October to eliminate trade barriers with the E.F.T.A.
Little economic research has been done on why the explosion in free-trade pacts should happen now. Yet five basic reasons appear to explain the new profusion:
* The end of the cold war has shattered the economic ties of former Communist countries and left them to form new alliances which tend to be free-trade deals with neighbors and Western countries.
* Latin American countries have been lowering their trade barriers unilaterally to encourage imports of cheap foreign equipment and other goods that make their own industries more efficient and internationally competitive. Once the barriers have been lowered considerably, free-trade pacts require little additional effort.
* Nations in existing regional agreements are bringing in their neighbors to offer larger markets to companies within their borders. The European Community once meant free trade among six northern European countries, but now includes 12 countries extending the length and breadth of Western Europe, and will involve 19 countries when the pact with the E.F.T.A. is concluded.
* Trade agreements mimic cross-border investment patterns, said Karl P. Sauvant, a senior United Nations economist. Big companies increasingly assemble manufactured goods in many countries from parts made in many countries. These corporations are demanding that their international production patterns be protected by trade pacts insuring that restrictions are not imposed on shipments of vital parts and finished goods.
* After years of viewing agreements overseas as plots to exclude American exports, the United States is beginning to forge its own agreements and take a benevolent view at least toward similar deals in Latin America. President Bush has set forth a vision of a free-trade area extending from the Arctic to Tierra del Fuego.
But what the Administration may welcome in principle and at home in the Western Hemisphere, it does not always greet abroad. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who today becomes White House chief of staff, recently delivered a stiff warning against trade deals in Southeast Asia that might keep American goods out of one of the world's fastest-growing economic regions.
Mr. Baker's concern over Southeast Asia reflects the concern many academic economists have about creating regional agreements to steer business toward allies instead of the cheapest producer. Since the publication of a famous book, "The Customs Unions Issue," by Jacob Viner, in 1950, economists have generally agreed that free-trade pacts are bad if they divert more existing trade to neighbors than they create in new trade.
Creating trade is good because it allows each country to specialize in those products it makes most efficiently, thereby increasing world economic output. Diverting trade to regional allies is bad, economists agree, because the allies may make goods that could be produced more efficiently elsewhere.
Yet fears of regional agreements may be overblown. After many years of alarms that the European Community may systematically exclude American goods, the fact remains that American exports to the community have more than doubled in the last six years, while imports from the community have risen only 27.3 percent. As a result, the United States has gone from an $18.65 billion trade deficit with these countries in 1985 to a surplus of $16.73 billion last year.
Part of the improvement may reflect the precipitous fall in the value of the United States dollar since 1985. But economic studies of the European Community have consistently shown that, with the conspicuous exception of farm products, the community has created more international trade than it has diverted.
Many of the same worries about protectionism are being raised about the North American Free Trade Agreement by some conservative analysts. Attention has focused on rules that limit eligibility for lower tariffs to goods produced mainly in North America.
Negotiators in Geneva have been stalled for two years in trying to produce a global free-trade accord. A strong argument in favor of pursuing regional accords while waiting for progress in Geneva is set forth in a just-published book by Kenneth A. Oye, director of the Center for International Studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In the book, "Economic Discrimination and Political Exchange: World Political Economy in the 1930's and 1980's" (Princeton University Press), Mr. Oye criticizes the popular notion that regional trading blocs worsened the Great Depression.
Mr. Oye notes the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 raised tariffs on all imports. Other countries were more selective, keeping tariffs low for neighbors or former colonial possessions so as to hold on to those markets. The result was a plunge in the American share of world exports to 10.3 percent in 1933 from 15.6 percent in 1929.
American exporters responded by lobbying successfully for the Regional Trade Agreement Act of 1934, under which the Roosevelt Administration negotiated deals with France and 10 Latin American countries. The expansion of regional trade then was better than no trade, Mr. Oye contends, adding that this argument applies today.
"The stagnation at the level of the GATT quite naturally leads to bilateral and regional bargaining, and I'm saying that's not bad, insofar as the second-best approach can and does lead to increased openness," he said in an interview.
But other economists, led by Mr. Bhagwati, contend that this view underestimates the enormous reductions in worldwide tariffs on manufactured goods that the GATT has already engineered.
 
 
PLAYING BY THE RULES OF ORIGIN
 Largely unnoticed in the debate over regional free-trade agreements is that almost every one has some rules, known as rules of origin, that require that goods be produced within the participating nations to qualify for lower tariffs.
The rules are intended to prevent nations outside the agreement from taking advantage of the lower tariffs. Mexico, for example, has a 10 percent tax on imported asparagus while the United States has a 25 percent tax. The North American accord will eliminate these taxes over 15 years only for asparagus grown in North America. But the taxes had to stay in place for imports from Peru and other countries, so those countries could not circumvent the higher American tariffs by shipping their asparagus to the United States by way of Mexico.
The preference given to Mexican asparagus could cost Peru some sales; indeed, Latin American, Asian and Caribbean nations worry that the North American trade agreement will cost them exports even if they are more efficient producers.
Some European countries have used rules of origin more restrictive than the North American agreement's. For example, the North American accord requires that at least 50 percent of the value of a car be produced in North America for it to qualify for duty-free treatment, and that percentage will rise to 62.5 percent over eight years.
The Ford Motor Company, which wanted a higher standard, complains that when Nissan recently set up a factory in England, France required that at least 80 percent of the cars' value be produced within the borders of European Community countries. To be sure, the French rules for counting local content then were less restrictive than the North American agreement's, but not enough to outweigh a difference of 17.5 percentage points.

HEADLINE: All About/Currency Printers;
The Companies That Make Money From Making Money

BYLINE: By DAVID BERREBY; David Berreby is a Brooklyn-based freelance writer.

 BODY:
Brand-new American products are scarce in the former Soviet Union, but by next month almost every Lithuanian will be using some. The litas, Lithuania's new currency, is made in the U.S.A.
Like the paper currencies of Malaysia, Haiti, Venezuela and a score of other nations, the litas is a product of the United States Banknote Corporation. Its main office is in Manhattan and it prints in plants in Philadelphia, Chicago and Los Angeles (where the 100-litu note, featuring a handsome scene of a peaceful Lithuanian town, was printed). 
 In fact, if history is any guide, the crisp, fresh bills that new regimes and resurrected nations are expected to put into circulation soon will be printed mostly by companies, not government presses.
Whether they are creating a new monetary unit, redesigning notes that now bear the "wrong" portrait or just replacing bills after their 15 months or so of life, all but about 30 countries in the world rely on a small, interlocked world of "security printers."
Such changes are good news for these companies, whose bread and butter was once stock certificates. With stock transactions becoming more and more computerized, the bulk of business and the growth at U.S. Banknote, the largest security printer in the United States, is in currency, travelers' checks and government documents like food stamps, according the Stanley Kreitman, president. Not to mention the holograms that are now placed on many credit cards, another U.S. Banknote product. The company -- the result of a merger in 1990 between United States Banknote and the International Banknote Company -- earned $4.7 million on revenues of $161 million last year.
Winning a government's order for currency "is really like selling any other industrial-type product," said Mark Crickett, divisional marketing manager for currency for Thomas De La Rue & Company. "It's a very specialized type of printed document, but you market it on quality, reliability, price, as you would any other."
Thomas De La Rue, a subsidiary of London-based De La Rue P.L.C., is the leader among money printers, with more than 90 nations among its clients. It had net income of $80 million on revenues of $646 million in the fiscal year that ended March 31.
Mr. Crickett declined to talk about any of his customers specifically. According to the Standard Catalog of World Paper Money, a publication for collectors, De La Rue's clients include Hong Kong, Guyana, Haiti, Peru and both pre- and post-revolutionary Nicaragua. (Substituting Sandino for Somoza on the 1,000-cordoba note posed no great problem for De La Rue's engravers and designers).
 
Push That Sale!
Marketing Counts, As Does Unrest
 As with any other product, marketing is important to the money-printing business, and U.S. Banknote has a well-traveled sales staff of four devoted to currency, Mr. Kreitman said. It paid off in the Baltic, where his company won Lithuania's business and a share of Estonia's, even though other companies, including De La Rue, Giesecke & Devrient of Munich and Johan Enschede en Zonen of the Netherlands, have closer offices and printing plants.
"It was good old-fashioned American salesmanship," said Mr. Kreitman, who declined to reveal the specifics of the litas contract.
Price, service and incentives are the key elements, Mr. Kreitman said. While money does not go on sale, "sometimes, we'll provide financing," he said. Payment, of course, is not taken in product samples, but by a letter of credit for a hard currency.
The unit of sale is a thousand bills, Mr. Kreitman said, and currency usually costs $26 to $45 per thousand to make, depending on what optional features a government orders, either to foil counterfeiters or for other reasons. (Some of Israel's shekels printed by Johan Enschede, for example, have special bumps for blind people to read.)
How much a country orders depends on its population and, more important, its inflation rate, said Mr. Kreitman, "though an order is rarely for less than 50 million notes."
For currency printers, like undertakers and journalists, upheaval and tumult are good for business.
"When inflation really got bad, there were Latin American countries in the 1980's whose largest imports were paper money," said David C. Harper, editor of The Bank Note Reporter, a monthly publication for currency collectors published by Krause Publications in Iola, Wis. The need to remove suddenly unpopular symbols can spur new orders sooner than replacement for normal wear and tear would require, he said.
It's only natural, then, that currency-makers have followed developments in the former Communist world with interest. The Baltic Republics, which declared their independence first, have already provided business. By far the biggest order so far, though, is from Ukraine, which will soon introduce a national currency, the grivna. Last fall, the new nation ordered 1.5 billion notes from the Canadian Bank Note Company of Ottawa, for $36 million (Canadian). The company is a privately held concern that prints some of Canada's own currency (another private company does the rest) and for "five to ten" other countries, said Shirley Arends, a company vice president.
Shipments are expected to arrive in Ukraine in October and again in January, she said. Given the Ukrainian inflation rate, she said, "We think they'll be looking for further notes beyond their initial order."
Earlier this month, the company signed a contract to print currency for Tajikistan.
But the Ukrainian and Baltic orders have been exceptions. So for now, currency makers are seeking other opportunities.
For example, "We also have contracts for stock certificates for the Central Moscow Stock Exchange and the Kazakhstan Stock Exchange," Mr. Kreitman said. And, based on the state of negotiations when the Yugoslav war began, he said, "once the situation settles down I assume we'll be doing Croatia."
 
Counterfeiting
Color Printers Pose New Problems
 During World War II, one of Germany's master engravers was enlisted, along with a gang of conscripts, by the Nazis to churn out counterfeit British pound notes. That continued a style of economic warfare that had been tried much earlier by the British themselves against American rebels.
In June, the issue surfaced again in a congressional Republican task force on terrorism which accused Iran of printing high-quality fake $100 bills. (The Iranians denied the charge.)
The currency enemy now is not so much the experienced forger but the ordinary criminal with access to advanced color photocopiers and computers.
Cynthia Rapp, a spokeswoman for Sicpa S.A., the leading maker of ink used in currencies, cited the case of two Wichita high school students who were charged with counterfeiting in 1988. The authorities said the two had printed about $15,000 in fake cash using a parent's photocopier.
"The color copier makes counterfeiting something that anybody can do with no expertise," Ms. Rapp said.
While currency makers already have an array of design tricks to foil the fakes, including special ink not available for use in copiers, even more are due soon.
Working with its suppliers, U.S. Banknote can offer paper made so that a distinctive thread of another material runs through each note. Some American currency has a polyester; some British pounds have a metal thread. Another anticopier device used in American bills is "microprinting," which creates a legend around the bill's portrait that is so small no copier can reproduce it distinctly.
Despite such safeguards, the dollar remains a favorite target, and a relatively easy one at that.
"U.S. currency is a single color, it's all the same size, there's no watermark," noted Mr. Kreitman.
 
Check It Out
Holograms, Inks Hold Promise
 A possible future security tactic may be to put a hologram on every bill, assuming the technologies are developed to allow printing a hologram directly onto paper. Mr. Kreitman said the flatness of a holographic image on a fake bill would be easy to spot.
Meanwhile, Sicpa, the ink producer, is offering currency printers a special ink that changes color depending on how light strikes it. Thus, a genuine bill will change color when moved, but the fake will not.
This "optically variable ink" is already used in currencies printed for Argentina, Israel, Kenya, Singapore, Thailand, the United Arab Emirates and Zaire, said Ms. Rapp.
"It's a way for the man on the street to check any bill," she said.
 
 
 
THE SWISS CONNECTION
 Around the world, probably fewer than a dozen companies literally make money. When they do, it is almost certainly with the inks supplied by a single privately held Swiss company, on presses made by another Swiss enterprise and with paper from a few specialized providers.
Crane & Company of Dalton, Mass., for example, gets about 30 percent of its revenue from supplying paper for currency, said James Manning, a company spokesman. That includes paper for the United States dollar, for which Crane has an exclusive contract.
The ink for more than 80 percent of the world's currency, including the dollar, comes from Sicpa S.A., based in Lausanne. (The name was originally an acronym for Societe Industrielle et Commerciale des Produits Amon, and the Amon family, which started it, still controls the company.)
Most of the world's currency, including the United States dollar, is produced by the intaglio method of printing, on presses made by De La Rue-Giori S.A., a privately held Swiss company of which De La Rue P.L.C. of London owns 50 percent.
In the intaglio method, letters and images are engraved onto a metal plate. The plate's surface is inked, then wiped clean, so that ink remains only in the etched lines. When the ink is taken up by a piece of paper, it "actually sits on the surface of the note, like a business card," said Carl Meyer, a spokesman for the Secret Service.
The method, more expensive than offset printing, requires special presses and is itself one of the oldest anti-counterfeiting techniques.
Currency paper "isn't made from ground-up trees," said Mr. Manning of Crane. "We use waste cuttings from the textile industry, old blue jeans, and so on. And about 25 years ago, in response to the higher amount of synthetic fibers going into clothes, we started going straight to the cotton plant for raw material."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Soft-currency exports, hard-currency revenue. Litu for Lithuania at U.S. Banknote's Los Angeles plant. (Scott Robinson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: World Markets;
It's Dim Days on the Bourse

BYLINE: By Roger Cohen

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Battered by high German interest rates, uncertainty over European monetary union and malaise stemming from the war in what was once Yugoslavia, the French stock exchange is in the doldrums. And few analysts expect any significant upswing before the end of the year.
After climbing steadily from the start of the year until May 11, when the 40-stock blue-chip CAC index stood at 2,077, or 17.6 percent above its Jan.1 level, the Bourse has slumped. It closed on Friday at 1,724.18, down 2.3 percent from Jan. 1. 
 Behind the decline lies the evaporation of the hopes that characterized the first few months of 1992. At that time, it was widely believed the United States would emerge more strongly from recession. It was also thought that the fiscal and inflationary pressures on the German economy stemming from unification would be resolved faster, allowing interest rates to come down and spurring a European economic recovery.
Instead, the United States economy has stalled and German (read European) interest rates have continued to go up. Because the currencies of European Community countries are tied within a narrow band by the European Monetary System, interest-rate policies throughout the bloc are effectively pegged to Germany's.
"With interest rates at around 10 percent, there is no immediate hope of an upturn on the Bourse," said Jean Borgeix of the Pinatton brokerage house. "I think we need to get rates down to 8 percent to relaunch investment and attract people back to the stock market."
In this sense, the situation in Europe -- where all stock exchanges have suffered in recent months -- is the opposite of that in the United States, where Wall Street's bull market has been supported by very low interest rates.
Few see any hope of imminent change. "I don't think German rates will budge much before next year," said Alain Ferri, president of the Ferri S.A. securities firm.
On top of this, the new uncertainty surrounding European monetary integration itself has hurt confidence. A French referendum on monetary union will be held Sept. 20, and opinion polls now suggest a close result. Denmark rejected the plan in a vote last June.
If France also rejects the program agreed upon under last year's Maastricht Treaty for the introduction of a single European currency by 1999, the plan will effectively be dead. So, too, will the rigorous budgetary and inflation standards set by the treaty to insure that European economies be sufficiently harmonized to allow a single currency.
The prospect of an abrupt reversal in Europe's 35-year-old process of integration is causing profound uneasiness, several brokers said.
But there is also widespread concern that France's image could suffer from a rejection of monetary union, and that an unraveling of the treaty would lead to pressure on weaker European currencies because the targets and budgetary discipline imposed at Maastricht would no longer apply.
"Investors are concerned that a no vote might put further upward pressure on interest rates because weaker currencies such as the lira would be under attack," said Marc Warnier of Patrice Warnier S.A., a securities firm.
He predicted that the Bourse would continue to decline at least until the Sept. 20 vote. Another school, however, argues that the collapse of the Maastricht Treaty might give individual European economies breathing space by enabling them to maneuver more independently of Germany's current deflationary policies.
"That could eventually lead to an upswing on the Bourse, because the French economy is fundamentally strong," said Mr. Borgeix of Pinatton.
Indeed, with inflation at 3.2 percent and a budget deficit equivalent to just 2 percent of gross national product, the French economy is widely viewed as the strongest in Europe and the best placed to lower interest rates.
The sharp improvement in the country's economic performance over the past four years, combined with the rapid modernization of the Bourse, have transformed the standing of an exchange once shunned by foreigners.
Jean-Francois Theodore, president of the Bourse, said foreign, and particularly United States investment now accounts for about one-third of trading volume. The total capitalization of the Bourse has grown rapidly, to $969 billion, from $603 billion in 1987. "We believe we now have one of the most transparent and highly computerized exchanges," Mr. Theodore said.
A further boost to the Bourse will probably be given by a law that goes into effect Sept. 14. Known as the Plan d'Epargne en Actions, or plan for savings in shares, the law has been widely advertised by banks. It will allow people to invest a maximum of 600,000 francs each, or $120,000, in shares on a tax-free basis, provided they hold the stocks for at least five years.
With the new law imminent, and a French vote in favor of European monetary union still the most likely result, some brokers think the time has come to invest.
Among the stocks widely cited as favorites are the food group BSN, the Michelin tire company, the Peugeot auto group and -- provided a reasonable settlement is reached in the pay dispute between the company and the contractors completing the channel tunnel -- the Eurotunnel group.

PUB-DATE: August 23, 1992

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1761 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/August 16-21

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Let the People Pay the Debt 

Though he spoke for 53 minutes in accepting his party's renomination, President Bush had little to say about his accomplishments for the economy. The nation's woes, he said, were the fault of a Congress that failed to pass his economic plan and forced him into a one-time tax increase. Mr. Bush said he would cut taxes if re-elected and enforce a spending freeze on his own, through vetoes. He also outlined a novel approach to trimming the deficit: put a box on Federal tax forms that people could check if they wanted 10 percent of their payments to be used to reduce the deficit. The total would be deducted from spending. "I laughed when I heard it," said Norman Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute. "It will do nothing but shuffle numbers. There are no specifics as to where the cuts will come from."
 
Pentagon Pinch on R.& D.
 
A week after a panel of the National Science Foundation chastised business and government for spending too little on research and development, the General Accounting Office said the Pentagon would reduce its outlays to Sematech, the semiconductor research consortium. Sematech has 12 corporate members as well as the Pentagon and has been credited by several companies with helping them regain strength in manufacturing. The Defense Department had been ponying up $100 million a year for the consortium, but wants to cut back to $80 million and spread it among several organizations. Why? Studies by market research firms like the Dataquest Corporation, of Cambridge, Mass., suggest America is winning back market share from Japan. Dataquest said America's share of the world's chip market was 36.5 percent last year, up from 34.9 percent in 1990.

A Housing Spurt That Wasn't
 
Among economists, the consensus view was that the housing market would pick up a little steam. After all, it is interest-rate sensitive and rates on mortgages are at 20-year lows. The consensus was wrong. The Commerce Department said housing starts fell in July by 2.8 percent, the second decline in a row. The reason for the tumble, analysts said, was flagging consumer confidence. "We've got a tug-of-war going between lower interest rates and the factors causing the lower interest rates," said David Seiders of the National Association of Home Builders.

Behind the Jobless Figures
 
At first glance, the sharp increase in jobless claims looked like grim news: the Labor Department said they reached 474,000 in early August, growing by 71,000, for their largest increase since the 1982 recession. But on closer examination, most of the new claims were the result of a two-week shutdown of Midwestern plants by the General Motors Corporation. Excluding G.M., the jobless claims were virtually unchanged.

Not What Lincoln Said
 
In his eloquent and witty speech to the Republican faithful -- "I knew Jefferson, he was a friend of mine" -- Ronald Reagan portrayed Lincoln in a new light: that of Lincoln the supply-sider. Mr. Reagan quoted Lincoln as saying: "You cannot help the poor by destroying the rich. You cannot help men permanently by doing for them what they could and should do for themselves." Mr. Reagan lifted those quotations from "The Toastmaster's Treasure Chest," his secretary said. Trouble is, the words Mr. Reagan put in Lincoln's mouth were those of John Henry Boetcker, a minister and pamphleteer from Erie, Pa., born in 1873.

While high-level Republican honchos spoke in Houston about family values on what was billed as "Family Night," the band played music in between the speeches from the play "La Cage aux Folles." Though the play is about a loving, caring, long-term relationship, it is perhaps not exactly the type of relationship the Republicans had in mind.

Socking It Out in Baseball
 
Baseball -- the owners' game -- is as rough and tumble as anything that happens on the field. To get approval for selling the Giants for $110 million and moving the team to St. Petersburg, Fla., Bob Lurie, the team's owner, is switching positions and backing a group of owners who want to oust Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent from his job, according to baseball insiders. Dissident owners, led by Jerry Reinsdorf of the White Sox, are unhappy with Mr. Vincent's handling of labor relations, television and allocation of expansion money between the leagues. Mr. Lurie needs help from the dissidents to move the Giants since some American League owners don't want Florida to be an all-National League state.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Credit and Blame on Trade
 
America's worldwide trade deficit narrowed in June, but the key word is slightly. The Commerce Department said the deficit was $6.59 billion, while May's gap was revised downward to $7.14 billion. But while the Administration quickly took credit for June's 7.2 percent gain in exports, no one was eager to take credit for the 4.7 percent gain in imports.

Japan's Blindfold Strategy
 
Japan's solution to its stock market woes can be summed up by the maxim, "What you don't know can't hurt you." In an effort to instill a measure of confidence in the stock market and keep investors from selling, Finance Minister Tsutomu Hata said last week that, among other things, financial institutions would be permitted to withhold negative financial news from the public. Though he has no power to enforce it, Mr. Hata also told financial institutions not to sell stocks on which they can still record a profit until after the fiscal year ends Sept. 30. The strategy appears to be working. Though the stock market lost about 60 percent of its value in the last three years -- more than the American market lost in the three years after the 1929 crash -- it staged a comeback last week that was so strong it seemed as if the market was on steroids. The Nikkei climbed 12.8 after Mr. Hata's remarks and closed the week at 16,216.88.

The Honda Motor Company said net income for its first fiscal quarter fell 22.6 percent from a year ago to $131 million due to slack sales in Japan and North America.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
American's Price Turnaround
 
When American Airlines cut its prices and simplified its advance-purchase requirements in April, it sent the financially fragile airline industry into a tizzy. Other airlines said American was trying to drive them out of business. But American, the nation's No. 1 carrier, has taken its share of lumps too. Though it did not disclose an exact figure, the AMR Corporation, American's parent, said last week its third-quarter losses would be even higher than its $48 million operating loss in the second quarter. American earned $70.3 million in its third quarter last year. To stem those losses, American said it would raise fares 15 percent to 25 percent. "Perhaps this will shock the industry into some sensibility," said Julius Maldutis, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc.

Bud's Expose on Coors
 
In the bruising beer wars, Anheuser-Busch Inc., which brews Bud Light, has a message for people whose taste in suds runs to Coors. In commercials running in New York and Pennsylvania, the folks at Bud said the "pure Rocky Mountain spring water" in Coors Light is sent by railroad tank car to a processing plant in Virginia where it is mixed with -- horrors -- "local water." To get Anheuser to stop its unflattering -- but true -- ads, the Adolph Coors Company took the folks at Bud to court. Last week, Federal District Judge Michael B. Mukasey ruled Coors could not stop Anheuser-Busch from "hoisting Coors by its own petard." Coors said it was considering an appeal.

Wang Crosses Chapter 11 Line
 
Wang Laboratories, the once high-flying high-tech company founded by An Wang, an Asian immigrant and inventor, landed in Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code after circling around it for three years. Wang, which owned the market for dedicated word processors, saw its market eaten up by more versatile PC's. Though it moved successfully into the minicomputer market, its PC's flopped and it never developed products for the more lucrative work station and networking markets. In its filing, Wang listed $1.3 billion in debt and $1 billion in assets. The filing was "absolutely crucial to our company's survival and the preservation of thousands of jobs," said Richard W. Miller, Wang's chairman. Wang is expected to lay off 5,000 workers in the coming months, leaving it with 8,000. In 1988, it had 31,500 employees.
 
Paying for Broken Heart Valves
 
About 450 replacement heart valves produced by Pfizer Inc.'s Shiley unit have failed. Linked to those failures are 300 deaths. Last week, a Federal District Court judge in Cincinnati approved the settlement of a class-action lawsuit affecting 51,000 people with Shiley replacement valves. In the settlement, Pfizer agreed to pay $500,000 to $2 million for each valve failure, which is expected to cost the company between $165 million and $215 million for the failures to date. Pfizer set aside $300 million for the claims in January. But the settlement could eventually cost the company "several hundred million dollars more," depending on how many more valves fail and have to be replaced, said the judge, S. Arthur Spiegel. Another suit seeking damages for mental anguish has been filed in state court in Orange County, Calif.

Chrysler Muscled the Money
 
After waiting anxiously for weeks, the Chrysler Corporation finally got its 152-member banking syndicate to approve a $6.8 billion line of credit. The new credit replaces loans of equal size to the Chrysler Financial Corporation that are used to finance car sales. But getting a "yes" on the credit line took muscle. Chrysler enlisted the support of Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan to talk up the company's good points with the banking syndicate's reluctant German members. The German banks were worried about Chrysler's $4 billion in unfunded pension liabilities. The credit rating agencies, which put Chrysler's debt solidly in the "junk" category, were pleased with the agreement. "We view the loan agreement positively because it removes a risk we were worried about," said Solomon Samson, managing director of the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

Investing in Flat Screens
 
Motorola Inc. said last week it would buy a 20 percent piece of In Focus Systems Inc., of Tualatin, Ore., for $22 million. In Focus is one of the few American companies making sophisticated flat-panel display screens.

HEADLINE: Networking;
A New Hub Lets More LAN's Join the Conversation

BYLINE: By STEPHEN C. MILLER

 BODY:
Making a company's disparate computer networks work together is not easy. In many large companies, there is a mainframe network surrounded by a proliferation of local area networks with a hodge-podge of operating systems and wiring schemes. Providing simultaneous translation at the Tower of Babel was a minor matter compared with getting a network with S.N.A. (System Network Architecture -- I.B.M.'s mainframe wiring scheme) to talk to one with Ethernet wiring to talk to one with Token Ring or, Noah forbid, to an Appletalk network.
The job is made somewhat simpler through microprocessor technology known as an intelligent hub, which translates the signals from one kind of network into ones understandable by another. Hubs connect LAN's so that users on a network with one wiring scheme can get data or use peripherals from one with another scheme. 
 Hubs are digital versions of the old PBX patch panel telephone rooms. Now, just as a telephone operator sitting at a computer terminal can reroute a phone extension to a new location with a few key strokes, hub technology can switch computer users to different networks.
One limitation to current hub design is that most can connect LAN's only with one other kind of wiring scheme. The Chipcom Corporation of Southborough, Mass., has developed a hub that lets an administrator mix and match a network with up to three wiring schemes. The hub is called the Online Concentrator. "Being able to route three different networks through the same hub gives a network manager greater control at a lower cost," said Mary Modahl, director of network strategy research for Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass.
Another advantage of the Online Concentrator is that it is really two hubs in one, so that if one crashes, the second can handle the network traffic until the first unit is repaired. This is known as fault-tolerance.
The Online concentrator handles Ethernet, Token Ring and F.D.D.I. (Fiber Distributed Data Interface) networks. The biggest Online Concentrator sells for $4,250 and can support up to 128 users depending on the wiring scheme. The smallest (which is not fault tolerant) sells for $1,695 and can handle up to 40 users.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Glitter, but Little Gold, in Regionals

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
While most mutual fund managers scour the country, and often the world, for investment opportunities, a handful prefer stocks from their own backyard. For the most part, their loyalty hasn't paid off.
With a few exceptions, the $820 million group of regional equity funds, which invest chiefly in stocks of companies based in one area, have mediocre performance records, reflecting at least in part the booms and busts of regional American economies. 
 Yet fund sponsors, bursting with regional pride, keep the market for new offerings hopping. The two most recent entrants: the Atlanta Growth Fund and the Arkansas Equity Growth Fund. Next: the Home State Pennsylvania Growth Fund, which debuts in September.
Why the proliferation? "One answer is they are easy to market," said John Reken thaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, an investment newsletter in Chicago. They appeal to local patriotism and are relatively easy to explain to investors.
Then too, regional fund managers presumably have an edge over managers of national funds because they have a smaller area to oversee. They can frequently visit the companies whose shares they hold, establish relationships with management and be alert to changes. Because of the narrow focus of each fund, managers should be in the best position to discover up-and-coming companies taking root in their areas.
Notwithstanding the logic, however, regional funds as a group have had a lackluster record. "It's difficult to separate the stock-picking question from the regional question, but the bottom line is that the funds haven't been successful," Mr. Rekenthaler said.
Basically, the weakness in the funds is the flip side of their strength: When the local economy suffers, so do they. That's bad news for their local investors, whose jobs or financial situations already depend heavily on the health of the regional economy.
Among the regional flops is the Calvert Washington Area Growth Fund, which merged with Calvert-Ariel Appreciation last September after returning nothing at all for the five years ended Aug. 31, 1991. That month, Transamerica Sunbelt, which gained an annual average of 6.8 percent in the same period -- nearly four percentage points behind growth funds, on average -- merged with Transamerica Special Emerging Growth. On Oct. 1, Southeastern Growth changed its name to Mentor Growth and expanded its charter after returning 7.7 percent a year in the same five years. In 1990, the Growth Fund of California lacked enough sponsorship even to get off the ground.
Only two of the regional funds have 10-year records, and one is a dud: the Fund of the Southwest, which invests up to three-quarters of its assets in companies with significant business ties in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana, New Mexico and Arizona. It gained an annual average of 11.2 percent through June 30, 1992, lagging growth funds by about four-and-a-half percentage points.
In its defense, while the Fund of the Southwest languished with the oil-dependent economy of the region during the mid-1980's, a new manager, Sharon Stone, reconfigured it when she took over in late 1987.
She shifted from energy stocks into services, discount retail and consumer nondurables, including Wal-Mart Stores and Dillard Department Stores. The increased diversification removed some of the industry-specific risk, and created a decent five-year track record. The fund, sold with a 4.75 percent load, actually outperformed growth funds for the five years ended June 30, returning an annual average of 10 percent, compared with 8.2 percent.
The other granddaddy of the regionals is its shining star and accounts for more than half of the group's assets: the $500 million IAI Regional Fund, a no-load fund that concentrates its investments in seven states in the upper tier of the Midwest.
Its manager, Bing Carlin, buys a mix of small and large companies; over the years, "the fund has been a very reliable offering, maneuvering handily through a variety of market conditions thanks to good stock picking and well-timed moves to cash," Morningstar analysts say. The fund rose 19.2 percent annually in the decade ended June 30, compared with 15.6 percent for all growth funds.
Another regional fund worth looking at is the Composite Northwest 50, which returned 12.3 percent for the five years ended June 30, compared with the 8.2 percent for all growth funds. It is an index fund duplicating the Composite Northwest 50 Index, which was devised by the fund's sponsors and is made up of 50 companies that do business or are located in Alaska, Idaho, Montana, Oregon and Washington. The fund is partly sheltered from downturns in the regional economy because while companies like Nike, Microsoft and Boeing (all in the Composite index) depend on the Northwest region for labor, they don't for revenues. While the fund is skewed toward cyclical companies, it has some holdings in most industries.
Or cast an eye on ASO Outlook Regional Equity, a bank-sponsored fund with a 4.5 percent load that invests mainly in small to medium-sized companies in the deep South, including Alabama, Florida and Georgia.

GRAPHIC: Table lists total annual returns on regional stock funds traded by Morningstar Inc, through June 30, 1992.

HEADLINE: Technology;
A Way to Look Into the Heart and Detect the Killer Plaque

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SOUTH SAN FRANCISCO, Calif.

 BODY:
Physicians have long sought a window into the heart, some means to glimpse the progression of the fatty plaque in coronary arteries before it causes a heart attack. Scientists at Imatron Inc., a small medical technology company here, say they have developed a scanning device that can do just that.
Heart specialists who have used the device say it provides a reliable early indicator of coronary artery disease, or atherosclerosis, and can eliminate for some people the need for more painful, time-consuming and far more expensive tests like the angiogram. The need for such an indicator is compelling, they add, because for many of the 1.5 million people who have heart attacks in the United States annually, the first symptom is death. The situation is all the more tragic because if caught early enough, coronary artery disease can be slowed or reversed with diet changes or drugs. 
 Physicians have had no early indicator because existing tests were either inconclusive or too dangerous and expensive for use on patients with no symptoms. Imatron's device, known as the Ultrafast CT, identifies coronary artery disease by detecting and quantifying the presence of calcium in the arteries. Not related to dietary calcium, arterial calcification is a byproduct of the cholesterol-laden plaque of heart disease.
"I call it the mammogram of the heart," said Arthur S. Agatston, an associate professor at the University of Miami School of Medicine and director of the noninvasive cardiology lab at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami. Just as mammograms are now recommended for all women over 40 for early detection of breast cancer, "there's enough evidence now to recommend mass screening" with Ultrafast CT for coronary artery disease, he said.
Simple cholesterol tests are not a reliable indicator of who will get coronary artery disease because most people who have heart attacks have only average or slightly elevated cholesterol levels, Dr. Agatston said. And even among people with cholesterol levels as low as 180 (the average is 210), heart attacks are still the leading cause of death. Nevertheless, for many people, although not all, lowering cholesterol levels significantly does slow or stop the disease, he said.
"We have to look directly at the disease itself, at the coronary arteries, noninvasively, in a quiet, inexpensive way," Dr. Agatston said. "We have to image the coronaries and see the people who are developing atherosclerosis and treat them aggressively." He has scanned 2,500 patients, none of whom had symptoms, and found 500 with signs of coronary artery disease.
Ultrafast CT works on the same principle as a conventional CT (computed tomography) scan, but, as the name implies, much more rapidly. The speed is essential for recording clear images of the beating heart.
A conventional CT scan mechanically rotates an X-ray tube around a patient to obtain multiple images, or slices, that are then compiled by a computer. The fastest such devices take about a second to complete a scan. While they can be used to make images of other parts of the body, they are not effective for hearts because the heart is in constant motion and the CT images are therefore blurred.
Ultrafast CT places the patient inside a giant X-ray tube and uses a varying electromagnetic field to rotate the electron beam under and around the patient's body. Scans take 50 to 100 milliseconds -- 10 to 20 times faster than the convention CT. As a result they can freeze the moving heart, just as a fast shutter speed on a camera can freeze motion. The calcification can then be identified as a light area on the image, just as bone appears on an X-ray.
Imatron is publicly held, its stock traded over the counter, and had earnings of $1 million, or 1 cent a share, in 1991, on revenues of $18.9 million. Imatron's founders, a group of radiology specialists from the University of California at San Francisco, originally developed Ultrafast CT to record heart function, blood flow through the heart and defects in the heart muscle itself. Because calcium, like bone, blocks the passage of X-rays, and because there is a 100 percent correlation between coronary calcification and atherosclerosis, Ultrafast CT was a natural candidate for early detection of coronary artery disease.
"The nice thing about calcification is it's very easy to see on the Ultrafast CT, and physiologically, the only way you can get calcification is by coronary atherosclerosis," said David G. King, Imatron's director of clinical science and the developer of the coronary artery scan function. "That's why it's very good for screening -- the object is you don't want anybody walking away from the test who has disease undetected."
Mr. King, 44, was on the team at EMI Ltd. of England that developed the first CT scanner in 1973, and had a strong motive for being the first patient scanned by the Ultrafast CT four years ago -- a cholesterol reading of 330, far above the 200 considered normal. Yet a scan of his arteries showed no calcification, fueling his belief that many people are given costly cholesterol-lowering drugs when in fact they do not have atherosclerosis. Coronary artery scanning could reduce or eliminate this unnecessary medication, he said.
In addition to showing the presence of calcium, Ultrafast CT can compute the amount present by computing the square area occupied by the deposits. Follow-up scans can then show the progression of the disease, or the impact of drugs or diet on halting it. About 6 out of 10 asymptomatic patients have no calcium. For the remaining four, two typically have small amounts, and should have follow-up scans; two have advanced disease and should see a cardiologist for drugs or other therapy to lower cholesterol, according to Imatron.
The Ultrafast CT units sell for about $2 million, although most hospitals lease them. Most hospitals charge $350 to $400 to perform an Ultrafast scan. Imatron has sold 50 scanners worldwide, 14 of them last year. Some analysts say sales would be stronger but for the poor marketing skills of a company run by scientists. But some physicians blame the cardiology community itself for clinging to older tests, even though they may be more dangerous and expensive, in the case of angiography (a $1,500 test in which a dye is injected into the arteries and an X-ray is taken), or less conclusive, in the case of treadmill tests or simple cholesterol counts.
"Cardiologists are in love with angiography," said Bruce H. Brundage, chief of cardiology at Harbor U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Torrance, Calif., and the first physician to use Ultrafast CT to scan for coronary artery disease. "The hard facts of life out there are that there is still an economic incentive to do angiograms," he said. "Any relatively inexpensive test might be threatening to them."
AND even some supporters of Ultrafast CT say that Imatron has erred in promoting it so heavily as a screening device for coronary artery disease when it actually has many functions that would better justify its considerable cost. These include imaging the action of the heart muscle, defective valves, and even tumors within the heart itself.
Patrick F. Sheedy 2d, a professor of diagnostic radiology at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., said the company risks alienating heart specialists by promoting its scan over long-established procedures. "The wild-eyed enthusiast is not going to convince all the cardiologists in the country that this is what they ought to do," he said. Nevertheless, the Mayo Clinic has two Ultrafast CT's and has scanned several hundred patients.
Another question is, "once you find the presence of coronary calcium, what does it mean," said Dr. Brundage of Harbor U.C.L.A. Medical Center, which also has two Imatron devices. "How aggressive should we be once we identify it? It seems to me we should define risk relative to age." One comforting fact, for those whose tests are clean: "the absence of calcium virtually excludes coronary artery disease," Dr. Brundage said.
The reluctance of insurers to pay for costly screening tests like the Ultrafast for asymptomatic patients has contributed to the slow acceptance of Imatron's device. Yet that price could fall as low as $100 in sufficient volume, or about the same as a cholesterol test, which insurers do pay for.
Mr. King said he thinks that ultimately insurers will realize it is less costly to prevent disease than to treat it. "We are spending more and more dollars on people who are sick, people with advanced disease who have had heart attacks," he said. "Finding the disease earlier, preventing the coronary events, preventing people from going on drugs unnecessarily, will save money."

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Women Talk About What They Want

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
SOME time back, when my mother was in the market for her first new car, she called to say that she had been reading up on automobiles and she had been shopping around.
"I think I've found what I want," she said. "But the best thing about it is that the salesman is a woman." 
 We talked about the vehicle -- a Plymouth compact -- and we agreed that it was probably just right for her. "I'm glad," she said, "because I wouldn't buy it if you didn't approve. But I'll tell you something else. I also wouldn't buy it if I couldn't buy it from a woman."
At the time, my mother was 74 years old and not exactly a feminist. But her tour of the showrooms had demonstrated what so many women have learned: Car salesmen frequently treat them with condescension, no matter that they've done their homework.
More and more dealerships are addressing the problem, though, if not because of a social conscience then because it is simply good business. Female buyers now represent nearly half the market, and they influence much of the rest of it.
They also know their own minds, according to a couple of new studies, one by J. D. Power and Associates, the other conducted for Woman's Day magazine.
The Power Report, a newsletter published by the California consulting firm, notes in this month's issue that women were the principal drivers of 46 percent of the new cars registered for personal use between May of 1990 and April 1991. Of those, it says, small and sporty cars predominated.
Tom Healey, director of media and advertising for J. D. Power, said the company's data show that the Geo Storm and the Isuzu I-Mark were the models with the highest incidence of female drivers and that economy seemed to be the primary selling point. Next in popularity with women, he said, were the Nissan Pulsar, Volkswagen Cabriolet and Eagle Summit.
"There is some reflection in the data of how much women can or want to spend for new cars," Healey said. "It seems to me, though, that there is also an element of fun and style in the choices."
Safety, too, is high on the list, according to the Woman's Day survey in which 1,000 women across the country were contacted by Yankelovich Clancy Shulman, an independent polling company. While about a quarter cited operating costs as the most important selling point, 23 percent said they were looking for safety.
The most-wanted feature, cited by 86 percent of the respondents, was a driver's air bag. Passenger bags and antilock brakes tied at 84 percent, followed by traction control (82 percent), anti-theft systems (54 percent), four-wheel drive (44 percent) and keyless remote locks (37 percent).
The study conflicts somewhat with the data from J. D. Power in that the majority of the women said they drove domestic cars. Asked which they thought were better, nearly half said domestic, 32 percent said foreign and 21 percent were unsure.
The vote for "vehicle driven most often" went to sedans, with 52 percent. Hatchbacks and sports cars were predictably most popular with younger and single women, and women with children preferred vans over station wagons.
Also no surprise was the fact that men and women like different sorts of automobiles. Traditional muscle cars such as Chevrolet's Camaro and Ford's Mustang are bought mostly by males, according to the Power survey. Luxury models and high-priced sports cars also tend to have a masculine audience.
Most of the women responding to the poll by Woman's Day said the thing they liked best about their cars was the handling. To nearly half, the car was an expression of their personalities, and 70 percent said the vehicles gave them a sense of independence.
On the negative side, cost of operation was the biggest complaint, but the women also said they were not averse to doing some maintenance jobs themselves. Most said they did not mind filling the gas tank or checking the oil.
Surprisingly in this era of maintenance-free cars, 40 percent also said they would be comfortable jump-starting the engine, and 28 percent said they would change their own flat tire.
Jane Chesnutt, the magazine's editor, said she thinks one of the more interesting aspects of the study also was women's influence in the purchase of family cars.
"Sixty-five percent share the decision equally with their husbands when buying themselves a car, and 22 percent say they're the primary decision maker," she said. "Forty-five percent say they play an equal part in the decision to buy their husbands' cars."
They also say, almost to a woman, that they have veto power over cars that fail to move them.
And, like my mother, nearly two-thirds said salesmen treated them worse than they treated men. Specifically, the women said, the tactics that bothered them most were pushiness and being treated "like an invisible person."
Some of the dealers, it seems, have yet to see the light.

GRAPHIC: Table: "The Gender Gap" lists the top 10 models as preferred by women and men, according to a study of 1990-91 car registrations by J. D. Power and Associates, a California consulting firm. (Source: J. D. Power and Associates)

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Rebecca L. Walzer, Keith S. Goldfeld

 BODY:
Rebecca Leah Walzer, a daughter of Michael and Judith B. Walzer of Princeton, N.J., was married there last evening to Keith Stuart Goldfeld, the son of Stephen and Laura Goldfeld of Princeton. Rabbi Edward Feld performed the ceremony at the Institute for Advanced Study, where the bride's father is a professor of social science.

HEADLINE: Pro-Choice Means Women Can Make Decisions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While I respect Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and appreciated his pro-America, pro-change, pro-choice address at the Democratic National Convention, I must take issue with his "Reducing Casualties in the Abortion Battle" (Op-Ed, Aug. 5). 
 As an abortion rights activist, I realize the need to find a common ground between the opposing sides. However, a pro-choice stand encompasses not only the abortion issue; pro-choice is pro-individual freedom. The Governor attempts to include the pro-life ideology to the extent that he misrepresents the pro-choice side, which he publicly advocates.
His emphasis on abstinence, "the path of restraint," is insulting to women and men. Governor Cuomo seems to argue that the only purpose of sex should be reproduction. The decision to have sex for reproduction or for pleasure and intimacy must be made by two consenting, protected individuals; it should not be legislated by government.
With the freedom of self-determination that this country grants comes responsibility. Because unprotected sex can affect more than the individual by passing a disease or bringing a child into the world, we must advocate birth control and safe sex, as Mr. Cuomo states, but ultimately it is up to the individual. Our schools have the responsibility to educate about contraception, as he says. But a problem lies in trying to unite the pro-choice and the pro-life sides because many people who oppose abortion rights also oppose contraception.
Mr. Cuomo's examination of adoption seems also to pander to the pro-life faction. Yes, adoption is an option for women who have white, healthy babies. Minority and handicapped babies often sit in orphanages for years.
I wholeheartedly applaud his suggestion, which follows the New York State model, to aid women financially who decide to bring a child to term, especially as the pro-life movement seems to see life as starting at conception and ending at birth. They force women to have babies and then oppose programs to help impoverished women raise these children.
However, Mr. Cuomo writes of abortion for those women who "consider abortion because of economic extremity," meaning abortion is only acceptable in certain financial situations. What of teen-agers or single parents who do not feel ready to give a child what it needs emotionally?
Governor Cuomo makes a judgment about when it is permissible for a woman to have an abortion. Abortion rights activists fight to keep abortion an option for all women. The pro-choice stand, unlike the pro-life stand, acknowledges women as intelligent, rational beings who can make this very serious and personal decision for themselves without government intervention.
The movement needs Governor Cuomo, a strong pro-choice advocate with acuteness and political power. However, it is vital to acknowledge that pro-choice extends to individual freedom because, without that, this country is not a democracy. This right goes hand in hand with responsibility. However, it is not as easy as Mr. Cuomo suggests to unite both sides of the debate, because the right to choose abortion is not an isolated issue.
 
JILLIAN STRAUS
Washington, Aug. 6, 1992

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Divided Government: Messy, but Not Fatal

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN accepting renomination last week, President Bush sounded one of the fundamental themes of his re-election campaign. He assailed Congress for its failure to approve many of his proposals on education, health care, crime and taxes.
Mr. Bush is sure to hammer that theme again and again in the next 10 weeks, in the hope that voters will blame Congress rather than him for the stagnation of the economy and other domestic problems. Mr. Bush's indictment of Congress reflects the conventional wisdom in Washington, which holds that Government is inevitably paralyzed when one party controls the White House and the other controls Congress. 
 But is that so? In a recent book, "Divided We Govern" (Yale University Press, 1991), Prof. David R. Mayhew, a political scientist at Yale, challenges the conventional wisdom. He studied 267 major laws enacted from 1947 through 1990 and concluded that divided partisan control of Congress and the White House makes "very little difference" in the output of legislation.
"From the Taft-Hartley Act and Marshall Plan of 1947-48 through the Clean Air Act and $490 billion deficit-reduction package of 1990, important laws have materialized at a rate largely unrelated to conditions of party control," Mr. Mayhew says in his book.
His finding suggests that governments with a Republican President and a Democratic Congress, seen as the norm in recent years, may not be cause for so much consternation as many people believe. Conversely, it suggests that Gov. Bill Clinton might not have clear sailing with Congress if he wins the Presidential election.
Words like "deadlock" and "stalemate" are often used to describe the situation on Capitol Hill. Mr. Bush continually rails against "the gridlocked Democratic Congress," as he did in his acceptance speech. Congress, he says, has become a "master of inaction," and he invites voters to "join me in rolling away the roadblock at the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue." But Mr. Bush has done less than some of his predecessors to roll away that roadblock.
 
The Great Persuaders
 Professor Mayhew found that strong Presidential leadership and strong commitment to solving national problems could create broad bipartisan majorities for the passage of major bills even in times of divided government.
He cites these examples: the Civil Rights Acts of 1957 and 1960, the Landrum-Griffin Labor Reform Act of 1959, the Tax Reform Act of 1969, the Clean Air Act of 1970, the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, the New York City bailout in 1975 and the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986.
President Richard M. Nixon extracted large amounts of legislation from a Democratic Congress. If Mr. Bush needs a more recent model for such collaboration, he can look to Ronald Reagan, who blustered, wheedled and manipulated Congress until it passed many of his proposals.
Most notably in 1981, Mr. Reagan persuaded a Democratic House to pass the biggest tax cut in American history and a separate bill that trimmed spending in myriad programs, including welfare, food stamps, Social Security, education, housing and farm subsidies.
Mr. Reagan had a powerful, coherent vision of smaller Government, and he pursued it doggedly. He sensed shifts in national mood and exploited them to advance his budget-cutting, tax-cutting program.
By contrast, Mr. Bush's domestic proposals seemed to have no unifying theme and often read like a laundry list. He has not shown the will to ram legislation through Congress, and he has not given Congress a clear sense of his own priorities. Neither he nor his lieutenants have shown much appetite for a sustained engagement with Congress on the complex details of health-care, budget and tax legislation.
 
Budget Rejected
 When Mr. Bush's budget was laid before the House of Representatives in March of this year, it was rejected by a vote of 370 to 42. Republicans voted against it by a margin of nearly 3 to 1. Representative C. W. Bill Young, Republican of Florida, voted for it, but said he disliked the proposal to increase Medicare premiums for elderly people with incomes over $100,000 for an individual or $125,000 for a couple.
Mr. Bush did little to whip up Congressional support for his budget. The idea of tying Federal payments to family income was a cornerstone of his effort to restrain the growth of benefit programs, which account for half of all Federal spending.
Mr. Mayhew's study suggests that Gov. Bill Clinton may be raising unrealistic expectations if he thinks he can work miracles with a Democratic Congress. President Jimmy Carter had more than a few problems with Democratic power barons on Capitol Hill. "To suppose that an American party winning Congress and the Presidency thereby wins the leeway of a British parliamentary party is to be deluded by the election returns," Professor Mayhew says in his book.
James L. Sundquist, a political scientist at the Brookings Institution, a research center in Washington, says that for much of the period from 1947 to 1990, the Democratic Party was itself deeply divided, and conservative Democrats often collaborated with Republicans.
But many of those conservative Democratic Southern lawmakers have been replaced by moderate Democrats more aligned with the outlook of the national party. So Mr. Clinton, if elected, might have an easier time dealing with Congress than Mr. Carter did. "If Democrats again have an opportunity to run a unified Government," said Mr. Sundquist, "it will be more cohesive and ideologically homogeneous." Of course Mr. Bush argues that electing a Republican President and a Republican Congress would also produce a more cohesive, harmonious and productive government.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Crazy for Country Music

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
TWO guys are running for President.
One lost his father before he was born, was raised by an alcoholic, abusive stepfather, and has a gambling mother who has been married five times, to four men. He's had to own up to some of the most publicized marital troubles of modern times, and has a brother who he helped land hard time for a coke rap. 
 The other was the pride of Greenwich Country Day School, where he arrived each morning in a chauffeured sedan. At Yale, he was tapped by Skull and Bones, America's most exclusive secret society. His mother was a tennis champion and he spends as much time as he can each year at the family compound in Maine.
Which life sounds like a country music song?
"I'm pretty certain there has never been a presidential candidate that seems to spring more clearly from the world of country music than Bill Clinton," said John Morthland, author of the standard 1984 reference book, "The Best of Country Music."
"It's always been about working class people from the Bible Belt," he said. "Democrats mostly, rowdy people who stray and regret it. Unlike what you saw in Houston, the music has always supported a huge diversity of values."
But it is the unrowdy Mr. Bush who subscribes to Country Music magazine, while Mr. Clinton pledges his allegiance to Elvis. (Like the Holy City of Jerusalem -- a touchstone for three of the world's major religions -- the King is considered sacred by fans of both rock and country.)
Over the past four years the President has made much of his love of country music. The devotion is genuine, but it is one that also seeks to remind those disaffected, hard-scrabble Reagan Democrats that their true compatriot in this election from Houston, not from Hope.
 
D-I-V-O-R-C-E
 Nothing could have made that case more forcefully than when Hillary Clinton asserted her identity earlier this year by taking a swipe at "Stand By Your Man," Tammy Wynette's anthem to the long-suffering wife. At the time, nobody mentioned another hit by Ms. Wynette: "D-I-V-O-R-C-E," nor has anybody in the Republican Party lately been heard humming the Johnny Cash classic, "A Boy Named Sue."
Drawing political values from music can be a tricky business, as the Republicans should have noticed by now. Country music in particular has never sold better to the suburban voters whom both parties lust after.
But for every song that evokes nostalgic images of religion, patriotism and plucky independence, there are at least three that go the other way, sounding themes of adultery (George Strait's "All My Ex's Live in Texas" comes to mind), booze and wanton dissolution. Temptation -- whether it's the lure of the bottle (as in George Jones's "If Drinkin' Don't Kill Me, Her Memory Will"), of the road (Roger Miller's "King of the Road"), or of another woman (David Allan Coe's "Now I Lay Me Down to Cheat") -- runs like a ruby red weave through country music.
Just check out the lineup at the convention. Wynonna Judd, one of the Republican's most cherished sweethearts, performed. But so did Tanya Tucker, the 33-year-old one-woman showcase for vocal purity and sexual liberty. Ms. Tucker, who once bragged that she has had more boyfriends than some people have had hot meals and who is an unwed mother of two, is no Murphy Brown. The last time Ms. Tucker appeared at a Republican convention, in 1980, she sang a duet with her beau at the time, Glen Campbell. She was 21, he was 44.
 
Stand by Your Music
 Lee Greenwood introduced Barbara Bush on the night she had staked out to honor traditional families. Mr. Greenwood is from the most commercial strain of country -- a music by and about white people -- and he's as proud of that as he is of America. Just now he is on his fifth wife, who, like Ms. Tucker, has two children born out of wedlock.
"Do these people ever actually listen to our songs?" said Rodney Crowell, a country music veteran whose newest album, "Life is Messy," pretty much sums up the dimestore philosophy of many of his musical colleagues. "George Bush came down to the Country Music Awards show earlier this year. Has this American art form fallen so low in self-esteem that we would just turn our award ceremony into a campaign event for a guy who doesn't even talk about any of our problems?"
Country musicians often address themes the Democrats hope to win with -- the economy, education and jobs. Buck Owen's 1966 hit, for example, "Waiting in Your Welfare Line," is a song ostensibly about a man seeking a handout of love. But they apply their true ardor to songs about God and Mama.
As always, God played a big role at the Republican convention, appearing in almost every speech. But perhaps it was Kitty Wells, the first queen of modern country music, who presented the strongest vision of the Lord's sense of life among the earthy in her signature song, "It Wasn't God Who Made Honky Tonk Angels."
Many people have noted that the real Southerners in the race, Mr. Clinton and, of course, Albert Gore of Tennessee pretty much steer clear of country music.
Perhaps because they don't want to rub the country's face in the fact that they both come from the South, it seems unlikely that they're going to want to spend much time fronting a fiddle band.
But this year the Democrats may be taking an even greater musical risk than the Republicans by favoring rock 'n' roll. Mr. Clinton wanted James Brown's "I Feel Good" as a theme song until an alert aide reminded him that Mr. Brown had just gotten out of prison for aggravated assault and carrying a shotgun. After his staff bought what seemed like half the compact disks in America, he settled for a convention finale of "Don't Stop Thinking About Tomorrow" by Fleetwood Mac, a group that has had at least its fair share of problems with traditional family values.

HEADLINE: AUGUST 16-22: Panic Control;
Japan Gives Banks a Break To Save the Market As a Recession Threatens

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Japan's Minister of Finance put his finger in the dike last week, announcing measures to discourage banks from dumping shares into the cratering stock market. The move was cheered as a step away from financial panic. But far more is needed to contain the flood.
Like their American counterparts, Japanese banks are sitting on humongous losses in commercial real estate. And to raise money for dividends, they have been tempted to sell securities bought for a song before the market peaked in 1989. 
 But with stocks already down by three-fifths -- some $3 trillion -- and the economy sputtering toward recession, the Government is eager to halt the vicious cycle in which the banks' rush to liquidity tightens the noose on businesses already lacking cash. Under the new rules, banks are allowed to pay dividends without showing profits. And as long as they hang onto stocks that have fallen in value, they can avoid revealing the losses on their balance sheets.
This is a palliative, everyone agrees, not a cure for what ails the over-extended Japanese financial system. Indeed, it smacks of the desperate efforts in the mid-1980's to postpone the day of reckoning for America's savings and loans.
What could make a real difference, though, is a stiff dose of public spending that generates jobs and profits. Just such a $25 billion to $50 billion package was promised at the Munich economic summit in July and is expected to be proposed formally within weeks.
