LENGTH: 1462 words

HEADLINE: IDENTITY CRISIS;
Being Whatever It Takes to Win Election

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT'S going to be a crowded autumn.
There are, as far as can be seen through the fog, four serious candidates for the Presidency. On the Democratic side, there is Bill Clinton, the big-government, tax-crazy, special-interests-loving, old-fashioned liberal; and Bill Clinton, the covenant-building, moderate-minded, stand-up-to-the-interest-groups New Democrat. The Republicans have put forward George Bush, the vacillating, pawn-of-the-rich, inside Washington, country-clubbing middle-of-the-roader who wants everything to stay just the way it is; and George Bush, the arch-conservative, deeply religious, tax-cutting, Washington-bashing architect of bold new change. 
 This embarrassment of candidates was nearly inevitable. Men who want to be President, and the men and women whose job it is to get them there, are, despite their predilection for the language of idealism, strictly in the realism business. They do, as Mr. Bush has famously noted, whatever it takes. And what it takes, it has become increasingly clear, is a campaign of relentless, comprehensive distortion.
As the Republicans convened in Houston last week, the NBC news anchor Tom Brokaw offered an observation on the way journalists have come to cover political campaigns:
"The news cycle has become a 24-hour-a-day thing, and it moves very fast all the time now. What happens is that a fragment of information, true or false, gets sucked into the cycle early in the morning, and once it gets into the cycle it gets whipped around to the point that it has gravitas by the end of the day. And, unfortunately, people are so busy chasing that fragment of information that they treat it as a fact, forgetting about whether it is true or not."
The professionals of politics know that Mr. Brokaw is correct, and bank on it. In a time of information overwhelm, with the electoral process uncontrolled by party discipline and with the fates of candidates almost utterly dependent on the whims of passing public perception, they understand that the essential daily achievement of the candidate is to do himself right, and his opponent wrong, by that day's flow of pictures and words.
The flow is so fast, and so endless, that it is impossible for most voters (and for most journalists) to examine its contents except by occasional, shallow dips in the edge of the stream. The result is the campaign of 1992, which, although it still has months to go, has already reached new levels of manipulation of truth. On both the Republican and Democratic sides, the candidates and their campaign staffs are relentless in their efforts to idealize themselves and to demonize each other.
Indeed, this dual task was the only important goal of both the Democratic nominating convention held in New York last month and the Republican gathering in Houston. In both cases, the goal was achieved superbly.
Thus, Mr. Clinton, in the course of his party's nominating convention, and in the weeks since, has drawn a picture of himself as the exemplar of a new breed of Democrats that knows how to say no to constituency groups, is tough on defense, serious about cutting government spending and opposed to radical notions of any sort. There is evident truth in this portrait; the Arkansas Governor is a charter member of the Democratic Leadership Council, the centrist group dedicated to these propositions, and his record as governor shows that he consistently has favored the centrist, compromise approach.
In the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton has advocated reforming the welfare system to oblige able recipients to work and establishing boot camps that would offer "harsh punishment" to juvenile criminals.
While he has supported legal abortion, he has suggested that states should have the right to impose some limits on abortions, and has argued that the government should do what it can "to make it as rare as possible."
He has angered some black political leaders with his (rather gentle) admonitions to black audiences on the necessity for self-discipline and a sense of responsibility.
But in the crucial matters of his economic plan and his party platform, said a leading policy expert of the left who spoke on the condition of anonymity because he did not want to represent the view of any party faction, Mr. Clinton has "put forward the most progressive agenda since 1972, put forward under a smoke screen that this was the most moderate Democratic convention and the most moderate Democratic platform ever."
Mr. Clinton has promised to re-distribute wealth by raising taxes on the rich, to double the rate of cutting the military budget, to invest huge sums in creating jobs by building roads and bridges, to hugely increase education spending, to fully fund Head Start, to provide national health care for everyone and paid for in part by new taxes and to give poor families tax credits.
Several consultants on Democratic policy called it the most progressive redistribution-of-wealth plan since the campaign of George S. McGovern.
Similarly, Mr. Clinton's campaign has in recent weeks put forward an image of his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, as a cookie-baking, home-making old-fashioned candidate's spouse, preferring to ignore her long and substantive career as a lawyer, liberal legal philosopher and advocate of profound change in the legal status and rights of children.
Building on these aspects of Mr. Clinton's views and life, Mr. Bush and his operatives will spend the next several months, as they have spent the past several days, working to create an opponent of nightmarish proportions -- a sort of Bill Dukakis-Carter-McGovern-Clinton.
A classic and important example can be found in the Republicans' charge -- employed by many during the convention week, including Mr. Bush himself -- that Mr. Clinton had raised taxes and fees 128 times in his home state of Arkansas.
As the columnist Michael Kinsley detailed in a recent report, the figure of 128 is false, based on trickery like counting taxes more than once, counting components of certain taxes as separate taxes in themselves, and including a number of minor fee increases that are a routine and inevitable feature of all governments. The accounting also fails to mention tax cuts enacted during Mr. Clinton's tenure as governor, or to note that Arkansas, a poor state, ranks 47th among the states in terms of the taxes it imposes as a share of personal income.
Mr. Bush's attempts to rework his self-portrait have been far more ambitious and more elaborate than Mr. Clinton's; their scope is breathtaking at times.
A President whose primary interest has been foreign affairs, Mr. Bush now depicts himself as a visionary of domestic change frustrated by a Democratic-controlled Congress. The son of a United States Senator, a child of wealth and privilege, the product of Andover, Yale and Greenwich, Conn., he styles himself as a man of down-home Texas country. A career public official who has spent most of his adult life in appointive or elected office in Washington, he now runs -- and rails -- against the bureaucrats and politicians of the Federal city.
An instinctive moderate who earned the enmity of religious and values-oriented conservatives in his first term, he now runs on a 'family values" agenda that the supporters of conservatives like Pat Buchanan and Pat Robertson regard as their own. The signatory of a tax increase that broke the defining promise of his 1988 Presidential candidacy, he now places the blame for that increase entirely on Congress, and promises a new tax cut if re-elected.
 
The Bush Bogeyman
 With ammunition like that, Mr. Clinton finds it a simple matter to mold from the stuff of Mr. Bush's record and life a counterpart to the Republican Clinton-bogey, a George Hoover-McCarthy-Goldwater-Bush. The Bush-bogeyman, to hear Mr. Clinton tell it, is an irresponsible do-nothing President who is solely to blame for all that is wrong with the country, and gets no credit for anything that is right. The America Mr. Clinton conjures of the Reagan-Bush years seems a country of such dark, dismal misery as to be at times unrecognizable to one who lived in it.
It is a political given that both candidates will continue on this course; it has worked too well for them not to. Mr. Clinton's convention, with its days of praise for himself and its days of denigration of Mr. Bush, took him from well behind in the polls to far ahead. Mr. Bush's convention, which exceeded even Mr. Clinton in both puffery and calumny, seems to have brought him back on par with his rival.
Neither the mythical candidates of self-creation nor the bogeymen of the other side will be real, but reality-based. And, in the age of the docu-drama, that will be good enough for one of them to win.

PUB-DATE: August 23, 1992

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1126 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Seeing Foreign Policy In a Rear-View Mirror

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
THE striking thing about the discussion of foreign policy so far in this election season is the gap between the weighty issues at stake and the content of the debate. It would be hard to recall a campaign in which so little has been said about so much by so many.
True, at last month's Democratic convention in New York, where Gov. Bill Clinton devoted 141 words to foreign policy in his acceptance speech, Democrats debated foreign policy in the halls. But it was not the traditional arguments between realists and idealists, interventionists and isolationists. The debate almost seemed to be between people who believe that the country should have a foreign policy and people who believe that it should not -- that after the cold war, the focus had to be at home because domestic issues were so pressing. At the Republican convention last week foreign policy figured in almost every speech, but not because there was any serious discussion of the issues. 
 Instead, foreign policy has been turned into the Bush campaign's all-purpose cleanser. It is being used to wipe away or excuse shortcomings of the Bush Presidency.
For instance, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Mr. Bush had broken his no-new-taxes pledge mainly because he needed Congressional backing for the Persian Gulf War and because the President had a lot of distractions on his mind, including Iraqi "threats to poison the Bethesda, Md., water supply" or to rain missiles on the United States. Mr. Brady said this in all seriousness.
Speaker after speaker at the Astrodome said in effect that George Bush might not have had much of a domestic policy, but that was because he was totally preoccupied with winning the cold war. No one mentioned, however, that Franklin D. Roosevelt had managed simultaneously to promulgate and manage the New Deal while ushering the nation into World War II.
 
Justified in Churchillian Terms
 Even the shift of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to the White House, a desperate political move aimed at rescuing the Bush campaign, was justified in Churchillian terms more appropriate for the Council on Foreign Relations than for a smoke-filled room. In a world where power abroad increasingly depends on economic strength at home, Mr. Bush said, it is crucial to merge foreign and domestic policy in the White House. Why the President just happened to realize this in the heat of the campaign was left unsaid.
In a way, Mr. Bush's own campaign theme -- we saved the world in the first four years, now we will save America in the next four -- has unintentionally nurtured the impression that foreign policy is like a diet you can turn on and off. But foreign policy cannot be put on hold. Indeed, the next President will have to be able to walk and chew gum as never before.
In the wake of the cold war, the United States is entering a period of zero-based foreign policy. All issues -- from whether or not to maintain troops abroad to whether or not to bother solving regional problems like the Middle East -- are up for grabs.
Yet, to the extent that there has been a foreign policy debate in this campaign, it has been entirely backward looking, with Mr. Bush using his successes abroad to excuse shortcomings at home and Mr. Clinton focusing his critique on Mr. Bush's coddling of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq before the gulf war, while trying to ignore Mr. Bush's successful handling of the war itself.
But one wonders whether four years from now this campaign will be looked back on for the paucity of serious discussion about issues as elemental as how to meet the challenge of Japan, or respond to the ethnic violence in Europe.
"One reason for campaigns is to enable the candidate to build a mandate to govern," the foreign policy historian Michael Beschloss said. "When you have a campaign that is a silly season on foreign affairs, the result is that the President has to build a mandate from scratch after he takes office -- without really knowing what support is out there."
The disconnectedness of the current foreign policy debate is underscored by the fact that within the last week the Administration has initiated a dramatic shift of policy toward Iraq. It is a shift that could very easily lead to the disintegration of Iraq, and no one has told the American people, let alone debated it.
Britain, Saudi Arabia and France have agreed in principle to an American proposal to shoot down any Iraqi fighter planes that try to attack the rebellious Shiite Muslims who live below the 32d parallel.
President Hussein has been engaged in a brutal repression of the region's Shiite Muslims, who would like to carve out their own state. Since the end of the gulf war in March 1991, the United States has chosen not to intervene there, arguing that intervention could lead to a breakup of Iraq and that would upset the fragile balance of power in that corner of the world.
 
Why Iraq but Not Bosnia?
 But now Washington and its allies have reversed course and decided that they are ready to risk a disintegration of Iraq to expel Mr. Hussein. Yet no one has really explained this to the public, or explained why Washington would shoot down Iraqi planes that kill Shiites but not Serbian planes that kill Bosnians.
In part, this is because President Bush has long had an aversion to discussing his foreign policy moves in public. His policy has always been like a well-acted silent movie for an audience that enjoys singing along. But it is also because Mr. Clinton has been loath to challenge him on current Iraq policy for fear of looking soft or unpatriotic, and for fear of shifting the debate from at home to abroad, which plays to Mr. Bush's strength.
Moreover, Mr. Clinton does not seem to have made up his own mind on future foreign policy. He is not ready to posit a Wilsonian or Carteresque morally based foreign policy to contrast with Mr. Bush's pragmatic, interest-based handling of the issue. Mr. Clinton has tried to mix moralism with muscle, selectively accusing President Bush of being overly cynical in coddling tyrants from Baghdad to Beijing, but not suggesting that he would be excessively moralistic. This middle-of-the-roadism is not exactly great timber for a fiery debate.
And over and above all this, the poverty of real foreign policy debate can be explained by something very simple: that a bipartisan intuition is now taking hold among Republicans and Democrats.
It is an intuition that the post-cold war world is a tangled mess, where every situation is painted in shades of gray and where there will be no easy victories to be plucked. The reason both parties have focused their debate backwards is because that is the only direction in which they can see clearly any more.

HEADLINE: Women Get Into Political Football -- as the Ball

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
STANDING before a prime-time crowd that screamed their names in adulation, Barbara Bush and Marilyn Quayle led the Republican Party into a frenzy of family values on Wednesday night, taking turns before an audience of 23 million. Signs bearing their names appeared among the faithful. "Barbara for President" was one popular, if less than serious sentiment. And cries of "Ma-ree-lyn" resounded just as loudly as any cheer ever sent up in the Houston Astrodome.
It was a galvanizing moment, the work of pros. 
 So was the script that preceded. In back-to-back interviews leading up to Family Night, Mrs. Bush and Mrs. Quayle protested repeatedly that they were well-meaning but of no real account. Both said they had not bothered to read the party platform and allowed that they were just amazed to be flung up to the political front lines. Barbara Bush warned of an "overrated" speech by an "overrated" speaker. Mrs. Quayle dismissed her contribution as nothing more than "a teeny weeny little talk."
These affecting moments, too, were the work of pros.
At a time of social change, when the stay-at-home images of women are being constantly challenged and reworked, the Republicans last week effectively mixed old "aw shucks" rhetoric with the fact that this cyclone-prone political season has swept women center stage. There are, of course, some hardball politics at work here. Seven million more women than men voted in the last three Presidential elections. Both sides need those votes. Yet, however complicated the living and working arrangements of 1992 may be, simple messages still sell best. So the Republicans brought out an old one: Women, God bless them, are happier at home. And those who aren't can hurt you.
The role of the politicians' wives, so inconsequential in most years, has become a core question. And with no fallback formula, the political solution has become to give voters a little bit of everything.
Republicans have sculpted an array of messages combining competence with a total lack of threat. Mrs. Quayle befuddled a whole generation of women when she said "Most women do not wish to be liberated from their essential natures" -- without explaining whether the receptionist who works for minimum wage because she must has abandoned some profound part of her being. By contrast, Barbara Bush, reputed to be a scrapper in private, bounds about with a self-deprecating grandma demeanor in public. The Democrats, lacking that convincing retro-mom and retro-granny combo, have to face the tougher issues head on. After hailing Hillary Clinton as a model new woman able to balance a family and a thriving law practice, Democrats retreated in the face of stinging criticism and rewrote the script for their leading lady. By early summer, Mrs. Clinton's image had metamorphosed from that of mother, lawyer and outspoken champion of the Children's Defense Fund to a presumably kinder, quieter wife and mother who beams incessantly at her man. The make-over helped quell alarm that she would crash the White House as Mr. Clinton's equal. But the attacks are still coming.
Thus, during the Democratic convention, there was no Hillary Clinton center stage to do anything but clap, smile and do a little dancing. Instead, the Democrats addressed the gender gap by trotting out their female candidates and setting them up in a grand tableau that stretched the length of the Madison Square Garden stage. They also indulged in a fair amount of talk about "skirt-tails," giving a nod to the fact that Bill Clinton could use a boost from Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein, the popular Senatorial candidates from California -- not the other way around.
The Republicans never really had that option. Any showcase of their women candidates would have undoubtedly risked awkward reminders of the bitter abortion debate. So they shifted course. "There has been a basic strategy this year by the Democrats saying that it is the 'Year of the Women,' " said Ian Weinschel, a political consultant who helped shape Patrick Buchanan's candidacy. Not wanting to be outdone, the Republicans figured out how to show off one of their prime political assets, Barbara Bush, while also sounding the horn for their favorite family values theme. "From a pure strategy standpoint," said Mr. Weinschel, "it made a lot of sense to put Barbara on."
The result is that Americans are now faced with cardboard cutouts that match political agendas more than real life. "People don't really know what to do with women in power," said Barrie Thorne, the head of the women's studies department at the University of Southern California. "Nancy Reagan was the 'vanity queen' to Barbara Bush's 'Queen Mum.' But these are all like plots of novels."
Low-income women who feel demonized by the Republican attacks on their absence from home, yet unfulfilled by low-paid and low-skilled jobs, often simply can't relate. The First Four Ladies, said Sandy Pope, a former executive director of the Coalition of Labor Union Women, "are financially able to make a whole array of choices that most of us aren't. We are debating about whether somebody should have given up their law practice, or whether someone has a 'real' family because they only had one child. But what is the real message? That these men's wives can stay home with the babies if George Bush goes back to the White House? Fine. But where's the economic program to make that possible?"
There are downsides for both sides. "For the Republicans to have a grandmotherly wife as the symbol of womanhood is a little out of step," said Ruth B. Mandel, director of the Rutgers Center for the American Woman and Politics. "It's a nostalgic image and therefore may seem safer for prime time. But to me it's a sign of total desperation."
Hillary Clinton's image as a softened-up professional has left some voters cold as well. Some working women resent the obvious repackaging as a stab at their own lives. "What is wrong with someone who is a dedicated mother and also works?" said Barbara D. Boehm, a wife, mother and associate curator at New York's Metropolitan Museum.
She believes the women are merely being used to deflect attention from issues like abortion and the economy. She is angry at the prospect of a political catfight. "The idea of pitting women against women is really very disturbing," she said. "I'm particularly troubled that they are going to try and set up a 'good mom' versus 'bad mom' fight."
Christine LaFia, a sociologist at Berkeley, dreads what she sees as a Republican design to "make Hillary appear as the dragon lady and Barbara the nurturing savior of the whole female species."
The day after the Republican convention, the polls showed George Bush and Bill Clinton running nearly neck and neck. Even though many voters may resist intellectually the spectacle of women having at each other, perhaps on some subliminal level the tactic has already proved effective. Whether it will work over the long haul probably will not be known until November. By then the smear campaigns and manipulations by political staffs may have backfired. Elaine La Roche, a Wall Street investment banker and a founder of a Republican group formed to help women candidates, said she objects to the blatant attempts to sculpt the images of the candidates' wives. "I don't know that I am going to see Hillary's name on the ballot," she said. "And I find it curious that we have come to this in 1992."
It may have been easier for everyone when "the wives" were merely a matter of hats, hemlines and hairdos. But unless women do return to home and hearth, it's unlikely that voters will soon be spared a replay of this year's family feuds. It was no coincidence that Mrs. Bush and Mrs. Quayle gave endless interviews in Houston any more than it has been a fluke to see Mrs. Clinton and Mrs. Gore fade into a background of towering cornstalks and bales of hay. Is it a backlash? The wives will never say.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
NASA Chief Faces a Huge Foe in Cost Cutting

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
NASA's new administrator, lean, mean and ready do things differently, may have met his match as he wrestles with plans he inherited for a monster project that is overweight, over budget and overly political in this election year. The would-be orbiting outpost for astronauts, known as space station Freedom, could easily foil efforts at slenderizing. The cold war's end and a lingering recession have produced a major slump in the aerospace industry that no politician wants to deepen right now with a new round of layoffs.
"He has made it very clear from the beginning that he's going to trim the fat out of NASA," said Jerry Grey, head of science and technology policy for the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, an engineering society based in Washington. "But he's not going to make any major changes till after the election." 
 The space station, the centerpiece of NASA's ambitious plans for this decade and the next century, has become an unpleasant example of how badly big science can go awry. When first proposed by President Ronald Reagan in 1984, it was to be a relatively modest, $8 billion project of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration that would push back scientific frontiers and be completed in 1992, in time for the 500th anniversary of Columbus' journey to the new world.
Over time, however, its proposed size grew as NASA formed a web of scientific and contractor alliances meant to shield the project from political foes. Today, after $8 billion in design work, it is envisioned as a 350-foot hulk costing between $30 billion and $40 billion to build, with 30-year operating expenses estimated at up to $100 billion. The space shuttles would begin lofting its parts in 1995, and after 18 such flights, the structure would be permanently occupied by about the year 2000.
Its defenders say it would be useful for studying the long-term effects of weightlessness, for growing super-pure materials and crystallizing proteins that medicine needs to study and for enabling astronomical observations. Cynics say it is an extremely expensive way to do research that has either already been done on the Russian space station Mir or is not crucial anyway.
Last year Congress threatened to scrap the outpost, prompting NASA to flood Capitol Hill with promotional packets. "Space station dollars are spent on the ground!" declared one, which added that the project had a "procurement constituency" of more than 2,000 businesses in 40 states. It warned that for the Houston area alone, killing the station would mean a loss of 11,100 jobs.
Enter Daniel S. Goldin, a 52-year-old native New Yorker and industry executive with no Washington job experience who in April took NASA's helm, ready to ignite a revolution and get the agency making innovative spacecraft again -- for less money. "He's a faster, cheaper, better kind of guy," said a White House official. "He's obviously outside the NASA culture."
At TRW Inc., one of the nation's top aerospace contractors, Mr. Goldin had been influenced by the small-is-beautiful school of aerospace design, which argues that the revolution in miniaturization has opened up new ways to explore the heavens inexpensively.
At NASA Mr. Goldin started an exercise in which "red teams" and "blue teams" fought each other to find potential cost reductions of 20 percent to 40 percent. But the results on the station program were lackluster. And he did something more basic, telling the new team to explore the option of lofting the sprawling outpost without using shuttles.
 
Ride a Russian Rocket?
 "It's the first time since 1970 that there will be a serious look at what's the best station to build, rather than the best one that can fit in the shuttle," said Dr. John M. Logsdon, director of the space policy institute at George Washington University and a station historian.
The most radical outcome would be for NASA to loft station parts on a 20-story Russian rocket known as Energia, whose services the Russians have repeatedly offered. Energia, which has flown only twice and thus has unproven reliability, can in theory lift five times as much as the shuttle. And pulling back on shuttles might free billions for other NASA projects since they currently consume about half the agency's $15 billion annual budget.
The issue now facing Mr. Goldin is whether rational analysis can be reconciled with bureaucratic inertia and election-year politics. Vice President Dan Quayle, who heads the National Space Council, recently told workers at Douglas Space Systems in Huntington Beach, Calif., a major space station contractor, that their future would be assured if the Republicans stayed in power.
"As long as George Bush is President, space station Freedom is safe and so are your jobs," he told 3,500 workers on Aug. 12. Gov. Bill Clinton, contrary to Mr. Quayle's jab, has voiced support for the outpost and also advocates more teamwork with the Russians.
Experts say some slimming or delays are inevitable no matter who wins, given Congressional cutbacks. The station recently survived a major floor fight in the House, which nonetheless gave it only $1.7 billion of the Bush Administration's $2.25 billion request. The Senate gave it $2.1 billion, and the conference committee will probably split the difference at $1.9 billion.
John E. Pike, head of space policy for the Federation of American Scientists, a private group, said that, in the end, Mr. Goldin would probably be forced to make minor rearrangements in the status quo.
"My hunch," he said, "is that it's going to be like Churchill and democracy -- that space station Freedom is a bad program but all the alternatives are worse."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview;
NOMINEES CRITICIZE EACH OTHER'S PLAN TO REVIVE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
The race for the Presidency began in earnest this weekend, as President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton engaged in a furious exchange over each other's economic proposals and, by extension, their political character.
The opening debate set the tone and the subject matter for what strategists in both campaigns predict will be a harsh and brutally competitive 10-week struggle that could ultimately come down to a handful of states in the industrial Midwest. 
 Mr. Bush, reveling in polls that show him closing in on the Democrats, rolled through Georgia today with another attack on Mr. Clinton as a committed taxer and spender who would conspire with the Democratic Congress to plunder the budget.
 
Bush Emphasizes Trust
 "I'm going to ask the American people, who do you trust to bring it all home?" Mr. Bush declared at a rally of 20,000 people in Woodstock, Ga. "Foreign policy, security policy, economic policy, who do you trust?"
He added, to a roaring crowd that chanted his name: "If you listen to these guys, and you'd think the deficit is a big game of the 'Wheel of Fortune.' You know that one? They want to buy three vowels -- i.o.u. That's not good enough for the American taxpayer."
Mr. Clinton moved quickly this weekend to try to defuse Mr. Bush's promise of new across-the-board tax cuts by characterizing it as a cynical, empty gimmick with as little shelf life as Mr. Bush's promise four years ago of "no new taxes."
 
Clinton Sees 'Bogus' Claim
 Traveling on another bus trip through the critical state of Ohio, Mr. Clinton asserted that Mr. Bush's plans to revive the economy were "totally bogus." The Democratic nominee, campaigning in Parma, asserted that "he can't battle me on the economy" and contended that Mr. Bush had "imperiled our national security by having no economic policy."
Senator Al Gore, the Vice-Presidential nominee, demanded, "Do you want four more years of a read-my-lips recession?"
The first round of post-convention polls shows, once again, the extraordinary volatility of the electorate this year, with Mr. Clinton's once-formidable lead significantly eroded. A new poll for The Los Angeles Times, conducted Thursday and Friday and released today, showed Mr. Clinton now leading by 8 percentage points, down from a lead of more than 20 points the week before.
 
Travels Reflect Battlefields
 Analysts in both parties said that beneath the wild swings in the polls was the reality of a intensely competitive race in an angry and economically anxious year. "This is the most open, fickle, volatile electorate we've ever seen," said Peter Hart, a Democratic poll taker.
The candidates' travel schedules over the coming week are a road map to where this election will be fought, won and lost. Mr. Bush roared out of his convention this weekend into the South, ordinarily a Republican bastion but newly competitive this year because of the all-Southern Democratic ticket. Bush campaign advisers say they hope to consolidate their electoral base in that region and the Mountain West, then carry the battle to a belt of industrial states, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan and Illinois.
The Bush advisers say this would enable them to assemble a winning majority in the electoral vote, which is 270, even without carrying California, where the Democrats have had wide leads in this summer's polls. This explains why Mr. Bush will be at the Illinois State Fair on Sunday, and will be back in Illinois and Michigan by midweek, after a swing through Connecticut and New Jersey, where the campaign also has high hopes.
Roman Catholic voters are expected to be an important part of this industrial state strategy; they are a principal target of Mr. Bush's "school-choice" proposal, which would give parents vouchers they can use in private or religious schools. Republicans also expect them to respond to the appeal of "family values."
The Bush campaign hopes to raise economic fears in those states with its attacks on Mr. Clinton as a tax-and-spend liberal and to suggest that the Democratic ticket would put the environment over jobs, particularly jobs in the automobile industry.
 
Messages From the Bus
 The Democrats, for their part, were back in a bus this weekend, rolling through Ohio, Pennsylvania and upstate New York. By midweek, they will be on another bus trip through Texas. While Texas has been a reliable part of the Republican coalition in years past, the Clinton campaign clearly has hopes there this year.
"We're going there for a reason," said George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's deputy campaign manager.
The Clinton campaign is also trying hard to regain control of a debate it largely dominated for a solid month after the Democratic convention in New York. "Obviously, the credibility of what Bush said Thursday night will be very important to the future of this race," said Stan Greenberg, the Clinton campaign's poll taker.
Mr. Clinton and his advisers wasted little time in attacking Mr. Bush's economic proposals for across-the-board tax cuts and spending caps. They called them irresponsible gimmicks, with James Carville, a top Clinton strategist, asserting, "We're going to make them eat the numbers."
Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign, countered: "They're just calling Bush a liar, which I don't believe will work. I don't believe they want to get into a contest of who's the most trustworthy, although it's fine with us if that's what they want to do."
The Clinton campaign was also moving quickly to paint the Republicans' "family values" appeal, which reached a peak at this week's convention, as pandering to the party's right wing.
 
Predictions of Ugly Contest
 "We don't believe American families want Pat Robertson and Jerry Falwell and Pat Buchanan defining their values," Mr. Carville said. "We're going to remind the American people who was in control of that convention. They are going to hear again and again about Pat Robertson and Jerry Falwell running the convention and running the government."
Both sides predicted that the tone of the race would be ugly, and predictably blamed each other for it. "They're going to deliberately make it nasty because they don't want to talk about the real issues," said Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic National chairman.
Mr. Hart, the Democratic poll taker, said the Republican convention was filled with innuendo and outright attacks on the character of Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, who was assailed as a militant feminist who equated marriage with slavery.
Noting that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was back in political control, Mr. Hart said: "The last time around we said it was Lee Atwater's campaign; this time it's clearly Jim Baker's. He's laid his first marker down, and it's going to be brass knuckles."
The Republicans countered that their party hardly had the franchise on negative politics. "I think Clinton's losing his composure and we haven't even started yet," said Mary Matalin, deputy manager of the Bush campaign. "As Phil Gramm said, he's been running up and down the field by himself -- and there's another team on the field now."
The pace of this campaign, already unusually intense for summer, will only escalate, both sides said; the traditional start of a campaign on Labor Day has become a mere formality. Robert M. Teeter, chairman for the Bush campaign, told reporters this week that Mr. Bush "will not take any sustained period of time off and he'll be out campaigning from now on."

HEADLINE: IRAQ AIRCRAFT BAN AROUSES ARAB IRE

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Eighteen months after they helped the multi-national coalition chase Saddam Hussein from Kuwait, Egypt and Syria are keeping a distance from their former Western partners, who are bracing for another military showdown with Iraq.
In Damascus, Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa said on Friday that his Government rejected outright plans by the United States, Britain and France to bar Iraqi combat planes and helicopters from flying over southern Iraq, where they have been attacking Shiite Muslim dissidents. 
 Although the Syrian Government is a bitter foe of Mr. Hussein, Mr. Sharaa said Syria was as opposed to its former Western allies' threatening the "territorial integrity" of Iraq as it was to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait two years ago.
In its public pronouncements, Egypt, which is heavily dependent on American economic and military aid, has been much more circumspect, and neither President Hosni Mubarak nor anyone else has directly challenged the plan for what the Western allies call a "no fly" zone.
 
No Partition, Egyptian Insists
 But in remarks on Thursday, Foreign Minister Amr Moussa declared that Egypt was opposed to any attempt to "partition" Iraq, a buzzword among Arab critics who see the allied plan as leading to a de facto partition, since it would divide the country into a Kurdish region in the north and a Shiite Muslim region in the south, framing a Sunni Muslim region between them.
So far, the plan to create the protected zone, which British officials say will go into effect sometime early next week, has won the qualified support of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, which will once again furnish landing fields for allied planes involved in the operation.
Editorial comment in Egypt's semi-official press, and Egyptian officials speaking behind the scenes, have been sharply critical of the plan. For example, Samir Ragab, whose commentaries often reflect official thinking, said today that the United States initiative sets a dangerous precedent.
"What Iraq faces today could be repeated tomorrow in many other Arab countries," he wrote in the English-language Egyptian Mail.
 
Al Ahram Watches U.S. Voters
 In another editorial today, Al Ahram, Egypt's leading newspaper, suggested that the timing of any military confrontation with Iraq appeared to be governed by what it described as "narrow political interests," including what it said was President Bush's calculation that a military strike on Iran would benefit him in the fall election.
Such reactions are sharp departures Cairo's strong role in helping shape the allied coalition that faced down Iraq over Kuwait.
Cairo and Damascus not only furnished important political cover for the American-led task force but they also contributed troops to the multinational force, about 35,000 from Egypt and about 20,000 from Syria.
Some Egyptian officials fear that the latest plan is a recipe for instability and could strengthen the hand of Iran. In Mr. Moussa's remarks, in which he also called on Iraq to stop persecuting its own minorities and abide with United Nations accords, the Foreign Minister warned of certain "regional schemes" to exploit the situation.
Western diplomats here said he was making a veiled reference to Iran, which in the past has furnished weapons, money and fighters to support Shiite rebels battling Iraqi forces.
 
The Greater Fear
 Although Persian Gulf countries also fear the Islamic leadership in Iran and do not want to see it extend its reach into the south, they are more worried about the possible revival of Mr. Hussein and his military.
Newspapers and political leaders in Iran have also attacked the allied plan to provide air cover for the Shiites. Ayatollah Mohammed Yazdi, the head Iran's judiciary, said Friday that Iran continued to be opposed to all "satanic" designs by the United States.
But at the same time, Iranian radio and news agencies have provided a regular forum for Shiite rebel leaders in Iraq, to make the case to the rest of the world they are under siege by Baghdad and need a safe haven.
In Baghdad today, Prime Minister Mohammed Hamza al-Zubaydi told a special Cabinet meeting that Iraq would mobilize "all our official and popular potential" to resist the allied plan to impose a closed air zone over the south of the country.
"The three imperialist countries are terrified of Iraq's steadfastness in the face of the unjust blockade that has been in force for more than three years," he said.

HEADLINE: Baker's Deputy, Now Acting Secretary, Presses Ahead With a Full Schedule

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the career diplomat whose conservative pinstripes do little to dampen his exuberant personality, takes over as Acting Secretary of State on Sunday with neither illusions nor regrets.
"I am nothing if not clear about who I am," he said in an interview on Thursday in the opulent Deputy Secretary's suite, which he will keep when he assumes direction of the State Department at one of its busiest moments in recent times. Across the foyer, the office of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who moves to the White House as chief of staff, will remain empty. 
 Mr. Eagleburger is expected to remain as Acting Secretary at least until after the elections in November, when the future of the Bush Administration will be decided.
"I'm going to be the Acting Secretary of State for some months through an accident of history, and I understand that," Mr. Eagleburger said. "I also understand that I am not Secretary of State for four years and should therefore not be thinking about whither the foreign policy of the United States in the year 2000."
 
Is He a Caretaker?
 But he added, with the gusto and informality that contrast markedly with the self-controlled demeanor of Mr. Baker: "I'm going to do the best damn job I can do in this period of time."
Does that make him a caretaker?
"If you want to ask a nasty question, I suppose in one sense that's true, yes," he said. "I don't happen to think that makes any difference. I'm going to do what has to be done. I'm going to try to deal with issues in as creative a way as I can."
Last week, Mr. Baker and his departing inner circle of top advisers let it be known that they plan to stay engaged in foreign policy. As one of them told reporters: "The fact that we are going to the White House does not mean that we are in any way precluded from being actively involved to the extent that we have time to be or want to be."
Mr. Eagleburger is a State Department management expert whom colleagues describe as a practical administrator. He reaches down for advice into the far corners of the building's six floors where area specialists often felt neglected by Mr. Baker and his close-knit group.
"I'm going to use all the instruments of the building, whether Foreign Service or not," he said from his seventh-floor suite. "But there are going to be some times when I am going to want to decide things up here."
 
Sees No Major Changes
 He added, however: "I don't think you should expect any very major changes in the way the place operates. I happen to think Jim Baker ran it pretty well."
And he says he will not hesitate to call on Mr. Baker when needed.
"One obvious area I can identify right now, where I wouldn't hesitate for a minute to pick up the phone and call him, is on the Middle East," he said. "He's lived it, he's breathed it, he's created it and it would be insane for me and for the country if I weren't prepared to ask him for help when we needed it. I think that would be less true in other areas."
Mr. Eagleburger, a University of Wisconsin graduate who joined the Foreign Service in 1957, retired from the department in 1984 but returned as Deputy Secretary of State at President Bush's request in 1989. Despite Mr. Baker's shadow, he says he expects to enjoy considerable autonomy at the State Department.
 
In Charge "in Reality"
 "Jim Baker's made it clear to me, the President's made it clear, I'm not only legally but in reality in charge for the period of time left," he said.
The new Acting Secretary of State has a very full schedule.
On Monday, only an hour after a new round of Mideast peace talks are scheduled to begin in Washington, Mr. Eagleburger, who is 62 years old and not in the best of health, will be taking off for London to press for a more coherent international response to the continuing carnage in what was once Yugoslavia, where he served as Ambassador a decade ago.
His long association with Belgrade, the Yugoslav capital and now the center of a Serbian nationalist movement that is tearing Bosnia and Herzegovina apart, has elicited criticisms from Bosnians, Muslims and Croatians, as well as from Democrats in Congress who say he moved too slowly in responding to the crisis. Mr. Eagleburger has acknowledged that he may have misjudged the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, whom he remembered as a more reasonable man before Yugoslavia slid into chaos.
 
Trouble With Iraq Looms
 Mr. Eagleburger is opposed to the use of force against the Serbs to bring peace to Bosnia, saying that Yugoslav history suggests that "putting foreign troops on the soil there would make the situation worse, not better."
In a matter of days, tension building over Iraq may turn into open confrontation if President Saddam Hussein persists in flying sorties against the Shiite Muslim population in the southern region near Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. The United States and its allies are expected to issue an ultimatum to Iraq next week that it must stop the flights or risk having the planes shot down.
In September, Washington's Asian economic partners want Mr. Eagleburger to attend a high-level meeting in Bangkok on Pacific area trade and other issues that have been eclipsed by American concentration on the former Soviet empire and the Middle East.
"I'd better have some time for Asia," he said, listing his concerns, among them the intransigence of the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, the need to patch up relations with the Philippines and the steady movement toward the diplomatic recognition of Hanoi.
 
The Importance of Japan
 "The real question in the Pacific is obviously Japan," Mr. Eagleburger said. "In the last analysis, the U.S.-Japanese relationship is so important to both of us that neither one of us is going to be so insane that we are going to tear it apart," he said.
Mr. Eagleburger, who left government service in the 1980's to work for the consulting company of his friend and associate Henry A. Kissinger, also said that the consequences of the collapse of the Soviet Union would be "with this Administration for the rest of the term and into the next term and for a long time for all of us."
A motif running through American policy in all areas of the world, Mr. Eagleburger said, is the increasing reliance on international organizations, from the Organization of American States in Haiti to the European Community or the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe for Yugoslavia.
"One of the things we are seeing is that, except in exceptional circumstances like Iraq, one superpower in an otherwise not-superpower world often means that your superpower strength is not applicable," he said. "And therefore you've got to find other instruments and institutions that you can use to bring weight to bear -- including our own superpower status, but in a context that can make it useful."
 
Status of His Health
 Mr. Eagleburger, who frequently walks with a cane after the replacement of a kneecap, and who recently appeared at the State Department with his arm in a cast, is a heavy smoker who alternates cigarettes with squirts of spray to control a perennial problem with asthma. He admits to being overweight.
But the cane and the cast were gone when he strode into the sitting-room area of his suite for an interview, and he greeted a question about his health with a look of resignation.
"I have read enough in the last two weeks to convince myself I have one foot in the grave and the other on a banana peel," he said. "But I can assure you that for whatever period of time is necessary, I will be careful not to let the banana peel slip."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush, in Georgia, Questions Clinton's Vision of the Family

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WOODSTOCK, Ga., Aug. 22

 BODY:
In a small Southern town that looked like a set for Andy Griffith's Mayberry, President Bush raised doubts today about the Democrats' vision of family, and his surrogate cited Woody Allen as symbolizing the party's values.
As many as 20,000 exuberant supporters packed the center of town and remained buoyant through a driving rain as Mr. Bush said he understood "the American way" and warned that Mr. Clinton was in league with a "gridlocked Congress" that would neglect the crowd's interests. 
 "It's a choice about the character of the man that you want to lead this nation for another four years," said Mr. Bush, who was drenched after refusing an umbrella. The choice, he added, was about "our belief in a strong defense, in strong families and in leaving the world a better and more prosperous place for the young kids here today."
 
An All-Out Assault
 Signaling that he was primed for battle, Mr. Bush closed with these words: "So you tell Governor Clinton and that Congress, 'If you can't run with the big dogs, stay under the porch.' "
Mr. Bush's feisty language was tame compared with the warm-up act, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who represents this town north of Atlanta and who repeatedly attacked the Democrats as having "weird values."
In his all-out assault on the Democrats before Mr. Bush arrived in this town of storefronts draped with American flags, Mr. Gingrich, the second-ranking House Republican, cited Woody Allen, who has professed love for the daughter of his former lover, Mia Farrow. Ms. Farrow has accused Mr. Allen of sexually abusing her young daughter.
"I call this the Woody Allen plank," Mr. Gingrich said. "It's a weird situation, and it fits the Democratic party platform perfectly. If a Democrat used the word 'family' to raise children in Madison Square Garden, half their party would have rebelled and the other half would not vote."
He added: "Woody Allen had nonincest with his nondaughter because they were a nonfamily."
 
Bush Compliments Gingrich
 The Bush campaign sought to distance the President from Mr. Gingrich's comments. "We do not stand foursquare behind every single statement each of these surrogates makes," said Tony Mitchell, the campaign's deputy press secretary. "And, no, the President does not want to make Woody Allen an issue."
Still, Mr. Bush complimented Mr. Gingrich as someone "who helps us so much in Washington," and went on in his remarks to emphasize the family-values issue. As "the best evidence" of his commitment to family values, the President introduced his wife, Barbara, as "a great First Lady who stands for the family and family values." The crowd then broke into chants of "Barbara! Barbara!"
The President continued his pro-family, anti-Clinton, anti-Congress themes as he went on to another rain-soked rally of thousands in Hoover, Ala., where he accused Mr. Clinton of proposing the biggest tax increase in history, an assertion the Democrat rebuts. "They talk about change," Mr. Bush said. "The only thing you'll have in your pocketbook is change if this guy gets elected."
 
Tax Cut Not Mentioned
 Buoyed by polls that show him closing in on Mr. Clinton since the Republican convention, Mr. Bush has eagerly taken on his rival. But he has barely mentioned the across-the-board tax-cut proposal that was a core theme of his acceptance speech, and he did not disclose details of the plan today.
In fact, Mr. Mitchell said he was not sure "whether the specifics will be decided by the election or not." But he rejected Mr. Clinton's assertion that Mr. Bush was a "great fear monger" on economics. "It's not that we're trying to stir up fears," Mr. Mitchell said. "We're just trying to point out a legitimate economic policy difference."
Mr. Gingrich, who aides said was furious over Mr. Bush's reneging on his "no new taxes" pledge in 1990 but now attacks Mr. Clinton's economic proposals, told reporters the President should lay out details of his proposal. There was no mention of Mr. Gingrich's overdrafts at the House bank when Mr. Bush derided the "rubber-check Congress."
It was Mr. Gingrich's oratory this morning that demonstrated how far the Republicans might go in questioning Mr. Clinton's trustworthiness and character. He was particularly critical of Mr. Clinton's appearance on MTV, when the Democratic candidate said with a smile that maybe he should have inhaled marijuana -- a joke about his oft-repeated comment that he had tried the drug but "didn't inhale."
"He has a deep psychological need to pander to the worst instincts of whatever group he's in front of," Mr. Gingrich said. "He, in effect, said to these kids it was all right to inhale."
Mr. Gingrich called the Governor's comment "a sick thing" and "the most single destructive action by a politician in my lifetime."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1172 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
CLINTON BORROWS TOUGH G.O.P. TACTIC

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Striving to hold his ground in what polls show is a tightening race for President, Gov. Bill Clinton is relying on a tactic that the Republicans used in their convention and in the campaign: blending attacks on the opponent with softer themes and images intended to make the candidate personally attractive.
For example, on Friday, Mr. Clinton came close to calling President Bush a liar in the morning, then embarked on a telegenically warm and fuzzy bus tour with his running mate, Senator Al Gore, and their wives that afternoon. 
 Even as Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore court enthusiastic crowds in the Rust Belt this weekend and in Texas and Louisiana later this week, the Arkansas Governor's attacks have sharpened, with the veneer of his genial smile softening them only a little.
 
The Opening Salvos
 "George Bush is a lot more interested in beating me than in helping you," Mr. Clinton told the Detroit Economic Club in a speech that included the substantive opening salvos of the fall campaign. "He can't say anything about his record, so he just says anything to stay in power."
In a campaign that suddenly seems more October than August, the attack-and-retreat technique will require tit for tat, slug for slug, and both parties seem prepared to line up their battering rams long before Labor Day.
Although this blend of positive and negative campaigning is closely identified with Republicans in the last three elections, Mr. Clinton got plenty of practice in it during the process of dispensing of his Democratic primary opponents and then building a lead over Mr. Bush in mid-summer.
Mr. Clinton's top aides say they are not alarmed by the new public opinion polls suggesting that the Republican convention helped President Bush erase most of Mr. Clinton's lead. "We planned for it," said Dee Dee Myers, Mr. Clinton's press secretary. "We always expected they would have a convention that was good for them. We planned to be slugging it out all fall. The polls will bounce around and will not settle down before next week."
Mr. Clinton's analysts also say they planned two alternate responses to Mr. Bush's convention speech: one if he introduced dramatic new policy initiatives, which he did not; the other if he did not offer anything substantially new.
 
Intention Was to Respond
 "The intention was always to respond," Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's polltaker said, here after Mr. Clinton's speech on Friday. "Had the President given a genuine policy address and advanced an economic plan, you would have seen economic plan against economic plan. But he raised the trust issue, and we joined the trust issue."
Ms. Myers said: "I think that the long view of the speech is going to be that he proposed an across-the-board tax cut, health care for every American, vouchers to send children to private schools, a capital gains tax cut -- all of that without proposing how he would pay for it. He's going to have a lot of explaining to do once the election unfolds."
The campaign at this point is a contest to see which candidate can emerge as both stronger and more attractive. The Democrats are counting on what they believe is a permanent sense of exasperation with Mr. Bush among the voters, and Clinton strategists are also arguing that their candidate will prove more intrinsically attractive than previous Democratic nominees have.
From the campaign's polling, said one strategist, "the one thing we have here is people who don't want to vote for Bush." The Clinton forces find hope in that because, the strategist added, "Mondale was ahead of Reagan and Carter was ahead of Reagan, but they lost because people just didn't want to vote for Carter and Mondale."
Mr. Clinton and his advisers also sense that an opening exists to persuade voters that Mr. Bush is ultimately responsible for deficits, inflation, joblessness and other economic troubles.
The determination of the Clinton forces to respond quickly to Bush attacks has become an article of faith in the third-floor "war room" at the campaign headquarters in Little Rock, Ark. Mr. Bush was still delivering his acceptance speech at the Republican convention on Thursday night when Clinton aides began dispensing their rebuttal, which was faxed, copied and slipped under the hotel doors of reporters traveling with Mr. Clinton by midnight.
 
Playing the 'Trust' Card
 Quick response, whether to personal accusations, attacks on Mr. Clinton's wife, Hillary, or assaults on the specifics of the Democrats' proposals, kills further inquiry, they reason.
At the same time, the Clinton organization is working to build voter trust while exploiting voter distrust of Mr. Bush, using every available opportunity to point out that the President reversed his pledge not to raise taxes. Mr. Bush has made "trust" a major theme of his campaign.
At times, Clinton aides seem to long for their old underdog status. In the role of challengers, they say, they will be better able to drive home another portion of their fall strategy: they want to cast the Republicans as fat-cat insiders who are out of the mainstream.
"They are desperate to hold on to the White House," Mr. Clinton told reporters last week, repeating an observation he had made more than once. "They cannot imagine what life would be like if they didn't have Camp David and they didn't have all the dinners at the White House and they didn't have all the perks and powers of the Presidency. The national Bush crowd think it belongs to them. They will do anything to hold it."
The Democrats were happy to seize on the call by Patrick J. Buchanan, in his run for the Republican nomination, for Americans to "take our culture back." They accuse the Republicans of "narrow casting" their appeal to alienated white males and religious conservatives.
"They are running to the right," said James Carville, a senior Clinton strategist. "The religious right, it's like they wrote the platform."
 
The Scrappy Victims
 Another emerging Clinton theme is that the Democrats are the scrappy and noble victims of unfair Republican attacks.
When Mr. Clinton criticizes Mr. Bush, it is with a slightly pained tone, but he seemed to relish defending his wife when Republican speakers and officials attacked her during their convention last week.
Mrs. Clinton, playing her role in the campaign's master plan, refused to be drawn into the debate, instead letting her husband rise to her defense and to the defense of their daughter, Chelsea, whom they have adamantly protected from the press and the political fray.
"They want one set of rules for themselves and another set of rules for everybody else," Mr. Clinton complained at one point. "They want to be nice people except when they need votes, in which case they want to trash their opponents. The worst example of all, of course, is the way they have just grossly distorted Hillary's work and tried to target her. They go around and extol family values and attack my family. Before you know it, they'll be after Chelsea."

HEADLINE: Times Sq. Subway Station Plan Is Canceled

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The postponement of a plan to build four giant office towers in Times Square has forced the New York City Transit Authority to abandon a $165 million project to renovate the ramshackle Times Square subway station, dealing another blow to efforts to revitalize the neighborhood.
The Transit Authority's proposal for the labyrinthine station, the second busiest in the subway system, had depended on an investment of $90 million from the office towers' developers, the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty. But now that the recession has prompted state and city officials to release the developers from their obligation to construct the towers anytime soon, the subway project is neither financially nor structurally feasible. 
 "Frankly, we don't know what we're going to do," said Jerome Forman, senior vice president at the Transit Authority. "The strategy that was in place is not going ahead."
 
Commuters Still Stranded
 The subway project had been a centerpiece of the Times Square redevelopment plan. It was supposed to transform the station, which connects eight subway lines and serves more than 200,000 passengers a day, into a bright, clean and efficient transportation hub, thereby encouraging more people to visit the Times Square area. Commuters have long voiced disgust over the station's gloomy and sometimes threatening corridors.
The renovations, which took a team of 20 architects and engineers more than five years and $16 million to design, would have been the most extensive ever undertaken by the Transit Authority. They had been scheduled to start in 1991, but were delayed by design and engineering problems and concern over the schedule for the office towers.
But even before the tower project was postponed, some subway-rider groups had criticized the plans as excessive, saying that the Transit Authority should use its money for more basic improvements, like new signs and lighting, instead of rebuilding the complex. They also raised concerns about the Transit Authority's policy of relying on money from developers at the mercy of fluctuations of the real-estate market.
 
Station Opened in 1904
 The Times Square station opened in 1904 when the city's first subway, built by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, was completed. Since then, the station has expanded haphazardly, creating a jumble of confusing passageways. The renovation was intended to change that.
The Transit Authority had intended a four-year construction effort. Successive sections of the station were to be renovated as a central rotunda, six new entrances and five elevators for the elderly and the handicapped were built. The plan was so complicated that workers would have raised an entire block of Seventh Avenue by one foot, relocated a 48-inch water main and moved thousands of cables.
To modernize the shuttle to Grand Central Station, contractors would have ripped up one of its tracks and built a central platform for the remaining two. The Transit Authority would have peppered the station with new lights and signs and art by Roy Lichtenstein, Jacob Lawrence and Jack Beal.
But the blueprints for the renovation were intricately linked to the construction of the four towers along Broadway and Seventh Avenue between 41st and 43d streets.
 
An Integrated Design
 "A lot of the configuration of the subway station was predicated on the buildings," Mr. Forman said. "Some of the entrances to the subway would come up through the buildings. It was a very integrated design."
The Transit Authority had expected to combine $75 million from its capital budget with the developers' $90 million, so its own money is still available for a smaller project.
Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, a state agency, said she was exploring a proposal that would allow the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the parent body of the Transit Authority, to supplement the $75 million with money from its capital budget. The extra money is expected to be reimbursed from "project revenues" to the developers when the towers are eventually built, she said.
But Mr. Forman said that even if the Transit Authority received more money, it could not simply trim the old plans because their engineering and architectural specifications were so connected to the tower plans. At the earliest, he estimated, work on a smaller project could not begin before 1994.
He added that even if the Transit Authority decided to confine its renovations to the shuttle platforms, his engineers would still have to redraw much of their previous plan for that section of the station.
"I don't think anybody should rush out and commit these kind of funds to something that isn't well thought out," he said. "At this point, none of the options are great, none of them are easy and they will all take a commitment of time and money."
 
'Back to Square One'
 Some advocates for subway riders said they hoped the postponement of the renovations might force the Transit Authority to re-examine its original project and realize that it was too ambitious.
"They should go back to square one," said Joseph G. Rappaport, coordinator for the Straphangers Campaign. "They should not try to cut the plan in half."
Mr. Rappaport said the Transit Authority was foolish to spend so much money on a single station when much of the subway system's infrastructure was outmoded.
Some commuters who regularly pass through Times Square said they were irked by the prospect of years of delay on the renovations.
"This station is run down and it's unpleasant," Vinette Noel said on Friday morning as she waited for the No. 1 train to take her to the Upper West Side, where she works as a housekeeper. "It makes me feel as if I want to avoid riding the subway. I wish they'd clean it up and get it over with."
Mary Castria, who commutes into Manhattan from New Jersey, said she long ago steeled herself to the station. But she worried about its effect on the legions of tourists who troop through Times Square every day.
"It's dirty and it smells," she said. "You see a lot of people from out of town here and you wonder what they think of it."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Bus Tour;
CLINTON DISMISSES HIS DROP IN POLLS

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARMA, Ohio, Aug. 22

 BODY:
His once-formidable lead in the polls much diminished, Gov. Bill Clinton campaigned relentlessly today in the nation's economically troubled industrial Midwest in search of new campaign momentum.
He dismissed the new voter surveys showing that the Republican National Convention had given President Bush a significant lift. "I didn't trust the polls when I had a big lead and I don't trust them now," he said. "But I don't think the people are going to lose their trust in me on the basis of some Republican attacks in Houston." 
 In the end, the Democrat nominee predicted, the election will be decided by voter dissatisfaction with an incumbent President who, Mr. Clinton asserted, could not be trusted and had no vision to save a nation mired in economic troubles.
"I think as the days go by the people will see the whole thing was a gimmick," Mr. Clinton said when asked about the Republicans' convention, which ended in Houston on Thursday.
 
Vowing to Be Different
 "You've got to remember," he continued, "that they ran the most negative convention in anybody's memory. They threw the kitchen sink at us. They did that on prime-time television."
The Clinton-Gore campaign, the Arkansas Governor vowed, would not stoop to such tactics.
"We're just going to go back to our positive campaign," he said, "and tell people what we're going to do to put them back to work."
The President and Vice President Dan Quayle might take issue with that assertion. Over the past two days, since the polls first indicated that Mr. Bush was closing the gap on Mr. Clinton, the Arkansas Governor and his running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, have stepped up and sharpened their attacks.
Again and again they have tried to turn the favorite Republican issues of trust and family values on the President and Mr. Quayle. In more than one instance, Mr. Clinton has accused the President, without equivocation, of knowingly telling untruths about the Clinton and Gore political records.
Again and again Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore have asserted that if the President and Mr. Quayle truly believe in family values, they would do more for the children of America.
"How can you be for family values when you don't value family?" Mr. Clinton said at a street rally here this afternoon. "It's harder to raise children now than it was four years ago. I value your children."
 
Some Disenchantment
 Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, along with their wives, Hillary and Tipper, are midway through a three-day bus trip across the southern rim of Lake Erie, from Detroit to Buffalo.
The crowds, ranging from several thousand here to about 5,000 last night in Cleveland, have frequently roared their approval of Mr. Clinton's promises to put American back to work, particularly the people of the industrial Midwest, traditionally an important political battleground in all Presidential campaigns.
But while the crowds along the route of the bus trip have been mostly friendly to Mr. Clinton, random conversations with bystanders indicate the polls very well may be right at this point.
"I just don't know what I'm going to do in November," Anna Anders, an unemployed bookkeeper, said after shaking Mr. Clinton's hand at the street rally here. "I keep trying to get off the fence, but no one has really convinced me to do it yet. I'm worried about my country. But for the moment you could say I'm watching and waiting."
In Cleveland this morning, Mr. Clinton told a clutch of well-wishers and reporters waiting outside his hotel not to be fooled by "all the trash" put out about trust and family values at the Houston convention. He contended that the real issue of the campaign was the economy.
"George Bush can't battle on the economy," he said. "He's got the worst economic record in 50 years. International economics is now part of our national security and he has imperiled national security by having no economic policy."
Later at a rally for senior citizens in East Cleveland, a predominantly black suburb that is dotted with boarded-up factories and rubble-choked lots, Mr. Clinton accused Mr. Bush of ignoring the nation's urban needs.
"You need a President who wakes up every day thinking about these problems," he said.
Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, along on the bus trip to help with the campaigning, warmed up the senior citizens crowd. He characterized the Republican convention as "the biggest cover-up since Watergate."
That brought an audible chuckle from Mr. Clinton. And when it came time for the Governor to take the microphone from Mr. Bradley, he began by noting that Mr. Bradley was a former basketball all-star for the New York Knicks, then said:
"The biggest cover-up since Watergate -- now that's what I call a slam-dunk!"
