HEADLINE: Town Rebuffs Big Company, Worrying L.I.

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 21

 BODY:
The scene could have come straight from a New York neighborhood fighting to block a drug-treatment program or a shelter for the homeless: outraged neighbors complaining that an intruder would change the character of the streets, set a damaging precedent and lower property values.
The outsider, however, was Canon U.S.A. Inc., precisely the kind of company most communities dream of having in their tax base: a $4 billion nonpolluting giant that wanted to expand its headquarters on Long Island while other companies were shutting down and moving far from New York. 
 Yet despite a carefully drafted proposal intended to meet local concerns, the Japanese-owned camera and electronics company has been told to look elsewhere -- and may do so in another state -- continuing a frustrating, six-year hunt for a bigger home. "A decision like this is devastating," said David Farr, Canon's general manager, after learning of Brookville's intent to block the move.
 
Executives Fear Official Apathy
 Canon's search for a new headquarters has become one of Long Island's longest-running corporate sagas. Before setting its sights on Brookville, the company, which is based in Lake Success, spent two years trying to acquire a 50-acre parcel at Roosevelt Raceway in Hempstead. It finally gave up after the land became entangled in unrelated investigations of possible corruption in its acquisition by the current owners. The inquiry was dropped early this year.
Although Nassau County officials say the company has simply had a run of bad luck, business leaders say Canon's frustrations reflect a sluggishness on the part of state and county officials to keep companies from fleeing New York before it is too late.
"We've had some notorious failures in recent years," said James L. Larocca, president of the Long Island Association, a group representing developers and other major concerns. "This economy has lost one in 10 jobs. It's hard to reconcile that with appearing to thumb our noses at a company with the reputation of Canon."
In addition to frequent complaints about high energy costs and taxes, business leaders feel there is a grass-roots antagonism toward development that has discouraged public officials from openly supporting them, especially in conflicts with other local officials. Public opposition, though, usually focuses on projects that could claim woods or wetlands, and often seem a reaction to overdevelopment of earlier years.
In addition, because home rule gives taxing authority to more than 600 jurisdictions, means county officials are often reluctant to step in on local disputes. That is what happened to Canon.
 
Every Village a Kingdom
 "In our system of allocation of powers, the power to deal with this situation rests with a village government that apparently feels no relationship to the rest of the Long Island economy," Mr. Larocca said, pointing to Brookville's population of 3,000.
"You can't overestimate how important it is," Mitchell L. Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center, said of the town's attitude toward Canon. "There's no manufacturing. There's no polluting. It's exactly the kind of activity you want to keep in the region."
The Brookville Taxpayers Association, which spearheaded the local opposition, said it feared increased traffic and, most of all, opening the way for other corporate headquarters.
 Canon's search for a corporate headquarters began six years ago at the sand pits of Oyster Bay, a bleak stretch of industry on Long Island's North Shore. The company never bought the land, however, because soil borings showed the land was made of clay, and unable to support construction, said Richard Ignatow, a landscape architect who studied the soil conditions.
 
Raceway Is Considered
 Canon then considered Roosevelt Raceway, agreeing to pay $1 million an acre for 50 acres, but allegations of corruption involving the defunct raceway, unrelated to Canon's proposal, forced county officials to back out of the deal two years ago.
Around the same time, a board member at the New York Institute of Technology, a private institute in Old Westbury that is struggling through the recession with a $100 million debt, suggested that Canon consider the deSeversky Conference Center, a branch of the school situated on 100 acres in Brookville.
The conference center is an elegant 68-year-old brick mansion, not visible from any road or house in Brookville. Its marble halls, veranda and grand staircase are the stuff of fantasy. Canon had planned to refurbish the house and add another building for a work force it projected would grow by 1,000, to 1,800.
"We thought it was a gentle and low impact development," said William Udry, the school's senior vice president for finance. "The citizens felt it would lead to a precedent." Canon offered $20 million for the house and the land.
 
Local Political Maelstrom
 But Canon did not realize that it was plunging into a maelstrom of local politics in Brookville.
A wealthy enclave of sprawling estates, Brookville has been spared the economic jostles of the 1990's. With property taxes that range from $15,000 to $20,000 a year per home, the major preoccupation here is preserving what is commonly referred to as "a way of life." It is the same phrase North Shore residents used in the late 60's to keep the state from building a bridge connecting Oyster Bay to the rest of America via Rye, N.Y.
Over the course of the following year, Canon met with residents of Brookville and the surrounding villages, who raised a series of objections. Homeowners complained that Brookville's own master plan called for houses on lots of two to five acres. Canon agreed that it would only build on a total of five acres, including the mansion, thus preserving 95 acres of the campus's lawns, majestic oaks and weeping willows.
To answer concerns about the increased traffic, the institute -- whose student body was dwindling anyway -- agreed to lower its maximum enrollment to 6,000 from 7,500. Canon promised to build its parking garage underground. Another objection concerned groundwater protection, though some argued that one corporate headquarters on five acres would pose less of a threat than 20 homes on 100 acres.
 
'Commercialization' vs. Taxes
 Though the Taxpayers Association did not make much of it, Canon would also have put the property back on the tax rolls. According to one Canon-financed study, the company's taxes to Brookville would have totaled 25 percent of the village's total tax base. But since most property taxes go to the county, rather than the village, the impact on residential bills would have been much less than 25 percent.
"The community said the help to their property taxes was not the dominant factor in their mind, but that the further commercialization of the North Shore was," said Michael P. Galgano, the Mayor of Brookville.
The group contended in a flyer that Canon would produce "37 times more sewage, garbage, traffic and pollution" than 20 houses on the 100 acres.
Donald Siegel, a professor at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, said of the association, "They've been somewhat immune to the recession, and that's reflected in their attitude about this."
 
Number of Foes Unclear
 It was never clear, however, whether the objections represented a groundswell or a restive minority.
Steven Glazer, the head of the Taxpayers Association and the losing candidate in the last mayoral election, said that he sent questionnaires to members in Brookville and the surrounding villages, and that nearly all the responses opposed Canon's coming to Brookville. He added, however, that only 10 to 20 percent of the surveys sent out were mailed back.
 
An Out-of-Town Audience
 Also, a sign-up sheet from the most contentious of the meetings between Canon and local homeowners shows that most of the 250 people who attended were not from Brookville but from nearby towns, said Jean Pailet, the Brookville Village Clerk.
Mr. Pailet said that it was a opinion by a lawyer for the village, rather than popular opposition, that swung the Mayor and village trustees against Canon. The decision said that a special exception from the residential zoning granted to the school for the deSeversky center could not be legally extended to Canon.
Canon only learned of the planned rejection after Mr. Galgano wrote to residents in early July that the board would probably turn Canon down at its next meeting.
Once again, the corporate giant was stung. "We genuinely believed that the project was a win-win proposition for all, including the village of Brookville, New York Tech, Canon U.S.A. and the larger Long Island community," Mr. Farr said.
In the aftermath, New York officials have rushed to soothe Canon's wounds. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called Canon's president in Japan, Hideharu Takemoto, pledging to help Canon stay in New York.
New York officials are fashioning a package of tax breaks and other incentives. They have also proposed other possible homes, including a section of the State University of New York at Old Westbury and the Long Island Developmental Center.
Officials from Connecticut and New Jersey have hinted that they have also been trying to woo the corporate headquarters.
Here in Nassau County, Steven Latham, the man County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta has charged with keeping Canon in Nassau, proposed they take another look at Roosevelt Raceway.
"Now they don't appear to be interested when you could do it, though they were when you couldn't," Mr. Latham said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis;
One Economy, 2 Visions

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Their gimmicks and vague promises aside, President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton present contrasting pictures of the state of the American economy and starkly different views about what needs to be done in the next four years.
Mr. Bush maintains that the American economy is inherently healthy and that the Government should take a hands-off approach and leave the free market alone. 
 Mr. Clinton holds that the economy is seriously off track and that the Government should step in and actively change the course.
 
Economy Leads Polls
 The economy is an important issue in any Presidential campaign, but rarely has it been so central as it is now. When voters have been asked in surveys this year what the most important problem is facing the country, the economy swamps all others.
And the Presidential candidates are giving the voters a clear choice on the matter.
Mr. Bush believes that wealthy Americans are taxed too much. Mr. Clinton would raise their taxes.
Mr. Bush would cut Government programs to the bone to lower the budget deficit. Mr. Clinton would expand Government spending on capital projects like roads and bridges, transportation systems and computer networks.
Mr. Bush would loosen Government regulations so businesses could become more prosperous. Mr. Clinton wants new regulations on business to protect the environment and force energy conservation.
Mr. Bush's ideas about health care and job training are grounded in tax incentives. Mr. Clinton would require employers to provide medical insurance and training to their employees or pay money to the Government to do the job for them.
 
Underscoring Differences
 Mr. Bush favors free trade at almost all costs. Mr. Clinton is increasingly taking the view that the United States should be tougher on its trading partners.
The sharp distinctions between the candidates' economic positions were underscored this week.
In his speech Thursday night in Houston accepting the Republican Presidential nomination, Mr. Bush declared, "Don't let anyone tell you that America is second rate." The main problem, he went on, was "a simple fact: Government is too big and spends too much."
Contrast that with what Mr. Clinton told the Detroit Economic Club in an hourlong luncheon speech on Friday.
"Our economy is struggling, and the American dream is in trouble," he asserted. The country, he said, needs the Government to develop "a national economic strategy."
Both candidates bemoan the budget deficit, which will approach $350 billion this year, the highest ever. But neither offers a clear prescription for what to do about it.
Mr. Bush favors a Constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget and says he would put a spending cap on "mandatory programs." He offered a new gimmick on Thursday night: He would allow taxpayers to earmark up to 10 percent of their income taxes to reduce the national debt.
But those are empty promises without a specific accounting of which programs would be cut by how much. What would be spent on Medicare and Medicaid, on veterans' pensions, on farm-price supports? What would happen to food stamps, to unemployment compensation, to student loans? As has been the case throughout his Presidency, Mr. Bush declines to provide such an accounting, refusing to say specifically what he would like to cut and what he would like to preserve.
 
Evading Tough Moves
 Mr. Clinton says he would cut the deficit in half in four years. But his numbers are based largely on much more rapid economic growth than most economists think is likely, on lowering military spending by more than the Bush Administration is projecting and on automatic changes in the savings and loan program that will occur regardless of what the next President does. And he has his own gimmick: He would raise, he says, $45 billion over the next four years by tightening tax collection on foreign corporations that do business in the United States, a sum that even strong Clinton supporters see as at best an exaggeration.
The fact of the matter is, the only way to get a firm handle on the deficit is to raise taxes on ordinary Americans, reduce spending on popular programs or both -- steps neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Clinton is prepared to advocate in the heat of an election campaign.
But that does not diminish the contrast in the candidates' principles and programs. Nowhere is it clearer than in the case of taxes.
Mr. Clinton would raise the top tax rate, now 31 percent, to about 36 percent on taxpayers with total incomes above $200,000 a year. He would also stiffen the minimum tax owed by upper-income taxpayers who have many deductions and impose a 10 percent surtax on incomes over $1 million. He would use the revenue raised to give middle-income taxpayers a 10 percent tax cut or to give families with children a tax credit. He has never said precisely who would qualify for the tax cuts.
Mr. Bush promised the Republican convention on Thursday night that he would ask Congress to reduce taxes "across the board" if offsetting spending reductions could be found. The only two specific tax policies he mentioned were a lower capital-gains tax and a larger personal exemption, both of which would give maximum benefit to the wealthiest taxpayers.
Last spring Congress approved a bill that would have given Mr. Bush much of what he wanted in the way of taxes: a lower capital-gains rate for all but the richest 2 percent of taxpayers, expanded individual retirement accounts, tax breaks for the real estate industry and for business investments in plants and equipment, a lower minimum tax and a repeal of luxury taxes on yachts, furs, airplanes and jewelry.
Mr. Bush vetoed the measure because it would have balanced those tax reductions with the kind of higher taxes on the wealthy that Mr. Clinton wants.
The President holds that tax increases for the most affluent taxpayers would quickly devolve into tax increases for ordinary families. Mr. Clinton, the President said Thursday night, "says he wants to tax the rich, but, folks, he defines rich as anyone who has a job."
In his speech in Detroit, Mr. Clinton was equally caustic about Mr. Bush's philosophy, calling it "the wrongheaded notion that prosperity will trickle down if we just make the rich even richer and get the Government out of the way."
In many respects, this is the same argument that has been running through American politics since Roosevelt ran against Hoover, since Eisenhower ran against Stevenson, since Kennedy ran against Nixon -- the debate over the proper role of the Government and who should pay the taxes and whether income should be redistributed.
For all the talk in Madison Square Garden last month and in the Astrodome this week about abortion and welfare and family values and foreign affairs, this division over the economy may well be what decides the election of 1992.

HEADLINE: Art and Commerce: a College's Turbulent Tale

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAVANNAH, Ga.

 BODY:
Even before the pipe bomb explosion that led to the cancellation of graduation exercises, before the $12 million lawsuit by disgruntled students and the purge of skeptical faculty members and trustees, a lot of people here had begun to wonder just what was going on at the Savannah College of Art and Design.
Depending on who's talking, the college is either a model of entrepreneurial education -- an institution that in 14 years has gone from a mere idea to one of the largest of its kind in the nation -- or a place that deserves the contempt of protesting students who call it SCAM instead of SCAD. But at a time when the standard answer to everything from education to the Presidency is that it needs to be run like a business, there's an intriguing tale (call it "The Art College That Ate Savannah") in the combination of art, academics and commerce that surrounds the college. 
 Run by the family that started it, SCAD now enrolls about 2,300 students and owns more than 30 buildings, mostly restored 19th-century structures, in Savannah's historic, moss-draped downtown. "I would hate to think what downtown Savannah would be without SCAD." said Lee Adler, the leader of Savannah's historic-preservation movement.
But a growing number of past and present students, employees, teachers, administrators and trustees say the college's mission has more to do with money and power than with education.
 
A Family Affair
 In dozens of interviews, these critics depict a tax-exempt institution that operates like a family business, routinely provides false information to prospective students and has subordinated educational needs to economic ones.
"SCAD is becoming a pariah institution," Russell Barclay, the former head of the liberal arts department, wrote trustees in May. In an interview, he added, "There's no end to the people who would love to have this kind of a deal: a tax-exempt family with a tuition-driven life style."
SCAD, an accredited four-year college of art and architecture, is a highly unusual academic institution. Professors don't have tenure and are on one-year contracts. They are expected to raise money, generate favorable publicity and recruit students as well as teach.
The president is Richard Rowan, a former Georgia Department of Education administrator with the demeanor of a high-powered salesman. The provost is his wife, Paula Rowan, a former teacher in Atlanta. The vice president for admissions is Mrs. Rowan's mother, May Poetter; the comptroller is her father, Paul Poetter. A school spokesman and editor of the administration-run newspaper is Mrs. Rowan's sister, Pamela Afifi. An architecture professor is Mrs. Afifi's husband, Emad Afifi.
Teachers, students and even former trustees say the Rowans run the school without any real oversight. There is no student government or student newspaper, and a fledgling faculty senate began only after the turmoil of the past year. The college's paid general counsel, Hugh Dorsey 3d, who founded the institution along with Mr. Rowan, is also the head of its trustees.
"I don't think I ever voted on one thing," said Pat Conroy, the novelist, who spent two years on the board and then resigned, worried that there was no oversight to the Rowans' willy-nilly expansion. "It was one of the most bewildering things I've ever been a part of. I left the board because I was afraid that if I stayed on it I would end up in jail."
 
It Started in an Armory
 SCAD's story started in 1978, when the Rowans, neither of whom had a doctorate or a career centered on art, moved to Savannah with the idea of starting an art college. They had considered various kinds of colleges before deciding that the lack of art schools in the Southeast and the rich stock of unused buildings in Savannah's historic downtown made the city a perfect site.
By their own account in the administration newspaper, The Georgia Guardian, they began small, selling their home in Atlanta and trading in their car for a Volkswagen. They bought an abandoned armory, and after doing much of the renovation on their own, attracted 71 students for the college's first year in 1979.
Borrowing aggressively, buying everything from 19th-century buildings for offices and classrooms to an Art Deco diner for a campus eatery, they made the college perhaps the most active real estate player in downtown Savannah. And they gained an reputation for playing hardball with their own employees and with others.
For example, a former professor, Murray Wilson, and a former student, Mickey Youmans, said Mr. Rowan had them use a concealed microphone to bug and tape-record an accrediting team from the Georgia Department of Education visiting the college in 1986. In an interview, Mrs. Rowan denied that such an incident had taken place.
As the college has grown, the Rowans have prospered. They now drive a Mercedes, raise rare Arabian horses and travel extensively on school business, dining at restaurants like Le Cirque in New York and staying at hotels like the Ritz in London. College officials refuse to say how much the Rowans earn, but the college's annual statement to the Internal Revenue Service, required for its tax exemption as a not-for-profit educational institution, says the two together made $358,000 in salary in 1991.
 
Economics and Academics
 In the interview, Mrs. Rowan said much of the conflict surrounding the school stemmed from its innovative policies and its rapid growth in the middle of stodgy Savannah.
"Suddenly things have turned from where some of these people might say, 'Well, you're in our neighborhood,' to realizing that they are in our neighborhood," Mrs. Rowan said. "And I think that has an unsettling effect on some people who would prefer the status quo."
But to critics, the college has become an economic enterprise first and an academic one second, in which everything is driven by a need to attract enough students to pay the bills.
As some faculty members wrote in a recent memorandum to accrediting bodies: "In its bizarre and chaotic organization, in its deceptive admission practices, in its neglect of basic academic resources in favor of showy trappings which which to entice prospective students . . . and especially in the cynical subordination of academic needs to financial concerns in the development and oversight of its academic programs, SCAD has shown a wholesale disregard for the values of American higher education."
In a lawsuit against the college that has not yet come to trial, four students allege that SCAD misrepresents itself to prospective students -- offering facilities that don't exist, making false claims about career placement of graduates and making excessive claims for its degree programs. Mr. Dorsey, the counsel who is also head of the trustees, says the lawsuit is groundless.
In interviews, several former recruiters said they were paid a fee for each student who enrolled. The National Association of College Admission Counselors, of which SCAD is a member, says it expressly forbids that practice. Mrs. Afifi said admissions personnel, like other employees, received a base salary plus periodic bonuses and raises based on merit.
Statistics provided by the college in recent editions of Peterson's College Guide say 45 percent of applicants are accepted. Recruiters say they are told to report average Scholastic Aptitude Test scores around 1,000.
But students, teachers and four former recruiters, in separate interviews, say that virtually anyone who can pay is accepted and that the average S.A.T. score is around 850, with many hundreds of points below that. Mrs. Rowan says the college stands by its figures.
 
Elegant but Empty
 Past and present employees say even basic information on enrollment has been routinely inflated over the years to burnish the institution's image.
The catalogue distributed last year describes the home of the video school as follows: "Among the spaces within the richly ornamented Romanesque-style facade are classrooms, equipment rooms, editing suites, and a 36,000-square-foot sound stage which can be adapted to multiple uses."
The building is an unoccupied shell.
Many students say the college provides an excellent education despite its problems. "The facilities and the faculty are just great," said Alan Bucknam, a photography student. "It's the administration that's just a little screwed up."
But others say they didn't get what they paid for, and several this summer said the college balked at sending out their transcripts when they tried to transfer.
Marissa Magaz, a former graduate student who is one of those suing SCAD, said she gave up a job as head of the fine arts program at a school in Miami to come to Savannah, only to decide that SCAD's unusual degree of master of fine arts in art history was useless in pursuing the doctorate she was seeking. One of her former professors, Jim Rogers, who has since left SCAD, terms it "a bogus degree oriented toward getting as many bodies and keeping as many fees as possible."
The administration's supporters say the problems this year reflect the discontent of a few faculty members. "I see a great future for the college, and I want to be a part of it," said Judith Van Baron, recently named vice president for academic affairs.
But critics say the college is better at marketing and sales than education. "I'd jump in a minute, but most of my credits won't transfer," said Katie Steinwart, who said she hadn't planned to apply to SCAD but enrolled after being offered a $10,000 scholarship, which starts at $1,000 a year and adds $1,000 a year until it's worth $4,000 if a student stays in school as a senior. "Once you're in, they've got you. The whole school is a scam."
 
A Tumultuous Year
 The administration's resistance to a proposed student constitution in the spring set in motion a tumultuous series of events that brought many of the questions about the school into the open. Administration officials, citing a small explosive device found near an administration building on April 6, tried to stop leaders of the student movement from enrolling unless they signed legal documents prepared by the college. A second pipe bomb forced the cancellation of graduation.
Since then, organizations like as the American Association of University Professors and the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools have said they plan to investigate the school this year. In the most severe blow thus far, the National Architectural Accrediting Board, which accredits the nation's schools of architecture, put SCAD on probation, forcing it to meet its standards or lose accreditation in 1993.
Three trustees critical of the administration were immediately replaced by the board. Convinced that the college is dependent on an unsustainable rate of growth, some former faculty members and trustees are trying to lure a competing art college to Savannah. The School of Visual Arts in New York has expressed an interest in a possible branch here.
Mr. Dorsey, the head of the trustees, said the college would once again enroll the largest freshman class in its history. But about two dozen faculty members, or more than 20 percent of those who began last year at the college, were either not given new contracts or chose not to return. Over the past year the college lost the two top academic administrators under Mrs. Rowan -- one was dismissed and the other resigned -- as well as four vice presidents and several deans.
The college faces continuing financial pressures and has cut back on its construction and maintenance staff at a time when its 1991 financial statement says $4.5 million in mortgages are coming due between 1992 and 1996. A year ago, the college told the Federal Department of Education that it was scheduling a bond issue. But it has not yet issued any new bonds.
Even the harshest critics say that the Rowans pulled off a miracle in building a college that still has extraordinary potential, and that downtown Savannah desperately needs such an institution. But many now fear the entrepreneurial dazzle that built SCAD is killing it.
"There's nothing wrong with running a college in a businesslike fashion," said Harry Dixon, who was dismissed as academic dean this year after raising questions about the Rowans' management. "But when the business is the bottom line rather than the education, when respect for students and faculty goes out the window, then you've got a real problem. When I started here I think SCAD was about education. I don't think it's about education anymore. It's about building an empire."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Savannah College of Art and Design in Georgia is considered either a model of entrepreneurial education, the largest of its kind in the nation, or a college more concerned with money than education. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times); Richard Rowan, the president of the Savannah College of Art and Design. As the college has grown, Mr. Rowan and his wife, Paula, the provost, have prospered.

HEADLINE: Small Farms Cultivate Way of Life, and Profit

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
The family farm, that white clapboard idyll where Mom cooks in a ruffled apron and Pop works in bib overalls, has for decades been lodged more firmly in the American heart than in the nation's countryside. In the last 30 years the number of farms in the United States has dropped by half, to just over two million.
But as the number of traditional farms dwindles, a new type of farm -- and a new type of farmer -- is sprouting up across America: modest plots tended by savvy, part-time farmers who plow, weed and water as much to cultivate a way of living as to grow profitable crops. 
 "County extension agents and farm-market managers across the country are all seeing a steady infusion of highly educated, part-time farmers sprouting up on the fringes of major cities," said Howard W. (Bud) Kerr, director of the Office for Small Scale Agriculture in the United States Department of Agriculture, which tracks small farmers and publishes a free newsletter for them. "They farm for pleasure and profit, and for the quality of life that it offers."
The tailored lawyer who grows mache lettuce on the weekend, the Southeast Asian immigrant whose day job with a state health department supports his snow-pea patch at home, the Nike-clad math teacher who tends bees after school, the retired steelworker who earns most of his income from an acre of organic herbs -- these contemporary farmers are far from the American Gothic portrait that politicians summon when they extol "the American way of life."
These new-style agriculturalists are rapidly becoming keepers of the mythic American farm.
A study released in July by the Agriculture Department's National Agricultural Statistics Service showed that while the number of large farms -- the average size is now 468 acres -- continued to decline in 1991, the number of small farms with annual sales of $1,000 to $9,999 increased by 3,000, to 1.006 million farms this year from 1.003 million in 1991. But officials say that while the increase is significant because of the continuing drop in other areas of agriculture, it still only hints at the growth of small farms.
Agricultural experts say that the reported income of small farms represents a fraction of the money actually earned by small-scale farmers who sell directly to the public. The experts say that "exurban micro farming" is even more widespread than Government data indicate.
"There is no question that part-time farmers are proliferating," said Karl Ohm, publisher of Rural Enterprise, a quarterly trade magazine for fruit and vegetable growers that is published in Menominee Falls, Wis. Mr. Ohm, like many experts, feels that a confluence of economic and social forces is changing who farms in America and what they farm.
 
Vulnerable Large Farms
 Since World War II, American farms have generally grown to industrial size and become heavily dependent on fuel-intensive equipment, petroleum-based pesticides and fertilizers and large-scale bank financing. When oil prices and finance costs began rising in the late 1970's, large farms were vulnerable. Smaller farms were not as heavily shackled with such overhead and could also respond more quickly to urban-centered, carriage-trade markets demanding specialty produce.
At the same time, Mr. Kerr said, zoning regulations around many major metropolitan areas increasingly forbid the division of small parcels of land. "So basically you have a new generation of gentry," he said. "Zoning makes them buy a five-acre parcel and they aren't sitting in their new house too long before they realize that they can either mow a lot of grass or put in some goats or some row crops."
In addition, Mr. Kerr said, local tax laws sometimes favor agricultural use of land. And for retirees and less wealthy families, he said, turning a profit from the backyard is a way of supplementing income.
 
Cornerstone of Direct Sales
 "It's been a quiet revolution over the past decade," Mr. Ohm said, adding that direct marketing from roadside stands and urban farmers' markets is its cornerstone.
Dr. Donald Albrecht, an associate professor of rural sociology at Texas A & M University who helped analyze the data, points out that the growth of small urban farms means little in terms of the national food supply. "Seventy-five percent of the nation's food still comes from 3 percent of its largest farms," he said.
But sociologically, Dr. Albrecht said, the shift in farm population patterns is significant. "We're looking at a whole new image of the American farmer," he said.
Bernie Brand, a 58-year-old junior high school mathematics teacher and beekeeper in Shoreview, Minn., near Minneapolis, is hardly a portrait of the traditional American farmer.
But he turned his beekeeping hobby into a business for two reasons: to make extra money and to give his two sons a quality of life otherwise lacking in the suburbs. Seventeen years later, he has saved about $20,000 toward his sons' college education. "More importantly, my 14-year-old and 17-year-old don't spend their summers roaming the mall," he said. "They work the bees, extract honey and help sell it at the farmers' market."
His wife, Patty Brand, the manager of the St. Paul Farmers' Markets, said her family mirrors a trend. "It's getting harder and harder for a farm to be the sole support of a family," she said. "We lose about 10 old-time growers a year, and usually they are replaced by people like us, part-time farmers with children and full-time professional lives."
 
Labor-intensive and Profitable
 Generally, Mrs. Brand said, part-time farmers in her area begin with specialty products like herbs, honey or organic produce. Around the country, first-generation immigrant farmers also rely on specialty produce. That trend, which began nearly two decades ago with growing herbs, exotic lettuces and miniature vegetables for restaurants, has grown from a boutique activity to the mainstay of many small family farms, said Pedro Ilic, a farm adviser with the University of California Extension Service in Southern California.
"It's labor-intensive farming that doesn't require a big cash outlay for overhead," Mr. Ilic said. Since 1980, he said, 845 Mexican-American, Southeast Asian and Chinese families have been able to make livings on Fresno County plots averaging 3.3 acres.
Besides profiting from the labor that is often available in large, extended families, immigrant small farmers choose to work the land for the quality of life it offers.
"I can make as much extra money as I need working as a translator," said Chue Vang, a trilingual Laotian who immigrated to Missoula, Mont., in 1979 and works for the State Department of Health there. "But on five acres I can make that money growing long Asian green beans, snow peas and chives, and my son doesn't go with the gangs. He works with me. He gets straight A's and he goes to Outward Bound."
 
Now It's Amber Waves of Herbs
 Mr. Kerr of the Office for Small Scale Agriculture says that, besides young professionals, he has also noted a steady increase in retirees who turn gardening hobbies into sources of income. Leroy Wilton, a 53-year-old retired steelworker in Pasadena, Md., for instance, raised herbs for many of the 26 years he worked at Armco Steel. After being forced into early retirement last year, he said, he built a greenhouse on his one-acre lot and turned his hobby into a year-round source of income.
"My only regret is not doing it sooner," Mr. Wilton said. "I wish I could have given my own kids what I'm giving my grandchildren, working with them on the herbs. The country's falling apart, and this is a way to keep families together."
One- , three- and five-acre plots are far from the amber waves of grain that rustle in the American Dream. The suburban hobby or fun farm that becomes a family's profit center will do little to stem the decline of a far-flung rural culture. And agricultural experts like J. Tevere MacFadyen, author of "Gaining Ground," a study of small farms in America that was published by Holt, Rinehart & Winston in 1984, are quick to point out that the rising breed of small family farms thrives because the society has elevated certain commodities, like herbs and organic produce, into discretionary purchases. But they worry that these farmers are vulnerable to changes in the economy and the fashions of the table.
 
Elbow Room on the Nonfarm
 Dr. John Fraser Hart, who has studied farm life and population patterns as a professor of geography at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, and who wrote "The Land that Feeds Us" (W. W. Norton, 1991), said the new small farmers are tapping another fundamental American characteristic. "They're looking for elbow room, freedom, self-determination," said Dr. Hart, who has just completed a survey of farms along a major highway near Minneapolis and St. Paul.
"Thirty years ago that highway was all large farms," he said. "Today over half are what we've traditionally called 'nonfarms,' places so small they aren't normally tracked by the census. I couldn't find a farmer at home between 9 and 5, because every one of them works full-time jobs in the city. But on the weekends there they were, out in the field with their kids, the happiest, most solid families you can imagine.
"Well, we don't have the right words for any of this yet, I mean, data-wise. But as far as life style goes, what we're seeing is little patches of Americana, that sort of dream that won't die."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I can make as much extra money as I need working as a translator," said Chue Vang, of Missoula, Mont., who works for the state Department of Health. "But on five acres I can make that money growing long Asian green beans, snow peas and chives." He prepared his produce for market. (Larry Mayer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bias Beating And a Death Shock a City

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla., Aug. 21

 BODY:
Last weekend in this small Southeast Florida city, a 19-year-old pre-medical student who came to this country as a child with his parents from Vietnam, was fatally beaten by a group of young white men after he objected to a racial slur one of them used.
The student, Luyen Phan Nguyen, of Coral Springs, died Monday. The Broward County Medical Examiner said the fatal blow was a kick behind an ear that fractured a neck bone and severed arteries. 
 On Wednesday, with newspapers and television stations reporting each development, the police began arresting young men they said were tied to the beating.
On Thursday, 175 friends and family members held a Buddhist ceremony for Mr. Nguyen, and some prayed near where he was beaten. Afterward, the county's small Asian community pleaded for justice.
Former classmates at Coral Springs High School said Mr. Nguyen was popular and an excellent student. He was on the school math team, ran track and was in the environmental club. He would have been a sophomore this fall at the University of Miami.
 
Lingering Unease for Residents
 With the arrests and the family's anguish receiving wide publicity, residents said it would take a long time to recover from the kind of violence and bias that were virtually unknown in their upper-middle-class city of 85,000 people.
"This is Coral Springs, a family neighborhood," said Yazid Ali, who moved here a year ago from Jamaica, Queens, with his wife and young son. "In this neighborhood, you can't fix your car in the street. You get a ticket for that. You can't have a sign advertising your business on your car. There are so many rules. I can't understand how this could happen."
The incident began late Saturday at a party attended by Mr. Nguyen and the young men in the apartment complex where Mr. Ali lives. Someone made a derogatory remark about Mr. Nguyen's nationality. He protested and left, witnesses told the police. They said several young men followed Mr. Nguyen out the door.
"It started off with some young guy wanting to be a tough guy, and everybody just got involved," said a police investigator, James P. Milford. "They chased him down like a hunter chases down an injured deer."
Mr. Ali said he heard cursing and "drunk talk" around 11 P.M. in a grassy area between buildings. He went to his balcony and saw 15 to 20 people, some of them hitting someone on the ground.
"I yelled, 'Let him up, let him up!' " Mr. Ali said. "They were really beating up this kid."
 
8 Arrested in Beating
 A neighbor telephoned the police as the beating continued and after a few minutes, Mr. Ali said, it stopped. Witnesses said the attackers got into cars and left as residents tried to help Mr. Nguyen, who appeared to have stopped breathing. Paramedics arrived and took him to a Fort Lauderdale hospital, where officials said he was on a life-support system until he died.
By Friday, the police had arrested eight men in the case, 18 to 22 years old, and charged them with second-degree murder.
Coral Springs's police chief, Roy A. Arigo, said that some of the suspects had minor criminal records but that most were middle-class working men with no record of trouble. One had just returned home after completing Marine boot camp at Camp Lejeune, N.C., and one said he was unemployed. The others said they worked at resorts, automobile dealerships and other businesses.
Rights groups issued pleas for tolerance, saying they feared the incident might be an indication that bias was on the rise here. The state authorities said 43 bias crimes were reported in Broward County in 1991, none involving Asians.
Like Mr. Ali, many Coral Springs residents seemed to fear that the kind of violence they fled in other parts of the country and that they associate with other parts of Southeast Florida seemed to be gaining in the city.
Coral Springs's Mayor, Jeanne Mills, blamed a "party out of control," where "everyone was under some kind of influence."
Chief Arigo said: "Coral Springs enjoys a very low crime rate. In fact, the crime rate is the lowest for a city of our size in Southeast Florida, but this just goes to show you that no matter where you live, violence is part of society."

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
White, Male, Middle-Aged And Wavering

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: RIDGEWOOD, N.J.

 BODY:
Every Tuesday afternoon, about 100 business executives gather at the Knights of Columbus hall in this prosperous suburb. The group is middle-aged, all white, virtually all men ("A few ladies," says Steven Salaway), with impressive resumes -- vice presidents, division managers, systems analysts. Most are in the $70,000 to $120,000 salary range.
As a group they are not political, but individually, they tend to vote Republican. These are the out-of-work Republicans. It is why they meet, to share job leads. Some, like Mr. Salaway (bank vice president, $86,000) have been out two years. Many Americans who voted for President Bush in 1988 are now jobless. Unemployment is 9.8 percent in New Jersey, (a 10-year high); 9.4 in Michigan; 8.9 in California; 8.6 in Florida, all states that went for Mr. Bush. 
 While Republicans in Houston cheered family values, these people fretted over house payments and health insurance. Many would not give their names because they now call themselves consultants and don't want employers knowing it's a fancy title for jobless. Mr. Salaway has been set back 10 years financially. When William Graham visited his son at camp, the 11-year-old asked, "Dad, you found a job?" The father said, "Not yet." And the boy asked, "Dad, we in the poorhouse yet?"
To businessmen like these, perhaps the single most surreal moment of the Republican convention -- even more surreal than Marilyn Quayle bashing draft dodgers -- was the Secretary of Labor saying, "Are we better off than four years ago? Of course we are!"
The men at the Knights hall (they use it free) are not dinosaurs, not steelworkers or coal miners. They are management information systems specialists, fellows who know how to maximize performance from a computer system. If the economy were growing, they'd be in the thick of it. Most have been laid off during "downsizing" -- the lopping off of entire corporate divisions. Nothing personal. As their job searches stretch on, they view the economy as a downward spiral of shrinking companies going through round after round of layoffs to stay solvent.
Inflation's upward spiral helped unseat a President in 1980 and these people have that spiraling feeling again. "I'm diehard Republican," said Mr. Salaway. "I almost voted for a Democrat once -- I can't remember who." If the election were tomorrow, he said that he could not vote for Mr. Bush and that he had several Republican friends who felt the same. "Bush pretended the economy was fine too long."
"I'm definitely not voting for Bush," said Ted Sogrotzki, another longtime Reagan-Bush man. He came to the meeting like he used to dress for work, in gray suit and carrying a brief case. He's "90 percent sure" he'll vote for Bill Clinton. He found nothing new in the President's speech of a lifetime.
The economy is moving them. Walter Mazuryk voted for Mr. Bush in '88; he's moved to undecided. "I'm afraid to vote for a Democrat but I'm left with no choice." Alex Diamant couldn't get enthusiastic about anyone in '88 and didn't vote; he's moved to Mr. Clinton.
They care about family values, but few look to politicians for them. It is partly that the press has ballyhooed Gennifer and Jennifer to the point that they seem to cancel each other out. But beyond that, does anyone believe a national politician has made family a top priority? "For national businessmen and politicians, family is secondary," said Allan Karan. "Work is primary." Who spends more time raising their children, unwed mothers or the Vice President of the United States? "Family values is a smokescreen to hide the economy," says Mr. Mazuryk.
Weekly meetings are so impressive, they're painful to watch. Most participants arrive 15 minutes early. They bring job leads that didn't work for them, but may help others. Six new members introduced themselves; three had been vice presidents. They sat in rows of 10 so job leads could be efficiently distributed and collated. Free computer courses were announced in subjects like AS400/RPG3. A speaker lectured on interviewing techniques, and they took notes. They make you realize how much work unemployment is.
Each week they survey themselves. "I'd like a count of how many had interviews this week for a real job, not a recruiter or agency?" Sixteen. "How many went on a second interview?" Five. "How many offers?" Zero.
"It's scary how fast we're growing," said Mr. Mazuryk. "Each month we get 20 to 30 new members and maybe six people find a job." Afterward, they raced off. Jim Matulevich, a systems manager, had to get to a $5-an-hour liquor store job. Many will stay with Mr. Bush, but a lot are ready to hold their noses and vote Democrat and this looks to be an election that will be decided by the nose-holders.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
'Thunder' Rumbles In Travers

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22

 BODY:
Thunder Rumble, who delivered a rousing upset three weeks ago when he won the Jim Dandy Stakes at odds of 25-1, delivered just as rousing an encore today when he won the $1 million Travers Stakes by four and a half lengths and shot to the head of the class of 3-year-old colts.
He not only outran Devil His Due and Dance Floor, but all three of them outran the speed demons in the field of 10: Dixie Brass, who led into the homestretch but faded to finish fourth; Furiously, who won his first three races by 31 lengths but ran sixth in the big one, and Alydeed, the Canadian superstar and the favorite today, who stalked the leader for one mile but retreated in the stretch and finished eighth. 
 In the end, racing's celebrated house of upsets lived up to its billing in the 123d running of the Travers before a crowd of 46,372 spectators that thronged the old track in the countryside.
Here was a horse who didn't run in any of the Triple Crown races last spring, who was scratched from the Wood Memorial on the morning of the race with a virus infection, who ran once between the middle of March and the beginning of the Saratoga season, finishing seventh in an allowance race. Even when he won the Jim Dandy and paid $51.80 to anybody smart enough or bold enough to bet $2 on him, people didn't take him seriously.
In the Travers, running against all that speed, he drew the No. 10 post position on the far outside, and he was the fifth choice in the betting at 7-1. And, if all that weren't enough, he was the only horse in the field who was bred in New York State, which hadn't produced a winner of the Travers in this century.
"But I don't tell him he's a New York bred," said Richie O'Connell, who trains Thunder Rumble for Konrad Widmer, an economist from Switzerland who had never seen him win a race.
 
Some Nervous Moments
 Well, Widmer saw him win one today. But as he watched with his trainer, their underdog seemed to be moving from one trap to another.
"I was horrified," O'Connell said later. "He went wide at the first turn. He was frequently in a box. He went wide again on the far turn."
"And, after all that," he said, "he wins drawing off. I'm impressed."
He had a right to be impressed. Three weeks ago, Thunder Rumble won the Jim Dandy at a mile and one-eighth in 1:472/5 , the fastest time in 29 years. Today, he won the Travers at a mile and a quarter in 2:004/5 , delivering the third best time in the history of the race and matching the time set by the renowned Easy Goer three years ago.
Herb McCauley, who has ridden Thunder Rumble in all five victories in his seven starts this year, was impressed, too.
"When the horse broke out of the gate," McCauley said, "I saw Dixie Brass shooting for the lead on the fence. He was obviously the speed. I elected to take my horse back and not swing too wide too early. I didn't know if it would work. I didn't know if he would fire when they got down to serious running."
 
Dixie Whistles
 Most of the serious running was being done by Dixie Brass, who shot the first quarter-mile in 23 seconds and did three-quarters in 1:103/5 . As expected, he was being chased by Alydeed, briefly by Furiously and finally by Thunder Rumble, who made his move with a quarter-mile to go.
"When I let him out between the three-eighths and the quarter pole," McCauley said, "I had a ton of horse."
At the close, the ton of horse had four and a half lengths on Allen Jerkens's Devil His Due, who ran third in the Jim Dandy, and he in turn had four and a half lengths on Dance Floor, who is owned by the rap star Hammer and who had run ninth and last in his last two races.
The winner rewarded his partisans with $17.20 for every $2 bet, and rewarded his stable with $600,000.
Dixie Brass? His trainer, Dennis Brida, put it simply: "He got tired." Then he added: "He hung as tough as he could. Maybe the mile and a quarter is beyond his scope."
Alydeed? His rider, Craig Perret, reported: "I didn't want to go to the lead too soon. But when I asked him to pick it up, he didn't accelerate. I smacked him once, and he didn't give me anything."
Furiously? His rider, Mike Smith, said with regret: "I had it clear down the backstretch. but then I look, and here comes that Thunder Rumble. He flew right by me."

 
 
FINISH LINE
 Alydeed, who has been running on the medication Lasix to control pulmonary bleeding, was examined after the race but no sign of bleeding was found. . . . The weather was clear, the track was fast and the crowd was betting: $6,529,085 was wagered at the track, a record for Saratoga. The total handle at home and away reached $15,777,166. . . . PAT DAY rode the winners of the first four races, but then his streak was broken. In the Travers, he ran ninth aboard the long shot Hold Old Blue. Then he ran eighth on Devil On Ice in the $122,400 King's Bishop Stakes, which was won by D. WAYNE LUKAS'S Salt Lake, who outran the favored Binalong by three lengths with NICK ZITO'S Agincourt next. Salt Lake raced the seven furlongs in 1:212/5 and paid $19 for $2 to win.

(Associated Press)(pg. 2); Thunder Rumble, ridden by Herb McCauley, winning the 123d Travers Stakes ahead of Devil His Due at Saratoga yesterday. (Associated Press)(pg. 1)

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
3 Find Reality Is Part of the Game

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

 BODY:
They did not plan to be spectators on Saturday afternoons. After all the letters and phone calls from college football coaches, the visits and decisions, this much seemed clear: Michael Miller, Bryan Fortay and Robert Smith each possessed the gifts to make a difference in a sport that turns nearly all the others into witnesses.
As the structure of college football continues to evolve, with a coalition of bowl games attempting to reshape the sport's decisive moments and with severe economic and pressures threatening further change, there is one factor that has remained constant since the days of the flying wedge. At the highest level, on the most memorable Saturdays, the history of the game is often determined by the remarkable accomplishments of great players. 
 "Ninety-five percent of your athletes have to be good enough not to get you beat, not to lose a game for you," said John Cooper, the Ohio State coach. "But you better have somebody who is going to win the game for you."
Miller, Fortay and Smith still fit that description, even after a difficult season of inactivity in which their careers took sudden detours. In a period of several weeks late last summer, circumstances turned each of them into spectators. The circumstances illustrated the competitive and academic pressures of Division I-A football; the players' return represents an acknowledgement that they had little choice but to come to terms with the system.
Miller, who had been advertised as the next Rocket Ismail before he graduated from Willowridge High School in Sugarland, Tex., left Notre Dame to return home after 31 seconds of playing time, citing the frustration of being injured and the pressures created by Ismail's accomplishments. He returned in January after realizing he had made a mistake and starts his sophomore year at the school in September.
Also a year ago, Fortay, who lost the competition to Gino Torretta for the starting quarterback spot at Miami, was driving north to New Jersey, to transfer to Rutgers, before the 1991 season started.
And Smith, a tailback who had gained 1,147 yards as the Big Ten freshman of the year at Ohio State in 1990, left the team -- but not the school -- last August. Smith's charge that an atmosphere emphasizing athletics over academics was in conflict with his responsibility as a pre-medical student made him a national symbol for academic neglect in athletic departments.
Once the college choices of the three were made, their status as prize recruits had not shielded them from the realities of their business. An injury, or a coach's decision, or an assistant coach's approach, or a breakdown in communication, contributed to problems that had to be addressed.
"To them," Smith said of coaches, "it's a job. To me, it's a way to pay for school. That's a very big conflict."
When their situations became unbearable last season, the only way out was to get out.
"It really wasn't hard at all," Miller said. "One day I woke up. 'Hey, it's time to go.' Things weren't going the way I thought they go. I was disappointed, hurt. I just up and left. I didn't really think. I just did it."
Miller played in one game, at Michigan, returning one punt for 5 yards and three kickoffs for 19. The previous time Notre Dame had played at Michigan, in 1989, Rocket Ismail had returned kickoffs for touchdowns of 92 and 89 yards. Ismail was a sophomore that season, and healthy, and he had been able to develop a knowledge of the system. Miller was an injured freshman standing in the place of a departed legend.
"He looks like Rocket," Notre Dame Coach Lou Holtz said in February 1991. "He talks like Rocket. His facial expressions are like Rocket. He's not quite as tall as Rocket, but he's got the same bubbly personality. They tell me he's slightly faster than Rocket. He's very good at kickoff returns and punt returns, and he's more advanced as a wide receiver than Rocket at this stage."
Holtz also said this: "We do not expect him to be another Rocket."
It was too late. The coach's detailed comparisons had already chiseled the expectation into stone.
The coach had omitted one important similarity. Miller has the ability to run 40 yards in 4.35 seconds, but he would rather not be a focal point off the field.
"Another guy on the team," Miller said. "That's the way I prefer it."
A year ago, Miller's speed and potential transformed the 5-foot-7-inch, 155-pound freshman into the college equivalent of a No. 1 draft choice. A summer injury made the expectations unreachable.
"A few guys back home were just in the weight room," Miller remembered. "I was never really a big lifter in high school. It was like, 'Hey, I wonder how much you can squat.' I never squatted in high school. I was like, 'Well, let's see.' "
Miller lifted about 300 pounds, and felt his legs were tired when he ran afterward. He first thought the discomfort was just a cramp, and did not see a doctor for more than a week. But the fatigue turned out to be a severe hamstring pull.
His injury created a cycle that would soon cause him to leave. Missed practice time caused him to fall behind, and his painful hamstring prevented him from catching up. Miller was gone the Monday after the Michigan game, and was soon enrolled as a non-scholarship student at the University of Houston.
"I wouldn't like to see anyone else go through anything like that again," Miller said. "Anyone."
Fortay's problems also began before he left high school. His 4,100 passing yards at East Brunswick High School in New Jersey made him a target of the elite. Fortay listened as Miami Coach Jimmy Johnson and assistant Gary Stevens placed him in the impressive line of Hurricane quarterbacks.
Craig Erickson, the successor to Steve Walsh, had two years left, which would leave Fortay as the starter as a third-year sophomore in 1991.
"I heard Lou Holtz say you should not choose a school for a coach," Fortay said. "But with all other things being equal, why do you choose a school? A guy you feel comfortable with for the next five years, four hours a day, every day. You've got to feel comfortable with him."
Fortay made his commitment before Christmas of 1988. By early March, everything had changed. Johnson had left to coach the Dallas Cowboys, and was replaced by Dennis Erickson of Washington State.
"So here I go from a coach I feel really comfortable with to somebody I've never even spoken to on the phone," Fortay said. "And this is after nine months of perpetual call after call, after letter after letter, to the point where I'm hiding from people. And all of a sudden I've got a coach I've never even talked to. Something is wrong there."
The letter of intent binds the athlete to the school, but a coach's contract does not prevent a sudden departure. Fortay was on the Miami roster as a backup in 1989, and sat out in 1990. A year ago, just over a week before the season, Miami announced its starting quarterback. Erickson acknowledged that Fortay had better statistics in scrimmages, but said he chose Gino Torretta because of the experience. Within days, Fortay was driving north.
Robert Smith's situation did not take him anywhere. He was even in Ohio Stadium for three games last fall, using his evasive tactics. He was just evading a different group of people.
"Just basically scooting in and out," he said. "Getting the head down low a little bit. Getting the hat on, the glasses. I wasn't really seen too much during the games."
Smith's dispute with former assistant coach Elliot Uzelac -- a conflict Smith described as one of ideologies, not personalities -- put a face on the issue of time demands faced by major-college athletes.
"I want exactly what Robert is talking about," said John Cooper, the Ohio State coach. "All we had to do is communicate. If Robert Smith had come to me and said: 'Coach, I have a problem. There's a conflict. What should I do?' Boom -- go to class. It could have been avoided. It should have been avoided."
A year later, Smith has returned to the team, but an edge in his voice brings a reminder of the emotion of the time. "Saying that I caused the controversy is like saying that law causes crime," Smith said.
The controversy was especially intense with the backdrop of all those loyal thousands in scarlet and gray. "If the whole world was against me, I still would have done what I did," Smith said.
Smith considered leaving for Stanford or Southern California, but chose to stay because leaving would have disrupted his academic schedule and forced him to miss another season. The restrictions on athletes who transfer were also a consideration for Miller and Fortay.
Miller was able to return to Notre Dame because he had not gone to Houston as a scholarship student. Fortay, by rushing to enroll at Rutgers before 1991 classes started, became eligible to play this season. Smith remains on schedule to graduate with his class in 1994, and has three more seasons of eligibility.
"I feel a lot more comfortable with Coach Cooper and the coaching staff now, that they are more dedicated to us as students as well as athletes," Smith said.
"I think I'm different mentally. I've put college football into a more clear perspective in my life. I see it as a means to an end even more now. I always did, but I do realize I need to play. How long that is in the future I really don't know."
The fall quarter at Ohio State was weeks away, and for most of the day, Smith was nothing but a football player. Inside Ohio Stadium, workers were reassembling the huge bleachers that fill in the south end of the gray horseshoe and expand its capacity to 91,470. And not far away, on the practice fields outside the massive, $10.6 million Woody Hayes Athletic Center, the Buckeyes were working to meet the standard expectations of all those thousands in scarlet and gray.
As the sun began to set and Smith and his teammates sprinted at the end of their day of work, it seemed as if nothing had changed. There was still a job to be won, a system to be mastered, and a coach to be satisfied.
"It's not my job to keep them happy," Cooper said with a smile. "It's their job to keep me happy. That's the way I look at it."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 737 words

HEADLINE: Houston's Two Conventions

 BODY:
There were actually two Republican conventions in Houston, not one. The first, aimed at softening up the Democrats while firming up Mr. Bush's right wing, consisted of numbingly repetitive attacks on Congress and coarse slurs about the Clintons. It seemed to go on forever.
The second convention lasted almost an hour: Mr. Bush's acceptance speech. Here, at last, real issues like foreign affairs and the recession were engaged. Mr. Bush mentioned "family values" only once and left Bill and Hillary Clinton's personal life alone. He wasn't mean. Hard-edged, but not mean. 
 Things were choreographed this way, of course -- Bad Cop followed by Good Cop. But the Bad Cops went far beyond the normal bashing expected in politics. Directly or by innuendo, they were often divisive and occasionally savage.
Pat Buchanan derided the Democrats as "pro-lesbian and pro-gay." He spoke movingly of unemployed whites in New Hampshire ("our people") but described Los Angeles's angry blacks as the "mob." Dan Lungren, California's Attorney General, went Mr. Buchanan one better in the whites-are-victims, blacks-are-victimizers game, rehearsing at length the Willie Horton case and applauding the 1988 ads.
Pat Robertson warned that Mr. Clinton would appoint homosexuals to key posts; William Bennett inveighed against "rampant promiscuity." And even Marilyn Quayle, a sort of honorary Bad Cop, got in a few licks by reminding her listeners that not all baby boomers "dropped out, took drugs, joined in the sexual revolution, or dodged the draft."
Abortion, raging feminists and homosexuality seem to be this year's version of the distractions Mr. Bush offered four years ago: school prayer, the Pledge of Allegiance, flag burning. But by Thursday morning, the litany had tired all but the most evangelical Republicans.
Some delegates saw the whole question of "family values" less in terms of cultural issues like abortion and more in terms of economic issues like family leave and day care. Others didn't want to talk about family values at all. "I came down thinking about the economy," said Joan Rader, a Connecticut delegate.
The economy was, in fact, the central political issue for Republicans on their way into Houston and the central political issue on their way out. Mr. Bush spoke at length, and with justifiable pride, of his achievements in foreign policy. He spent many tedious minutes bashing Congress, the weakest part of a speech that seems to have had too many writers and too few editors.
Then he turned to the economy, made sweeping promises, and provided few details.
The centerpiece of his economic program is an unspecified across-the-board tax cut matched by unspecified spending cuts. The only new wrinkle was a proposal to allow taxpayers to dedicate up to 10 percent of their Federal taxes for deficit reduction, with a dollar-for-dollar reduction in Federal spending.
The program makes no economic sense. For starters, it won't jump start a laggard economy. The spending cuts will offset the tax cuts, leaving the net impact on the economy close to zero. Nor does the program address the 20-year slowdown in productivity. Untargeted tax cuts won't channel investment into new equipment or worker training, the engines of economic growth.
Mr. Bush promised more than he could possibly deliver. Neither he nor Congress has summoned the courage to propose enough spending cuts to balance even the current budget, let alone a budget thrown further into the red by a tax cut. Mr. Bush would save money by capping entitlement programs. But he apparently won't touch Social Security and veterans' benefits; to save hundreds of billions a year from what's left, he'd have to virtually eliminate Medicare and Medicaid.
The check-off for deficit reduction amounts to a truly ominous war on government -- indeed, a war on the poor. Instead of having Congress, elected on the basis of one person one vote, decide how much to reduce the deficit, Mr. Bush would empower individuals to decide. Only in his scheme, votes are proportional to income -- in effect giving the rich the power to kill programs for the poor.
After Houston, Mr. Bush hit the campaign trail, much as Bill Clinton did. A wise move: He has but two months to turn a list of dubious and disconnected proposals into a plausible, coherent agenda for growth. No amount of talk about family values can disguise that obligation.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Bush Gets Tough On Iraq

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB; Anna Quindlen is on vacation.

 BODY:
The decision to close the skies to Iraqi aircraft below the 32d parallel makes good sense. It protects Iraqi Shiites from Saddam Hussein's murderous ways. It also could weaken Saddam. His rush to invite U.N. inspectors for a firsthand look at the Shiite situation proves he understands the danger.
But check out the story behind the decision. It shows the lengths to which President Bush will go to win re-election, and how far his foreign friends will lean to help him. It also shows that crass political motives sometimes lead to good foreign policy. 
 Of course, Bush Administration officials say there is an important new element below the 32d parallel, namely Iraqi use of fixed-wing aircraft to bomb Shiites. This factor, they insist, overcame doubts about military action on the part of Mr. Bush and Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser.
But that explanation sounds limp. Iraqi forces have been using helicopters all along. With fighting now concentrated in the marshlands, helicopters would seem a much more effective weapon than fast-moving fixed-wing aircraft. It is not clear that bombing by aircraft helps much militarily.
In any event, Administration officials are quick to add that Mr. Bush and his coalition partners have a larger purpose in imposing the "no fly" rule. It is to prevent Saddam from committing "genocide" against the Shiites. (So, what about genocide in Bosnia?)
An admirable goal in Iraq, but not credible as the driving reason behind the new decision. Saddam reportedly has been slaughtering the Shiites for 18 months, and the allies never lifted a finger to help.
Administration officials, then, fall back to the deeper reason for the new get-tough policy: toppling Saddam. The idea is to face the highly nationalistic Iraqi military with a choice between preserving the unity of the country and retaining Saddam.
Yet the allies could have put the "no fly" squeeze on Saddam and sent that signal to his military months ago, and saved many Shiite lives to boot.
Again, officials say there are reasons. They wanted and still want to keep Iraq whole to ward off scrambles for Iraqi territory by neighbors. They claim, dubiously, they satisfied Turkish concerns by making clear the U.S. would not support an independent Kurdish state in northern Iraq. Yet they worry about the ties between the Iraqi Shiites and their Iranian brethren, and the threat to Saudi Arabia.
Bush aides say they finally came to realize that the Iraqi Shiites are more "Iraqi" than "Iranian" and "fundamentalist." They now believe they can safely aid the Shiites without actually splitting this territory from Iraq. The aides admit this is a tricky and risky line to walk. Indeed it is, and Mr. Bush -- and especially the Saudis -- chose not to walk it until a few weeks ago.
At that moment of revelation about Shiites a few weeks ago, what was truly new in the situation surfaced not in Iraq but in the U.S. Bill Clinton pulled way ahead in the polls, and Mr. Bush began searching the horizon for a magic campaign bullet. There, he found new resolve to confront the bully who had made him so popular in the first place and whose smiling presence hangs gloomily over the Bush Presidency.
It seems plausible that key Desert Storm partners dropped their strong objections to military action south of the 32d parallel mainly to elevate Mr. Bush's election prospects. Prime Minister John Major owes him for helping his recent comeback in British elections, and King Fahd owes him for saving Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Bush must resort to foreign extravaganzas for November. He cannot hope to turn the economy around in the next 70 days.
So look for whirlwind world action, which James Baker is already orchestrating out of the White House. There soon will be a much-needed, nonstop conference on Yugoslavia and maybe a high-profile Mideast summit meeting. More dramatically, U.S. fighters will shoot down Iraqi planes if Saddam is dumb enough to test the President. Mr. Bush is even ready to go further and use his fighter-bombers against Iraqi tanks and troops if they attack the Shiites again.
While Mr. Bush's motives churn unreliably in political impurities, they carry him toward better policies he has long ignored or resisted.

HEADLINE: American Electric Power: A Help . . .

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Coal-Burning Utility That's Trying to Paint Itself Green," (July 26) leaves the impression that the American Electric Power Corporation's donation of reclaimed land to the International Center for the Preservation of Wild Animals (now known as the Wilds) was a thinly disguised public relations exercise. On the contrary. The loss of jobs in southeastern Ohio resulting from coal-mining cutbacks is a major concern and A.E.P.'s gift ultimately will result in the creation of employment opportunities for the region. 
 Most significantly, it was A.E.P.'s expensive reclamation and careful attention to positive environmental standards over the years that made this area ideal for endangered species breeding and preservation. The mission of the Wilds is to serve as a unique resource for zoological parks and for university and field scientists involved in restoration ecology, species reintroduction and myriad other investigations. Ultimately, the Wilds will attract thousands of visitors who wish to see, experience and learn more about the natural world. These visitors, in turn, will require services and those services mean more jobs for the people of the region.
By providing the land, A.E.P. has contributed to an enormously significant conservation project, and provided a sustainable benefit to the area economy.
 
ROBERT W. REECE
Columbus, Ohio, Aug. 11
 
The writer is executive director of the Wilds.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Paranoia in the Ranks? No, Realism.

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Middle- and less-than-middle managers may be forgiven if the current terms of art in human resources -- including downsizing and streamlining -- seem more like euphemisms for bloodletting. According to Workplace Trends, a newsletter that keeps track of corporate staff cuts at all levels nationwide, 550,000 lost their jobs last year, up from 110,000 in 1989, when Workplace began collecting the data.
Because much of the current cutting is coming from their ranks, middle managers may also be forgiven for feeling that they have been forced into a nasty game of duck-and-cover by senior executives hunkered down and pushing buttons far from any set of coordinates that might put them at risk. 
 That feeling, however excessive it may sound, is not an illusion, according to research by three business school professors who tracked the efforts of 46 large companies to reverse their reverses in fortune -- defined in the research as at least a year of negative earnings. Kose John and Larry Lang, finance professors at New York University, and Jeffry Netter, an assistant professor of finance at the University of Georgia, report in the current issue of the Journal of Finance that companies have many first-strike responses to intimations of disaster.
"They retrench quickly," Mr. Lang said. "They become more focused, sell assets and divisions." Using 1980-90 information from Standard & Poor's Compustat data base and company documents, as well as news accounts, the three researchers found, among other things, that the corporations under study typically cut some 2,000 employees, or about 5 percent of their work force, in the first year after the negative earnings.
What the companies don't do is introspect much about the reasons for their plight. Most companies first blame what the authors call "exogenous variables" -- external conditions -- for their problems, including the state of the economy, mentioned by 92 percent of the companies, and competition, foreign and otherwise, mentioned by roughly half. The "endogenous," or internal, problems include writeoffs, failed acquisitions, high costs and -- way down the list -- poor management or mistakes.
In bad times, said Mr. John, "the super rational strategy would be to cut labor and make changes in top management. But on average the top man does not turn over." The study found little difference between the average turnover rate of top management at firms in general and the turnover rate for companies in trouble. "Top managers," said Mr. Lang, "never, never blame themselves."
The researchers acknowledge that they do not have data to say that poor management alone led the companies under scrutiny into a big muddy. But Mr. John argues that at some point "external factors" become mere excuses. "They play some role, but the issue is, should top management have anticipated them?" he said. Mr. Lang added: "That's their job. They make millions of dollars, but they cannot handle a crisis."
The authors stop short of saying that palming off blame is a flaw of the American character. But, Mr. Lang said, Honda never uses economic conditions, even for its United States plants, to explain away problems. General Motors, on the other hand, has used recession, and the market's shift to small cars, to account for its woes.
Mr. John and Mr. Lang say they expect the thinning of the middle ranks to continue for five more years, as companies that diversified in the 80's return to their "core competence" areas. A transition to high efficiency is imperative, they say, and the process will continue to be painful for many. But unless a company is actually close to bankruptcy, said Mr. Lang, "C.E.O.'s don't suffer."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 6, 1992, Sunday
