HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
New Year's Revolution: Bowls Try Banding Together

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

 BODY:
Not so long ago, when all those representatives of bowl games set out each autumn in their brightly colored blazers to seek teams, they were united only in a distrust of their competitors, a willingness to be entertained and a desperate need to find a respectable clothier.
 But now the Orange, Cotton, Sugar and Fiesta Bowls have banded together with six conferences and Notre Dame in an effort to introduce the concepts of dignity and organization to the college football season. The merger of all those loud jackets into a Rainbow Coalition could eventually mark 1992 as the year in which chaos began to give way to order on New Year's day and night. 
Unless chaos forces a punt.
 The coalition members are hoping their nine-year agreement will allow the bowls to collectively market and sell the same type of late-season suspense, week by week, that has made the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament a billion-dollar event.
 
Matchup Speculation Won't End
 Plan on hearing the word "unless" a lot this season. As the parity achieved by years of scholarship limitations further complicates college football's long-established order, bowl scenarios could come and go in the time it takes to set up a field goal attempt, and the possible matchups could change by the week.
 In a season that has already seen the unveiling of Northwestern's new slogan -- EXPECT VICTORY! -- you weren't really banking on the status quo, were you?
 The purpose of the coalition, according to its founders, is to create the best possible matchups and not merely No. 1 vs. No. 2. But nearly nine months after Miami won the Orange Bowl and Washington won the Rose Bowl to stake conflicting claims to the unofficial national title, a championship match could be the coalition's biggest, and most difficult, triumph.
 
Traditional Alliances Preserved
 The new system will rely on the continuing relationships between conference champions and three of the four bowls -- the Big Eight Conference with the Orange Bowl, the Southwest with the Cotton Bowl, and the Southeastern with the Sugar. The champion of the realigned S.E.C. will be determined by the first conference championship game, between east and west division winners, on Dec. 5 in Birmingham, Ala. The game is expected to produce at least $4.5 million for the conference.
 If the first and second-rated teams in the country come from the Big East Conference, the Atlantic Coast Conference or Notre Dame, those two teams will meet in the Fiesta Bowl.
 If those teams are not No. 1 and 2, the Orange, Cotton and Sugar Bowls will select opponents in order of the ranking of the Big Eight, S.W.C. and S.E.C. champions by The Associated Press poll of reporters and broadcasters. The Fiesta Bowl would choose last.
 The Big East and A.C.C. champions are guaranteed spots in the Orange, Sugar or Cotton Bowls. A plan to use the A.P. poll may be replaced by a formula that incorporates the USA Today/CNN poll of coaches.
 The most potentially damaging flaw of the system is this: If two of the teams from the Big East, A.C.C. or Notre Dame -- say the Irish and Miami -- happen to be Nos. 1 and 3, or Nos. 2 and 3, the agreement does not include a provision for them to meet.
 At a conference scheduled for late this week in New York City, coalition members intend to devise the marketing strategy they hope will enable them to explain the system to anyone who does not yet understand it.
 Which seems to be nearly everybody.
 "Let's don't start shootin' holes in something that hasn't had a chance yet," said Jim (Hoss) Brock of the Cotton Bowl. "A lot of people are taking shots at us that don't know what they're talking about. The best thing is to grin at 'em and head on down the road."
 The problem the football establishment faces is that the road the coalition is taking remains unpaved and uncharted, and its trip comes at an economically perilous time.
 Football programs will soon be limited to 85 scholarships. Pressures to make the percentages of male and female athletes more closely resemble those for student populations may result in limits on the size of football squads. The expansion of the National Football League season threatens the New Year's Day showcase that the colleges have enjoyed for decades. And the departure of underclassmen to the pros has cost college football Heisman Trophy attractions like Michigan's Desmond Howard.
 
Big Ten Precipitated Move
 Critics have already described the coalition as far from perfect and ready to collapse under its own weight.
 "Let me ask you one question," said Brock, the Cotton Bowl man. "Where would we be if we weren't in it?"
 A plausible answer is this: in deeper trouble. The decision of the Big Ten conference last year to commit its runner-up to the Citrus Bowl in Orlando, Fla., and a third team to the Holiday Bowl in San Diego, Calif., threatened to reduce the bowl system to a collection of pre-arranged marriages. Bowl tie-ins would have guaranteed much-needed revenue for conferences. But a lack of flexibility in creating matchups might have led to a credibility crisis for a disorganized bowl system already known for its backroom dealing.
 Matchups would not be finalized until after the S.E.C. championship game on Dec. 5, although some could become obvious before that point. Barring the presence of an undefeated team in the Rose Bowl between the Big Ten and the Pac-10 Conference champions, the coalition would be virtually guaranteed of having the most attractive teams.
 Unless Penn State is undefeated. In its final season as an independent, Penn State was not included when the coalition finalized its agreement. The Nittany Lions, in an effort to salvage a spot in the rapidly changing bowl marketplace, agreed on May 20 to go to the Blockbuster Bowl in Miami's Joe Robbie Stadium.
 This is how the coalition's first season could become bizarre. Pac-10 teams play eight-game league schedules, and U.C.L.A., which is considered Washington's biggest threat, is the one conference team the Huskies will not play.
 If the two teams tie for the Pac-10 championship and their overall records are the same, the Rose Bowl spot would go to the team that has gone the longest since its last trip to Pasadena on New Year's Day.
 The scheduling quirk could mean that an undefeated and highly ranked Washington team might not play in the Rose Bowl. And since the second team from the Pac-10 is available to the coalition bowls, a Miami-Washington game could happen in the Fiesta Bowl.
 Unless . . .

HEADLINE: Muted Hostility and Seeds of Hope

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE with MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
A year after violence between blacks and Jews ripped through Crown Heights, "there is turmoil," said Mildred Scott, a retired school administrator who is active in many community groups, referring to residents' anxieties about police protection, equality in city services and the future of the neighborhood.
"But," said Mrs. Scott, who is black, "there is also a new awakening. People believe they can make a change." 
 Despite such statements, Mrs. Scott and many other Crown Heights residents are haunted by the indelible sounds and images of their community last August: Jewish men, fists and weapons raised, racing through the streets; black youths overturning police cars; neighbors hurling racial epithets, bottles and rocks.
 
Grief, Anger and Violence
 The violence, which went on for four days, was set off by a day of grief and anger in which a 7-year-old black child, Gavin Cato, was killed by a car driven by a Hasidic man. Hours later, the police said, a 29-year-old Hasidic scholar visiting from Australia, Yankel Rosenbaum, was surrounded by a gang of black youths and stabbed to death, apparently in retaliation.
The chaos grabbed headlines around the world and inspired a one-woman play, "Fires in the Mirror," a critical and popular success, in which the actress Anna Deavere Smith performed monologues of more than 20 different characters involved in the confrontations.
These days the streets of Crown Heights are quieter, said most of the dozens of residents interviewed in the last few days. But they concede that it is an uneasy peace, born more of a desire to avoid further violence than to foster profound understanding between blacks and Hasidim. The changes are most often expressed in small civilities between neighbors of different races: a simple hello or thank you. Many black and Hasidic residents temper their words and actions lest they offend. Walks have less swagger, words have less bite.
 
Working for Understanding
 More ambitious residents have joined committees and formed an interracial basketball team and rap group. They have painted murals calling for peace. They have spent hundreds of hours discussing tensions over which groups get more in the way of housing, police protection and other city services.
"I try to be more friendly to my black neighbors and they do the same," said Ohev Sholom, 42, a maintenance worker. "If I try to cross in the middle of the street, a black man will stop his car and let me. That wouldn't have happened last year."
Bryan Scott, 19, who works at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, admits that the change is often tentative. "There is the understanding that there has to be interaction, but nothing personal," he said. "I guess fear is the best word, but it is not really fear, we just don't want to go through that hassle. It's not good to go to sleep with helicopters overhead."
Even for New York, Crown Heights is a neighborhood of striking contrasts. The very poor live only blocks away from the well to do. On one block, reggae music blares from once-graceful apartment buildings where windows are boarded up and graffiti covers the crumbling walls and shattered doors. Black youths gather to socialize outside corner bodegas. On another, Jewish women, their heads covered in keeping with their religion, dart in and out of well-kept homes where they live side by side with black professionals. Hasidic men in black coats and fedoras pass black teen-agers in oversized blue jeans and baseball caps.
As they work toward better communication, black and Jewish community leaders say they have worked to garner more jobs and better housing for their followers, to elect more responsive leaders and to pressure city officials for services.
 
Years-Old Chasm, Common Ground
 A few of those interviewed saw no need for change, believing that last August's violence was an aberration in their otherwise harmonious community. Some said that the little acts of civility that have proliferated since the unrest do not address inequities that exist in the treatment of two groups. And most agreed that the best thing to come out of the violence was the public admission that there were longstanding hostilities between blacks and Jews. The chasm between them has existed for so long, they say, that it is unrealistic to expect marked change in one year.
"If the gap was so large, it is not going to be filled overnight," said Lola Poisson, executive director of the Haitian Community Health Project in Crown Heights.
Rabbi Shea Hecht, a spokesman for the Crown Heights Jewish Community Emergency Committee, which was formed during last summer's violence, finds that "most of the people here get along."
"Do we love each other?" he asked. "No, we don't love each other. But I don't know if that's necessary."
On Tuesday, Richard Green, the executive director of the Crown Heights Youth Collective and one of those who kept last year's disturbances from becoming more violent, supervised the finishing touches on a "Unity Wall" mural painted by black and Hasidic youths across the street from the faded red cross painted on the sidewalk where Gavin Cato was struck. The mural depicts a Noah's Ark scene and faces of various races. "It's about us building for us," said Mr. Green, his paint-splattered orange overalls hanging on his tall, wiry frame. "That's what we've learned in this past year. We have to teach our young people a certain level of respect, a certain level of morality."
Mr. Green says he would like to see the surrounding block permanently closed to traffic, to create both a safe haven for children to play and a market for pushcart merchants.
After the violence, Rose Wexler, whose days are spent shopping and caring for her four children, joined an interracial women's group, the Brooklyn Women's Coalition, where she has begun making friends outside her Hasidic community.
"You're looking at a person who went through a terrible time during the riots," she said. "But I feel that I'll accomplish a lot more by looking at those things that bind us as mothers, as wives and as Americans. My approach over the past year has been to work with the positive."
Avrohom Shemtov, a 22-year-old student, admitted that he had grown up believing that "most blacks were criminals." Now, he has made friends with black students in his classes at Kingsborough Community College. Last semester he enrolled in a discussion group at Brooklyn College for Jewish and black youths to discuss their respective cultures and perspectives. He plans to continue with the group this fall.
Baku James, an eighth grader at Intermediate School 51, made friends with a Jewish boy who was also enrolled in an art program at the Brooklyn Children's Museum that encouraged black and Hasidic youth to work together. "People kept to themselves before the riot," he said. "Now people are trying to understand each other."
Baku said that despite such attempts at understanding, he and his new friend still live in largely separate worlds, with Eastern Parkway as the line of demarcation: Jews to the north and blacks to the south.
"If we have to go over there we don't say nothing to them," he said. "And if they have to come over here, they don't say nothing."
Despite their differences, both the black and Jewish communities of Crown Heights have been victimized by discrimination and are sensitive to perceived slurs from any group.
 
Handshakes, Smiles And Basic Hostility
 In Crown Heights, the ultra-Orthodox Hasidim see themselves as outsiders even among other Jews and as easy targets for dissatisfied blacks. The neighborhood's unemployment rate for blacks is higher than in other parts of Brooklyn and schools are among the most crowded in the city. A report prepared by a black-Jewish coalition appointed by the Brooklyn Borough President's office found that 22,000 recent immigrants, most from the Caribbean, are adding to the competition for scarce city resources.
Additionally, the Hasidic community practices separatism from the outside world as a matter of faith, so that even basic civilities like shaking hands with members of the opposite sex are curtailed by religious law.
"When we talk about having the young people get together, it does create a certain amount of anxiety about going too far in the togetherness -- about overstepping boundaries," said Rabbi Abraham Flint, a spokesman for the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council.
There are blacks and Jews who believe that the handshakes and smiles and attention to boundaries have not changed the environment that fomented last August's turmoil. Each side believes the other gets a disproportionate share of housing, quicker police response, and more city money for their community programs. Until those inequities are addressed, they say, another racially charged incident will simply precipitate more days and nights of violence.
Thaddeus Owens Jr., a black community organizer who is the son of the judge who presided over the case in which a black youth, Yusuf K. Hawkins, was killed after venturing into a white neighborhood, said that he felt racial tensions have grown in Crown Heights in the last year.
Reginald Butts, who owns a packing and shipping business, has lived in Crown Heights for more than 30 years. He said he had not really seen any change. "There is a basic hostility that persists to this day," he said. "You may be walking down the street and four or five Hasidic men will be walking in the opposite direction and none of them will yield."
Rabbi Shmuel Buttman, a spokesman for the Crown Heights Community Emergency Committee, said that since last August, "the quality of life has not been the same."
"People are afraid to walk in the street," he said. "You have to look over shoulders. It has left a mark on this community."
There are tests ahead for the fragile peace of Crown Heights.
On Tuesday night, the freshly painted "Unity Wall" mural, across the street from where Gavin Cato was struck by a car, was defaced. White paint was smeared over the mural's white, Asian and American Indian faces, but the black faces were untouched. The vandalism was denounced by community leaders, but some said they hoped it showed how much work is still needed.
 
'A Lot of Anger And a Lot of Hate'
 Earlier this month, after months of pressure from Jewish groups to arrest black youths involved in last August's violence, Raymond Wesley, a 28-year-old was charged with inciting the disturbance. When arrested in April, Mr. Wesley was initially charged with first-degree riot, but a grand jury voted to reduce the charges. Some blacks have argued that Mr. Wesley was arrested arbitrarily to appease the Hasidic community, which they say has strong ties to the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes. Mr. Hynes has denied any favoritism.
Next month, Lemrick Nelson, 16, goes on trial in the stabbing death of Yankel Rosenbaum, the Hasidic scholar stabbed hours after Gavin Cato's death. Mr. Nelson, who is charged with two counts of second-degree murder and criminal possession of a weapon, faces up to 25 years to life in prison if convicted. Many blacks are angry that no charges have been filed in the crash that claimed Gavin's life. The police ruled that it was an accident and that the driver was not at fault.
"There is a lot of anger and a lot of hate, unfortunately, on both sides," said Henry Rice, a program specialist with the National Conference, formerly the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Mr. Rice, 23, joined the organization last December. He is black and has lived in Crown Heights for 11 years.
"The attitude of a lot of Jewish people in the neighborhood is that as long as there is quiet and calm, there is peace," Mr. Rice said. "That is suicidal. When it's quiet, people are just waiting to see what's going to happen next."
Yet he points to his own situation as a sign of hope. He said he had purposely learned about other peoples and other cultures and formed many relationships with people of good will through the National Conference.
"There was a beautiful house on President Street I used to ride my bike past as a kid and wonder who lived there," Mr. Rice said. "I was in that house the other day, sitting with the Jewish owners, trying to figure out how to bring people together. That's progress."

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
In Dead of Summer, Dreams of Ski Heaven

BYLINE: By Michael S. Malone; Michael S. Malone writes frequently about Silicon Valley from Los Altos, Calif.

 BODY:
It was the hottest week of the year -- over 90 degrees -- in Silicon Valley, but for the daredevil skiing executive, now is the time to make reservations for this winter's excursion.
Not for this group the crowded winter resorts of Lake Tahoe or Aspen. Real skiing occurs in places that only helicopters can reach, where runs are measured in miles, avalanches lurk around every bend, and in a week of skiing one might not cross a single ski track. 
 Operators of "heli-skiing" adventures now offer trips to the Sierra Nevada in eastern California, the Wasatch Range in Utah and even northern India. But the most action is in the Canadian Rockies of British Columbia, in mountain ranges with unlikely names like the Bugaboos, Cariboos, Monashees, Adamants, Gothics and Bobbie Burns. By far the biggest organizer of these expeditions is Canadian Mountain Holidays Inc. of Banff, Alberta. It now sends helicopter trips to nine areas of the Canadian Rockies and has six lodges, 300 employees and $24 million in annual revenues.
Celebrated names on the C.M.H. guest list include King Juan Carlos of Spain; Richard Marriott, vice chairman of the Marriott Corporation; Pierre Trudeau; Willy Bogner, the Olympic gold medalist and chairman and chief executive of Bogner Fashion, and William T. Esrey, chairman and chief executive of Sprint. Visiting royalty pose special challenges, said Martin Von Neudegg, a C.M.H. vice president, because Canada requires they be accompanied by security personnel. The result can be armed bodyguards made to ski down mountain slopes hundreds of miles from the nearest possible threat.
Silicon Valley has had its own contingent, including James Morgan, chief executive of Applied Materials, the venture capitalist William Davidow, and the semiconductor industry pioneer Robert Noyce, who died in 1990. Like many others, Mr. Davidow recalls his most memorable moment as flying off a cliff "and looking down through my skis and seeing the ground get further and further away, then closer and closer, and then landing in an explosion of powder."
Mr. Morgan talks of the cleansing of the spirit that comes during such vacations. "The high altitude and clean air revitalize your mind and soul," he said.
For Canadian Mountain Holidays, 14-passenger twin-jet Bell 212 choppers not only deliver customers to the slopes, but are the only contact the lodges have with the outside world.
That's not to suggest these lodges are primitive. Each comes with Jacuzzi, sauna, full bar, massage therapists and gourmet chefs. Just because the snow is up to the roof and the nearest building is over the horizon doesn't mean you can't enjoy medallions of veal in lemon tarragon mousse or other entrees good enough to have been written up in Gourmet magazine. There's even a baker at each lodge.
This luxury is matched by what awaits outside. A typical day during the standard one-week visit begins at 7:30 A.M. with a stretching class, old-fashioned mountain breakfast and then the chopper ride up a nearby mountain. Groups of 11 and a trained guide do 8 to 15 runs a day, ranging from 2,500 to 7,000 vertical feet each (the longer an approximately 4.7-mile run). Even when the lodges are full, there are at most 44 skiers from C.M.H. on terrain the size of Rhode Island, so there is little chance of feeling crowded. If the weather is good, lunch is served on the slopes. Between 4:30 and 6 P.M., it's back to the lodge for a soak or rubdown, then the gourmet dinner. Afterward, ski movies are sometimes shown or the guests organize skits or costume nights. Mostly, there's a lot of talk, some of it about business. For example, the idea behind what was to become the Association for California Tort Reform, a program to reduce litigiousness in the state, was born in one such late-night conversation.
None of this comes cheap. Rates begin at $2,282 per person and climb to $4,350 per person per week, depending on the time of year. The highest rates are in February and March in a season that begins two weeks before Christmas and runs until the beginning of May. That covers everything, including skis and a guarantee of 100,000 vertical feet of skiing. There is also that soupcon of danger required by every overachiever: The Canadian Rockies is notorious for fatal avalanches. On top of that, there are the usual accidents that happen when humans hurdling down mountainsides collide with trees and rocks. More than one chief executive has had a leg or arm sewn up on the dining table. Luckily, because at least a third of the clientele is doctors, there is sometimes a trained physician around to do the stitching.
Despite these impediments, helicopter skiing has proven immensely popular. Since its founding in 1965, Canadian Mountain Holidays has served 62,000 skiers. (Its summer "heli-hiking" program, which offers a similar program for wilderness hikes, has had 19,000 clients since 1978.) Not surprisingly, some of these customers are true ski fanatics. More than 550 have skied more than one million vertical feet with C.M.H., enough to earn a special ski suit as a reward ("My $30,000 ski outfit," jokes one honoree). Ned Damon, a former rodeo and water ski champion, has skied 9,370 miles -- the equivalent of a trip from New York to Switzerland and back -- over years of 17-week stays. Mr. Damon's wife, Carolyn, has skied 13 million vertical feet.
But even in this exclusive skier's paradise, the vagaries of the outside world intrude, most notably in a changing guest list that reflects the ups and downs of the economy. For example, Mr. Von Neudegg said with a laugh, "We used to get a lot more guys from Drexel Burnham than we do now."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Baker Returns, Bringing Tried-and-True Tactics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
With but 10 weeks to election day, James A. Baker 3d took over as White House chief of staff this evening amid expectations that he planned to reorder the top of the Republican re-election apparatus.
Mr. Baker replaced Samuel K. Skinner as President Bush's top aide at 6:30 this evening, minutes after the President returned from a post-convention speaking trip to a carefully orchestrated welcome by a thousand cheering Federal employees and their families at the White House. 
 Under Mr. Baker's direction, aides said, the campaign will shun major policy initiatives in the remaining 73 days before the election, concentrating instead on a relentless effort to cast Mr. Bush as a better-prepared, more capable and more trustworthy leader than his Democratic challenger, Gov. Bill Clinton.
 
What Worked in '88
 The same tactic worked in 1988, when Mr. Baker took over the President's campaign in late summer and it roared from behind to trounce the Democratic nominee, Michael S. Dukakis. Mr. Baker will be helped by a team of aides, all veterans of the 1988 race, who are following him from the State Department to the White House.
Mr. Baker is expected to put his stamp on the White House and the campaign rapidly. A senior White House official said in a recent interview that the President had given his old friend the authority to hire and fire both White House and re-election staff members.
As Mr. Baker has already swept out the top ranks of the White House, replacing Mr. Skinner's staff with his own advisers in virtually every decision-making position, he was widely expected to "run a rake through the campaign," as one Republican associate of Mr. Baker said late last week.
 
Sticking With Teeter?
 Bush aides and Republican strategists said Mr. Baker has been urged to recruit a veteran political strategist to oversee operations at the Bush campaign offices four blocks from the White House, but it was far from clear whether he would follow that advice. Other Republican Party officials said he could well decide instead to rely on the campaign's current chairman and his old friend, Robert M. Teeter, to execute a strategy dictated by the White House.
Mr. Teeter runs the campaign's daily affairs and oversees long-range strategy, and Frederic V. Malek, an investor and airline executive, manages its finances and operations. A Washington lobbyist and conservative political strategist, Charles Black, has acted as a senior adviser to the two.
Officials called it unlikely that Mr. Baker would risk further turmoil in Mr. Bush's re-election bid by dismissing top officials outright. But they also agreed that the locus of decision-making will shift from the campaign offices to the White House, and that the authority of some of the top three will diminish dramatically in fact, if not in title.
"The very first thing you have to do is walk in the door and immediately set a tone and direction, and start moving," said a senior Administration official who is familiar with Mr. Baker's thinking. "Everything has to be integrated. You're talking about the entire process of defining what is the difference between George Bush and his challenger, and we've only got 10 weeks to do it."
Another Administration official who is an associate of both Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker said: "Baker's not going to run the campaign. The nuts and bolts will stay where they are. But the two most important things now are where the President goes, and what he says. And both of those things are going to be coming out of the White House from now on."
 
Doomsaying Officials
 Circumstances are vastly changed this summer from those in 1988, and Mr. Baker's associates and Administration officials are already seeking to lower expectations of his success.
Several of them noted in interviews last week that Mr. Baker this time was taking over both a White House and a campaign on the fly, coming from a short vacation and work on Middle East peace talks, the war in Bosnia and the growing crisis in Iraq.
Some of this aides are in a similar position. One top State Department official who will accompany Mr. Baker to the White House, Dennis Ross, was vacationing in California last week. A second, Margaret Tutwiler, returned only today from a safari in Africa.
Asked about changes in the campaign, one Baker associate responded: "That's going to be the subject of some discussion. I can't tell you how much we don't know about the campaign."
Such ignorance is probably overstated. Mr. Baker is legendary for his ability to stage manage the perception of his role, and there is ample reason for him to depict this crisis as a struggle that for which he is ill prepared, and which he could well lose.
Mr. Baker may indeed lose, but there is little chance that he is ill prepared, for that is not his nature.
As Secretary of State in mid-July, well before his shift to the White House was announced, Mr. Baker had already solicited advice from advisers on whether and how he should take on a new White House role. This month, engulfed as he was in diplomatic work, he still found time to devise a farewell address to State Department employees that became the blueprint for Mr. Bush's own acceptance speech at the Republican convention, and very likely for the campaign itself.
 
Prime Office Space
 Coming with him to the White House are the four aides who more or less oversaw the State Department for Mr. Baker for the last four years, and who will effectively run the White House for the duration of the campaign. Their roles and importance are reflected in the locations of their new offices in the coveted West Wing of the White House.
Mr. Baker will take the spacious yellow-and-white office held by Mr. Skinner, barely 40 steps from the Oval Office. Closest to him, in a windowless room occupied until now by a counselor to Mr. Skinner, will be Ms. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman and Mr. Baker's closest adviser.
Ms. Tutwiler will take the job of White House communications director, now held by Marlin Fitzwater, overseeing speech writing and scheduling. But a primary duty will be to serve as Mr. Baker's link to the national press -- the one White House official, aside from Mr. Bush himself, who knows Mr. Baker's thinking and can speak for him without hesitation.
Next to Ms. Tutwiler, in an office held until now by Mr. Skinner's deputy, Henson Moore, will be Robert B. Zoellick, the new deputy chief of staff. Mr. Zoellick, the former undersecretary of state for economic affairs, will manage the White House staff and work on policy options for a second term.
Upstairs, on the second floor, will be Dennis Ross, another policy expert who will oversee the Bush domestic agenda, and Janet G. Mullins, who will handle political affairs. They will take over offices once held by Mr. Skinner's domestic-policy experts, Clayton K. Yeutter and Roger B. Porter.
Mr. Skinner and Mr. Porter are moving to rooms in a staff building across the street from the White House. Mr. Skinner will remain about a week to help Mr. Baker before becoming general chairman of the Republican National Committee, a new post created for him this month.

HEADLINE: Latin American Indians: Old Ills, New Politics

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INGENIERO JACOBACCI, Argentina

 BODY:
It had snowed a foot and a half deep three days earlier, and a biting wind whipped down the hills around the Atraico reservation in the stretch of Patagonian wasteland that is home to 22 families of the Mapuche Indian tribe.
Secundino Cona, a 65-year-old Mapuche with a square, weathered face, huddled with his wife, Dominga Miyaleo, and their two sons around the tiny wood-burning stove in their dirt-floor adobe hut, sipping mate, a drink steeped from dried leaves of a South American evergreen. 
 Mr. Cona spoke of the firewood promised by the province government that never seems to arrive, and about his inability to imagine electricity, running water, television or automobiles ever being part of daily life here.
"The winter is very sad on the reservation," he said. "Animals die. Children get sick. We are alone."
Such pessimism, against such a harsh backdrop, could be repeated by many Indians throughout Latin America. From the Sierra Madre of Mexico to southern Patagonia, many of Latin America's 30 million indigenous people are living in a kind of permanent refugee status.
Whether the Indians are corralled into reservations like Atraico, pushed deeper and deeper into the Amazon jungle, or isolated in remote mountain areas, their cultures, religions and languages are under constant pressure from the Westernized world.
Five hundred years after the arrival of Europeans, Indians in Latin America eke out an existence far bleaker than that of native Americans.
"In the United States there is at least a sense of shame about how you treated the Indian and a feeling that some compensation is needed," said Edgardo Bujaryisqui, the Mayor of Ingeniero Jacobacci, 35 miles north of the Atraico reservation. "That consciousness or that sense of guilt just does not exist in Latin America."
Though life for the Mapuche is bleak, the group is perhaps one of the best examples of a growing trend in the last five years in Latin America of Indian groups trying to assert their rights, reclaim territory, and challenge existing laws and Government policies. Mapuche from Chile and Argentina recently proclaimed the intention of creating their own nation, and in the Chilean city of Temuco, a Mapuche leader was jailed for calling on Indians to refuse to pay taxes to the Chilean Government and to refrain from voting.
 
Will Some Groups Survive?
 But the prospects of redress for the Indians of Latin America seem remote in light of the economic problems, including debt, that hobble the region. This, in turn, raises the question of whether the Indian cultures now on the margin of society can continue to survive on their own.
Some argue that it would be better to try to bring native groups into mainstream society, saying that attempts to preserve those cultures merely keep the Indians suspended in the past.
"There is what I call the National Geographic approach here, a ridiculous hope that these people are going to go back to the countryside and resume the wonderful rural, indigenous life again," said Hernando de Soto, a Peruvian economist. "That is not going to happen. What they forget is, to these people, the medical attention and education in Lima, for example, as bad as life might be, is 10 times better than rural bliss."
Others say it is absurd to talk of saving Indians by allowing their cultures to vanish.
"None of us are necessarily advocating that Indian groups should be frozen in time from the benefits that can be gotten from national society, such as education and health care," said Ted Macdonald, projects director at Cultural Survival, a Harvard-based research group for American Indians.
"These people are saying they want to be part of the world as equals, while maintaining a sense of their own identity and difference within that world."
 
Plight Varies Widely
 To be sure, the plight of Latin American Indian groups varies from country to country. The Brazilian and Venezuelan Governments, for example, have created large reservations for the Yanomami Indians, whose lands had been invaded by miners. But such moves generally come only after much pressure from Indian groups within the country and from international rights organizations.
In some of the countries with more prominent aboriginal populations, like Colombia and Bolivia, the Indians have become well enough organized that they have succeeded in getting favorable laws passed and getting members of their tribes elected to Congress.
There are some countries, like Mexico, where many citizens have some Indian ancestry and greatly prize their Indian heritage. But this does not often spill over into efforts to protect the land and culture of Indians who still practice the old ways.
And there are countries, like Peru, where the political control exercised by whites with bloodlines anchored in Europe is so strong that the needs of native groups are all but ignored.
 
Growing Sense of Despair
 "The policies of governments have been to let us die little by little without pain," said Eugolio Frites, a Kolla Indian from northern Argentina and a lawyer. "They don't think us capable of civilization."
These pressures have bred despair. Suicide is common in some tribes in the Amazon. In the Peruvian highlands, there is growing addiction to cocaine derivatives, a dangerous step beyond the coca-leaf chewing that has been Indian practice for centuries.
Government officials here estimate the per capita income of the Mapuche at less than $500 a year. Measuring the income of many Indians is nearly impossible, since the majority live on subsistence farming. Some groups deep in the Brazilian Amazon may seldom deal in currency, while Indians closer to cities may have a large number of people in the broader work force.
The United States Government spends $3.5 billion a year on programs covering the roughly one million Indians living on reservations, or $3,500 a person. The United States calculates that the average household income of American Indians on reservations is $20,025. Native groups in Canada fare even better.
Government help barely exists for Indian groups in Latin America. Anthropologists who study the region say they know of no program specifically aimed at helping Indians, though the Inter-American Development Bank and the United Nations are discussing the creation of an Indian fund of about $40 million that would be used to help Latin American indigenous groups.
 
Reformers Face Opposition
 Small groups from various Indian tribes across Latin America have been formed to express discontent and try to assert their rights. They often face powerful opposition.
In Chile, Pehuenche Indians are under pressure by the country's most profitable company, Endesa, to cooperate in the building of a series of dams on land that has traditionally been theirs.
In Brazil, the creation of reservations for the Yanomami and Kaiapo have brought a strong political backlash against the Government of Fernando Collor de Mello from mining and lumber interests.
Among the Mapuche, Indian rights advocates are divided between those who seek a closer relationship with the mainstream Argentine culture and province governments, and those who have adopted a more radical stand, calling for the creation of an autonomous Mapuche nation.
More than 200 representatives of the more radical Mapuche in Chile and Argentina met recently in Neuquen, in central Argentina, to discuss how to create a new nation and recoup large amounts of ancestral territory. But these are goals that many Mapuche leaders concede they are unlikely to achieve.
"Every time they rise up, they get hit with a blow that is two or three times worse," said Gustavo Flichman, a specialist in Indian affairs at the Center for Advanced Studies at the University of Buenos Aires. "They want to develop their culture without being stopped from being part of the mainstream of life. But so far that is impossible."
Mr. Flichman noted that in Argentina, which has 14 tribes and more than a million Indians in all, many live on public land or in national parks, but are barred from hunting and from using the wood there to build fires. Their indigenous religions are not legally sanctioned by the state. In many areas, Indians cannot get title to land they have lived on for generations. And when they try to live in the cities, they face frequent discrimination.
"Kids are told in school, 'Behave, don't act like an Indian,' " Mr. Flichman remarked.
Herded onto reservations or left to wander on public lands, the Mapuche found sheep farming their one source of income. But falling prices for wool and the increased fencing of grazing land by ranch owners have made conditions particularly difficult.
 
Inhospitaple for Shepherds
 The plains of Patagonia are so arid that it takes five acres to support one sheep. This was less of a problem when the range was open, but with the fencing of land, the pasture available to the Mapuche at Atraico is down to about 1,000 acres a family. The cost of irrigation is prohibitive.
Thus the typical Mapuche family here can graze at most 200 sheep, which produce about 1,600 pounds of wool a year. At the going rate of 40 cents a pound, the family's annual income is $640.
"The rich have fenced in the land," said Geronimo Colinamon. "Before, you could use the territory of the neighbors and we could have 1,000 sheep. Now I can have only about 150 sheep."
Mapuche worry that the social fabric of the reservation is crumbling. Since the land is supporting fewer people, most of the young leave to find work in the cities. Often they do not return.
"Two or three Mapuche can't do anything; we will just die out," said Ignacio Antitru, the Atraico community's political leader. "If we don't work together, we will lose our right to exist."
The system of chiefs, by which the reservations are governed, is also disappearing. Atraico's chief died several years ago, and the community has been unable to find anyone to replace him. Members now temporarily appoint one of their own to represent them at Mapuche gatherings and in contacts with the province government.
With the death of the chief, who also served as the tribe's religious leader, the annual religious festival called the camaruco, an important vehicle for maintaining the Mapuche language as well as religion, has also died. Very few Mapuche in Atraico speak the native tongue any more.
"We have practically lost the language," said Jose Colinamon, who lives in a tiny hut with his wife, Julia Rosa. "The old people are the ones who speak, but so few are left. And the young ones are pressured not to speak the language."
And Juan Sargento Profil, an 80-year-old chief from another reservation about 60 miles west of Atraico, explained matters this way: "Our god is angry with us -- that is why our life has been so hard. We have adopted the white man's religion. We are speaking his language. We are not doing camaruco. Therefore he lets the animals die."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Two or three Mapuche can't do anything; we will just die out," said Ignacio Antitru, a leader of the Atraico reserve in Argentina. The Mapuche, like many indigenous people in Latin America, are fighting for survival. (Nathaniel C. Nash/The New York Times) (pg. A1)

HEADLINE: U.S. WILL TIGHTEN HEALTH-LAB GOALS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has drafted a broad strategic plan that sets new priorities for the Government's vast biomedical research efforts, which until now have proceeded along largely disparate paths chosen by individual scientists and research institutions.
The Government plan is intended to channel $9 billion in Federal money to areas Washington deems critical to the nation's health, while for the first time also trying to insure that American medical researchers proceed along lines that keep the United States economically competitive. 
 The plan has alarmed many scientists, who say it gives the Government too big a role in defining priorities and places too much emphasis on the commercial exploitation of their work. These scientists say Washington is trying to set a national industrial policy.
 
A Call for Priorities
 But in an interview, Dr. Bernadine P. Healy, director of the National Institutes of Health and the principal architect of the new plan, said, "I don't understand why industrial policy is such a bad word." If scientists and the N.I.H. do not set clear priorities, she added, Congress and other outsiders will do so.
For a decade, the Reagan and Bush Administrations have resisted efforts by Democrats in Congress to get the Government more deeply involved in managing the economy, subsidizing new technologies and directing research, as Japan and some European nations do. The Administrations' free-market economists assert that the Government has no business picking winners and losers.
The strategic plan is intended to bring order to the network of research units that make up the N.I.H., through which the Government finances research on cancer, heart disease, AIDS, diabetes, arthritis, stroke and scores of other illnesses. It is also intended to clarify research goals to insure that the Government gets a high return on its investment of $9 billion a year. Eighty percent of that money goes through the N.I.H. to private researchers around the country; under the plan, substantial amounts of research money are expected to be awarded to scientists working in particular areas.
Among the plan's stated goals is to expand biomedical and related sciences "in order to enhance the nation's economic well-being." The plan says, for example, that such fields as biotechnology, molecular medicine, immunology and vaccine development should be favored because these areas offer "substantial contributions to the enhancement of the nation's economic growth, productivity and competitiveness."
"Critical science and technology are an investment in the future," the plan says.
Biotechnology sales in the United States totaled $4 billion last year and are expected to reach $50 billion by the year 2000, analysts at Ernst & Young say.
But Dr. William D. Terry, senior vice president at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, expressed the concern of many scientists that Government direction could have adverse effects.
"Unless you assure continued support for high-quality fundamental basic research, there is a potential for killing the goose that has laid many thousands of golden eggs," said Dr. Terry, who worked at the N.I.H. for two decades. "Ideas come out of the head and experience of an individual investigator and do not necessarily fit into the overall game plan of the N.I.H."
 
Economic Goals
 The scientists' concerns include these aspects of the N.I.H. blueprint:
*The strategic plan says that one of the main N.I.H. goals is "to enhance the nation's economic well-being"; an earlier draft said the goal was to increase the nation's "economic competitiveness." The economic payoff was, until now, seen as a happy byproduct of the Federal investment in biomedical research, not as an objective to be pursued for its own sake.
*While recognizing that the creative ideas of individual investigators are the engine of scientific research, the strategic plan makes clear that the Government will play a bigger role in defining overall priorities for such research. Many scientists doubt that the Government has the wisdom, foresight or expertise to set priorities or objectives for basic research.
*The N.I.H., which flourished as a loose amalgamation of many independent units, will now have a "corporate philosophy" and structure and will operate on a corporate model, with stronger central direction from Dr. Healy's office.
Dr. Healy, a cardiologist who worked on science policy in the Reagan White House, said: "The N.I.H. really does need a little more central leadership. If you have strong organizational units and no sense of central leadership, you have anarchy, people going in different directions, pulling against one another, duplicating effort, often destructively at odds. That kind of anarchy is not healthy for any organization."
But Dr. David P. Rall, who worked at the N.I.H. for 37 years, said, "I always thought good basic research flowered in a bed of anarchy."
Dr. Rall, who served as the director of the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences from 1971 to 1990, said Federal officials were "not smart enough to know which research will really be the most profitable."
In addition, Prof. David A. Clayton of Stanford University, a biochemist and molecular geneticist, said that science was moving so fast nowadays that a strategic plan might be outdated by the time it is published.
The strategic plan is subject to approval by the Public Health Service, the Department of Health and Human Services and the White House Office of Management and Budget. But Dr. Healy said it had already "made a difference in the distribution of money." N.I.H. officials are putting more emphasis on the health problems of women and minorities, nutrition, the prevention of disease and environmental health risks, she said.
Dr. Healy promised that the Government would not "micromanage" the work of private researchers who get N.I.H. grants.
The history of science is full of cases in which basic research, with no obvious practical application, produced major discoveries of immense unexpected value. For example, Dr. Baruch S. Blumberg, winner of the Nobel Prize in 1976, was trying to understand why people varied in their responses to disease when he found clues in the blood of an Australian aborigine that led to the discovery of the hepatitis B virus and to the invention of a vaccine against it.
Dr. Blumberg said the strategic plan must not undermine research inspired by the curiosity of individual scientists. "Much of the highly targeted research in the war on cancer in the 1970's was inappropriate because we did not know enough about the basic science of cancer virology," he said.
 
Healy Defends Plan
 But Dr. Healy said: "Priorities have always been set for research. But they were set secretly, chaotically, sometimes by accident. I am saying, 'Let's get the process out in the open, and let's get scientists more involved.' "
She also makes no apology for emphasizing the practical side of the agency's work. "We have allowed ourselves to be insular and ivory-towerish and were not connecting to the public," she said. "N.I.H. does not exist to do science for science's sake, but to do science in service of the public, to improve the health of 250 million Americans."
Stimulating economic growth is "a new responsibility for N.I.H. that did not exist 15 or 20 years ago," Dr. Healy said.
The guts of the strategic plan -- the statement of mission, goals and philosophy -- is firmly in place. Federal officials have not decided how much detail to include.
Their working papers suggest that they are likely to recommend networks of high-performance computers to study genes and design drugs; more aggressive work on vaccines, including vaccines to prevent cancer; more emphasis on the research needed for new biotechnology products, and more work on breast cancer, including studies of the genetic differences between male and female breasts.
Begun as a one-room laboratory in 1887, the N.I.H. now has 15,000 Federal employees and almost 200 advisory committees. It finances the work of 100,000 scientists at more than 1,800 institutions around the country. Research grants are awarded through a system of peer review, with outside experts judging the merits of each application.
Dr. William E. Harmon, director of the kidney-disease program at Children's Hospital in Boston, said: "There is a sort of chilling breeze blowing through basic science laboratories. Scientists are concerned that N.I.H. is going to tell us what to investigate, and we will lose some of our own initiative."
Dr. Steven L. Teitelbaum, a professor of pathology at the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, spoke for many scientists when he said: "The best basic research is hypothesis-driven. The scientist formulates a hypothesis and examines it according to the scientific method. My concern is that the strategic plan moves away from hypothesis-driven research toward pragmatic research."

(Stephen Rose for The New York Times) (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: Chinese and South Koreans Formally Establish Relations

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Monday, Aug. 24

 BODY:
China and South Korea formally established diplomatic relations this morning, and Beijing announced that the South Korean President, Roh Tae Woo, would make an official visit "in the near future."
A joint statement, signed at a ceremony here and broadcast live on Chinese television, ended four decades of official hostility based on ideological rivalry and bitter memories of the Korean War of 1950-53. China took hundreds of thousands of casualties in joining North Korean troops in that war against American-led United Nations forces. The Chinese have remained one of North Korea's closest allies. 
 The statement today called for an exchange of ambassadors, and it requires South Korea to break diplomatic relations with the Chinese Nationalist authorities on Taiwan. Beijing will continue to recognize North Korea and could play a role as an intermediary between the two rival Governments on the Korean peninsula.
The statement said: "The Government of the People's Republic of China and the Government of the Republic of Korea believe that the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries will be conducive to the relaxation of tension and stability on the Korean peninsula, and also to peace and stability in Asia."
South Korea hopes that Beijing will nudge the North toward a more accommodating policy, but the Chinese seemed to take a somewhat ambiguous position on that in the announcement today.
 
A Korean Matter, China Says
 The statement, which was signed by Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China and his South Korean counterpart, Lee Sang Ock, said that Beijing respected the desire of the Korean people for quick reunification through peaceful means and supported their efforts to reach that goal. But it added that they must reach that goal "by themselves."
In Seoul, the South Korean capital, President Roh was quoted by the Reuters news agency as saying: "The normalization of ties between our two countries marks a significant turning point in world history in that it heralds the beginning of the end of the cold war in East Asia, which remains as the last legacy of the cold war era."
In recent years, China has adopted an increasingly pragmatic foreign policy, based largely on economic interests rather than Communist ideology. It has recognized Israel and re-established relations with Indonesia, both of which it used to denounce regularly, and relations have been warming with South Africa as well.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Criticizes President's Remarks on Religion

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton accused President Bush today of promoting religious and political intolerance in the United States for political gain.
In one of the sharpest counterattacks yet in the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton said that Mr. Bush had abandoned the American principle that individuals should be free to disagree on personal issues, especially religious and family values. 
 "I think he is promoting an atmosphere of intolerance in this country that is inconsistent with the spirit of Thomas Jefferson and Abraham Lincoln," the Arkansas Governor contended.
He was referring to a comment by Mr. Bush on Saturday that Democrats "took words to put together their platform but left out three simple letters: G,O,D."
 
Family and the Economy
 After attending a church service in Erie, Pa., the Democratic nominee told reporters: "The implications that he has made, that Democrats are somehow Godless, are deeply offensive to me and to all of us who cherish our religious convictions but also respect America's tradition of religious diversity. He has basically said that unless you believe in the Republican platform, you don't believe in God and you're not an American."
Mr. Clinton added that he thought Mr. Bush had made the comments for political purposes.
The introduction of religious tolerance into the campaign is the latest permutation in a debate that has come to interwine family values and the condition of the economy.
Mixed into the debate is a Republican assertion, more in the form of allusion than direct statement, that Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, are not good family people.
Mr. Clinton's response to this has been that he and his wife fully understand and respect family values, and that why else would they have spent much of their adult lives promoting health, education and job programs to help the nation's families and children?
"Now that's family values," he declared today in a speech to 5,000 or so people gathered on the grassy quadrangle in Chautauqua, the lake resort whose fame is built on its annual series of summer lectures.
If Mr. Bush truly understood and respected family values, Mr. Clinton argued in one of the more extensive speeches he has given on the subject, he would have made greater efforts to promote similar family programs and, moreover, would not have let the nation slip into a debilitating recession.
"I don't think that's family values," Mr. Clinton told the crowd in Chautauqua. "Unless we do a better job of lifting our people up, we're all going to be dragged down."
Winding up a three-day bus tour around the south shore of Lake Erie with his running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, Mr. Clinton also responded sharply today to an assertion on Saturday by Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House minority whip, that the Democratic platform had a lot in common with the personal life of Woody Allen.
The film maker has acknowledged having an affair with an adopted daughter of his former lover, Mia Farrow.
 
'He Just Has No Shame'
 "That remark by Gingrich was off the wall and out of line and he just has no shame," Mr. Clinton said.
Asked whether he thought the comment by Mr. Gingrich, who was campaigning yesterday in the South with Mr. Bush, reflected the President's thinking, Mr. Clinton told reporters: "Of course it does. He was speaking for him and he picked him to speak."

HEADLINE: Tough Task Ahead in Beating Trial

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The Federal Government plans to bring four Los Angeles police officers to trial next month for their roles in the beating of Rodney G. King, hoping to succeed where the State of California failed four months ago. But legal experts say the Federal prosecutors may have even more trouble winning convictions than the state did.
The Federal charges, which were brought this month, accuse the officers of depriving Mr. King of his civil rights when they beat and kicked him for 81 seconds on the night of March 3, 1991. The episode was captured on an amateur's videotape and provoked the nation's deadliest riot in this century after the officers were acquitted last April. The Federal trial is tentatively set for Sept. 29. 
 Difficult as it turned out to be to prove charges of assault in the first trial, experts caution that the Federal charges set an additional requirement: that the jury find that the officers knew they were using excessive and unnecessary force, that they intentionally broke the law.
 
'Very Tough to Prove'
 "What has to be shown is that they intended to deprive Rodney King of his constitutional rights," said Kim A. Taylor, a professor of law at Stanford University. "It's very tough to prove. Because of the bias most juries have in favor of police officers, unfortunately, I think it would be extremely surprising to me if there were a conviction."
The Justice Department loses about 25 percent of the official-misconduct civil rights cases it chooses to bring to trial out of hundreds of complaints it receives. The difficulty of proving criminal intent is one main reason.
"There is no magic formula," said a Federal law-enforcement official who said policy required that he not be quoted by name. "You can't read a person's mind. The jury is always instructed that you have to infer intent from the surrounding circumstances and the nature of the assault."
 
States Are High
 The stakes in the case are high following the violent reaction to the acquittal in the first trial. In the unexpected calm of what has turned into a hot and muggy summer, the city seems to be holding its breath as it awaits the start of the Federal trial.
All four policemen are white; Mr. King is black. Federal prosecutors began preparing their indictment, which makes no mention of a racial motive, after a jury of 10 whites, 1 Asian and 1 Hispanic member in suburban Simi Valley acquitted Sgt. Stacey C. Koon and Officers Laurence M. Powell, Timothy E. Wind and Theodore J. Briseno on April 29 of all but one count among charges of assault and use of excessive force.
Rioting swept Los Angeles after the acquittals, taking 51 lives, causing $850 million in damage and bringing a web of social tensions to the surface. Many community leaders say these tensions could boil over again if the four officers are acquitted a second time.
Mr. Wind, who was a rookie officer without tenure at the time of the beating, was dismissed from the police force. The other three men have been suspended without pay and are awaiting police department administrative hearings on their job status.
On Aug. 5 a Federal grand jury returned indictments that charge the three officers with violating Mr. King's Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable arrest. Sergeant Koon is charged with depriving him of his 14th Amendment right to due process of law for failing to restrain the officers. If convicted, each defendant faces up to 10 years in prison and $250,000 in fines.
All four men pleaded not guilty on Aug. 10.
The start of the Federal case is expected to be delayed by legal maneuvers, including a defense request for a change of venue because of publicity.
Federal prosecutions that follow state court acquittals trouble some legal scholars, like Alan M. Dershowitz of Harvard Law School, who calls them "a second bite at the apple." But the Supreme Court has ruled that such cases do not constitute double jeopardy because of the separate jurisdictions of state and Federal courts.
 
A Close Legal Call
 Legal scholars say they can be difficult to win because defense lawyers are familiar with the witnesses and evidence and because juries can be influenced by the earlier acquittal.
And in cases involving specific intent, juries must make a close legal call. This difficulty is illustrated in the Justice Department's suggested language for a judge's instructions to a jury: "An act is done willfully if it is done voluntarily and intentionally and with the specific intent to do something the law forbids; that is, with an intent to violate a specific protected right."
In a case like this one, said Prof. Drew Days of Yale Law School: "There has to be some point at which one concludes that they have got beyond the point of effecting an arrest and have decided to become judge and jury on the spot. This is the source of additional pause on the part of jurors in trying to arrive at a decision."
Proof of intent almost always depends on circumstantial evidence, said Richard Cohen, legal director of the Southern Poverty Law Center, which specializes in representing the victims of racial violence. "Typically, you look at people's conduct before and after the event," he said.
 
Pieces of Evidence
 The first trial in the beating, which came after Mr. King had been stopped for speeding, included several pieces of evidence that might be used now in an attempt to show the officers' intent.
These included police computer messages before the beating that appeared to involve racial slurs, a radio message afterward in which one of the police officers seems to be laughing about his actions, and a conversation where police officers jokingly say they "hit some home runs" during the beating.
If the Federal prosecutors can prove, as the state prosecutors failed to do, that the officers lied about the beating in their police reports, this would also suggest that they knew what they had done was wrong, Mr. Cohen said.
He said a prolonged beating, in this case 56 blows, also offered a better chance of conviction, suggesting that force continued beyond the point at which it was needed to complete an arrest. But in the first trial, defense lawyers apparently convinced the jury that Mr. King continued to provoke the blows as he rolled about on the ground. The officers asserted that they were following standard procedure in subduing an unruly suspect.
Many analysts say prosecutors in the first trial made a mistake in deciding not to call Mr. King to the witness stand, and he is expected to testify in the Federal trial. But some analysts are now warning that Mr. King, an unemployed construction worker with a criminal record, could present problems to the prosecution.

HEADLINE: Yugoslav-American in Belgrade Leads Serbs Who Won't Follow

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Since Milan Panic, a California millionaire, returned to his native Yugoslavia to assume the job of Prime Minister, he has vowed to end support for Serbs fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina, to allow observers to move freely through Yugoslav territory and to halt "ethnic cleansing," which he described in his inaugural address as "the disgrace of our nation."
But although Mr. Panic's words have been welcomed, he has been unable to keep his promises. Several programs have been blocked by Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, the larger of the two republics that make up the truncated Yugoslav federation. Others have been sidetracked by members of Mr. Panic's Cabinet, some of whose members were imposed on him by Mr. Milosevic and the Yugoslav President, Dobrica Cosic.
 
Not Welcome at Peace Talks
 Despite Mr. Panic's efforts, the war in Bosnia is still raging, and foreign governments are tightening their sanctions against Yugoslavia. 
Some organizers of the peace conference that opens Wednesday in London are so skeptical of Mr. Panic's ability to influence events that they sought to exclude him. He finally won the right to attend, but as a private individual, because the conferees do not recognize the federal Government in Belgrade. The principal Serbian spokesman is likely to be Mr. Milosevic.
Mr. Panic's sharpest critics say he is allowing himself to be used by hard-liners like Mr. Milosevic, presenting a sympathetic face to the world while they quietly continue aiding Serbian fighters who are forcing thousands of Bosnians from their homes.
Those who sympathize with him urge that he be given more time to change a political culture where democracy is a new concept.
 
Behind on Points
 "He has raised hopes that with his American style, his optimism and his energy, he can get this country out from under the sanctions and wind the war down," said a foreign diplomat. "But in terms of clout and political power, he still has a long way to go. He's working in a field where he has no experience, and this is one of the biggest snake pits in the world."
Perhaps no European leader faces as daunting a challenge as that confronting the 63-year-old Mr. Panic (pronounced PAHN-itch). Yugoslavia has been blamed for triggering the savage war in Bosnia and has become an international pariah, choked by sanctions and convicted of brutal aggression in the court of world opinion.
Although Mr. Panic was still in California when Serbian leaders began their march into isolation, those who led the country into its current disaster are still in powerful positions. Chief among them is Mr. Milosevic, an unabashed Serbian nationalist who is widely viewed as Mr. Panic's principal rival. The two have built a fragile relationship, but devote much of their energy to outmaneuvering each other.
Thus far, Mr. Milosevic appears to have won most of these confrontations. He reportedly vetoed Mr. Panic's choice to head the foreign ministry, and has prevented the Panic Government from recognizing Croatia, which outsiders say it must do if it hopes to persuade the United Nations to lift economic sanctions.
Asked in an interview if Mr. Milosevic was his greatest problem, Mr. Panic smiled and replied, "I think he's Yugoslavia's problem."
 
Lazar the Loser (Gasp!)
 In his duels with Mr. Milosevic and his other adversaries, Mr. Panic relies principally on the colorful style that he developed during 30 years as a California entrepreneur.
That style was on full view Friday, when he appeared before Parliament to urge new steps toward peace. After deputies began to attack his proposals, he launched into a tirade that included ridicule of Serbia's most revered hero, Prince Lazar.
In the 14th century, Prince Lazar led his small Serbian force in a suicide attack against invading Turks. Generations of Serbs have honored him as a figure who chose to uphold the nation's dignity even at the price of death.
"That was a stupid fight," Mr. Panic told the stunned Parliament. "How can you glorify a defeat? You people here today are not just fighting the Turks, you are fighting the whole world," he exclaimed, his voice rising in controlled anger. "I will not accept that! We are not going to fight the world! We are going to make peace!"
When jeers began to rise from the assembly, Mr. Panic picked up a glass of water and shouted, "You don't think I'm a fighting Serb? Then I'll throw this glass in your face."
 
'Shock Therapy'
 Never having seen such conduct, many deputies began to laugh. Mr. Panic laughed with them, breaking the tension, and later several congratulated him.
"They needed that, they really did," Mr. Panic said later. "They need shock therapy. They are living in Disneyland. They're in the Twilight Zone."
Even his admirers are not sure Mr. Panic will be able to shake a nation that has been lost in almost suicidal fatalism since the days of Prince Lazar. Nearly everyone here, though, welcomes his upbeat enthusiasm.
"I see Mr. Panic as, first of all, different from what we have had," said Tibor Varad, a Harvard-trained lawyer and Mr. Panic's Minister of Justice. "His being here does not guarantee change, but it is a chance for change. He can't do everything at once, but we are in a position where many things need to be done at once. This is his predicament."
In his first six weeks in power, Mr. Panic has spent most of his time abroad, trying to convince foreign leaders that he is sincere in his campaign for peace. He has traveled to more than a dozen countries, and twice visited Sarajevo, the besieged capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
 
Center Ring, or Sideshow?
 On his recent visit there two weeks ago, he failed to meet his adversaries, apparently because he had not arranged appointments. But his party was hit by sniper fire that killed an American journalist, leading some to suggest that Mr. Panic was endangering himself and those around him by taking trips that had more publicity value than political effect.
Many diplomats in Belgrade are convinced there can be no real progress toward peace while Mr. Milosevic is in power. Acutely aware of that sentiment, Mr. Panic is trying to find a way to ease the President of Serbia out.
He has directed the Justice Ministry to draw up a plan for early elections; Mr. Milosevic might choose not to run, or might be defeated if he chose to become a candidate. But Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party, successor to the Communists, controls Parliament and has thus far blocked any elections.
"Mr. Panic came here as a kind of messiah, or at least he was announced as one," said Vuk Draskovic, leader of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement. "He asked 100 days to end the war, lift the sanctions and set the stage for what he called American democracy. But almost 50 days have passed, and Mr. Panic has done nothing to loosen the noose.
"Bonn or London or New York are not to blame for the sanctions. Belgrade is responsible for them, Mr. Milosevic and his Government are responsible. He is the world's most hated man, and as long as he is in office, there will be no progress and no lifting of sanctions. If Mr. Panic is able to remove him, then all of us in the democratic opposition will cheer. But so far he is not strong enough to do it."
 
From $20 to Drug Entrepreneur
 Although he considers himself a "patriotic Yugoslav," Mr. Panic has been much shaped by his life in the United States. Reflecting his mixed background, he speaks English with a Balkan accent and Serbo-Croatian with an American accent.
The Serbian-born Mr. Panic, who in his youth was a Yugoslav cycling champion, emigrated to the United States in 1956, arriving in New York with "two suitcases and $20," according to his official biography. He made his way to California, and in 1960 founded ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., which grew into a multimillion-dollar company based in Costa Mesa, Calif.
His business career has been marred by legal trouble. In 1991 his company paid $600,000 in costs and penalties after the Food and Drug Administration charged that ICN had misrepresented the medicinal qualities of a drug called Virazole. The company had described the drug as an AIDS treatment.
Mr. Panic is currently facing charges of defaulting on an $8.4 million loan he assumed when he bought a California motel in 1985, as well as charges that he owes real estate taxes on another motel.
 
A Man of Money
 Some ICN shareholders complained when it was disclosed that Mr. Panic took salary and compensation worth more than $6 million in 1991. The company's profit that year was only $5.8 million, but Mr. Panic defended his earnings by saying he had taken steps that would bring far greater profits.
Mr. Panic has been a generous donor to political causes, favoring liberal Democrats and especially the former California Governor, Edmund G. Brown Jr. But he is also an active backer of the conservative Freedom Foundation, which is supported by Associate Justice Antonin Scalia and a former delegate to the United Nations, Jeane Kirkpatrick.
After making a series of speeches in recent years to business and scientific groups in Yugoslavia, Mr. Panic emerged as an intriguing local personality. Several months ago, as the country was plunging into its current abyss, Mr. Cosic, the President of Yugoslavia, telephoned him and asked him to return and lead the Government.
Mr. Panic received a special waiver from the Treasury Department allowing him to work in a country that was under United Nations sanctions, and assurances from the State Department that he would not be stripped of his United States citizenship. He was inaugurated on July 14.
 
Out of Control
 Sitting on a sofa at the Belgrade mansion where he now lives (his family has remained in California), Mr. Panic said much of the violence in Bosnia is being perpetrated by bands beyond the control of Serbian, Muslim or Croatian leaders.
"At first I thought those three leaders were three crooks," he said. "Now I believe that they may not be the most decent human beings, but they are not directing this war. There are 1,200 or 2,000 really bad guys out there who are responsible for most of these atrocities you hear about. They are called paramilitary, but they are really just terrorists."
Some commentators here predict Mr. Panic will not survive more than a few months as Prime Minister, and he does not expect to stay for more than two years. In that time, he said, Yugoslavs should be able to learn the rudiments of democracy.
"If I talk to you in Chinese and you don't understand, that doesn't mean you are not intelligent," he said. "It just means that you haven't had a chance to learn Chinese. That's the way it is here with democracy. I have to start with lesson one. But we are making progress toward democracy, and progress toward peace. If people pray for me, I think we can succeed."
