HEADLINE: Voices of Stoicism, Fear and Revelry As Many Prepare to Ride Out Storm

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Shortly before noon, with the sun still shining brightly but with reports of the approach of Hurricane Andrew beginning to throb with urgency, Karen Madsen drew the drapes, shut off the electricity and said goodbye to her waterfront condo here.
Like most of the other residents in her six-building complex overlooking Biscayne Bay, Ms. Madsen, a 46-year-old banker, had not installed storm shutters and said she had no way to board up the huge plate-glass windows that give her fourth-floor apartment a spellbinding marine panorama. 
 "I just have to hope for the best," she said as she checked into a hotel on the edge of Miami International Airport where the loading ramps were jammed and airline officials said every flight out was booked solid.
 
Stoicism and Daring
 As the most powerful hurricane in years bore down on the glistening, glass-encased hotel and office towers, the mansions and the simple sunbaked homes of Miami, residents and visitors turned to face the story each in his own way.
Everyone was at least a little apprehensive. Some were terrified. Some were stoic, fatalistic. Some laughed at the danger.
Many took the advice of the authorities and headed for shelter well away from the magnificent waters that embrace the city.
But throughout the vast evacuation zone from the Florida Keys to well north of Miami, many others said they would ride out the storm no matter what anyone told them.
James L. Greenhill, an 87-year-old lawyer who has undergone several hip operations, said he did not want to leave his third-floor apartment and could not even if he wanted to.
"I can't even move without those damn things," he said, gesturing contemptuously toward a pair of spindly alloy walkers.
"I'm staying," Mr. Greenhill said firmly. "I don't know where the hell to go. The shelters are awful."
His wife, Doris, who had set out kerosene lamps and flashlights and was boiling a batch of eggs, offered no dissent. "If the house goes," she said, "we go. I hope it is not painful."
 
Stuck in the Keys
 In Key West, many tourists who were unable to get away on commercial or chartered flights tried to hire taxis to drive them to Miami, 164 miles to the northeast, but found no takers. "It's an eight-hour drive to Miami, and we may get stuck on a bridge," said Morgan Haas, a cab driver.
Actually, the trip to Miami was taking about five hours by late afternoon, Monroe County emergency officials said. Normally, the drive is about three hours.
Joe Morgan, a Key West bartender, said he would rather stay home than risk getting caught in heavy traffic. "Just think," he said, "there are other islands, and we're at the end."
Mr. Morgan and his friend Don Kissee were stocking up with 10 gallons water, rice, beans and, Mr. Kissee said, "Don't forget the two cases of Red Stripe beer."
 
A Run on Supplies
 Toward evening, most of the South Florida gas stations and hardware stores and pharmacies and groceries that had been mobbed since midnight Saturday had shut down, their owners and employees gone off to take care of themselves and their families.
But in the island community of North Bay Village, halfway between Miami and Miami Beach in Biscayne Bay, clerks at the big, pink-trimmed Woolley's Supermarket, a new local chain that has aggressively going after sales in these recessionary times with a 24-hour operation, were still ringing up sales from a few stragglers who ducked through a narrow opening in the stainless-steel window coverings.
At Woolley's, like most other stores by now, there was plenty of fresh produce, but the bread shelves and all the bottled water and whole sections of canned goods were gone.
So were all the flashlight batteries.
Michael Campbell, a physical education teacher who moved from Newark almost exactly a year ago for the "nice weather" and now picks up extra money as a part-time stock clerk, said a lot of people at Woolley's and other stores where he had stopped for storm supplies had attacked the shelves "as if the end of the world was coming."
"People were bumping and shoving," Mr. Campbell said. "I reached for a roll of masking tape at a discount store and a woman physically pushed me out of the way as if I was reaching for money. I took a roll and gave her one. Pathetic."
 
Teak Protection
 At the Shell Lumber and Hardware Store in Coconut Grove this afternoon, more than 50 people waited to buy sheets of plywood to board up their windows. Some had been waiting for hours.
Griffith Pitcher, a lawyer, said he said he was concerned that the lumber yard was increasing its prices throughout the afternoon. Original plywood prices quoted at around $22 had moved up $40 as he was waiting, he said.
A salesman, Herb Cilio, confirmed that the price had risen but said it was because the store had run through the cheaper stocks of plywood by early this morning. By afternoon, he said, the only supplies left were of red oak, mahogany and teak.
At the Publix Supermarket in Coconut Grove, Ivette Abreu, a 16-year-old working on the cash register, said crowds were so bad in the morning that managers often had to lock the doors.
 
Making Room for Guests
 By early evening, few cars were on the streets. By dusk, most of whatever was going on was going on inside.
At the University of Miami's School of Medicine, guards went from floor to floor unlocking doors to private offices that were being converted into temporary shelters for friends, family members and others who had no other place to go.
Though the building usually has about 50 guards and other staff on Sunday evenings, a guard said more than 200 people were there tonight. Most arrived carrying pillows, bags of food and radios.
At the curb in front of Woolley's, Shanna Ochery, a 29-year-old unemployed cocktail waitress, and Michael Swift, a 38-year-old hotel pool attendant from New London, Conn., were sitting in Ms. Ochery's faded 1983 Le Baron Chrysler convertible with the top down. They were wishing that their friend James Roberts, a 35-year-old aviation mechanic who lost his job when Pan American World Airways went bankrupt, would hurry with the beer.
"We're going to have three cases of beer and a couple watermelons," Mr. Swift said. "We've got a first-floor apartment over on the water. We figure this thing is going to hit pretty hard. But we're going to ride it out."
Ms. Ochery, who said she has lived in Miami for years, said she was not nervous. "No," she said. "I've never been in a hurricane before." She tossed her platinum ponytail and a laugh creased her deep tan. "Hey," she said, "you gotta die sometime. It can't be that bad."
 
'It's My Property'
 David Fugatt, who served with the Marines in Vietnam, said everything he had was tied up in his sprawling waterfront home and the adjoining set of apartments. "They'd better be ready to arrest me," he said of the police. "I'm not going." He was paying for 10 cans of food for his two cats. He had already provisioned his 52 exotic birds.
Sure, Mr. Fugatt said, he was tempting fate. "But," he said simply but unequivocally, "it's my property. I've got to protect it."
Munsey Goldstein who is 75 years old and retired from the liquor business in Baltimore, was not nearly so determined. He and his wife, Lily, had wrapped their treasured paintings in towels and clothing and placed them on high closet shelves. Then they packed overnight bags and headed for a hotel, leaving their house with its big picture windows, standing on a spit between the ocean and the bay, to confront the storm as best it could.
"We didn't board up," he said. "We couldn't do that ourselves."
"I'm very nervous," Mr. Goldstein said, but he was not too nervous to remember to brag about his son, the jazz musician, who lives in New York and makes a lot of money, he said, ghost writing scores for big names in the movie business.
"First, there's the heavy rain," Mr. Goldstein said. "Even a heavy downpour clogs the street drains. So I'm afraid of the water. And the flying objects that can break windows. And then we're afraid of robberies. They wait for times like this. And we've got tremendous trees two, three stories tall. Wouldn't you be worried?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: In preparation for Hurricane Andrew, Ramona Myrick taped windows in Pompano Beach, Fla. The hurricane which struck the Bahamas yesterday afternoon is expected to reach the coast this morning. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
President Bush appears to have written off the dollar for now. If it falls, even from the all-time low it reached on Friday against the German mark, so be it, as long as the swoon is slow and orderly. The decision does not mean that the Administration would tolerate a sudden, steep plunge. And it carries risks that could unnerve both the bond and stock markets. [Page D1.]
The mark's strength is forcing Britain to confront its most painful lesson yet about the costs of economic integration with the Continent. And with the pound, like the dollar, plunging in value, London stands at the brink of being forced to prop up its currency. Any further drop could, in fact, force Prime Minister Major to raise interest rates at a time of recession. [D1.]
 
The Economy
 Among many economists who shape the strategies of banks and investment houses, patience with the President ended with his speech last week. The very highlight of his plan -- offsetting cuts in taxes and spending -- was widely denounced in interviews as poison for an economy in a joyless, jobless recovery. [D1.] 
 Some economists are beginning to smell a whiff of deflation, a decline in the overall level of prices. Yet nobody sees much chance that full-fledged deflation will occur. [D2.]
The Administration has drafted a broad plan that sets new priorities for the Government's biomedical research efforts. [A1.]
 
International
Japan's most famous personal computer entrepreneur is in the midst of a fight to save his company from bankruptcy. Kazuhiko Nishi's problems are typical of those afflicting Japanese businesses as the country's speculative boom has come to a halt. [D1.]
A year after being named chairman of Argentina's securities commission, Martin Redrado shows signs of strain. [D3.]
 
Companies
 LSI Logic says it will take a restructuring charge of up to $110 million and lay off about 450 employees. [D2.]
A longtime Digital executive, F. Grant Saviers, has joined Adaptec as president and chief operating officer. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
Summer TV has a successful look this year. At least four series introduced as summer entries, and perhaps more, have scored well enough to receive orders for new episodes, guaranteeing that this will be the first strong crop of shows ever introduced in the summer months. Bill Carter: Television. [D1.]
GQ defied the odds and now leads a British market for men's general-interest magazines. Although Esquire, which started its British edition in February 1991, is seeking to challenge that market, success has remained elusive so far. [D6.]
A "tolerable loss" is how NBC executives describe the results of the network's investment in the 1992 Summer Olympics. [D6.]
The decline of Pulitzer's chain of community weeklies in Chicago's suburbs could be a harbinger of the 90's for similar small newspaper groups that sprang up around many cities. [D6.]
A burst of activity has belied the notion that nothing happens in advertising in August. Shearson Lehman Brothers parted ways with Chiat/Day/Mojo, and executives of Leo Burnett U.S.A. and DDB Needham New York visited Fruit of the Loom in connection with an account review. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
The Harvard Business School is expected to name a new publisher of the Harvard Business Review soon, and it appears close to filling the top editorial job at the magazine. [D6.]
 
Today's Column
A cooler summer has meant fewer parched throats, and that has frustrated many businesses. Foremost among the disappointed, perhaps, are aluminum companies, which supply the raw material for soft-drink and beer cans. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Voters;
Some Ohioans Finding No Easy Political Home

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LORAIN, Ohio, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Spirits were high at the Great Tomato Weigh-In and Festival here the other day. With the sun shining, the soda cold and a gentle breeze off Lake Erie rustling the trees, it was just about a perfect day, said Priscilla Davis. Then the subject of the Presidential campaign came up.
"They both stink," the 36-year-old part-time bank teller said of President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. "There's too much dirt being dug up on each candidate that has nothing to do with the election or the lives of real people. They don't care about us, and they don't know anything about family values. What does politics have to do with it?" 
 She stalked off, but after a few feet whirled and said: "The more I think about this mess, the madder I get. Some choice."
Ohio is considered to be one of the pivotal battle grounds in this fall's campaign. And as hopeful gardeners brought their prize tomatoes to be weighed at the festival 30 miles west of Cleveland, Governor Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, were stating a bus caravan across the state to rally support.
But for many in this tired but proud city, the rallying calls of both parties sound hollow.
If this part of Middle America is also Skeptical America, the people in Lorain have earned their skepticism the old-fashioned way: it was given to them, one disappointment at a time. Many said they had heard too many political apologies and promises before.
"I'm for George Bush all the way, but I think he really messed up with that 'No new taxes' stuff," said Jim Trinter, who is 36 and an out of work restaurant manager. "He let the people down."
The 71,000 people of Lorain have been let down for at least 10 years. Thousands of jobs have been lost to plant closings or relocations. Crime is up. The schools are financially strapped and the young pack up and escape as soon as they can because the future looks brighter almost anywhere but in Lorain, a once-booming steel mill and ship-building center.
"We have five children, and they couldn't find anything around here," said Therese Francis, 66. "Any college graduate has to leave town to find a job. Now, that really impacts family values."
The voices of the people here are uncertain, angry and fed-up. But they are also voices of hope, humor and determination that things are going to get better, because, as one woman put it, "they can't get any worse."
 
The Economy Is the Issue
 The major issue for many here is the economy and getting people back to work. People said the issues of family values, character and leadership, although important and much talked about at the national conventions, take a back seat to the economy and who can fix it.
"Family values is not going to take care of our economy," said Jose Ortiz, 35, as he loaded wallboard into a van to make extra money constructing an addition to a house. "I think we need a change. Before they had steady jobs. Now you're hustling. Whatever job that comes up, you try to grab it."
On the South Side of Lorain, Edward Guggenbiller, 33, and his wife, Melody, 30, were busy painting their single-story house on Saturday. He works as a landscaper; she is employed as an accountant for a brass and bronze casting company. They consider themselves middle class but struggle to make ends meet.
"The middle class is going to hurt if Bush is re-elected," Mrs. Guggenbiller said. "We're for Clinton."
But not everyone is having that hard a time, even in Lorain.
Not far away, the shrill of a referee's whistle pierced the morning air as the boys from Southview High School met the Keystone High School boys in a football scrimmage. It was the Saints vs. the Wildcats in a preseason workout game.
Vaughn Zajicek, 37, and his wife, Yolanda, 35, were watching their son, Vaughn, play tight end. Mr. Zajicek, a former steel worker who now works as a safety director for a trucking company, said he is voting for President Bush without hesitation.
"I've been working since the Republicans have been in," he said. "I'm better off now than I was four years ago. I was getting back on my feet in the Reagan Administration, and with the Bush Administration, I'm doing very well. I'll take that into consideration more than anything else."
 
Idealism Ends With Age
 The mood here seems to mirror recent polls showing the President doing best among men, while more women perfer Mr. Clinton. Several of the men here said they were once young Democrats but are now older and wiser Republicans, a maturation that they said began with the election of Ronald Reagan.
They are men like Kirk Knisely, 33, the head lifeguard at Lorain's Lakeview Park who is a special education teacher for the city's schools. As sailboats eased arcoss the lake, Mr. Knisely said he was a Democrat but lost his idealism when he graduated from college. He is voting for Mr. Bush.
"I see all kinds of messed up kids as a result of dysfunctional families, with lousy familial values," he said. "If there were more good-paying jobs, that would go a long way in helping families develop good family values. I think everything revolves around the economy. When people are working and making money, a lot of these other questions are moot."
Many here are still on the fence, one week leaning toward Mr. Clinton and his talk of change, and the next week or even day tipping toward Mr. Bush and his talk of experience on the world stage.
The night before President Bush addressed his convention, the home of Dwight and Therese Francis was a house divided.
Mr. Francis, 64, a retired steel worker, buys an American car almost every other year because, he said, "I worked in a steel mill for 41 years; if I buy a foreign car, I'd be turning my back on everything I am."
Mr. Francis is voting for Mr. Bush.
His wife was leaning toward Mr. Clinton because she believed the country needed a change, the economy needed a fresh start. But after watching the Republican convention and especially Barbara Bush's speech about her husband, Mrs. Francis has changed her mind.
"The way she described her husband, I decided that he was a pretty good man," Mrs. Francis said. "I'm leaning toward Bush now. But that could change."
Back at the Great Tomato Weigh-In, the weighing was still a few hours away when Mary Hress, 68, and her daughter, Adrienne Terleck, 40, began setting up a table to sell homemade pot holders and towels on the lawn of the Autumn Aegis Nursing Home. The tomato festival was helping raise money for the home.
Mrs. Hress said she was a lifelong Democrat and would support Mr. Clinton. Mrs. Terleck, a public school teacher in Lorain, said the first time she voted for President, it was for Richard M. Nixon.
And that was the last time she voted for a Republican, she said.
"I think Bush is a good man, but he's not for the middle class," she said. "The way government can help improve family values is to encourage day care on the job and equal pay for women. I think Clinton will be better at that."
Mrs. Terleck looked over at her mother and smiled.
"Our country is like one big, broken family and it needs to be put back together," Mrs. Terleck said. "We need a woman President to put our house in order."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I think Bush is a good man, but he's not for the middle class," said Adrienne Terleck, a public school teacher in Lorain, Ohio. She and her mother, Mary Hress, sold crafts yesterday at the Great Tomato Weigh-In. Both said they supported Gov. Bill Clinton for President. (Roger Mastroianni for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: EAST HAMPTON JOURNAL;
What If They Built a Ferry to the Hamptons and People Came?

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON

DATELINE: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.

 BODY:
WHEN Jennifer Quinn plans her weekends, she takes any ferryboat she can find.
"I've been to Nantucket, Martha's Vineyard and Block Island this summer, and if I could take a ferry directly to the Hamptons, that would be fantastic," she said Friday, standing at the Orient Point ferry terminal at the eastern tip of Long Island's North Fork. "Where do I sign?" 
 Ms. Quinn, a 28-year-old computer programmer from Boston, shifted her beach gear from one arm to the other and added her name to a petition calling for year-round car ferry service from New London, Conn., to the Hamptons on the South Fork.
The proposal has been welcomed by much of the business community in the Hamptons, stung by the recession and a rainy summer season, but rejected by many long-term summer residents who envision hordes of day-trippers disturbing what's left of a gentle sun-and-surf life style in the seaside villages in East Hampton and Southampton.
"With all that ferry traffic, I'd never be able to get across the street," said Gary Brennan, 48, a writer who has been summering in East Hampton for 16 years. "If I want gridlock, I can stay in Manhattan," he added, juggling his morning newspaper, coffee, blueberry muffin and the bumper-to-bumper traffic on Main Street.
After Ms. Quinn made her return trip reservation at Orient Point for Sunday evening, she joined a carload of friends for the hourlong drive to the South Fork and the beach at Southampton, as did many of the passengers in the cars rolling off the 9 A.M. boat from New London.
With the prospect of more time on the beach and less time on a crowded road, more than 17,000 New London-to-Orient Point ferry passengers have signed similar petitions, said Richard MacMurray, the general manager of the Cross Sound Ferry Service, which would like to open the new ferry line across Long Island Sound, through Block Island Sound directly to the Hamptons.
"We're testing the waters," he said. "And if enough people want it, we'll try to make it happen."
Mr. MacMurray would like to build a new ferry terminal several minutes east of East Hampton at Promised Land, a part of Napeague State Park on Napeague Bay. The site is now a dilapidated fish processing factory.
A recent poll of almost 300 members of the East Hampton Chamber of Commerce found that among the 100 who responded, the ferry plan was favored by a four-to-one ratio. As a result, the business group has asked the town board to seriously consider the idea, despite the strong opposition from many local residents.
"The main objections are environmental," said Joan McKenna, a writer who lives in East Hampton Beach, just down the road from the proposed ferry landing. "Napeague Bay has some of the cleanest water in the area, and a ferry would only create problems, not solve any."
Tony Bullock, a Democrat and Supervisor of the Town of East Hampton, said the town board had already passed a resolution expressing no interest in the ferry. He said the Promised Land site was state-protected wetlands with a road system "that can hardly handle a golf cart, let alone a tractor-trailer."
"I just don't see any crying need to bring more cars in here in the summer. It would be handy for some residents who visit New England on a regular year-round basis, but we don't need the added public safety problems of crowd control, idling engines and beer bottles on an already fragile peninsula."
However, Fred W. Thiele Jr., a Republican and Supervisor of the Town of Southampton, said he would like to study the idea. "It's been a difficult few years for the tourism industry, and a ferry might help."
State Assemblyman John L. Behan, a Republican from Montauk, said he had yet to see any official plans or proposals for the project.
"There's nothing I can sit down and look at, so there's no point in my taking sides," he said. "Right now it all looks like a pie-in-the-sky thing."
Mr. Behan, whose father once operated a ferry service to Block Island and Newport, said he had talked with Mr. MacMurray and with the state's Park Department officials. "And it's my strong understanding that the state is not interested at this point," he said.
Mr. MacMurray said he would not approach the state unless he was certain there was enough public demand for the ferry service. If he did, he said he would limit the service to smaller boats that carry no more than 24 cars a trip, or around 200 cars a day.
He said the fare would be a few dollars more than the $27 per car for the hour-and-a-half ride from New London to Orient Point. A trip to the Promised Land terminal would add about 20 minutes to the ferry ride.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A proposal for ferry service from New London, Conn., to the Hamptons on Long Island's South Fork has met with opposition. The trip would take about 20 minutes longer than the hour-and-a-half trip to Orient Point on the North Shore, where cars lined up for the ferry to Connecticut on Saturday. (Lois Raimondo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
For Misplaced Students, Special Education Can Disable, Too

BYLINE: By Joseph Berger

 BODY:
MARGARITA OTERO PARKER has seen both her sons labeled handicapped by New York City's school bureaucracy, and she cannot understand why.
These young men, who live on the Lower East Side, are not blind, retarded or crippled, yet because of sporadic misbehavior, both were classified as emotionally disturbed. That is a catch-all that sweeps in everyone from psychotics to class clowns who irritate their teachers once too often. 
 But once consigned to so-called special education classes, students like Mrs. Parker's sons often find themselves in a Kafkaesque cul-de-sac, virtually never escaping. Mrs. Parker's eldest, Julio Otero, now 22 years old, so despaired of the dull and juvenile classes he attended that he dropped out after the 10th grade.
His brother, Christopher Parker, a tall 14-year-old with lively green eyes and a talent for drawing cartoons, has been chafing in most of his classes since the third grade.
"They don't teach you nothing in this classroom," he says, confirming that, for one thing, he has not mastered grammar.
Actually, he complains, he is required to spend too much time out of the classroom, visiting guidance counselors and tutors, going to work programs at a bicycle shop, taking trips to museums or to a pizza parlor. In his rough way, he suggests, he feels patronized by all this "babywork." All he craves is to sit in a real classroom, to hear a spirited lesson.
Thousands of the genuinely handicapped belong in special classes. But too often, critics say, assignment there is not driven by a handicap, but by money and expedience.
The Board of Education likes the classification because it can collect Federal and state money to pay for small classes and teachers and counselors it otherwise cannot afford. (A disabled child's schooling costs $17,000 a year, almost three times as much as a mainstream child.) The school unions like it because, even in threadbare budgets, teachers must be hired for the handicapped.
The special-education juggernaut has channeled one of every eight New York children -- 123,000 in all -- into handicapped classes, more than double the 1979 figure. Yet 75 percent fall into two amorphous categories -- learning disabled and emotionally disturbed.
Elizabeth C. Yeampierre, executive director of Advocates for Children, a nonprofit group that handles 1,500 special education complaints a year, says most placements make no sense. Why else, she asks, would so disproportionate a number of Hispanic children, whose real handicap is not being able to speak English, be labeled learning disabled, and so many poor young black males be labeled emotionally disturbed?
Frank Sobrino, a board spokesman, declined to discuss Christopher's case, citing confidentiality. But other officials said that Christopher was regularly found to be disturbed by three-member teams of psychologists, social workers and teachers who gave him batteries of tests.
Children in the program do not have much use for such euphemisms. They call those in classes for the learning disabled stupid and those in classes for the emotionally disturbed bad. While such judgments are harsh, they are also perversely savvy. For as Ms. Yeampierre and the board's own studies have shown, special education is too often a "dumping ground" for laggard readers or unruly students.
Defenders of special education say that it is often the only way to provide children like Christopher with the small classes and counseling that they need. But Mrs. Parker, who works for the Housing Authority, says that the annoying tradeoff is that Christopher is now stigmatized as emotionally disturbed. Yet Christopher, she says, has never done anything more bizarre than get into a street fight.
To be sure, Christopher is no angel. Warren Parker, a recently unemployed warehouse manager, says his son is a restless boy with a low flashpoint who has lashed out at teachers. In fact, Mr. Parker suggests, his son is a chip off the old block. And he said his own teachers, in the plainer language of the day, branded him a punk, not emotionally disturbed.
Christopher sat calmly through an hourlong interview with a reporter, showing off a mostly lucid three-page story he had written called "Dungeons and Dragons," complete with illustrations and maps.
If Christopher is truly disturbed, the law still requires schools to move him into mainstream classes with dispatch. But only 5 percent of those in special education ever get out, mostly because they fall behind academically.
In fact, Christopher has been in handicapped classes so long that, even if he is transferred to mainstream Seward Park High School, he is apprehensive about whether he can do the work. For him, the handicapped classification may have become self-fulfilling.

HEADLINE: Where Office Buildings Were Planted, Doubts Now Grow

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 22

 BODY:
For 30 years this mid-Westchester city has been rebuilding itself into what some said was a prototype of the modern suburban center.
But now, in a city where heavy traffic roars past towering office buildings and a jumbo mall but where there is no longer a single movie theater, some here are saying they are not sure they like what they have created. 
 "We do more than work," said Rita Malmud, the chairwoman of the Downtown Revitalization Task Force, formed by White Plains this spring. "We do more than shop. We also have a life after 5 P.M."
The doubts about the choices White Plains made were brought sharply into focus by a recent report by a commercial real-estate brokerage and consulting company. During years of redevelopment, more than half of the downtown was bulldozed for urban renewal. Office buildings were favored for that empty space. But now, the report found, 27 percent of the prime commercial space in White Plains' central business district is vacant.
While some, including Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio, blame the recession, others think the vacancy rate reveals deeper problems with the direction of White Plains' growth.
The report, by Rostenberg Doern Company, said that White Plains, along with St. Louis and Miami, had the highest office vacancy rate of 34 major business centers studied across the country.
Planning experts and others said the office vacancy problem raised fundamental questions not only about White Plains but also about many of New York's other satellite cities, like Stamford, Conn., and New Brunswick, N.J., and about suburban centers across the country that have been shaped by similar development forces.
 
'This Empty Feeling'
 "The great difficulty for the regional centers -- and White Plains epitomizes it as much as anywhere else -- is that everyone has this empty feeling about the regional downtowns," said Richard Anderson, who was until this summer president of the Regional Plan Association, a planning group for the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut area.
Until the current recession, office construction was seen as the magic bullet of urban redevelopment in places like this city of 48,000. Largely because of office buildings built since the 1970's, White Plains' daytime population, according to city officials, swells to some 250,000.
But in a common pattern in suburban centers, even in good economic times, many of those office workers do not stray far from their office buildings during the day, and most of them go right home at night.
No one can prove which is the cause and which the effect, but modern suburban centers are often antiseptic, car-oriented places rather than cities with individual character, said Peter Mosbacher, the executive director of the New York Main Street Alliance, a private group that helps communities revitalize their business districts. "They've become 9-to-5, Monday-to-Friday office centers," said Mr. Mosbacher.
White Plains' predicament seems a particular irony because the city, the Westchester County seat, was among the most forceful suburban centers in the New York area in trying to reinvent itself. In the 1960's, it paved the way for an unprecedented renewal when it bulldozed 135 acres of its downtown, more than half of the 250 acres in the central business district, although it left such old streets as Mamaroneck Avenue untouched.
 
Mayor Redevelopment
 When the offices were filled and new projects were on the drawing boards, it was not popular to raise questions about the shape of the new White Plains. Mr. Del Vecchio, the outspoken longtime Mayor, a former Democrat and current Republican, is more identified with the transformation than any other public figure.
This week Mayor Del Vecchio, who likes to say he has been "thrown out of three of the four political parties" because of his strongly held views, angrily dismissed the reports of a high vacancy rate as a "numbers game." And he said in an interview that there was nothing wrong with White Plains that an economic recovery would not fix.
"We did a billion dollars worth of construction in 10 years, and it was a tremendous success," he said. "The present setback will be taken care of as soon as we get an upturn."
But others wonder whether the vacancy rate highlights an assumption that crept into planning during good economic times -- that the city merely needed to be hospitable to developers and the quality of life would take care of itself. "We were," said Ms. Malmud, "built on the premise that everything would be expanding and that things would be glorious."
That helped obscure the fact, she said, that the new city being constructed here lacked the amenities and attractions that typically draw people to cities. Historically, because of local opposition, cabaret licenses have been difficult to get here, essentially depriving White Plains of a night life. There are few restaurants or galleries that draw in the evening hours, and there is no longer a single supermarket, complain Mayor Del Vecchio's critics.
White Plains' main retail street, Mamaroneck Avenue, was once dotted with so many fine stores that it was known as "little Fifth Avenue." These days it has a vacancy rate of about 30 percent, and there are so many close-out and cut-rate stores that, according to one local barb, it is a challenge to spend more than a dollar on the street that once was home to establishments like Bonwit Teller, gone now from the retailing scene altogether.
The Galleria Mall, a 150-store project built in the heart of the renewal zone during the 1970's, has been criticized as an architectural fortress cut off from the city that discourages pedestrian traffic and helped speed the decline of Mamaroneck Avenue, one block away.
All of this city's experience, Ms. Malmud said, suggests that White Plains needs to re-evaluate its commitment to offices and the kinds of stores that are at home in the mall.
But there are some who worry that the patterns that led to the current situation are simply being repeated. Mary Ann Keenan, the Democratic president of the White Plains Common Council, said the city never stopped to evaluate what kind of place it was creating as one heady project after another got under way. And she said there are signs that, even with the high office vacancy rate, little has changed.
Mayor Del Vecchio and his advisers, Ms. Keenan said, were influenced by their affection for development. They would talk, she said, about wanting people on the streets of the city at the same time they were mapping out six-lane streets through the heart of the redeveloped zone.
 
His Views Are Unaltered
 Mayor Del Vecchio defends his development policies, attributing the current problems to politics and to local entrepreneurs who failed to attract people. In an interview this week, he echoed traditional views of suburbia, saying, "If you want a play or the arts, you have to go downtown" -- by which, he said, he meant New York City.
And he assailed critics as Johnnie-come-latelies who were not around during the difficult days when it was hard to imagine a city where there were only acres of cleared land.
"The decisions we made were the right decisions," he said. "In 20-20 hindsight, they say we should have done something different. Where were they then?"
Ms. Keenan said the questions being asked these days are not just about the past. With the office buildings a quarter empty and the main shopping street suffering, she said, the city is still working hard to encourage developers of two new malls on the sites of defunct department stores in central White Plains.
Three major office building projects that would add more office space than the 1.57 million square feet that is currently vacant have their city approvals. Those projects are awaiting only better economic conditions before construction is expected to begin. Once again, Ms. Keenan said, there seems to be a belief that whatever the problem is, it can be fixed by construction.
"For three years," Ms. Keenan said, "I've been saying, 'How much is too much?' And everyone just looks at me, and the developers say, 'Mary Ann, you can't stop now.' I say, 'Why can't we stop now?' "

HEADLINE: Economists Skeptical Of Tax Plan

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Maybe George Bush is a Republican, maybe he did run his own business, and maybe he does want to treat Wall Street to a cut in the capital gains tax. But among many of the economists who shape the strategies of the nation's banks and investment houses, patience with the President ended with his speech last week.
The very highlight of his plan -- offsetting cuts in taxes and spending -- was widely denounced as poison for an economy in a joyless, jobless recovery. "Almost every economist would agree that equal cuts in taxes and spending actually depress the economy," said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company. "It is not a growth program." 
 The financial community's economists do not exactly feel betrayed by President Bush; it is not as if he called for a tax on securities trading to help finance food stamps. They are just deeply disappointed.
 
'A Vote of No Confidence'
 The disappointment with a President seemingly made to Wall Street's measure runs so deep that not even the brightening of his political prospects now brings the financial community much cheer.
Edward A. Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, said that some are wondering just how much worse a Clinton Presidency could be. "The conventional wisdom is that Wall Street prefers Bush to Clinton," he said. "But the deficit expanded to all-time records under Bush. You could argue that a Democrat couldn't have done any worse.
"If you look at the vote today in the financial markets, it was a vote of no confidence," he said on Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average sank 50.79 points, to a four-month low of 3,254.10, on Friday.
Neal M. Soss, chief economist at First Boston, is among those who worry that the President is simply grasping for political gains. "These proposals don't have much content, but to the extent they do, they are impractical or unlikely of adoption," he said. "On the other hand, they may make attractive political promises."
Not that Wall Street is rushing to embrace Bill Clinton. Mr. Soss fears that the candidates will merely compete in offering budgetary blandishments. "So maybe you're in a bidding war on fiscal policy, which sends interest rates up," he said.
 
Applause, and Skepticism
 Some features of the Bush plan did find favor -- caps on spending for entitlement programs especially. But controlling Government spending depends on limiting payments for Medicare, Medicaid, food stamps, farm subsidies and veterans' benefits, Mr. Sinai said. "It's courageous and politically difficult," he said. "All of us who for years have worried about the deficit would have to applaud."
Mr. Bush's proposal for letting voters earmark as much as 10 percent of their tax payments for deficit reduction met with skepticism, however, as economists questioned whether Federal bookkeepers would reduce spending accordingly.
"It does not change whatsoever the flow of revenues to the Government's coffers," said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley. "Does that reduce the deficit? It's an open question."
 
'Banana Republic Status'
 Among academic economists, Paul Krugman, an economist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has consulted for the Clinton campaign, began his review of the Bush speech with a dismissive chuckle. "He's for cutting wasteful Government spending, but not any particular spending," he said. "If it's going to be real tax cuts and fictitious spending cuts, then we could be well on our way to banana republic status."
Many other economists have in recent months urged higher public spending, even at the cost of a wider deficit, to revive the economy. Robert Solow, also at M.I.T., helped persuade more than 70 of his colleagues to sign an open letter to that effect in March. The President's call for reduced spending only confirmed his lack of interest in restarting the economy, Mr. Solow said. "You could never tell from the speech that we're in a recession that doesn't want to end," he added.
Most economists say that cutting taxes and spending equally depresses the economy. Taxpayers save some of the extra money, failing to fully compensate for the Government spending that is lost.
But other economists, including Milton Friedman, say that the President's spending cuts could actually stimulate the economy. "Whether you finance it by taxes or borrowing, there's that much left for the private sector," said Mr. Friedman, who is now at Stanford's Hoover Institution. But with Congress apt to spend as much as it can, he said, "The only way to reduce spending permanently is to reduce taxes."
Even supply-side economists, who believe that tax cuts can pay for themselves through the resulting economic growth, are divided over the Bush plan. Jude Wanniski, president of the Polyconomics consulting firm, said the President should not make tax cuts dependent on spending cuts.
On Friday, Mr. Wanniski pounded out a letter to his clients accusing the President of giving in to "the budget-balancing proclivities of the Country Clubbers who remain firmly in control of the Republican Party."
But Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at the Office of Management and Budget under President Ronald Reagan, said Mr. Bush had finally returned to the supply-side religion. Mr. Kudlow, now chief economist at Bear, Stearns, is one of the few Wall Street economists to applaud the Bush plan. Or perhaps, the Kudlow plan.
Mr. Kudlow said that the President's proposals reflected a memorandum that Jack Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, had recently given to the President -- a memo, Mr. Kudlow said, "which I helped draft."

HEADLINE: Computer Pioneer's Moment of Truth

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 23

 BODY:
As Japan's most famous personal computer entrepreneur, Kazuhiko Nishi, nicknamed Kay, has often seemed out of place in this land of conservative, conformist businessmen.
He is a college dropout, he started his own company rather than work for a large one and he has flaunted his wealth with a flamboyant style that has included dashing from meeting to meeting by helicopter. 
 But now the 36-year-old entrepreneur, often called the Steve Jobs of Japan in reference to the Apple Computer co-founder, is in the midst of a fight to save his company from bankruptcy. His problems are only too typical of those now afflicting Japanese businesses as the country's speculative boom has come to a halt.
 
Expansion Leaves Debts
 Driven by Mr. Nishi's grand visions and the easy availability of money during the boom in the last few years, Mr. Nishi's company, the Ascii Corporation, borrowed heavily as it expanded wildly beyond its basic businesses of software and computer magazine publishing. Now, the Japanese stock market has crumbled, money is tight and Ascii cannot pay its debts.
A coalition of six banks is expected to reach an agreement soon to provide Ascii with more than $100 million to allow the company to survive. But in return for the bailout, Mr. Nishi will have to sell off unprofitable parts of his empire. And while industry executives expect him to remain Ascii's president, he might have to give up some of his autonomy in running the company. A spokesman for Ascii said that Mr. Nishi could not be interviewed until an agreement was reached with the banks.
Mr. Nishi's plight is drawing widespread attention here because he has come to symbolize Japan's entrepreneurial sector, which the Japanese Government is trying to nurture. Small companies, which often develop the most creative products, are a big reason for the success of the American personal computer industry, a success Japan has yearned to emulate.
 
Software Companies Failing
 "If his company fails, it's going to discourage a number of future potential entrepreneurs," said George Hara, a venture capitalist and president of Data Control Ltd., a software company.
Already, small Japanese software companies are dropping by the wayside because Japanese corporations, hurt by the recession, are slowing their investments in office automation and because banks, needing to shore up their capital, are reluctant to give such companies new loans to tide them over the hard times.
In 1991, 87 software companies filed for bankruptcy protection, nearly double the 1990 total of 45, according to Tokyo Shoko Research, which monitors the financial health of companies. And through July of this year, 65 have filed for bankruptcy.
Part of Ascii's problems, Mr. Hara said, stems from the fact that start-ups in Japan have a difficult time luring experienced managers away from big companies. Such managers might have held in check some of Mr. Nishi's wilder dreams and helped Ascii control its costs.
Ascii (pronounced AS-key) was named after a code by which computers represent the alphabet. The company was started by Mr. Nishi and two friends in 1977, the year in which the first hugely successful personal computer, the Apple II, was introduced. Mr. Nishi, then a student at Waseda University, later dropped out to concentrate on the business.
His first big break came the next year when he called on another college-dropout-turned-entrepreneur, William H. Gates of Microsoft. Ascii became Microsoft's distributor in Japan and Mr. Nishi became a vice president of Microsoft in addition to his job at Ascii. The two men, who are the same age, became close friends and soulmates.
More a visionary and charismatic salesman than an engineer, Mr. Nishi helped create the personal computer business in Japan. He persuaded NEC to design Japan's first personal computer. And he put together the team that designed the first laptop computer, the Tandy Corporation's Model 100. In those days he was legendary for flying across the Pacific as often as two or three times a week, and for falling asleep on the floor out of exhaustion.
But Mr. Nishi was also prone to make big decisions on a whim and to spend freely, which led Microsoft to break with Ascii in 1986 and set up its own Japanese distribution. One of the final straws came when Mr. Nishi spent $1 million to have a huge mechanical dinosaur constructed in Tokyo as an advertising gimmick. The breakup between Mr. Gates and Mr. Nishi was bitter, although the two men now talk periodically.
Ascii overcame that setback, and its sales grew rapidly until leveling off last fiscal year at 34.5 billion yen, or about $270 million. The company issued shares to the public in 1989 and the stock soared, giving Mr. Nishi a fortune of more than $100 million.
He bought a customized Bentley and other fancy cars and an apartment on Central Park South in New York. He amassed huge collections of Chagall lithographs and of compact disks, at one time ordering a record store to send him one copy of each disk it sold.
The rising stock market also made it easy for Ascii, like other Japanese companies, to raise money by issuing bonds convertible into company stock. Buyers of such bonds accepted low interest rates on hopes of making their returns by converting into valuable shares.
Ascii ventured into computer chip design and sales and satellite data delivery. It invested in several American technology companies, including Informix, a software company, and Nexgen, a company trying to clone Intel's microprocessors. And as part of Mr. Nishi's efforts to move into multimedia -- the combination of computers and video -- Ascii bought the Japanese unit of Vestron Inc., a videocassette distributor, and a one-third stake in the Edward R. Pressman Film Corporation, the American independent movie maker that produced "Conan the Barbarian."
 
Investments During the Boom
 Ascii even went into the helicopter charter business and, like many other companies, invested in art and real estate, which seemed like good investments during a time of rising prices. Mr. Nishi was hatching plans to build an industrial park for software companies in northern Japan, equipped with modern electronics technology and its own airport. The plan has since been put on hold.
About a year ago, Ascii's two other co-founders, Akio Gunji, the chairman, and Keiichiro Tsukamoto, vice president, resigned abruptly, apparently in protest over the rapid expansion. "They could not keep up with me as I stepped on the gas too much," Mr. Nishi said at a news conference at the time.
But now, Japan's stock market has fallen and Ascii's stock has plunged from a peak of 21,000 yen to close at 515 yen on Friday, making Mr. Nishi's 11.9 percent stake worth less than $5 million.
Bonds worth about $85 million are due next March, and bond holders are not likely to want to convert them into such low-priced stock. Ascii will have to come up with cash to pay those bondholders. That is why it is hoping to borrow from the six banks.
Ascii has other needs for money as well. The company's total debt is 31.2 billion yen, or about $245 million -- or more than $350 million if its affiliates and subsidiaries are included. But the company still expects to report a pretax profit of 1.3 billion yen, or about $10 million, in the fiscal year that ends in March.
 
Need for a Larger Partner?
 Some experts think that if it is to continue to grow, Ascii might need to sell a stake in itself to a larger company, perhaps even an American one. Canon Inc. said last week that it had been asked to help support Ascii but that it had no money to spare. Ascii said it had only asked Canon to take part in a joint venture, not a bailout.
Some who know him say Mr. Nishi has now become a little less extravagant in his spending habits. But he is still coming up with visions and is not afraid to speak his mind. In a speech at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in May, for instance, Mr. Nishi said what some other Japanese engineers might think but cannot say: that Japan's high-definition television system, the pride of the nation, is essentially obsolete because it uses older analog technology rather than the newer digital technology.
It is for comments like that that Mr. Nishi has been treated with a mixture of awe and disdain here. Some of his supporters say Japan's business establishment might not be unhappy that the upstart is getting his comeuppance.
"People like him are not easily accepted by the Japanese establishment," said Mr. Hara, the venture capitalist, who works in the United States as well as Japan. "His style is completely acceptable by the world's standard, but not here."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS: Rising Mark Reverberates in Britain and U.S.;
Sacrificing The Dollar to Spur Exports

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
President Bush did something unexpected in Houston last week. In the midst of all the speeches about pride in America, he appeared to have written off the dollar for now. If it falls, even from the all-time low it reached on Friday against the German mark, so be it, as long as the swoon is slow and orderly.
The decision is not necessarily bad -- or even avoidable. And it does not mean that the Administration would tolerate a sudden, steep plunge in the dollar. But it carries risks that could unnerve both the bond and the stock markets unless the dollar stabilizes more or less on its own. If the dollar plunges, investor confidence could erode further, pushing down stock and bond prices, and undermining the economy and Mr. Bush's campaign. 
 Until last week, John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers in New York, along with many other market analysts, thought that the Administration and its allies still wanted to halt the dollar's decline. There had been coordinated central bank intervention in support of the dollar in July and August, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in interviews that the dollar was falling "ahead of itself."
 
'Exports Are the Key'
 But even though there was further intervention on Friday, Mr. Lipsky said, the "style and the scale of the intervention Friday left the markets with a clear impression that a decline in the dollar, as long as it was orderly, would be tolerated."
Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, also changed his mind. After listening to the President's Houston speech, he said: "Clearly exports are the key to his economic strategy. The dollar is not a primary concern of this Administration. Quite the opposite. If the economy requires a weaker dollar for exports, then they'll allow it."
Of course, in the secretive world of central banks and currency markets, there is always room for mistakes in interpreting policy moves. The central bank intervention on Friday might simply have been either unsuccessful or inept, and the market's reading might have been wrong.
But that does not change the uncertainty surrounding the Presidential election or the pressures placed on the United States and on the rest of Europe.
 
The Baker Touch
 Still, the policy choice, if it has been made, has the mark of James A. Baker 3d, the President's new chief of staff and guiding light for the re-election campaign. As the Treasury Secretary in the second Reagan Administration, Mr. Baker engineered the legendary Plaza Accord of 1985 that initiated a period of international economic cooperation and brought the dollar down from record levels to levels that helped stimulate American exports and reduce the troublesome trade imbalance.
In his acceptance speech last week, Mr. Bush emphasized the importance of exports in a growing economy. Of course, a lower dollar could make American companies even more competitive abroad.
More important, the policy may be just an acceptance of the inevitable because the international financial cooperation that Mr. Baker fostered, which was useful in stopping previous declines in the dollar, seems absent now.
The United States appears to be at economic odds now with Germany. The Bundesbank, the German central bank, has been pushing up interest rates to combat the inflation unleashed by the costs of the unification of the two Germanys. At the same time, the Federal Reserve has been pushing down rates to try to stimulate the weak American economy.
For the course of the dollar to reverse, investors must expect that Germany will lower interest rates or that the United States will raise them. At the least, investors and speculators must believe that there will be no more increases in Germany's rates and no more cuts in America's.
Short-term rates in Germany are close to 10 percent, three times the levels in the United States. And there is still the clear threat that the Bundesbank will push interest rates higher even as the Fed comes under continuing pressure to lower rates.
 
Reminiscent of 1987
 This situation reminds some traders and analysts of a similar dispute between the United States and Germany over interest rates and the level of the dollar that preceded the stock market crash of 1987. Mr. Baker, as Treasury Secretary, was in the middle of that conflict. But the disagreement today seems more muted, as the Bundesbank has participated in the recent efforts to support the dollar.
If the dollar's decline remains orderly, American financial markets might even rally, building upon the prospects for low inflation and slow economic growth. Several economists and traders said at the end of last week that the bond market could still rally to 7 percent yield from 7.35 percent on the 30-year bond, the lowest in two decades. Bond yields fall as prices rise.
"If the fundamentals give strong new signals then the market will react," Mr. Lipsky said.
The risk is that the dollar decline could get out of hand, as the failure of coordinated central bank intervention made clear on Friday. Despite dollar purchases by 16 central banks, led by the Federal Reserve, the American currency dropped more than 1 percent against the mark in just a few hours. And the fall took the stock and bond markets with it.
 
Influence on Fed
 Furthermore, if the Administration is believed to be willing to let the dollar decline continue, it may be hard to bar the door to big speculators who would relish testing how low the dollar can go. A sharper dollar fall could forestall an easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve that would otherwise occur and help the economic recovery. It might also lead to a decision to take more active measures, like raising interest rates, to shore up the dollar and maintain confidence in the financial markets.
Then, even if the Fed did not raise short-term rates, the recovery could be stalled if the meager housing boom is shut down. Such a crisis before the November election could be a disaster for the President, especially after he pointedly told America last week that he was the one to trust to keep the economy on an even keel.

HEADLINE: Argentina's Stock Regulator Faces Daunting Task

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 23

 BODY:
When Martin Redrado was named chairman of Argentina's National Securities Commission a year ago, he was just 29 years old, fresh from jobs in the United States with Salomon Brothers and the Security Pacific Bank, and the outlook for the Argentine stock markets he was to regulate seemed bright.
The economy was stable and growing at almost 5 percent a year, inflation was running below 20 percent, and the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange was booming, having just been discovered by a cadre of emerging-market investors from the United States and Europe. 
 Mr. Redrado set out to toughen enforcement to insure a fairer market, to lower the cost of trading on the exchange and to encourage more participation by institutional investors both inside Argentina and abroad.
 
Signs of Strain
 But now the landscape is bleaker, and Mr. Redrado shows signs of strain. Highly praised during the first months on the job, he is now criticized for being too much a booster of Argentine stocks and too little a hands-on regulator and enforcer.
"The general view of Martin is that he did a great job deregulating the market last year, but recently he has been promoting the market and the buying of stocks," said one leading securities analyst who insisted on anonymity.
There is reason for the griping. Since June, stock prices have plunged about 50 percent after a spectacular rise of almost 400 percent last year. The market decline paralleled similar falls in Mexico and Brazil in June, when Ross Perot was running strong in the Presidential race in the United States and came out against the free trade agreement with Mexico.
What investors found in Buenos Aires when they scrutinized the market more carefully was that stock prices were extremely high compared with their underlying earnings. That, coupled with the heavy borrowing to buy stocks, touched off the plunge.
Last week, the market fell 9.3 percent, adding to the gloom. Argentine investors, who thought they were riding an endless upward price spiral, have lost bundles. Foreign investors are now on the sidelines. And charges of insider trading and market manipulation are common.
 
Looking Long Term
 "We are going through a painful learning process," Mr. Redrado said in an interview recently. "We are trying to change a market that had been highly speculative and short-term oriented. Companies do not give out a lot of information. There is not a lot of research. Somehow, we have to get people to look at the long term."
That will not be easy. Decades of high inflation and sometimes hyperinflation have created a business culture here more concerned about fluctuations in currencies than in capital investments. And the stock market has been known for its lack of regulation.
Even though the economy has been stable now for 18 months, the slightest hint of a possible devaluation of the Argentine peso or an increase in social spending still sets the markets ajitter.
In the face of the uncertain investing climate, Mr. Redrado says he faces a quandary: the markets still need tighter regulation, he admits, but he feels he should also help create an image of Argentina as a good place to invest. That, he submits, naturally calls for a little cheerleading.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Redrado's regulatory model is the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. The most prominent picture in his office is of himself with the S.E.C. chairman, Richard C. Breeden, and President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina. That picture suggests a desire, perhaps, to bring some of the credibility of United States markets to Argentina.
In fact, the linkages go beyond the photograph. Last fall, the National Securities Commission signed a memorandum of understanding with the S.E.C. that provides for the exchange of market and investigative information. Three Argentine enforcement officials have received training at the S.E.C. enforcement division in Washington. And the two organizations are seeking World Bank funds to bring S.E.C. officials to Argentina to train the whole 107-member enforcement team. The Buenos Aires Stock Exchange, earlier this month, signed an agreement with the American Stock Exchange providing for the exchange of information.
"I think this market is moving very much in the right direction," Mary Shapiro, an S.E.C. commissioner, said during a recent visit here. "What is still lacking are resources for the regulators, a greater education of the public and a higher level of professionalism."
 
Eliminating Restrictions
 In addition to edging closer to American regulators, Mr. Redrado has used his ties to the Economy Minister, Domingo Cavallo, and to President Menem to pass legislation bringing brokerage commissions down to a level roughly equal to those in the United States. A half-percent stamp tax, an eight-tenths of 1 percent transfer tax and all capital gains taxes on foreigners have been eliminated. And Mr. Redrado has cut the fees the exchange charges on large transactions by more than two-thirds.
The commission also pushed legislation to remove restrictions on foreign ownership of Argentine companies and give banks entry into the brokerage business. And Mr. Redrado hopes that by the end of the year, Congress will approve a new law that will permit pension funds to invest in stocks. He predicts that could bring in $300 million a month of investment into Argentine capital markets.
The more open climate has brought a flood of investment into the market. At the beginning of 1991, less than $5 million in stocks were traded daily; now the volume is about $60 million.
Perhaps Mr. Redrado's biggest task, however, is to make fraud and manipulation unprofitable, and this may involve some of the country's most influential business executives and lawyers. While specific details of wrongdoing are hard to come by, brokers and analysts say stocks are routinely manipulated, and that brokers trade ahead of large clients.
 
Few Penalties
 While the securities commission can sue a company for insider trading, fines are a maximum of $8,000 and criminal prosecution is nearly impossible.
The commission's strongest enforcement action to date was a move last month against, Colorin, a paint company that did not disclose an 800 percent increase in its net worth until after its stock had risen considerably. Admitting that it was nearly impossible to discover who benefited, the commission fined each board member $8,000.
Currently, Mr. Redrado is trying to get the Congress to approve new powers for the commission that would permit fines equal to twice the value of any illegal profits, in addition to forcing the return of all such profits.
The commission has yet to get a handle on the very high leverage that undergirds much of the market, as banks and brokers routinely lend clients most of the money to buy shares.
In March, when Telecom, one of the two privatized telephone companies, sold shares to the public, bankers set up booths in the streets of downtown Buenos Aires offering to lend investors 80 percent of the purchase price of Telecom shares. The large loans available for stock purchases exacerbated the market's plunge this summer, as investors had to sell to cover margin calls.
 
A Rich Resume
 Such gyrations and anxiety over the market's future keep Mr. Redrado constantly in the headlines, which he seems to enjoy. Although young, he already has a rich resume. After graduating from Harvard University with a master's degree in public administration in 1985, he spent six months in Bolivia with the Harvard economist Jeffrey Sachs, helping the Government of President Victor Paz Estenssoro bring a runaway inflation rate down to less than 20 percent a year. In the process, the Government laid off thousands of mine workers and balanced its budget.
Later that year, Mr. Redrado went to work for Salomon Brothers in its international capital markets group in New York and London. In early 1989, he moved to Security Pacific, where he was named managing director for the international division in early 1991.
He took on the job of heading Argentina's securities commission in mid-July 1991 at the urging of Mr. Cavallo, whom Mr. Redrado had met when they were both studying at Harvard. When he was first appointed, he said, his age used to be a problem. "In the press, they used to call me that young chairman of the securities commission," Mr. Redrado said. "Recently, they've taken off the young."

HEADLINE: LSI Logic Expects $100 Million Loss

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Hurt in part by ferocious competition in the personal computer market, LSI Logic Inc., a leading maker of custom semiconductor chips, says it will take a restructuring charge of up to $110 million and lay off about 450 employees.
The layoffs will include 175 nonproduction workers in the United States and 275 production employees at a German plant that will be phased out of operation during the next six months. 
 Company executives pointed Friday to disappointing sales in Japan and in the military and aerospace markets. They said LSI planned to refocus its strategy on more profitable parts of its business. It will also look for new partners for both its design and manufacturing operations, they said.
Although the personal computer market accounts for only about 10 percent of LSI's sales, executives said the company had also been hurt by the problems at one of its big customers, the Digital Equipment Corporation, the giant maker of minicomputers.
LSI, which is based in Milpitas, Calif., said it expected the restructuring charge to result in a loss of more than $100 million in its third quarter, which ends in September. The company, a pioneer in the market for custom chips, had a profit of $804,000, or 2 cents a share, on sales of $172.4 million in the third quarter last year. It lost $5.9 million on sales of $151.8 million in the second quarter of this year.
 
'Long, Grinding Recession'
 "This has been a long, grinding recession, and at the same time we have a major slowdown in Japan," said Wilf Corrigan, chief executive of LSI.
He said that he expected the industry to pick up again in 1993 and that he was already seeing signs of a recovery.
The company said that by restructuring its operations and cutting costs it expected to save about $10 million in expenses each quarter, making a profit possible by the fourth quarter.
Mr. Corrigan said chip makers were coming under pressure because technology cycles in the business were actually becoming shorter as semiconductor designers pushed toward chips with circuit lines narrower than one micron.
"In the past, you could assume a new generation of tech could last three to four years," he said. "The increments of each generation of technology are shorter now."
As part of its shift in strategy, LSI will move its high-volume chip-manufacturing operations to Japan, where it is now developing a second factory in partnership with Kawasaki Steel. In the future, American operations will focus on low-volume manufacturing and pilot production, as well as development of new technologies.
In the personal computer market, for which LSI has sold the chips that surround the central microprocessors, the company has been hammered by waves of price reductions and cost-containment pressures from I.B.M. clone makers like Compaq Computer, Dell Computer and AST Research.
LSI executives said the company planned to refocus its efforts on markets in which it is able to differentiate its chip designs from those of its competitors, achieving higher profit margins as a result.
Mr. Corrigan said LSI was now in serious discussions with two semiconductor companies about a future manufacturing alliance and was involved in informal talks with half a dozen more. He cited recent international alliances among chip makers -- like one linking I.B.M., Toshiba and Siemens, another linking Texas Instruments and Hitachi, and a third linking Fujitsu and Advanced Micro Devices -- as an important trend as companies look to offset the huge costs of developing the next generation of chip-making factories.

HEADLINE: Even Falling Prices Can Be Painful

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
It's not just the $5 New York-Washington bus fare, the Gap stores' 26 percent cut in jeans prices and the aggressive air fare discounts, which could push some airlines into oblivion.
The prices of many items -- from gold and other commodities to television sets and new-model Chevrolets -- are falling. They are not just going up more slowly or going down only after allowing for inflation, but are actually falling, period. 
 Even the Government's far-ranging tally of consumer food prices showed a decline, albeit modest, during the first seven months of 1992. If sustained, this would be the first full-year fall since 1961.
 
Only a Whiff of Deflation
 Some economists are beginning to see what Edward Yardeni of the Wall Street firm C. J. Lawrence calls a whiff of deflation.
Yet nobody, including Mr. Yardeni, seems to think there is much chance that full-fledged deflation will occur. Deflation, according to the formal definition, is a decline in the overall level of prices, not just for certain items.
Nearly everyone agrees that deflation is a bad thing, even though it creates some individual winners -- like bondholders and other fixed-income lenders, so long as the borrowers do not default.
"We better hope we don't get to deflation," said Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist for ASB Capital Management, a Washington money manager. "It's a black economic hole that's hard to get out of," as ever-falling prices cripple production and profits and then jobs and incomes.
But the United States is far from repeating this unhappy experience, which occurred in the 1930's, economists say. For one thing, the chances of deflation in the 1990's are minimized by the existence of economic stabilizers, like unemployment insurance, which automatically injects increasing amounts of money into the spending stream as jobless rolls swell.
"No, I can't see anything" that suggests the threat of deflation, said Patrick C. Jackman, chief economist for the Labor Department unit that compiles the Consumer Price Index. Noting that American wages are still rising, though more slowly than in the past, he added, "It would take monumental drops in food and energy prices to have the C.P.I. go negative."
 
What We Have Now: Disinflation
 What this country and others do have is disinflation -- a slackening of price increases. Most policy makers regard this as a significant achievement, because it brings stability to the economy and financial markets. But it also has unwelcome side effects, especially in the near term as individuals and businesses adjust to it, and these effects have become painfully clear.
Perhaps the most obvious is the plight of retirees and others who rely on certificates of deposit and other shorter-term investments. With interest rates falling with inflation, their returns have withered to half or a third of previous levels.
The negative aspects of lower inflation also show up in the housing market, where mortgage rates are still falling and home prices in many parts of the country are severely eroded.
This combination produces various drags on the economy, some obvious and some less so.
Unlike inflationary times, when each price jump tends to encourage the financially able to buy before prices go up again, declining prices cause people to wait -- or even freeze them into inaction.
Ever-lower mortgage rates, for example, encourage the thought that financing terms may get still better, deferring purchases and discouraging the building of new homes. At the same time, properties on the market continue to languish and more owners cut prices. As equity erodes, these people not only feel poorer and buy less but may be unable to move, perhaps to a new or better job.
"That kind of thing can obviously slow the economy down," said Norman Robertson, economist for the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
On the positive side, those able to refinance their homes generally wind up with lower monthly payments, freeing the savings for other purposes. And of course, some buyers do act promptly as lower rates and lower prices make housing easier for them to afford.
Generally speaking, falling or nonexistent inflation makes debts more burdensome, sapping confidence and wherewithal as the borrower must repay in sound dollars instead of depreciated ones. This is what William Jennings Bryan protested a century ago using the image of a cross of gold to castigate unsympathetic Wall Street bankers.
Such consequences, at least temporarily restraining the economy, suggest to many that the ideal may be a modest, steady rise in prices.
"In mild inflation, the wheels of industry are initially well lubricated and output is near capacity," asserts Paul A. Samuelson in "Economics," his classic text. "Private investment is brisk, jobs are plentiful. Such has been the historic pattern." Losses to bondholders, it is thought, tend to be less than the gains to the rest of society.
While sometimes disputed, support for this view seems to be increasing. This may reflect the steadily growing service sector of the economy, where there seems to be almost inexorable upward pressure on wages, at the expense of the manufacturing sector. What happens, it seems, is that anti-inflation measures fall unduly on the latter.
 
Manufacturers Tend to Suffer
 "The more you squeeze inflation down, the more it comes out of the manufacturer's hide," observed Mr. Robertson, voicing the complaints of some of his bank's industrial customers even as the Federal Reserve was meeting last week to decide whether to cut interest rates further.
The Fed's choice seemed to be between buying more insurance against economic relapse or consolidating gains on the price front that have brought the inflation rate down to 2.3 percent over the latest three months.
But if modest inflation is the ideal, there is little agreement about just what level it should be.
"I don't think we have any idea of that," said William Branson, a Princeton University economics professor working temporarily at the International Monetary Fund. More important, he said, is preventing large unanticipated swings in aggregate prices.
"The big problems," Professor Branson said, "are in the transition from one level to another, or when there's a rise in the uncertainty" attached to any current rate.
