HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Suburban Weeklies Hit By Rivals and Recession

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The decline and possible demise of Pulitzer Publishing Company's chain of community weeklies in Chicago's northern suburbs could be a harbinger of the 90's for similar small newspaper groups that sprang up in the 80's around many cities.
For months, Pulitzer has been trying to sell the 15 papers after watching advertising decline 40 percent over three years and profits disappear entirely. Should no buyer emerge by Oct. 13, the company has said it will cease publishing the papers, ending 150 jobs. 
 "We got caught by a structural change," said Nicholas G. Penniman 4th, senior vice president of newspaper operations at Pulitzer, who added that he thought other groups of suburban weeklies could easily share the same fate.
 
Negative to Positive?
 Pulitzer acquired the papers from the Lerner family in 1985, a time when such publications were taking advertising dollars from metropolitan dailies all over the country. Indeed, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Pulitzer's flagship paper, was being battered by suburban weeklies, and the company thought it could turn that bitter experience into gain by doing the same thing to The Chicago Tribune and The Chicago Sun-Times.
When Pulitzer bought the Lerner group, it included 56 free publications under half a dozen titles to which a community's name was attached, such as The River Grove Times and The Niles Life. Most of their advertising revenue came from help-wanted classifieds, which were plentiful enough to create comfortable profits, though Pulitzer would not disclose numbers.
But Pulitzer failed with its fundamental strategy of winning real estate and automobile classifieds and retail ads from the major Chicago dailies.
 
Zoned Editions
 Like many metropolitan papers that watched competition in the suburbs mount in recent years, The Tribune invested heavily to create zoned editions that were essentially local papers tucked inside the big daily. The Sun-Times is more focused on the city but has aggressively defended its traditional strength in automotive classifieds.
When recession hit three years ago, help-wanted classified linage sank. And in hard times, the first cost cut that retailers make is advertising, beginning with second-tier publications like suburban weeklies.
To cut costs, Pulitzer converted to paid circulation, consolidated titles and dropped some towns. This cut circulation to between 100,000 and 150,000, from 300,000 in 1985, making advertising even harder to sell.
Mr. Penniman said Pulitzer had decided to sell because it considered the prospects grim, even if the economy improved. The employers who once swelled his papers with help-wanted classifieds probably will not rehire -- or advertise -- at anything like previous levels, he said.
And he said that suburban weeklies were being squeezed not only from above, by mass-market competitors like metro dailies, cable television and direct mail, but also from below, by even more narrowly focused community papers.
These papers, which through computer technology can spring up virtually overnight, are inexpensive to produce and increasingly are published in Korean, Hindi or other languages that reflect the ethnic cast of many suburban subcommunities.
Charles J. Carey, vice president of Henry Ansbacher Inc., the New York investment bank that Pulitzer hired to sell the Lerner group, said he thought a new owner might be able to restore profitability with an ultra-lean operation. He added that several serious buyers were interested.
But John Morton, a newspaper stock analyst for Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington, said that small weeklies within 50 miles or, in some cases, even 150 miles of a major city would probably have a hard time in the coming years.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The 'American Century': Beneficence or Illusion?

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Grand Illusion
Critics and Champions
of the American Century
By John B. Judis
344 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.
 Is this departing century the American Century or is that idea only a "Grand Illusion," as John B. Judis calls it in the title of his thought-provoking book? In a Presidential election year, is the American Century just an old-fashioned jingoistic slogan, backed up by military threats and force, or do the words have some kinder, gentler meaning that takes into account the rest of the civilized world? 
 In a grandiloquent essay that appeared in a February 1941 issue of Life magazine, Henry Luce, founder of the Time Inc. publishing empire, tried to define what he branded the American Century. "It now becomes our time," he wrote, "to be the powerhouse from which the ideals spread throughout the world and do their mysterious work of lifting the life of mankind from the level of beasts to what the Psalmist called a little lower than the angels."
Fifty years later, after the American-led coalition victory in the Persian Gulf war, President Bush repeatedly invoked the notion of an American Century again. Speaking to Congress, he said the nation's best days were yet to come in the next American Century. At the Air Force Academy, he told the cadets that the United States had the strength to bear the burden of world leadership. On Veterans Day 1991, he said that the gulf war demonstrated that "America holds a special place in history" and that "we've sought to extend the blessings of liberty throughout the world."
In his well-organized and opinionated book Mr. Judis, a writer for In These Times and The New Republic and author of "William F. Buckley Jr.: Patron Saint of the Conservatives," presents a variety of views on the theme of the American Century. The author follows the Lytton Strachey ("Eminent Victorians") style of history: essays in iconoclasm built around a group of conflicting personalities.
Among them are Henry A. Wallace, Walter Lippmann, George F. Kennan, J. William Fulbright, Barry Goldwater, Lee A. Iacocca, Henry A. Kissinger and three Presidents, Richard M. Nixon, Ronald Reagan and George Bush. Some of these experts regard the idea of an American Century to be elusive or illusory, others see it as benevolent or belligerent. As an example of the author's range of characters, he labels Mr. Iacocca a "car salesman" playing the role of an "industrial statesman," while Ralph Nader, opposed to the Government's bailout of Chrysler, is described as "a left-wing trustbuster in the Jeffersonian tradition." The reader is seldom in doubt about which personality the author prefers.
The notion of America as the symbol of freedom and exemplary values goes back to Colonial times. In 1630 John Winthrop, the leader of the Massachusetts Bay Company, told his fellow passengers on the Arbella that they had not sailed across the Atlantic to find wealth but to build a "city on a hill." From John Winthrop to Henry Luce to George Bush, and many others, the tone of America as a superior nation has been evangelical: God's country.
Although the phrase "the American century" sounds simplistic and presumptuous, Mr. Judis finds that some American visionaries did indeed define a greater world role for the United States, though usually in less chauvinistic and more acceptable language.
Theodore Roosevelt and progressive intellectuals like Herbert Croly, the New Republic editor, and Walter Lippmann, the columnist, believed that the growth of industry could be shaped to serve egalitarian ends. President Franklin D. Roosevelt linked World War II to the effort to secure the Four Freedoms (freedom of speech and worship, freedom from want and fear) for people everywhere. Henry Wallace, Roosevelt's Vice President before Harry S. Truman, called for a global New Deal and the century of the common man. The postwar Marshall Plan to rebuild Europe began on President Truman's watch. During the Vietnam War, Lippmann, Kennan and Fulbright argued against expanding the evangelical role of the United States by military means. But Mr. Reagan's two terms in office increased the influence of the religious right and revived the cold war's evangelism.
In a chapter titled "George Bush and the Next American Century," Mr. Judis writes that with the threat of Communism gone, Mr. Bush was "utterly unable to articulate a new sense of America's purpose." In 1988, "emulating Reagan, he ran on the hollow promise of retaining the American Century." When the 1992 race started, "he began calling for a 'next American Century,' reducing Luce's call to arms to a campaign slogan."
"Grand Illusion" even challenges the way President Bush has handled foreign affairs. Mr. Judis maintains that while Mr. Bush was influenced by the Realpolitik of Mr. Nixon and Mr. Kissinger, "he had never tried to reconceptualize America's role in the world." On domestic matters, the author is even more critical: "As someone who had tried to span the different worlds of upper-class Connecticut and nouveau-riche Texas, Bush had unusual difficulty identifying with average Americans. As President, he seemed as distant from a laid-off Chrysler worker in St. Louis as from a Kurd on the Turkish-Iraqi border."
Comparing the first and last decades of the 20th century, Mr. Judis concludes that the difference between the Republican Roosevelt and the Republican Bush marks "the difference between the beginning and the end of the American Century." The author says that in an economically interdependent world, America's military power "is increasingly irrelevant" -- one of his opinions that surely can be challenged. Even if a Pax Americana isn't possible, such a view seems far-fetched in an armed world where tyrannical governments with nuclear ambitions still exist.
As a polemicist, Mr. Judis makes no effort to be evenhanded about the personalities in "Grand Illusion," which is why his book makes for such lively reading.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Meeting On Vincent Could Be Ordered

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Commissioner Fay Vincent will conduct a telephone meeting of major league club owners today, but it won't be the session sought by the owners who want to dismiss him.
Today's meeting will deal with the sale of the Detroit Tigers. It is a formality because owners in both leagues already have unanimously approved the transaction in unofficial league votes. The type of meeting the anti-Vincent faction of owners wants, in which they would ask Vincent to resign or be fired, would not be a formality. It could, on the other hand, turn out to be unofficial, and its results unenforceable. 
 Vincent has refused the request of the two league presidents to call a meeting that would deal with his status. But the two presidents, Bobby Brown and Bill White, at the urging of some of their employers, are expected to act under a provision of the Major League Agreement and summon the owners to a joint session in which Vincent would indeed be the main topic of discussion.
"I certainly wouldn't be surprised if there were a meeting," Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers said yesterday.
Brown and White wrote to Vincent last Monday asking him to call a meeting so the owners could discuss "the terms and conditions of the commissioner." Vincent's opponents, who appear to be blaming him for many of baseball's economic problems, want him to resign under threat of dismissal. Vincent, whose term runs through March 31, 1994, says he will not resign and that he cannot be fired. And he has hired a lawyer, Brendan V. Sullivan Jr., to represent him in case the owners do try to fire him.
 
Presidents Could Call a Meeting
 If the commissioner does not call a meeting within five days after receiving the request of the league presidents, according to Article V, Section 3 of the Major League Agreement, the presidents may call the meeting themselves. Five business days are up today, meaning Brown and White could make their move without further delay..
"I haven't talked to any owners today," Brown, the American League president, said yesterday when asked if he would call a meeting. "I will wait to see what they communicate tomorrow, and the next step will be taken depending on what they communicate."
Vincent's supporters say such a meeting would be unlawful because the Major League Agreement prohibits the owners from doing anything about a commissioner's powers during his term of office. Asked about the possible illegality of a meeting, Brown said, "I'd check with our league counsel to see if it was legal or illegal."
White, the National League president, declined to discuss the matter. "These things are internal matters," he said. "They will be handled internally."
Brown said that seven American League owners asked him to ask the commissioner to call a meeting. White would not say how many National League owners asked him.
If such a meeting is scheduled, it's not known who would attend, although it appears that Vincent wouldn't. The commissioner's supporters might choose to boycott the meeting as a way of showing their disdain for the effort of their colleagues to oust Vincent.
On the other hand, Vincent's supporters might feel they should attend so that they could counter the arguments made by those opposed to Vincent, arguments that could influence the owners who have remained neutral in this dispute.
 
Disagreement on Numbers
 In fact, there don't seem to be many neutrals. There also is disagreement about how many owners line up on each side. The anti-Vincent faction insists that a majority of the 28 club owners opposes the commissioner. No member of that group, though, has been willing to identify the members of that majority.
According to various owners and officials, an unofficial lineup would seem to look like this:
*Opposed to Vincent: Cubs, Dodgers, Cardinals, Giants, Pirates, Angels, White Sox, Indians, Brewers, Twins, Yankees, Blue Jays.
*Supporting Vincent: Mets, Astros, Expos, Braves, Padres, Marlins, Rockies, Orioles, Red Sox, Athletics, Mariners, Rangers.
*Undecided or unknown: Reds, Phillies, Royals, Tigers.
Blue Jays officials had indicated their support of Vincent, but they recently hinted that they might have signed a document that charges the commissioner with wrongdoing in half a dozen areas.
One owner said a lawyer for the Cubs wrote that document, which has not been presented to Vincent, and he described it as "vicious." The Cubs have been identified by more than one owner as the leader in the move to oust the commissioner. The Cubs are unhappy with Vincent's efforts to diminish the influence and income of television superstations, including the one owned by the Tribune Company, which owns the Cubs.
They have also sued Vincent over his ordered realignment of the National League, which would put the Cubs in the Western Division and give them later and less attractive times for some of their broadcasts.
With Vincent refusing to resign, his opponents could vote at the meeting to fire him. But without his consent to that action, which he described as illegal in a letter he wrote last Thursday, his opponents most likely would have to seek court action to enforce the dismissal and Vincent's eviction from his office at 350 Park Avenue.
Although different owners might have different reasons for wanting Vincent out, the major overriding reason is an economic one. Owners, especially those of small-market teams, fear for their future because of the escalation of player salaries and the threatened reduction of revenue from the next national television package.
Some of Vincent's supporters have suggested that the real aim of the dissidents is to break the players' union, but that they know they can't attempt it with Vincent in office.
When the owners locked out the players from spring training camps in 1990, Vincent helped negotiate an agreement with the union. His opponents believe he was too conciliatory in that instance and that he has continued to be too soft toward the union.
One Vincent supporter said that what the owners really would like to do to ease the economic problems is to enter into a new plan of collusion. The owners were found guilty of collusion from 1985 through 1987 and agreed to pay the players $280 million.
But Vincent, who wasn't commissioner at the time, is the only member of the major league baseball establishment who has acknowledged collusion took place. The owners don't like him for that, and, the Vincent supporter said, they know they can't try it again as long as he is around.
Another major conflict is over superstations. Vincent has been working hard in baseball and in Congress to reduce the effect of several superstations on locally televised games and to extract bigger payments from the superstations. The competition provided by superstations serves to undermine local television revenues.
The Cubs' parent company, the Tribune Company, resents Vincent's efforts because it owns a superstation, WGN-TV. It also holds television rights to six teams besides its own, and all but one of those teams is aligned with the Cubs against Vincent.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Quick Mischief's Upset Adds to Wacky Weekend

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23

 BODY:
Racing people were still trying to figure out how Thunder Rumble had shot to the head of the class of 3-year-old colts by winning two major races in three weeks at the Saratoga Race Course. And while they were doing it, the fillies and mares took the stage today and supplied an upset of their own: Quick Mischief outran the highly favored Versailles Treaty by nearly seven lengths in the $200,000 John A. Morris Handicap.
Versailles Treaty, a daughter of Danzig owned by Cynthia Phipps and trained by Shug McGaughey, doesn't get outrun very often and not by very much. In 16 races before today, she won eight times and ran in the money all 16 times. She ran in the money this time, too, but still was a soundly beaten 3-5 favorite in a Grade I stakes for fillies and mares on a race track renowned for beaten favorites.
 
Surrounded by Questions
 Meanwhile, the colts were still surrounded by questions about their own recent upsets. Ten of them ran a ringing Travers Stakes on Saturday, with $1 million on the line and 46,372 persons watching and betting $6.5 million, the most money ever wagered in one day at Saratoga in the 125-year history of the track. 
 But only one of the 10 colts had an excuse: Bien Bien, who shipped in from California after winning two recent stakes there, buckled coming out of the starting gate and tore a gash in his right front foot. Chris McCarron, who also had flown from California just to ride the colt, spent the entire mile and one-quarter trying to get back into the race while Dixie Brass set a sizzling pace before tiring with an eighth of a mile to go.
That was when Thunder Rumble did his number, as he did in the Jim Dandy Stakes three weeks earlier when he outran Dixie Brass by half a length at odds of 25-1. This time, at odds of 7-1, he ran down Dixie Brass in the final eighth of a mile and won the race by 4 1/2 lengths over Devil His Due. They were trailed by Dance Floor and Dixie Brass, while Furiously faded to sixth and the Canadian star Alydeed retreated to eighth.
 
A Fun Trip
 "That was fun," said Richie O'Connell, who trains Thunder Rumble for a Swiss economist, Konrad Widmer. "I was very sure he would win, but I didn't expect him to gallop. I would have to think, because he won with such authority, that he has to be considered at the top of his division."
Nobody disagreed with O'Connell's victory claim. In fact, the trainers of the speed demons agreed that their horses could run fast but not long, while Thunder Rumble and Devil His Due had showed that they could run very fast and very long.
"Dixie Brass came back good," his trainer, Dennis Brida, said this morning. "He ran as well as he could. The track was not really speed-favoring, especially going long, and I don't think he wants to go a mile and a quarter. We'll drop him back to a shorter distance. Like I've said before, I think we've got one of the best milers in the country."
 
Alydeed Comes Up Short
 Distance also may have been the undoing of Alydeed, who stalked the leader for one mile but then stopped stalking and dropped to the rear. His jockey, Craig Perret, suggested after the race that the colt may have suffered from pulmonary bleeding, which troubled him earlier this year.
"He hasn't run a race that dull since I've known him," said Perret.
But the horse was examined back at the barn, and no sign of bleeding was found. His trainer, Roger Attfield, said simply: "I don't know what the problem was. He took a blood test three days ago and the results showed him to be as healthy an equine as you could want to see."
"I've said he may be an exceptional miler," Attfield said. "But he didn't run an exceptional mile this time. I don't know what happened, and maybe I hope I never find out."
 
No Contest
 In the Morris Handicap, the main question was whether Versailles Treaty could catch Quick Mischief, who led all the way. The answer: No way. Quick Mischief, a 6-year-old mare owned by Greg G. Mordas of Millstone Township, N.J., and trained by Charles Carlesimo Jr. drew far in front in the homestretch and won by 6 3/4 lengths. Versailles Treaty was next, half a length in front of Scotty Schulhofer's Shared Interest.
The winner ran the mile and an eighth in 1:474/5 , returned $9.80 for $2 to win and went home with $120,000.
"Mostly, I train allowance and claiming horses," the trainer said, "so winning a race like this feels great."
 
FINISH LINE
 JULIE KRONE returned to the races after missing most of the last week with a siege of colitis, and rode Shared Interest. But two races earlier, she rode her first winner in a week aboard BILL MOTT's 2-year-old filly Jill Miner.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Grading Bush's Speech

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
All eyes have been fixed on the effect of the Bush acceptance speech: conventioneers bought while investors sold and pollsters bounced.
But what of the speech itself? Did it measure up to the standard set in Mr. Bush's first acceptance speech four years ago -- and did it live up to the advance word that it would not only "redefine" his image but would tell the American people where he hoped to lead them in a second term? 
 Those of us who were rooting for him to deliver a thematic, inspirational address that set forth realistic economic and foreign policies were disappointed. Here is a report card from a former Republican speech-writer who still wishes he could be more of a Bush supporter:
1. Structure: It was as if the first and last 10 minutes of the speech were written by an articulate idealist (Ray Price, my estimable Nixon colleague) but an interminable 40-minute middle -- a laundry list, complete with the hoary line-item veto, left over from the State of the Union Message -- was jammed in by a scathing partisan (Robert Zoellick, James Baker's writer). Result: a pushmi-pullyu polemic, going in opposite directions.
2. Tone: Throughout his speech's sagging center, Mr. Bush adopted the uncharacteristic pose of ridicule. His shaft at Mario Cuomo's indecisiveness was lost on listeners unfamiliar with Baskin-Robbins; his "Slippery When Wet" charge was insensitive to auto accidents in the Clinton and Gore pasts; two references to Elvis Presley were one too many, and a derogation of the "tasseled loafers" of lawyers seemed out of place for a patrician more familiar with Gucci than most Democrats. Mr. Bush, good at sincerity, is poor at ridicule.
3. Delivery: In rejecting Democratic ridicule, as in his repeated "tell that to" passage, he used Churchillian anaphora to drive home his point with confidence and zest; Roger Ailes, his coach, has reason to be proud. However, in the speech's roughest personal shot -- "while I bit the bullet, he bit his nails" -- Mr. Bush, perhaps because it was out of character, blew the line.
4. Phrasemaking: "The gridlock Democrat Congress" is a nice evocation of Harry Truman's "do-nothing 80th Congress," and picks up on Ross Perot's favorite word. "A rubber-check Congress and a rubber-stamp President" was good, but the use of alliteration -- calling Congress a web of "PAC's, perks, privileges, partisanship and paralysis" that "puts politics ahead of principle, and above progress" -- was Harding-like in its excess. ("Not nostrums but normalcy, not experiment but equipoise . . .") Good focus on the target was shown in "Our policies haven't failed; they haven't been tried," but "our new crusade," coined to counter the religiosity of Clinton's "New Covenant" and to evoke Eisenhower, is unlikely to catch on.
5. The Fresh Idea: The tax-return checkoff is a gimmick to try to deal with the worst shortcoming of the Bush Presidency: unrestrained spending that caused a ballooning deficit. His serious plan is to throttle down increases in Medicare, Medicaid and veterans' benefits to the rate of inflation and new beneficiaries -- a necessary discipline -- but in this he bit his nails rather than the bullet. By sugarcoating his entitlement restraint with a vague promise of tax-rate reduction, Mr. Bush destroyed the credibility of deficit reduction.
6. Omissions: The speech was improved by leaving out cracks about Hillary Clinton or overtly dwelling on family values; it was diminished by a fear of mentioning or comforting the unemployed.
7. Peroration: His railroad-whistle- in-the-night passage -- standing a pre-dawn watch "when God introduces you to yourself" and presaging a national sunrise -- worked.
8. The Implanted Film Clip: As "an aside," he promised to "never let politics interfere with a foreign policy decision" no matter how much it would help his re-election.
This is a rhetorical time bomb set to go off at a moment of crisis. Intended for replay when he zaps Saddam or puts medics in Sarajevo, those words may turn out to be the most memorable line of a speech in which the President "redefined" himself as Harry Truman because he could not define himself as George Bush.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Price Of Lies

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
If you wonder why Americans have become so cynical about politics, take a close look at George Bush's acceptance speech at the Houston convention. It was a classic of the misrepresentations, the hollow promises, the brazen falsehoods that have made people turn off.
The big news in the speech was the promise of an across-the-board tax cut. Everyone likes the idea of paying less in taxes. But the Bush plan was so hollow that it collapsed at once when analyzed -- not only by the Democrats but by conservative economists. 
 Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Nixon, told The Boston Globe: "We're not likely to see any tax cuts out of this. It's just to fill up the space until the election."
The Bush plan calls for tax cuts to be matched by cuts in Federal spending. But Mr. Stein pointed out that the President also demanded a constitutional amendment to balance the budget, and any spending cuts would have to go to reducing the deficit. "You can't sell the same spending cuts twice," he said.
Moreover, some of the particular cuts proposed by Mr. Bush -- in medical care for the elderly and the poor -- have no chance of enactment, and he knows it. In fact, his budget this year called for increases in Medicaid spending.
But my favorite passage in the Bush speech was this one: "From Angola to Central America they [the Democrats] said, 'Let's negotiate, deliberate, procrastinate.' We said, 'Just stand up for freedom.' "
The purpose of that passage was of course to make the Democrats look unpatriotic. Mr. Bush was using the tactic pioneered by Richard Nixon and Joe McCarthy. But in the examples he chose he turned the record exactly backward.
In Angola, the consistent American policy through the Carter, Reagan and Bush Administrations was to help negotiate an end to the brutal civil war. The policy was brought to a successful conclusion -- an admirable conclusion -- by Hank Cohen, Mr. Bush's Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. Mr. Cohen must be surprised to hear that his President thinks he was unpatriotic.
In Central America, the Reagan policy, created by Al Haig, was to stoke up war. Mr. Bush's Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Bernard Aronson, turned that policy around. He aimed for a negotiated end to the war in El Salvador and a political solution in Nicaragua.
The peaceful policy worked -- with crucial help from Jimmy Carter at the Nicaraguan election. Mr. Aronson, too, must be surprised to know that President Bush disapproves of negotiation.
Then there was Mr. Bush's statement that Bill Clinton had "raised taxes and fees 128 times" as Governor of Arkansas. Dan Quayle first used that figure. It has the delusory precision of Joe McCarthy's claim that he had the names of 155 or 163 Communists in the Government.
But the figure had been examined by Michael Kinsley in The New Republic, and exploded, before the convention. Mr. Kinsley showed that the list produced by the Bush-Quayle campaign was, as he put it, "hilariously shoddy."
One item listed as a "tax increase" was a 1987 law lengthening the Arkansas dog-racing season. Why? More days, more revenue from the state gambling tax. Another was a $1 increase in court costs imposed on convicted criminals. And so on.
There have been about as many tax cuts as increases in Mr. Clinton's years as Governor. And Arkansas is 49th among the 50 states in per capita state and local taxes.
The word carpenters who put together the Bush speech surely knew the 128 figure was phony. They put it in there anyway, and Mr. Bush used it.
Does that matter? Maybe I am naive, but I think it does. Hyperbole is to be expected of politicians. But deliberate lies? I think that kind of politics has brought this country close to disbelief in its own political system.
When an incumbent President makes such a speech, the purpose is to distract the voters from his record. But as Mr. Bush spoke, the real world reminded us of the record. The dollar fell to a record low against the German mark. The stock market dropped sharply. And the largest number of Americans in a decade filed new unemployment compensation claims

HEADLINE: Rising Mark Reverberates in Britain and U.S.;
Weak Pound May Require Hard Choice

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The recent strengthening of the German mark is forcing Britain to confront its most painful lesson yet about the costs of economic integration with the Continent.
Although deeply ambivalent about unification with Europe, Britain agreed two years ago to link its currency to the value of other European currencies, promising to keep the pound within an agreed-upon range relative to the mark. 
 And with the pound, like the dollar, plunging in value against the mark last week, Britain now stands at the brink of being forced to prop up the value of its currency. Any further fall in the value of the pound, in fact, could force Prime Minister John Major into a step he is clearly loath to take: raising interest rates to support the pound, despite the additional economic suffering such a move would inflict on the recession-bound British economy.
 
A Challenge for This Week
 Mr. Major and Norman Lamont, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, are expected to try to deal with any further decline in the pound this week by first trying to intervene heavily in foreign currency markets to check the strength of the mark, perhaps in coordination with the Federal Reserve in the United States and other central banks that are concerned with the weakened dollar. The pound traded below 2.8 marks on Friday, and finished the day just two pfennigs above the lower limit allowed under the exchange-rate mechanism of 2.778 marks.
But analysts said that previous efforts to bolster the pound, and the dollar, had been unavailing, and that if Mr. Major and Mr. Lamont plan to stand by their pledge to maintain the pound's value and stay in the exchange-rate mechanism, they may soon find themselves with no choice but to raise interest rates by a full point or two from their current level of 10 percent.
"The rules appear to require us to put up interest rates," Peter Morgan, the director general of the Institute of Directors, a business trade group, said in a radio interview with the BBC on Saturday. "It is the economics of the madhouse, but we have agreed to play by the rules."
 
Building Up the Pound
 Government officials said participation in the exchange-rate mechanism had built confidence in the stability of the pound and had helped impose a financial discipline on Britain that contributed to a decline in inflation rates and to what until now had been a general downward trend in interest rates.
"Since we have joined the E.R.M., we have been able to bring down inflation and interest rates on a regular basis, but nobody ever thought this would be a one-way street," Gerry Malone, the deputy Conservative Party chairman, said in a radio interview with the BBC. "What would totally undermine confidence in the Government's policy would be if there is a problem like this and we were prepared to rule out the possibility of the use of interest rates as a mechanism to maintain our position in the E.R.M."
Yet in a country that remains divided about how far it should go in integrating itself into a unified Europe, the possibility of having to sacrifice short-term domestic economic priorities to the possible longer-term benefits of stable currency valuations has in a matter of days become a potent political issue.
 
Deep Political Splits
 It has not only widened the split between Mr. Major's Conservative Party and the opposition Labor Party, but also enlarged the deep fissures within the Conservative ranks over Britain's proper role in the new Europe. And it could put Mr. Major, who is currently serving his rotating term as President of the European Community, in an awkward position as he tries to use that post to advance Britain's interest in the balky process of unification.
"An increase in interest rates would be a terminal blow to factories already low in orders and homeowners already in arrears," said Robin Cook, a member of Parliament who serves as the Labor Party's spokesman on trade and industry issues. "As president of the E.C., John Major should be taking the lead in getting a coordinated cut in interest rates across Europe."
The possibility of interest rate increases has already started debate anew over whether Britain should remain within the exchange-rate mechanism at all. And it seems likely to refocus attention on the larger question of how much control the nation should be prepared to give up over its own economic destiny to make itself part of a unified Europe.
 
Cost of High Interest Rates
 Any move to raise interest rates would hit consumers and homeowners hard by pushing up mortgage rates and other key rates, and could choke off what few signs of recovery the British economy has shown in recent months.
Even a sharp increase in interest rates, though, might not hold the pound's value for long, some analysts said. Opinion polls in France show growing sentiment against approving the Maastricht Treaty on European unification when it is put to a referendum in that country next month. A French vote against the treaty, analysts said, would virtually insure the end of the current efforts at unification. That in turn would raise further questions about the long-term prospects of the British economy and could drive the pound lower once again.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 27, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Monday showing the declining value of the dollar and the British pound was labeled incompletely. The scale represented the ratio of each currency's value in German marks to its value on Jan. 1, with 100 as a starting point, and the lines showed how those ratios had changed.

HEADLINE: HURRICANE ANDREW;
Hurricane Rips Through Florida and Heads Into Gulf

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
One of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes of the century slammed into South Florida yesterday, causing at least nine deaths, leveling thousands of houses south of Miami and all but destroying an Air Force base.
As the hurricane swirled westward into the Gulf of Mexico, residents of coastal Louisiana and Mississippi began preparing for the storm's relentless winds by stocking up on food and taping windows. The National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla., issued a hurricane warning for the area from Pascagoula, Miss., to Vermilion Bay, La., and said it could strike the Gulf Coast as early as tonight. 
 Blustering along with winds that at times reached 150 miles an hour, Hurricane Andrew peeled roofs from houses and other buildings in South Florida and flipped over huge commercial fishing boats like children's bathtub toys. It left tracks from Miami's elevated mass-transit system rail system dangling from trestles.
 
Disaster Area Declared
 President Bush declared much of South Florida a disaster area, opening the way for Federal disaster assistance in the form of emergency money for rent payments, loans for businesses to rebuild and unemployment assistance for hurricane-related job losses. After flying to Miami to inspect te damage, Mr. Bush said, "I want to let the people know at this moment, this terrible moment, that all of us are concerned. And I'll say to the people of Florida, the rest of America is here to back you in any way we can."
Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, who also toured the area, described the damage as "devastating."
"I never saw anything like that," Governor Chiles said. "It's like an air bomb went off."
By 2 A.M. today, the hurricane, its winds about 140 m.p.h., was 305 miles southeast of New Orleans, moving west-northwest.
 
Guard Controls Looting
 While downtown Miami and Miami Beach suffered relatively little structural damage, the storm's fury was concentrated just 10 to 15 miles farther south, in areas like Cutler Ridge, Homestead and Kendall, where some Miami Beach residents huddled in a shelter that lost its roof in the storm. Their Miami Beach apartment building was unscathed.
But even in Miami, entire neighborhoods had no electricity, no telephone service and no running water. Much of the city's glittering skyline fell dark at nightfall after a day that began with blasts of tropical air stripping the paint off houses and the sky turning green and yellow and purple.
Thousands of National Guard troops were sent in to join local law-enforcement officers trying to prevent looting, which had been reported sporadically throughout the day. Miami and Dade County, the jurisdiction that surrounds the city, imposed 7 P.M.-to-7 A.M. curfews.
The Air Force had evacuated all but 18 of its 4,300 military personnel from its base at Homestead over the weekend, and most of its F-16 fighter jets and C-130 transports had been sent to bases in South Carolina and Georgia. Still, the preparations were not enough. "Homestead Air Force Base no longer exists," said Toni Riordan, a spokeswoman for the State Community Affairs Department.
Officials said Florida would have suffered more casualties if people had not followed the evacuation orders issued Sunday night. More than a million people left their homes for safer quarters -- shelters, hotels or friends' houses inland. "Thank goodness we had the kind of evacuation we did," Governor Chiles said. "There was no way in the world anybody could have survived."
Suddenly, the landscape was fantastical: tall palm trees yanked out of the ground with balls of roots and turf still attached, leaving lawns looking like pockmarked green carpets. In places, it was as if a giant, mad wood-chopper had hacked its way through cypresses, pines and palms. In other places, roofs had been sheared away like sardine-can lids and sailboats grabbed from the water and dropped randomly on what had been dry land. Small airplanes were strewn along runways at the Tamiami Airport; the hangars that had sheltered them had been blown away.
"It's like building blocks, and somebody comes along and steps on it all," Dade County Manager Joaquin Avino said.
 
Help From the Unscathed
 Taking in the strange-looking scene in the aftermath of the storm, Floridians created strange-looking scenes of their own. In Kendall, a man tottered on a bicycle, steering with one hand while he aimed a video camera with his other. In Florida City, where Col. Bill McDonald of the Monroe County Sheriff's Office said there had been two hurricane-related deaths, officers borrowed a van from a Baptist church to patrol the streets. Only 1 of 11 police cars had survived the storm.
But for all its fury on the mainland, the hurricane barely touched Key West. By last night people from Key Largo were bringing supplies north to Florida City. Greg Brown, a grocery-store butcher in Key Largo, was headed to the mainland with a pickup packed with frozen pizzas, bagels and other perishables.
And even on the mainland, the devastation was leavened by relief that the storm had followed the path it did. In Miami Beach, Mayor Seymour Gelber said the storm had been "considerably less devastating than everyone had anticipated."
 
No Way Back for Some
 Evacuees were allowed to return to their homes beginning at 5 P.M. yesterday, and most did so. On some streets there were impromptu block parties, but some elderly people who live in hotels spent a second night in emergency shelters because there were no buses to take them back. Reporters who tried to cross from the mainland to Miami Beach were turned back by police officers, who admitted only those with identification to prove that they lived there.
Information from the areas hardest hit was difficult to come by for much of the day. At 11 P.M., The Associated Press was reporting nine hurricane-related deaths in Florida, but the Florida emergency agency said it could confirm only two. With much of the state unreachable by phone, stories of the destruction trickled in gradually, in some cases through a ham radio station at the United Nations that is part of a loose network of about 70 stations.
David Rosen, the station manager, said that an operator in Homestead had reported that blocks and blocks of homes were in splinters and that people were having trouble identifying the intersections in Hartford Square, a few miles from Homestead.
 
Looting and Inconvenience
 Like people up and down the coast, residents there had shuttered their homes, packed their suitcases and checked into hotels or found government-run shelters. Mary Barmmer,who lives in an unincorporated section of Dade County south of Miami, spent Sunday night in her husband's office building near Miami International Airport before heading for a hotel in Kendall.
Her 14-year-old son, Brendan, was worried about his 9-year-old cat, E.T., whom they left at home. "I don't know if he can take all the stress," he said.
The Marriott they checked into had windows that had blown in and toilets that had exploded as the storm approached and the air pressure dropped.
In Miami Beach, residents told of seeing looters casually strolling the streets, carrying merchandise like running shoes. But Mayor Gelber said there had been only three reported instances of looting, affecting primarily businesses on Lincoln Road, the city's pedestrian shopping mall.
Of more concern than looting, Mr. Gelber said, was the absence of basic public services. "We don't have water, and we don't have electricity except for one small 10-block strip," the 72-year-old mayor said. "People are grumbling, as one would expect. They have already forgotten the fright of what the hurricane had in store for us. They all want to be back home, working on their problems and enjoying the ordinary amenities of life to which people are accustomed. I walked up 14 floors to my condo today, for instance."
In the hardest-hit areas of southern Dade County, progress in reopening highways and restoring telephone service was too slow for many returning residents. Spokesmen for both the Department of Public Works and the telephone company said that repair crews had to wait for word from Florida Power and Light that wires that had been knocked down by falling trees were no longer live.
Ms. Riordan, the spokeswoman for the Department of Community Services, said that state officials were having trouble moving some emergency equipment and National Guard units to Dade and Monroe Counties because residents returning home from temporary shelters were jamming the Florida Turnpike.
"It's bumper to bumper," she said.
 
Airport Damaged
 Miami International Airport remained closed to commercial flights, and officials said that it would not reopen until repairs had been made to damaged areas. Security fences around runways and some passenger jetways were damaged, and the Federal Aviation Administration will not allow normal service to resume until repairs are made. Authorities said that the airport's one functioning runway was being reserved exclusively for relief flights.
Many local institutions were ordered to remain closed today. Local courts will be closed, and postal employees were told to stay home. The University of Miami said it would be closed at least through Wednesday.
All the damage came from a hurricane that seemed to blossom suddenly, on Saturday, into one of the most powerful ever to strike the East Coast. Meteorologists attributed this to a variety of factors.
As it chugged across the Atlantic, the storm's energy was sapped by a competing low-pressure system to the north. This second storm not only competed for energy; its high-level winds also clashed with those of the hurricane.
When the northerly storm moved away, Hurricane Andrew began to gain strength. At the same time it moved over warmer water, which imparted more energy to it. And as it approached the Florida coast, it met a huge high-pressure system, covering the eastern United States, whose "friendly" wind patterns allowed the hurricane to build. The big high-pressure system also blocked the hurricane from moving farther north, directing it instead toward southern Florida. And the strong east-to-west winds along the high's southern edge pushed the hurricane along a bit faster than might otherwise have been the case, causing it to clear Florida in a relatively brief three hours.
"This was like a trot as opposed to the standard walk," said Fred Gadomski, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University's Weather Communications Group.
Forecasters predicted yesterday that the edge of the high pressure system would continue to guide the storm northwestward through the Gulf of Mexico toward the mouth of the Mississippi. They forecast the storm's peak winds at between 110 and 130 m.p.h. when it makes landfall on the Gulf Coast, probably between 8 P.M. today and 2 A.M. Wednesday. That would make it a Category 3 storm on the Saffir-Simpson scale of hurricane intensity, with Category 5 the strongest.
The hurricane's winds are expected to diminish rapidly after it makes landfall along the Gulf. But forecasters expect its rains to cause widespread flooding as the storm breaks up and its remnants move up the Missisippi Valley before turning northeastward.
The course that the storm appeared to be following was close to that of Hurricane Betsy in 1965, a Category 3 storm that struck both southern Florida and New Orleans, causing nearly $1.5 billion worth of damage and killing 75 people.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Rochester Serves as Model In Controlling Health Cost

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCHESTER

 BODY:
In the search for ways to slow the surge in national medical spending, policy makers and economists are paying growing attention to this prosperous industrial city of 232,000 in upstate New York.
Health-care experts say Rochester is one of the few American cities that have systems that work. Although medical costs have also been rising rapidly here in recent years, they are still at least 25 percent lower per capita than national levels. And in Rochester, only 6 percent of the population does not have insurance, according to a survey by Louis Harris & Associates, far below the 14 percent national rate. 
 By cooperating closely, instead of competing ferociously as they do in most cities, the doctors, the hospitals and the local businesses have kept the quality of care high, with a relatively low level of waste and unnecessary care. The General Accounting Office is preparing a report on the Rochester system for Congress.
 
Program Called 'a Jewel'
 "Rochester is a jewel in a sea of health-care despair," said Stephen Skorcz, a Toronto hospital executive who was president for four years of the Rochester Area Hospitals Corporation, a nonprofit planning and research group that the hospitals established.
The Rochester program has served the interests of the city's largest employers, including Eastman Kodak and Xerox, by holding down the growth in costly health-care benefits. But the chief beneficiaries have been the families and small businesses that would typically not have access to affordable care because they were not part of a larger group.
 
Equality of Payments
 Under the Rochester plan, they pay the same monthly premiums for each person as Kodak and Xerox, for equal benefits. And unlike most health-care plans for small groups, no one pays more or is refused coverage because of age, sex or a previous medical condition.
Doctors and business and hospital executives around the country say one reason the Rochester system works is that local industry, vigorously led by Kodak, which has 39,000 employees here, cooperates closely.
All but a few employers buy their insurance from Rochester Area Blue Cross and an independent health maintenance organization, instead of following the national pattern of insuring themselves in separate arrangements. This self-insuring can reduce a large company's costs, at least for a time, but it often increases the burden for small companies, which have few employees over which to spread the risks.
David E. Edwards, Kodak's benefits director, compared the company's community-first philosophy to the maxim "the family that prays together stays together." Kodak's 1991 health costs averaged $2,100 an employee in Rochester, which was 25 percent lower than at the company's operations in other cities. Kodak's total cost last year for all employees, retirees and dependents was $240 million.
Rochester Area Blue Cross and Blue Shield said the cost of health-care coverage per employee in company plans here was $2,378 in 1991, about one-third less than the $3,573 reported in a national survey of employers by the A. Foster Higgins benefits consulting firm. Those numbers include both employer and employee contributions.
In addition, Blue Cross administrative costs were 7 percent of revenues, much lower than national estimates of 14 to 24 percent for most insurers. Rochester Blue Cross officials said the reasons for their lower costs included the efficiency of their electronic claims processing, the high productivity of their employees and therelatively low spending on advertising.
More than half of the region's one million people are in health maintenance organizations, which are prepaid health plans that offer comprehensive coverage, including regular checkups, and try to help their members avert expensive hospital stays. Even the handful of self-insured employers, including Bausch & Lomb and General Motors' Delco Chassis and AC Rochester units, say most of their Rochester people are in one of the two local H.M.O.'s, one of which is offered by Blue Cross. Blue Cross H.M.O. premiums last year were as much as 25 percent lower than for comparable for traditional coverage.
 
Reins on Hospitals
 Another area of industry cooperation has included close oversight of the area's seven hospitals, which represent a large portion of the costs of health care. Backed by state health planning laws that require approval for big projects or purchases, the Rochester business executives who sit on the hospital boards have kept a tight lid on new buildings and technology. "No one proposes a Taj Mahal," said Albert D. Sharbonneau, executive vice president of the Genesee Hospital in Rochester, which has 424 beds. "It's not worth your time."
No additional hospital beds have been authorized since the 1960's, so more than 90 percent of the beds are always occupied. With all the patients they can handle, "the hospitals haven't had to get into helicopter wars," said Arthur Liebert, president of the 526-bed Rochester General Hospital, referring to the helicopters some hospitals deploy in emergencies.
Avoiding expensive duplication, the hospitals have agreed over the years on which institutions should perform certain specialized services -- like organ transplants, open-heart surgery, pediatrics, psychiatry -- usually with related teaching programs at the University of Rochester medical school.
Under industry pressure, the hospitals agreed to let the Hospital Corporation set communitywide budget ceilings for a time in the early 1980's. This forced them to squeeze down spending. Then because costs were lower than the going rates paid by Medicare, Rochester voluntarily gave back to surprised Federal officials a total of $4.8 million in 1984 and 1989 to prove the effectiveness of its approach.
"When we took the check down to Washington, they didn't know what to do with it," said Dr. James A. Block, who headed the Hospital Corporation at the time and is now president of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. "Nobody had ever returned Medicare money before."
But when the hospitals began to experience operating losses in the late 1980's, they rebelled against the budget ceilings. Other developments, including expensive new diagnostic equipment and surgical procedures, soon were pushing medical costs in Rochester up as rapidly as in other cities, albeit from a much lower base.
 
Costs Begin to Climb
 "Costs have been creeping up in the past few years," said Patricia M. Nazemetz, Xerox's benefits director. But she said that local business executives were trying to get planning back on the table, with all the interested parties taking part in the discussion.
To keep the hospitals cooperating, Donald D. Zrebiec, a retired Xerox executive, is helping to direct a program in which management experts from Kodak, Xerox, General Motors and I.B.M. are advising eight Rochester area hospitals on how to improve the quality of their service.
With hospitals closely controlled in New York State, most health-care spending has moved to physicians' offices and clinics, which often buy their own computerized scanners and magnetic-imaging machines. The Rochester Area Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association is considering an innovative plan that would put pressure on these buyers to get approval as the hospitals do.
Another cornerstone of the Rochester plan is the single-price approach, known as community rating.
Under community rating, everybody -- young and old, healthy and infirm -- is grouped together so the risks and costs are spread evenly across large numbers of people. By contrast, when they become sick or grow old, most individuals and members of small groups have to pay higher premiums or drop their coverage, joining more than 30 million Americans who are uninsured.
Al Ross, a 59-year-old home maintenance contractor, kept his Blue Cross coverage in Rochester after he moved with his wife and two children to Hilton Head Island, S.C.. "Here they charge according to your age," he said of South Carolina, "and there is an additional charge for each child. I'd feel crushed if I had to pay that."
 
Trends in Health Insurance
 Only a few other places, notably Hawaii, have kept community rating, which was common before insurers began to compete for the business of small groups with varying rates. This and other kinds of competition in health care came into vogue in the 1980's in hopes that the pressures of the marketplace would slow rising medical costs, but the practice has tended to favor groups of healthier people and exclude people who are at risk of incurring higher medical bills.
Modified versions of the single-price approach have recently been adopted statewide by Maine, Vermont, Oregon and New York, where the law will take effect on April 1. Community rating is also under study in several other state legislatures and in Congress.
Commercial insurers who oppose community rating say the system would force them to raise premiums beyond the reach of many young and healthy policyholders. That has not happened, however, in Rochester. But Chris Petersen, a senior counsel with the Health Insurance Association of America, a commercial insurers' group, contends that the Rochester system can function only because Blue Cross plans in New York are exempt from state taxes and get discounts on hospital charges.
 
Power of Example
 Policy makers in Washington and across the country express interest in adopting at least parts of the Rochester system. But experts disagree over how many of the Rochester advantages could be replicated elsewhere.
People in Rochester "have been out in front in showing how they can behave as a community," said Dr. Merlin DuVal, a former Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare who is dean emeritus of the University of Arizona College of Medicine.
Dr. Block of Johns Hopkins said the Rochester approach could be transferred to any city if local business leaders would join in supporting a unified regional insurance program. Kodak executives said they were discussing similar approaches in several cities where the company has large plants.
But Humphrey Taylor, chief executive of Louis Harris and Associates, was doubtful. "They have a sense of community in Rochester, which just doesn't exist in most places," he said.
Even if the Rochester program cannot be translated exactly, it may well offer some useful lessons to communities elsewhere. "The Government can learn from Rochester's example," said Howard Berman, president of Rochester Area Blue Cross and Shield. "We have an American success story."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Tells of Plan For More Spending To Train Workers

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANSONIA, Conn., Aug. 24

 BODY:
Declaring that the nation "cannot afford to waste the talent of one single worker," President Bush said today that he would ask Congress next year to approve a major expansion of Federal job training programs that would provide about $10 billion in additional money over five years.
The proposal would provide vouchers that could be used to pay tuition at trade schools, colleges and community colleges for unemployed adults and some others in danger of losing their jobs. The plan is clearly a response to accusations in the political campaign that Mr. Bush has been insensitive to the American work force. 
 The President made the proposal at the Lincoln Technical Institute in the blue-collar town of Union, N.J., and moved on for a campaign stop in Ansonia, Conn., which has been hit hard by the economy, before changing his schedule to fly to Florida to tour areas devastated by Hurricane Andrew.
Contrasting his plan with that of his challenger, Gov. Bill Clinton, Mr. Bush said it would not rely on new taxes and would be financed largely by cutting other domestic programs. But the President, who has repeatedly assailed Mr. Clinton for proposals that could add to the Federal budget deficit, would not say where those cuts would be made.
"My opponent agrees with this in principle," Mr. Bush told several hundred students who gave him an enthusiastic greeting for his morning appearance at the New Jersey school. "But when you get to the details we really do have a vast philosophical difference. I believe we can pay for this new job training offensive without raising taxes on people or increasing overall Government spending."
Mr. Bush toured the school with Labor Secretary Lynn Martin and asked students and an instructor questions about the maintenance of diesel engines.
Torie Clarke, the Bush campaign press secretary, said Mr. Clinton's plan to create jobs would impose a 1.5 percent payroll tax. "He would destroy jobs to supposedly create jobs," she said.
Clinton campaign officials said today that the President's proposals were a poor attempt to mimic Mr. Clinton's record on job training without explaining how he would pay for it.
In his economic and education proposals, Mr. Clinton has called for job and apprenticeship training, including programs for high school graduates who do not go on to college, and for workers who lose their jobs because of reductions in military spending.
The Clinton proposal would require businesses with 50 or more employees to devote 1 1/2 to 2 percent of its payroll to job training.
 
Old and New Ideas
 Mr. Bush's proposal incorporates several programs that already exist or have already been proposed by the Administration. Some provisions are essentially the Administration's response to criticism of the recently signed North American Free Trade Agreement. Unions criticized the pact as neglecting the hundreds of thousands of American workers who fear they could lose their jobs because of increased imports from Mexico and the possible shift of some manufacturing jobs to Mexico, where the wages are lower.
Mr. Bush's plan would apply to workers who have lost their jobs, who have been notified that their jobs are being eliminated and workers in industries who fear job losses in the future.
These people could get vouchers of up to $3,000 a year to refine their job skills or learn new ones. These vouchers could be used at colleges, trade schools or training institutions. Workers would also be eligible for counseling and job-search assistance.
In addition, workers who had lost their jobs, had exhausted their unemployment insurance and were in retraining programs would be eligible to receive Federal assistance until until they found a job.
The President's plan would combine and restructure two programs that the Administration has been seeking to overhaul: the Economic Dislocation and Worker Adjustment Assistance and the Trade Adjustment Assistance Acts.
Administration officials said the Government now spends about $740 million a year for job training. That would increase to roughly $2 billion a year over the next five years.
The new plan calls for other additional spending to expand youth job programs and establish a Youth Training Corps to train poor young people in conservation and environmental work. It includes a drug treatment plan under which those who completed the program would get priority status for admission to the training corps.
The program is similar to one proposed by Senator David L. Boren, a Democrat of Oklahoma, and would admit 113,000 disadvantaged youths to vocational training or other programs each year, an increase of 43,000.
Mr. Bush's proposals were well received in New Jersey and by supporters at a rally here at the Chamber of Commerce at Warsaw Park Hall.
"If our nation is to succeed in this world economy," he said in New Jersey, "we cannot afford to waste the talent of one single worker."
In Ansonia, about 10 miles northeast of Bridgeport, Mr. Bush recalled his achievements abroad and then said it was time to emphasize domestic problems. "And so now the challenge for this country is to bring that spirit home, from Warsaw, Poland, to Warsaw Park and to focus this great nation on the mission ahead."

HEADLINE: Europeans Cooling on Bosnia Partition

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Two days before the start of international talks on ending the fighting in the former Yugoslav republics, European leaders appear to be backing away from a policy of partitioning Bosnia and Herzegovina along ethnic lines as an expedient way to curtail the violence, a senior Bush Administration official said today.
The two-day conference on the Balkans, sponsored by the European Community and the United Nations, will take place here in London on Wednesday and Thursday. 
 A shift by the Europeans on the division of Bosnia would set the stage for the United States to promote its more difficult long-haul policy of excluding Serbia from international affairs while destroying its economy through tougher sanctions.
The Administration and the Bosnian Government strongly oppose the partition policy that Europeans call "cantonization," saying it would reward Serbian aggression and send the wrong message to other armed ethnic groups across Europe and Asia.
 
Eagleburger Takes Over
 The Acting American Secretary of State, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, arrived here today on his first full day in charge to lead the American delegation to the talks. Mr. Eagleburger, a former Ambassador to Yugoslavia, speaks Serbo-Croatian and knows many of the participants in the warfare now tearing apart what used to be Yugoslavia.
On his flight here, the Secretary said he would not remain in office beyond this coming January, the end of President Bush's term.
Referring to Inauguration Day, he continued: "I do not intend to be employed by the United States Government after Jan. 20 next year, no matter what happens, and so my objective is to keep things on as even a keel and get as much accomplished as I can."
At the London talks, the Administration is expected to call for the establishment of a high-level, permanent body drawn from the European Community and the United Nations to police Belgrade's conduct under rules to be established in Security Council resolutions. This body would provide the continuity that is now missing from sporadic and largely unsuccessful efforts to deal with the Balkan crisis.
The plan is not dissimilar to the policy of putting steady, intrusive pressure on Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi President, making him an international pariah under a reinvigorated United Nations and subjecting his country to continual oversight.
Iraq, as well as the Balkans, will be on the agenda Tuesday when Mr. Eagleburger is scheduled to hold talks with European leaders, including the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev.
The Balkan conference is expected to discuss the deployment of troops to insure the delivery of relief supplies to Bosnia. The Administration, which has pledged air and naval support, wants troops on the ground to operate under United Nations command, a senior official said. Britain and France have promised to send contingents; the United States has not.
Administration officials attending the conference want to explore ways to tighten sanctions against Belgrade and to curtail the smuggling of vital supplies to Serbia along the Danube River.
The senior official said that there was "some fairly substantial evidence" of a private smuggling trade in violation of sanctions. Officials say they plan to look into reports that regional governments or their leaders might be involved in smuggling.
The Balkan conference is expected to begin discussing the needs of about two million refugees who will have to be housed and fed through the coming winter. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees will hold a pledging conference in September to raise money for the task.
 
Appeal to Muslims
 The senior Administration official said that Muslim nations are being asked to give generous help to fellow Muslims in Bosnia, who have borne the brunt of the war.
The official said that in addressing the fighting in Yugoslavia, the Administration assumes that there are no quick fixes and that "there are limits to our ability to influence these events."
The official mentioned that while Serbs are the aggressors in the Balkans, "Serbia is not the only party to this dispute that needs to have its conduct examined."
There is some evidence, the official said, that Croats, too, have been doing "some unacceptable things and that Muslims in Bosnia on occasion are taking potshots at people when they expect that this will lead to a charge that it's the Serbians that are doing it."
The Serbian Government, led by President Slobodan Milosevic, backs ethnic Serbian forces carving up Bosnia and Croatia. Mr. Milosevic is reported likely to be present at the London conference.
Even if a cantonization is rejected there, the American official said, this does not solve the problem of how to get the Serbs out of areas they now hold.
"But they need to understand that in the end that's what they're going to have to come to," the official said, adding that "one of the things the Serbs should get through their heads is that history doesn't end tomorrow."

HEADLINE: A Surprise For Schools On Budgets

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Many school superintendents across the city have found they are receiving significantly less money than they expected for the coming school year and are angry they will be forced to increase class sizes and trim staff.
In part, their disappointment reflects a letdown after the announcement last month of a budget agreement that Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and Mayor David N. Dinkins said virtually eliminated a $120 million shortfall hovering over the school system. They promised that increases in class size would be averted. 
 But yesterday Mr. Fernandez acknowledged in a memorandum to the 32 superintendents that some economies will be necessary because the school system did not receive as much as it hoped from the city to cover increases in student enrollment and increases in the cost of supplies. However, he said, the school system's predicament is not as dire as some superintendents are making it out to be.
Mr. Fernandez did not accuse the city of reneging on its deal. his statement seemed to imply that the initial claims the Board of Education made about that deal may have been exaggerated.
 
'Playing With the Numbers'
 Max Messer, superintendent of District 8 in the east Bronx and the head of the city's Association of Superintendents, said that a few days after the announcement he received a budget that had 10 percent less cash for instruction than last year, $41 million compared with $45.6 million.
"Someone is playing with the numbers," he said, echoing the comments of his counterparts in perhaps half the city's 32 school districts.
Cuts of that magnitude, he said, would force him to lose 6 to 10 assistant principals and as many as 6 guidance counselors. Some schools, he said, would be forced to fill one class at each grade level with more students than contractual ceilings allow.
Several district superintendents said they had received essentially the same allocations as last year. But, they said, with inflation, enrollment increases and a more expensive payroll, that money would have to stretch further. A few superintendents, however, are breathing a sigh of relief that they will not have to endure another round of punishing cutbacks.
"I think we feel it's basically about the same as last year," said Andrew Lachman, assistant to Anthony J. Alvarado, the superintendent of District 2 in Manhattan, of his district's real spending power.
News of the complaints by the superintendents elicited an expression of irritation by City Hall at the Board of Education's leadership. Jennifer Kimball, a spokeswoman for Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, said that Mr. Steisel felt he had been assured by Mr. Fernandez and H. Carl McCall, president of the seven-member Board of Education, "that there would not be such an impact" on class sizes or staff.
"If they need more money, they will have to find internal savings," Ms. Kimball said after speaking to Mr. Steisel at his vacation retreat.
Yesterday, the Educational Priorities Panel, one of the city's leading educational advocacy groups, released a list of 16 districts it said had seen their instructional budgets drop between 3 and 13 percent.
"It's going to mean there's going to be less assistant principals, less counselors and in some districts it's going to be larger classes," said Noreen Connell, the panel's executive director.
She warned that some poor districts will be forced to channel Federal and state money for remedial education into standard classroom services. That, she said, would not only be a violation of government regulations but would deprive the districts of the extra reading and mathematics tutoring the children need.
 
Fitting the Formula
 The difference in how districts have been responding to their allocations, which are determined by a set formula, may have something to do with different factors the districts face. Districts that had few teacher retirements this year -- and thus did not hire many low-salaried novice teachers -- are suddenly finding they have to use the same pool of money to meet a more expensive payroll.
Districts that have had greater than anticipated enrollment increases have to staff more classes with the same instructional budget. Districts that have lost enrollment may find their budget cut from the levels of the previous year.
Mr. Fernandez wrote the superintendents yesterday that "although our stated objective was to eliminate any further budget cuts, we could not nor did we guarantee that result."
The agreement with the city, he said, will eventually provide the school system with over $400 million in new revenues and accruals from previous years that it had never been allowed to count before. But for the present even that sum "is insufficient to keep the board's budget intact."
 
Fernandez Promises Help
 Mr. Fernandez promised to have experts from his staff help superintendents find ways of minimizing the pain, although many superintendents warned that students would feel pain.
