HEADLINE: Beijing Journal;
No Praise, Please! He Wants to Be the Premier

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Of all the names being bandied about these days as potential prime ministers, one evokes a special tingle -- depending on your vantage point -- of either hope or horror.
Zhu Rongji, a former rightist who has spent more years in disgrace than in power, is the fastest-rising star in China's political firmament. But Mr. Zhu, a fluent English-speaker and aggressive advocate of economic change, faces a horrendous image problem within the party leadership: admirers abroad have affectionately dubbed him "China's Gorbachev." 
 This helps Mr. Zhu about as much as it would benefit President Bush for China's hard-liners to hail him as "America's Mao Zedong."
"You're not going to write a story saying how great Zhu Rongji is, are you?" a Chinese official who likes Mr. Zhu asked reproachfully. "Because whenever there's an article like that, he gets whacked politically."
 
Specter of Gorbachev
 Vice President Wang Zhen, an acid-mouthed octogenarian who peppers his conversations with village expletives, is said to have warned colleagues last year that "there is a Gorbachev sleeping beside us." Mr. Wang did not mention any names, but that's the kind of comment that would have Politburo members craning their necks to look at Mr. Zhu.
Still, the 63-year-old Mr. Zhu (whose name is pronounced joo rong jee) has managed to survive both the attacks and the compliments. In his spacious, air-conditioned second-floor office, just inside the north gate of China's park-like leadership compound of Zhongnanhai, Mr. Zhu has amassed prestige and authority along with the calligraphy that he hangs on the wall.
Named a Deputy Prime Minister last year, Mr. Zhu is one of several contenders hoping to replace Prime Minister Li Peng when his five-year term expires early next year. It is unclear, however, if the position will be vacant; Mr. Li is a skilled tactician who is fighting for a second term.
"Zhu Rongji is doing really well right now," said a family member of a top official. "But in China, the better things look for you, the worse your prospects really are. It's the bird in front of the flock that gets shot."
Some officials say the present fragile consensus at Beidaihe, the beach resort where China's elderly leaders are playing bridge and deciding the nation's future, is to allow Mr. Li to retain the post of Prime Minister. But they say that even according to this plan, Mr. Zhu would become first deputy prime minister in charge of the economy, so that he would be breathing down Mr. Li's neck.
"Even if Zhu Rongji isn't made Prime Minister, it may not matter so much," said a party member who has discussed policy with Mr. Zhu. "Because in any case, he'll be in charge of economic policy."
When summoned to Beijing last year from his previous post as Shanghai's Mayor, Mr. Zhu was given the task of unsnarling endless debt chains among state-owned companies. Partly because he was more successful than most people expected, he was named head of a new department called the Economic and Trade Office. It is emerging as a super-ministry with overall responsibility for managing the economy.
 
Nominal and Real Power
 Officials say that a deal has been struck for Mr. Zhu to vault onto the Politburo's standing committee, the nation's top policy-making body. It is exceeded in authority only by the so-called sitting committee of octogenarians who are nominally retired but continue to hold ultimate power.
The key to Mr. Zhu's success is that Deng Xiaoping, the nation's 87-year-old senior leader, is acting as his campaign manager. Mr. Deng has gone out of his way to praise Mr. Zhu's understanding of economics.
Mr. Zhu is disliked not only by some hard-liners, however, but also by many midlevel and senior officials. They find him a terror to work for. Extremely demanding, Mr. Zhu scolds people publicly in a society where it is considered more polite to stab them in the back.
"Some comrades are kind of muddled, and even when you point out some problems they figure they're in the right," Mr. Zhu said in a recent confidential speech, defending his style. "Even their self-criticisms are superficial. So then you've got to criticize those laggards by name.
"I also encourage everyone to criticize me," Mr. Zhu added in the speech, parts of which appeared in a restricted-circulation publication for party officials. "A couple of times, the criticisms were pretty nasty, and they weren't entirely fair. But I listened. Whether or not the complaints are correct, it's good for them to let off steam."
Mr. Zhu still speaks Chinese with a trace of a Hunan Province accent, reflecting his childhood there, but he studied electrical engineering at Qinghua University in Beijing and has spent most of his life in the capital. He took up Mao's invitation in 1956 to offer the party constructive criticisms, and a year later he fell victim, along with others who spoke out, to the "anti-rightist campaign."
By a fluke he escaped with extremely lenient punishment: he was allowed to hold on to a job in the central Government, but in disgrace. In 1978, when Mr. Deng came to power, Mr. Zhu was rehabilitated and climbed onto the fast track.
 
An Embarrassing Encounter
 While many Chinese believe that Mr. Zhu is different from other leaders, the last thing he wants is for this to be pointed out. When he once found himself seated beside an American correspondent at a dinner, he studied the reporter's name card and then asked accusingly, "Weren't you the one who wrote that article?"
The journalist asked if he meant an article that had appeared 10 months earlier, reporting that Chinese like Mr. Zhu much more than other leaders. "Yes, that article," Mr. Zhu said coolly, and he switched to English and quoted the headline word for word.
When the reporter acknowledged writing the article, Mr. Zhu paused for a moment in horror, and then pivoted. For the rest of the dinner he engaged in conversation exclusively with the person on his other side.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Zhu Rongji, a former rightist who has spent more years in disgrace than in power, is China's fastest-rising political star. He is one of several contenders hoping to replace Prime Minister Li Peng when his term expires next year. Mr. Zhu, left, spoke at a meeting about transportation problems in Beijing. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Jet Sales to Saudis and Taiwan Weighed

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
With thousands of military industry jobs at stake in states like Ohio and California, the Bush Administration is poised to approve multibillion-dollar sales of fighter jets to Saudi Arabia and Taiwan that it once opposed or considered too controversial to pursue immediately, Administration officials say.
Under pressure to help the ailing military industry, the Administration in recent weeks has also dropped its longstanding opposition to spending $1.5 billion on the V-22 Osprey aircraft, which is being developed in Texas and Pennsylvania, and rescinded a Federal rule that hindered contractors seeking to convert military technology to nonmilitary uses. 
 The actions mark a significant shift by the Administration. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has tried to soften the impact of the end of the cold war for members of the armed services, but he has said the Pentagon is not a "social welfare agency" for workers in the military industry.
Administration officials say their recent decisions are not motivated by election-year politics, but they acknowledge that continuing military production in states with a lot of electoral votes is politically popular during a recession.
"The jobs argument has never been more powerful than it is now, with the economy the way it is," said one Defense Department official.
Indeed, the Administration has in recent months affirmed a directive to United States embassy workers to help American military contractors with their sales. The contractors had complained that diplomats helped other American businesses dealing abroad but not their industry.
 
Promoting Sales
 "Word has gotten around the overseas establishment that Washington is appreciative of efforts to promote military sales as well as commercial sales," said Joel L. Johnson, an official of the Aerospace Industries Association, an industry group.
The Administration's two most significant decisions involve a proposed $5 billion sale of 72 F-15 fighter planes to Saudi Arabia and a proposed $4 billion sale of about 150 F-16's to Taiwan.
Senior Administration officials say that Washington is still considering the merits and timing of both sales. "There has been no decision made" about the Saudi sale, Acting Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said in an interview on Thursday.
But other Administration officials, as well as military industry officials, lawmakers and senior Congressional aides familiar with the arms sales, say that the Administration is leaning in favor of both deals.
 
Worry About Peace Talks
 The question of whether to sell the F-15's to Saudi Arabia dates to early this year, when the Saudis formally asked to buy 48 F-15E and 24 F-15H planes.
The F-15E, an advanced air-to-ground version of the F-15, was used by the Air Force in the Persian Gulf war to attack Iraqi targets on the ground. The F-15H is a two-seat version of the F-15. But industry officials said the Saudi sale would probably involve 72 F-15S's, a version of the F-15E with less capable radar.
The Administration was cool to the Saudi request, although it supported the sale to a valued ally. The State Department did not want to jeopardize the incipient Middle East peace talks. Washington was negotiating to provide loan guarantees to Israel if Israel froze construction of Jewish settlements in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
Since then, however, the sale's chances have improved: Several aerospace companies, union officials and Congressional supporters of the sale mounted a major lobbying effort. A new government in Israel reached agreement with Washington on the loan guarantees, and the peace talks, which resumed here today, appear able to withstand a controversy over arms sales. And in the United States, at least for now, concerns over arms proliferation in the Middle East have given way to domestic worries.
 
20,000 Jobs at Stake
 McDonnell Douglas, the St. Louis contractor that builds the F-15, has no new orders for the plane beyond the 45 that will be delivered to the United States Air Force beginning in 1994. Unless the Saudi sale is approved, the company says its production line will close. McDonnell Douglas officials said 1,000 workers have already been laid off as F-15 production declines and commercial aircraft orders dip.
The officials say as many as 20,000 aerospace jobs could be lost, including those of subcontractors in Connecticut and Southern California, by early next year if the Administration does not approve the Saudi sale this summer.
Congress reviews all proposed arms deals and can reject them. In the past, some Democrats with military plants in their districts opposed arms sales to the Middle East, but many now support the deals to help employment at home.
To take advantage of this sentiment before the November elections and to complete the Congressional review before lawmakers recess in October, the Administration needs to notify Congress of the sales in the next week or so, Congressional aides said.
Opponents of the Saudi sale concede that Mr. Bush has enough votes in Congress to allow the sale to go through. "In a tough economy, the sale would be tougher to block," said Representative Mel Levine, a California Democrat who is a leading opponent of arms sales to the Arab countries.
 
Surprise at Taiwan Deal
 The Administration's reconsideration of selling F-16's to Taiwan took many industry and Congressional officials by surprise. Mr. Bush said in an interview by a network of Texas radio stations on July 30 that the United States was re-examining the sale of F-16's, built by the General Dynamics Corporation in Fort Worth.
General Dynamics, which has already announced that 5,800 jobs would be cut by 1994 because of declining F-16 production, said 3,000 jobs could be saved if the Taiwan sale was approved. Subcontractors, particularly in Ohio and Maryland, would also save several thousand jobs, company officials said.
Unlike the Saudi sale, the F-16 sale would face virtually no opposition from Democrats or Republicans in Congress, lawmakers said, even though the Administration would be reversing a 10-year policy against selling warplanes to Taiwan. In 1978, 29 years after the Nationalist Chinese government fled from the mainland to Taiwan, the United States recognized the government in Beijing as the legitimate Chinese government, and four years later it agreed to phase out arms sales to Taiwan.
Selling F-16's to Taiwan could jeopardize American relations with China, which has bought Russian-built Su-27 fighters. But most Congressional officials said Mr. Bush's close ties with Beijing would survive the sale to Taiwan, which wants to replace its aging fleet of American-built F-5E's and old F-104's.
As an American official familiar with both the Taiwan and Saudi sales said, "The driver of this is the politics and economics of it, not the national security issue."

HEADLINE: Gold Bar Journal;
An Espresso Rush in the Northwest

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GOLD BAR, Wash., Aug. 19

 BODY:
In the beginning there was just coffee, black or with cream. About 35 cents a cup. Refills free. And the finest cup of joe in the land came from the timber towns of the Cascade Mountains, or so went the legend that grew with the television series "Twin Peaks."
But caffeine is not so simple anymore in this valley cut by the cold flow of the Skykomish River, about 50 miles northeast of Seattle. Only a handful of cafes remain where waitresses call everybody Sweetie and pour the old-fashioned bottomless cup. 
 In its place is the snort of loggers and backpackers alike: espresso. In this valley alone, there are 14 espresso outlets, including at least four drive-though booths. Perhaps only bungee-jumping, advertised from cranes along the edge of the road, has made for a more startling addition to the roadside attractions of United States Highway 2.
This development may not affect family values or the cost of a 2-by-4, but it surely says something about rural America.
In the town of Sultan, just a few miles west of here, men with chainsaws in the front seats of their cars and missing fingers used to plant themselves in the Dutch Gap Restaurant to drink coffee by the quart before venturing out for a day's work in the woods.
No more. In February, a drive-through espresso booth opened up across the street from the Dutch Gap -- the third such espresso stand in town to open within the last year. The Coop 'n' Cone Kitchen and a gas station had also added espresso to their respective menus of fried chicken and unleaded gasoline.
Within a month, people started getting hooked on shots of steam-processed coffee, for $1.65 a pop. By this summer, Scott Jeffries was selling up to 300 drinks a day from his booth.
"It's an addiction," said Mr. Jeffries, "and I'm a legal pusher."
This week, on a typical morning, there was a line of pickup trucks outside the Sultan drive-through espresso booth while the Dutch Gap was largely empty. Sullen-faced men in baseball hats ordered from a menu with a dozen variations on espresso.
They could choose from lattes (pronounced LAH-tay), a blend of expresso and steamed milk), single or double, caffeinated or decaffeinated, iced or hot, with fat or low-fat milk, and a bewildering assortment of cappuccinos and cafe mochas -- or simply plain espresso.
"It's gotten to the point where some people come through for three of them a day," said Mr. Jeffries. "They say if they go too long without a latte, they get a headache."
Just a few miles north of here, a similar pattern has taken hold in the town of Granite Falls, another hamlet built by loggers and miners in the era when brawniness was king. The True Value hardware store added a bright copper $5,000 Italian espresso machine last year, setting up shop amidst the bins of galvanized nails and drill bits. Soon enough, as many people were coming in for espresso as they were for hardware.
The Pacific Northwest is fast becoming known as a sort of "latte-land," as Jean Godden, a columnist for The Seattle Times, calls it. About five years ago, the first few espresso stands started appearing on Seattle streets. Now, there is a booth on virtually every downtown corner.
But few people ever thought the fever for steamed milk and high-potency coffee would spread to the tough-guy timber towns of the Cascades.
The economics, from the seller's point of view, may be one thing driving the expansion. It costs between $5,000 and $10,000 for a good multiple-spigot espresso machine. But after the machine is paid for, the profits pour in. Espresso vendors, once thought of as poor, suffering souls who sat in the rain, find they can make up to $150,000 a year on a single stand.
But that does not explain why so many people, from all walks of life, would give up the ancient routine of slow-sipping coffee in the morning for the blast-hit effect of espresso.
In this valley, the icons have fallen fast. Zeke's Drive-In, a semi-world-famous burger joint just north of Gold Bar, is the latest drive-in to add espresso. Now, it outsells the huckleberry milkshakes. The waitresses attribute espresso's lure to the stepped-up pace of American life, even on the back roads.
"Everybody just wants 'em to go," said Dana Goodwin, who works the window at Zeke's. "We hardly sell any plain old cups of coffee anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Drive-through espresso stands are a startling addition to the back roads of the Cascade Mountains. A motorist picked up a steam-processed jolt of caffeine at a booth in Sultan, Wash. (Therese Frare for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Rochester's model health care system is being studied by the G.A.O. for a report to Congress. Close cooperation -- in contrast to fierce competition nationally -- among physicians, hospitals and local businesses, has kept medical costs 25 percent lower per capita than national levels, and most people are insured. The city's doctors are conservative in medical practice. [Page A1.]
Five diet companies petitioned the F.T.C. to set standards and regulations for fair advertising in the $33 billion industry, which has been under Federal investigation. Critics called the petition a delaying tactic. The companies are Jenny Craig, NutriSystem, Physician's Weight Loss, Diet Center and Weight Watchers. [D1.]
 
International
The dollar plunged 2 percent against the German mark, to a new low of 1.4015, despite central bank intervention. The mark is attractive because of high German interest rates. [D1.] 
Japan is working to develop extremely fast computers that can mimic the human brain, understand speech and interpret facial expressions and gestures. [C1.]
 
Companies
T.W.A. said it had an agreement in principle for employee ownership. The deal could give the carrier, which has been losing almost $1 million a day, a new lease on life. [D1.]
Eastman Kodak will introduce its Photo CD system in professional versions today. The system allows pictures taken with conventional cameras to be recorded on optical compact disks in digital form, for later display on television sets and computer terminals or transmission over telephone lines. [D4.]
Maytag said its earnings would drop one-third from the $24.2 million it reported a year ago, and that it would reorganize its North American and European operations. [D4.]

Northwest Airlines is selling Capitol Records' compact disks and cassettes through an in-flight service called the World Record Shop, a joint marketing venture. [D4.]
 
Markets
Stock prices retreated around the world because of the dollar's sharp fall. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 25.93 points, to 3,228.17. Major indexes fell more than 2 percent in London, Paris, Zurich and Hong Kong, and 1.3 percent in Frankfurt. [D6.]
Global credit markets were also shaken by the dollar's fall. In America several big municipal issues were halted because of chaos in the Treasury markets. [D13.]
Gold prices climbed as the dollar fell, reaching $341.60 an ounce, up $4.30, on the Comex. [D14.] Energy futures prices surged, as Hurricane Andrew pushed into the Gulf of Mexico, threatening offshore drilling platforms. [D14.]

A year of losses for property insurers is likely to worsen, as a result of the damage wreaked by the hurricane. But the losses are not expected to lead to a rate rise. Market Place. [D1.]
Rising costs of employee benefits, notably health care, are leading many employers to cut payrolls but not overtime, for which the cost is less than hiring new workers. Business Scene. [D2.]

NEW YORK CITY
 
MOTHER INDICTED IN DAUGHTER'S KILLING
A 68-year-old Queens woman who said she shot her crack-addicted daughter to death after enduring years of lies, thefts and threatening demands for money has been indicted on manslaughter charges. But by declining to bring the most serious charge, murder, the grand jury has opened the way for a possible plea bargain that would allow her to avoid prison. A1.
 
Indictment reflects a growing tendency to recognize strain of crime, experts say. B3.
 
NEW INCINERATOR SEEN AS LIKELY
Mayor Dinkins is virtually assured of prevailing ultimately in the City Council on his long-term garbage-disposal plan, which includes building a new incinerator in Brooklyn, two senior Council staff members say. The Mayor and the Speaker have enough votes to succeed, they said, because even if a majority on the Council should reject the plan tomorrow, the opponents do not have enough votes to override a mayoral veto of that action. B3.
 
ACCESS TO COURTROOM SOUGHT
Opponents in the Woody Allen-Mia Farrow child-custody case have actually agreed on something as lawyers for both sides joined in trying to keep television cameras out of the courtroom. In a legal argument pitting public access to information against the children's right to privacy, lawyers for Mr. Allen and Ms. Farrow argued that the case involved potentially damaging evidence that should not be disclosed. But a lawyer for the New York Broadcasters Pool, a media professional group that sought access to the proceedings on behalf of Court TV, said it was already too late for that. The judge denied access to cameras for a hearing today, but did not rule on the possibility of future televised hearings. B3.

HEADLINE: Citing Budget Shortfall, Moody's Lowers Rating on Trenton's Debt

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Citing shortfalls in the New Jersey budget, Moody's Investors Service downgraded the state's credit rating today, moving it from Aaa, the top class, to Aa1, the second highest.
The downgrading means the state will have to pay higher interest rates when it sells bonds to finance public works. New Jersey has more than $3.3 billion in general obligation debt outstanding, and more than $5 billion in total tax-supported debt. 
 Gov. Jim Florio said that he was disappointed by Moody's decision, but he said New Jersey still had the best rating in the Northeast.
Moody's said that since the 1988-89 fiscal year, economic forces have hurt the state's "once-substantial" surplus and projected "a sizable budget gap requiring resolution in fiscal 1994."
"Fiscal 1993 revenues and spending assumptions appear vulnerable to the same recessionary forces as those which undermined prior years' results," the New York firm said in a statement.
 
Larger Gap in 1994
 Both Governor Florio and State Treasurer Samuel F. Crane blamed the Republican-controlled Legislature for contributing to the lowered bond rating. They said the Republicans' decision to roll back the sales tax from 7 percent to 6 percent had cost the state $608 million in revenue and a budget adopted last month that cut $1.1 billion from Governor's proposed budget had further weakened confidsence.
"Clearly the state would have been in a stronger fiscal position if the Legislature hadn't removed $600 million in revenue," Mr. Crane said in a statement that was issued tonight.
Mr. Florio said his administration would do "everything possible to create jobs and to fight the effects of a bad deal" that he said the Republican budget gave the state.
The state's $14.6 billion budget for the 1993 fiscal year took effect July 1.
There have been projections of a $1.7 billion deficit in the 1994 budget, which begins next July 1. The Republican leadership, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco and Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, have concurred with that projection and have said they will begin working on the 1994 budget within the next several weeks. Both men were unavailable for comment tonight.
The current budget includes no capital projects for which bonds would normally be issued.
The downgrading by Moody's follows a similar action last year by Standard & Poor's, another Wall Street rating firm.

LENGTH: 1827 words

HEADLINE: Immigrants Swindle Their Own, Preying on Trust;
Race, Religion and Ethnic Background Give Con Artists an Inside Track to Victims

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
When Satya Paul Gupta sold his share in a gas station in Mount Kisco, N.Y., he knew exactly what to do with the $80,000 he netted. He turned every penny over to Deepak Gulati, a compatriot featured as an expert on the "You and Your Money" segment of a television program aimed at New York's Indian immigrants.
Mr. Gupta, who is 58 years old, said he had "greedy faith" that his life savings would be safe with a fellow Indian, particularly the soft-spoken television celebrity with an office on Madison Avenue and an offer of what amounted to 12 percent yearly interest on four-month promissory notes, or I.O.U.'s. 
 But he was mistaken. Unbeknownst to Mr. Gupta, he was buying into a modern version of what Government investigators call an affinity scheme, where crooks and victims are linked by religion, race or ethnicity. Swindling fellow immigrants is an age-old American phenomenon, but recent fraud schemes have made wide use of media geared toward immigrants. With new foreign-language cable TV shows, newspapers and Yellow Pages, immigrant swindlers can reach a wider pool of potential investors, thus rising to an ever grander level of financial chicanery.
In the last five years, the Securities and Exchange Commission has investigated seven fraud schemes involving immigrants lured by one of their own into a fraudulent American dream. Swindlers have targeted Indians (twice), Poles (twice), Salvadorans, Chinese and Vietnamese, and investor groups have lost from $1 million to $34 million.
"The numbers are mind-boggling," said Jeffrey R. Zuckerman, an S.E.C. lawyer in New York.
Mr. Gulati, a 43-year-old native of New Delhi, pleaded guilty last month to defrauding fellow immigrants of at least $3.2 million. Federal prosecutors say that about 100 Indian and Pakistani investors, including Mr. Gupta, had bought his 12 percent promissory notes, which were not registered, insured or backed by collateral. In a classic Ponzi, or pyramid, scheme, Mr. Gulati continually used proceeds from new investors to pay interest to earlier investors. In such schemes, the pyramid usually collapses when the pool of new investors dries up, or when the swindler is caught.
 
'My Greedy Faith'
 "He was of our kind, and he wouldn't cheat us, or so I thought," said Mr. Gupta, who lives in Sunnyside, Queens. "But I was a damn fool, and now my wife is cussing me. After 35 years of hard work in this country, we may have lost everything because of my greedy faith in Deepak Gulati."
Mr. Gulati did not return telephone calls to his office and home.
The original Ponzi artist, Carlo Ponzi, engineered one of the first truly ambitious affinity schemes of the 20th century. In the early 1920's in Boston, Mr. Ponzi targeted his fellow Italian immigrants, including his own family members, his parish priest and players at a local boccie court. Eventually reaching beyond Italian immigrants, Mr. Ponzi persuaded some 20,000 investors to give him about $10 million before his scheme collapsed and he was jailed. He died a 66-year-old pauper in Rio de Janeiro in 1949.
 
Confidence Games And New Arrivals
 Forty-three years after Mr. Ponzi's death, a diverse group of schemers is following in his footsteps, preying on the trust of newcomers to the country.
Early last year, in the largest recent case, about 1,200 Eastern European immigrants, most of them Polish, lost $34 million in a Ponzi scheme in New York run by Eugene R. Karczewski, a prominent Polish businessman in Brooklyn, and his son, Eugene Jr., Federal prosecutors said. Last month, the father was sentenced to five years in prison and the son to three years. The Karczewskis, who claim they are now virtually broke, were also fined $15 million and ordered to pay back the immigrants they cheated. Many of them lost their life savings after falling for advertisements on Polish television programs that promised 14 percent interest on investments supposedly secured by mortgages.
"As the economy gets tighter, those on the margin, like immigrants, tend to be more susceptible to deals that are just too good to be true," said William R. McLucas, director of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division in Washington. "My sense is that there's been a definite increase in the volume of fraud based on religious, racial and ethnic identification."
Immigrants are particularly vulnerable because they are often uncomfortable with mainstream American banks and unaware of investment services, authorities said. And illegal immigrants are the most easily conned -- and the most likely to lose everything.
In Washington, D.C., Salvadoran immigrants, many of them illegal, lost more than $7 million by handing over their savings to the Latin Investment Corporation. Latin Investment promoted itself as a bank in the Spanish-language Yellow Pages, S.E.C. officials said. Salvadoran immigrants appreciated the ease of doing their banking in Spanish, without having to supply Social Security numbers.
 
$2 Million Is Misappropriated
 What they did not know was that their bank was neither licensed nor insured. They also did not know that the Salvadoran owner, Fernando Leonzo, and his associates had misappropriated $2 million to buy themselves houses in the suburbs and finance personal businesses, S.E.C. officials said.
Unlike the Salvadorans in Washington, the Indians who entrusted their money to Mr. Gulati were legal immigrants and, for the most part, professionals. But that did not make them more resistant to a con.
"We are a first-generation immigrant community, and people feel safer within the confines of the community," said John Perry, editor of News India, a weekly published in Manhattan. "Had a sales pitch similar to Gulati's come from an American native, we would have been more naturally suspicious."
Mr. Gulati appeared every other weekend on "Vision of Asia," a variety program on WNJU-TV, Channel 47, widely watched by Indian and Pakistani immigrants. With a master's degree in business administration from the University of Chicago, Mr. Gulati was the featured financial expert during a segment called "You and Your Money." Although Mr. Gulati paid for his time on the air, the segment was never identified as a commercial, investors said. Mr. Gulati did, however, ask viewers to call (800) DGULATI to make reservations for the free seminars he was holding at Indian restaurants in the metropolitan area.
"When it comes right into your living room, you tend to accept it as the truth," Mr. Gupta said. "I swear by God if I had not seen that guy every week on the TV -- if I had just received a letter in the mail -- I never would have trusted him."
Deepak Viswanath, the producer of "Vision of Asia" could not be reached for comment.
 
Feeling the Sting Of a Swindle
 Even a business school professor in Manhattan fell for Mr. Gulati's pitch, investing $10,000 in the 12 percent notes.
"I usually approach things with a certain method," the professor said. "But because he was Indian -- it influenced me. It made me not think about things I'd usually think of, given my profession. Being swindled like this makes me feel rather stupid."
Like most investors who were interviewed, he spoke on the condition of anonymity.
In "Dear Client" letters, Mr. Gulati solicited investments, ranging from $5,000 to $100,000, in notes that were "fully secured, collateralized and guaranteed." In meetings, he told clients that $150 in "liquid assets" backed every $100 invested in the notes, and that every account was insured to $500,000 by the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, an insurance program run by the securities industry. Those claims were false, S.E.C. officials said.
Mr. Gulati admitted to a former employee, Ravi Murarka, that there was no collateral. "Gulati gave me a lecture on greed, fear and how Wall Street 'really' works, and explained that 'everybody' on Wall Street steals," Mr. Murarka told investigators.
 
Using the Proceeds To Cover Mistakes
 Mr. Gulati also told Mr. Murarka that he used proceeds from the notes to "finance his mistakes" in other business ventures. S.E.C. officials said that Mr. Gulati poured profits from the notes into a business he owned, Digitech International, which sells telephone voice scramblers, tie-clip microphones, and other spy equipment.
Mr. Gulati, who falsely told investors he had worked for Merrill Lynch, promised that investments would be returned after four months unless a rollover, or reinvestment, was requested, former employees said. But investments were usually automatically rolled over, the employees said. Few clients demanded their money back because they were receiving their interest payments. When clients did try to reclaim their principal investment, Mr. Gulati instructed his salesmen to pressure them to remain. If that failed, he ordered the salesmen to redouble their efforts to sell the 12 percent notes, the former employees said.
When the S.E.C. froze Gulati & Associates' assets in February, the company owed investors $1.9 million. It had $17,000 on deposit at Citibank.
Mr. Gulati's scheme also involved the fraudulent sale of $1.3 million in shares in a limited partnership called Telecommunications Security Associates, the S.E.C. said.
"I believe he was a very good con man, never really overdoing it, always very reassuring" said a pediatrician who lost $50,000. "Myself, I'm very badly burned. But I almost forgot my own troubles when I spoke to an elderly woman who lost her whole life savings and is very, very depressed."
 
Defrauded Investors Make Their Claims
 Mr. Gulati, who lives on the Upper East Side, faces up to 5 years in prison when he is sentenced Oct. 14 in Federal District Court in Manhattan. He has already been ordered to repay $3.2 million and pay penalties of $5.7 million in a judgment won by the S.E.C.
The S.E.C. is trying to seize Digitech's inventory, estimated at about $800,000, to pay back defrauded investors. But the State Bank of India, which gave Mr. Gulati a $1 million line of credit starting in 1987, also claims the inventory as collateral. Mr. Gulati still owes the bank about $700,000, Federal prosecutors said. Prosecutors charged him with obtaining the credit by filing false documents, including lies about his net worth.
"He has definitely taken down some families," said Mr. Perry, the New India editor. "Others have lost the money for the college tuition of their children and the forthcoming marriages of their daughters."
Many investors believed that American regulatory agencies would be too vigilant to let something like this happen.
"In India, you certainly cannot do all these crook things, and still drive a Cadillac," Mr. Gupta said.
Mr. Gupta had intended to retire in India, where his $80,000, plus interest, would allow him to "live like a king."
Now he does not know what he will do. "I'm just out of luck," he said. "I don't have a pension. I don't even have life insurance."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. Staff to Pay for Part of Health Benefits

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 24

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said today that as a cost-control measure, it would require white-collar workers to pay part of their health insurance.
The plan, which marks the first time the company has asked its employees to chip in for health care coverage, could be in place by Jan. 1. 
 "The new salaried employee plan will be, generally speaking, a flex plan and will provide coverage for routine, preventative and catastrophic health care, comparable to the level salaried employees or retirees have now," a spokesman said. But the level of deductibles and co-payments will also rise under the plan, which affects about 100,000 salaried employees and 90,000 retirees.
The spokesman declined to say how much GM would save by adopting the plan -- other than to say the savings will be significant -- or how much money each employee would have to pay for health care benefits. But he said monthly premiums would depend on the number of dependents and options.
He said the change pertained only to white-collar workers, retirees and their dependents in the United States. But G.M. is expected to discuss the issue with the United Auto Workers union in contract talks next year.
Last year G.M. spent $3.4 billion on health benefits -- an amount equal to $929 on every car sold in the United States.
The new plan will also allow employees to select different types of health care services, such as health maintenance organizations, which are less expensive than traditional plans but restrict services to a select group of medical staff.
Rising health-insurance costs have become a major source of strife between unions and management. In 1989, Three-fourths of all strikes involved worker objections to paying a larger share of insurance premiums.
In the 1970's, spending for medical care rose rapidly but was not out of line with inflation in other goods and services. In the 1980's, inflation cooled, but health care costs kept climbing and insurance premiums skyrocketed.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Calm After the Storm Seen for Insurance Rates

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
After battering South Florida with the fiercest blows of any storm in 35 years and now taking aim at the Texas-Louisiana Gulf Coast, Hurricane Andrew is likely to make a bad year of losses worse for many property insurers.
But analysts say the damages would have to be extraordinarily high to cause the insurance industry to raise rates substantially, possibly buoying their stocks. 
 The stocks of most property and casualty insurance companies slumped yesterday amid a weak bond market and fears that Andrew's legacy could push industry claim payouts near the record level of more than $7 billion set in 1989. That was the year of Hurricane Hugo, for which companies paid out $4.2 billion in claims, and the San Francisco earthquake, for which $1 billion was paid.
 
Catastrophes This Year
 In the first six months of this year, insured losses from damaging hailstorms in Texas, Kansas and Florida, the Los Angeles riots, the downtown Chicago flood and other catastrophic losses amounted to $3.7 billion, according to Property Claim Services, an industry trade group in Rahway, N.J.
But analysts say it is too early to make estimates on damage to South Florida and that Hurricane Andrew's toll would have to be far greater than from Hurricane Hugo to spur industry executives into raising rates substantially.
A rise in rates this year would end what has been an unusually long period of more than five years of gradual price reductions in commercial insurance rates. The previous "down" cycle for rates lasted from 1979 to 1984.
 
Pain Before a Rise
 "You need some pain before the industry is going to raise rates," said Gloria L. Vogel, insurance analyst at Lehman Brothers. "Clearly, a hurricane means additional losses for these companies. If it's enough to change psychology in the industry, it will be the catalyst that turns things around for the long term. But that remains to be seen."
But Thomas V. Cholnoky, insurance analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, thinks it will take more than one bad storm for rates to rise.
"I don't think the hurricane in itself is enough to turn the cycle," he said. "This bad news won't be bad enough."
He said investor hopes for rate increases could push the prices of insurance stocks higher in coming weeks after the full range of Hurricane Andrew's devastation is known. That happened late in 1989 after Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco earthquake struck.
"But when the realization set in that nothing was happening with pricing, the stocks gave back their gains, if not more," Mr. Cholnoky said.
Michael Frinquelli, insurance analyst at Salomon Brothers, said prospects for any lasting, significant change in stock values of property and casualty insurers for the next six to 12 months were "dull."
Stocks of property and casualty insurers have outperformed the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index in six of eight months so far this year, even though first-half profits lagged behind the period in 1991. Cigna, for example, said insurance losses more than tripled in the first six months this year from the period last year; at Safeco, weather-related payouts nearly doubled.
Yet in the stock market, the industry lost ground only in April and May amid concerns about the Los Angeles riots, with insured losses estimated near $1 billion.
The bond market, which rose in value earlier this year as interest rates descended through the year, explains much of Wall Street's moderately solid appetite for insurance stocks despite lower earnings. About 75 percent of the industry's assets are invested in bonds, and those values have risen handsomely.
Moreover, the sluggish economy has brought some relief for insurers from a slowdown in auto crashes, construction injuries and other high-volume staples of property and casualty underwritings, said Mr. Frinquelli of Salomon Brothers Inc.
Some of the biggest price gains posted in the industry this year through last Friday include US F& G, up 76 percent, to $12.75; Mercury General, up 55 percent, at $47.125; Geico, up 44 percent, to $57.50, and Cincinnati Financial, up 37 percent, to $49.25.
"If interest rates go down further, the industry's wealth will build faster and the market may respond to that," Mr. Frinquelli said. "But the market will react most positively when premium rates start rising. We simply now see no near-term prospect of that. The industry has too much capital."
In yesterday's trading, Geico fell 37.5 cents, to $47.125; Cincinnati Financial dropped 75 cents, to $48.50; Mercury General lost 87.5 cents, to $46.25, and USF & G lost 87.5 cents, to $11.875.
Ms. Vogel of Lehman Brothers said that insurers with the biggest exposure to losses in South Florida included State Farm, Cigna, Travelers and Allstate, a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company. State Farm, for instance, has 23 percent of the home insurance market in Florida.
Shares of Cigna lost 62.5 cents yesterday, closing at $51; Travelers dropped 50 cents, to $20.625, and Sears lost 12.5 cents, to $41.375. State Farm is a mutual company and does not have publicly traded stock.
Charles B. Gates of the First Boston Corporation said that if huge losses from Hurricane Andrew began a spate of rising rates for commercial lines, the shares of Marsh & McLennan, the world's largest insurance broker, would benefit.
Profitability and dividend yield at Marsh & McLennan easily exceed market averages, and the firm's consulting arm would help earnings in an improving economy, Mr. Gates said. Marsh & McLennan shares lost $1 yesterday, to $78.25.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Tsongas Attacks Bush Plan But He's Tepid on Clinton's

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 24

 BODY:
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts came down here today to help Gov. Bill Clinton do a bit of Bush-bashing. Or so the visit was touted.
He did bash the President, calling the tax cuts and other economic proposals that Mr. Bush offered at last week's Republican convention "cynical, outrageous nonsense" and asserting that Mr. Bush had lost the will and capacity to govern. 
But by the time he had unloaded all that, Mr. Tsongas had also managed to duck, weave and drolly chuckle his way around a solid endorsement of the economic proposals offered thus far by Mr. Clinton.
"Clearly it's not my plan," Mr. Tsongas said at one point, standing next to the man who bested him in the spring primaries.
Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton differed sharply back then over tax policy, with Mr. Tsongas opposing any cuts and Mr. Clinton favoring a cut for the middle class. But after Mr. Clinton locked up the Democratic nomination, the two men made their peace and Mr. Tsongas said he would support the Governor in the fall.
He reiterated that support today, asserting that it was "staggeringly clear" that Mr. Clinton was the preferable candidate in the race. "Bill Clinton is very bright," he said.
 
Political Dance
 But what of Mr. Clinton's economic plan, asked the reporters gathered at the Governor's Mansion here.
Not to worry, Mr. Tsongas replied, predicting that Mr. Clinton would "do the right things" as President because, he said, the Governor had good instincts and, well, unlike Mr. Bush, had no White House record to defend to the dogged, wrongheaded end.
Mr. Tsongas won more than 550 delegates before dropping out of the 1992 race. With the Bush-Clinton race tightening, Mr. Clinton is likely to need all the support from Tsongas backers that he can get in the fall.
Mr. Tsongas mentioned his supporters several times today. But he kept sliding away from giving them any real guidance on what to think about the Clinton economic plan.
About the closest he came to a judgment on the plan, which includes some new job-creation proposals and, since the primaries, a scaled-back tax cut for the middle class, was to characterize it as having "movement" and "evolving" in a positive direction.
"I intend to work with Governor Clinton and to press my views upon him and the people around him," Mr. Tsongas said. "That has been the case for several months and that will continue. I'm not one who is in the position of saying, 'Well, the kinds of things I advocated are past history.' "
Was that a way of saying, a reporter asked, that the Clinton plan did not go far enough, that the Governor should move closer to Mr. Tsongas's point of view?
Mr. Tsongas did not get a chance to answer.
Mr. Clinton, who had watched all of this impassively, nipped forward to the microphone, mustered a wan smile, and declared:
"Yeah. That's a way of saying it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Bill Clinton was joined by Paul E. Tsongas at a news conference in Little Rock, Ark., criticizing President Bush's economic program. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Vice President;
New Angle In the Jabs At Clinton

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Aug. 24

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle suggested today that Gov. Bill Clinton, who has signed four death warrants, was soft on capital punishment because he had mentioned Gov. Mario M. Cuomo as a possible appointee to the Supreme Court. The New York Governor has vetoed death penalty bills in each of the 10 years he has been in office.
At the same time, Mr. Quayle said, support for the death penalty should not be a litmus test in the selection of Supreme Court Justices. But when asked at a news conference in Knoxville, Tenn., why it was then bothersome that Mr. Clinton might name a death penalty opponent to the High Court, Mr. Quayle would only say that he was trying to make a point about Mr. Clinton's consistency. 
 "His party is divided on this issue," Mr. Quayle said. "So Bill Clinton says, 'Well, I'm for capital punishment but, by the way, those of you who oppose capital punishment, be reminded that one of my first appointments would be somebody like Mario Cuomo, if not Mario Cuomo, and of course you all know that he's an outright opponent of the death penalty.' It's having it both ways. That's why he has the name Slick Willie."
George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, dismissed the comments as "just more silliness from Dan Quayle."
"Governor Clinton is the only candidate in the race who has carried out the death penalty, and Dan Quayle's just trying to create an issue where none exists," he said.
Mr. Quayle made his remarks in front of Knoxville's police academy before a backdrop of uniformed officers, a setting that has become a political advance man's cliche. His mission was to elevate crime as an issue in a campaign that has been dominated by debates on the economy and values.
The Vice President cited Justice Department statistics showing that per capita crime rates in Arkansas had increased during Mr. Clinton's tenure, and that they had increased more significantly than in the country as a whole.
Mr. Quayle also campaigned today in Newport News, where he told shipyard workers that the Democrats would "take a meat ax" to national defense.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Maytag Sees A Profit Drop In 3d Period

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Maytag Corporation, citing slack demand and intense competition, said yesterday that it expected third-quarter earnings before one-time charges to drop one-third from the $24.2 million, or 23 cents a share, of net income it reported for the period a year earlier.
To address those conditions, Maytag said it would reorganize its North American and European operations. 
 Leonard A. Hadley, president and chief executive of the Newton, Iowa, maker of home appliances, said in a statement that Maytag would take charges totaling about $95 million before taxes, or 57 cents a share after taxes. Maytag expects to recover the charge in about three years through improved profits, he added.
The company also said it would take a continuing after-tax quarterly charge of $4.5 million, plus one-time charges totaling $307 million, as it adopts, retroactive to Jan. 1, two accounting rules related to the costs of retirement benefits.
Maytag's disclosure did not sit well on Wall Street. Investors pushed down Maytag's shares almost 10 percent, or $1.375, to $12.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The reorganization is designed to streamline marketing and sales operations at a number of Maytag's most important business units, including Magic Chef, Jenn-Air and Hoover.
Maytag plans to consolidate Magic Chef's sales and marketing force into the Indianapolis headquarters of the Jenn-Air division; discontinue Jenn-Air's two-step method of selling through distributors, and pare back Hoover's European manufacturing operations.
Job cuts resulting from the reorganization will be minimal, said Maytag, which has 21 manufacturing operations in seven countries and employs 22,000 people.
Although Maytag cited generally weak economic conditions at home and abroad as a major cause of the lower earnings projection, analysts called the reorganization more a reflection on Maytag than on the state of the so-called white goods industry.
"Five to eight years ago Maytag was viewed as the premier company in this industry," said Jonathan L. Goldfarb of Merrill Lynch & Company. "But their profitability has been eroding consistently over the last couple of years. Certainly, if the economy was doing better, Maytag would be doing better. But these difficulties are much more particular to Maytag itself than the industry generally."
Indeed, after a very poor year in 1991, demand for major appliances like refrigerators, washing machines and microwaves appears to be firming. Data from the Association of Appliance Manufacturers indicate that in 1992 through July, shipments of major appliances had grown more than 6 percent from a year earlier.
A Maytag spokesman said that unit sales of major appliances had risen 3 percent to 5 percent through the first half. "Even though we are seeing sales go up, there is great pressure on profit margins," he said.
While conditions in the United States may be somewhat better, business in Europe continues to suffer.
The Hoover appliance and floor-care operations in Europe continue to lose money, Mr. Hadley said, citing excess capacity and the "unexpected further deterioration of economic conditions in the United Kingdom and other countries."
Mr. Goldfarb said that over the last few years, competitors like the General Electric Company of Fairfield, Conn., and the Whirlpool Corporation of Benton Harbor, Mich., have taken on Maytag in the margin-rich luxury-appliance category. Maytag's efforts to market lower-priced appliances have not proved terribly successful, he added.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leonard A. Hadley, president and chief executive of Maytag. (Maytag Corporation)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Congressional Race;
Oklahoma Lawmaker Faces 4 Rivals and a Scandal

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Representative Mickey Edwards plaintively folded his hands at his waist like a choir boy ready to confess as he recalled to a group of voters his 386 overdrafts at the House bank.
"If my own mother had been alive, even she would not have voted for me," Mr. Edwards, the fourth-ranking Republican in the House, said with a bittersweet grin. "My son Patrick told me, 'Now you've really screwed up.' " 
 Running neck and neck with two of four other candidates in Tuesday's Republican primary, the man who has epitomized Republican politics in Oklahoma for 16 years sought an understanding chuckle from his audience at the recent luncheon. Instead, it left him standing gamely in an unforgiving silence.
It was an awkward moment in an otherwise friendly event, where constituents nodded approvingly as Mr. Edwards listed all the military and social programs he has attracted to Oklahoma's Fifth Congressional District as a ranking member of the House Appropriations Committee.
 
A Proven Provider
 Voters in this diverse district, stretching from Oklahoma City's prosperous suburbs north through the flat wheat and oil fields to the Kansas border, are strongly opposed to Washington business as usual. But they are also uneasy about breaking with a proven provider, as shown by Mr. Edwards's climb in the polls in recent weeks, from a sure loser to a possible survivor, at least through the Sept. 15 runoff.
The primary contest has produced few policy differences between Mr. Edwards and his two principal opponents, Bill Price, a former Federal prosecutor, and State Representative Ernest Istook; all three are staunch conservatives who want to slash taxes.
Instead, the campaign has become a referendum on Congress itself. As Mr. Edwards tells voters, "I do not apologize for my incumbency," his opponents make slashing attacks on Congressional privileges and call for term limits for members of Congress.
Polls this year have suggested the complexity of voters' feelings about Congress around the country. Typically, they are disgusted with the institution for its overall performance, but they want their own representatives to protect or even expand their services.
One voter here, Ruby Wimsett, said she probably would not decide whom she would vote for in the primary until the moment she casts her ballot. As she watched five Shriners skid their dune buggies in tight figure eights in a rodeo parade in Ponca City, the 68-year-old unemployed cashier said: "I guess I think about the bank a little bit. Otherwise, I'd definitely vote for Mickey. He tries to help us."
 
'A Pig Is a Pig'
 A defining moment of the campaign came in a television debate on Aug. 14, when Mr. Istook accused Mr. Edwards of being a pork-barrel operator who drives up the Federal budget deficit.
"It's not pork," said Mr. Edwards, "if you're bringing jobs that will be created anyway and you have them in Oklahoma rather than West Virginia."
In response, Mr. Istook shot back, "A pig is a pig no matter whose pigpen it happens to be in."
Mr. Edwards's political problems began last spring, when he was identified as one of the 22 current or former House members who most abused their privileges at the now-defunct House bank. He first responded to the publicity over his 386 overdrafts by saying that he had been told he could draw against his next month's pay.
But the powerful reaction of indignation from his constituents forced him to return home for an "apology tour" of town meetings, and he has been apologizing ever since in radio and television commercials.
 
Bad Year for Incumbents
 Mr. Edwards is fortunate that reapportionment did not dismember his district, so he does not have to sell himself to new voters who have had no stake in his career.
But the national trend may be running against Mr. Edwards, as demonstrated by 16 primary defeats of House incumbents so far this year, the highest number since 1946. In a couple of cases the losses were caused by reapportionment, but the 1946 record will almost certainly be overcome by the time the primary season ends in early October.
Mr. Edwards says he cannot run away from his insider status, and the central message of his advertising campaign is: "I've always been there when you needed me. Now I need you."
The potency of his argument for reciprocity is underscored by the omnipresence of his commercials. He has the most ample campaign war chest of all the candidates, much of it provided by a local business community that appreciates Mr. Edwards's work for deregulation of the oil industry and against an automobile gasoline tax.
Both of his major opponents have held public office, but they take the approach of outsiders. They have generally preferred to attack Congress rather than Mr. Edwards directly, in part to avoid building up a sympathy vote for the incumbent.
 
'Family Values' Stessed
 As in the national campaign, both challengers have stressed "family values" in their campaign speeches and literature, hoping to win a strategic advantage over Mr. Edwards because of his well-publicized four divorces.
When Mr. Price and his wife, Mary, passed out campaign pamphlets in Oklahoma City last week, they attracted a generally positive reaction. But after meeting them, most voters spoke of Mr. Edwards as their Congressman, and said that after 16 years they have become accustomed to him.
"Mickey didn't come out well with the check scandal," sighed Donna Stroberg, a 28-year-old accountant, "But I've been over all pleased with his past performance." Then she added, "I'm not thrilled with any of the candidates."
Local Republican activists say they are concerned that a runoff could become more bitter and divisive, and open the possibility that a Democrat could win the seat in November. Seeing an opportunity, five Democrats are running in their own primary race.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 25.93 as World's Stocks Fall

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
Stock prices retreated around the world yesterday as the dollar's sharp fall spread concern about the unsettling consequences of a weakening American currency.
In the United States, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 25.93 points, to 3,228.17, and has now dropped 75 points in the last two trading sessions. Worse, major stock indexes dropped more than 2 percent yesterday in London, Paris, Zurich and Hong Kong, and 1.3 percent in Frankfurt. 
 Only in Tokyo, where the Nikkei index hit a six-year low last week, did share prices rebound, rising 2.5 percent. Gold prices climbed $4.30, to $341.60 an ounce, on the New York Commodities Exchange.
Traders and analysts expressed alarm at the diminishing price of the dollar, which fell to its third straight all-time low against the German mark yesterday. Despite renewed dollar-buying by the Federal Reserve and other central banks, the dollar fell to 1.4015 marks in New York, from Friday's close of 1.4295.
"The collapse of the dollar has unnerved market participants," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenhemier & Company. "It's mainly psychological, but it's also symptomatic of an economy that has no great vigor."
 
Shift in Funds
 The dollar's fall has been caused primarily by the yawning disparity between interest rates in the United States and Germany. This has caused investors to shift funds from dollars to marks to earn higher interest rates, and analysts do not see any near-term solution.
"There is no way to define how low the dollar can go," warned Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation. "Government policy can't stop it. Only when it burns out by itself will there be a turnaround."
Chris Bourdain, manager of foreign exchange sales at Credit Suisse New York, added : "Intervention in the current environment is not really going to help. We may have even further down to go."
For stock markets in the United States, Mr. Hoey said, the dollar's skid has eroded the high availability of cash, which had fueled the markets since last December. But he argued that the weakness in economies in Asia and Europe would, by the end of the year, make the American recovery look strong by comparison.
"Are we in a dollar crisis? You bet," he said. "Is it stoppable before it burns out? No. But will it still be dropping a year or even six months from now? I don't think so."
In London yesterday, the Financial Times Stock Exchange index of 100 issues lost 54.6 points, or 2.3 percent, to 2,311.11, as investors bet that British interest rates, now at 10 percent, would rise.
Kevin Gardiner, an economist at S. G. Warburg & Company in London, said that although the Government had tried to reassure traders that no interest rate increase was planned, some rise seemed inevitable.
In New York, the stock market's retreat was unusually broad, as declining stocks outnumbered gainers by nearly 4 to 1, with 1,490 gainers to 399 losers. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange, however, was moderate, at 166 million shares, compared with 204 million on Friday.
Insurance stocks took a beating, as Hurricane Andrew raised expectations of costly damage. American International, Cigna and Aetna each fell.
Among smaller stocks, prices dropped even more sharply. The Nasdaq composite index fell 8.31 points, or 1.5 percent, to 555.39, while the Russell index of 2,000 stocks dropped 2.52 points, to 187.48. The American Stock Exchange index fell 3.41 points, to 380.90.
The surge in gold prices was spurred at the session's opening by the decline in the dollar, said Richard McGraw, chief dealer at Credit Suisse New York. But he added that most of the day's buying came from short-sellers, who had in recent weeks and months bet that the price would fall. Since gold has dropped steadily, the short-sellers were buying yesterday to lock in their gains.
As for the stock market, some analysts view the current spreading of gloom as a sign that the bottom is near.
"Like most markets, when you get toward the perception of a one-way risk, where everyone thinks it can only go down, that means you're getting close to a turnaround," said Mr. Hoey of Dreyfus.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Gold Rises $4.50 an Ounce On Weakness of the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices climbed yesterday on the continued weakness of the dollar.
At the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose $4.30 an ounce, to $341.60. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted gold at $341.60 late yesterday, up $4.10 from Friday. 
 The dollar fell sharply again, continuing its plunge through record-low territory despite attempts by central banks to bolster its value. The dollar fell more than 4 cents against the British pound and about 3 pfennigs against the German mark.
The dollar's plunge helped push down stock and bond prices for the second straight trading day. But the falling dollar pushed gold prices higher. Because gold is quoted in dollars, when the dollar falls, gold becomes cheaper when bought with other currencies, attracting foreign buyers.
The dollar's value has dropped for much of this year amid concern about the American economy and the higher interest rates offered on investments in other countries.
Higher rates abroad mean that investments denominated in dollars earn less than if investors put their money in similar securities in other countries. That has lessened the dollar's appeal to global investors.
Dollar-buying on Friday and yesterday by many of the leading central banks, including the Federal Reserve, failed to do much to prop up the dollar.
The dollar fell to an all-time low against the German mark yesterday. In New York, one dollar bought 1.4015 marks, down from the low of 1.4315 marks that had been set on Friday. The dollar closed in London at 1.4050 marks, down from 1.4375 marks late Friday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 125.33 yen, down 1.12 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 124.65 yen. In New York, the dollar bought 124.60 yen, down from 125.75 yen late Friday.
In London, the British pound rose sharply to $1.9925, from $1.9480 late Friday. In New York, one pound cost $1.9920, up from $1.9560.
Silver prices fell in London to a late bid of $3.72 an ounce, from $3.76 late Friday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for current delivery fell to $3.712 from $3.723.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Connecticut Visit;
Hard-Hit City Gets Glimpse of Bush

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANSONIA, Conn., Aug. 24

 BODY:
President Bush came to this depressed one-time manufacturing center this afternoon, said thanks for "a great send-off" to the thousands of people who had waited hours in a sweltering stadium, and promptly left, the blades of his helicopter flattening the ball field grass in a moment of Presidential pomp.
It was the biggest thing to happen to Ansonia in a long time, yet it hardly seemed enough for the many people who have lost jobs here and have not been able to find new ones. 
 "The whole state is down because of the cutbacks in military spending," said Joe Ardito, manager of a vacuum-cleaner store here, who was having lunch today in a coffee shop called "Good Morning America." "There are a lot of people around here who are hurting. When you go by our mall, for instance, on Main Street, it's really suffering because the people are suffering. There just isn't enough money around."
Ansonia, with 18,000 people, was booming just five years ago, many people here said today, when helicopters and other military supplies were being churned out by local manufacturers like Sikorsky. It was hard to buy a house then, and prices skyrocketed. Today, prices are down, and many of the storefronts are vacant.
 
Shouts and Counter-Shouts
 Most of those in the crowd of an estimated 8,000 at Andrew F. Nolan Stadium were Bush supporters, and many held placards that proclaimed "Bush Quayle 92."
Yet, amid the cheers and cries for "Four more years" that greeted the President as he stepped from his limousine to the waiting helicopter, there were people shouting "No more Bush."
Before coming to the stadium, Mr. Bush had spoken at a fund-raising luncheon in Middlebury and to business leaders and local Republican officials in Ansonia.
At one point during the wait for Mr. Bush (he was about an hour behind schedule), a local official tried to lead a chant that consisted solely of the words "George Bush." Booing from the people who had arrived with placards that declared "We need jobs" and other slogans drowned out the chant, and the official hastily asked the high-school band to play a few more peppy songs.
"After 40 years of Republicanism, I'm a Democrat this year," said Lynda Bluestein, who moved to Fairfield, Conn., this year from Orange County, Ca., and arrived at the event with her two teen-age children.
"I'm a one-issue voter, and I'm pro-choice," she said. "I am the perfect Republican, married to a doctor and I stayed home with my children. But we can't tolerate the last four years, especially the Republican Party and it's far-right wing."
One Ansonia resident, Kathy Crotto, said she was still undecided about whom to vote for. "I think Bush is good internationally," she said, "but as far as our economy is concerned, it's pretty terrible."
 
In Democratic Territory
 But John Coscia, a retired defense worker from Ansonia, defended the President. "I think George Bush comes across as a totally honest, sincere and dedicated person," he told The Associated Press. "I don't think, listening to Clinton and Gore, that they're going to wave some magic wand and put everybody back to work."
President Bush spent just five minutes at the stadium. He cut short his Connecticut campaigning to fly to Florida to inspect the damage from Hurricane Andrew.
In 1988, Mr. Bush lost Ansonia to Michael S. Dukakis by 30 votes. Voter registration in the city is overwhelmingly Democratic, but like many Connecticut residents, people in Ansonia have no qualms about crossing party lines, especially in a Presidential year.
Outside the stadium, an unemployed couple set up their own enterprise zone in their front yard to take advantage of the crowd and the heat. "I've been out of work for six months," said Stacey Treszi, a onetime manager for a city agency who was frying hot dogs and handing out cold cans of soda with her husband, David. When someone complained about the high prices -- $1 for a soda -- she replied, "These are Bush prices."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Company to Shut Suburban Atlanta Paper

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
The New York Times Company said yesterday that it planned to close The Gwinnett Daily News, a suburban Atlanta paper that it acquired five years ago.
The offices, equipment and subscription lists of the Gwinnett County paper are to be sold to Cox Enterprises Inc., publisher of The Atlanta Journal and Constitution. 
 The asset sale, involving two large companies, is subject to a review by the Justice Department. Consequently, said Walter E. Mattson, president and chief operating officer of the Times Company, no date has yet been set for the sale.
 
Battle for the Suburbs
 The move follows a bruising competition between The Daily News and The Journal and Constitution for readers in Atlanta's affluent and rapidly growing northern suburbs.
"We are proud of the fine job performed by our employees in Gwinnett," Mr. Mattson said. "They produced an excellent newspaper and fought a tough battle against a very aggressive competitor. Unfortunately, in spite of all their efforts, the newspaper consistently lost money with no hope of reversing those losses."
The proposed sale is expected to reduce the Times Company's third-quarter earnings by about $35 million after taxes, or 45 cents a share. The Times Company issued a statement saying that because it had earlier placed a hiring freeze on its Regional Newspaper Group, it would be able to offer jobs at other newspapers in the group to many of the 290 Gwinnett employees.
"The company had the hope, which proved to be unachievable, that the market dynamics could be changed," said Peter P. Appert of C. J. Lawrence, a Wall Street brokerage firm.
From the time The New York Times Company bought The Daily News in July 1987, the paper grew quickly, almost doubling its average daily circulation to 50,589 at the end of 1991. But the paper did not achieve the financial expectations reflected in the Times Company's investment, a purchase price of $90 million plus $40 million for new offices in 1990.
The recession held down advertising sales. Growth in Gwinnett County, which had been rapid in the 1980's, started to slow.
 
Responding to Competition
 Also, The Journal and Constitution "woke up to the competitive threat," Mr. Appert said. When The Daily News switched from afternoon to morning publication in May 1988, The Journal and Constitution, which have a combined daily circulation of more than 480,000, increased their coverage of the region to daily from weekly and distributed free newspapers in the area for several days.
The Daily News, which started daily publication in 1965, began publishing as a weekly in 1898 as The Gwinnett News-Herald.
The Times Company hired a newspaper broker, Dirks, Van Essen & Associates, to solicit bids for the paper. The Dirks firm spoke with more than 40 potential purchasers, but none wanted to keep the newspaper open, given the competition and market factors.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Are Shaken by Dollar's Fall

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The sinking dollar continued to rattle the American bond market yesterday, and foreign bonds also fell sharply, as Europe was hit by the uncertainty that the dollar is unleashing and by the threat of higher interest rates.
The corporate and municipal bond markets were also stunned, with several big new municipal issues halted because of the chaos in the Treasury markets. Among the delayed issues was a $666 million offering of revenue bonds by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York. Traders said several corporate financial officers who were ready to sell new securities had also pulled back for now. 
 While economists and analysts waited to see how much farther the dollar would fall and whether the Bush Administration would take any action, the 30-year American bond dropped more than a point and the average discount rates on three- and six-month bills, which had been at their lowest levels in years, leaped when they were auctioned yesterday. Prices also fell sharply in the corporate and municipal bond markets.
 
Too Much Supply
 With the auction of two- and five-year notes today and Wednesday and the hangover of supply from the big quarterly Treasury auction a week ago, the market seems to have more than it can handle at the moment. And the two auctions may not go well.
"There is a combination of bad factors in the market now," said one government securities trader. "The dollar is a real problem for the election process, for confidence and for the financial markets. People don't mind if it goes down. They just don't want it to get out of hand."
Despite repeated rounds of dollar buying by the Federal Reserve and a host of European central banks, the dollar plunged almost 2 percent against the German mark yesterday, ending in late New York trading at 1.4015 marks, its lowest close since the mark was created in 1948.
Long-term 10-year bonds in England were off about a point. The problem there is also currency. With the rise of the mark against the dollar, the German currency has also strengthened against the British pound, pushing the British currency to the bottom of its trading range in the European Monetary System.
If the pound falls much farther, the British Government will probably have to raise interest rates to defend it and keep it within its trading band. Such a move is likely to stun an economy that is having even more trouble generating growth than the American economy.
French bonds were off about three-quarters of a point as some investors sold to invest in Germany, where the dollar's decline is having a muted impact. German long bonds were up about a quarter of a point, in part because of the shift from other European markets, traders said.
 
Fed Unlikely to Cut Rates
 The fall of the dollar has managed to hurt American Treasury securities from the short end to the long end. Traders said that the dollar's decline seems to diminish the likelihood that the Federal Reserve can ease in the near future because another cut in interest rates would weaken the dollar.
"The dollar really lessens any possibility of an ease soon," said Eric Rosenfeld, co-head for fixed-income securities at Salomon Brothers. "It put us back in the 50-50 mode."
In one reflection of this concern, the average discount rate on three-month Treasury bills auctioned yesterday jumped 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than last week's auction, to 3.14 percent. On the six-month bill, the discount rate was up 6 basis points, to 3.24 percent.
At the same time, the uncertainty about the dollar makes investors much less willing to hold long-term securities, which are more volatile and subject to greater losses if a sudden dollar collapse precipitated even sharper drops in the bond market.
In late trading in the secondary market yesterday, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was offered at 9722/32 , off 13/32 points, to yield 7.44 percent, compared with 7.35 percent on Friday. The 6.375 percent 10-year bond was off 17/32 points, to yield 6.68 percent, compared with 6.51 percent on Friday. In preauction or when-issued trading, the new five-year note had a yield of 5.73 percent, up from 5.53 percent at the end of last week. The new two-year note had a yield of 4.29 percent, compared with 4.12 percent Friday.
In the two trading days since the dollar broke to its lowest level in history against the German mark, the price of the long bond has dropped 1 1/2 points. This caused the yield on the bond to jump 12 basis points.
Before the dollar interruption, the yield on the long bond this month first fell to its lowest level since January and then to its lowest level since January 1987.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of three- and six-month bills yesterday:
