HEADLINE: Cook Denies He Killed Athlete on Beach

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Aug. 24

 BODY:
An unemployed cook was arraigned today in the slaying of Wayne Belliveau, a 23-year-old weightlifter and college football player who was shot during a melee at a beach in Rocky Point on July 5.
The suspect, Maximo Suriel, 27, of Coram, pleaded not guilty in Suffolk County Court. He was arrested early Sunday after a friend of Mr. Belliveau's, Scott Marchese, spotted him at a Port Jefferson bar and called the police. 
 The arrest followed a determined effort by family and friends to track down the killer of Mr. Belliveau, a 310-pound athlete from Rocky Point who died only days before he was to report for football practice at North Carolina State.
Posters in local store windows and on telephone poles offered $25,000 in reward money raised by local businesses and private donors for information leading to a conviction. Mr. Belliveau's parents, Ronald and Catherine, spoke at local gatherings to press the hunt, while word that the assailant's first name might be Max circulated through this North Shore hamlet of 8,700 people.
 
Picked Out in Lineup
 Lieut. John Gierasch, commanding officer of the Suffolk police homicide squad, said several witnesses to the shooting had picked out Mr. Suriel in a police lineup after his arrest.
The police said Mr. Marchese was at another bar around 3 A.M. on Sunday when an unidentified person came to summon him to Harborgates in Port Jefferson, where the person said someone fitting the killer's description was a customer.
The lieutenant said the circumstances of the shooting remained unclear. According to the police account, Mr. Belliveau, Mr. Marchese and a friend, Kerri Miller, 19, of Sound Beach, got into an argument with a group of people at the beach shortly before 2 A.M. The police said a fistfight broke out moments before someone, whom they now believe was Mr. Suriel, shot Mr. Belliveau and wounded both his companions.
Judge Rockwell Colaneri of Suffolk County District Court ordered Mr. Suriel held without bail.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 26, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article and headline yesterday about the killing of a college athlete on Long Island misstated details of a court appearance by a man who is accused of the killing. The suspect, Maximo Suriel, did not enter a plea at his arraignment on a charge of second-degree murder.

HEADLINE: Lawmaker's Defense of B.C.C.I. Went Beyond Speech in Senate

BYLINE: By DEAN BAQUET with JEFF GERTH

 BODY:
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the powerful Republican from Utah who is a member of the Judiciary Committee, worked behind the scenes on behalf of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International while at the same time pressing the bank to make a $10 million loan to a close business associate.
From documents and interviews with bank lawyers, a picture emerges of Mr. Hatch and an aide as integral parts of the bank's efforts to escape Senate scrutiny and avoid bad publicity after the bank pleaded guilty in 1989 to Federal charges of illegal laundering of drug money. 
 Mr. Hatch gave a widely reported speech on the Senate floor in 1990 defending B.C.C.I. and he later publicly acknowledged asking the bank to lend money to Monzer Hourani, a Houston businessman. But an examination of the bank documents and the interviews with lawyers and others found that the relationship went much deeper. These were among the findings:
*In late 1989, when a Senate subcommittee began a formal investigation of the bank's ties to dictators and terrorists, Michael Pillsbury, a longtime aide to Senator Hatch and an expert on national security, sat down with the bank's lawyers and offered advice on how to counterattack another Senator's inquiry, according to Mr. Pillsbury, as well as some of the bank's lawyers.
*After B.C.C.I. resolved the money-laundering case in Tampa, Fla., by reaching a plea agreement that many Government officials complained was far too lenient, Mr. Hatch talked to high-ranking Justice Department officials and urged them to step forward and defend the plea deal. A senior Justice Department official acknowledged the call. And a B.C.C.I. lawyer in Washington, Raymond Banoun, said he was present in Mr. Hatch's office when the Senator placed the call.
*The Senator said he made his Senate speech on behalf of B.C.C.I. after being assured by the bank's lawyers that the Florida money-laundering case involved only low-level corruption. Some of B.C.C.I.'s lawyers, including Mr. Banoun, said in interviews that they had talked with the Senator only reluctantly, fearing such a meeting would backfire and anger the Justice Department. The lawyers said they met with the Senator only because of pressure from Mohammad Hammoud, a close friend of Mr. Hatch and also a large B.C.C.I. shareholder. Mr. Hammoud died in 1990.
*Mr. Hatch earlier acknowledged news media reports that he telephoned B.C.C.I.'s president in London, Swaleh Navqi, to ask him to consider lending money to Mr. Hourani. He portrayed the efforts to get the loan as a casual request that produced no results. But a detailed loan proposal was made by Mr. Hourani, B.C.C.I. documents show. No loan apparently was made to Mr. Hourani, a close friend and campaign contributor to Mr. Hatch.
Mr. Hatch's motivation for helping the bank was not clear. But at least three of his friends stood to benefit if B.C.C.I. could remain a going concern in the United States: Mr. Hammoud, a large shareholder in B.C.C.I.; Robert Altman, one of the bank's chief lawyers, and Mr. Hourani, the business associate and campaign contributor who was trying to get a loan.
Mr. Hatch declined an invitation to discuss the details of a New York Times examination of the documents. In a recent statement responding to questions from The Times, Mr. Hatch said he would ask the Senate Ethics Committee to investigate the activities of Mr. Pillsbury, the aide who met with the B.C.C.I. lawyers.
Mr. Pillsbury, in an interview last week, said the discussions with the lawyers were held at the Senator's behest. Mr. Pillsbury, formerly a high-ranking State Department official, said he did not know of the Senator's attempts to secure a loan for Mr. Hourani. Mr. Pillsbury said he encouraged the Senator to request the ethics panel investigation "to show there were no improper contacts by me."
 
Senator Searching His Files for Details
 The Senator's staff said Mr. Hatch would make no additional comment because he was searching his files for more details of his dealings with B.C.C.I., Mr. Hourani and Mr. Hammoud. Last year the Senator produced a letter from the Justice Department stating that he was not under investigation for his relationship with B.C.C.I.
Mr. Hourani did not return repeated telephone messages left at his Houston residence.
B.C.C.I. was shut down last year after regulators around the world accused it of one of the biggest financial frauds in history. Since the shutdown, law-enforcement officials have accused the bank of bribing officials throughout the third world to attract government deposits to B.C.C.I.
Clark M. Clifford, a former Defense Secretary, and Mr. Altman, his law partner, have been charged with taking bribes from B.C.C.I. in exchange for concealing its ownership of First American Bankshares, a Washington holding company of which Mr. Clifford was the chairman. Both have denied the charges, which were filed in Federal and New York State courts.
 
The Regulatory Net Began to Tighten
 The examination by The Times shows that Mr. Hatch's dealings with B.C.C.I. in 1989 and 1990 coincided with the bank's efforts to use political influence around the world to stave off the law-enforcement officials and regulators who had begun to scrutinize its far-flung operations after years of regulatory neglect.
This push came after the bank's October 1988 indictment on money-laundering charges in Tampa. But even before the indictment, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's Subcommittee on Terrorism, Narcotics and International Operations, led by Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, had begun its own inquiry.
By late 1989, the bank's lawyers were recommending that it plead guilty. But several of the lawyers said in interviews that B.C.C.I.'s top executives expressed dismay at the prospect of pleading guilty, at the soaring cost of the defense and at the negative publicity that would result from the plea and the Senate panel's hearings. The executives wondered whether some lobbying could be done to influence the committee investigation and the criminal case, according to the lawyers, who insisted on not being identified.
Another B.C.C.I. lawyer, Mr. Banoun in Washington, said the criticism "filtered back to us, that we were really dealing too much with it as a criminal case and not worrying about the Hill and the public relations issues."
Mr. Banoun said that around the same time, Mr. Naqvi, the president of B.C.C.I., called him to say that he had been visited in London by Mr. Pillsbury, who recommended that the lawyers meet with him and plan strategy for lobbying Congress. The lawyers said Mr. Naqvi told them that Mr. Pillsbury was accompanied by Mr. Hammoud, the B.C.C.I. shareholder and Mr. Hatch's friend. Mr. Naqvi quoted Mr. Hammoud as saying that Senator Hatch wanted to meet with B.C.C.I.'s lawyers.
 
Holding Meetings About Meetings
 "Hammoud was complaining to the bank," Mr. Banoun recalled. Quoting Mr. Hammoud, he said: " 'Here Senator Hatch wants to meet with those people, and the lawyers weren't setting up a meeting. Hatch wants to meet with you guys.' "
Mr. Banoun said he had told Mr. Naqvi by telephone that the Senate staff member's interest in a continuing investigation was so unusual that he feared it might be a Government "sting" operation. He warned the bank president to be certain not to pay Mr. Pillsbury any money or reimburse any of his expenses. He said he feared any payments might be construed as a bribe.
Shortly after the telephone call from London, Mr. Pillsbury showed up at the legal defense team's headquarters in Washington, along with Mr. Hammoud.
"He said he was inquiring on behalf of Hatch," Mr. Banoun recalled Mr. Pillsbury's saying at the time. By Mr. Banoun's account, Mr. Pillsbury said that he put notes of every meeting with the lawyers in writing and sent them to the Senator. Mr. Pillsbury confirmed that he passed on the notes.
Mr. Banoun said Mr. Pillsbury asked for Government tape recordings made by Customs agents in Tampa during the undercover operation. The lawyer said he stalled Mr. Pillsbury and never gave him the tapes. At the time, they had not been made public, he said.
 
'Couldn't Say No' To a Senate Aide
 "We didn't say no; he was a Senate staffer," Mr. Banoun recalled. "You just couldn't say no."
Mr. Banoun said he had given Mr. Pillsbury a copy of a defense motion accusing the Government of misconduct in the undercover operation.
"He thought it was a good motion," Mr. Banoun recalled, and he suggested that it should be circulated publicly.
Mr. Hatch has said he did not know that his friend Mr. Hammoud was a major B.C.C.I. shareholder. But Mr. Banoun said he thought Mr. Pillsbury, the Senator's aide, was aware of the connection.
Mr. Banoun said Mr. Pillsbury and Mr. Hammoud had arranged for the lawyers to meet the Senator at his office. By this time, Mr. Banoun said, the Government prosecutors and B.C.C.I.'s lawyers had reached a plea bargain over the money-laundering case. But the agreement was subject to approval by the judge in the case, and some members of Congress, led by Senator Kerry, were publicly attacking it.
Under the proposed plea bargain, B.C.C.I. was to pay $15 million in fines and admit that it had laundered money. For its part, the Government said it would not pursue various other accusations against B.C.C.I. But this generated controversy among Congressmen and law-enforcement officials who considered the bank to be guilty of much more than money laundering. Some Government officials even said the agreement was a result of the bank's political connections.
Mr. Banoun recalled that during this furor "Pillsbury said, 'Hatch wants to meet with you guys; he wants to know about the plea agreement, and wants to know why it's not being defended.' "
 
Defending Bank And Its Prosecutors
 Mr. Banoun said he had met with the Senator, who "was really annoyed, could not understand the department, why it was throwing in the towel." The "department" he referred to was the Justice Department.
During the meeting, Mr. Banoun said, Mr. Hatch placed a call to the Justice Department to complain, and pressed department officials to come to Congress to make their case in support of the plea bargain arrangement.
A department spokesman would not comment. But Robert S. Ross Jr., then executive assistant to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, said he spoke to the Senator around this time.
"He wanted a briefing," Mr. Ross said. "He wanted to know what was going on." Mr. Ross said he did not view the discussion as unusual, given Mr. Hatch's position on the Judiciary Committee.
"He wasn't being a lobbyist for any particular side," Mr. Ross said.
Mr. Banoun said he had at least one other meeting with Mr. Hatch, though he could not recall specifics.
The judge approved the plea agreement in January 1990, and the attacks in Congress continued.
The next month, Mr. Hatch took the Senate floor. In a speech largely written by Mr. Altman, one of B.C.C.I,'s own lawyers, Mr. Hatch defended the bank and the Justice Department. "The case arose from the conduct of a small number of B.C.C.I.'s more than 14,000 employees," Mr. Hatch said.
Two weeks later, by Mr. Hatch's account in an interview last November, the Senator telephoned the bank's president, Mr. Naqvi, and asked that he consider lending money to Mr. Hourani, the Senator's Houston business associate and friend.
 
Big Contributor Hurt By Houston Slump
 Mr. Hourani, portrayed by business associates and court documents as hard hit by the Houston recession of the late 1980's, was a big campaign contributor to Mr. Hatch. In 1987 and 1988, he and his employees gave a total of at least $12,000 to the Senator's campaign organizations.
In 1988, the Senator and the developer entered into an unusual investment. Mr. Hatch said Mr. Hourani had invested $10,000 of Mr. Hatch's money, using it to buy a one-bedroom apartment in a development in southwest Houston. The 600-square-foot apartment is on the first floor of a 20-year-old complex, across a highway from a pawnshop. It is appraised at about $20,000.
On April 2, 1990, less than a month after the phone call from Mr. Hatch to B.C.C.I.'s president, Mr. Hourani wrote a three-page letter to Mr. Naqvi, outlining a proposal for the bank to give him loan guarantees, in exchange for a percentage of whatever projects were financed.
It is not known what became of the proposal, though Mr. Hatch said Mr. Hourani had never received financing from B.C.C.I.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Bush's Gains From Convention Nearly Evaporate in Latest Poll

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
President Bush's gains from four days in the spotlight at the Republican National Convention have almost completely evaporated, as the President failed to convince the public that he is committed to change and to reviving the economy, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas re-established a strong lead, holding a 51 percent to 36 percent edge in the poll, which was taken Sunday and Monday. That is about the same margin he held before last week's convention. 
 The poll showed the public had far more interest in hearing about Mr. Clinton's favorite issues, the economy and health care, than in topics featured at the convention, like family values and homosexuality.
The survey of 903 registered voters also provided fresh evidence of the loose allegiances of voters this year, showing that large numbers of men, young people, the poor and the financially comfortable all shifted back and forth in the last two weeks.
 
Turnaround Among Men
 Men, for example, had supported President Bush by 47 percent to 40 percent in a Times/CBS News Poll taken last Thursday as the convention ended. By the time of this poll, they supported Mr. Clinton by 51 percent to 38 percent. Their shift accounted for most of the change between the two polls, as the earlier one favored Mr. Clinton, but only by 45 to 42 percent overall.
Robert M. Teeter, chairman of the President's re-election campaign and a leading Republican poll taker for a quarter century, said he thought the results were more favorable to Mr. Clinton than was actually true. He said the Bush campaign had done no fresh polling since the convention but added, "Usually you will not lose what you gained" from a convention.
"My view is the race is about 50 to 40," he said.
Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker, said his latest data did indicate a double-digit Clinton lead that "re-emerged immediately after Bush's speech." He said Mr. Bush had created high expectations for his acceptance speech but did not meet them.
Despite four days of continual attacks, Mr. Clinton emerged from this poll with 36 percent of the public viewing him favorably and 28 percent unfavorably. The negative rating was up from 24 percent before the convention, a shift within the poll's margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, but down from 34 percent unfavorable recorded last Thursday.
Mr. Greenberg said Mr. Bush "appears to have grazed Clinton but done nothing for himself."
 
Three Failures Found
 After weeks of predictions that Mr. Bush would use his Thursday acceptance speech to re-establish his image with the public, the poll measured three striking failures.
First was the overall public answer to the question "Do you approve or disapprove of the way George Bush is handling his job as President?" While many questions were asked only of registered voters, that query was put to the 1,186 adults, registered or not, in the overall sample. Thirty-eight percent said they approved and 53 percent said they disapproved, exactly the same percentages that were recorded in a pre-convention Times/CBS News Poll. No incumbent has ever won a new term after having an approval rating that low this close to Election Day.
Martin Wattenberg, a professor of political science at the University of California at Irvine, called the approval rating "the most significant figure in the poll." If Republicans could not improve those figures at the convention and build broader support for Mr. Bush, he said, "They will have to run an incredibly negative campaign."
The poll also found that while 95 percent of registered voters said there should be "real change in the way things are going in this country," only 15 percent said Mr. Bush could bring it about. Indeed, only 34 percent of his own supporters said he could. Sixty-one percent of the public said Mr. Clinton would cause "real change."
The survey also showed that only 24 percent said Mr. Bush "has offered specific ideas to get the United States out of the recession." That was up only one percentage point from the pre-convention poll. Forty-nine percent said Mr. Clinton had offered specific ideas, up from 48 percent.
The poll did not ask any questions directly about the convention in Houston, but it sought to find what subjects the public wanted the candidates to spend a lot of time discussing. Nine Americans in 10, regardless of whom they favored, wanted substantial discussion of how the candidates planned to improve the nation's economy and how they would improve the country's health care system, subjects Mr. Clinton discusses in almost every speech.
Two subjects that were frequently raised at the Republican convention, "family values" and "legal rights for homosexuals," excited less interest. Only 23 percent wanted to hear about homosexuals' rights. Forty-nine percent of registered voters, including 63 percent of Bush supporters and 40 percent of Clinton supporters, wanted to hear candidates "discussing how they would uphold traditional family values."
One hopeful Republican interpretation of the survey came from Linda DiVall, a poll taker who said that Republican gains shown in the poll in the South and Midwest and among Roman Catholics were encouraging. Even fluctuations among young voters and men, she said, showed that the Bush campaign had an opportunity to win them. She said this race was distinguished by low intensity and low levels of support for both candidates, and by frequent shifts in support.
Mr. Clinton, for example, went from a 43-to-43 percent tie with Mr. Bush before the Democratic convention in New York to a 55-to-31 percent lead immediately after, a lead that decreased a little to 52 to 35 percent just before the Republican convention in Houston.
Mr. Greenberg disagreed with her, saying, "This is the last time George Bush will have the stage to himself" to make his case. Another Democratic poll taker, Peter D. Hart, compared Mr. Bush to a slumping baseball player batting against second division pitching and still not hitting: "It was his convention, his terms, and his own pitching machine, and his average stayed the same."
 
Clinton Slows in South
 In the South, the 49-to-38 percent lead Mr. Clinton held before the Republican convention was reduced, in the latest poll, to a 46-to-41 percent lead. Among Midwesterners, his lead dropped from a 54-to-31 edge to a 52-to-38 percent lead. And among Roman Catholics, a 57-to-31 percent lead narrowed to a 51-to-38 percent edge.
Nationally, when undecided respondents were asked if they leaned toward either candidate, more said they preferred Mr. Clinton; his lead widened slightly to 55 percent to 39 percent.
Mr. Greenberg and Mr. Teeter both suggested that the poll taken last Thursday may have exaggerated Mr. Bush's temporary gains from the convention by a couple of percentage points.
But it was clear to them and to others that there have been major fluctuations among men in this series of polls while women's support for Mr. Clinton remained more constant.
Barbara A. Bardes, a professor of political science at Loyola University of Chicago, said she believed "men just haven't decided which issues are most important to them in this election." Women, she said, have at least temporarily settled on the importance of the question of freedom of choice concerning abortion and are widely unhappy with attacks on Hillary Clinton, whether they like her or not.
Ann F. Lewis, a Democratic consultant in Boston, said, "It really does seem these days that men are much more responsive to politics of emotion, especially certain kinds of patriotic symbolism, while women are more likely to focus on the family budget and the nation's well-being."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sunday and Monday with 1,186 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 903 said they were registered voters.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all registered voters in the country.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For results based on men, for example, it is plus or minus five percentage points, while for women it is four percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for example, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: Home Resales Up 3.9% in July

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes rose 3.9 percent in July from the previous month, signaling a modest recovery in the sluggish housing market, a real estate group said today.
The National Association of Realtors said sales had increased to an annual rate of 3.48 million units, seasonally adjusted, from 3.35 million in June. The organization said the rise was largely spurred by the lowest mortgage rates in 19 years. 
 July sales were up 6.7 percent from July 1991, the real estate group said. Prices for existing homes fell 2.4 percent, to a median price of $102,600 in July, and were down 7.8 percent from $103,400 last year.
Sales in the Midwest surged 12.8 percent from a month earlier and almost 20 percent from last year. Sales also rose in the South, up eight-tenths of a percent from June and 5 percent from last year.
But sales were unchanged from the previous month in the Northeast and West, though Northeast sales were 5.9 percent higher compared with a year ago. Sales in the West, however, were off by 4 percent from July 1991.
While the improvement in the sales of existing homes was good news for the housing business and should help new-home construction, economists did not view it as an indicator of greater consumer confidence or a strong, widespread recovery.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Slight Gain Managed By Dollar

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
After falling sharply against the German mark in the last week, the dollar stabilized in volatile trading yesterday, but many traders predicted that it would soon drift lower.
Foreign exchange traders said some people were selling marks to take profits now that the dollar has plunged some 17 percent against the mark in four months. 
 In New York, the dollar closed at 1.4027 German marks, up slightly from its all-time low of 1.4015 on Monday.
"The dollar has absorbed a lot of selling, falling some 4 or 5 percent in the past three days," said Jay Tucker, manager of the foreign exchange department at the First Boston Corporation. "The dollar needs to consolidate a little before it moves again. But the potential for the dollar to weaken is still there."
 
Central Banks Step Back
 Currency traders said the Federal Reserve and other central banks, which intervened heavily to defend the dollar on Friday and Monday, refrained from intervening yesterday, because they saw that the exchange markets were remaining orderly and that the dollar was not plunging.
In morning trading, the dollar sank to a new low of 1.3945 marks, before bouncing upward in the afternoon.
Stocks on the New York Stock Exchange followed the dollar, ending up for the day after heading downward in the morning. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,232.22, up 4.05 points.
Traders said the dollar was hurt in the morning by a Conference Board report showing that consumer confidence had fallen in August to its lowest level since March.
 
Some Signs of Strength
 The bad news on consumer confidence was offset somewhat by reports showing that sales of existing homes rose 3.9 percent in July and that sales of domestically made cars and light trucks rose 10.2 percent in the 10-day period ended Aug. 20.
Economists say the main reasons for the dollar's slide are the stubborn weakness of the American economy and the differential between Germany's high short-term interest rates and America's low rates. The high German rates are spurring many investors to buy marks to invest in lucrative German bonds, while America's poor economic performance is discouraging many foreign investors from buying dollars to invest in American stocks.
"The currency market has not shaken off the image of malaise about the U.S. economy," said Curtis Perkins, a currency trader with Chemical Bank. He forecast that the dollar would soon fall to about 1.38 marks.
Another factor pushing down the dollar yesterday morning was news that a poll found that a majority of French voters planned to oppose a plan calling for countries in the European Community to adopt a single currency and bind their economies closer together. A referendum is set for a Sept. 20. The poll caused many traders to buy the mark because France's rejection of the plan would be expected to lead to a realignment that devalues many European currencies against the mark.
Later in the day, however, news of another French poll was released showing that the French, by a narrow majority, still favored the Maastricht Treaty, which calls for setting up a single European currency no later than 1999.
 
No Alarm in Washington
 Although officials in Europe say the dollar's lows indicate a lack of confidence in the American economy, officials in Washington did not express alarm about the dollar's decline.
The weaker dollar is expected to help bolster American exports, which the Bush Administration says is vital for future economic growth. But at the same time, a weaker dollar could ultimately help spur inflation by making imports more expensive.
This morning, Hans Tietmeyer, deputy president of Germany's central bank, sought to push up the dollar, saying that the selling of the American currency was overdone.
Currency traders say the intervention of the central banks was aimed not so much to reverse the dollar's decline, as to make sure the dollar did not enter into a free fall.

Dollar Off Against Yen
 By The Associated Press -- In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.85 yen yesterday, down 0.48 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 124.85 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.55 yen, down from 124.60 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9900, down from $1.9925 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.9895 to buy one pound, less than Monday's $1.9920.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.2475 Swiss francs, up from 1.2430; 4.7825 French francs, down from 4.7865; 1,071.00 Italian lire, down from 1,072.50, and 1.1900 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1891.
Gold prices fell worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $340.60 an ounce, down $1 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold had fallen to a late bid price of $340.50 an ounce, off $1.10.

HEADLINE: When Voters Take a Holiday

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DUTTON, Ala., Aug. 25

 BODY:
It was Election Day in Dutton today, and no one voted.
But everybody had a good excuse: No one was running for Mayor or for any of the five seats on the Town Council, the only positions at stake. 
 As a result, this northeastern Alabama town of 243 people will end up with no elected officials when the terms of the Mayor and the four remaining Council members expire in October. A fifth Council post has been vacant for more than a year, ever since its occupant moved away. None of the offices carry a salary.
Perry Roquemore, executive director of the Alabama League of Municipalities, said his office was prepared to ask Gov. Guy Hunt to appoint four new Council members so the town can continue to do business.
"I don't know that there's any reason why no one is running," said Mayor Larry Stockman. "There's no financial crisis. I really don't think it's news, either."

HEADLINE: Stocks Level After Dollar Calms Down

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Calm returned to Wall Street yesterday after two straight days of losses as a steadier dollar enabled blue-chip stocks to close slightly higher.
 But buyers were still in short supply, a fact borne out by losses in many smaller stocks. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.05 points to close at 3,232.22. Declining issues led those that gained, 1,002 to 719, on the New York Stock Exchange as volume swelled to 202.8 million shares, from 165.7 million on Monday.
 The dollar hit an all-time low of 1.3945 German marks in early trading after a French opinion poll showed a majority against Europe's Maastricht Treaty on economic and monetary union.
 But the United States currency bounced back to end the session at 1.4027 marks, compared with 1.4015 marks on Monday.
 The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell 10/32 , or $3.44 for every $1,000 face amount. It yielded 7.47 percent compared with 7.45 percent late Monday.
 There were several French polls on the Maastricht Treaty on European unity. While the first showed 51 percent opposed to the treaty, a second survey showed 51 percent in favor.
 
After the Survey
 The first survey started a sharp selloff in the dollar, which quickly spread to the stock market, where the Dow lost as much as 21 points.
 Jack Solomon, a technical analyst at Bear, Stearns, said stock prices could be poised to go higher. "The fluctuations seem to be tamping down," he said about the currency markets.
 A rise in I.B.M., which added 2, to 87 1/8, helped strengthen the Dow.
 Several analysts said I.B.M.'s gain could reflect assumptions that multinational companies will benefit from the dollar's weakness.
 "You're going to get some very strong effects for companies that do a lot of business overseas," said Ron Hill, a strategist for Brown Brothers Harriman.
 "The market is trying to right itself," said Ed Laux, a senior vice president of Kidder, Peabody. He added that the rise in the Dow "is probably an encouraging sign."
 But analysts noted that much of the economic news remained tepid. The consumer confidence index for August fell to 58.0 from 61.2 in July.
 
Gains Seen for Drugs
 Several analysts said drug companies should benefit from the dollar's weakness because many have significant overseas operations. Merck rose 5/8, to 51; Pfizer added 1/2, to 80 1/2, and Bristol-Myers Squibb rose 1 1/2, to 67 1/4.
 Picturetel slumped 4 1/4, to 11 1/4, after saying it expected to break even in the third quarter on revenues that are flat or slightly lower than the second quarter. Hambrecht & Quist and Alex. Brown cut ratings.
 Ford Motor gained 1 3/8, to 40 1/8. It said domestic car sales from Aug. 11 to 20 rose 13.7 percent.
 The hurricane took its toll on Seibels Bruce, which slipped 2 5/8, to 3. Lincoln National's American States said it had canceled a planned merger with the insurance concern because of losses caused by the hurricane.
 Grand Metropolitan fell 2 1/2, to 30, after it issued a profit warning. Morgan Stanley downgraded its rating.
 The Nasdaq market index lost 1.17, to close at 554.22.
 The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.89, to 411.61. The American Stock Exchange index fell 1.38 points, to 379.52. The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index rose 0.13, to 226.47. The Wilshire Associates Equity Index was 3,952.592, down 2.1 points, or 0.05 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Deere Profit Falls 70.9%; Sales Weak

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Deere & Company said yesterday that its net income fell 70.9 percent, to $9.1 million, or 12 cents a share, in the third quarter.
Sales were down slightly, to $1.75 billion, as the nation's largest maker of farm equipment was buffeted by soft market conditions worldwide for its products. 
 In the comparable 1991 quarter, the company earned $31.3 million, or 31 cents a share, on sales of $1.79 billion.
 
Weakness Was Widespread
 In the latest quarter, which ended on July 31, the demand for lawn and garden equipment was weaker than expected, Deere said. Demand was also sluggish for industrial and agricultural equipment in the United States and foreign markets. "That doesn't leave much," said John J. Mackin, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company.
Higher prices for many Deere products helped offset some of the declines, but the company said competitive pressures forced it to offer incentives that hurt profit levels.
The quarterly results were generally within analysts' estimates. Deere had said in late July that its equipment division would lose money this year and that it planned to cut production sharply in the fourth quarter.
The company's stock closed yesterday at $38.50 a share, down 87.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company expressed little optimism about the outlook for the economy. "Consumer confidence remains at a low level and the pattern of slow, uneven growth in the domestic economy is expected to continue," said Hans W. Becherer, chairman and chief executive of Deere, which is based in Moline, Ill. "The extent of recovery in housing starts and consumer spending for durable goods will be key determinants of the level of future demand for our construction and lawn- and grounds-care equipment.
"In North America, farmers continue to be cautious buyers, and overseas agricultural equipment demand is expected to remain soft," he added. "Accordingly, our outlook for the remainder of this fiscal year and into early 1993 remains uncertain."
In reaction to the slowed demand, the company has cut production, and plans to continue doing so.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Matsushita's Net Drops 76%; JVC Will Pare 700 Workers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, one of the world's largest makers of consumer electronics, said today that its net income plunged 76 percent in the April-June quarter.
Meanwhile, the Victor Company of Japan, which markets consumer electronics under the JVC label, said it planned to trim 700 people at its video plants over a year through attrition and a hiring freeze on new high school graduates. 
 Matsushita and JVC cut their earnings forecasts for the coming months. Instead of a small profit, JVC now expects a $208 million loss.
Japan's electronics industry has been hit particularly hard by the sharp economic slowdown in Japan and stagnation overseas.
Sales have also been slow because many of the industry's main products -- stereos, TV's and videocassette recorders -- are mature goods for which technological change is slow and ownership already widespread.
Matsushita posted earnings of 9 billion yen, or $72 million, for its first fiscal quarter, compared with 38.2 billion yen a year earlier."Severe external conditions, most notably decreased demand for video and audio equipment," cut the quarter's sales 3 percent, to 1.71 trillion yen, or $13.7 billion, from 1.77 trillion yen.
The company said Japan's economic slowdown and weak demand in Europe and the United States had hit sales particularly hard. Sales of video equipment fell 11 percent, while audio equipment dropped 5 percent.
Sales in Matsushita's entertainment divisions, consisting mostly of MCA Inc., the American conglomerate that it acquired in December 1990, fell 1 percent.
Matsushita also said it was lowering its earnings forecast for the parent company for the first half of the fiscal year, which began in April. It said net income would plunge 53 percent, to 29 billion yen, or $232 million, compared with its earlier forecast of a 26 percent decline.
 
JVC Sees Deficit
 JVC, a leading maker of videocassette recorders, said it expected to lose 26 billion yen, or $208 million, for the fiscal year.
JVC, which does not report quarterly results, had said it expected a profit of only 1 billion yen, or $8 million, because of the weak market for audio-visual products.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Despite Woes in Real Estate, Wells Fargo Rebuilds Profits

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Wells Fargo & Company, one of the nation's most successful banking companies in the late 1980's, has hit a rocky patch.
Problems with bad real estate loans wiped out all but $21 million of its 1991 earnings, and earnings of $201 million in the first half of this year were below par by Wells Fargo's standards. At midyear, Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, held $13.6 billion of commercial real estate loans -- the most of any bank in the country -- with about 11.5 percent badly delinquent or so troubled that full repayment is not expected. 
 Nevertheless, the company has the endorsement of investors like Warren E. Buffett, who has bought about 10.8 percent of the company since May 1991, and Walter H. Annenberg, who announced earlier this month that he had bought 5.3 percent of Wells Fargo's stock. Why?
One reason is that unlike the situation at many other banks, which have weak profits in other parts of their business as well as real estate problems, Wells Fargo's trouble's with real estate loans have highlighted its strength in other facets of banking. Another is that the 1986 acquisition of Crocker National by Wells Fargo was a model for other bankers who are seeking to improve profits by merging with a competitor and eliminating duplication in offices, computer systems and employees.
Today, Wells Fargo is making new efforts to squeeze even greater profit from its consumer business. After educating consumers in the 1980's about the benefits of telephone banking and automatic teller machines, Wells recently raised its prices for those services for certain customers.
"A lot of other banks are chafing to start charging for services they have been giving away," said Les Dinkin, managing director at NBI, a bank consulting firm in New York. "It's a way to rebuild earnings and capital," he said, adding that higher fees help profits and build relationships if customers are persuaded to increase their deposits so that fees do not apply.
On July 1, Wells Fargo imposed new charges on telephone banking -- a 24-hour phone line available to check balances, transfer funds between accounts and answer other inquiries. All customers are allowed three free calls a month. For additional calls, customers who lack the minimum average checking balance of $750 or the combined balance in all accounts of $2,500, Wells charges 50 cents a call to a computerized voice and $1.50 to human operators.
According to a recent report by Salomon Brothers, which Wells Fargo officials declined to confirm, about 90 percent of the bank's customers used the telephone service fewer than three times a month, but 10 percent (with average balances of only $200) used the service 12 to 14 times a month, often to see if a check had cleared.
Wells Fargo has also started charging a $1 monthly fee for customers who use their plastic bank cards -- the same one used for automatic teller machines -- for purchases, mostly groceries and gasoline. Such card use is widespread in California and is growing rapidly elsewhere.
To further reduce costs, on May 1 Wells Fargo stopped returning canceled checks to customers who signed up for lower-cost checking accounts in which all deposits and withdrawals are made at automatic teller machines. Customers who need the checks for tax records, may obtain up to 12 a year at no charge, but they pay fees for additional requests. The program, called check truncation, has been used by a handful of banks, including the Bank of America, for several years, and is spreading to others.
The new consumer charges are part of a long-term effort that made Wells Fargo one of the top banks in the country in terms of cost control in recent years. In 1991, its efficiency ratio, or operating expenses divided by revenues, was 58.8 percent, the fifth best among large banks, according to Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm. The BankAmerica Corporation has been improving but was still 12th in the Keefe Bruyette ranking, at 61.6 percent.
Despite Wells Fargo's efficiency, the bank's efforts to charge consumers for the services are not likely to generate enough money to make investors and analysts forget the company's problems with commercial real estate.
John Leonard, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, estimated the new fees could increase Wells Fargo's revenues by $10 million a quarter, and nearly all of that would be profit. Still, it would make only a dent in the losses from writing off bad loans and replenishing the reserve for loan losses.
Since Wells announced a $132 million increase in foreclosed real estate, to $555 million, at midyear and a $250 million-plus increase in nonperforming loans, to $2.33 billion, analysts see little decline in loan write-offs or the provision to loan-loss reserves for a few more quarters.
But because other parts of Wells Fargo's business are in such good state, Mr. Leonard estimates that a stabilization of problems with bad loans would allow profits to improve. By 1993, the company could be earning $12 a share, up sharply from 16 cents a share in 1991, he projects, and even surpassing the record $11.16 a share earned in 1990 after excluding one-time benefits.
But not everyone is sanguine. George Salem of Prudential Securities, for example, fears that problems with California's real estate markets and the economy will keep loan problems high and retard the bank's recovery.

HEADLINE: Oil Industry Is Battened Down

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The oil industry braced for Hurricane Andrew today, completing evacuations of thousands of workers from the 3,700 drilling platforms in the Gulf of Mexico and scaling back or shutting down operations at dozens of gasoline refineries in Texas and Louisiana.
In financial markets, there was little worry that Hurricane Andrew would disrupt the nation's gasoline supplies. After rising more than 2 cents in trading on Monday, unleaded gasoline for September delivery fell 0.60 cent today, to 62.13 cents a gallon. 
 Paul D. Mlotok, an oil analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, said that past hurricanes had brought brief disruptions, at worst, to refineries along the Gulf Coast.
 
Modern Designs
 Many modern refineries are designed to withstand winds of up to 200 miles an hour, with drainage systems to cope with water surges that can leave water at depths of six feet or more on refinery grounds.
But no one predicted that refiners would escape the storm unscathed. When Hurricane Alicia struck on Aug. 18, 1983, near Galveston, Tex., about 100 miles west of Hurricane Andrew's likely landfall, gasoline production at Gulf Coast refineries dropped. Output was down by 500,000 barrels a day -- a little less than 10 percent -- for a week after that storm, said Peter C. Beutel, energy director at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
The Shell Oil Company, the largest producer of oil and gas from platforms in the Gulf of Mexico, said 850 of its 900 employees and contract workers had been ferried to coastal loading zones since preparations for the hurricane began early Monday.
Shell Oil operates in 57 separate production fields in gulf waters, and has shut virtually all of its daily crude output of 145,000 barrels a day and 490 million cubic feet of gas output, or half of its normal daily volume. Many gas-drilling platforms in the western gulf region continue to operate, said Holly R. Hutchins, a Shell spokesman in Houston.
At Cameron, La., about 40 miles east of Port Arthur, Tex., dozens of large refineries were preparing for the storm, including ones operated by Fina, Chevron and Star Enterprises, a joint venture of Saudi Aramco and Texaco.
The companies said today that they had suspended operations. Rick Hagar, a spokesman for Fina, based in Dallas, said the company decided to shut its Port Arthur refinery, which consumes 150,000 barrels of crude daily, at 4 P.M., Eastern daylight time. Most of its 450 workers were sent home. An emergency crew of 30 people planned to spend the night in the refinery's control room, which has walls designed to withstand major explosions.
Production at the Citgo Petroleum Corporation's large refinery in Lake Charles, La., 50 miles east of Port Arthur, was also halted late today. The refinery, which supplies much of daily gasoline shipments to Citgo stations east of the Rockies, has a capacity of 320,000 barrels a day of crude. Including a nearby plant that produces lubricants, Citgo has 1,500 employees at the site.
Coast Guard officials said they could not estimate the number of workers taken ashore by boat or helicopter from offshore platforms since early Monday, but the number probably exceeded 10,000.
Commercial traffic along the lower Mississippi River was halted at New Orleans, where more than 20,000 people working along docks and at warehouses that generate sales of $10 million daily at the Port Authority of New Orleans were sent home for the day.
Dozens of vessels, including many that serve offshore drilling platforms, were moored along the deep-water harbor that runs from the mouth of the Mississippi River toward Baton Rouge, La., about 180 miles upstream.
"Right now, we think we're going to be along the eastern edge of the storm, and we should be O.K.," said J. Ron Brinson, the port authority's president and chief executive.

HEADLINE: BEIJING SENTENCES, THEN RELEASES FOE

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 25

 BODY:
In what appears to be the last political trial related to the Tiananmen Square democracy movement, China sentenced an influential economist today to three years in prison for counterrevolutionary crimes and then released him for time served.
Wu Jiaxiang, a 37-year-old theorist who was detained on July 17, 1989, was allowed to return home this afternoon after his sentence was read out to a courtroom, a family member said. Mr. Wu was jailed for five weeks more than his official jail term, and one of the reasons appears to be that officials wanted to end the three-year series of Tiananmen political trials by allowing the last person tried to walk away from his sentencing a free man. 
 "This is the last trial," said John T. Kamm, an American businessman and human-rights campaigner who met this week with justice and police officials. "They wanted to close it with a release."
Officials told Mr. Kamm that all Chinese who were detained in connection with the Tiananmen Square democracy movement have now been tried and that a handful of other Chinese prisoners also have been released recently. But they evaded questions about what would happen if Chinese dissidents still wanted by the Government returned to China.
 
'Brain Trust' Member
 Mr. Wu was a senior researcher at the Communist Party Central Committee General Office and was held in Qincheng Prison, where he was allowed to read but not write.
He was charged with counterrevolutionary incitement and propaganda. Mr. Wu did not actively take part in the protests, although he is believed to have been accused of writing a set of counterrevolutionary" slogans that were used in Tiananmen Square demonstrations.
A native of a remote village in Anhui Province, Mr. Wu grew up in the countryside. After the Cultural Revolution, he attended Beijing University and his career soared.
In the late 1980's, Mr. Wu became a member of the "brain trust" of young intellectuals surrounding the Communist Party leader, Zhao Ziyang. Mr. Wu wrote several important policy speeches and a book on the theory of Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader. He was close to Gen. Wang Ruilin, Mr. Deng's chief of staff.
 
Reports of Breakdowns
 But those contacts did not help him after his arrest.
"He's one of them," said a Chinese journalist. "And they think he betrayed them."
There have been reports that Mr. Wu also suffered from mental breakdowns, and the family member reached today suggested that Mr. Wu would need some rest to recuperate mentally from his ordeal.
"On the outside, he looked okay," said the family member, adding that he did not have a chance to speak much with Mr. Wu.
 
Steel Worker Reported Freed
 A poet and prominent essayist, Mr. Wu was one of the original proponents of "new authoritarianism." That theory held that Chinese required enlightened despotism, rather than Western-style democracy, to promote the growth of a healthy economic system and prepare for broader freedoms later on.
Mr. Wu was a close associate of Bao Tong, the former political secretary of the Politburo, who was sentenced last month to seven years in prison.
The Government also told Mr. Kamm that it had released Zhu Jianbin, a 37-year-old dissident who had been imprisoned for 11 years because of his involvement in the Democracy Spring movement that began in 1978. Mr. Zhu, a steel worker who edited a pro-democracy journal, The Bell Tolls, was detained in 1981 and virtually nothing has been heard of him since then.
Officials told Mr. Kamm that Mr. Zhu was tried and sentenced in April 1981 to six years in prison for counterrevolutionary incitement. They said he broke prison regulations when he assaulted someone in a brawl and then had his sentenced increased by "several years."
 
Prisoner's Wife Released
 The authorities would not say when Mr. Zhu was released. They told Mr. Kamm that Mr. Zhu has returned to his home in Wuhan and now has a job.
Another dissident, Hou Xiaotian, said today that she had been released after four days of questioning about her plans to protest on behalf of her imprisoned husband. Ms. Hou said she was released late Sunday night but had been kept in a guest house rather than a prison and had been well treated.
Her husband, Wang Juntao, is serving a 13-year sentence for his role in the Tiananmen democracy movement. He began a hunger strike on Aug. 11 to protest actions by authorities to block two suits he is filing against the court and a prison.
Ms. Hou said the authorities told her that her husband had lost about 22 pounds since he began his hunger strike, but that he was eating again on an irregular basis.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Signs Farm-Protection Bill Into Law

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GENEVA, N.Y., Aug. 25

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed a farm-protection bill into law today, and the New York Farm Bureau called it the most significant new farm legislation in a decade.
The bill limits the right of local governments to ban normal farm practices, protects farmers against nuisance lawsuits, classifies farmland and farm buildings in a lower tax class and creates farmland protection boards in each county. 
 It also requires that people buying land in farm areas be told about local farming practices that may cause noise, dust and smells.
"New York's agricultural industry is an invaluable asset to our state's economy and quality of life," Governor Cuomo said at a ceremony at the state's Agricultural Experiment Station in Geneva, about 50 miles southwest of Syracuse.
The bill, which the Legislature passed in July, gives the state Department of Agriculture and Markets the authority to decide whether farming activities -- such as using agricultural chemicals, running grain-dryer fans or operating a combine at night -- are justified.
The law also requires that the department be involved when a public project, such as a road, is proposed for agricultural land.
"This is the biggest piece of legislation for agriculture in the last 10 years," said Mark Emery, a spokesman for the state Farm Bureau.
There are about 38,000 farmers in New York State, down about 4,000 from 1982.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Criticizes Clinton as Hard On Car Industry

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CANTON, Mich., Aug. 25

 BODY:
President Bush ventured into the backyard of the American automobile industry today to depict his Democratic rivals as environmental extremists whose policies would throw hundreds of thousands of Michigan residents out of work.
Under rain clouds at an outdoor rally in this township that is home to both laid off General Motors workers and affluent executives, Mr. Bush strongly criticized Gov. Bill Clinton's support of a proposal to raise automobile fuel efficiency standards to 40 miles a gallon by the turn of the century from the current 27.5. He also contended that the Governor had started with a bad environmental record in Arkansas and then moved too far in the other direction. 
 "He's gone all the way over from that lousy record now to becoming bright green," Mr. Bush told thousands of cheering supporters at the Canton Township Heritage Park west of Detroit. "He's turned that bright, and if Clinton has his way, Michigan auto workers are going to be turning green with illness."
Citing figures from a motor vehicle industry group, Mr. Bush said that in Michigan alone, "40,000 workers would go from the assembly line to the unemployment line if we go from those ridiculous standards."
 
Going After Gore Book
 Acknowledging that he does not usually single out Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, Mr. Clinton's running mate, Mr. Bush said he could not help himself today. While Mr. Clinton has praised Mr. Gore's best selling book, "Earth in the Balance: Ecology and the Human Spirit," Mr. Bush recited passages from it that he said were distressing.
Ridiculing "this famous book now that Governor Clinton talks about," the President went on: "On page 325 of the book, he makes an interesting comparison. He says that the automobile industry -- and I quote right here, quotation, 'poses a mortal threat to the security of every nation, that is more deadly than that of any military enemy we're ever again likely to confront.' That is Mr. Clinton's running mate talking about the auto industry that means so much to our country."
Still mocking Mr. Gore's book, Mr. Bush then said: "And one page later, he calls for the 'elimination of the internal combustion engine.' What kind of people are we dealing with here?"
In a telephone interview from Ohio, where he was campaigning, Mr. Gore chuckled when told that the President was reciting from his book.
"This is simply one more effort by the self-proclaimed environmental President to divert attention from his total economic and environmental failure," he said. "What the auto industry needs is not political posturing but a strong economy and money in the pockets of consumers who can then purchase new cars and trucks."
Mr. Gore also disputed Mr. Bush's figures about jobs that would be lost under the Democrats' proposals, saying there have been 250,000 jobs lost under the stewardship of the Bush Administration, with another 600,000 lost in related industries.
In another effort to portray the Democratic ticket as extremist, the President alluded to the bus trips Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore have taken around the country. "So when that Clinton-Gore bus goes off the left side of the highway onto the shoulder," he said, "we've got to guard against that, too."
With Bush campaign aides describing Michigan as a crucial battleground in November, Mr. Bush found a receptive site for his warnings about tighter fuel standards. The Congressional district that includes Canton has 25 plants of the Big Three auto manufacturers, and Michigan has one of the highest unemployment rates in the country, 9.4 percent in July.
Mr. Bush flew into the nearby Willow Run Airport in Ypsilanti, and his motorcade rushed by a sprawling plant that General Motors recently announced it would shut down, possibly next summer, leaving an estimated 4,000 workers without jobs.
The President came to Michigan for his offensive on the environment after what he billed as a nonpolitical stop in Chicago this morning at a convention of the American Legion.
At that appearance, his aides passed out literature critical of Mr. Clinton's record regarding the Vietnam-era draft, while Mr. Bush stayed above the fray.
In a break from his pattern since the Republican Convention last week, in which he has attacked members of Congress at virtually every stop, the President praised a Democratic Congressman, Representative G. V. (Sonny) Montgomery, a friend of his who has long been close to veterans.
But he was not kind to Democrats here. As supporters wielded brooms with signs reading "Clean the House!" and opponents waved pink slips, Mr. Bush took on the Congressman here, Representative William D. Ford, chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, for opposing his education proposals.
"I'm a little tired of Congressmen that talk one way in Michigan and vote different in Washington," the President said, his voice rising in anger. "I'll give you an example. One of those Democratic leaders that blocked this new proposal in education is named Congressman Ford, Bill Ford. He has stood against school choice and just about every education reform I have put forward. And what's worse, Governor of Arkansas agrees with him."
Turning to international affairs, Mr. Bush pressed on: "You want to stand up to a Baghdad Bully like Saddam Hussein? Governor Clinton waffled. Congressman Ford said, 'no way.' I say 'yes.' "
In another attack on the Democrats, Mary Matalin, the deputy campaign manager, distributed to reporters a four-page "counter-rebuttal on Clinton's tax-and-fee record." The paper was a defense of criticism of the Bush campaign's list of 128 purported state tax increases under Governor Clinton. It said, among other things, that it was "grossly dishonest" for the Governor to call Arkansas a low-tax state.

Since 1985, Larry Hogue, a homeless man who the police say becomes violent when he smokes crack, has been a frightening fixture for the residents of the Upper West Side neighborhood around West 96th Street. Though he has been arrested many times, he has not been convicted of any crimes serious enough to keep him off the street for longer than a year.  WOMAN WITH AIDS
 WINS JUDGMENT
A Buffalo woman with AIDS has been awarded $155,000 for what a Federal judge said was the humiliating treatment she received in the Erie County jail. The woman was placed in a unit usually reserved for mentally disturbed and suicidal inmates, forced to wear plastic gloves when she used a typewriter in the jail library and denied regular attendance at Roman Catholic services. The prison also placed red stickers on her belongings to indicate she had AIDS. B4.

 A VICTORY FOR NASSAU COUNTY

 MARINAS IN THE DOLDRUMS
With waiting lists for dock space suddenly a thing of the past and boat owners shopping for bargains, marina operators are scrambling as never before to attract customers. "Basically, between the weather and the recession, people are just not using boats the way they did in the past," said Eliot Howell, who owns a marina in Hampton Bays, L.I. B4.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Continues to Slump

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
American consumer confidence in the economy eroded further this month to the weakest level since March, the Conference Board said yesterday.
The results of the board's survey reflected growing uncertainty about the recovery from recession. Consumers' attitudes were more negative than in July, regarding both the current situation and expectations for the immediate future. 
 "There now appears to be scant likelihood of any significant quickening in the pace of economic growth in the immediate months ahead," the business research group predicted.
Economists said the weak job market and the economic oratory generated by the Presidential election campaign were making consumers more wary of spending. The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index, which assesses consumer sentiment on a monthly basis, fell 3.2 points from July to 58 this month. In July the index fell a revised 11.4 points from the previous month. Since June the index has fallen about 20 percent. In March the index was 56.5.
"The present low reading is historically associated with a lackluster economy," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center. "The promise of business recovery, which was suggested by the markedly improved confidence readings recorded in the spring, has all but withered away."
The gain in the spring months had been considered an important sign that consumers were growing more confident about their finances.
Gary Ciminero, chief economist at the Fleet Financial Group, a large regional banking company in Providence, R.I., said consumer confidence had reached a low enough level to generate concern.
"It's not a good portent for George Bush or for the economy," Mr. Ciminero said. "The economic recovery, if you want to call it that, is going to be working against the headwind of very slow consumer spending."
The Consumer Confidence Index, calculated on a 1985 base of 100, is compiled from responses to questionnaires sent to 5,000 households nationwide to assess financial and job security. The questions cover topics ranging from personal buying plans to the outlook for business and employment.
Many economists pay close attention to the index, which provides insight into consumer attitudes toward spending and borrowing. Consumers account for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and drive recovery and expansion.
This month, only 10 percent of those surveyed said they believed that present business conditions were good, but more than four times as many said they were bad. That is weaker than in July.
On employment, the figures are even worse. Only 5.5 percent of all respondents said jobs were "plentiful," but more than eight times as many said they were "hard to get." That is also weaker than July.
The despondency over job security has been reinforced by large-scale layoff announcements in recent weeks and the Government's own employment data, which have shown that the economic recovery is not producing many new jobs.
Consumers are similarly less secure in their expectations for the months ahead. The survey shows that 18.4 percent expect business conditions to improve, while 13.9 percent fear they will worsen. In July about 20 percent believed that business conditions would get better.
One out of eight respondents worried that family income would decline in the next six months.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Dollar's Fall Alters Bond Dynamics

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Bad economic news is usually good for the bond market. Traders, speculators and investors translate a decline in car sales, or a sluggish increase in jobs, into the expectation of slow economic growth, which in turn means that inflation will decline and the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates. And low inflation and low interest rates send bond prices higher.
But the plunge in the dollar since the end of last week seems to have temporarily changed that formula. 
 Take, for example, the decline in consumer confidence reported yesterday. The Conference Board said that confidence fell to its lowest level since March and that its index had fallen 20 percent in three months.
 
Dollar Changes the Equation
 That is the kind of bad news that has been good for the bond market recently. But not yesterday. The reason is that the drop in confidence also brought the dollar lower initially, and that scared traders more than enough to offset the initial boost from the Conference Board report.
"We got ourselves into an unfortunate trap where bad news seems to cut both ways," said Stephen Slifer, financial market economist at Lehman Brothers.
In late trading, the prices of bonds and notes were off modestly across the board, giving up the gains they made in the morning, even though the dollar managed to stop its decline and end a smidgen higher in New York.
The auction of $15 billion in new two-year notes also did not go too well. Demand was not strong and the average yield of 4.30 percent was 21 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above where the yield was in the preauction, or when-issued, market last week, before the decline in the dollar pulled the bond market down with it.
 
Yield Inches Higher
 In late trading yesterday, the yield on the new note had inched higher to 4.34 percent. The five-year note auction today could also be difficult, traders said, if the yield does not hold at the 5.75 percent of yesterday or even inch up a little to attract long-term investors.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was offered in late trading at 9712/32 , down 10/32 to yield 7.47 percent, up from 7.44 percent Monday. The 10-year bond was also off 10/32 to yield 6.72 percent, up from 6.68 percent. Shorter maturities were also off for the day.
 
Foreign Bonds
 Bond markets in Britain, France and Italy fell sharply yesterday as several new opinion polls raised doubts about whether French voters would approve the Maastricht Treaty. That pact outlines the steps Europe would take toward an integrated economy and a single currency by the end of the century.
"The markets are warming to the idea that the French may vote no," said George Magnus, chief international bond economist for S. G. Warburg Securities in London.
"It is clear that the number of undecideds has fallen, and fallen in favor of the no's." he said. "Even if there is a very slender yes vote, after a week or two Maastricht will not be retrievable."
Such a no vote, in the referendum scheduled for Sept. 20, would probably eliminate any chance that Europe could move to a unified economy in an orderly way. More important, there would be growing doubts about the future of the European Monetary System, which has brought stability to currencies. In addition, European countries' efforts to lower inflation and curb government deficits might lose their momentum.
The doubt about the outlook for the French referendum just added to the trouble bond markets already faced as the American dollar continued to decline yesterday. The dollar hit a new intraday trading low of 1.3945 marks to the dollar before it recovered to finish slightly higher in New York.
In Britain, the 10-year bond futures contract was down about 5/8 point. In France, the 10-year bond contract was off 3/4 point. In Italy, where bonds have been hit the hardest recently, the bond contract was off about a third of a point.
Both Britain and Italy have the added problem of very weak currencies that are threatening to breech the bottom of their trading limits in the European Monetary system. If this happens, it is likely that both countries would have to raise interest rates, a fear that is also troubling their bond markets.
In Germany, bonds held steady, in part because that market is one where the uncertainty about the dollar and the doubts about the Maastricht treaty is having comparatively little effect. The markets that are suffering the most are those where there is the most chance of higher interest rates or a currency devaluation because of the dollar's decline. A devaluation is an alternative to raising interest rates.
The opinion poll that rocked the markets was one for Paris Match magazine, showing the treaty being rejected by a 51-to-49 percent margin. Although several other polls released later in the day showed narrow support for the treaty, investors seemed to conclude that even a close vote for the treaty would set back the move to a unified Europe.
Following is the result from the Treasury's two-year note auction yesterday:

HEADLINE: Cultural 'Experiment' Changes Name at 60

 BODY:
In 1932, when a young couple in Syracuse began a program to bring people of different cultures together through one-to-one citizen exchanges, they called it the Experiment in International Living.
Sixty years and thousands of successful exchanges later, it is no longer an experiment. Not only does the organization have millions of alumni worldwide,but it also now administers 260 different programs in 67 countries. The Experiment's directors thus took the occasion of its 60th anniversary yesterday to announce a name change; it will be called World Learning Inc. 
 The nonprofit organization, based in Brattleboro, Vt., administers programs worldwide, including higher-education courses in international studies, management training and languages; an au pair program that uses families' needs for child-care helpers as a way to foster citizen exchanges; semester-abroad programs for college students in 35 countries; scholarships for inner city high school students to live with families abroad, and international development programs, like an AIDS prevention and control project in Uganda.
A 1932 camping trip to Europe with 23 other young adults led Donald and Leslie Watt to pioneer the concept of "home stays" among people of different countries. In 1961, the Kennedy Administration called on the organization to help develop the Peace Corps. The Experiment's president, Frank G. Boyce, served as the first director of the Peace Corps' division of private and international organizations.

HEADLINE: Nassau Clerk Agrees to Timetable for Clearing Backlog

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Nassau County Clerk's office, showing the first signs of overcoming long delays in recording documents, signed a consent decree today with the County Bar Association pledging to bring its work up to date within three months.
The agreement promises to remedy backlogs in granting index numbers and entering court judgments that lawyers complained were hindering their work in Nassau County. 
 In addition, court cases more than four years old, which had been off limits to lawyers because of a shortage of employees to retrieve the case files, would now be provided within three weeks, said A. Thomas Levin, the past president of the bar association who sued the County Clerk, Harold W. McConnell, over the backlogs.
 
'Exasperating' Negotiations
 Mr. Levin, who described negotiations on the agreement as "time-consuming and exasperating," said the changes would still allow the clerk's office some delays in performing its duties.
"They won't be the outstanding county clerk's office in the nation," Mr. Levin said, "but they'll at least be average."
In an era of dwindling tax revenues and a recession, the County Clerk's office has become a symbol of government ineptitude. Millions of dollars in undeposited mortgage and transfer taxes remain stuffed in envelopes at the same time that budget shortfalls have forced the county to move to double its mortgage recording tax to 2 percent.
Today's consent decree, which would take effect after approval by the Board of Supervisors next month, addresses only the office's court-related operations. It came after a State Supreme Court justice ruled that the clerk's office was not meeting its obligations in a timely fashion. Failure to comply with the consent decree could lead to a contempt of court citation for Mr. McConnell.
A separate section of the clerk's office responsible for recording mortgages and collecting related taxes and fees, which lost a separate lawsuit by the mortgage industry, would not be affected by the agreement. But officials at the New York State Land Title Association, which brought that suit, said they hoped the 25-week delay in recording mortgages would be reduced.
Michael L. Hopkins, a lawyer representing the County Clerk's office, said the targets in today's consent decree were "attainable and doable."
While nobody was available at the County Clerk's office today to describe what steps were being taken to reduce the backlog, estimated at 50,000 unrecorded mortgages alone, Mr. Hopkins said a new computer system and an employee-training program were already cutting delays.
"These are all things that had been worked toward well before the onset of any litigation," he said. "The thing really is moving along swimmingly."
The agreement would eliminate a current 48-day backlog for index numbers by Oct. 1 and would cut a half-year delay in entering court judgments to five days by Dec. 1.
 
'It's Embarrassing'
 By Dec. 1, the clerk's office would also deliver files of cases more than four years old within a week. Until today, the County Clerk's office routinely denied requests for those files, citing a lack of personnel to retrieve them from storage in Hempstead. Many of the cases were still unsettled, and the files for others were needed to enforce court judgments or to aid in subsequent litigation.
Benjamin Zwirn, the Democratic Supervisor of North Hempstead, said he was not encouraged by the agreement. "It's embarrassing that the lawsuit settlement calls for them to not bring it up to date but to only reduce the backlog by a couple of weeks," he said.
Mr. Zwirn, who had complained that millions of dollars in mortgage taxes and fees due North Hempstead were caught up in the backlog at the clerk's office, had petitioned Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to use his constitutional authority to remove Mr. McConnell from office.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harold W. McConnell, the Nassau County Clerk, who has been sued over backlogs in the entering of court judgments. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)
