HEADLINE: With Business Adrift, Marinas Cut Their Fees

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., Aug. 21

 BODY:
It's been what Eliot Howell delicately terms a very quiet summer at Corrigan's Yacht Yard and Marine Sales on the Shinnecock Canal.
Slips have gone begging, even though rates are down about 20 percent. Rain has washed out weekend after weekend. Even on sunny days, fewer boats venture out, and often only for short trips. 
 "We are not a ghost town, but usage is down rather dramatically," said Mr. Howell, the marina's owner. "Basically, between the weather and the recession, people are just not using boats the way they did in the past."
Many marina operators are telling similar stories of a multibillion-dollar industry that seemed to have no limits five years ago, but now is hitting bottom.
With waiting lists for dock space suddenly a thing of the past and boat owners shopping for bargains, operators are scrambling as never before to attract customers with lower rates. "There is no question that slip prices are lower," said Ray Bovich, the president of the Connecticut Marine Trades Council. "The operators realize that this is a marketplace based on discretionary income."
Seasonal slip rentals range from $35 to $75 a foot, industry officials and marina operators said. Dick True, executive secretary of the Empire State Marine Trades Association said prices had dropped as low as $25 on inland waterways. The season is from April 1 to Nov. 15.
 
'Too Many Slips'
 For some, adjustments have come too late. Since 1989, the shrinking market has pushed scores of marina operators into bankruptcy and many others to the brink.
"The trend all over New York, Connecticut, New Jersey and Rhode Island is too many slips, too many marinas," said John Brewer, the president of the Brewer Yacht Yard Group, which owns 13 marinas in five northeastern states.
The marina industry is big business in the region. Trade associations say there are about 1,200 commercial marinas in New York, 450 in New Jersey and 200 in Connecticut.
The marinas hit hardest by the recession, operators say, are the ones that also sold boats. When the new-boat market collapsed, dealers were left with finance costs for huge inventories they could not move. "The days of Sea Rays and Bayliners being produced like Fords and Chevrolets are gone," Mr. Brewer said.
A 10 percent Federal luxury tax on boats costing more than $100,000 has held sales flat, dealers complain, even as it has forced boat manufacturers out of business. The tax applies to the portion of the purchase price in excess of $100,000.
The National Marine Manufacturers Association in Chicago says the tax, which took effect in 1989, put 20,000 people out of work.
Marina operators also complain that they became a target for a spate of user fees just as the industry began its slide. In Connecticut, for example, Mr. Bovich said seven new taxes have been imposed on recreational boating since July 1989. He said these included a 6 percent state tax on labor and repairs, slip fees and winter storage.
In addition, many boat buyers attracted by easy bank credit during the 1980's got caught by the recession in the 1990's and no longer have boats to use.
"A lot of the banks went ga-ga, and now they are eating a lot of repossessions," said Mr. True, of the Empire State Marine Trades Association.
But repossessions only partly explain a mystery marina operators are brooding over. "The question is, where did all the boats go?" said Mr. Howell.
One answer may be that operating costs are keeping many boats out of the water entirely, or at least closer to port.
 
High Cost of Gasoline
 "Long trips are not doable in this economy," said Patricia Appey of Sayville, L.I., a manager for a franchising company.
Mrs. Appey and her husband, Carl, a semiretired computer consultant, rent a slip for their 38-foot Egg Harbor cruiser at Corrigan's, but have thought twice this year about filling its 300-gallon tank with gasoline that costs more than $1 a gallon.
The Appeys' traveling companions, Susan and Allan Schule, also of Sayville, took a trip this year in their 34-foot Silverton from Corrigan's to Newport, R.I., where Mrs. Schule said she was surprised to see how many restaurants and shops had changed hands or gone out of business since their last visit two years ago. She said there was also no problem finding a slip at a marina that once required reservations three months in advance.
"It was sad," said Mrs. Schule, who works as a secretary for her husband, an insurance agent. "It just wasn't as crowded as it used to be."
In their struggle to survive, marina operators are expanding repair and maintenance service, scheduling special events, and adding amenities like swimming pools and tennis courts to make their marinas into destinations, not merely departure points.
"Amenities are the key," said George F. Van Zevern, the editor and publisher of Marine-Dock Age, an industry trade journal. "You have to make the marina more than a storage depot for boats. You have to play up the family concept."
Boat owners rent dock space by the foot. For example, the owner of a 20-foot boat renting a slip at $50 a foot would pay $1,000 for the season. Boat owners pay marinas separately for winter storage, taking the boat in and out of the water, maintenance, repairs and gasoline. Some marinas charge extra for amenities like swimming pools or tennis courts.
 
Then Came the Rain
 Jeffery L. Strong, owner of Strong's Marina in Mattituck, L.I., said he combined lower slip fees with the scheduling of six "fun-type events" to lure boaters and their families this summer. A result, he said, was an increase in slip rentals over last year. Mr. Strong said he slashed the seasonal fee for a 20-foot boat to $750, from $1,400.
There are limits, however. "When they cut the slip fees, they are cutting their own throats," Mr. True said.
Industry spokesmen are sounding an upbeat note, saying that a rise in boat sales this spring heralded the start of a recovery that faltered only because of summer rain.
But this rainy season, coming on the heels of a 1991 season acknowledged as the industry's worst ever, optimism has been hard to come by.
At the Peconic Yacht Basin in Riverhead, L.I., the manager, Douglas J. Riemer, said nonstop rain on the weekend of Aug. 15 and 16 set a record at the 130-slip marina, which opened nine years ago. "We didn't sell one gallon of gas," said Mr. Riemer. "Four bags of ice and no gas; 1992 makes 1991 look good."
 
Some Are Doing Well
 Jack Weinberg, the dockmaster of the New London (Conn.) City Pier, said visiting yachts have been in short supply. "Last summer we had a lot of big boats that were on their way from Florida to Cape Cod," he said. "This year we never saw them."
Still, some marina operators report they are doing well. Dennis L. Snow, the owner of the Mystic Shipyard in Mystic, Conn., said he suspected a rise in transient visitors was explained by the newly opened Foxwoods Casino on the Mashantucket Pequot Reservation in nearby Ledyard.
"The weather was like dumping another recession on us," said Allan Davidson, the owner of the Green Cove Marina in Brick, N.J. "Otherwise we would have seen some positive things."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The recession and a summer of dismal weather have dealt a harsh blow to the multibillion-dollar marina industry. Eliot Howell, top, the owner of Corrigan's Yacht Yard in Hampton Bays, said that boat use was down "rather dramatically." Robert Garland, who was laid off from his job as a marine technician last month, washes and waxes boats at Corrigan's, but he is finding that work is still in short supply. (Photographs by Lois Raimondo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bank Yields On Accounts Decrease

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money-market accounts and certificates of deposit were squeezed in the latest period ended today, The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication, indicated.
But a closer look shows money-market accounts are down a bit more than C.D.'s. This is because the money-market accounts reflected recent market trends for short-term rates before the weakened dollar drove the short-term rates up again. That rise was not that significant, however, because rates have remained at historic lows. 
 On Monday, at the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, rates rose for the first time in three weeks. Many interest- rate watchers consider the auction a fairly reliable barometer of how banks may eventually set rates for depositors in the weeks ahead.
The average rate at auction for a three-month bill climbed 4 basis points, to 3.14 percent, while for a six-month bill, the rate rose 6 basis points, to 3.24 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Some analysts speculate that rates will continue to slide through Labor Day; by then, the Federal Reserve will have had two months to assess the impact of its last cut in the discount rate on July 2. The discount rate is the interest the Fed charges banks for loans.
According to analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor, the last rate cut neither encouraged consumers and business to borrow, nor led banks to lend money more readily. Thus, some analysts believe that the Fed may be forced to ease credit further. But the current weakness in the dollar argues against such a Fed easing, and some analysts say the Fed could be forced to raise rates to support the dollar.
In the latest week, at New York-area banks, including commercial and savings, the combined average yield on a money-market account fell 3 basis points, to 3 percent, the yield on three-month certificates stabilized at 3.04 percent, and a six-month certificate slipped 1 basis point, to 3.24 percent.
At commercial banks, the cuts were mixed, with an average money- market account yield down 2 basis points, to 2.84 percent; a three-month certificate up 1 basis point, to 2.91 percent, and a six-month certificate unchanged at 3.07 percent.
Savings banks moved aggressively this week, cutting money-market accounts an average 4 basis points, to 3.16 percent. They sliced 1 basis point off the three-month C.D., to 2.91 percent, minor compared with the 5-basis-point cut the previous week. For a six-month C.D., the average yield slipped 3 basis points, to 3.41 percent.
For New York-area yields, the largest adjustments were at Carteret Savings in New Jersey, which pared 27 basis points from its money-market account, to 3.29 percent, and at Astoria Federal Savings, which cut the three-month C.D. 11 basis points, to 3.19 percent, and the six-month C.D. 15 basis points, to 3.25 percent.
Outside the New York market, the yields at 20 large banks were unchanged to slightly down, with an average bank money-market account holding at 2.9 percent and a six-month C.D. down 2 basis points, to 3.12 percent.

HEADLINE: Banks Planning to Lend To Aid Florida Cleanup

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Florida's largest banks said yesterday that they were ready to play a big role in financing the cleanup of South Florida in the aftermath of Hurricane Andrew.
The First Union National Bank and Barnett Banks Inc. announced that they would each provide $1 billion in loans to businesses and communities in the areas hit by the storm. 
 Nationsbank Inc. said it was preparing a program similar to the one carried out by its predecessor, the NCNB Corporation, after Hurricane Hugo devastated South Carolina three years ago. That $1.35 billion program included expedited loan approvals, preferential rates and flexible, tailored repayment terms to rebuild homes and businesses.
And Sun Banks Inc., the Florida subsidiary of Sun Trust Banks Inc., said it would provide customers as much assistance as necessary.
 
Lift to the Economy
 Bankers at these institutions emphasized that business considerations were not the primary motive in announcing the programs. But they acknowledged that the infusion of money needed for the cleanup could provide a needed lift to the South Florida economy.
"Nobody wants a disaster to generate business," Russ Hoadley, a spokesman for Barnett Banks, said in a telephone interview. "But we learned from our colleagues in South Carolina after Hugo and in California after the earthquakes that your customers really remember how you treated them during and immediately after one of these events. You can win 'em or you can lose 'em for a long time as a result of how you behave."
Banks in Flordida, like many big institutions, are flush with cash because of slack loan demand during the recession, tightened lending practices and heightened Federal regulation.
Early estimates of the damage ranged as high as $20 billion. Most of the destruction was in Dade County, which includes Miami and areas south of the city most devastated by the storm. The wreckage left on Florida's west coast around Naples as Andrew swept into the Gulf of Mexico was relatively minor.
 
More Time Needed
 Bankers and economists emphasized that it would be some time before the true cost of the storm was known.
"I have talked to people in Tallahassee who say they don't know where people are getting these estimates," said Tom Cunningham, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta. "People won't know for some time how much damage was done. But the number will be big."
John Nabors, an executive vice president and head of credit administration at Sun Banks in Orlando, said his bank had not yet formulated any formal hurricane-related lending program. But the bank has a long history of responding to these sorts of disasters, he said.
"We have been through a lot of hurricanes since we set up here in 1934, and have a track record of providing assistance to our customers, be it $1 billion or $2 billion," he said.
As in much of the country, the recession had crimped loan demand in South Florida, Mr. Nabors and other bankers said. But in the wake of the hurricane, that condition is almost certain to change. And banks, which have been loading up on Treasury securities instead of making new loans for the last year or two, are in excellent shape to respond.
"There is a lot of liquidity in the banking system," Mr. Hoadley at Barnett Banks said. "But we would much rather have a surge in loan demand caused by a robust economy" than a disaster.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Gains in Vehicle Sales Are Less Than Expected

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks built in North America rose a disappointing 10.2 percent in mid-August, compared with a weak period last year. The increase fell far short of the recovery that auto makers had been expecting.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 6.2 million, up from 5.7 million in the first third of the month but well below the 7.0 million level that would herald the stirrings of robust demand. 
 "Clearly, we've seen the rate slipping for the last couple of periods, and that's consistent with other signals in the economy like the weak employment numbers and the low levels of consumer confidence," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York.
 
 
Strength in Truck Sales
 All percentage changes are adjusted to reflect the average daily selling rate, which depends on the number of selling days in each reporting period. There were nine selling days in the latest period and eight last year.
Domestic car sales for the 10-day period that ended on Aug. 20 edged down six-tenths of a percent, to 160,595, from the 143,541 sold in mid-August 1991.
Light-truck sales rose a robust 27 percent, to 130,245, from 91,131 a year earlier. Strong light-truck sales tend to lead the auto industry out of recessions, an important reason that auto makers have been expecting a gain in car sales.
Over all, domestic vehicle sales for the period rose to 290,840, from 234,672 last year. Vehicles are considered domestically made if they are produced in Canada and Mexico, as well as the United States.
The General Motors Corporation continued to struggle, with its car sales falling 7 percent, to 63,585. Only Cadillac and Saturn posted increases among G.M.'s car divisions. G.M.'s light-truck sales, however, rose 19.3 percent, to 48,506, mostly because of sharp increases for full-size pickups.
The Ford Motor Company strengthened its share of the American automotive market with double-digit increases in cars and light trucks. Sales of Ford's domestically built cars rose 13.7 percent, to 48,569, while the company's light-truck sales rose 36.7 percent, to 44,418.
Ford's Mercury Sable, Mercury Topaz and Mercury Grand Marquis sold strongly during the period, as did the Ford Taurus, Crown Victoria, Thunderbird, Escort and Tempo. Sales of pickup trucks and Explorer sport-utility vehicles were also sharply higher.
The Chrysler Corporation's sales of domestically built vehicles were estimated by Ward's Automotive Reports at 41,300, up 7.3 percent from 34,200 last year. Chrysler reports its sales on a monthly basis only.
The Honda Motor Company reported a 16.5 percent drop in sales to 14,080 cars, from 14,983 last year.
 
 
Toyota Sales Are Up
 The Toyota Motor Corporation said sales of Corolla and Camry models built in North America rose 9.8 percent, to 12,289, from 9,946 in mid-August last year. Toyota also sold 2,857 domestically built compact pickups, which it did not produce in North America a year earlier.
The Mazda Motor Corporation sold 2,741 domestically built cars and light trucks, up from 1,847 a year earlier.
Car dealers across the nation noticed inconsistent buying trends, adding to evidence that a sustained recovery has yet to materialize. Tom Chergey, sales manager for Fiermonti Oldsmobile-Saab in Concord, N.H., said, "I think my domestic sales are spotty because it's an election year, and no one knows what is going to happen."
But John Wiegers, general manager of Bob Allen Ford in Overland Park, Kan., said the preference for American-made vehicles "is still near the top of priority lists."
Bill Talbott, president of Greenbrier Motors, a Chrysler-Dodge dealership in Lewisburg, W.Va., said customers had wanted to trade for new cars for some time, but had not done so until recently "because they probably have caught up with their debt."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Prices Stage a Retreat As Hurricane Fears Wane

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Oil prices retreated yesterday from sharp gains posted the day before as fears receded that Hurricane Andrew would wreak lasting damage on oil rigs and refineries along the Gulf Coast.
 "We're still at the mercy of the hurricane," said Tom Blakeslee, analyst at Pegasus Econometric. But he said other factors, including increased OPEC crude oil production and seasonal increases in North Sea output, pointed to lower prices. 
 "The hurricane probably won't do lasting damage to oil refineries so the market couldn't sustain the short-covering effort," said Jim Steel, an analyst with Refco.
 October crude oil sank 39 cents, to $21.15 a barrel, giving back most of Monday's 46-cent gain. September unleaded gasoline dropped 0.60 cent, to 62.13 cents a gallon, and September heating oil fell 1.08 cents, to 58.23 cents a gallon.
Cotton prices also receded after posting the maximum gain on Monday, when traders feared that hurricane-driven rains might swamp the Mississippi Delta crops.
 October cotton, which jumped 2 cents a pound Monday at the New York Cotton Exchange, fell 1.23 cents to close at 58.95 cents a pound.
 Grain futures were slightly higher, with the hurricane seen as an equalizing factor: more rain could help some crops while the storm may damage others.
 State crop reports issued Monday afternoon showed the expected record corn crop was still behind in development, making it vulnerable if an early freeze strikes.
 September wheat rose 4 cents, to $3.25 a bushel; September corn added 1.4 cents, to $2.26 1/4 a bushel; September soybeans firmed 2.25 cents, to $5.62 a bushel, and September oats lost three-quarters of a cent, to $1.29 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Sifting for Profits in Keating's Desert Monument

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
Sprawled across 130 desert acres on the southern slope of Camelback Mountain, the $300 million Phoenician resort is one of the most expensive hotels ever built. The guests have tea amid a $1.7 million art collection, play on a top-notch irrigated golf course and swim in a pool that is lined in mother-of-pearl tile. Some travel magazines rate it among the top resort hotels in the world.
"It's a spectacular property," said Saul F. Leonard, hotel consultant based in Los Angeles. "But was it built to make money or as a monument?" 
 He and others suggest that the founder, Charles H. Keating Jr., caused this great 580-room Phoenician to rise out of the Sonoran Desert as a kind of monument to himself. And this, they say, is what it has become.
 
Glitter May Not Mean Profits
 Mr. Keating is now serving a 10-year sentence in a California prison for his role as a principal architect of the nation's savings and loan scandal, brought on in large measure by excessive and overextended real estate dealings.
The Phoenician, with its glitter and opulence -- and fame -- is attracting tourists in relatively large numbers. But the question is whether, given its enormous costs, it can ever reach profitability.
The hotel's troubles date almost to its opening, on Oct. 1, 1988. Within five months the Federal Government found itself the unproud owner, taking it over after Mr. Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan and the parent company, the American Continental Corporation, declared bankruptcy.
Soon after that, Federal agents and Phoenix plainclothes police officers staged a predawn raid on both hotels and sealed off Mr. Keating's office in the Phoenician. They fired him and discharged 25 employees, including Mr. Keating's wife, Mary Elaine, two daughters and two sons-in-law.
Last year, eager to be rid of the property, the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency set up to take over failed savings institutions and their properties, sold the Government's 55 percent interest in the Phoenician and in a sister hotel in Phoenix, the Crescent, for a total of $111.5 million. Mr. Keating had built the Crescent, for business travelers, in 1987 for $50 million.
The buyer was the Government of Kuwait. At first glance, considering the initial cost of the two hotels, the Kuwaitis might again seem to have become the beneficiary of not insubstantial United States aid.
The Kuwaitis are generally regarded as shrewd investors, and they are hardly strangers to the desert. But some analysts now doubt that they can ever extract profits from the Phoenician.
Not that the hotel has proved unpopular. In fact, its notoriety is thought by some to be an advantage in that respect.
"Our occupancy rate year-to-date is averaging over 70 percent," said Hans D. Turnovszky, the hotel's president and general manager. That compares with a 66.1 average occupancy rate for all resorts in the United States last year, according to Smith Travel Research.
"Usually it would take years and a tremendous amount of money for an independent property to get the kind of name recognition the Phoenician got for free," said Vicki Bhandari, the senior hospitality consultant for Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a Phoenix accounting firm that specializes in resort hotels. "But the Phoenician was helped by all the reports about the savings and loan troubles."
Four hours after Mr. Keating was dismissed, Mr. Turnovszky was installed at the Phoenician, arriving fresh from managing the Lodge at Vail in Vail, Colo. In all, he has managed hotels and resorts on four continents,
From the beginning, as part of his plan to restore the hotel's image, Mr. Turnovszky refused to discuss Mr. Keating. "When anyone asked, I said: 'It's not my problem. It's the Government's problem,' " Mr. Turnovszky said. "I never met the man."
 
Working for the Kuwaitis
 Mr. Keating, before his empire unraveled, had already sold 45 percent of the Phoenician and Crescent to the London-based Kuwait Investment Office for $173.6 million. That office, a little-known arm of the Kuwaiti Government, handles the country's portfolio of foreign holdings, which has been estimated at between $80 billion and $100 billion.
The investment office has usually avoided the limelight, except when it bought a 21.6 percent stake in British Petroleum after privatization of the oil company in 1987 -- and was subsequently ordered by the British Government to scale back its investment to 9.9 percent.
As a matter of policy, the Kuwaitis themselves refuse to discuss any aspect of their investment in the Arizona hotels. Mr. Turnovszky says he sends his employers monthly reports and flies to London to attend quarterly meetings of the nine-person board, of which he is a member.
"They are very interesting to work with," he said of the Kuwaitis, "because they are very astute and knowledgeable, and they treat business as business." The Kuwaitis, he says, believe that the Phoenician is a good investment and that Arizona is a growing market.
Under Mr. Turnovszky, the hotel has been aiming for a 50 percent mix of business and leisure travelers, and more foreign guests. Foreign visitors now account for 15 percent of the resort's total business, up from 2 percent a few years ago, thanks in part to sales agents in many countries and to its membership in the Leading Hotels of the World Ltd., an association of luxury hotels that share a worldwide reservations system.
But are luxury resort hotels, surrounded by other luxury resort hotels, necessarily good investments -- even in a revitalized economy? Especially one that to break even, Mr. Turnovszky says, must fill 60 percent of its rooms each night at an average rate of $450?
Not everyone thinks so.
Edward Watkins, the editor of Lodging Hospitality magazine, calls the Phoenician "a boondoggle from the beginning." In 10 years, he said, "I don't think it will be the quintessential Phoenix resort, or at the top of the market."
Room rates range from $280 to $415 a day in winter, single or double occupancy, to suites from $775 to $1,300. Both presidential suites are often occupied -- at a cost of $4,000 a night in high season.
But most hotels here, including the Phoenician, reduce their rates about 50 percent in the summer, when temperatures soar well above 100 degrees.
The daily room rate at Arizona's 20 leading resorts last year averaged only $121, according to Kenneth Leventhal & Company. Leventhal does not break out rates for individual hotels, but one analyst knowledgeable about Phoenix hotels said the Phoenician, whose financial numbers are closely guarded, probably averages $180 a night, or about 40 percent below the precious break-even point.
"The problem for the Phoenician," the analyst said, "is that there are too many resorts here chasing too few guests."

HEADLINE: Jobs Decrease In Electronics

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA, Calif., Aug. 25

 BODY:
The American Electronics Association said today that the electronics industry had lost 15,000 jobs in the second quarter, bringing total losses for the first half of the year to 55,000.
On June 30, employment in the United States electronics industry was 2.335 million, or 2.3 percent less than the 2.39 million reported on Dec. 31, the association said. 
 Its chairman, Robert Gilbertson, said that this was the smallest job loss in the industry since the second quarter of 1990.
The segment of the industry with the largest percentage drop in this year's second quarter was search and navigation equipment, which reported a 2.1 percent decline.
Semiconductor makers posted the largest gain, with an increase of 4.3 percent.
The figures are based on data provided by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics and are subject to revision.

HEADLINE: Net Off for Bayer of Germany

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Bayer A.G., inventor of the Bayer aspirin, reported a big drop in profits today, but said it could not issue its figures in the United States, where a court ruling prevents the company from operating under its own name.
 Bayer said second-quarter earnings fell 11.5 percent, to 942 million German marks, or $662.1 million. That compared with 1.07 billion marks, or $748.6 million, a year earlier. 
 Bayer, one of the world's biggest chemical companies, blamed a sputtering world economy and a weaker dollar for the results.
 "This fall in earnings was caused by continued pressure on prices, especially in the sectors geared to the manufacturing industry," Bayer said in the report, "and the situation was exacerbated by adverse exchange-rate movements."
 The company distributed the results worldwide, but excluded the United States because of a ruling handed down in July by a Federal court in New York on an issue that dates back to World War I.
 "We are not allowed to use the Bayer name in any way or any form in communication with the general public," said a Bayer spokesman, Thomas Reinert.
 Bayer's United States assets -- including its trademark and the famous Bayer aspirin label -- were confiscated during World War I and auctioned off to Sterling Products Inc. for $5.31 million.
 The Bayer trademark now belongs to Sterling Winthrop Inc., a subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Company.
 During the 1950's, Bayer said it began to rebuild its business in the United States under the name Rheinchem Inc. through joint ventures and acquisitions.
 It paid Sterling Drug Inc. $25 million for limited use of the name Bayer in the United States six years ago in a deal that allowed it to sell nonpharmaceutical and nonconsumer products through Bayer USA Inc.
 "But then Sterling got the impression that we were overstepping the rights accorded to us under the 1986 agreement," Mr. Reinert said.
 Following unsuccessful negotiations in 1990, through which Bayer tried to get back full use of its trademark, Sterling sued the German company.
 Bayer said the United States District Court in Manhattan ruled on July 22 that it had violated Sterling's ownership rights to the Bayer name and trademark in the United States.
 Bayer has appealed the court ruling, and industry sources say the appeal could succeed on the ground of the First Amendment right to free speech. A spokesman for Sterling Winthrop in New York had no immediate comment today.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:
New for Bobby Brown
Four years ago the singer Bobby Brown released his "Don't Be Cruel" (MCA) and changed the black-pop firmament, relegating older styles to the pop dustbin. Mr. Brown and two other acts, Keith Sweat and Guy (and their producers), came up with new jack swing, a style that mixes hip-hop rhythms and pastiche with soul singing and fervor. Mr. Brown not only sold six million copies of his album but also got himself arrested in Columbus, Ga., for lewdness during a performance. Since then he has formed his own record label, fathered some children, lavishly married the singer Whitney Houston (who is pregnant) and toured.
But four years is a long time, and in pop terms Mr. Brown, who had built an audience of both black and white teen-agers, has to start all over again with his new album, "Bobby" (MCA). Second albums after huge successes have been wilting recently; just ask Hammer, Slaughter, Firehouse and Wilson Phillips. At this point, is Mr. Brown a player at all? 
 MCA records has shipped a million or so copies of the record but has been cautious in its marketing. Instead of forcing retailers to buy huge quantities, inflating sales figures, the company laid off.
"This is a major recession we're in," said Jonathan Coffino, the senior vice president of sales at MCA. "It's a radically different economic environment than when 'Don't Be Cruel' was released." He said that he thought the record would do extremely well and that the label was releasing a couple of singles from it "to get it really going."
"The only people that don't have to do that anymore are country acts," Mr. Coffino said, "and that's because their demographic is so huge."
The record company held listening sessions around the country for radio, retail and the press. The first single, "Humpin' Around," was released to black and top 40 stations simultaneously to try to capture both black and white audiences. This week in Billboard, the single had already broken into both the rhythm-and-blues top 10 and the general top 10. Still, buyers at some larger chains report lukewarm pre-release interest in the album, saying that both Eric Clapton's "Unplugged" and a Christmas album by Garth Brooks were generating more interest.
"A lot of radio stations are adding 'Humpin' Around' to their play lists," Lew Garrett, the vice president of buying at the Camelot record chain, said of Mr. Brown. "But he's been away a long time. Do kids still remember or care? Urban audiences are good about that, they'll remember him. But the key is whether white kids remember or care. The pop audience is what took him to six million, and whether that can happen again is subject to debate. Given the record on follow-up albums, kids' attention spans are pretty limited."
But more than anything, big records depend on music. Mr. Brown's "Bobby" is where black pop is today, a nearly perfect example of pop songwriting and production. With contributions from the best producers working, including Teddy Riley, the head architect of new jack swing, and the team of L. A. Reid and Babyface, the album has a rhythmic urgency that's helped out by distinct melodies that radio will love. The album moves from the hard funk of the lead single, "Humpin' Around," to the ballads of " 'Til the End of Time," and duets with Ms. Houston and Debra Winans. On "Don't Be Cruel," Mr. Brown sang as if he was a better dancer than singer, which he was. But he has improved and moved from boy to man. There's a passion and urgency in his voice that makes the standard pop love stories seem believable.
"I wanted to make an album that was vocally better," he said. "The album took a long time, nearly a year to make, because it took a lot of planning, because I wanted to keep appealing to a wider audience. And I wanted to create new ideas, to find a new trend, a new sound that would be appealing to my audience. That's the toughest part of making a record, picking the right songs, the right sounds.
"But a lot of things have changed in the last four years. Grab your seat: I've grown and matured. I've become real appreciative of the things I have. I don't want to lose focus, which I could have, because there are so many temptations on the road. Though if I had stayed at home and never become anybody, there'd probably be more. I've gotten married, opened up a studio in Atlanta, started a record label. I'm still myself, but Whitney has really lent me a lot."
 
New Jill Swing
 No woman has really made it big in new jack swing; it's been an exclusively male domain. Enter Mary J. Blige, whose recent first album, "What's the 411?" (Uptown/MCA), is racing up the charts on the strength of the first single, the wistful "You Remind Me." Ms. Blige (pronounced as in "oblige"), a native of New York, found her circuitous way to Uptown records with help from the singer Jeff Redd. Andre Harrell, the head of Uptown and one of the industry's most acute talent scouts, having signed Guy, Jodeci and others, saw what he wanted immediately.
"She sang for me in my office," Mr. Harrell said. "I thought that she could be a major female soul singer. I thought she could be the queen of hip-hop soul, which is exactly what she is becoming."
"What's the 411?" has some fine singing on it, surprising in a genre not known for fine singing. Ms. Blige, almost inevitably, comes from a gospel background, and she imbues her singing with loss and longing.
"I've been singing in church, around the house and in school," she said. "I sang in the choir in my church in Yonkers, I sang lead and I could never figure out why the members wanted me to sing lead, but I did it."
There are thousands of churchgoing virtuoso singers, but they don't all have Ms. Blige's sense of style or attitude. She's an around-the-way girl, a hip-hop culturist, and it shows in her demeanor.
"I'm not sure why there hasn't been another new jack swing woman, really," she said. "There's nothing wrong with being hard-core. I grew up in a neighborhood where that's all there was. If people are looking for long dressed and high-heel shoes, they'd better look somewhere else."
Mr. Harrell has an idea why women have been so scarce in the genre.
"There hasn't been a woman with the voice and the life style and the attitude of an inner city young adult girl. I had one other girl I signed five years ago, but we couldn't get along. I had my eye set on developing the right girl, and Mary was just right. She embodied the attitude: cool, humble, soulful. She reflects the reality of today's black girl, so she'll sell."

HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Marian Burros

 BODY:
THE story of food irradiation bears a striking resemblance to the story of silicone breast implants: proponents are ignoring the risks while promoting the benefits.
The crucial difference is that many scientists are trying to prevent approval of the irradiation process until its safety has been tested to everyone's satisfaction, instead of letting it go on the market first. The public, always squeamish when words connected with radioactivity are used, is not rushing to embrace irradiated foods. Last winter, a store in North Miami Beach, Fla., received widespread publicity when it put irradiated strawberries on the market, but it is not clear how well they sold. 
 Irradiation is hardly a new process; it has been around for 40 years but its prominence in food rises with each Government decision that advances its use. The Food and Drug Administration has declared irradiation, which is the bombing of food with gamma rays, safe for preserving certain foods; the World Health Organization also says irradiated food presents no health risks. This year, the United States Department of Agriculture published proposed regulations for irradiating poultry, and a food irradiation plant has opened in Florida.
But questions that have troubled scientists and environmentalists about food irradiation have never been answered satisfactorily. No one knows whether the process creates new chemicals at levels that may be harmful, or whether the loss of nutrients from irradiation is unacceptably high, or to what extent adding more processing plants that use nuclear components increases the risk of nuclear accidents.
The proponents of food irradiation ridicule these concerns. Opponents, they say, are Luddites, the same kind of people who once opposed pasteurized milk. Proponents see the process not only as a way to extend the shelf life of perishables like strawberries without using chemicals, but also as a way to kill harmful bacteria like the salmonella in poultry, a widespread problem. (Recently a noncontroversial method to kill salmonella has proven successful in tests. It involves dipping the carcasses in a bath of water and trisodium phosphate, a chemical used in food processing.)
Groups as diverse as the Public Citizen's Health Research Group, the American Association of Retired Persons and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. have asked the Agriculture Department to withdraw its proposal until all the safety questions are answered.
No one is saying that irradiated foods are radioactive; they aren't. But the question that causes the most concern is whether irradiation results in the formation of toxic chemicals and other "radiolytic" products, created when the bombardment of the food with gamma rays breaks up some of the molecules. In the 1970's, an internal task force of the F.D.A. estimated that 10 percent of these radiolytic products might be unique to irradiated foods, but it concluded that the amounts of such toxic chemicals that are formed -- like benzene, which causes cancer -- are too small to be significant.
Not everyone agrees. In "Food Irradiation: Who Wants It?" (Thorson Publishers Inc., 1987), Tony Webb, Tim Lang and Kathleen Tucker write: "It is safest to assume that there is no safe level of exposure to such chemicals; any dose can cause the initial damage that develops into a cancer." They add, "The fact that a chemical change is small does not eliminate the risk."
The F.D.A. based its approval of irradiation on only five or six animal studies. It had some 400 to choose from but said all the rest were flawed. Dr. Donald B. Louria, chairman of the department of preventive medicine and community health at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark, said the few studies on which the agency relied were also flawed. "Taken together," Dr. Louria wrote in his critique, "these studies could not possibly establish the safety of food irradiation. Indeed, two of the studies suggest the technology is not safe."
There is still another safety question: the usual dose of radiation does not kill the bacteria that cause botulism, a particularly virulent form of food poisoning. The bacteria that cause off-odors and flavors are killed, so in those cases where an odor might warn of spoilage, that safety mechanism would be gone.
The May issue of the Berkeley Wellness Letter, published by the University of California at Berkeley, quotes an article in the September 1990 issue of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists that says the proponents of irradiation "have not produced any projections of the actual economic, or other, benefits of longer shelf life, especially in a developed country that has an abundant food supply." The Wellness Letter goes on to say: "Though it's also been claimed that irradiation will make insecticides and fungicides obsolete, there's some evidence that certain foods may be more vulnerable to the ravages of fungi and insects after irradiation."
Food safety is one consideration; loss of nutrients is another. According to the April issue of Nutrition Action, a health newsletter published by the Center for Science in the Public Interest, in one study the vitamin C content of potatoes was reduced by 50 percent after the potatoes had been given a standard dose of radiation. In another study, one-third the level of radiation permitted by the F.D.A. reduced thiamin levels in pork by 17 percent, and a normal dose of irradiation reduced thiamin levels in chicken breasts by 9 percent. Vitamin E content was also affected.
Proponents of irradiation say vitamin losses in irradiated food are comparable to those that occur in cooking. But many foods that would be irradiated, like poultry and pork, would be cooked after irradiation, further depleting vitamin levels.
In "Food Irradiation: Who Wants It?" the authors also point out that selling irradiated food as fresh is deceptive because fruits and vegetables -- irradiated or not -- lose nutrients after picking. A six-week-old irradiated strawberry, though appearing fresh, would have less nutritional value than a non-irradiated strawberry a few days old.
Even though nuclear opponents do not ordinarily become involved in nutrition issues, this time they have, since the radioactive isotopes used to irradiate food pose potential problems to plant workers and people who live near the plant. Nuclear opponents say food irradiation plants would just add to the increasing problems of nuclear-waste disposal.
Dr. Shelden Margen, professor emeritus of public health nutrition at Berkeley, said: "There are potentially serious concerns about the issues of waste disposal, engineering safety, transport of radioactive material, production of new isotopes, handling by poorly trained personnel and others we haven't even thought of yet."
Because of consumer resistance to irradiated foods, many companies, including Kraft, Conagra, Kellogg, A.& P. and Kentucky Fried Chicken, have said no to them. So have some states. New York and New Jersey have moratoriums on the sale of irradiated food, and Maine has an outright ban.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, has asked the Agriculture Department to determine the safety of irradiated foods before they are permitted on the market.

HEADLINE: AT DINNER WITH: Rob Morrow;
He's No Peevish Dr. Fleischman, But He's at Home in Bagel Town

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
ROB MORROW was looking nothing like a petulant small-town doctor as he padded in to dinner in a baggy blue suit that could have been fairly cheap or very expensive: it was hard to tell. (Expensive, it turned out. "Issey Miyake," he confessed, abashed. "I'm a clothes horse and wish I wasn't, but I am.")
Mr. Morrow seemed a bit smaller in person than he does on television, and his face was overwhelmed by a thicket of hair and a beard he had let grow between seasons of his show, "Northern Exposure." He is now in Seattle, shorn again, filming episodes for the show's third season, which begins on CBS next month. He plays Joel Fleischman, a persnickety doctor from New York forced to begin his career in a backwater Alaskan town to repay the state of Alaska for sending him through Columbia medical school. 
 The network had low expectations for the show, a throwaway that was supposed to fade as quickly as an Alaskan summer. But with its literate scripts and its slyly off-kilter characters, like the truculent hermit (Adam Arkin) who is an accomplished chef and a New Republic writer, it has become a hit, a "Twin Peaks" for normal people. Much of its charm comes from Mr. Morrow, who earned his first Emmy nomination this year and who somehow makes peevishness sexy.
No pique was in evidence as Mr. Morrow settled down at a cozy table in the back of Josephina, a restaurant near Lincoln Center, which he chose because the chef is a high-school buddy and because he likes the food, which tends to be low in fat. Cheerfully, he explained his hair.
"I have to look a certain way all year round, so when I'm not working I don't do anything to it," he said. "I don't even comb it." As for the beard: "I don't even like the way it looks." His voice was quiet and had the familiar New York cadences, but was not querulous or combative the way Dr. Fleischman's can be. When he smiled, though, his eyes crinkled at the corners in fine Fleischman fashion.
The show is filmed in Seattle and in the tiny town of Roslyn, Wash., and the parallels between fact and fiction are all too obvious. Both Mr. Morrow and Dr. Fleischman are fierce New York City partisans who long for home. (Dr. Fleischman misses the bagels, and Mr. Morrow misses "the kind of vitality you get in New York.") Both have found themselves in Pacific Coast towns where the pace is slow, the people are unfamiliar and the weather is freezing. Mr. Morrow, whose Seattle home is a rented condo with a nice view, at least has more chances to escape than his character does; he often spends weekends among actor friends in Los Angeles.
"There's a certain correlation, geographically and sociologically," between himself and Joel Fleischman, he said. "But Joel is a lot more belligerent than I would be: nasty and selfish."
And while Dr. Fleischman works hard, so does Mr. Morrow. For more than a year, he has devoted most of his spare time to a short film about a young boy and his abusive stepfather. The film, which he wrote, directed and produced, is called "The Silent Alarm," and he thinks it will be ready for next spring's film festivals.
Mr. Morrow's parents were divorced when he was growing up in Hartsdale, N.Y., and he remembers what it was like to be a child struggling to make sense of a world he couldn't control. He tries to project this sense in his film, which he made with no dialogue, explaining that children often can't articulate what they feel. "At that age, at 7, you're conscious enough to have a visceral awareness, but you're not old enough to either, A, articulate, or B, stand up for yourself," he said. Although he said it was not autobiographical, "the film presented itself to me in terms of some events I had heard about, thought about and imagined."
Mr. Morrow manages to stand up for himself now, so much so that stories portraying him as spoiled and bratty began to circulate this summer when he put off returning to the "Northern Exposure" set, holding out for a salary increase. (He was earning about $18,000 an episode.) He finally showed up, without missing any work, but the producers sued him for breach of contract and threatened to replace him.
All that was resolved in mid-July, when the lawsuit was dropped and Mr. Morrow got a raise. (How much, he wouldn't say.) It is his contention that people should remember that for much of his adult life he was unemployed and broke. "You see all those numbers about what actors make, but it's not that simple," he said. "If you amortize what I'm making over 12 years of not making any money, it's not that impressive."
Although he may seem like a friendly guy effortlessly playing a like-minded character on television, Mr. Morrow takes a serious, precise approach to his craft. Some people say his fussing and intense concentration make him a prima donna.
"I'm insecure, with all of the obvious neuroses that actors tend to have," he said. "But anyone who would consider me a prima donna doesn't understand what acting is. I'm not saying, 'Light me this way,' 'No, that's not a good angle,' 'I won't wear that color.'
"What I do is, sometimes I get upset and vehement. If someone wants me to sit and it doesn't feel right, no one can make me do it, and it causes conflicts. I don't mean from a bellicose point of view. But it does become a question, sometimes, of 'Do we waste time trying to get Rob to do it, or do we just give in and let him do it his way?' "
Mr. Morrow likes to while away the extra hours in Seattle on the golf course. He is learning tai chi from a videocassette and still feels twinges from a rotator cuff injury that he got while knee-boarding, a variation of water-skiing, more than a year ago. About to turn 30, Mr. Morrow admits to having "a great fear of death." Still, he gets a certain kick out of doing what he likes.
"As an adult, I realize if I don't like the first 50 pages of a book I don't have to finish it, and if I order a bottle of wine, I don't have to drink the whole thing," he said, ordering a bottle of wine but not drinking the whole thing, or even half. He goes to the movies all the time, often alone, but leaves early if he doesn't like it, which is most of the time. "I feel obligated to see a lot of movies because I feel a part of this business," he said, "and if the energy and focus is going to go into them, I should see them. But it's a rare movie that can transport me."
It first happened to him when he was very young and his parents took him to see "2001: A Space Odyssey."
"I just remember not having a clue what it was, but the imagery was so powerful, it tapped into a kind of spiritual place within me," he said. "I've seen it eight times." He has also seen nearly every episode of "Twilight Zone"
"They all had a little moral in them," he said.
Chatting about the mysterious differences between men and women, which he said prompted him to have his ear pierced ("I liked the kind of feminine aspect of it, even though I will never get to the point where I really understand where you are," he explained), Mr. Morrow ate some but not all of his melange-of-vegetable soup and a pasta dish.
The head chef, Louis Lanza, a classmate from Edgemont High School in Westchester, came out to catch up. Mr. Morrow likes Mr. Lanza a lot, but does not remember Edgemont High fondly. He lost interest in school completely by his senior year, dropped out, moved to Manhattan to become an actor and supported himself with a series of fledgling-actor jobs, like balloon-messenger.
With his longtime girlfriend, whom he politely refused to discuss or even name, he helped found an acting troupe called Naked Angels in 1986. Loving the theater, Mr. Morrow tried to avoid working in television, although he played some unmemorable parts, including a hunky bartender in the unsuccessful NBC series "Tattinger's."
"I said 'No, no, no,' for a couple of years, but I was so much in debt that I thought, 'I have to be an adult here,' " he said.
"Northern Exposure" seemed different: "It read like no other TV pilot I'd read," he said, "and it was not morally reprehensible."
Despite such unanticipated delights as being the host of "Saturday Night Live" this year ("It was like being Mick Jagger," he said), Mr. Morrow worries about being forever typecast as Joel Fleischman. "I was at a wedding recently, and a person who I know slightly said, 'Hey, Joel,' " he recalled. "I didn't know what to say. I don't want to be called Joel. It's not my name."
Mr. Morrow had to leave, and the taxi dropped him off at his brownstone apartment in the West 70's. He was due to leave soon for Seattle and was scrambling to get more work done on his movie. Why didn't he take a break, he was asked.
"You're talking about someone who is naturally disposed to anal-retentiveness," he said matter-of-factly, and he could well have been describing Joel Fleischman, M.D.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Baseball's Strange Bedfellows

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
LET'S try to understand this. The Chicago Cubs, owned by the Tribune Company, are in the forefront of a crusade to get Fay Vincent. One of the major reasons a group of owners wants to get Vincent is that baseball has serious economic problems, which he hasn't solved and won't let them solve by trying to bust the union.
 But the Tribune Company, which happens to have a history of taking severe positions against unions, is also the outfit that allowed the Cubs to make Ryne Sandberg the highest-paid player in baseball history. Leapfrogging over the $6 million plateau -- Bobby Bonilla had reached $5.8 million -- the Cubs signed Sandberg last March to a contract extension, effective in 1993, that will average $7.1 million a year. 
 Owners of other clubs collectively shook their heads in despair. Escalating salaries are killing them (they were unable to eliminate them via collusion) and here one of their own went bonkers. Some owners said angrily that the Cubs weren't signing a baseball player, they were signing a matinee idol: a handsome and talented television star who would attract viewers and improve the ratings for superstation WGN.
The Tribune Company, its critics said, didn't care what the Sandberg signing would do to the salary scale. In the days that George Steinbrenner executed intelligent but expensive free-agent signings, he bristled at charges that he created new salary plateaus. He always blamed someone else, saying another team got there first.
 But the Tribune Company was so far beyond everyone else, it couldn't find a scapegoat. The Sandberg signing instantly put small-market teams like the Baltimore Orioles and the Minnesota Twins at risk with their franchise players who could be free agents after this season. The Orioles have found a way to sign Cal Ripken Jr.; the Twins squandered one opportunity to sign Kirby Puckett and hope to have another. But the Tribune Company won't care if the Sandberg signing results in the Twins' loss of Puckett.
 The way some owners see it, the Tribune Company also cares more about its supersta tion than about the economic welfare of the teams its baseball team plays against. The Tribune Company cares so much about its superstation that it wants to oust the commissioner, who is trying to blunt the economic impact superstations have on the local television revenue of other clubs. But other owners ignore the Sandberg signing and the motive behind it, and they ignore the superstation effect.
 Instead of using their hands to applaud the commissioner for his efforts, these owners join hands with the company that costs them money in more ways than one. This unseemly game abounds in contradictions.
 Half of the existing National League clubs ask the commissioner to realign the league. He grants their wish and orders four teams to change divisions, bringing a lawsuit on his head and office. Now at least half of the half dozen teams are prepared to ask him to resign or face dismissal, legal or not.
 Vincent campaigns hard for new stadiums in Cleveland and San Francisco. He gives the Giants' owner, Bob Lurie, potentially critical bargaining leverage in San Francisco by telling him he can explore all of his options. Now the owners of the Indians and the Giants (who were also one of the N.L. teams urging realignment) are among his opponents.
 Peter O'Malley of the Los Angeles Dodgers and Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox, some owners say, do not care for each other (which is putting it kindly). Yet they are in the forefront of the move to get Vincent.
 O'Malley, who doesn't want to lose his West Coast rivalry with the Giants, is quoted by another owner as saying he will vote for the Giants' move to St. Petersburg, Fla., because Lurie joined the anti-Vincent faction.
 Some of the owners, at least, very likely want to get Vincent out of the way quickly so they can implement their strategy for the next round of labor negotiation: reopening their agreement with the players in December, then locking them out next spring. The union says it has heard that some owners want to shut down the game for the entire year so they can regain control over the players.
 "When this all came up with the commissioner last June and again now," Donald Fehr, the union chief said yesterday, "I asked what is it they want him to do that he won't do or what are they afraid he might do that they don't want him to do? I have heard rumors that a significant number of owners want to try to break the union."
 Before they try that, they have to break Vincent, whatever strange combination of conspirators the effort requires.

LENGTH: 632 words

HEADLINE: The World Needs An Army on Call

BYLINE: By David Boren; David Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, is chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Americans are not enthusiastic about having the United States stand alone as the policeman of the world. There is a feeling that we simply no longer have the resources, given the pressing need to rebuild our strength at home, to play that role any longer.
This does not mean, however, that Americans have been lulled by the dangerous siren song of the new isolationists. We understand more clearly than ever that our economic well-being and national security depend on developments and relationships outside our borders. 
 No American, for example, wants to allow Saddam Hussein to thwart United Nations weapons inspections and rebuild his military capability. No American can remain indifferent to the images of starvation and brutality in detention centers in Bosnia and Herzegovina; the hideous policy of "ethnic cleansing" is something many of us never expected would occur again in our lifetimes. It has filled our people with a sense of moral urgency and an overwhelming feeling that we must do something to stop it.
But while Americans want something done, they do not want to do it alone. For the United States to act, the burden must be shared. It is time to create a genuine multilateral mechanism that can deal not only with these crises but also those that inevitably lie ahead.
Instead of shrinking from the task, we should welcome the fact that we are the first generation, perhaps in centuries, to have the opportunity to act boldly in the absence of confrontation between great powers.
The opportunity for the United Nations is clear. In the aftermath of World War II, President Truman wanted to empower the new United Nations to create a new world order. Addressing the General Assembly at its opening session in October 1946, he said, "We shall press for the preparation of agreements in order that the Security Council may have at its disposal peace forces adequate to prevent acts of aggression."
That promise was never realized because of the cold war and the Soviet Union's use of its veto power on the Security Council.
But under Article 43 of the United Nations charter, the Secretary General still has the authority to ask member nations to designate military units that can be deployed in the event of a crisis "to maintain international peace and security." In June, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali asked member countries to make that authority a reality.
Richard Gardner, a professor of international law at Columbia University, proposes that 40 to 50 member nations contribute to a rapid-deployment force of 100,000 volunteers that could train under common leadership and with standardized equipment. Intelligence could also be shared to allow the United Nations to anticipate problems and take preemptive action.
It is time for us to create such a force, and the United States should take the lead in proposing it.
Of course, details would have to be worked out. The War Powers Act would have to be amended to insure that the United States does not surrender its right to final approval of committing American troops to life-threatening situations. Members of the United Nations that lack veto power in the Security Council could condition their commitment to a rapid-deployment force on the right to withdraw units for their own urgent national security interests.
Still, the existence of such a force, uniformly trained and ready to act, would go a long way toward making the "new world order" more than just a slogan. It would help discourage regional conflicts, violations of basic justice, the proliferation of weapons and international terrorism.
History tells us that periods without confrontations and military contests between great powers are rare. We must seize this moment. History will hold us accountable if we do not.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Macy to Post Positive 4th-Period Cash Flow

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
R. H. Macy & Company has told its suppliers and their financial advisers that it expects to report positive cash flow for its fourth quarter ended July 31, reversing the results of the two previous quarters.
Although Macy will not issue financial statements for the fourth quarter or for July until the end of October, it disclosed information about its liquidity and its cash flow projections in a report to agencies that monitor retailers' credit as well as to garment industry financiers and some suppliers. 
 The company said its efforts to control expenses and inventory and maintain gross-profit margins had helped counter the effects of straitened economic conditions in regions of the country where its stores were concentrated.
 
A Promising Sign
 "Higher unemployment and weaker consumer confidence, particularly in the company's strongest market areas of San Francisco, New York and Los Angeles, continued to depress the sales performance of Macy's stores in July," Diane Price Baker, Macy's senior vice president and chief financial officer, said in the report Friday.
Despite depressed sales, Ms. Baker said, Macy's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortizationwould enable the retailer to satisfy the requirements of the debtor-in-possession financing package that was arranged when Macy filed for bankruptcy protection on Jan. 27. Debtor-in-possession financing gives companies that file under the bankruptcy laws a line of credit to pay for continuing operations.
Suppliers said Macy's ability to generate some positive cash flow despite weakened sales performance was encouraging. "I think it signals that they've spent some time getting their inventories into shape, and now there's a light at the end of the tunnel," said Bud Konheim, president of Nicole Miller Ltd., a fashion apparel manufacturer that ships its goods to Macy. "Are they out of the woods yet? Who knows, but it's a first good sign."
Mr. Konheim said the report would also help assuage concerns about Macy management's ability to stabilize the company's business.
 
Conservative Fall Strategy
 In its monthly financial report to the Federal bankruptcy court, Macy's has detailed losses that have raised eyebrows on Seventh Avenue. Macy reported an operating loss of $32.9 million in June, plus interest expenses and restructuring charges that brought its total loss for the month to $64.7 million.
The extent of the losses, which have been running at about $1 million a day, has caused some in the garment industry to wonder whether Macy would meet financing requirements.
As of Aug. 1, Macy's had access to $76.1 million in cash and $509.2 million of its debtor-in-possession financing. Ms. Baker said the company would start borrowing from its working capital this month to buy fall and holiday merchandise.
She said Macy's fall sales plan was conservative, taking account of the stagnant economy and a program to reduce promotions and markdowns.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 27, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about R. H. Macy's financial performance described some of its past results incorrectly. The company said it had a positive cash flow in its third quarter.

HEADLINE: Balkans Session Is Long on Talk, Short on Action

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
An international conference on the crisis in the former Yugoslav republics opened here today to rousing condemnation of the Serbs from nearly two dozen nations, but virtually no calls for action beyond tightening economic sanctions and sending observers.
Only the Foreign Ministers of Turkey, speaking for the Islamic Conference, and of besieged Bosnia and Herzegovina, suggested that the use of force might be the only effective response. 
 The Bush Administration, arguing that a tighter embargo could weaken the Government in Belgrade and reduce its support for Serbian nationalists in Bosnia, proposed that international inspectors be sent in significant numbers to end what it said had been flagrant violations of economic sanctions.
 
'The U.S. Is Ready'
 Acting Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said in a speech to the conference that the goal of these measures would be to interrupt the shipment of goods into Serbia overland and along the Danube.
"We must resolve no longer to tolerate continuing and flagrant violations of the sanctions regime," he said.
"We will move quickly to place multi-national sanctions monitors in Romania," he said. "The United States is ready to contribute experts and equipment to this operation." He said similar arrangements should be made with Hungary, Bulgaria, Albania and Macedonia.
The conference on the Balkans is taking place in orderly, genteel London against a backdrop of news reports of some of the most intensive bombardment of Sarajevo and other Bosnian cities seen in weeks.
Mr. Eagleburger called these attacks an "outrage," and said that by the end of the session the talks, sponsored by the United Nations and the European Community, might propose punitive action. But by the end of today, State Department officials were expecting only position papers and a still-undefined plan of action for the sanctions and for observers.
Saying that the crisis in what was once Yugoslavia "was willed by men seeking to perpetuate Europe's last Communist regime by manipulating age-old hatreds and fears," Mr. Eagleburger also called today for the immediate stationing of human rights observers in areas that could be the next targets of Serbian nationalists: three regions in Serbia named Kosovo, Vojvodina and Sandzhak. Kosovo, in the south, has many residents of Albanian heritage, and Sandzhak, a region in Serbia northwest of Kosovo, has many Muslims.
Americans could be part of the human rights and sanctions-monitoring teams, officials said.
 
Tough Talk by Germany
 The toughest language of the opening session of the talks came from Germany's Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, who accused the Serbs, sitting across the table, of genocide and warned them that they would keep no land. Germany has had a long relationship with Croatia, and has been a leading critic of the Serbian leadership.
"Do not deceive yourselves," Mr. Kinkel said to the Serbs. "The international community will never accept the acquisition of territory through force and terror."
He accused them of a "war for a Greater Serbia" as ethnically pure as possible, and added that "here the root of crimes against humanity lie."
Mr. Eagleburger echoed the warnings later when he said: "History teaches that the conquests of past ethnic cleansers have tended to be short-lived."
The Acting Secretary of State welcomed an offer by some Serbs to permit the stationing of international observers along the Serbian-Bosnian border and at air bases in Serbia and Montenegro to prevent the movement of arms or supplies to Bosnian Serbs.
That pledge was made here on Tuesday and again today by Milan Panic, the Prime Minister of what remains of Yugoslavia -- made up of Serbia, the old Yugoslavia's largest republic, and Montenegro, its smallest. Mr. Panic is attending the talks as an individual because his government is not recognized as the successor to the old Yugoslav state.
 
Bosnian Serb Walks Out
 Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, did not oppose the idea when it was proposed, American officials said.
But as if to underline the divisions among Serbs, and illustrate the limited influence of Mr. Panic in Bosnia, the leader of Bosnia's ethnic Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, walked out of today's session because he had been relegated to observer status. His gesture was intended to demonstrate that he wanted equal status with the Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
"Bosnia-Herzegovina doesn't exist anymore as a state," Mr. Karadzic told the BBC.
Bosnia and Herzegovina declared independence in March, following Croatia and Slovenia in departing from the Yugoslav federation, a nation born in 1918 of a group of "south Slav" peoples and religions.
Since the declaration of independence, the republic has been carved up into ethnic enclaves by militias in fierce fighting that has left thousands killed and hundreds of thousands homeless out of the total population of 4.3 million.
One Bosnian cease-fire after another has been declared and then quickly broken, and the Muslims, who make up almost half the population, have accused Serbia of being the aggressor.
Mr. Milosevic, who had a place at the table as the leader of Serbia, sat in stony silence through most of today's proceedings. American officials said that he had not sought a meeting with Mr. Eagleburger, a former United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia whom he has known for many years.
Mr. Panic told a reporter in Belgrade that he would have preferred to have Mr. Milosevic, the Serbian Communist-turned-nationalist, skip the conference. But, Mr. Panic said, Cyrus R. Vance, the former Secretary of State who is now the United Nations negotiator for the region, had urged both men to come.
"If I disagree with him in London, it looks like I'm a traitor," Mr. Panic, a Serbian-born American citizen, said before leaving for the talks. "If I agree with him, I look like I'm his man. But Cyrus Vance called me and told me to bring him, so that's what I'm doing."

HEADLINE: Toronto Journal;
New Planet Swims Into Canada's Ken: It's Mexico

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Taco Loco opened a month ago in Kensington Market in Toronto, with Maria Molinaro from Guadalajara offering her homemade cornmeal tortillas along with "autenticos" tacos, burritos, quesadillas, tostadas and tamales.
"We're doing great," said her husband, Sam Molinaro, at a table below the Mexican flag. "A lot of Canadians are getting to know Mexico through travel and business, and they really go for the Mexican food." 
 A few blocks away, at Bloor Street and Spadina, is the Taco Taco Taqueria, which opened two months ago. Lucky Jara, born in Mexico, raised in Ecuador, was stirring the pinto beans behind a delicatessen display case rendered Mexican by platters of hot peppers in huge pottery casseroles and a spectacular Mexican rag doll in a billowing, blue-flowered dress with an armload of fruits and vegetables.
"People are trying to hire me away," she confided, "but I'm happy right here." The owner, Sam Pinellis, is so happy that he plans to open two more taquerias.
 
Museums Plan Exhibitions
 A few doors from the Taco Taco Taqueria is the Viva restaurant, with a tractor-sized machine of stainless steel that can turn out 30 tortillas a minute.
Canadians have suddenly developed a fascination with Mexico. Not only are the fast-food shops and fancier Mexican restaurants thriving, after being virtually nonexistent in Canada five years ago, but vacation and business trips are also up dramatically and student exchange programs are more active than ever before. At least five museums in this the most populous region of Canada are to open major exhibitions on Mexican themes.
While Canadians have always had a keen intellectual interest in Mexican culture, the new attention largely reflects economic and business forces, including Canada's moves to join Mexico and the United States in a North American free trade area.
Many analysts see a natural alliance forming between the two countries as they discover common interests in their trade and other dealings with the world's remaining superpower.
 
Job Competition Feared
 "Canada and Mexico will be cooperating ever more closely to offset the overwhelming economic power of the United States," predicts Alan M. Rugman, professor of business economics at the University of Toronto.
Yet fears that North American free trade could mean job competition at least tempers some of the enthusiasm for the Mexicans. Opponents of free trade are expected to argue the need to protect jobs in the coming political battle over ratification of the trade pact.
Workers in apparel, footwear, toys and plastic products are considered vulnerable to greater competition from Mexico. On the other hand, there could be increased employment in high technology sectors like software and telecommunications as markets open in Mexico for Canada's wares.
Canadians have long flocked to Mexico for vacations, but only recently, mirroring increased prosperity in Mexico, are Mexicans starting to come here in important numbers.
Gonzalo Moreno, owner of a Mexico-Canada travel service, Moreno Tours of Toronto, said he was handling two to three busloads of Mexican tourists a week, whereas "we were lucky to get one busload five years ago."
Increasing student contacts are also deepening the relationship.
"My future may well be down there," said Alex Mercon of Seneca College in Toronto, who has just returned from six months' study at the Technological Institute of Oaxaca in southeastern Mexico.
"Mexicans are really moving ahead," added the 22-year-old student of international business. "Canada and the United States have stabilized, while Mexico has the real potential."
Strengthening business ties have contributed to the unusual surge of interest in Mexico by Canadian museums.
 
Others on the Bandwagon
 Robin Etherington, museum director in Guelph, a university town about an hour by car northwest of here, said that because a number of businesses in that area were considering expansion into Mexico, the "time is right" for an exhibition on Mexican culture. Her theme: "the phenomenal 5,000-year-old textile tradition in Mexico." In cooperation with the nearby Wellington County Museum and Archives, she has devised a display to open next November.
At least three other museums are on the Mexican bandwagon. The Art Gallery of Ontario has a show on tour of the works of Mexican artists active 30 to 60 years ago. The exhibition depicts their profound influence on Canadian artists.
"The Mexicans provided an exemplar for the socially conscious art that was of major importance to the development of art in Canada, and it was fortuitous that our show was contemporaneous with 1992 and the rediscovery of the Americas," said Christine Boyanoski, associate curator of Canadian historical art at the gallery.
Both the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto and the Art Gallery of Hamilton, about a half-hour drive southwest of Toronto, are getting exhibitions ready for this fall to give Canadians a better insight into the most popular holiday in Mexico. This is the Day of the Dead, Nov. 1, when families lay out food and drink and mementos for deceased loved ones.
The Mexican community in Canada is small, probably no more than 7,500, the Mexican Embassy estimates.
Maria Claudette Santillana, a 22-year-old exchange student from Oaxaca now living with a Toronto family and studying at Seneca College, offered perhaps one of the reasons when she observed: "Canada is a great place. But I don't like the winter."
