HEADLINE: U.S. Aide Who Quit Calls Yugoslav Policy Ineffective

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
The State Department official who managed the United States' day-to-day policy toward the Balkans said today that he resigned in protest over what he called the Bush Administration's "ineffective" and "counterproductive" response to the fighting in the former Yugoslavia.
"What's going on in Bosnia is genocide, and the U.S. had a moral obligation to stop it," the former official, George D. Kenney, said in a telephone interview. "The Administration is not dealing seriously with the Yugoslav crisis. The things we've tried up to now haven't worked and we need to try some different approaches." 
 Mr. Kenney resigned from the Foreign Service on Tuesday. His departure and criticisms were first disclosed in The Washington Post today.
The former official, who is 35 years old, joined the Foreign Service in 1988 and had been acting chief of Yugoslav affairs for the last month, after having served as deputy chief since Jan. 31. He reported to policy makers, but was at the senior working level of the State Department bureaucracy.
Mr. Kenney said that "the risks of a Vietnam quagmire in Yugoslavia are vastly overblown" and that the United States and its Western allies should arm the poorly equipped Bosnians so they can reclaim territory lost to Serbian attacks. He also recommended air strikes against Serbian positions.
"In the short run, it would increase the violence, but in the long run it would decrease the violence," Mr. Kenney said. "It's more destabilizing to allow the Bosnians to be murdered."
 
Limits of U.S. Involvement
 President Bush has pledged American air support, if requested, to help deliver relief supplies to Bosnia and Herzegovina, but he has repeatedly ruled out punitive air strikes against Serbian targets or sending American ground forces to the region.
Mr. Kenney predicted that an international conference under way in London to discuss the Yugoslav crisis would most likely fail without strong pressure against the Serbs, including the threat of military action.
He charged that the Administration's Yugoslav policy lacked urgency. "It boils down to a cold, political calculation," he said. "The Administration decided that it's far away, Americans don't care about it, and it's too politically risky to get involved in."
In the interview, Mr. Kenney criticized senior Foreign Service officers for not challenging their superiors to take a more active role.
"After 12 years of the same kind of Republican administrations, the senior levels of the career officers have been so well trained in political obedience that no one wants to rock the boat," said Mr. Kenney, who said he last registered as a Republican.
There were indications that other career Foreign Service officers, including some middle-level officials above him, sympathized with Mr. Kenney.
 
Indications of Support
 "A lot of people share many of his views, particularly on the lack of action in response to this growing crisis," one State Department official said. "But many people also feel that it is naive to place the blame on career State Department officers who are carrying out the President's policy."
The State Department colleague said that Mr. Kenney, while not a Yugoslav expert by training, was hard-working and committed to improving the plight of the people caught in the civil war.
"He was trying to push for a more activist approach, and was more willing to contemplate U.S. engagement," said the American official, who added that Mr. Kenney was particularly concerned about famine and other hardships this winter.
The State Department issued a short statement today in response to Mr. Kenney's resignation, but did not address his policy criticism.
"We certainly understand his frustration in dealing with this crisis and the many horrors that have occurred in the former Yugoslavia," said a Department spokeswoman, Nancy Beck. "It's an enormously complex problem and one we've found through all of our efforts and those of the international community is not easily solved. We've been making strenuous efforts and will continue our efforts to try to stop the killing and try to help those in need."
At the conference in London today, senior State Department officials suggested that Mr. Kenney's resignation was a misplaced gesture. "If this is an expression of frustration, everybody is frustrated with it," an official said.

Bush Backs Duty-Free Trade
 WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- President Bush invoked his executive authority today and approved duty-free trade for all the former Yugoslav republics except Serbia and Montenegro. In light of "the Balkan nations' ongoing political and economic reforms, I have determined that it is appropriate," Mr. Bush told leaders of Congress.

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Soar in Tokyo; Nikkei Rises 1,013.35, or 6.1%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Japanese stocks soared today in heavy trading, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues surging 1,013.35 points, or 6.1 percent, to close at 17,555.00.
Brokers said investors regained confidence in the market after the index broke through the 17,000-point level during the morning trading session. Many investors had regarded that level as a short-term ceiling. The Nikkei has not closed above 17,000 since July 15. 
 Brokers added that prices were surging in anticipation of the Japanese Government's stimulative economic package, which is due to be released on Friday.
Also, there was speculation in Tokyo's financial markets today that the Bank of Japan might cut the nation's discount rate as early as Friday, despite clear signals from the central bank that it had no intention of doing so.
An estimated 620 million shares were traded today, compared with 320 million on Wednesday.
"Investors are encouraged by the market's firmness as they have seen it move steadily during an adjustment period after recent big jumps," a broker at a big securities firm said. "Also, there is growing confidence about the Government's measures to boost the economy."
Brokers said investors expected the market to be firmer in September because the Government had asked financial institutions not to take quick profits in shares.
Stocks were also helped by broad buying by foreign and corporate investors, who were encouraged by Wednesday's advance on Wall Street.
On Wednesday, the Nikkei gained 160.88 points.
In the currency market here today, the dollar was higher against the yen, buoyed by renewed tensions in the Middle East. At midday, the dollar was trading 125.30 yen, up from 124.85 yen in New York on Wednesday.
The yield on 10-year Japanese Government bond fell to 4.630 percent in early trading today from 4.645 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: WARNING TO BAGHDAD;
Iraq Says It Is Ready to Fight Allies Over Air Zone

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Baghdad vowed today that it was ready to go to war again with the United States and its allies as they prepared to enforce a plan Thursday to take control of the skies over southern Iraq. But at the United Nations, Iraq's diplomats began a last-ditch effort to avoid a confrontation.
After the allies gave Iraq 24 hours' warning before they shoot down any Iraqi airplanes or helicopters flying south of the 32d parallel, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, Iraq's representative, said he had asked the United Nations to send a multinational team of observers to the area.
 
'Wise Man's Committee'
 Mr. Anbari said Iraq had rejected outright the American-led plan for a what is called a "no fly" zone, delivered to him at the United Nations today by the United States, France, Britain and Russia.
But he asked the United Nations to establish what he called a "wise man's committee" composed of Arab representatives and members of the Security Council, to help "defuse the crisis as well as establish the truth as Iraq has been saying it."
The allies, who say the exclusion zone is necessary to protect Shiite Muslims in the south from Iraqi air assaults, are unlikely to accept the Iraqi suggestion since they had rejected earlier Iraqi proposals over the last week for legislators and others to visit Iraq and see that the Shiites are not being persecuted, as the allies argue.
 
Threat to Expel Aid Workers
 Earlier today, Iraq's public response to the exclusion zone was carried on the front page of Al Thawra, the newspaper of the ruling Baath Party.
"Our great people and our valiant armed forces are fully prepared to confront the enemies," the newspaper said, calling the conflict with the United States-led alliance as a "holy war."
But the Iraqi response, the most recent in a stream of angry denunciations aimed at the United States and Britain in the last week, stopped short of saying that Baghdad would send its planes into action against allied forces.
United Nations officials said they feared that Iraq might also make good on a threat to expel United Nations guards protecting the organization's aid workers inside the country, if the United States and its Western partners attack Iraq. About 120 guards and 75 aid workers remain in the country.
Aid workers and guards have already been withdrawn from southern Iraq. A United Nations Children's Fund worker and eight guards returned to Baghdad from Basra on Monday after Iraqi officials warned they might become the target of demonstrations.
Even before it was officially announced, the allied plan has evoked a less-than-enthusiastic reaction in most Arab capitals.
Only Kuwait has said it backs the plan. Others, including major partners in last year's alliance that pushed Iraq out of Kuwait, have expressed either outright opposition or refused to take a stand.
Syria, which contributed troops to the coalition 18 months ago, declared itself flatly opposed to the plan, and officials in Egypt worried aloud that the no-fly zone would lead inevitably to the dismemberment of Iraq.
But in London, Dr. Laith Kubba, who is a Shiite and a member of the Iraqi National Congress, an opposition group based in London, described the announcement of the zone as "a courageous step."
But Dr. Kubba said the allies must be prepared to go beyond enforcing the ban on air operations in the zone, and be willing to take on Iraqi ground operations mounted against the Shiites. "That, after all, is the essence of U.N. Resolution 668 -- to stop indiscriminate attacks against the population, and halting the repression of minorities by the Iraqi Government," he said.
With the American warplanes ready to take to the air over southern Iraq on Thursday, the military situation facing Shiite Muslims remains unclear.
 
Iraqi Aircraft Go North
 The Pentagon reported on Tuesday that Iraq had removed its airplanes and most of its helicopters from the areas below the 32d parallel.
But Iraqi opposition groups based in London and Damascus said President Saddam Hussein was moving additional forces into the region, including two large Army units intended to reinforce what they called an "economic and military blockade" of the south.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Durable goods orders plunged 3.4 percent in July, the sharpest drop of the year, eradicating economists' hopes that the economy could grow vigorously enough to spawn new jobs by year's end. Aircraft orders were weak. The report was viewed as most unwelcome for President Bush's re-election campaign. [Page D1.]
The Government waited far too long to investigate B.C.C.I., a report by a House subcommittee indicates. A number of Federal agencies received hundreds of tips over a decade, it says, that the bank was spending billions in financing illegal activities including fomenting unrest in Pakistan, smuggling arms in the Middle East and working with organized crime in the United States. [D1.]
 

International
A key to Japan's financial problems is its "nonbanks." These specialized lending companies poured huge sums into ill-considered real estate loans just before property prices plunged. Now the Government must restore confidence in the financial system. [D1.]
Growing doubts that Europe's economic-unification treaty will be approved in its present form roiled financial markets. The Bank of England intervened in foreign currency markets, helping stabilize the pound at 2.794 German marks. [D2.]
 
Companies
Hurricane Andrew was an ill wind that blew some good to building-supply companies, restaurants and sellers of furniture, appliances and household goods -- all businesses that will benefit as people rebuild. Economists even forecast jumps in employment and personal incomes once billions of dollars from insurance and Government aid begin arriving in the areas affected. [D3.]
The News Corporation continued its turnaround, with net income of $47.9 million in the fourth quarter in contrast to a loss of $348.9 million a year earlier. Its Fox network earned $45 million for the year, in contrast to losses at CBS and NBC. [D4.]
Toyota's operating profits dropped 63 percent to 124.86 billion yen, or about $1 billion, in its latest financial year. [D3.]
Mentor Graphics said it would eliminate 100 to 200 jobs and freeze salaries through 1993. [D3.]
Mellon Bank sued Bipin C. Shah, a former executive vice president, who left the bank in late July to form a new company that will compete with many of Mellon's businesses. [D3.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks rose, underpinned by solid gains in Treasury bond prices and a calmer currency market. The Dow Jones industrial average tacked on 14.59 points to close at 3,246.81. [D8.]
Japanese stocks surged today, with the Nikkei index gaining 1,013.35 points, or 6.1 percent, to close at 17,555.00. [D1.]
The bond market rallied across the board, and the Treasury's five-year note auction went fairly well. [D14.]
The dollar continued its slight rebound against the mark, after plunging to lows earlier in the week, while gold prices fell. [D16.]
Sugar and cotton prices declined and energy prices stagnated as Hurricane Andrew's damaging effects on the Gulf Coast were offset by beneficial rain in previously dry areas. [D16.]
 
Today's Columns
Bonn's high, inflation-fighting interest rates have already drawn money out of dollar investments, and longer term, economists say, the strong mark could harm the economies of Britain, France and Italy as well. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Goody's, a highly successful initial public offerings, owns 116 stores throughout the South that sell moderate-priced clothing. It has done stunningly well in a difficult retailing environment and reported record profits in its latest quarter. Market Place. [D8.]
Philip Morris is seeking more sales from less cigarette. It is spending heavily to promote a new 85-millimeter version of Benson & Hedges with sales of its 100-millimeter cigarette lagging. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D18.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Republicans Re-Think 'Family Values' Focus

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Having loosed some of the more ferocious dogs of political war to attack Bill Clinton and the Democrats on such intimate matters as God, family and the sort of woman Mr. Clinton married, officials of President Bush's campaign are now trying to change the subject -- or at least the tone of the discussion.
After the national convention's acidic assaults on the Democratic nominee, his wife and his party failed to restore Mr. Bush to parity with Mr. Clinton in public-opinion polls, Republican strategists are saying the economy, not "family values," is the central issue, and they are trying to distance Mr. Bush from some of the harsh words spoken on his behalf. 
 Charles Black, senior political adviser to the Bush campaign, said the campaign had no intention of dropping the subject of family values entirely, believing the collection of family, religious and social issues to be important to many swing voters in what is expected to be a close election.
 
Two-Step Tactic
 Instead, it seems clear, the Republicans will continue what has evolved as a two-step tactic that Democrats criticize as disingenuous, slashing at Mr. Clinton through the words of surrogates and, when backlash threatens, disavowing the troublesome remarks.
This approach was exhibited at elaborate length today not only by Mr. Black but by Mr. Bush.
Invited at a news conference to impugn Mr. Clinton's patriotism, Mr. Bush pointedly declined. And he suggested that the personal tone of the campaign was attributable to a handful of "hot shooters" on both sides -- a term he apparently coined on the spot and uttered with airy dismissal.
But he also signaled that he was not about to abandon a tactic Republicans have used to great effect in the past five Presidential elections. "I'm going to continue to talk about the values that I think are very, very important," Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Black, speaking to reporters today at a weekly breakfast familiar in Washington as a launching pad for trial balloons, repudiated remarks made last weekend by the House Minority Whip, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, to the effect that the family life of Woody Allen represented a sort of Democratic ideal.
Mr. Black said today that Mr. Gingrich "in no way was speaking for the President."
Mr. Black also dismissed a recent series of broadsides and barbs directed at Hillary Clinton by numerous Republican speakers.
Although the "family values" subject was raised in convention speeches by the President, Mrs. Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle, Marilyn Quayle, the conservative columnist Patrick J. Buchanan, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and William J. Bennett, the former Education Secretary, Mr. Black said his recollection was that most of the talk in Houston had been about the economy.
Mr. Black's remarks reflect a concern among White House and campaign officials, and among other Republican strategists and politicians, that the "family values" is both more troublesome and less profitable than had been thought.
 
Not Attracting Voters
 A White House official, speaking on the condition that he not be identified, said Mr. Bush's strategists have become concerned that the subject of family values, inherently personal and emotional, had led a number of convention speakers, including the President, to use language that could repel rather than attract voters.
"I don't think it's a fundamental backing off, but maybe a cooling down," said one White House official who spoke on the condition he not be identified.
In apparently seeking to distance the Bush campaign from the recent Republican criticisms of Mrs. Clinton that have received heavy, mostly unfavorable, attention, Mr. Black termed these remarks "a minor distraction."
"Look, we had 122 speakers at our convention last week and I think two of them referenced Mrs. Clinton," he said. "You can't do a convention like that without having some wild rumors, gossip, red herrings and other things distract from your main message."
Leading Republicans, however, including Mr. and Mrs. Bush and the chairman of the Republican Party, Richard N. Bond, talked prominently about Mrs. Clinton in various forums in Houston even if they did not mention the Democratic candidate's wife during their formal convention speeches. Mr. Black was asked if he had told the Bushes and Mr. Bond that he considered their comments inappropriate. He said he had.
 
G.O.P. Criticism
 Mr. Black's comments today come at a time when some Republicans outside the campaign are beginning to voice a distaste for the family values message.
"Some of us are getting pretty sick of this family values," said Tommy Hartnett, a Republican Senate candidate from South Carolina. "It was supposed to take a night at the convention. It's important, but so are other things."
"The message has to be about the economy," said the Republican consultant Michael Deaver. "We've got real day-to-day, life-and-death problems that are facing people every morning. You try to lecture them about family values and they're going to say, 'Don't tell me about God. Tell me about how I'm going to eat. Tell me about how I'm going to pay the rent.' "
Mr. Black said the Bush campaign would indeed focus its primary attention on the economy "even though the economy is bad and people are unhappy with the economic performance of this administration," and will devote a great deal of effort to portraying Mr. Bush as a President who would revive the economy through tax and spending cuts, while depicting Mr. Clinton as a devotee of higher taxes and more government spending.
Noting that while such issues as prayer in school, school choice, abortion and family-oriented welfare changes are issues that may not move the electorate as a mass, he said: "This is a game of margins. I don't think anybody believes this election is going to be won by a landslide."

HEADLINE: Dow Up 14.59, to 3,246.81, as Volume Falls

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Solid gains by Treasury bonds and a calmer currency market pushed blue-chip stocks higher yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 14.59 points, to 3,246.81.
Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by 1,013 to 732 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume totaled 171.8 million shares, versus 201.6 million on Tuesday. 
 Despite the gains, some analysts were unconvinced about the market's direction, noting that political and economic uncertainties remain significant hurdles.
The 30-year bond was up 5/8, yielding 7.41 percent, down from 7.47 percent on Tuesday. A sale of five-year notes went smoothly, traders said.
Meanwhile, the dollar held near its opening levels, higher than Tuesday's close and above the record lows scored in recent days. It was trading at about 1.4065 German marks at the end of Wall Street's day, up from 1.4027 marks on Tuesday.
Politics weighed on the markets somewhat, with a new poll showing that President Bush's rise in popularity after the Republican convention had all but evaporated.
Bob Walberg of MMS International said that light bargain-hunting probably helped stocks to recover but that "the big problem is the economy, which remains stuck in neutral."
"Unless we see a definitive sign, the stock market will have a hard time rallying," he said, adding, "I don't think 3,200 will hold.
Eric Miller, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said investors were not yet pulling up stakes in the stock market. "There's no indication of major raising of cash," he said, adding, however, that sentiment had become more guarded.
Computervision topped the volume list, down 1 1/8, to 10 1/4, after Lehman Brothers crossed a block of 3.5 million shares.
Shares of Novell Inc. jumped 3 7/8, to 49 1/2, after Lehman upgraded the stock and other firms repeated their strong buy recommendations.
Dycom Industries, a telecommunications company, rose 1 3/4, to 6 3/4.
 Eli Lilly said a unit had suspended shipments of two of its angioplasty catheters. Its stock fell 1/2, to 66 1/2, but a rival catheter maker, Scimed Life, jumped 6 3/4, to 56 1/2. Shares of Merit Medical slumped 2 3/8, to 4 5/8.
Adobe Systems dropped 3 3/4, to 32 1/8. Morgan Stanley downgraded its rating to a hold from a buy.
 Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.90 points at 413.51. The American Stock Exchange index rose 0.13 point, to 379.65. The Nasdaq index rose 4.58 points, to 558.80.

HEADLINE: Test Scores Are Up Slightly For College-Bound Students

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
College-bound high school seniors scored slightly higher on the Scholastic Aptitude Test this year than last, the first annual improvement for combined verbal and mathematics scores since 1985.
The average S.A.T. score this year was 423 on the verbal test and 476 on the math test, a total of 899 out of a possible 1,600 -- still far below the historic highs of the 1960's but 3 points higher than last year's combined total. 
 Educators said it was not clear whether the reversal signaled the end of a long downward trend that began in the 1960's. But they added that this year's scores appeared to be a real improvement, not a fluke of demographics.
 
Upward Trend?
 They noted that the number of students taking the test went slightly up along with the scores, from 1,032,685 in 1991 to 1,034,131 this year. As a rule, when the pool of test-takers grows to encompass more students from lower-income, less-educated families, the average score goes down.
"I'm encouraged by this year's results and hope they start an upward trend that puts the score declines of the 1980's behind us," said Donald M. Stewart, president of the College Board, which released the S.A.T. results today.
"One or two points may not seem like much, but each point is meaningful on a test taken by more than a million students who represent roughly two-thirds of all entering college freshmen," he said.
At the same time, Mr. Stewart and other educators said they were disturbed that rural and urban students continued to score lower than their counterparts from suburbs, medium-sized cities and small cities and towns. The average big-city scores were 411 on the verbal test and 465 on the math test, for a total of 876; rural scores were 414 on the verbal test and 459 on the math test, for 873; scores in other areas were 432 on the verbal test and 485 on the math test, for 917.
 
Students 'Left Behind'
 "Many students in rural and urban America are being left behind in a society that has few jobs for the undereducated and unskilled," Mr. Stewart said. "These are not just students who drop out of school, but also those heading for college."
And educators also expressed concern today that students' grades were rising faster than their S.A.T. scores. Though the overall grade average for those taking the test this year has risen to 3.12 on a 4-point scale, up from 3.07 in 1987, the combined S.A.T. score is 7 points lower.
The S.A.T., a two-and-a-half-hour multiple-choice test, is taken by high school students, most of whom plan to attend college, and measures verbal and mathematical ability. It is not intended to measure intelligence or the ability to learn.
This year's average score on the verbal test, 423, was up 1 point from 1991, reversing a decline that began in 1987. The average math score, 476, was up 2 points from last year and 10 points above the record low of 466 in 1980 and 1981.
Private-school students averaged the highest scores: 469 in verbal skills and 526 in math, for a total of 995. Students in religious schools averaged 439 in verbal skills and 474 in math, for a total of 913. The public-school averages were 420 in verbal skills and 475 in math, for a total of 895.
Foreign students taking the S.A.T. out-scored Americans in math by 57 points, averaging 533. Their average verbal score was 389.
Women's scores are historically lower than men's. This is attributed to the fact they more women who take the test come from lower-income and less-educated families. But female high school students overall have higher grade averages than their male counterparts. This year, women's scores rose 1 point on the verbal sections, to 418, and 3 on the mathematical sections, to 456, over last year's levels. Men's scores rose 2 points in verbal, 428, and 2 points in math, 499.
Since 1976, the average scores of black students rose 20 points on the verbal sections to 352, and 31 points on the math sections to 385. The average scores for whites fell nine points on verbal to 442 and two on math to 491.
The math scores of blacks and Puerto Ricans remained at 1991 levels, 385 for blacks and 406 for Puerto Ricans. In verbal, blacks were up 1 point to 352, and Puerto Ricans were up 5 to 366.
 
'Modestly Good News'
 The math average for American Indians increased 5 points over last year's results to 442, and verbal rose 2 points to 395. The math average for Asian-Americans was up two points to 532 and verbal was up 2 points to 413.
Mexican-Americans were the only ethnic group whose scores dropped from their 1991 performance. Their scores fell 5 points in verbal to 372 and 2 points in mathematics to 425.
Despite this year's gain in S.A.T. results, other educators cautioned against attributing the rise to any improvement in the quality of the nation's primary and secondary education.
"This is modestly good news," said Marc Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, a nonprofit policy and analysis organization based in Rochester. "But a difference of a point or two over one year and the next tells you very little about where American education is going.
The lower scores of rural and big-city students were of particular concern, and educators singled out family education and income as significant reasons for the differences. In rural and urban areas, those who take the S.A.T. come from families with income and education below the national average. Nationwide, 16 percent of those who take the S.A.T. report family incomes under $20,000; 24 percent in large cities and 19 percent in rural areas report such incomes.
In rural America, 85 percent of those who take the S.A.T. are white American citizens who speak English. Their average S.A.T. scores on the verbal and mathematics sections are 17 and 21 points below the respective national averages for whites. S.A.T. scores of most other rural ethnic groups are also below the national averages for their respective groups.
In big cities, half of those who take the S.A.T. are members of minorities, and 15 percent do not speak English as their primary language. Though only 5 percent of those taking the test reported having parents without a high school diploma, the highest percentages were among nonwhites.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

METRO DIGEST
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
12 PEOPLE WOUNDED AS GUNMEN OPEN FIRE
In what the police called one of the most violent shootouts in recent years, gunmen drove up to a Bronx apartment building and opened fire, wounding 12 people, many of whom crawled frantically for cover because they feared being shot again. The gunfire, which apparently stemmed from a dispute between drug dealers, touched off minutes of terror as residents poured from their buildings to look for friends and relatives among a tangle of bodies, victims and witnesses said. A1.
 
SANDBLASTING HALTED AGAIN ON BRIDGE
After suspending maintenance on the Williamsburg Bridge amid complaints that sandblasting was spewing dust and paint chips with elevated levels of lead into Brooklyn, New York City's Transportation Department has allowed the work to resume this month -- on the Manhattan side of the bridge. The new work was halted after residents and elected officials on both sides of the East River expressed outrage that the department had allowed sandblasting on five occasions in Manhattan this month. B3.
 
QUEENS MAN SURRENDERS IN SHOOTING
After nearly six weeks on the run, a 25-year-old Queens man surrendered himself to face charges that he shot and killed an off-duty Housing Authority police officer and another man after a brawl on a Bayside street. B3.
 
DINKINS GETS HIGH PRAISE
Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation who endorsed Mayor David N. Dinkins in the 1989 mayoral race and who has frequently criticized the Mayor's handling of New York City's severe budget problems since then, lavishly praised Mr. Dinkins for engineering a fiscal turnaround. B3.
 
PROJECT GAINS AN APPROVAL
To win approval for his Riverside South development project from Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, Donald J. Trump agreed to contribute $5 million to renovate the 72d Street subway station, set aside at least 10 percent of the apartments for subsidized housing and insure there would be no net increase of sewage to the North River treatment plant in Harlem. B2.
 
A sign on Maiden Lane raises a furor. Lower Manhattan Journal, B3.
 
REGION
 
AN AGREEMENT IN NASSAU
The Nassau County Board of Supervisors unanimously approved enough borrowing today to pay county salaries through the end of October, but not without an acrimonious debate over who was more fiscally responsible, Democrats or Republicans. B4.
 
IN A SEASIDE TOWN, DEADLY GAS
Deadly gas produced by decaying vegetation, buried under sand years ago in the New Jersey resort community of Sea Isle City, was released by a construction crew, killing one police officer, leaving another officer in critical condition and sending 38 people to the hospital. B5.
 
YEAR OF THE WOMAN TURNS NASTY
The political Year of the Woman took a decidedly unsisterly turn as two prominent New York feminists who support Geraldine A. Ferraro for Senate attacked the feminist credentials of the other woman in the race. They accused City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman of betraying the hope of the feminist movement that women in politics would behave differently, and with more principle, than men. B4.

HEADLINE: Rohatyn, a Dinkins Critic on Budgets, Praises the Mayor

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, who has frequently criticized Mayor David N. Dinkins over his handling of New York City's severe budget problems, lavishly praised Mr. Dinkins yesterday for engineering a fiscal turnaround.
"The city has made a lot of progress," Mr. Rohatyn, who endorsed Mr. Dinkins in the 1989 mayoral race, said at a meeting of the assistance corporation in Manhattan yesterday. "We haven't hesitated to criticize the administration when we thought it was appropriate, and we shouldn't hesitate to praise the administration when it is appropiate." 
 Mr. Rohatyn's remarks came during a presentation of a report by the assistance corporation evaluating the city budget for the fiscal year that began on July 1, as well as how the city balanced the budget for the fiscal year that ended on June 30. Mr. Rohatyn was among the fiscal experts who foresaw great problems for the city as recently as the spring, but he said yesterday that the Mayor had stabilized New York's finances to an extent that would have been hard to anticipate six months ago.
He described the report as the corporation's most upbeat ever, and in marked contrast with its annual review last year. "We haven't put out a report like this, even in the heyday of the Koch administration," Mr. Rohatyn said.
 
'Commendable Success'
 The Municipal Assistance Corporation, better known as the M.A.C., was created 17 years ago to float bonds for the city to help stave off bankruptcy. The corporation's report contended that the Mayor had demonstrated "commendable success" in shepherding the city through a very difficult economy.
The Dinkins administration managed to balance the city's budget without raising taxes and by cutting $2 billion in costs, said the report, the latest in a series of reports from independent fiscal monitors in the last two months that have congratulated the administration for stabilizing the budget without resorting to fiscal gimmicks.
The report also noted some potential problems that the city still faces, as have the previous reports. Chief among them, it said, is the lack of progress in contract negotiations with the unions representing city workers.
The contracts of all of the municipal workers' unions have expired, and negotiations that began in early June have not yet produced any substantial breakthroughs. The Dinkins administration contends that it will grant only wage increases that are financed through productivity gains.
"Despite the importance of these negotiations, however, progress to date has been disappointing," the report said. "More significant, leadership from the city as to what it seeks in concessions to meet its goals has not been evident."
 
'Our Work Is Not Done'
 Philip R. Michael, the city's Budget Director, said the administration recognized the significance of the labor talks. "I think we know, particularly with labor, that our work is not done," Mr. Michael said.
Mr. Michael also said the city could not obtain any productivity savings without the agreement of labor leaders. "You can lead, but both sides have to agree," he said.
The remarks by Mr. Rohatyn and other M.A.C. board members represented a marked shift from their tough criticism of the Dinkins administration over the last two years. "We feel much more confident in the city's ability to pre-act rather than react," said Mr. Rohatyn.
 
Money From Surplus
 Mr. Rohatyn indicated that the praise would not affect the outcome of a longstanding debate over how $200 million in M.A.C. surplus money would be spent. Mr. Dinkins would like to use the money as part of a labor settlement, while City Board of Education officials want the money for the city's schools.
Mr. Rohatyn has long insisted that both the Mayor and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would have to agree on any plan for the money. He suggested yesterday that it might be used to pay directly for construction that would ordinarily be financed through bonds.
Asked late yesterday if his comments suggested that he would endorse Mr. Dinkins for re-election next year, Mr. Rohatyn said he had always tried rigorously to separate his political endorsements from his official activities as chairman of the assistance corporation.
"I am fully alive to the fact that this may be beneficial to the Mayor," Mr. Rohatyn said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Suppliers Shipping Extra Goods to Storm Areas

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Retailers and building-supply companies today scrambled to meet surging demand for their goods after Hurricane Andrew battered South Florida and the Louisiana coast.
Some economists predicted that a rebuilding boom in those areas could last as much as a year, giving a modest spurt to employment and personal incomes once billions of dollars from private insurers and the Federal Government begin arriving. 
 Restaurants and retailers of furniture, appliances and other household goods will also see a surge in business, said Rosalind Greenstein, senior economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, in Lexington, Mass. But many small businesses that had struggled for more than two years in a weak economy are likely to fail now, she added.
 
Increased Shipments
 Executives at Home Depot Inc., the Atlanta-based discount retailer of hardware and building materials, said they were shipping thousands of extra supplies to their operations in South Florida, which included 18 stores before Hurricane Andrew struck early Monday. Thirteen stores are open and another four will reopen within three weeks, the company said, but another will take six months to rebuild.
"We are moving massive amounts of lumber, building materials and emergency-type supplies from our stores and distribution centers across the country into both South Florida and Louisiana," said Lonnie Fogel, a Home Depot spokesman. "This is an around-the-clock effort. Hundreds of truckloads have arrived into those markets and are en route."
Plywood, plastic sheeting, tarpaulins, nails, hammers and other hand tools are of particular need in South Florida to make immediate repairs of exposed sections of houses and other buildings.
Bruce Berg, president of Home Depot's Southeast division, in Tampa, said that wholesale lumber prices had soared by nearly 40 percent in the region in the last week but that for now, the company had not raised its retail prices and was losing money on those products.
"We cannot afford to lose large amounts of money forever," he said, "and we may have to rethink our policy."
Mr. Fogel said Home Depot had urged many of its suppliers, like makers of portable electric generators, to accelerate production to meet needs in the hurricane areas. That should prompt new hiring at some suppliers, he said, "because ultimately, factories will be cranking up."
Yet some construction suppliers were operating at full capacity before Andrew struck this week. Half the plywood mills in the Pacific Northwest were shut this summer after a Federal court banned logging in the spotted owl's wooded habitat there, said Sheila Weidman, a spokeswoman for the Georgia-Pacific Corporation. This put burdens on the remaining mills to meet normal demand.
"There is no additional capacity in the industry to meet the tremendous need that's been created by the hurricane," she said. For its part, Georgia Pacific has altered its product mix, making more plywood sheeting for roofing and construction and fewer finished siding products, she said.
"We're making every effort to divert materials to the hurricane-damaged areas," she said. Georgia-Pacific shipped 30 rail cars filled with plywood, at 3,024 sheets a rail car, to South Florida on Monday.
 
Lessons From Hugo
 The lessons in 1989 from Hurricane Hugo suggest that new jobless claims in the storm-ravaged areas will soar during the next four weeks, and then recede as programs for rebuilding and repair begin.
In South Carolina, personal income plunged 24 percent in the third quarter of 1989 after Hurricane Hugo devastated the state in September. Incomes rebounded to a gain of 36 percent in the next quarter after disaster aid and insurance money flowed into the state.
"Income grew a lot faster than it did in other parts of the country," said Daniel Friel, economist at Nationsbank in Charlotte, N.C. A similar pattern is likely in South Florida and Louisiana, and could give a spark to local economies in the storm-ravaged regions.
"In the Miami area, construction had been very hard hit, with employment falling sharply in the last year," he said. "It looks to us like the national economy will do better at some point next year. So this might be a good bridge" for South Florida "between now and when the national economy picks up."
In Louisiana, thousands of homes and small businesses were destroyed or scarred by the storm, and electric power was disrupted in several towns that serve as staging areas for the offshore drilling industry. These towns include Morgan City, New Iberia and Lafayette.
"A lot of the offshore industry's operating offices, fabrication yards and storage sites are located where the hurricane devastated things," said J. Rogers Pearcy, director of the Minerals Management Service's Gulf of Mexico region, in New Orleans.
In the financial markets, traders were unsure how to gauge the storm's effects. At the New York Mercantile Exchange today, crude oil for delivery in October rose 6 cents a barrel, to $21.21, and September unleaded gasoline rose 0.09 cent, to 62.22 cents a gallon. But September heating oil declined 0.11 cent, to 58.12 cents a gallon, and October natural gas settled at $1.882 for 1,000 cubic feet, off 4.7 cents.
"If anything had been damaged, we would know by now," said Peter Beutel, director of energy research at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "Bad news travels fast. We believe the market is heading lower in the next few days."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Building-supply companies are scrambling to meet surging demand in storm-battered South Florida and Louisiana. Residents surveyed property damage at a town house complex yesterday in Dade County, Fla. (Susan Greenwood for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Fell 3.4% in July

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Orders for cars, aircraft, industrial equipment and other durable goods suffered the year's sharpest decline last month, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.
The report removed any lingering hope among economists that the economy could grow fast enough to reduce unemployment by the end of the year. 
 July's 3.4 percent decline in orders was much worse than the flat performance most economists had expected. Those inclined to shrug rather than scowl pointed out that an especially large drop in aircraft orders, always a volatile category, was chiefly responsible.
Yet a 1.4 percent drop in unfilled orders -- the 11th straight decline, leaving the lowest backlog since February 1989 -- told others that factories will be running well below capacity for many more months.
 
A 'Barely Creeping' Economy
 "The fundamental point is that the economy is just barely creeping forward," said Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "There's no good news for the White House in this."
Though volatile, the durable-goods figures are regarded as a strong signal of things to come. The Presidential election might well turn on the economic outlook. And that outlook has remained dark amid reports that consumers continue to lose confidence, with the economy's second-quarter growth rate of 1.4 percent well below the 2 percent level needed to reduce joblessness.
Bond prices rose after the durable-goods report, as they usually do after signs of slow growth. The bond market rally and a stabilizing in the value of the dollar fed a nearly 15-point gain in the Dow Jones industrial average.
 
Glimmers of Hope Dashed
 A few glimmers of renewed business confidence, reflected in some surveys and stronger second-quarter earnings, had suggested that corporations might pull the economy along. The durable-goods figures indicated, however, that businesses, too, are remaining cautious. New orders for industrial machinery and equipment fell 1.8 percent; and for nonmilitary capital goods, 7 percent.
"Capital spending is not going much of anywhere," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities. "They took away the silver lining. I never thought we could get the economy to grow more than 2 or 2.5 percent. Now the question becomes whether we're going to 1 percent."
July's decline in durable-goods orders, to a seasonally adjusted $119 billion, continues a choppy pattern, with a rise of 2.8 percent in June and a drop of 2.1 percent in May. Last month's decline was the largest since a 5.3 percent drop in December.
 
'A Subdued Economy'
 The worst major category was transportation equipment, down 15.2 percent. Most of the decline came in aircraft and parts, saying to some economists that weak economies abroad are hurting the nation's exports. Military orders, overlapping with transportation, fell 26.4 percent.
Without transportation, new orders rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, almost enough to keep up with inflation in an area where prices have been fairly stable.
David D. Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial, was among those who said that this figure, excluding transportation, gives a better picture of the economy's prospects. "It's not a good number, but it's not terrible," he said. He expects slow, 2 percent, economic growth well into next year -- "a subdued economy, no doubt about it."
Orders for durable goods, expensive items meant to last at least three years, indicate whether consumers and businesses are willing to make major purchases, which often require borrowing.
Durable-goods components contribute to the Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators, due out next Tuesday. William C. Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, expects the index to rise just one-tenth of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rally as Dollar Stabilizes

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market put together a decent rally yesterday after the dollar stabilized, a key economic barometer confirmed that the economy was barely growing and the Treasury's five-year note auction went fairly well.
The rise in prices and drop in yields was across the board, from three-month bills to the 30-year bond. The move started slowly in the morning, gained as the report on durable goods was released and then moved on as it seemed clear that the dollar would hold its own for a day. 
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was offered at 98 in late trading, up 5/8, to yield 7.41 percent, compared with 7.47 percent Tuesday. The 6.375 percent 10-year bond was up 21/32, to yield 6.63 percent, compared with 6.72 percent the day before. The 4.25 percent two-year note that had a mediocre auction Tuesday rebounded yesterday. It was up 5/32 to yield 4.25 percent, compared with the 4.30 percent average yield in the auction and the 4.34 percent it was trading at after the Tuesday auction.
 
Presidential Election Uncertainty
 No one knows how long the dollar calm will last. Many currency analysts think the sluggish American economy, the uncertainty about the Presidential election and much higher interest rates in Europe will continue to push the dollar lower.
It is still hard to gauge how effective the coordinated central bank intervention, led by the Federal Reserve, has been and will be in slowing the dollar decline. In the last two days, the central banks have not intervened to buy dollars and the dollar has not declined. When they intervened last Friday the dollar fell 1 percent and when they bought dollars again on Monday the American currency fell 2 percent.
"It could turn around quickly," said John Costas, managing director of government trading and sales at the First Boston Corporation. "We will be as finicky as the dollar in the next couple of weeks."
It is possible that if the decline is slow, the fundamental forces that are supporting the bond market -- low inflation and slow economic growth - will prevail again. But no one seems willing to make that bet now.
The price rally yesterday, however, was not as much as might have been expected given that the durable goods report showed an unexpectedly sharp decline in July. The fall of 3.4 percent in orders was the steepest in six months and way beyond market forecasts, which ranged from up a little to down a little. Durable goods rose a revised 2.8 percent in June.
In addition, the level of orders on the books fell for the 11th straight month. Many economists say this decline means that it will be some time before manufacturing companies begin hiring additional workers, another factor that means economic growth will continue to be sluggish.
But traders said that the weakness of the dollar means that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to ease interest rates in the near future, even if the economic data continue to be weak. For investors, therefore, there is less of a chance that short-term interest rates will move lower soon, which would give the bond market another reason to rally. And so the durable goods report gave the market less of a boost than it might have a month ago.
"The Federal Reserve has been neutralized as a market factor by the dollar," said Joseph Liro, the newly appointed chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company in New York. "The Fed will not tighten to defend the dollar. And they can not ease because the dollar is too weak."
 
Treasury 5-Year Note Sale
 The Treasury auction of $10.6 billion in five-year notes went well, in part because the decline in bond market prices in the last several days had increased the coupon and the yield on the new note and made it much more attractive. Bond and note prices move in the opposite direciton of yields.
The average yield at the auction was 5.74 percent, which is far above the 5.56 percent a month ago, which is a reflection of the damage the falling dollar did to the bond market. The yield is even farther above the 5.46 percent the note was trading at in the pre-auction or when issued market late last week.
But the combination of a 5.625 percent coupon and a lot of cash that had been sitting on the sidelines for several days while the dollar was falling made for some decent demand, traders said. And that was also reflected in the trading after the auction results were announced. Late yesterday, the yield on the new-five year note had fallen to 5.67 percent, which means that the demand had drivien its price higher.
Mr. Costas of First Boston also said that the market was helped over all yesterday by some good buying from pension and other funds in the United States and from foreigners, who also had been sitting out the last several days. He said the combination of a stable -- but very weak -- dollar and the recent decline in bond and note prices made the American market especially attractive to foreign investors.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Taxable Fund Yields Are Off, While Tax-Exempts Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by money market funds were mixed in the latest week as the supply of municipal debt increased and the weak dollar made an impact in short-term rates, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
While yields on taxable funds slipped, the seven-day averages for the compounded yield and simple yield for tax-exempt funds both rose by 4 basis points, to 2.21 percent and 2.19 percent, respectively. For the 30-day average, the compound and simple yields are 2.19 percent and 2.17 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Assets of tax-exempt money funds showed a small inflow of cash to the funds in the current week, as assets grew by $73 million, to $96.3 billion.
Walter S. Frank, IBC/Donoghue's chief economist, noted that the municipal market now had a heavy supply of refunding issues and would probably see more yet, as municipalities come back to the debt market with new issues at the beginning of a new fiscal year.
"Insurance companies could also boost the supply of municipals for sale and drive yields higher," Mr. Frank said, "if in the wake of Hurricane Andrew's storm damage and their need to raise cash in order to make good on policies, they sell off some of their municipal bond holdings."
The average number of days left to maturity of tax-exempt securities held in fund portfolios remained unchanged at 64.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-free yield is 3.06 percent, while the equivalent for investors in the 31 percent tax bracket is 3.20 percent.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Strong Municipal Money Market funds ran its streak as the best-performing fund to 10 consecutive weeks, with a return of 2.97 percent. The fund's distributor is Strong/Corneliuson of Milwaukee.
 
Taxable Fund Yield: 3.107%
 Meanwhile, yields in taxable money market funds slipped, as assets jumped by $6.6 billion, to a total of $505.7 billion. The growth came from institutions fleeing to their traditional parking place in money market funds. A weak dollar has hurt both the bond and stock markets.
Analysts also took note that part of the $7.1 billion increase in institutional assets, to $184.5 billion, was the result of two funds moving over from the retail category.
The average seven-day compounded yield for taxable money market funds was 3.07 percent, down 3 basis points, with the simple yield down 2 basis points, to 3.02 percent. For the 30-day average, the compounded and simple yields are both down 3 basis points, to 3.12 percent and 3.07 percent, respectively.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios fell by one, to 63, though that was still the longest period to maturity in 10 years.
The Standby Reserve Fund, distributed by Cowen & Company in New York, had the best return among general purpose funds, with a yield of 3.84 percent, as it maintained its top spot for the fourth straight week.
By comparison, the average bank money market account slipped only one basis point this week, to yield 3.02 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication in North Palm Beach, Fla.

HEADLINE: Altered Riverside South Plan Wins Messinger Over

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
To win approval for his Riverside South development project from Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, Donald J. Trump agreed yesterday to contribute $5 million to the renovation of the 72d Street IRT subway station, set aside at least 10 percent of the apartments for subsidized housing and insure there would be no net increase of sewage to the North River treatment plant in Harlem.
He also agreed to pay half the annual maintenance for a public park that is to be built along the Hudson River as part of the project. 
 With these and other guarantees in hand after a 36-hour session that capped weeks of negotiations, Ms. Messinger announced her support for the enormous project, which is to rise over the abandoned rail yards from 59th to 72d Street in Manhattan.
In her years as a Councilwoman from the Upper West Side, Ms. Messinger was not known as a developer's friend. So her approval, while advisory, may add considerable political luster to the Trump proposal, which goes next to the New York City Planning Commission for review.
Indeed, she said last month that she would not support Riverside South in the form in which it had been considered by Community Board 7. The board, whose position is also advisory, turned down the project 35 to 1 after a series of hearings in which sentiment leaned against it.
The basic scope of Riverside South remains unchanged -- 16 apartment buildings with some 5,700 units, a 2.1 million-square-foot office and studio building and a 21.5-acre park. But Ms. Messinger said there had been "progress on almost all fronts" in talks with the Riverside South Planning Corporation, which is headed by Richard A. Kahan and financed by Mr. Trump.
And yesterday, Ms. Messinger described Riverside South as a "project that has enormous potential for breathing new life into our city."
In turn, Mr. Kahan said her decision would send a "powerful signal that there's a new way of doing business in New York City."
She signed an agreement yesterday with Mr. Kahan and Mr. Trump. The agreement recognizes the "poor condition" of the chronically overcrowded subway station stop at 72d and Broadway and the "additional riders the project will add to this station." Given this, the developer would contribute $5 million to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for rehabilitating the station, provided that the authority is committed to financing the balance.
If government subsidies are available to finance such construction, the developer would set aside at least 20 percent of the apartments as "affordable housing for persons of low, moderate and middle income." Absent such subsidies, the developer would subsidize 10 percent of the units out of proceeds from the project.
To prevent an increase in the overall flow of sewage to the North River sewage treatment plant in view of its operational flaws and uncertainty over its capacity, the developer would either build a sewage treatment plant on site or help finance the installation of low-flow plumbing fixtures in existing buildings in the area served by the plant.
 
Meeting Demand
 After December 1994, the developer would be able to hook up to the North River plant if the chairman of the City Planning Commission certified in writing that the plant "has sufficient capacity to meet the project's demand and the demand of all other affordable housing projects," as described in the city's 10-year capital plan, in the area served by the plant.
The developer would build a temporary park on the site "as soon as possible" after the renovation of the elevated section of the West Side Highway, whose course is eventually to be shifted inland to accommodate the permanent park. The developer would also contribute at least half the annual maintenance cost of the permanent park.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Toyota Posts 63% Decline In Yearly Net

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 26

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest car maker, today reported a 63 percent drop in operating profits for its latest financial year, citing weak demand for cars and a strong Japanese yen.
The company said its operating profit tumbled to 124.86 billion yen, or about $1 billion, for the year ended June 30, while current profit slumped 34.6 percent, to 375.86 billion yen, or about $3.03 billion. 
 In Japan, operating profits are pretax earnings that include special profits and losses; they are considered the best indicator of business health. Current profits are also pretax earnings but include gains and losses on investments in stocks and bonds and results from other nonoperating activities.
 
Expects to Maintain Profits
 "Slow car demand will fuel competition, and there are unpredictable factors such as currency rates and overseas demand," Toyota's vice president, Tatsuro Toyoda, said at a news conference. "But we expect we can maintain profits at previous-year levels."
Auto industry analysts said the drop in earnings was expected because of the slower demand for cars in Japan's slack economy. They added that Toyota's foreign exchange losses were larger than expected.
"The yen was very strong against both U.S. and European currencies," Mr. Toyoda said. "Put together, that had quite a severe impact on our profits."
Toyota hopes the Government's measures to stimulate Japan's economy will lead to a mild rebound in the demand for vehicles.
For the year ending June 30, 1993, the company forecast sales of about 9.4 trillion yen, or about $75.8 billion, up about 5 percent from the 8.94 trillion yen, or about $72 billion, for the year recently ended. But analysts say Toyota may be too optimistic about recovery in auto market.
"If they're basing their estimates on strong recovery in Japan and the U.S., they're in for an unpleasant surprise," said Mike Morizumi, an analyst with Lehman Brothers.
"Toyota's boosting market share in the U.S. and that's a plus, but they can't hope for very substantial improvement unless the domestic market turns around," said Masayuki Mochizuki, an analyst with W. I. Carr (Overseas) Ltd.
Toyota's profit growth in the current fiscal year will be flat at best, and even that target may be difficult to hit, analysts said.
The company will try to maintain profits by cutting costs and making more marketing efforts, Mr. Toyoda said. "And we must achieve our sales goal for this year," he added. "No matter what."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Rebound, Trading in a Narrow Range

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued to rebound slightly yesterday from all-time lows against the German mark and rose against other currencies. Gold prices fell.
"The dollar is staking a base around 1.4000 marks but we're still uncertain because that's near its new low," said Ziggy Zborowski, a trader at the Bank Leumi Trust Company. 
 The dollar closed at 1.4065 marks in New York, up from the 1.4027 on Tuesday and from its low close of 1.4015 marks it reached Monday. The dollar was quoted in late European trading at 1.4070 marks, up from 1.4020 late Tuesday.
Traders said the dollar moved in a narrow range, partly on speculation about a realignment of the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System, which links the currencies of most governments in the European Community.
Reports that a member of Germany's central bank supported a realignment lifted the mark temporarily. Later, the Bundesbank clarified that the official was only restating policy that realignment was possible, rather than advocating it. The statement pulled the mark back down.
John McCarthy, chief currency dealer at ABN-AMRO Bank in New York, said traders had been mildly disappointed by news that orders to American factories for durable goods fell 3.4 percent in July. "But the good sign was that the dollar still held up fairly well under that pressure," Mr. McCarthy said.
In New York, the dollar closed at 124.85 Japanese yen, up from 124.55 on Tuesday. Earlier in London, the dollar was quoted at 124.95 yen. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 124.95 yen, up 0.10 yen.
In New York, the British pound closed at $1.9860, down from $1.9895 on Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.2580 Swiss francs, up from 1.2475; 4.7950 French francs, up from 4.7825; 1,074.75 Italian lire, up from 1,071.00, and 1.19175 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18985.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.2590 Swiss francs, up from 1.2475; 4.7965 French francs, up from 4.7815; 1.5855 Dutch guilders, up from 1.5804; 1,074.25 Italian lire, up from 1,070.50, and 1.1907 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1889.
Gold prices fell worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $338.30 an ounce, down from $340.60 on Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell to a late bid price of $338.15 an ounce, off $2.35.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $338.35, from $341.65 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $338.75, from $341.65 late Tuesday.
On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $3.669 an ounce, down from $3.70 Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Bonn Punches, The Dollar Rolls

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THOSE looking to put the best face on the falling dollar need not look far: Cheaper greenbacks mean more exports, which in turn means more jobs for an economy in need of same.
And in this case, the best face is not a bad face at all. For one thing, the theory is on target. While the kick will not come soon -- certainly not before the election -- bargain dollars should eventually make everything from Boeing's jets to Frank Perdue's chickens more competitive abroad. 
 For another, the choices are limited. With German money markets paying close to 10 percent interest, the flight from dollars could not be easily reversed without significant help from the German central bank. And in the view of Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Public Policy, the inflation-busters at the Bundesbank would be "the last people on earth to listen" to Washington's pleas for easier money.
Nonetheless, few economists seem inclined to relax and enjoy the show. If the retreat from dollars turns into a rout, they say, the feeble economic recovery would be trampled underfoot. Even if it does not, the dollar-mark realignment could undo the best-laid plans for European monetary union and liberalized world trade.
Just why the dollar chose this month to head south is anyone's guess. C. Fred Bergsten of the Institute for International Economics points to George Bush's failure to outline a credible attack on the budget deficit and, more generally, to "growing doubts that the U.S. is going to get its economic act together."
But the current lure of German currency is hardly a mystery. With American banks paying less than 4 percent interest and their counterparts in Frankfurt paying more than 9 percent, investors who are otherwise inclined to hold cash in dollars are buying marks.
This rush from the dollar, notes Richard Cooper of Harvard, is self-limiting: at some depressed exchange rate, the extra five percentage points of interest in marks will not compensate investors for the risk that the dollar will bounce back. But Mr. Cooper does not claim to know where the buck will stop. And like most economists, he doubts the capacity of governments to manage exchange rates by direct intervention in the $1-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market.
For most Americans, a modest further decline in the dollar could prove a nonevent. The initial impact, argues Mr. Lawrence, is like a tax, as higher prices for imported goods erode Americans' purchasing power. Later, it should stimulate sales, as American goods become more attractive both at home and abroad. But the overall impact is likely to be lost in the tides of changing domestic demand.
Georges de Menil, senior editor of the European-based journal Economic Policy, emphasizes the positive: the system works. The whole point of floating exchange rates, he argues, is to let the big economies pursue diverging priorities -- in this case American recession-fighting versus German inflation-fighting -- without forcing confrontation.
The real risk, economists agree, is that the walk away from the dollar will turn into a run. Panic selling of dollar-denominated securities would devastate Wall Street. And it could drive the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates, tumbling Main Street back into recession.
Most economists regard this as very unlikely, as long as governments lean against the speculative winds by purchasing dollars at appropriate moments. Most, but not all, that is. "If I were James Baker," Mr. Bergsten said, "I'd be terrified."
What does worry many Europe-watchers, though, is the fallout on European Community politics.
Under the deal tentatively struck at Maastricht in December, Europe would eventually become a single economy with a single currency. But Germany's current take-no-prisoners effort to contain domestic inflation with tight money, while paying much of the bill for German unification with capital borrowed from abroad, is stiffening the resistance to the currency union from other members of the community.
Mr. Lawrence notes that high interest rates and appreciating exchange rates against the dollar, both courtesy of the Bundesbank, threaten the recovery of recession-mired Britain. And they could push the sputtering Italian and French economies over the edge. The timing could hardly be worse: France has scheduled a referendum on Maastricht for Sept. 20.
Another consequence of the dollar-mark shuffle could affect Americans more directly. The White House has been counting on German manufacturers to neutralize the influence of protectionist-minded European farmers manning the barricades against global trade liberalization. But Mr. Cooper notes that German industry's interest in open trade -- and for that matter, the rest of Europe's -- declines as currency appreciation makes its products less competitive abroad.
The almighty dollar may be a symbol whose time has gone. But the pain of adjustment, alas, goes deeper than $200 restaurant meals in Paris.

HEADLINE: ON PRO HOCKEY;
N.H.L. Meeting Instigated Little

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG BEACH, Fla.

 BODY:
This just in from the Gulf Coast, where National Hockey League owners have concluded their summer meetings: Helmets are now optional, and so is common sense . . . ice barons survive brainstorms in tropical hurricane zone . . . they came, they argued, they compromised . . . it's not the heat, it's the stupidity.
They could have done so much more. For the first time, owners seriously considered a rule that would have mandated the ejection of fistfighters. This would have eliminated the jobs of three dozen full-time goons whose only major league skill is to punch people's noses while standing on ice skates. 
 Almost half the teams were that dovish. But the hawks, led by the Edmonton Oilers, stopped the abolitionists' momentum by proposing a face-saving compromise that really changes little. The new rule says that only "instigators" of fights will be ejected. Last season, when instigators got only an extra two minutes, only 26 percent of the fights included an instigator penalty. With the new rule so much harsher, will referees see even that many instigators?
Pat Quinn, the president of the Vancouver Canucks, put it best. "The spontaneous fight was the only thing I was trying to protect," he said.
In this context, spontaneous is a euphemism. Precious few fights, maybe 1 in 10, are really spontaneous exchanges that flare suddenly from hard contact. What Quinn and his faction protected is the calculated, consensual fist fight between two willing participants.
Most hockey followers can predict these "spontaneous" fights weeks in advance. If, for instance, the Rangers play Detroit, Tie Domi and Bob Probert will probably have another "spontaneous" fight. These sideshows usually make the evening newscasts and give hockey's image a black eye. But they also sell tickets, at least according to some hockey executives, who have better sense than to say such a thing on the record.
Another privately-spoken fear is that elimination of goons could change the nationalist makeup of the sport. Most fighting specialists are English-speaking Canadians trained in the junior leagues of western Canada and Ontario. If those three dozen jobs were to open up, many would be filled by the skilled players of Europe, who are joining the league at a rapid rate, especially since the fall of the Soviet bloc.
Most N.H.L. executives come from Canada's junior leagues. They don't mind strip-mining the former Iron Curtain countries for stars like Jaromir Jagr, Pavel Bure and Sergei Fedorov, but they keep the peace at home if middle and low-level jobs are filled by home-boy hooligans who consider even Quebec to be foreign soil.
When they get pious, the executives like to declare "fighting isn't the big problem, it's the stick work." This was heard often at poolside over the weekend. So how will they curb these dangerous fouls? Mostly by changing one rule slightly, on an experimental basis, for the exhibition season. In layman's terms, you now can't hit a player above the waist with your stick. It used to be, you couldn't hit him above the shoulders. And, if you must break Mario Lemieux's hand with an unprovoked slash, try not to make it so obvious.
The most curious rule change is the one about helmets. Since 1979, any player joining the league had to wear one. Now, the helmet is optional. To critics, this is like telling motorists that seatbelts are optional.
But the pro-choice faction offers two arguments. One is that players without helmets are treated with more respect. If your face and head are bare, the theory goes, an opponent will be less likely to hit you there with a stick because the risks to you (and the possible punishments to him) are greater. The marketing part of the argument is that players whose faces and hairstyles are easier to see will become more familiar to fans who attend the games and watch on television. Familiarity, so that theory goes, breeds commerce.
This leads to Gil Stein, the interim president of the league, who replaced purge victim John Ziegler this summer, and is attempting to pursue a progressive agenda with aggressive methods.
Ziegler avoided television exposure; the Stein administration seeks it, and hopes to get a game-of-the-week contract from ESPN this season. Ziegler avoided confronting the goon issue; Stein forced a debate and almost forced a vote. Ziegler dragged his tassle-loafered feet on the possibilities of Olympic participation; Stein is pushing for it.
When owners appointed Stein, they expected a caretaker presidency. Stein, figuring his days were numbered anyway, is campaigning for the full-time job of commissioner. His chances are probably those of a snowball in Florida, for several reasons. He's a holdover from the Ziegler administration, he's an American, he's over 60 years old and he's willing to break eggs to make an omlette, as he showed by forcing the resignation of Brian O'Neill, the executive vice president, who is a respected member of the old boys' club that runs the league.
Asked about his chances, Stein said he's been getting plenty of positive feedback, although he added that he's not naive enough to think that this assures him of anything. Asked about other candidates, he made a weak joke about Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, possibly looking for work. Perhaps in a few months, they will both vie for places on the unemployment line.
