HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Saving Few Dollars Doesn't Make Sense

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Just when the Yankees are learning that their minor league system is capable of producing players talented enough to play in the major leagues, they are cutting back on the operation that has led to that discovery.
Just when rookies like Sam Militello, Andy Stankiewicz and Bob Wickman have provided a fresh look for a stale old team, the Yankees have decided not to have a team in the fall instructional league this year. This was an economic decision, one that should save them about $125,000, maybe a few thousand more. That sum will go a long way this winter toward signing Barry Bonds or Ruben Sierra or Greg Maddux or David Cone. 
 When George Steinbrenner, the absentee owner, began his reign in New York, one of his first acts was to slash the size of the Yankees' scouting staff. The Yankees, he concluded, were spending a lot of money unnecssarily on people who didn't add much to the organization.
To Steinbrenner's credit, though, he learned that he had made a mistake, and he rectified it, restoring the scouting staff to a size commensurate with the goals of an organization that wanted to win.
The Yankees are among seven teams that won't have an instructional league team this fall. Some organizations, like the San Francisco Giants and the Milwaukee Brewers, will have minicamps for minor leaguers instead next February, just before spring training.
A Yankees' minicamp is a possibility. At least the idea has been raised. "It's waiting to be budgeted. It's part of the 1993 budget," Brian Sabean, the vice president for player development and scouting, said yesterday.
Pre-spring training minicamps run about three weeks; the instructional league lasts six weeks. Depending on an organization's willingness to spend money, it could invite 30 players or it could invite 60 to attend the instructional league. One fall not long ago, the Yankees had two teams in the Florida section of the league. The Los Angeles Dodgers plan to have two teams in Arizona this year.
Why won't the Yankees have any teams?
"It was handed down from the partnership, and I take orders from headquarters," Sabean said. "They give me the money, and I try to make the programs work with the money I get."
The purpose of the instructional league is precisely what the name implies. Young players receive instruction in a more concentrated and more individualized way than is available during a minor league season.
Militello, the 22-year-old pitcher who has caused a sensation in four starts with the Yankees, spent the past two falls in the instructional league.
"The first year I worked on developing a changeup," Militello said yesterday. "Last year I pulled a hamstring and got to pitch in only four innings, but I still worked on the changegeup again. I worked on becoming more consistent with it. I also worked on my stretch delivery, holding runners on. It definitely helped."
When pitchers pitch in instructional league games, they do not worry about hits and runs or victories and defeats. They are there to work on specific elements of their pitching, so they likely will throw a changeup, if that is what they are developing, instead of the fastball they would go to if it were a game that counted.
Jerry Nielsen went to the instructional league in 1989. He had spent the first two years in the organization as a reliever, but since the Yankees wanted him to become a starting pitcher, he needed more innings of work to build up his arm. He went back the next year for half the instructional season, then went the whole way last fall.
"Last year was probably the most beneficial," the 26-year-old Yankee said. "I lowered my arm angle a tad to get more movement on my fastball. I had freer arm action."
Russ Springer, another of the young home-grown pitchers now in the majors, has spent three autumns in the instructional league.
"It's positive to go there," he said. "It's helped me. You want to win down there, but you don't have the pressure where you have to win. You're working on things and you can afford to do that there."
Pat Kelly is another who spend every autumn playing in the instructional league.
"I was there working on my hitting," the second baseman said. "For me, the individual kind of work was important. I went in the cage, hit, looked at tapes, then hit again. It helped. It got me to the big leagues. It got me exposure. It showed them I had desire. I had the desire to be there when I could have been home sleeping."
This fall the Yankees' minor leaguers will have plenty of time to sleep.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Awlful Choice on Bosnia

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
The Bosnian "peace" conference under way in London has the earmarks of deadly farce. Western leaders make tough noises about standing up for principle -- the principle of not legitimizing Serb conquests in Bosnia -- and prepare to set up a long-term negotiating process. Meanwhile they know that their efforts will not work, or work in time, to stop Bosnian Muslims from being slaughtered or driven into refugee camps.
Their game at the conference is to evade the real and alarming choice: Either do what they can militarily and economically to back up their principles and save lives that way; or accept Serbian demands for partitioning Bosnia along ethnic lines, strike the best bargain they can, and save lives that way. 
 Bush officials duplicitously pretend otherwise. President Bush and Acting Secretary of State Eagleburger insist they will not reward Serbian aggression and will settle for nothing less than restoration of the rights and territory of Bosnian Muslims. Yet they know that nothing they are doing, or plan to do, will bring this about.
George Kenney, the Yugoslav desk officer in the State Department, declared as much Tuesday when he resigned from the Foreign Service.
Western Europe's policy is no less cynical than Washington's. European leaders say they are beginning a new chapter in the Yugoslav peace process, one that will take several months to show results. Yet they understand full well that there will be little left of the Muslims in Bosnia several months hence.
Winter arrives early in the Balkans, as Europeans are well aware. Soon it will entomb the hundreds of thousands of ill-clad and unhoused Muslims.
This real policy choice of which I speak is deeply troubling to me. It is doubly disturbing because I and others have argued for months for Western leaders to take steps that had a decent chance of avoiding the present trap. All in vain.
Western leaders answered with the worst sort of cynicism and duplicity. As public disgust over Serbian horrors mounted, they tried to quiet the uproar by flying in food for the Sarajevan victims (though doing nothing for the countless others in remote parts of Bosnia). Even as they fed the dying, they secretly seemed to hope that the Muslims would give up quickly so the whole mess would go away.
Then the Western leaders tried to sell the phoniest of arguments. They maintained there were only two choices: massive ground force deployments and thus a Vietnam-like quagmire, or what they were already doing, i.e. feeding victims.
In fact, there were and are lots of options short of dispatching ground troops. (Ironically, it was the U.S. that toyed briefly and idiotically with the idea of sending 100,000 troops to protect relief convoys, and verged on sliding into another quagmire.)
Months ago, Western leaders could have put U.N. monitors on the Greek and Romanian sides of their borders with Serbia. This would have sharply reduced trade with Serbia and made U.N. sanctions far more effective. Months ago, they could have begun proceedings to charge Serbian and Croatian leaders with war crimes and launched nonstop negotiations to apply constant world pressure. Only in recent days and weeks have they acknowledged and just begun to act on these options.
There is still more they can do, short of land war, to force the Serbs to think again. They can threaten air attacks against military targets in Serbia, like airfields and bridges to Bosnia. They can threaten to arm the virtually defenseless Muslims -- and Albanians in Kosovo, if necessary -- to discourage Serbia from spreading its policy of "ethnic cleansing."
Western leaders have not been without means to influence events in the Balkans. They have chosen to ignore and deny those means, for reasons (fear of runaway separatism in Europe, impending elections?) we are all free to speculate about. Nor will they explain why they will use air power in Iraq and not in Bosnia.
Now, in conscience, they must decide on a clear course. If they have no intention of taking tough action immediately, they should stop posturing about principle and strike the best deal possible with Serbs to save Muslim lives. Or, far preferably, they should do all they reasonably can to honor principle and save lives.

HEADLINE: Retraining Won't Undo 'Free Trade' Disaster

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Test of Mr. Clinton's Backbone" (editorial, Aug. 9) criticizes Representative Richard A. Gephardt's objection to the trade agreement with Mexico and Canada. You cavalierly dismiss the valid concerns of labor and many manufacturers, although you don't mention them, over the agreement. Sure, people will lose jobs, you agree, but we can overcome the problem by retraining them. Retrain them for what? Selling hamburgers and fried chicken? To enter the automobile, electronics, computer and other distressed industries?
Retraining is no panacea for unemployment. It worked somewhat after World War II, but it has been a useless alternative ever since. It's an idea unsuitable to our troubled times. When you have a sick economy and a depressed and shrinking manufacturing base, it won't work. And even when the economy is humming, it's a questionable expedient. Even in welfare, retraining has been a wasteful effort; with all the retraining programs attempted in that area, what progress have we made in reducing welfare rolls? 
 Sorry, Representative Gephardt is right. What he and others are saying about the agreement with Mexico is true. Once the Bush Administration seals the agreement, the outcry will be nationwide and deafening. Take it from one who had been associated with an industry that has fallen victim to what you choose to call free trade.
 
CHARLES REICHMAN
Great Neck, L.I., Aug. 9, 1992
 
The writer retired as editor of Knitting Times.

HEADLINE: Retraining Won't Undo 'Free Trade' Disaster;
No to Transaction Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri has proposed a tax on trade between Mexico and the United States to finance retraining and adjustment for United States workers harmed by the transition to free trade and environmental infrastructure costs. Don Newquist, chairman of the International Trade Commission, states that while he does not prefer such a tax, it may be the only way to obtain the needed funds (Op-Ed, Aug. 12). The transaction tax is a bad idea. I will give three reasons why and suggest an alternative.
(1) Import tariffs are highly regressive. They are used as a revenue measure almost exclusively by countries unable to collect taxes through other more sophisticated techniques. Surely, we can do better. 
 (2) The average tariff on United States imports from Mexico is 4 percent. For the proposed transaction tax to raise sufficient sums, it would have to be at least 2 percent. If United States imports from Mexico are $35 billion, roughly their annualized level in 1992, this would raise $700 million. However, a 2 percent tax would remove half the benefit we hope to provide traders by gradually eliminating the tariff. It requires contortion to move two steps forward and simultaneously take one step back.
(3) Even more illogical, this transaction tax would apply only to United States exports destined for Mexico and Mexican exports to us. Third country traders, like Japan and Germany, could ship to either country without the tax. We would thus introduce discrimination against our own traders. This is lunacy. Charging the tax on imports from all sources has already been rejected by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade parties. They argue if the United States wishes to tax commodities as a revenue device, then tax all commodities, domestic and imported alike.
My suggestion for raising funds for the desirable purpose that Representative Gephardt and Mr. Newquist intend is to earmark the tariffs on imports from Mexico. This would raise at least double the revenue of a transaction tax of 2 percent. Since the revenue from these tariffs is scheduled to decline to zero over 10 years, we must start planning to do without these funds in any event. And it is the transition adjustment and retraining that is at issue here. Use the transition revenue to pay for the transition costs.
 
SIDNEY WEINTRAUB
Austin, Tex., Aug. 12, 1992
 
The writer is a visiting scholar at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, University of Texas.

HEADLINE: HURRICANE ANDREW;
After Homes Are Ruined, Hopes Are Dashed

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 27

 BODY:
It is a figure that staggers the imagination: at least one of every 10 of the two million residents of Miami and its southern suburbs was left without a home by Hurricane Andrew. With the storm gone and the authorities occupied with cleaning up debris and delivering food and water, the many homeless are now searching, desperately and largely without help, for places to live.
In the working-class suburb of Princeton south of Miami, for instance, more than 40 members of the Soto family have been crowded into the four-bedroom home of the family patriarch, Jose Soto, since Monday. Over the years, nine of Mr. Soto's children, their spouses and 23 of his grandchildren have built or bought homes within blocks of his house. All were destroyed. 
 "We're all of us looking for places to live, but we just don't know where to go for help," Nelly Soto said this afternoon as she hauled ice from her car into her father's house, which was left without electricity or potable water.
 
The Boom to Come
 In the long run, the destruction inflicted on Dade County, which includes about 30 municipalities, is expected to lead to a construction and employment boom. Kate Hale, the director of emergency services for the county, estimated Wednesday that at least 63,000 single-family homes and apartment buildings have been destroyed.
But for the moment, thousands of families of every economic class and ethnic background share the Sotos' plight. If nothing else, the storm was indiscriminate, displacing a few millionaire owners of mansions in the Cocoplum section of Coral Gables as well as many migrant farm workers living in trailer parks.
Insurance claims adjusters have descended on Dade County, trying to find homeowners who need cash for emergency supplies and new housing. But the dire conditions here are making it hard for adjusters and customers to find each other, and the checks being written are hard to cash because so few banks have reopened. [Page A15.]
Carlos Vargas, a Homestead resident who works for the state welfare agency and whose own trailer was destroyed, said he had seen people wandering the streets in a daze, with nowhere to go and no idea of where to seek help. Those without friends or relatives, he said, "are either moving into abandoned buildings or taking shelter in construction sites."
 
Staying With Friends
 Ann Jones, a 43-year-old customer relations officer at a travel company that sells real estate time shares, was forced out of her three-bedroom house when the storm leveled everything except the kitchen. She and her two children are staying with friends.
"I'm a working single parent who lives from paycheck to paycheck, and I paid the mortgage just before the storm hit," she said. "When I get back to work, I'll get a paycheck, but I don't have the money in the bank right now to pay first, last and security" for temporary rental quarters, as most landlords here require.
Ms. Jones said she had been left homeless by a hurricane once before. While living in her native Mississippi in 1969, she lost her house to Hurricane Camille but was helped by a government relief effort.
"After Camille, they sent people out door to door right away to see what you needed, and within three months, I was in a brand new house built after the hurricane," she said. "But this time, there are no numbers to call for help on housing, and when you call the other emergency numbers, you can never get through to anybody."
In fact, Ms. Jones said, when she finally got through to the authorities this week, "they said that unless you have a real emergency, don't bother us." She is willing to concede that her situation might not qualify as a real emergency by current standards, "since I have a place to stay for two weeks," but she wonders what will happen to the legions of homeless.
Recently, southern Florida has been a buyer's or renter's market. As a result of overbuilding in the 1980's and the recession of the 1990's, it has been possible to rent a decent one-bedroom apartment for $250 a month or buy a four-bedroom house for under $100,000.
But real estate analysts here are already predicting that prices will rise sharply, to the disadvantage of those who used up their savings to become homeowners and may find themselves unable to re-enter the market.
One such person is Tressey Walker, a 21-year-old school crossing guard. With the help of her mother and sister, she paid cash for a house. "And now all that money has gone down the drain," Ms. Walker said of the ruined $80,000, four-bedroom house that she shared with her three children in the southern suburb of Perrine.
On the rental side, even those able to meet the various requirements of landlords are running into trouble. They are finding that demand for housing of every type has taken a sharp leap upward precisely as the supply has dropped even more abruptly.
"I went over to the apartment complex where my sister lives," Mae Johnson, a 40-year-old mother of two teen-agers, said as she waited in a food distribution line. "There are empty apartments, but the manager told me that the people already living there whose own apartments are messed up get first choice."
For the thousands who lived precariously in trailer parks or migrant labor camps, the situation is even more onerous. Olinda Bonilla, a 30-year-old plant nursery worker who came to Florida six years ago from El Salvador, sat on a cot in a shelter at Homestead Middle School this morning, her two children at her side, and acknowledged that the storm had dealt a blow to her hopes:
"I applied for public housing a year ago, and I thought my chances of getting something soon were good. Nobody has come to talk to me about where I'm going to live now, but since everything here has been destroyed, I suppose that the public housing is also gone, and that the people who used to live there are ahead of me."
Enormous as the number of homeless is already, government officials say they expect it to grow. Thousands of people in Dade County are still living in the rubble of their homes, hoping to fend off looters.
As has been the case with distribution of food and water, private enterprise has rushed to fill the wide gaps in official efforts to deal with the sudden housing crisis. The Greater Miami Apartment Association is making available a limited amount of free temporary housing to those who can prove they have been left homeless by the hurricane. Some real estate brokers are also offering, without commissions, to match those left homeless with apartments that are vacant.
 
Everyday Things a Problem
 Many real estate agencies, however, have been immobilized by the storm, with no telephone and electrical service and their offices and records destroyed or waterlogged. Branches of many banks are still closed, and many of those that are open are limiting withdrawals, so that even those homeless who still have checkbooks do not have the means to make a down payment or security deposit.
Government officials realize that sooner or later they will be forced to confront the housing crisis. Some, like Alex Muxo, City Manager of Homestead, 90 percent of whose 30,000 residents are believed to be without a place to live, are already trying to mobilize a construction effort to provide temporary quarters.
"One of the things we have thought of is possibly a tent city," Mr. Muxo said. But such a plan locally would require an effort beyond the abilities of the small municipalities south and west of Miami.
In the meantime, people like the Sotos wait. "Fifteen years of effort to get everybody into houses of their own, and it disappeared in hours," a tearful Maria Soto said this afternoon.

Ms. Bonilla, who left El Salvador six years ago, admitted the storm has challenged her hopes for a better life. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times) (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: After Two-Month Standoff, California Appears on Verge of Passing a Budget

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 27

 BODY:
It has taken nearly two months, two agonizing months, during which California has been forced to pay it bills with i.o.u.'s, seen its once-enviable credit rating ruined, its old and poor threatened with loss of health care and its college classes shut. But it appears now that the Government of California, paralyzed by recession, is finally close to passing a budget.
Weariness, lack of pay, panic over getting re-elected, public ridicule and political realities are combining to force members of the Legislature to end a protracted stalemate with Gov. Pete Wilson in erasing a $10.7 billion budget gap. The likely winner in this standoff, at least in the short run, is the Republican Governor, but it remains to be seen how the public responds to the painful cuts in public services he would impose. 
 The settlement that is emerging reflects the fiendishly complex world of California politics: the Governor and the Democratic Speaker of the State Assembly, Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco, are like two scorpions in a bottle; the 250,000-member California Teachers Association holds enormous political power and throws its weight behind Mr. Brown, and the powerful Democratic President pro tem of the State Senate, David A. Roberti of Los Angeles, seems to want Governor Wilson to make him a judge when term limits force him to retire in two years.
 
Resigned to Accepting Cuts
 To isolate Speaker Brown, Governor Wilson is backing a deal being worked out by Mr. Roberti and the Republican leader, Senator Kenneth L. Maddy of Fresno. The liberal Mr. Brown, in turn, has been courting the Republican right wingers in the Assembly who have little love for the more moderate Republican Governor.
Oddly, the budget is snagged not over how to balance this year's broken budget but over the Governor's efforts to limit the growth in state spending for public education in future years. Having accepted the reality that there is no more money and having given up on raising taxes, liberal Democrats have glumly resigned themselves to enormous cuts in welfare, university support and other programs, but not on future education spending.
On Friday, the Senate is expected to pass the Roberti-Maddy plan, which closely resembles the Governor's own proposal. Its fate in the Assembly is less certain because of Mr. Brown's opposition. Agreement is difficult because the California Constitution requires a two-third's vote on budget matters, or 54 votes in an Assembly with 47 Democrats and 33 Republicans.
But there are growing signs that the Speaker is losing his grip on his battle-weary troops. "People here are truly exhausted," said Assemblywoman Delaine Eastin, a Democrat from Union City who is chairwoman of the Education Committee. "Every incumbent is in great danger now. If the Senate accepts it, there will be great pressure on us to accept." She added, referring to the Governor, "People feel, give this knucklehead what he wants."
Speaker Brown said on Wednesday that he would "lock down" the Assembly on Friday until a budget was passed. The legislative session officially ends on Monday.
In an interview as he walked into the Capitol this morning, Governor Wilson expressed confidence a conclusion was near. "It sounds like they intend to finish before we need a special session," he said. "They don't want that for sure because it means we have to start from scratch."
Whatever the precise details of the budget agreement, it will mean the beginning of the dismantling of many of California's vaunted social and educational services as the state copes with its worst economic downturn since World War II. State spending is expected to drop by more than $2 billion this fiscal year compared with last, or about 5 percent.
To be cut are health and welfare programs, by from 4.5 percent to 10 percent; Medi-Cal, the state's health-care plan for the poor, will be slashed by eliminating such "optional" programs as dental care for adults. The state's program for the retarded will lose about $100 million of the $700 million it gets. Fees at the three state college systems are going up drastically as state support for them drops by $419 million, or 10 percent.
But the fight over education has been the toughest, even though spending for schools would continue to grow under the Wilson plan. In 1988, voters passed a constitutional amendment, Proposition 98, that guarantees 40 percent of the general fund to education, except when revenues falter because of a poor economy.
The Governor now wants to "recapture" $1.1 billion of this money from last year, saying local school districts got more than they were entitled to because of the economic slump. But rather than make them repay money already spent, Mr. Wilson would apply the $1.1 billion as a "prepayment" on the current 1992-93 fiscal year and add another $732 million, essentially "loans" to be repaid from Proposition 98 money due in 1993-94 and 1994-95.
Together with $300 million diverted from the 107-campus community college system, which will be forced to raise fees, this would keep state support for public schools steady for this year.
In an interview, the Governor's Secretary of Child Development and Education, Maureen G. DiMarco, said this allowed the schools to keep up with new enrollment and actually increase spending per pupil by 1 percent.
But education leaders cried foul this week. On Wednesday, the elected Superintendent of Public Instruction, Bill Honig, called this "questionable gimmickry" that would reduce the base for school financing in future years and cost public schools $2.9 billion in support they otherwise would have been entitled to over the next four years.
 
"This Is Exploitation'
 Detractors say the Governor is using the school financing to position himself for re-election in 1994, that he is hoping that by limiting growth in Proposition 98 support now he will have a surplus to give schools a healthy "bump" in 1994. "This is exploitation of a real fiscal crisis for positioning," said Ralph J. Flynn, executive director or the California Teachers Association.
The teachers union's political action committee is by far the most potent single political force in California. During the last fiscal year it gave a total of $455,038 to legislators, 83 percent to Democrats. The largest recipient was Speaker Brown ($50,733), even though he has no significant opposition. The second largest recipient ($26,000) was Assemblywoman Doris Allen, a Republican from Orange County; she voted against the Republican Governor on a recent important budget vote.
The union also can marshal enormous forces on Election Day. It is therefore extremely difficult for incumbents, mainly Democrats, to defy its wishes on the budget. Indeed, cynics in Sacramento, of which there are several, argue that Speaker Brown is less interested in blocking Governor Wilson's budget than showing he tried to accommodate the teachers union.
"Oftentimes, he holds onto his positions, but bills pass," said Senator Maddy, the Republican leader, who said that the "more reasonable" members of the Assembly were "just waiting" for something to vote on.
And in the Assembly, the realities were beginning to sink in. "More and more we hear from our constituents, 'get any budget,' and the nuances of the Governor's not wanting to negotiate get lost," said Assemblyman Richard Katz, a Democrat from Los Angeles who opposes the education cuts.
But if the Governor wins, it may be a Pyrrhic victory. "Ultimately all these crises end up hurting the Governor," said a top Republican who is a friend of Mr. Wilson. "It is naive and unrealistic to think people won't blame the guy at the top. His only advantage is that he has a couple of years to redeem himself."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Kenneth L. Maddy of Fresno, Calif., the Republican leader, said the "more reasonable" members of the California Assembly were "just waiting" for something to vote on. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: HURRICANE ANDREW;
Destroyed: Front Line in Fight Against Cocaine Traffickers

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
One of the nation's most important Federal drug interdiction centers was destroyed by Hurricane Andrew, and the Customs Commissioner said today that she expected narcotics traffickers to try to take advantage of the crisis in the next several days and flood South Florida with cocaine and other illegal drugs.
But the Commissioner, Carol Hallett, said Customs operation centers in Jacksonville, Tampa and San Juan, P.R., had assumed radar and aircraft surveillance from the damaged installation at Homestead Air Force Base near Miami. 
 "We've been able to move people around and back up from other air branches," Commissioner Hallett said in a telephone interview from Miami. "There is not one opportunity created by this to give traffickers the slightest edge."
 
Might Never Reopen
 This is the second time in 47 years that Homestead has been destroyed by a hurricane, and it is unclear whether the base, which was already being considered for closing, will ever be rebuilt.
The Air Force sent 85 people to comb through the rubble at Homestead and determine how much damage had been done. Gen. Merrill A. McPeak, the Air Force chief of staff, said in an interview that it would take at least three months to restore power lines and water service at the base, and several more months to clean up the remaining debris at the 3,300-acre installation.
"The chances of returning there within a year are remote," said another senior Air Force official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Last year, the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, a panel charged by Congress with closing unneeded bases to cut military spending, named Homestead as a candidate to be shut down. The severity of the damage has prompted Air Force and Government officials to consider not rebuilding the base at all.
"It would cost hundreds of millions of dollars to put that base back into the shape it was before," General McPeak said. Over the next few months Air Force officials will be analyzing rebuilding costs, he said.
Built in 1942, Homestead was destroyed three years later, on Sept. 15, 1945, by a hurricane with winds of 145 miles an hour. It was officially abandoned three months later. In the three years it was open, Homestead trained hundreds of the Air Force pilots who flew the Berlin Air Lift of 1948. It was rebuilt in 1955 and played a significant role in the Cuban Missile Crisis in 1962, when its bombers and fighter planes were placed on high alert and a tent city of 10,000 Army troops occupied the base.
In recent years, Homestead has been home to an active-duty F-16 fighter wing and the Air Force's water-survival school for air crews, as well as significant elements of the Government program to stop cocaine smugglers headed for the eastern United States.
On Tuesday, all operations and maintenance buildings, the commissary and post exchange were destroyed. All of the remaining 200 public buildings lost their roofs. Two hangars were destroyed, along with two F-16 fighters inside, valued at $14 million each. The Pentagon said that the roofs had also been blown off half the housing on the base and that windows had been shattered in 90 percent of the houses.
The Air Force is scrambling to help the base's 4,400 military personnel and their 4,900 family members who were evacuated before the storm hit. Many of them are living in emergency shelters in or near Dade County. General McPeak said the Air Force would reassign them to other bases as soon as possible.
General McPeak said that the fighter wing's three squadrons would be split up and relocated to other bases. No decision has been made on the fate of an Air Force Reserve F-16 squadron located at Homestead, he said.
The Air Force said the base pumps more than $405.8 million into the Miami-area economy and generates more than 4,000 civilian jobs.
The drug interdiction center lost a Black Hawk helicopter and a Cessna airplane when the maintenance hangar in which they were stored collapsed in the hurricane. But 14 other small Customs aircraft had been flown to Tallahassee before the storm.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
The Clinton Bus Goes to Texas, A Tossup State

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 27

 BODY:
No Democrat has made it to the White House in this century without winning Texas, and today Gov. Bill Clinton went after Texas.
Sweeping from San Antonio to Austin and then heading for Waco in a caravan of buses, accompanied by his running mate, Senator Al Gore, the Democratic nominee relentlessly criticized President Bush's economic policies in an effort to lock up the state's 32 electoral votes. 
 "We need you, Texas," he shouted time and again at rallies and impromptu stops at highway crossroads.
 
Sagging Economy
 Polls indicate that Texas, President Bush's official home and fertile ground for Republicans in recent years, is a tossup at this point in the 1992 race.
The sagging economy is the major aid to Mr. Clinton's effort, but he has also been helped by his being the Governor of a neighboring Southern state, Arkansas.
Like Mr. Clinton, the President has vowed to fight strongly for Texas.
Mr. Clinton was working a rich lode and striking some pay dirt today if the size of the crowd here -- about 10,000 -- and the resonance of its cheers -- deafening -- are reliable indicators.
Caught up in enthusiasm of the partisan audience, Mr. Clinton cried out at the end of his speech, pointing toward a distant, heavily peopled line of trees: "I ask you for your vote -- you, way back underneath that tree, and that tree, and up in that tree."
 
'October Crowd in August'
 Mr. Gore, looking out over the sea of upturned faces and brightly painted political placards, said, "This is an October crowd in August."
Texas has been hard-hit economically not only by the national recession but also by a severe depression in its huge energy industry and cutbacks in military and space programs.
"There are lots of things that I want to do that will be good for Texas," Mr. Clinton said in San Antonio, enumerating the state's hardships during a morning rally. "I'm going to revitalize the energy industry by emphasizing natural gas production and getting more reliance on domestic production, by conservation and by less reliance on foreign oil. I support the space program, and I support new military technology."
Warming up the San Antonio crowd for Mr. Clinton, Gary Mauro, the Texas Land Commissioner and also the chairman of the Clinton campaign in the state, said Mr. Clinton had come to Texas with one overriding message.
"We want jobs in Texas," he said. "We want jobs in Texas. We want jobs in Texas."
Playing a similar role at the start of the Austin rally, Gov. Ann W. Richards said there was one overriding reason the Clinton-Gore ticket would be victorious in the fall. "This is the worst economic situation in Texas in my lifetime -- and I didn't get this hair of mine out of a bottle," she said. Mrs. Richards's hair is white.
The latest Clinton-Gore bus caravan, the fourth since July 17, ends Friday in Tyler. Campaign officials say Clinton poll takers will go to work in the state early next week to assess the impact of the tour on voters.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Al Gore and Gov. Bill Clinton shared the stage with a mariachi musician in San Antonio. (Associated Press)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Says Clinton Is Playing To Voters' Economic Worry

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FINDLAY, Ohio, Aug. 27

 BODY:
President Bush hammered away at Gov. Bill Clinton's political positions today, charging on a Midwestern campaign trek that his rival's foreign-trade policies would destroy jobs and investment and trigger a "worldwide contraction" in economic growth.
Speaking to workers at a factory in St. Louis and at a new industrial park in Findlay, the President likened Mr. Clinton to a "fear monger" who is playing to voters' economic anxieties by proposing to hamstring foreign competitors. 
 "I don't have to ask you to go back to the history books, but there was an occasion when that happened, right before the Great Depression," Mr. Bush said. "And we're fighting our way out of a tough recession now, and we don't need to throw more Americans out of work."
 
Quick Response From Clinton
 The Clinton campaign responded quickly with its own brusque attack on Mr. Bush's economic stewardship.
"Bill Clinton just believes we can do better than the no-growth, no-jobs policies of George Bush," said George Stephanopoulos, the Democratic candidate's communications director. "All George Bush wants to do is cut taxes for the rich."
To find joblessness and privation, Mr. Stephanopoulos suggested, "You don't have to go back 50 years -- you only have to go back three and one half."
By many measures, Mr. Bush has presided over the slowest rate of economic growth since the Depression in the 1930's.
The President's remarks were the climax of a week of speechmaking that has struggled to shift that aura of economic failure from the White House to Mr. Clinton and the Democratic-controlled Congress. This Midwestern swing began what Bush aides said would be a sustained effort to sharpen the differences between Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton on central issues, from taxes to the environment.
 
Differ on Trade Policy
 The attack on Mr. Clinton's trade policies brought into relief one of the sharpest distinctions between the two men. Mr. Bush says he can restore the nation's economic health by lowering taxes and reducing trade barriers, creating export-related jobs here.
Mr. Clinton says he supports greater foreign trade, too. But he has also complained that some foreign nations have an unfair edge over American workers, and that foreign companies should pay more taxes to support American job-training programs.
Under pressure from traditionally Democratic labor unions, Mr. Clinton has declined to endorse an agreement reached this month by the Bush Administration to create a free-trade zone embracing Canada, the United States and Mexico. The unions contend that the agreement will cause a loss of American factory jobs as some companies move to Mexico.
Mr. Clinton's budget proposals assume an additional $38 billion over four years in higher tax revenue from foreign companies that build or buy plants and offices in the United States.
Gene B. Sperling, Mr. Clinton's director for economic issues, said the Democratic nominee has called for tougher collection of existing taxes but has not explicitly endorsed the adoption of any new legislation.
"The aim and intention is not to increase taxes," Mr. Sperling said. "The aim and intention is to make people pay what they owe."
Mr. Bush criticized both of Mr. Clinton's positions today on a three-city tour in Missouri and Ohio.
The President's most bitter attack came in St. Louis, in a speech to about 1,000 workers at an emergency light-and-siren factory. There, he initially drew polite applause but won a long standing ovation after an attack on Mr. Clinton's policies.
"Governor Clinton says his tax increase will crack down on foreign companies," Mr. Bush said. "But that crackdown is more like an eviction notice. And when those companies pack their bags, they'll take those jobs with them. His tax would not only destroy jobs and reduce investment here, it would do the same throughout the global economy, causing a worldwide contraction."
In one of his most pointed attacks, the President said he knows Mr. Clinton's reputation is that of an "opportunist -- as the kind of guy who will say anything, do anything for political gain."
"But he should understand what's at stake here," Mr. Bush continued. "And if he doesn't understand, let me tell him. These are American jobs he's playing politics with."
In what seemed to signal a round of attacks on Mr. Clinton's political credibility, Mr. Bush also accused Mr. Clinton twice today of trying to straddle both sides of controversial issues, using quotations from his opponent's own public remarks to make his point.
In St. Louis, the President ridiculed Mr. Clinton's refusal either to endorse or oppose the free-trade pact. And later, at a rally in downtown Cincinnati, Mr. Bush accused his rival of backpedaling on a proposal to raise fuel-efficiency standards for automobiles. The President has said the plan would increase joblessness among auto workers.
Mr. Clinton said last Friday that he "never said that we shouldn't be flexible" in finding ways to increase fuel efficiency.
To that, Mr. Bush replied: "Is there a pattern going on here? Will Governor Clinton say anything to anybody?"

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Trail;
BARBARA BUSH ATTACKS DEMOCRATS IN CONGRESS

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Barbara Bush wrapped up her post-convention campaign swing in California today with some of the most partisan remarks of her political life, attacking Congressional Democrats and warning of economic doom under Bill Clinton.
"We have good programs, but the Congress is so wrapped up in their own scandals and their own funny doings that they're not willing to back good programs," she said in a radio interview on KABC-AM. 
 "Ever since the Democrats took over the Senate, it's just been an enormous fight," she said. "And what we're hoping is going to happen is they're going to clean the House and clean the Senate and give us a Republican President with a Republican Congress. Then watch how things grow."

HEADLINE: Between Four Rocks and a Hard Place

 BODY:
A dispute over four islands, lingering legacies of the cold war, threatens Japanese-Russian relations and an infusion of much-needed Japanese capital to the Russian economy. Both proud nations need to reach some accommodation and begin to close the books on their past when Boris Yeltsin, Russia's President, visits Tokyo in two weeks.
Japan says the islands belonged to it until Stalin seized them after the World War II surrender in 1945, and wants them back. But rising assertiveness among Russian nationalists, and a restive Russian military, could threaten any government in Moscow bold enough to commit itself to return all four islands. 
 The solution is a compromise that would return two of the islands now. The others could be jointly developed under dual sovereignty, paving the way for eventual reversion.
The islands cause patriotic hearts to pound in both countries. Though Mr. Yeltsin wants to strengthen economic ties with Tokyo, nationalists in Parliament and the military argue that returning the islands would be a sign of Russian weakness. They also fear loss of control of the ice-free straits between the Sea of Okhotsk and the Pacific Ocean.
These fears may dwindle if the U.S. agrees to downsize its naval operations in the area. The nationalists also overvalue the islands' untapped wealth, compared with Russia's need for foreign investment. Finally, U.S. experience suggests that Russia's prestige won't suffer. America's standing rose when it returned Okinawa to Japan in 1971.
Tokyo has no interest in putting Mr. Yeltsin between four rocks and a hard place. It can accept two islands now and two later and still provide generous aid and investment. And Washington could help broker such a compromise, opening a new era in Asian security.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Nodding to Bullies

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
The Serbian onslaught in what was Yugoslavia differs in many ways from the Iraqi occupation two years ago. But the two murderous aggressions have at least one element in common. Both were encouraged by the diplomacy of the Bush Administration.
Everyone remembers what Saddam Hussein took as a green light for his attack. A week before he moved, the U.S. Ambassador to Baghdad, April Glaspie, told him that the United States had "no opinion on the Arab-Arab conflicts like your border disagreement with Kuwait." 
 Ambassador Glaspie is indelibly associated with that disastrous piece of diplomacy. But she was only carrying out Administration policy. Secretary of State Baker instructed her on July 24, 1990, that the U.S. had "no position" on border disputes. And of course this followed years of U.S. aid to the Iraqi dictator.
In Yugoslavia, President Bush was warned by the Central Intelligence Agency in 1990 that the country would break up, probably within 18 months. That unusually firm prediction was made in a National Intelligence Estimate.
But Mr. Bush premised U.S. policy on the continuation of a united Yugoslavia. His instinct for the status quo overrode the reality of events on the ground -- as it had in the Soviet Union, where he held out to the end in support of Mikhail Gorbachev and the survival of the U.S.S.R.
In 1991, therefore, as the strains in Yugoslavia reached the breaking point, the United States position was that it preferred "unity and democracy" there. The Bush Administration said nothing to warn the Serbs against maintaining "unity" by violence. And that silence was crucial.
Prof. Charles Gati, a specialist on Eastern Europe, writes in the current issue of Foreign Affairs that the Bush position was interpreted by the Serbian leadership "as a green light to make Croatia stay within a united Yugoslav federation." There followed brutal Serbian military attacks on Vukovar, Dubrovnik and other parts of Croatia. From there the Serbs moved on to aggression in Bosnia.
"If the United States had done in mid-1991 as it is doing in mid-1992," Professor Gati writes, "the Serbians in Belgrade and Bosnia-Herzegovina might well have been deterred from proceeding as they have."
The same point was made recently by The Economist of London in an extended treatment of the Bosnian tragedy. It criticized both the Bush Administration and West European governments for not warning the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic, early on against aggression.
"The sooner one stands up to a bully," The Economist said, "the less force it takes."
The best account of the diplomatic record is a piece by John Newhouse in The New Yorker, rich in detail and sharp in analysis. He again faults the U.S. and its European allies for their diplomacy in Yugoslavia.
"The key Western governments flouted some first principles of statecraft," Mr. Newhouse says. For one thing, they "made clear what they wouldn't do in Yugoslavia" -- use force -- "thereby surrendering the heavy advantage of ambiguity."
Even after Yugoslavia unmistakably ceased to exist, and Serbian violence became flagrant, the Bush Administration's response was feeble. Its hallmarks, in Mr. Newhouse's words, were "passivity and uncertainty." As recently as last month President Bush dismissed the horror in Bosnia as "a hiccup."
America's voice was the one that could have made the difference. If the Bush Administration had told Mr. Milosevic at the beginning that violence would not be tolerated, I am convinced that he would have kept his guns silent. If we had moved American ships in the Mediterranean when the Serbs shelled Dubrovnik last fall, or when they shot down a European Community helicopter, I think they would have pulled back.
But Mr. Bush did essentially nothing -- until Bill Clinton called for armed protection of relief operations, to be authorized by the U.N. The President's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, called that idea "reckless." Then Mr. Bush adopted it.
Success in American foreign policy -- real success -- lies in preventing war by making clear that there would be a strong response. That is where Presidents succeeded throughout the cold war. It is where George Bush failed in Iraq and Yugoslavia.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
A GARBAGE PLAN FOR THE FUTURE
The City Council approved a long-range plan for disposing of the city's garbage that calls for building a new incinerator in the Brooklyn Navy Yard and significantly increasing recycling. The 51-member Council voted 36 to 15 to approve a revised version of Mayor Dinkins's plan at 7:35 A.M., after a night of red-eyed debate punctuated by shrill speeches and yelling matches between lawmakers. A1. 

Debate on garbage plan: a milestone for the new Council. News analysis, B3.
 
EDUCATORS BALK AT AIDS OATH
The groups that run programs in the New York city's schools on how to avoid AIDS are in open rebellion against the Board of Education's insistence that they pledge to place abstinence over safe sex in classroom presentations. More than 40 of the 200 AIDS education groups, with the full support of the Dinkins administration, have already refused to sign the pledge and most of the others are expected to do the same, a spokesman for the groups said. A1.
 
IN HUNTS POINT, HOPE IS SHAKEN
Longwood Avenue is one of those New York places living on the edge of rebirth, a neighborhood that believed it was starting to climb back from the devastation of the 1970's and early 80's to resemble what it once was. But a wild shootout that wounded 12 people there early Wednesday -- which the police said was so intense that it was a miracle that no one died -- has shaken that hope. A1.
 
UP IN ARMS ON UPPER WEST SIDE
A day after she endorsed Donald J. Trump's huge Riverside South development, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan found herself the target of criticism from some of the groups in her political base -- the Upper West Side. B3.
 
REGION
 
NEW FERRARO AD ATTACKS 'LIES'
Geraldine A. Ferraro released a new commercial in her campaign for the Democratic Senate nomination from New York, likening herself to Anita F. Hill as a woman bravely battling "lies, innuendo and smears." In the ad, a narrator says, "Geraldine Ferraro is being attacked by Al D'Amato, Bob Abrams and even Liz Holtzman." It slaps back at an ad by Ms. Holtzman, which uses a picture of the cover story of last week's Village Voice headlined "What You Don't Know About Ferraro and the Mob." B4.
 
A BAD TIME TO BE OUT OF WORK
Unemployment in Westchester County and on Long Island has reached the highest levels since 1977, state officials announced. The news was no surprise to hundreds of people attending a conference for the unemployed and the underemployed at Westchester Community College. B5.
 
A RECORD OF VIOLATIONS
The construction company operating the Sea Isle, N.J., site where a police officer was killed and 37 people were sickened had seven serious safety violations in January at another project, according to federal documents. On Shore Construction of Glassboro paid $11,310 to settle the claims after the Occupational Safety and Health Administration found "serious" safety problems on a work site in Cherry Hill. B5.
 
Our Towns by Andrew H. Malcolm B5
 
Chronicle B2

HEADLINE: Bridgeport Agrees to Expand 2 Waste Businesses

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 27

 BODY:
Officials today announced an agreement that could bring hundreds of construction jobs and millions in revenue to this perpetually cash-starved city: a plan to expand the regional garbage incinerator here and build a sewage-sludge processing plant next to it.
"This is an industrial town, and this is industry," Mayor Joseph Ganim said, putting the best face on the city's efforts to build up its battered revenue base. "This is a benefit to the taxpayers." 
 The financial pressures have not let up on Mayor Ganim since he took office last November and withdrew the city's attempt to resolve its financial problems in Federal bankruptcy court. Facing an $18 million deficit, he had no guarantees of aid from a state government that was sympathetic but too short of money itself to offer a bailout.
Nine months later, Mr. Ganim has managed to satisfy the state financial review board that oversees Bridgeport's budget, but some residents and elected officials are growing unhappy over the price the city is paying as it searches for a few million dollars in revenue here and a few million there.
 
Frustrated With the Opposition
 Earlier this week, for example, the current budget was finally balanced by selling the state 210 acres of city parkland for $5.9 million.
Mayor Ganim acknowledged the opposition, and his frustration with it, today in announcing the incinerator plan. Opponents, including environmentalists, politicians and residents of Black Rock, the neighborhood next to the city's harborfront industrial district, are a small group of "obstructionists," he said, "when the city still has serious financial problems."
While the opposition fears that Bridgeport could become a dumping ground for western Connecticut, Mr. Ganim said that expanding the Bridgeport Resco garbage-to-energy plant operated by Wheelabrator Environmental Systems made strong economic sense for the city.
The plant already has long-term contracts to burn garbage from Bridgeport and 17 other communities. Adding a fourth 750-ton-a-dayboiler would allow Resco, a Wheelabrator subsidiary, to seek contracts with Stamford, which is having problems with its incinerator, and New Haven and Waterbury, which are running out of landfill space, said the plant manager, James Dougherty. Those cities have not been approached, however.
For Bridgeport, the plan would provide $3 million when Resco obtains financing for the expansion, which Mayor Ganim is counting on for his next budget.
Similarly, the city would be paid $2 million when Resco obtains financing for a plant that would dry treated sewage sludge into a form usable in fertilizer. The plant would be designed to handle sludge from several communities besides Bridgeport.
In addition, Mr. Ganim said, the $1.8 million a year the city is now paid by Resco for being host to the incinerator would increase by $4 million a year if the expanded plant operates at 85 percent of its capacity.
Mr. Dougherty estimated that the expansion would create 800 construction jobs in Bridgeport, and that permanent employment would increase by 96 positions.
The plan is supported by unions and the Bridgeport Regional Business Council. But there is unease among aldermen at the way earlier decisions, like the sale of city parkland, have been rushed through with little time for close examination. They have insisted on seeing detailed information about Wheelabrator's proposal well before a public hearing next Thursday.
 
Losing a Piece of the City
 The aldermen's frustration over being pressured to support short-term budget repairs boiled over last week when Mayor Ganim presented the park deal's terms and asked for a vote with no public hearing.
The deal was crucial for Mayor Ganim, because it provided not only the $5.9 million for this year's budget, but also $9 million for the next budget, from the sale of the city's zoo, Beardsley Zoo, and its premier park, Beardsley Park, to the state.
While Connecticut has promised to maintain the land as a state urban park, it galled many residents and aldermen to lose a piece of the city for a quick budget solution. Some have observed that the city is now doing voluntarily what it could not have been forced to do under bankruptcy: sell off its assets.
"The sale addresses strictly a short-term, one-time budget gap," said Alderman Thomas White, a Republican. "But the transfer of our parkland appears, in this case, likely to be permanent."
Alderwoman Mary Bruce, a Democrat, referring to the University of Bridgeport's financial rescue by an arm of the Unification Church, asked: "If this passes tonight, what's next? What happens when the Reverend Moon makes an offer we can't refuse?"
This morning, as the Mayor was announcing the plans for the new waste operations, an auctioneer at City Hall was trying for the second time to sell off hundreds of tax-delinquent properties to erase a $2.5 million deficit left from the city's last fiscal year.
At the close of business, Bridgeport's finance director, Jerome I. Baron, reported that 60 tax-delinquent properties, out of 287 offered, had been sold at auction, for a total of $551,000.

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 635 words

HEADLINE: Giving the Jobless Tips and Hope

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

DATELINE: VALHALLA, N.Y., Aug. 27

 BODY:
Mel Speier learned some lessons today about maneuvering through the slippery economy, lessons like making sure that his business cards highlight his professional experience and his resume doesn't read like an obituary.
Mr. Speier, an executive who was laid off from a steel importing firm eight months ago, already had a briefcase stuffed with resumes when he came to a conference for the unemployed and the underemployed at Westchester Community College. 
 "You never know who you'll meet," said the 48-year-old Mr. Speier, his gaze cutting through the crowd.
Those he was likely to meet at the conference -- which coincided with the release of new unemployment figures for the state -- were hundreds of other people who did not need to be told the news to know that times are bad. Their expressions reflected the realities of the job market -- rejection, anxiety and anger.
 
'Sense of Betrayal'
 "A lot of them feel a sense of betrayal," said Thomas Corban, an economist with the New York State Labor Department, which jointly sponsored the job search conference with the community college. "They've done everything they thought was needed to insure them a lifelong job and they have found themselves jobless. There's a sense that the social contract between employer and worker has been broken."
The figures released today showed no sign of improvement in employment in the region last month. In Westchester County and Long Island, the rates hit the highest levels last month of any July since 1977.
"What these numbers are saying is that this region, which got into trouble well before other parts of the country, has had an extraordinary downturn that has been more severe here than in other parts of the country and is now having much more difficulty getting out of it," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.
To counter such a bleak outlook, the conference offered workshops in a variety of subjects like starting a new business, writing a resume and building self-esteem. Conference organizers told job seekers to concentrate their energy on potentially brighter spots in the economy, like job opportunities in the service industries, and urged them to use previous job experiences to sell their way into jobs that they never would have dreamed of before.
 
'Trying Everything'
 "I'm trying everything at this point," said Marie Harrington, an education consultant who was laid off eight months ago from a large chemical company. She said she is now considering fund-raising as a profession, and hoped to do some "networking" at the conference.
But the 52-year-old woman, who lives in Yonkers, said her joblessness gnaws at her every day, particularly when she sees commuters on their way to work.
"I was raised with a very strong work ethic and it's been very difficult," she said. "They tell you not to take it personally when you're laid off. But you realize who stayed and who was let go and you realize it is personal."
 
A Career Switch
 Like many other job seekers, Everett Smith is trying to make a switch in careers. His leap may be bigger than most. Mr. Smith, a long-distance truck driver by trade, is training for a career as an accountant.
He feels on shaky ground because he now works for a trucking company that transports cargo for General Motors. "You know what happened to them," he said of G.M., which has laid off scores of workers during the recession.
Mr. Smith, who is 42, said his employers have not told him anything to make him worry. But he said he does not want to take any chances.
"You learn more from what you're not told than what you're told," he said. "I've seen the changes in the American labor force and I realize my skills are just not compatible with the world economy."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 1687 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Manhattan Samples Suburbia

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
WHO is the audience? Who are things made for? Who buys the room fresheners, eats the new breakfast foods, reads the revamped magazines?
We do. We say, we'll try it. We'll pick up a trial size. Maybe we'll like it. Or maybe we'll end up feeling that we're the ones on trial. Do we belong in this target group? Do we want in or out? If we use enough of this stuff, will we get normal? 
 Not light thoughts for a late summer stroll in the park, perhaps. But when the setting is Hudson River Park, the new sylvan enclave on the northern edge of Battery Park City, such musings are not out of place. Hudson River Park is a trial-size park. Its 8.2 lushly landscaped acres are generous enough for several visits. If you live nearby, you'll visit often, particularly when the northern entrance to the park (at West and Laight Streets) opens this weekend. (The southern entrance to the park, which is open from dawn to dusk, is at West and Vesey Streets.)
But wherever you live, Hudson River Park is worth a close look. For if this trial succeeds, some variation of it may be coming soon to a waterfront near you. What we see here now could be a preview: a starter emerald for the "green necklace" city planners hope will eventually adorn the city's edge. As such, it represents a critical step in New York's efforts to build its way into the future.
The future will take some getting used to. We're accustomed to the industrial waterfront, or at least the decayed remnants of it, a once bustling place of shipping and manufacturing. Now, the edge of the city is shifting from production to consumption, from work to pleasure. It will require some mental adjustment to replace the blue collar with the green necklace, the image of tug boats and longshoremen with a new picture of fancy yachts and Sunday strollers.
The Battery Park City Authority, the builder of Hudson River Park, has made a substantial contribution to the adjustment. In designing the park, the authority paid uncommonly close attention to the desires of the local community. Speaking through their Community Board No. 1, TriBeCa and Battery Park City residents made clear that they didn't want the kind of public space the authority had created in the past. Instead of critically acclaimed public art projects prescribed by art experts, the community wanted waterfront pleasures with a somewhat lower brow. Active recreation, like half-courts for basketball. Sliding boards and swings for the children. A fountain gushing into a lily pond. Winding paths. Restrooms. A lawn with volleyball nets. Community gardens. And they didn't want these features threaded through blocks of buildings, like the feats of integrated urban design elsewhere at Battery Park City. They wanted open spaces concentrated in one generous landscaped expanse.
Clearly, the Battery Park City Authority believes in public service with a smile. It has rendered the community's wishes into a lavish portrait of a city at play. Designed by the Cambridge, Mass., firm Carr, Lynch, Hack & Sandell, with landscaping by Oehme, van Sweden & Associates of Washington, Hudson River Park is a "people's park" that's gone to heaven. Good design, a hallmark throughout Battery Park City, is once again on ample display. Materials and detailing are of supreme quality. The plantings could go right into HG magazine with only minimal touchup. But the focus has shifted from public art to public enjoyment. That emphasis is evident not only in the playground (designed by Johannson & Walcavage of Brooklyn) and other active recreation areas, but also in such refinements as setting the height of the park's granite walls so that people can comfortably perch upon them.
Passive pastimes are not stinted here. Loosely organized in a linear sequence along a serpentine promenade, and allowed to spill over onto the large lawn, the park's recreational areas unfold as a series of visual tableaux: vignettes of New Yorkers in the process of discovering how to use a waterside park. The river itself is the park's greatest visual asset. On Monday evenings, when pop music is performed at the park's pavilion, it feels like a sinful indulgence to turn one's back on the Hudson's majestic sweep, even though the urban backdrop of Manhattan skyscrapers is comparably grand.
These stunning backdrops offer more than drama. They also provide Hudson River Park with a visual unity that has eluded the park's designers. Considering that the park began as a wish list, perhaps it's not surprising that the end result is less a park than an inventory of features in search of one. For while there's consistency in such elements as paving and masonry walls, the parts do not cohere into the organic unity of nature or of art.
The landscape design aims for a picturesque park in the Frederick Law Olmsted tradition. But it's as if the designers have flattened Olmsted out with a rolling pin. In technical terms, the design is Olmsted in plan but not elevation. We have curving paths, but they curve along flat surfaces. They do not, as in Central Park, rise and descend through earth ridges and rock outcroppings. There was good cause to avoid such contours; they would have blocked the water views that are the park's most compelling attraction. Nonetheless, as a friend remarked, Olmsted without elevation is a miniature golf course.
The flat landscape allows the park's architectural elements undue prominence. In Central Park, gazebos and other features gradually materialize. They slip in and out of sight as you move through the landscape. The flat terrain at Hudson River Park doesn't permit this arcadian peek-a-boo. Instead, the park's built features rise up from the landscape like a row of houses on a suburban street.
The styles in which these features are executed reinforce the suburban impression. They're the familiar trio of home decoration: Classical, Traditional and Contemporary. For Classical, we've got a pavilion designed by Demetri Porphyrios, its wooden roof supported by columns with Ionic and Phrygian columns. The Traditional slot is filled by bishop's-crook lampposts and by the Park House, a rusticated stone structure with a shingled roof, modeled after Boston's 19th-century commuter rail stations.
Rough concrete walls give the basketball court a Contemporary look, but for the real cutting-edge statement, you call in an artist. In this case, Tom Otterness has made a small fantasy of a parklet, called "The Real World," that combines his familiar doughboy figures with exotic fauna in a madcap romp among piles of coins. But beneath their outward playfulness, these forms evoke a rancid Marxist take on the education of middle-class children. The hint here is that children's fables -- the pot of gold, the enchanted castle -- are veiled lessons for raising children to become materialistic monsters (like the developers of luxury housing for the city's emerald green necklace). What comes through in the sculptures' sugar-coated Marxism is the sugar-coating, however, not the Marx. This may be a blessing. But it is also a tribute to Battery Park City's power to reduce once radical propositions to sweetness and light. And it's this power, rather than the green lawns or their immaculate upkeep, that accounts for Hudson River Park's suburban atmosphere. The park's multiplicity of styles is an urban equivalent of the suburban paradox. Freedom of choice has been reduced to a norm: a staggering array of consumer choices that, like frozen entrees, somehow all turn out the same. No matter what the thermometer readings have been this summer, at Hudson River Park it's always 98.6.
The suburban atmosphere is no accident. It's the natural consequence of Battery Park City's mission to woo upper-middle-class residents back from suburbia. And the effects of this mission, too, take some getting used to. Even those who believe that the city cannot afford to lose more middle-income residents may find it uncomfortable to embrace the strategies required to retain them. We're used to government programs that house the poor. Luxury housing projects are an unfamiliar breed, and it's premature to judge whether their impact will be to further divide rich from poor or to help bridge the gap by shoring up the middle ground.
Yet it's only in the city that such projects are new. Suburbia has been a luxury housing project all along. The $18 million it took to create Hudson River Park (it actually came in $2 million under budget) is nothing compared to the vast sums suburbia routinely absorbs in highway funds and tax incentives. That's the competition the city is up against. The risk, of course, is that in competing against the suburb the city will end up becoming one. For decades, other cities have fought against the "Manhattanization" of their skylines. For New Yorkers, the prospect may well be the suburbanization of the shoreline, if not the entire metropolis.
Hudson River Park provides a chance to sort out our feelings about that prospect. It's dreary, of course, to contemplate a future in which New York, New York, has joined Classic and Traditional as one more homogenized decorative style. It's drearier still to contemplate a city subsiding without protest into the wreckage of its industrial past. For now, it might be best to think of Hudson River Park as evidence of a city willing to experiment with different visions of its future. Here, New York gets to try on an image of itself as a normal city with normal people living in it. For now, at least, the image doesn't quite fit.
 
Getting There
 Hudson River Park is west of the World Trade Center in Battery Park City. By subway, it can be reached from the Cortlandt Street-World Trade Center stop on the IRT line via the Nos. 1 and 9 trains or the BMT line on the N and R trains. Another option is the IND line on A, C or E trains to Chambers Street. M9, M10 and M22 buses go to Battery Park City. From New Jersey, PATH trains stop at Chambers Street-5 World Trade Center and a ferry runs between Hoboken, N.J., and Battery Park City. Ferry information: (201) 463-3779.
